hom.sense:
The thirteenth letter of the alphabet: called XiynN. It is one of the letters termed mahomuwsap [or non-vocal, i. e. pronounced with the breath only, without the voice]; and of the letters termed Xajoriy-ap, (TA,) from AlX-ajoru, which means “the place of the opening of the mouth.” (TA on the letter j. See also XiyonN in art. Xyn.) It is sometimes substituted for the affixed pronoun of the second pers. fem., ki; as in raOayotuXi for raOayotuki, and as in the following verse,
faEayonaAXi EayonaAhaA wajiyduXi jiyduhaA
walekin-a Als-aAqi minoXi raqiyqu
[And thy two eyes are her two eyes, and thy neck is her neck; but the bone of thy shank is slender]; i. e. EayonaAka and jiyoduki and minoki: this substitution for the affixed pronoun of the second pers. fem. is of dial. of Benoo-ʼAmr and Temeem; and is not restricted to cases of pausation, as is shown by the verse above cited, though some assert it to be so: it is also substituted for the k of diyk, when with kesr, so that they said diyXK: also for jK, as in mudam-aXN [or mudomaXN], for mudam-ajN [or mudomajN]: and for s, as in jaEoXuwXN, for jaEosuwsN. (MF. [See also De Sacy's Chrest, Arabe, sec. ed., iii. 530-31.])
[As a numeral, it denotes Three hundred.]

entry.sense: XuWobuwbN A shower, or fall, or what pours forth at once or without intermission, of rain (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ), &c.: (Ṣ, O:) or of rain with hail; for otherwise this term is not applied to rain: (ISd, TA:) pl. XaMbiybu: (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ:*) this is the pl. of XuWobuwbN (Ḳ, TA) in all its senses: (TA:) or rain that falls upon one place and misses another; like najowN and najaMCN. (AZ, TA.)
[A thin, not wide, cloud, of which the rain falls with vehemence. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]
A heat, or an unintermitted act, of running. (TA.)

Sharpness, vehemence, force, or strength, of anything: (Ḳ:) violence, or vehemence, of impetus or pushing or driving, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) of rain, (A,) or of anything. (Ḳ.) Kaab Ibn-Zuheyr says, speaking of a he-ass and she-asses,
UicaA maA QnotaHaAhun-a XuWobuwbuhu
raOayota lijaAEiratayohi guDuwnaA
i. e. When he runs vehemently [towards them, or rather when his vehemence of running is directed towards them], thou seest a wrinkling [or wrinkles] in his jaAEirataAni [dual of jaAEirapN, q. v.]. (Ṣ, O.)

The first appearance [or bloom] of beauty. (Ḳ.) One says of a girl, or young woman, Uin-ahaA laHasanahu XaMbiybi Alwajohi Verily she is goodly in respect of the first appearances [or bloomings] of beauty of countenance in the eye of the beholder. (O.)
The vehemence of the heat of the sun. (Ḳ.)
And The Tariyqap of the sun: (Ḳ:) XaMbiybu AlX-amosi signifies the lines, or streaks, (TaraAYiq,) of the sun when it rises. (O.)
XaMbiybu AlS-amogi What flows, of the [manna, or gum, called] migofar [q. v.], and remains like strings, or threads, between the trees and the ground. (T, L.) [See also maEaAbiybu.]

XaYiytN A horse that has a habit of stumbling; or that stumbles often: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it has no corresponding verb: and accord. to Aṣ, it signifies (Ṣ) a horse whose hind hoofs fall short of reaching [the spots that have been trodden by] his fore hoofs: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [but see XabuwbN:] pl. XuWuwtN. (TA.) [See also OaHaq-u.]

hom.sense: 1. XaYifato rijoluhu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXoOafu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XaOafN; (Ṣ, O;) and XuYifato rjlh; (O, Ḳ;) His foot became affected with an ulcer, or imposthume, such as is termed XaOofapN, breaking out in it. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

Accord. to some, (O,) XaOfu AljuroHi (O, Ḳ, [in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ XaOofu, and so accord. to the TḲ, and in the CK without C, but I think that the right reading is XaOafu, and that its verb is XaYifa, or it may be XaOofu, and inf. n. of XuYifa,]) signifies The wound's becoming in a corrupt state, so that it will hardly, or not at all, be cured. (O, Ḳ.)
XaYifa Sadoruhu EalaI-a His bosom bore concealed enmity and violent hatred, or rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, against me. (TA.)

XaYifato OaSaAbiEuhu, (Az, O, Ḳ,) or yaduhu, (M, TA,) His fingers, or his hand, became cracked, or disintegrated, in the parts around the nails; (Az, M, O, Ḳ;) as also saYifato, (O, TA,) and saEifato: so say AZ and IAạr, and in like manner says Th. (TA.)

XaYifotuhu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and XaYifotu lahu, (AZ, O, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXoOafu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XaOofN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) in the Bári' XaOafN, with fet-ḥ to the C, (TA,) and XaMfapN; (O, Ḳ;) and XaYifotu minohu, inf. n. XaOofN, omitted in the Ḳ [and Ṣ, and O], but correct, as Ṣgh has indicated in the Tekmileh; (TA;) I hated him; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) like Xanifotu lahu; (Ṣ and O in art. Xnf;) namely, a man: (Ṣ, O:) or the first and second signify, (Ḳ,) or the first also signifies accord. to IAạr, (O,) I feared, when I saw him, namely, a man, that I should smite him with an evil eye, or should guide against him one whom he disliked, or hated; (O;) or I feared that he would smite me with an evil eye, or I guided against him one whom he disliked, or hated. (Ḳ.)
And XuYifa He (a man, AʼObeyd, O) was frightened, or afraid. (AʼObeyd, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 10. AisotaXoOafato, said of a quroSap, [so in the TA, an evident mistranscription, app. for qaroHap, and so in the next paragraph, i. e. an ulcer, or imposthume,] means SaAra lahaA OaSolN [It had, or acquired, root, or rootedness, or permanence; as though it became a XaOofap]. (TA.)

[XaYifN part. n. of XaYifa, and properly meaning Having an ulcer, or imposthume, such as is termed XaOofap,] is applied as an epithet to a heart, in the following verse, cited by IḲṭṭ,
yaA Oay-uhaA AljaAhilu Oal-aA tanoSarifo
walamo tudaAwi quroSapa Alqalobi AlX-aYifo
[in which quroSapa is doubtless a mistranscription (like that in the next preceding paragraph) for qaroHapa; the obvious meaning of the verse being, † O thou ignorant one, wherefore wilt not thou revert, when thou hast not cured the sore of an ulcerated heart?]. (TA.)

XOfp An ulcer, or imposthume, (qaroHapN,) that breaks out in the bottom of the foot, and is cauterized, (Ṣ, IAth, O, Ḳ,) or is cut, (Yaạḳoob, IAth, O,) and goes away; (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, IAth, O, Ḳ;) and the word is also pronounced without C [i. e. XaAfapN]: (IAth, TA:) or an ulcer, or imposthume, in the foot of a person, who dies if it is cut: (O, Ḳ:) and it is also said to be a tumour in the hand, and foot, from the entering of a piece of wood, or stick, into the flesh of the foot, or the palm of the hand, and its remaining therein, so that the place swells, and becomes large. (TA.)
AisotaOoSala Qll-ehu XaOofatahu (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) is a prov. (Ṣ, O) meaning † May God cause him to go away like as the XOfp above mentioned goes away: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or this means may God extirpate him: for
XaOofapN is also syn. with OaSolN [i. e. Root,, &c.]: (O, Ḳ:) so says Sh. (O.) [See also 10 in art. ASl: and see what here follows.]
It is also said to signify The family and household of a man: and hence the form of imprecation, AisotaOoSala Qll-ehu XaOofatahumo [May God extirpate their family and household]. (TA.)
And ‡ Enmity. (TA.)
XaOafapN, thus with fet-ḥ to the C, is an epithet applied to a man, meaning Mighty, potent, powerful, or strong; inaccessible, or difficult of access. (TA.)
rijolN maXoWuwfapN A foot affected with an ulcer, or imposthume, such as is termed saOofapN, breaking out in it: (O, Ḳ:) from XuYifato rijoluhu. (O,* Ḳ,* TA.)
And maXoWuwfN, from XuYifa, Frightened, or afraid; (AʼObeyd, O, Ḳ;) applied to a man. (AʼObeyd, O.)

hom.sense: 1. XuYima Ealayohimo (Ṣ; MA, Ḳ,) inf. n. XuWomN, (MA,) He (a man, Ṣ) was, or became, unlucky, or inauspicious, (SaAra XuWomFA, Ṣ, Ḳ, in the MA Xwm Xd,) to them: (Ṣ, MA, Ḳ;) as also XaOamahumo, and XaOama Elyhm, and XaWuma Elyhm: (Ḳ:) or XaOamahumo, (AZ, Ḥam p. 224,) or XaOama Ealayohimo, (Ṣ,) or both of these, (TA,) aor. _a {yaXoOamu}, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. XaOomN, (TA,) he drew upon them ill luck, or evil fortune; (Ṣ, TA;) or caused ill luck, or evil fortune, to befall them from him: (AZ, Ḥam ubi suprà, TA:) or XuWumN as an inf. n. signifies the being unlucky: and the rendering unlucky: and so XuwmN [as it is commonly pronounced: see XuWumN below]. (KL.)
And XaOamahumo, inf. n. XaOomN, so in the L; in the Ḳ, XaO-amahumo↓, inf. n. taXoYiymN; but the former is the right; (TA;) He made them to go, or journey, to AlX-aOom [i. e. Syria]. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see what next precedes {1}.
3. XaAYimo biOaSoHaAbika Take thou the direction of the left hand with thy companions: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) yaAmino signifies “take thou the direction of the right hand.” (TA.)
And XaMCma He (a man) came to AlX-aOom [i. e. Syria]: like yaAmana signifying “he came to El-Yemen.” (TA. [See also 4.])

hom.sense: 4. AXOm He desired the left: like as Oayomana signifies “he desired the right.” (TA in art. ymn.)
And He (a man, Ṣ) came to AlX-aOom [i. e. Syria]: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA: [see also 3:]) or he went thither: and Oayomana signifies “he came to El-Yemen.” (TA.)
maA OaXoOamahu (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) How unlucky, or inauspicious, is he! (TA:) the vulgar say, maA OayoXamahu. (Ṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tXO-m bihi, (MA, TA,) from AlX-uWomu, (TA,) He found him, or it, unlucky, or inauspicious: and he became unlucky by means of him, or it: (MA:) or tXO-m signifies he had ill luck, or evil fortune. (KL.) See also 6.
And He asserted his relationship to [the people of] AlX-aOom [i. e. Syria]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a verb similar to tkw-f and tqy-S. (Ṣ.)

6. tXMCmwA bihi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA, &c.,) in some of the copies of the Ḳ tXO-mwA↓, (TA,) [and in like manner tXO-m bihi, which is often opposed to tayam-ana bihi, (see an instance in Bḍ xvii. 14,) is used in the Ḳ in art. ETs, and tXO-m minohu in the TA in the same art. as on the authority of IKh, whence it seems that both these verbs are correct in the sense here following, though the former is probably preferable, and AstXOm↓ bihi is used in the same manner in “Les Oiseaux et les Fleurs,” p. 83, as mentioned by Freytag, so that tXO-m bh and AstXOm are the contr. of tym-n bh and Astymn,] They augured evil from him, or it; regarded him, or it, as an evil omen; (Mṣb, KL;*) like taTay-aruwA bihi: (Mṣb:) deemed him, or it, unlucky, or inauspicious. (KL.)
tXMCm, thus, with medd, also signifies He took the direction of AlX-aOom [i. e. Syria]. (TA.)
See also 5.
10: see the next preceding paragraph {6}.
AlX-aOomu, the name of a certain country [i. e. Syria], is masc. and fem.; (Ṣ;) sometimes masc.: (Ḳ:) and may also be pronounced AlX-aAmu [as it commonly is in the present day]. (Mṣb.)
[And as this country lies on the north of Arabia, AlX-aOomu also signifies The northern region; opposed to Alyamanu.]

hom.sense: XuWomN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) thus, with C, but always pronounced XuwmN, without C, (TA,) is an inf. n.: (MA, KL: [see 1, first sentence, in two places:]) and signifies [as a simple subst.] Unluckiness, inauspiciousness, unfortunateness, unprosperousness, evil fortune, or ill luck; contr. of yumonN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [i. e.] i. q. aHosN: (Ḥar p. 158:) evil [of any kind]; syn. Xar-N: (Mṣb:) [and particularly] an evil omen: (PṢ:) and maXoOamapN↓ signifies the same as XuWomN: (TA:) [or, like manoHasapN, a cause of unluckiness,, &c.:] maXaAYimu is a pl. of XuWomN, [or of maXoOamapN↓: if of the former,] irreg., like as its syn. manaAHisu is [said to be] of naHosN. (TA in art. nHs.) It is said in a trad., Uino kaAna AlX-uwomu fafiI valaAvK AlmaroOapi waAld-aAri waAlfarasi, meaning If there be that whereof the consequence is disliked, or hated, and feared, [or if there be unluckiness,] it is in three things, the wife, and the house, and the horse: i. e., if any of you have a wife whose companionship he dislikes, or a house in which he dislikes dwelling, or a horse that he dislikes taking for the purpose of keeping post on the enemies' frontier, let him separate himself therefrom, by divorcing the wife, and removing from the house, and selling the horse: or, as some say, the XWm of the wife is her not producing children; and that of the house, its straitness, and the badness of its neighbour; and that of the horse, one's not going to war upon it. (JM.)
See also maXoWuwmN.

Also Black camels: and HiDaArN signifies “white” camels, (Ḳ, TA,) and is also written and pronounced HaDaArN: (TA:) neither of these has a sing.: (Ḳ:) both occur in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb: but accord. to one reading thereof it is Xiym; pl. of OaXoyamu: so says AA: and IJ says that XuwmN, [without C,] being originally XuyomN, of the measure fuEolN, may also be pl. of OaXoyamu. (TA.)

XaOomapN and maXoOamapN↓ The left, meaning the left side or direction or relative location or place; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. q. [yasorapN and] mayosarapN; (Ṣ;) contr. of yamonapN and mayomanapN. (Ḳ.) One says of a man, qaEada XOomapN [He sat on the left]. (Ṣ.) And one says, xuco bihimo XaOomapF i. e. [Take thou with them] the direction of the left hand. (Ṣ.) And naZarotu yamonapF waXaOomapF [I looked in a right direction and in a left direction]. (TA.) And hence OaSoHaAbu AlmaXoOamapi↓, in the Ḳur [lvi. 9 and xc. 19], (TA,) meaning [The occupants of the left: or] those who shall have their records given to them in their left hands: or the occupants of the low, or ignoble, place, or station: or the havers of unfortunateness (AlX-uWom): and OaSoHaAbu Almayomanapi is expl. as having the contr. senses. (Ksh and Bḍ in lvi. 9.)
Also, the former, A mole (xaAlN) upon the person: thus, with C, as mentioned by IAth: also mentioned without C in art. Xym. (TA.)
See also XaAmapN as meaning “a black she-camel,” in art. Xym.

entry.sense: XiYomapN Nature; natural, native, or innate, disposition, temper, or other quality or property: (Ḳ, TA:) mentioned thus, as with C, by AZ and Lḥ, and said by IJ to be sometimes thus pronounced; but the pronunciation thereof with C is held by ISd to be extraordinary. (TA.) [See art. Xym.]

XaAmiI-N, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) without C, (TA,) and XaMmK↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the measure faEaAlK, (Ṣ,) an allowable form, without I, (Mṣb,) like tahaAmK and yamaAnK, (TA,) and XaMmiI-N↓, (Sb, Ṣ, Ḳ,) [Syrian;] of, or relating to, AlX-aOom: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) one should not say XaOomK; any instance [of this] occurring by poetic license being accounted for as a case of the use of the name of the country for the rel. n.: (Ṣ:) the fem., applied to a woman, is XaAmiy-apN and XaMmiyapN↓, the latter without teshdeed: (Ṣ, TA;) the pl. of XaAmiI-N is XuwaAmN, like guraAbN [in measure]. (TA.)
[And hence, Northern.]
XaMmK, and XaMmiyapN the fem. of the former; and XaMmiI-N: see the next preceding paragraph.
XaAYimN: see maXoWuwmN.

OaXoOamu [More, and most, unlucky, inauspicious, unfortunate, or unprosperous].
The Arabs say, OaXoOamu kul-i QmoriYK bayona laHoyayohi, (Meyd, TA,) as some relate it, or, as others relate it, fak-ayohi, which means the same, (Meyd,) [app. meaning accord. to the TA, The most unlucky thing of every man is between his two jaws, or the two lateral portions of his lower jaw; but it is said that] OaXoOamu is here used in the sense of XuWomN [i. e. the unluckiness,, &c.]; and in a similar manner [the contr.] Oayomanu is used [in the sense of yumon]: so says AHeyth: (Meyd:) the prov. meaning the tongue. (AHeyth, TA.) The fem. is XuWomaI. (TA.)

Hence, (TA,) Alyadu AlX-uWomaI The left hand or arm; contr. of AlyumonaI; (Ḳ, TA;) i. q. AlX-imaAlu. (TA.) It is said in a trad., respecting camels, laA yaOotiI xayoruhaA Uil-aA mino jaAnibihaA AlOaXoOami [Their goodness comes not save from their left side]: i. e. they are milked and mounted only from the left side. (TA.)
See also maXoWuwmN, in three places.

Zuheyr, in the following saying,
fatunotajo lakumo gilomaAna OaXoOama kul-uhumo
kaOaHomari EaAdK vum-a turoDiEo fatafoTimo
uses it in the sense of the inf. n. XuWom; (Ṣ;) meaning gilomaAna XuWomK: (Ṣ, and EM p. 124:) he says, And it, i. e. war, will bring forth for you boys of ill luck, or evil omen; all of them like Aḥmar of' Ád: then it will suckle these boys, and wean them: by Aḥmar of ' Ád, he means Aḥmar of Thamood, for Aḥmar was the surname of him who hamstrung the she-camel of Sálih, and his name was Kudár: he says thus for the sake of the measure: or, as some say, Thamood were called 'Ád-el-Ákhireh. (EM.)
maXoOamapN: see XuWomN, in two places:
and see also XaOomapN, likewise in two places.

maXoWuwmN, (Ṣ, MA, Ḳ, KL,) and maXuwmN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the latter like maquwlN, (TA,) [a contraction of the former,] Unlucky, or inauspicious, (Ṣ, MA, Ḳ, KL,) EaI qawomihi [to his people, or party], (Ṣ, MA, Ḳ,) and EalaI nafosihi [to himself]: (Ksh and Bḍ in lvi. 9:) [and so XuWomN↓; (as in an ex. in the first sentence of this art.;) this being an epithet as well as a subst., like its syn. naHosN; syn. with maXoWuwmN, like as naHosN is syn. with manoHuwsN; and app., like naHosN, used alike as sing. and pl., for it seems to be originally an inf. n.:] and so XaAYimN↓; (Ḳ;) or this signifies drawing ill luck, or evil fortune, upon his people [and upon himself]: (Ṣ, TA:) and OaXaAYimu, a pl., likewise signifies unlucky, or inauspicious; (KL;) contr. of OayaAminu; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) these being pls. of OaXoOamu↓ and Oayomanu: (TA:) the pl. of maXoWuwmN is maXaAYiymu, (Ṣ, KL, TA,) which is extr., for by rule it should be maXoWuwmuwna. (TA.) One says also TaAYirN OaXoOamu↓ meaning [An omen] happening, or occurring, (jaArK,) with unluckiness, or inauspiciousness; [i. e. an unlucky, or inauspicious, omen;] (Ḳ, TA;) and [in like manner] TayorN OaXoOamu↓: and the pl. is OaXaAYimu [as above]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. XaOanotu XaOonahu i. q. qaSadotu qaSodahu [meaning I pursued his (another's) way, or course, doing as he did]; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:* in the Ḳ, XaOana XaOonahu and qaSada qaSodahu;) and in like manner one says, AXtOn↓ XaOonahu. (Ḳ.)
And AiXoOano XaOonaka Do thou what thou dost well. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.*) And Keep thou to thy affair. (IAạr, L.)

And maA XaOana XaOonahu He did not know, or had not knowledge of, him, or his affair or case or state: (Lḥ, IAạr, L, Ḳ:) [from a passage in the L, imperfectly written, it seems, accord. to Lḥ, to be said of one who does what another likes or dislikes, app. without regard to his liking it or disliking it, agreeably with what here follows:] or (Ḳ) this means, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or means also, (L,) he did not care for, mind, heed, or regard, him. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ. [In the Ṣ and L, the verb in the sense thus expl. is in the first pers.: and in one place in the L it is expl. by OaraAda, which often has this meaning.]) One says also, laOaXoOann-a XaOonahumo, meaning I will assuredly know, or try, prove, or test, (laOaxoburan-a,) their affair or case or state: (L:) or this means I will assuredly corrupt, or pervert, or mar, their affair or case or state: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:*) and laOaXoOanan-a xabarahu, (L,) or xabarahumo, (Ḳ,) means I will assuredly know, or try, prove, or test, [his, or their, state, or] him, or them. (L, Ḳ. [In the CK and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, laAuxobiran-ahumo, is erroneously put for laOaxoburan-ahumo.])

XaOana baEodaka means SaAra lahu XaOonN [i. e., app., He became a person to whom importance attached (accord. to the general meaning of lahu XaOonN) after thou knewest, or sawest, or mettest, him; baEodaka being for baEoda Eahodika bihi, agreeably with common usage]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: [4. AXOn XaOonahumo is mentioned by Golius as meaning “Corrupit ac pervertit rem eorum,” as on the authority of the Ṣ, (the right reading in which has been given above,) and on that of the KL, in my copy of which I find nothing of the sort.]
8: see 1, first sentence.

hom.sense: XaOonN A thing, an affair, or a business; syn. OamorN; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) and xaTobN [in the same sense, or in that next following]: (L, Ḳ:) a great thing or affair: (Ḥar p. 274:) state, condition, case, quality, or manner of being; syn. HaAlN: (Ṣ, L:) [also property, or nature: and importance attaching to a person or thing:] pl. XuWuwnN and XiYaAnN, (L, Ḳ,) the latter mentioned by IJ on the authority of AAF, and XuwnN occurs in poetry for the former of these, or as another pl. originally XuWonN, of the measure fuEolN. (L.) It is said in the Ḳur [lv. 29], kul-a yamK huwa fiI XaOon Ḳ [Every day He is employing Himself in an affair of some kind]: expl. as meaning that, of his business (mino XaOonihi [which may also be rendered “of his property”]) it is to render mighty one who is brought low, and to bring low one who is mighty, and to enrich one who is poor, and to impoverish one who is rich; and no affair occupies him so as to divert him from an affair (laA yaXoEaluhu XaOonN Eano XaOonK). (L.) [And one says, maA XaOonuka What is thy affair? or what is thy case? And XaOonaka, for AiXoOano XaOonaka i. e. Pursue thy way or course, or thy affair; or do what thou dost well; or keep to thy affair: or the like: and to this is often added, wamaA turiydu i. e. and what thou wilt, or wishest, or desirest. And mino XaOonihi Oano yafoEala kacaA It is of his business, or of his property, or nature, to do, or that he should do, such a thing. And rajulN saholu AlX-aOoni (a phrase occurring in the Ṣ and Ḳ in art. hX) A man of easy nature. And lahu XaOonN, sometimes meaning There is for him, or he has, a great thing or affair to perform or transact: but more commonly, great importance attaches to him, or to it: see 1, last sentence. And a grandee, or a prince, is said to be EaZiymu AlX-aOoni i. e. Of great importance or rank or dignity.]

Also [A suture of the skull; i. e.] the place of junction of the qabaAYil [or principal bones, namely, the frontal, occipital, and two parietal, bones,] of the head: (Ḳ:) sing. of XuWuwnN, (Mgh,) which signifies the places of junction, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh, L,) and of meeting, (Ṣ, L,) of the qabaAYil (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh, L) of the head; (Ṣ, L;) between every two of which qbAYl is a XaOon: (Aṣ, L:) [it is fancifully said that] from them come the tears: (Aṣ, Ṣ, L:) the pl. is also expl. as meaning the salaAsil [i. e. sutures as being likened to the slAsl (or lines) of writing] that unite the qbAYl: by Lth, as the namaAnim [likewise meaning sutures resembling lines of writing] of the skull; between the qbAYl: by AḤát, as the XuEab [meaning serrated edges] that unite the qbAYl of the head. (L.)

And The channel by which the tears flow, or run, to the eye:pl. [of pauc.] OaXoWunN and [of mult.] XuWuwnN: (L, Ḳ:) [perhaps thus called because supposed to come from the sutures of the skull: but they may have been supposed to come thence because tears are called maMCu AlX-uWuwni (as in a verse cited voce rasama); for this phrase may have been misunderstood as signifying “the water of the sutures of the skull,” whereas it seems to be properly rendered “the water of the channels of the tears:”] it is said that the XuWuwn connect the qbAYl of the head [expl. above] to the eye: Lth says that they are the ducts (Euruwq) of the tears from [the interior of] the head to the eye: and Th, that they are certain ducts (Erwq) above the qbAYl, which become strong by degrees as the man advances in age: (L: [but it seems that Th has confounded explanations of XWwn in two different senses:]) accord. to ISk, (Ṣ,) or AA and others, (L,) the XaOonaAni are two ducts (EiroqaAni) descending from [the upper part of] the head to the eyebrows and then to the eyes. (Ṣ, L.)
[The pl. XuWuwnN is also expl. as though meaning Tears themselves, in a phrase mentioned voce caYirN (q. v.), on the authority of the Ḳ.]
And XuWuwnN Alxamori means † The effluvia of wine that creep (maA dab-a mina Alxamori) in the veins of the body. (L.)

XaOonN also signifies A vein of earth in a mountain, (L, Ḳ,) i. e. a cleft therein, (L,) in which palm-trees are planted; (L, Ḳ;)
or in which trees of the kind called naboE grow; or that produces plants, or herbage: (L:) pl. XuWuwnN: (L, Ḳ:) which is said by ISd to mean lines, or streaks, in a mountain: or, as some say, cracks, or clefts: and to these cracks, or clefts, the poet Keys Ibn-Kuráạ likens [imaginary] clefts in the liver, occasioned by love. (L.)

entry.sense: Uin-ahu lamiXoOanu XaOonK Oano nufosidaka is a saying mentioned by Lḥ, expl. [only] by the words AI An nEml fI fsAdk [i. e. Oano naEomala fiI fasaAdika, app. meaning Verily he is busying himself in the doing of a thing in order that we may labour in causing thee to be in a bad, or corrupt, state]. (L.)
XaAhobal-uwT [a Pers. word, and also used by the Arabs in the present day, applied to The chestnut]: also written XaAho bal-uwT. (TA voce bal-uwTN and voce jamalN.)

XaAhiynN A certain well-known bird, (Ḳ, TA,) of those that prey; (Mṣb,* TA;) it is of the birds called Suquwr [pl. of SaqorN], as are also the baAXaq and the baAziI and the zur-aq and the yuWoyuW; (AḤát in “the Book of Birds,” TA in art. bXq;) [said by Golius, on the authority of Dmr, to be the white falcon; and to this bird it is perhaps applied by some of the Arabs; but some of them, I believe most of them, and I believe also that they do so most properly, apply this appellation in the present day to the gerfalcon, which is not wholly white; and some, to the falcon gentle:] the word is [of Pers. origin,] not genuine Arabio; (TA;) it is an arabicized word: the pl. is XawaAhiynu, and sometimes XayaAhiynu is used in its stead, formed by substituion [of I for w] for facilitating the pronunciation. (Mṣb.)
Also † The Eamuwd [meaning beam] of the balance. (Ḳ.)
And i. q. SanojapN [which signifies A balance, and a steelyard, and a weight of a balance]: so in the Expos. of the “Muwatta.” (MF, TA.)

hom.sense:
1. XaOawotu Alqawoma, (AZ, Ṣ,) aor. _u {yaXoOuwu}, (JM, PṢ,) or _a, (Ḥam p. 786,) inf. n. XaOowN, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) I preceded, or outwent, the people, or party. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.*) Accord. to [several of] the copies of the Ḳ, XaMCahu i. e. like XaAEahu in measure, which is incorrect, [in other copies XaMCaAhu↓, agreeably with what is said in the Ṣ,] signifies He strove, or contended, with him to precede him, or outgo him: or he preceded him, or outwent him: but in the Ṣ it is said, XaMCaAhu, of the measure faAEalahu, signifies he strove, or contended, with him to precede him, or outgo him: and XaMCahu like XaOaAhu, [the former belonging to art. XwO and] formed by transposition, signifies he preceded him, or outwent him; and both of these are used by the poet (El-Hárith Ibn-Khálid El-Makhzoomee, TA) in his saying,
mar-a AlHuduwju wamaA XaOawonaka naqorapF
walaqado OaraAka tuXaMCu biAlOaZoEaAni
this [passage in the Ṣ], however, is taken from what is said by AʼObeyd, in [his work] “El-Ghareeb el-Musannaf,” which is as follows: XaMCaniI AlOamoru, like XaAEaniI [in measure], and XaMniI, like XaEaAniI, mean the affair, or event, grieved me; and thus in the verse of El-Hárith Ibn-Khálid, which he cites; and the same is said in the T on the authority of IAạr, who says that the poet has used two dial. vars.: [accordingly the verse may be rendered, The camels with their saddles upon them passed along and they grieved thee not at all; but I see thee that thou art grieved by the women borne in the camel-vehicles:] it is said in the M, XaMCaniI AlX-aIoCu means the thing preceded me, or outwent me: and also the thing grieved me: formed by transposition from XaMniI, as is proved by its having no inf. n.: IAạr says that they are two dial. vars. because of his not being a grammarian. (TA.) [See also 8.]

And XaOawotu AlbiYora, (Lḥ, TA,) or XOwt mina AlbiYori, (Ṣ,) inf. n. XaOowN, (Ḳ, TA,) I drew forth the earth from the well: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) or I drew forth a basketful of earth (XaOowFA) or two basketfuls of earth (XaOowayoni) from the well. (Lḥ, TA.)

entry.sense: 3. XaMCaAhu: see 1. yuXaAwiI occurs in a verse of Milhah El-Jarmee, meaning yusaAbiqu, from XaOowN meaning TalaqN: one says XaOaAhu, aor. yaXoOaAhu, meaning sabaqahu: but the verb of the measure regularly formed from AlX-aOowu is XaMCI; so that yXAwI is formed by transposition and by the change of the C into I. (Ḥam p. 786.)
6. taXaMCaI maA bayonahumaA, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, taXAwaI,]) like taXaAEaI [in measure], (Ṣ,) The space between them two became farextending. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And tXMCI Alqawomu The people, or party, became scattered, or dispersed. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
8. AiXotaOaI He preceded, or outwent: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so says El-Mufaddal. (Ṣ.)
And He gave ear, hearkened, or listened. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: XaOowN The utmost extent, term, limit, point, reach, or goal. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
And A heat, or single run to a goal or limit: so in the saying, EadaA XaOowFA (Ṣ) or jaraI XaOowFA (Mṣb) [He (a horse, TA) ran a heat].
And i. q. him-apN: thus in the saying, Uin-ahu labaEiydu AlX-aOowi † [Verily he is far-aiming, or far-aspiring, in purpose, desire, or ambition]: (Lḥ, TA:) and saOowN is a dial. var. thereof. (TA.)

Also A [basket such as is termed] zabiyl; and so miXoMpN↓: (Ḳ:) or zabiyl↓ in which the earth of a well is taken forth; of the measure of miXoEaApN; and the pl. is maXaMCK: (Ṣ:) and XaOowN signifies, (Ṣ,) or signifies also, (Ḳ,) the earth that is taken forth from a well (Ṣ, Ḳ) with the like of the miXoMp, (as in a copy of the Ṣ,) or such as fills the mXoMp: (so in another copy of the Ṣ [agreeably with what next follows]:) a zabiyl of the earth of a well. (Aṣ, T, TA.)

And hence, i. e. as being likened to a zbyl of the earth of a well, † The dung that the he-ass and the she-ass casts forth: (Aṣ, T, TA:) or the dung of the she-camel; (M, Ḳ;) but the more approved word is [saOowN,] with s. (M, TA.)
Also The nose-rein (zimaAm) of a she-camel. (Lth, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: miXoMpN; see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
muXotaOK [part. n. of 8, q. v.:]
[and] i. q. muxotalifN [app. as meaning Disagreeing, differing, or discordant]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Xab-a, aor. _i {yaXobibu}, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XabaAbN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ *) and XabiybapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ *) and XubuwbN and XabiybN, (TA,) He became a youth, or young man; i. e. he attained to the state termed XabaAbN meaning as expl. below; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) said of a boy. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) [And in like manner Xab-ato is said of a girl, i. e. She became a young woman.]
Xub-a used as a noun: see below.

[Perhaps as an inf. n. of which the verb is Xab-a, (as Freytag has assumed,) but more probably of Xub-a, which will be found mentioned in this paragraph, for I do not find the former verb in the requisite sense,] Xab-N signifies Anything's being, or becoming, raised, or elevated. (Ḳ.)

Xab-a said of a horse, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,)) aor. _i {yaXobibu}, and _u, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. XibaAbN and XabiybN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XubuwbN, (Ḳ,) He was brisk, lively, or sprightly, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) and raised his fore legs (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) together, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) as though in leaping, (TA,) and played. (Ṣ. [See also Xab-at in art. Xbw, said of a mare.]) And likewise He was or became, restive, or refractory: one says, briYotu Uilayoka mino XibaAbihi and Xabiybihi and EiDaADihi and EaDiyDihi [I am irresponsible to thee for his being restive, or refractory, and for his biting]. (Ṣ.)

Xab-ati Aln-aAru, [aor., accord. to rule, _i,] (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Xub-at [pass. of the trans. verb Xab-a, q. v. infrà], inf. n. XubuwbN (which is of the intrans., TA) and Xab-N (which is of the trans. verb, TA), The fire burned, burned up, burned brightly or fiercely, blazed, or flamed. (Mṣb, Ḳ. [See also 5.]) [And hence,] Xab-ati AlHarobu bayonahumo ‡ [War, or the war, burned, or burned fiercely, between them]. (A, TA.)
Xub-a It was raised, or elevated. (O, TA.)

Xab-a Aln-aAru, aor. _u {yaXobubu}, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) inf. n. Xab-N (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and XubuwbN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the latter is the inf. n. of the intrans. verb mentioned above, (TA,) He kindled the fire; or made it to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;*) as also Xb-bhA↓, inf. n. taXobiybN; (L;) and AXb-hA↓: (A and TA in art. HX:) and so XabaAhaA. (TA in art. Xbw.) And in like manner, Xab-a AlHaroba † He kindled war, or the war; or made it to burn, or burn fiercely. (Ṣ.)

[Hence,] Xab-a, aor. _u {yaXobubu}, said of the blackness of a garment, (Sh, A, TA,) ‡ It heightened and increased, (A,) or made to appear bright and beautiful, and [as it were] burning, or glowing, (Sh, TA,) the whiteness of the wearer. (Sh, A, TA.)
And Xab-a lawonahaA (aor. as above, Ṣ) † It (a woman's hair) showed, [or set off,] and rendered beautiful, her colour, or complexion: (Ṣ:) it (a woman's head-covering, and her hair,) increased, and showed, [or heightened, and set off,] her beauty: (Ḳ:) it (a woman's black headcovering) increased her fairness, and rendered her beautiful. (TA.) And yaXub-u Alwajoha, said of patience, † It gives beauty and colour to the countenance. (TA, from a trad.)
See also 4, in two places.

entry.sense: 2. Xb-b Aln-aAra, inf. n. taXobiybN: see the preceding paragraph.

Hence, taXobiybu AlX-iEori ‡ The making the commencement of poetry elegant, or ornate, by the mention of women: (L, TA:) or the primary meaning of Alt-aXobiybu is the mention of the days of youth and of play or sport, and amatory language; and it is in the commencing of odes; and the commencement thereof is so called, absolutely, though there be not in it any mention of youth: (TA:) it means Aln-asiybu, (Ṣ, O,) or Aln-asiybu biAln-isaMCi, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, Alt-aXab-ubu bAlnisACi,]) i. e. bicikorihin-a: (TA:) one says, yuXab-ibu biqulaAnapa, (Ṣ, O,) and ytXb-b↓ bihaA [if this be not a mistranscription for yuXab-ibu], (TA,) meaning yanosibu bihaA: (Ṣ, O, TA:) [see this fully expl. in art. nsb: i. e.] Xb-b bifulaAnapa, inf. n. taXobiybN, means, ‡ He spoke of such a female in amatory language [in the commencement of his ode], (Mṣb, TA,) and alluded to the love of her: (Mṣb:) and Xb-b qaSiydatahu † He embellished [the commencement of] his ode by the mention of women: (Mgh, Mṣb:) and Xb-b qaSiydatahu bifulaAnapa ‡ [He embellished the commencement of his ode by mentioning, in amatory language, such a female]: (A, TA:) and XabaAbN↓ is used in the sense of taXobiybN; thus a qaSiydap is said to be HasanapN AlX-abaAbi ‡ [Beautiful in the mention of women, &c.]; and Jereer is said to have been Oaraq-u Aln-aAsi XabaAbFA ‡ [The most elegant of men in the mention of women, &c.]. (A, TA.)

Hence, i. e. from taXobiybN AlqaSiydapi, may be derived Alt-aXobiybu as a conventional term in the science of the division of inheritances; meaning † The mention of daughters according to the different degrees [of descent]: (Mgh:) it is as when one says, “he died, and left three daughters of a son, subordinate one to another, and three daughters of a son's son, in like manner, and three daughters of a son's son's son, in like manner, and the sons died and the daughters remained.” (O.)

taXobiybu Alkutubi signifies † The commencing of books, or writings: and hence Xab-aba yujaAwibuhu, occurring in a trad., meaning † He commenced answering him: not from the taXobiyb of women in poetry. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. AXb-hu Qll-ehu God made him, or may God make him, to become a youth, or young man; i. e., to attain to the state termed XabaAbN meaning as expl. below: and AXb- Qll-ehu qaronahu means the same: (Ṣ, A, TA:) the latter [lit. means God made, or may God make, his equal in age to become a youth,, &c., (see Ḥar p. 572,) and therefore] is tropical. (A, TA.)
OaXobayotu Alfarasa I excited the horse to be brisk, lively, or sprightly, and to raise his fore legs together, as though in leaping, and to play. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA.)
AXb- Aln-aAra: see 1.
And OuXib-a liI kacaA, and Xub-a↓, ‡ Such a thing was prepared, or appointed, or ordained, for me. (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA.)

OaXab-u ‡ He became one whose child, or children, had attained to the state of XabaAb [i. e. youth, or young manhood,, &c.]: (Ḳ:) [or] OaXab-a Alr-ajulu baniyna ‡ the man became one whose children had attained to that state: (Ṣ, TA:) and in like manner, OaXab-ato OawolaAdFA is said of a woman. (TA.)

And OaXab-a said of [the species of bovine antelope called] the wild bull, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He became such as is termed XababN [q. v.], i. e., (Ṣ,) he became advanced in age, or full-grown; (musin-, Ṣ, Ḳ;) one whose state termed UisonaAn [q. v.] had ended. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense:
5. [taXab-ati Aln-aAru The fire became kindled; or made to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame: see also 1.] One says on the occasion of kindling fire,
taXab-abiI taXab-uba Aln-amiymaho
jaMCato bihaA tamorN UilaI tamiymaho
[Be thou kindled like the state of kindling of the calumny that Temr brought to Temeemeh: but to what this alludes I know not]: it is like the saying, Oawoqada biAln-amiymapi naArFA [He kindled a fire with calumny]. (A, TA.)
See also 2.

10. UisotaXoba It is said in a trad., yajuwzu XahaAdapu AlS-iboyaAni EalaI AlkibaAri yusotavab-uwna [The boy's giving testimony against those that are full grown is allowable, when they (the former) are deemed to have attained to the state of youths, or young men]: it is as though it were said that if they take upon themselves the bearing witness in boyhood, and give their testimony when full grown, it is allowable: (TA:) or yusotaXab-uwna means they shall be sought youths, such as have attained to puberty, or maturity, in the case of giving testimony: or they shall be waited for, in the case of giving testimony, until the period of becoming youths, or young men. (Mgh.)

And it is said in another trad., AisotaXib-uwA EalaI Oasowuqikumo fiI Albawoli, i. e. Sit upon your shanks as one does when preparing to rise, not stooping with the whole body near to the ground; [having your feet only upon the ground; in the voiding of urine:] from Xab-a Alfarasu meaning “the horse raised his fore-legs together from the ground.” (TA.)
R. Q. 1. XaboXaba He completed [a thing]; (AA, O, Ḳ;) said of a man. (AA, TA.)

hom.sense: Xab-N, and its fem. Xab-apN: see XaAb-N.

Also The stones of zaAj [or vitriol]: (Ḳ:) or the stones from which zAj and the like thereof are obtained; the best whereof is that which is brought from El-Yemen, which is white Xb-, and is very glistening: (TA:) [but Xab-N yamaAniI-N, as also Xab-N alone, is a name now commonly given to alum:] or it is a certain thing resembling zAj: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or a species thereof: accord. to El-Fárábee, the stones from which come zAj and the like: Az says, it is one of the minerals produced by God in the earth, with which one tans, and resembling zAj, and the name [correctly] heard is thus, with b, but is by some mistranscribed with the three-dotted v, [i. e. Xav-N,] which is a kind of tree of bitter taste, and I know not whether one tans with it or not: accord. to Mṭr, in the saying that one tans with Xb-, this word is a mistranscription; for Xb- is a dye, and one does not tan with a dye; it is mistranscribed for Xav-, which is a kind of tree like the dwarf apple-tree, whereof the leaves are like those of the xilaAf [q. v.], and with them one tans: El-Fárábee also says, in the section of v, that the Xav- is a species of mountain-tree, with which one tans: from all which it appears that one tans with both of them; for an affirmation is to be preferred to a negation: (Mṣb:) and it is a well-known medicine; (Ḳ, TA;) as some say: so accord. to the correct copies of the Ḳ, in some of which, daMCN is put for dawaMCN. (TA.)

entry.sense: Xub- and dub-, though originally verbs, are used as nouns, by the introduction of mino before them: one says, OaEoyayotaniI mino Xub-a UilaI dub-a and mino Xub-K UilaI dub- Ḳ [expl. in art. dba]: (Ṣ:) and in like manner they are used in another saying expl. in art. db [q. v.]: (Ṣ in that art.:) or, without tenween, they may be regarded as verbs used in the way of HikaAyap [or imitation]. (MF.)
Xab-apN The burning, burning up, burning brightly or fiercely, blazing, or flaming, of fire. (TA.)

XababN and XabuwbN↓, applied to a [bovine antelope of the species called the] wild bull, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and to a sheep or goat, (Ḳ,) and muXib-N↓, applied to the former, and miXab-N↓, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) sometimes, applied to the former, (Aṣ, Ṣ,) or to both, (Ḳ,) Advanced in age, or full-grown, (musin-N, Ṣ, Ḳ,) whose state termed UisonaAn [q. v.] has ended; (Aṣ, Ṣ;) and muXib-apN↓ is in like manner applied to a she-camel as meaning musin-apN: (TA:) or XbuwbN↓, (AA, Ḳ,) applied to both, (Ḳ,) as also muXib-N↓, (TA,) or to a bull, (AA,) is syn. with XAb-N↓ [meaning youthful, or in the prime of life]: (AA, Ḳ, TA:) and accord. to AO, XababN, applied to a bull, means that has attained to the end of XabaAb [i. e. youthfulness, or the prime of life]: (Ṣ, TA:) or, as some say, that has attained to the end of his full growth and strength; as also XabuwbN↓, which is likewise applied to the female; or, accord. to AḤát and ISh, when he is a year old, and weaned, he is called dababN; and then, XababN [meaning more than a year old]; and the female, XababpN. (TA.)

hom.sense:
XabaAbN and XabiybapN↓ [both mentioned above as inf. ns.] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) [and XabaAbiy-apN↓ which is a simple subst.] Youth, youthfulness, the prime of manhood, or young manhood; syn. fataMCN; (Ḳ;)
or HadaAvapN; contr. of XayobN: (Ṣ:) or the state from puberty to the completion of thirty years; or from sixteen years to thirty-two; after which a man is called kaholN; (TA;) the age before Alkuhuwlap: (Mṣb:) or the state between thirty and forty: (Mgh:) or, accord. to Moḥammad Ibn-Ḥabeeb, the state from the seventeenth year to the completion of fifty-one years is termed XabaAbiy-apN↓; the period before, from birth, being termed guluwmiy-apN; and in the period after, a man being called XayoxN, until he dies. (TA.) One says, saqaI Qll-ehu EaSora AlXabiybapi↓ [May God freshen as with rain the times, or mornings, or afternoons, of youth,, &c.], and EuSuwra AlX-abaAYibi [the times,, &c., of the states of youth,, &c.]. (A, TA.)

[XabaAbN often signifies † The sap, or vigour, of youth or young manhood.] One says, AisotaHaAra XabaAbuhaA, as in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, † The sap [or vigour] of youth (maMCN AlX-abaAbi) flowed in her. (IB, TA in art. Hyr.) And AimotalaOa XabaAbFA † [He became full of the sap, or vigour, of youth or young manhood]. (The lexicons, &c., passim.) [But] maMCN AlX-abaAbi signifies [also] ‡ The freshness, or brightness, and beauty, of youth. (Ḥar p. 340.) [And XabiybapN↓ app. signifies also † Youthful folly, or the like; (see an ex. voce gamorapN;) and so, probably, does XabaAbN.]

[Hence,] XabaAbN also signifies † The first, or beginning, or the new, or recent, state, of a thing; (Ḳ, TA;) and so XabiybapN↓. (TA.) One says, qadima fiI XabaAbi AlX-ahori (A, TA) ‡ He came, or arrived, in the beginning of the month. (TA.) And laqiytuhu fiI XabaAbi Aln-ahaAri (A, TA) ‡ I met him in the beginning of the day: (TA:) and jiYotuka fiI XabaAbi Aln-ahaAri and biXabaAbi Aln-ahaAri † I came to thee in the beginning of the day: (Lḥ, TA:) or XabaAbu Aln-ahaAri means the period when the sun has risen high, when one fifth of the day has passed. (A in art. rOd.) And one says also faEala celika fiI Xabiybatihi↓ He did that at the commencement thereof. (TA.)
And see 2.
XibaAbN an inf. n. of Xab-a said of a horse. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
See also the next paragraph, in two places.
XibaAbN: see Xab-a {1}, in three places.

Also A horse whose hind feet pass beyond his fore feet; (Ḳ;) which is a fault: accord. to Th, such is termed XabiybN↓: IM says that the correct word is XaYiytN: [but] see this in its proper place. (TA.)
Also A thing with which a fire is kindled, or made to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so XibaAbN↓. (Ḳ.)

And [hence, as also XibaAbN↓,] ‡ A thing that serves [as a foil] for beautifying, or setting off, (Ḳ,) [or making to appear bright and beautiful,] or for increasing, or enhancing, and strengthening, [or heightening, in beauty,] (Ṣ, TA,) to another thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) So in the saying, hecaA XabuwbN likacaA ‡ This is a thing that serves for increasing, or enhancing, [or heightening, in beauty,] to such a thing. (Ṣ, TA.) One says of a woman's headcovering, huwa XabuwbN liwajohihaA ‡ [It is a thing that serves for giving an appearance of additional brightness and beauty to her face]. (A.)

entry.sense: XabiybN: see the next preceding paragraph.
XabiybapN: see XabaAbN, in five places.

EasalN XabaAbiI-N Honey of Shebábeh (XabaAbap); (A, TA;) or, of Benoo-Shebábeh, (Mgh,) a people of Et-Táïf, (A, Mgh, TA,) of [the tribe of] Khath'am, who possessed bees, and hence it was thus called. (Mgh.)
XabaAbiy-apN: see XabaAbN, in two places.
Xab-acaA zayodN i. q. Hab-acaA [q. v. in art. Hb]. (Th, TA.)

XaAb-N part. n. of Xab-a said of a boy; (Mṣb;) [Youthful, or in the prime of manhood; a youth, or a young man;] in the state from puberty to the completion of thirty years; or from sixteen years to thirty-two; after which a man is called kaholN; (TA;) in the age before Alkuhuwlap: (Mṣb:) or in the state between thirty and forty: (Mgh:) [or in the state from the seventeenth year to the completion of fifty-one years: (see XabaAbN:)] and IAạr mentions Xab-N↓ as an epithet applied to a man [in the same sense as XaAb-N]: (TA:) a female is termed XaAb-apN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Xab-apN↓; both signifying the same: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the pl. of XaAb-N is Xub-aAnN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XababapN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and XabaAbN↓, (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ,) or the last is an inf. n. used as an epithet applied to a pl. number, (Mgh, and Ḥam p. 50,) or it is a quasi-pl. n.: (TA:) females, (Mṣb,) or women, (Ḳ,) are termed XawaAb-N (Mṣb, Ḳ) and XabaAYibu, (Ḳ,) the latter said by AZ to be allowable in the sense of the former, (TA,) which is pl. of XaAb-apN, (Mṣb,) XabaAYibu, accord. to Az, being pl. (not of XaAb-apN but) of Xab-apN, like as DaraAYiru is of Dar-apN: (TA:) the dim. of XaAb-apN is Xuwayob-apN↓, and some of the Arabs say XuwaAb-apN↓, changing the I into A before a double letter [as in duwaAb-apN for duwayob-apN]. (ISd, L in art. hd.) One says, mararotu birijaAlK Xababap Ḳ meaning Xub-aAnK [i. e. I passed by men that were youths, or persons in the prime of manhood]. (Ṣ.)
See also XababN.
XuwaAb-apN: dim. of XaAb-apN fem. of XaAb-N, q. v.
Xuwayob-apN: dim. of XaAb-apN fem. of XaAb-N, q. v.
XawoXabN The scorpion. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
And The louse; syn. qamolN: (Ḳ in this art.:) or the ant; syn. namolN: (Ḳ in art. XXb:) fem. [or perhaps n. un.] with p. (TA.)
muXib-N and its fem. with p {muXib-apN}: see XababN, in three places.
Also the former, A lion: (Ḳ:) or a full-grown lion: syn. OasadN kabiyrN. (TA.)
miXab-N: see XababN.

muXab-abN AlOaZaAfiri [or rather AlOaZaAfiyri, pl. of the pl. OaZofaArN or of OuZofuwrN,] ‡ Having sharp-pointed nails or talons or claws; as though they flamed, by reason of their sharpness. (A, TA.)
maXobuwbN [pass. part. n. of 1]. You say naArN maXobuwbapN A fire kindled, or made to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame: XaAb-apN in this sense is not allowable. (Ḳ.)

[Hence,] applied to a man, (A, TA,) ‡ Comely, (Ṣ, TA,) of goodly countenance; (A, TA;) as though lighted up: bright, or fair, in complexion, and of goodly countenance; as though his countenance were lighted up with fire: pl. maXaAbiybu. (TA.) And ‡ A man of acute mind. (TA.) And TalaEati AlmaXobuwbataAni Alz-uharataAni [or Alz-ahoraAwaAni?] ‡ Venus and Jupiter, so called on account of their beauty and splendour, rose. (A, TA.)

Xibit-N [Anethum graveolens, or dill, of the common garden-species;] a certain herb, or leguminous plant, well known: (Ḳ:) it is said that sibit-N is an arabicized word from Xibit-N; but it has been stated before [in art. sbt, q. v.,] that both these are arabicized words from Xiwico [or Xiwido]; and that sbT [i. e. siT-N] is a dial. var. (TA.) [See also Xibiv-N.]
1: see the next paragraph {5}, in two places.

5. tX-bv bihi He, or it, clung, caught, clave, or adhered, to it, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA,) namely, a thing; (Ṣ, L, TA;) as also Xabiva bihi↓, aor. _a {yaXobavu}, inf. n. XabavN: (L, TA:) or, accord. to Esh-Shiháb, in the Expos. of the Shifè, to a thing in which was weakness: or, accord. to the 'Ináyeh, he, or it, clung,, &c., to it with weakness; and therefore mutaXab-ivN↓ is used as an epithet applied to a spider; and tamas-uka signifies a stronger action; and tXb-v bh is also expl. as meaning he, or it, took fast, or firm, hold upon it: (L, TA:) and he stuck, or fixed, or struck, the claw, or talons, or nails, into it: (MA, PṢ:) and Xabiva↓ AlX-aIoCa he laid hold upon the thing, and took it: IAạr was asked respecting some verses, and he said, maA OadoriI mino Oayona XabivotuhaA I know not whence I laid hold upon them [and took them]. (L, TA.)
Q. Q. 1. accord. to the Ṣ and L, Xanobava: see art. Xnbv.
XabavN The spider: (Ḳ:) or a large spider, with many legs. (TA.)

Also (Ḳ) A certain small creeping thing, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) having many legs, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) of the OaHonaAX [or creeping things, &c.] of the earth: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) it should not be called XibovN: (Ṣ:) or a certain small creeping thing, having six long legs, yellow in the back, and in the outer sides of the legs, black in the head, and blue in the eye: or a certain small creeping thing, having many legs, large in the head, of the AHnAX of the earth: or a certain small creeping thing, wide in the mouth, high in the hinder part, that perforates the ground, is found where there is moisture, and eats scorpions; and it is what is called XaHomapu AlOaroDi: (TA:) pl. XibovaAnN. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) The [marks termed] Oavor of the blade of a sword are likened by a poet, (Ṣ, TA,) namely, Sá'ideh Ibn-Ju-eiyeh, (TA,) to the tracks of XibovaAn. (Ṣ, TA.)
rajulN XabivN A man whose nature it is to cling, catch, cleave, or adhere, to a thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And DirosN DabivN XabivN [A tooth, or molar tooth,] that catches, or fastens, to a thing. (TA.)
XubavapN, (Ḳ,) or XubavapN DubavapN, (TA,) A man (TA) who cleaves to his qiron [i. e. opponent, or adversary], not quitting him. (Ḳ, TA.)

Xibiv-N [erroneously written in some copies of the Ḳ XibovN, and in the L XibivN,] A certain wellknown plant; (AḤn, L, Mṣb;) a certain herb, or leguminous plant; (Ḳ;) [i. q. Xibit-N and sibit-N, q. v.; i. e. anethum graveolens, or dill, of the common garden-species:] Ṣgh says that Xbv is a foreign word of which sibit-N is an arabicized form; and it is made of the measure fiEil-N because this measure has many examples; whereas the measure fiEil-N, of which UibilN is an instance, is extraordinary. (Mṣb.)
Xab-aAvN: see what next follows.

Xab-uwvN and Xab-aAvN↓ [so in the CK and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, but the latter is strangely said in the TA to be with kesr,] sings. of XabaAbiyvu, which signifies The flesh-hooks (kalaAliyb) of the fire. (Ḳ.)
AlX-anobavu: see art. Xnbv.
AlX-unaAbivu: see art. Xnbv.
mitaXab-ivN an epithet applied to a spider: see 5.

hom.sense: 1. XabuHa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. XabaAHapN, (TḲ,) said of a man, (Ṣ,) He was, or became, broad in the fore arms: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or long therein. (TA.)

XabaHahu, (A, O, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXobaHu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XaboHN, (TḲ,) He extended, stretched, or stretched out, it, or him; (A, O, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, a thing; (IF, L, Mṣb;) a hide, or skin, (A, L, Ḳ,) or some other thing, (L,) between pegs, or stakes; (Ḳ;) and a man, (Mgh, L, Mṣb,) between two things, to be flogged, (L,) [i. e.,] between two stakes inserted and fixed in the ground, (Mgh, Mṣb,) which are called EuqaAbaAni, (Mgh,) when he was beaten, or crucified, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or like him who is crucified; and Xb-Hhu↓ is used, accord. to some, in the same manner. (L.) And XabaHa yadayohi He extended, or stretched forth, his arms, or hands: (L:) or XabaHa [alone] he extended his arm, or hand, to offer a prayer, or supplication; (Ḳ;) or he extended and raised his arms, or hands, in his prayer, or supplication. (A.) And AlHirobaMCu yaXobaHu EalaI AlEuwdi ‡ The chameleon extends (Ṣ, A, O) itself (Ṣ, O) or its fore legs (A) upon the branch. (Ṣ, A, O.)
Also, inf. n. as above, He cut, hewed, or pared, it, namely, a stick, or piece of wood, so as to make it wide. (O, L. [See also 2.])
And He clave it, or split it, (Ḳ,* TA,) namely, another's head, or anything whatever. (TA.)
XabaHa lanaA He (a man, Ḳ) stood erect [as though drawing himself up] to us. (O, Ḳ.)
And XabaHa laka It (a thing) appeared, or became apparent, to thee. (L.)
XubiHa biOamorK He was, or became, attached, or addicted, to an affair; or fond of it. (O.)
2. Xb-Hhu: see 1.
Also, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taXobiyHN, (Ṣ,) He made it (a thing) wide. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And taXobiyHN signifies also The act of paring, or peeling, or the like. (O. [See also 1.])
And The act of pulling, or plucking, out, or up. (O.)
And Xb-H, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) He (a man, TA) became aged, and saw a [thing such as is termed] XabaH appearing as though it were two. (O, Ḳ.)
XaboHN: see XabaHN, in two places:
and see also maXobuwHN.

XabaHN (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XaboHN↓ (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) i. q. XaxoSN [i. e. The body, or bodily or corporeal form or figure or substance, of a man or some other thing or object, which one sees from a distance]: (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) a man, or some other creature, of which the XaxoS [or body,, &c.,] appears to one: (L:) and a thing that is perceived by sense (A, O, L) and by sight: (O, L:) pl. OaXobaAHN, (A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is of the former, (A, Mṣb,) and [of the latter] XubuwHN. (Ḳ.) One says, laAHa liI XabaHN, meaning XaxoSN [i. e. A body, or bodily form, appeared, loomed, or gleamed, to me]. (A.) And humo OaXobaAHN bilaA OarowaAHK [They are bodies without souls]. (A.) And Oacaq-u mino XabaHK baATil Ḳ, (A, O,) and mino xayoTi baATilK, a prov., (O,) meaning [More minute, or inconsiderable, than] the atoms that are seen in the rays of the sun entering from a mural aperture in a chamber: (A,* O:) or, as some say, than the thread that comes forth from the mouth of the spider; [meaning gossamer;] called by the children muxaATN AlX-ayoTaAni. (O.) And AlOasomaMCu DarobaAni OasomaMCu OaXobaAHK waOasomaMCu OaEomaAl Ḳ, meaning [Nouns are of two sorts,] the names of things perceived by sense, and the names [of actions, or rather of accidents or attributes, i. e.] of other things; like as they say OasomaMCu AlOaEoyaAni and OasomaMCu AlmaEaAniI. (A.) And halaka OaXobaAHu maAlihi The known ones of his camels, and sheep or goats, and other cattle, perished. (O, Ḳ.*)
XabaHN also signifies A door or gate, of high structure; (O, Ḳ;) and so XaboHN↓: (Ḳ:) [but the latter may have originated from a mistranscription; for Ṣgh says,] and so XabajN. (O.)
See also XabaHapN.

entry.sense: XaboHapN A rafter, or timber, (Euwd,) of the ceiling, or roof, of a house: so in a trad. where it is said, fanazaEa saqofa baytiI XaboHapF XaboHapF [And he pulled off the roof of my house, rafter by rafter, or timber by timber]. (JM,* TA.)
XiboHapN of horses: what is thus called is well known [as being A rope which is extended from a horse's fore leg to his hind leg: so in the present day]. (TA.)
XabaHapN a word occurring in the Ḳ and TA voce muXoTN and in the TA voce miHar-N, &c. [app. as meaning A broad piece of wood].

AlX-abaHataAni signifies The two pieces of wood of the minoqalap, (O, Ḳ,) which is the thing upon which bricks are carried from place to place: the pl. is AlX-abaHaAtu and [the coll. gen. n., of which XabaHapN is the n. un., is] AlX-abaHu↓. (O.)
XaboHaAn [whether with or without tenween is not apparent, as the fem. is not mentioned,] Tall; (AA, Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) an epithet applied to a man. (TA.)

XabiyHapN sing. of XabaAYiHu, (O,) which signifies Pieces of wood, (O, Ḳ,) broad, (O,) placed transversly, (O, Ḳ,) contrariwise, or on contrary sides, (O,) in the [camel's saddle called] qatab (O, Ḳ) that is of wood: so expl. by Shujáa. (O.)

hom.sense: muX-abaHN, applied to a [garment of the kind called] kisaMC, Strong, or stout: (O, Ḳ:*) or, as some say, wide. (O.)
And [applied to a stick, or piece of wood,] Pared, (Ḳ, TA,) and cut, or hewed [app. so as to be made wide: see 1]. (TA.)
And A species of fish.. (TA.)
maXobuwHN Wide between the shoulders. (L.)
maXobuwHu Alc-iraAEayoni and XaboHu↓ Alc-iraAEayoni A man broad in the fore arms: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or long therein: but AAF and Ibn-El-Jowzee prefer the former explanation. (TA.)
maXobuwHN biOamorK Attached, or addicted, to an affair; or fond of it. (O.)

1. Xabara, aor. _u {yaXoburu} (Ṣ, A, Mṣb) and _i {yaXobiru}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. XaborN; (IAạr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and Xb-r↓, inf. n. taXobiyrN; (IAạr, Ḳ;) He measured by the Xibor [or span] (IAạr, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) a garment, or piece of cloth, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or a thing: (A, Mṣb:) from AlX-iboru; like as one says buEotuhu from AlbaAEu. (Ṣ.) mano laka Oano taXobura AlbasiyTapa ‡ [Who will be guarantee for thee that thou wilt measure the earth with thy span?] is a prov. applied to him who imposes upon himself that which he is unable to accomplish. (A, TA.)
Xabara AlmaroOapa, inf. n. as above, † He compressed the woman. (TA.)

Xabarahu, (ISk, Ṣ, A,) aor. _u {yaXoburu} and _i {yaXobiru}, (TA,) inf. n. as above; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and AXbrhu↓, (Ṣ, A,) inf. n. UiXobaArN; (Ḳ;) and Xb-rhu↓, inf. n. taXobiyrN; (TṢ, TA;) He gave him (ISk, Ṣ, A, TṢ, Ḳ *) wealth, or property, (ISk, Ṣ, A,) or a sword, (ISk, Ṣ,) or a coat of mail. (Ṣ, IB.)
Xabira, aor. _a {yaXobaru}, He exulted; or exulted greatly, or excessively; and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully. (TṢ, Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in two places.
Also Xb-rhu, (AHeyth, Ḳ,) inf. n. taXobiyrN, (AHeyth, TA,) He magnified him, or honoured him; namely, a man: (AHeyth, Ḳ, TA:) and made him a near companion, a familiar, or a favourite. (AHeyth, TA.)

hom.sense: 4. AXbr He (a man) begat children tall in the OaXobaAr, i. e. statures: and he begat children short therein. (IAạr, TA.)
AXbrhu: see 1.

entry.sense: 5. tXb-r He was, or became, magnified, or honoured: and made a near companion, a familiar, or a favourite. (AHeyth, TA.)
6. tXAbrA They (two bodies of men, Ṣ) drew near, each to the other: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as though they became a span (Xibor) distant, one from the other; or as though each extended the span to the other. (Ṣ.)

XaborN The measure [of the width (see ciraAEN)], by the span, of a garment, or piece of cloth: so in the saying, kamo Xaboru vawobika [How much is the measure of the width, by the span, of thy garment, or piece of cloth?]. (Mṣb.)
Stature; (Fr, Ḳ;) and so XiborapN↓; whether short or tall: (TA:) pl. [app. of the latter] OaXobaArN. (IAạr, TA.) You say, maA OaTowala Xaborahu How tall is his stature! (TA.)
Life, or age; as also XiborN↓. (TṢ, Ḳ.) Thus in the saying, qaS-ara Qll-ehu Xaborahu and Xiborahu↓ [May God shorten, or God shortened, his life]. (TṢ, TA.)
‡ The act of giving: (A, IAth:) like as baAEN and yadN are said for “generosity.” (A.)
See also XabarN, in two places.

† The due for marriage, and for concubitus; (Sh, Ṣ,* Ḳ;*) such as what are termed mahorN and EuqorN. (Sh, TA.) You say, OaEoTayotu AlaroOapa XaborahaA I gave the woman her due for marriage, or for concubitus. (Ṣ.)
† The hire that is given for the stallion-camel's covering of the female. (IAạr, T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.*) The taking of this is forbidden. (T, Ṣ, Mṣb.)
‡ Marriage: (IAth, Ḳ:) because it is accompanied by a gift. (IAth, TA.) baAraka Qll-ehu fiI XaborikumaA May God bless your marriage is a saying mentioned in a trad. (IAth, TA.)

XiborN A span; the space between the extremity of the thumb and that of the little finger (Mṣb, Ḳ) when extended apart in the usual manner: (Mṣb:) of the masc. gender: (Ḳ:) pl. OaXobaArN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the only pl. form. (Sb.) [See also buSomN, and ciraAEN.] [Hence,] qaSiyru AlX-ibori (applied to a man, Ṣ) ‡ Contracted, or short, in make: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or, accord. to some of the lexicons, in step. (TA.)

[As a measure in astronomy, it is said in several of the law-books to be The twelfth part of the rumoH; and therefore twentytwo minutes and a half, accord. to modern usage: but there is reason to believe that ancient usage differed from the modern with respect to both of these measures, and was not precise nor uniform. See rumoHN.]
qibaAlu AlX-ibori † The serpent: (IAạr, Ḳ:) and so qibaAlu AlX-isoEi. (IAạr, TA.)
See also XaborN, in two places.

XabarN ‡ A gift; (Ṣ Mgh, Ḳ, TA;) as also XaborN↓ (Mgh, TA) and XiborapN↓: (IAạr, TA:) and wealth, or the like; syn. xayorN: (Ḳ:) the first is a word similar to xabaTN and nafaDN; and he who says that it is used by poetic license for XaborN [as it is said to be in the Ṣ] is in error: XaborN↓ and XabarN are said to be two dial. vars., like qadorN and qadarN. (TA.)

Also A certain thing which the Christians give, one to another, (yataEaATaAhu Aln-aSaAraI, Ḳ, TA, abEoDuhumo libaEoDK, TA,) like the qurobaAn [or Eucharist], (Ḳ, TA,) seeking to ingratiate themselves thereby: (TA:) or the Eucharist (qurobaAn) itself: (Ḳ:) or a thing which the Christians give (tuEoTiyhi), one to another, as though seeking to ingratiate themselves thereby: (Kh, Ṣgh, TA:) or (TA, in the Ḳ “and”) bodies: and powers, or faculties: (Ḳ, TA:) or (TA, in the Ḳ “and”) the Gospel. (Ḳ, TA.)
XiborapN: see XaborN:
and see also XabarN.

Xab-uwrN A trumpet; syn. buwqN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a certain thing in which one blows: (Mgh:) said to be an arabicized word; (Ṣ;) not genuine Arabic: (Mgh, TA:) accord. to IAth, it is Hebrew: (TA:) [app. from the Hebr. שׁוׄפָר, as observed by Golius.]
See also OuXobuwrN.
rajulN XaAbiru AlmiyzaAni † A man that is a thief. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
OaXobaru Wider in span; syn. OawosaEu XiborFA. (A, TA.) So in the saying, huwa OaXobaru mino SaAHibihi [He is wider in span than his companion]. (A.)
OuXobuwrN A certain fish; (Ḳ;) called by the vulgar Xab-uwr↓. (TA.)

hom.sense: maXobarN sing. of maXaAbiru, (TA,) which signifies Certain notches (HuzuwzN [pl. of Haz-N, in the CK erroneously written xuwuwozN,]) in the cubit, by means of which buying and selling are transacted: (Ḳ, TA:) of them is the notch (Haz-) of the span, and the notch of the half of the span, and of the quarter thereof: every notch of these, small or great, is termed maXobarN: mentioned by Ṣgh, from Aboo-Saʼeed. (TA.)

maXaAbiru also signifies Rivers, or rivulets, (OanohaAr,) that are depressed, so that the water comes to them from several places, (Ḳ, TA,) of such as overflows from the lands: (TA:) pl. of maXobarN and maXobarapN↓. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: maXobarapN: see what next precedes.
maXobuwrapN A liberal, bountiful, or generous, woman. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
XubaATN (AA, Ḳ) and XubaATu, being perfectly and imperfectly decl., (AA, TA,) The name of a month in Greek; (AA, Ḳ;) i. q. subaAT, q. v. (AA, TA.)

Xab-uwTN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and Xub-uwTN, (Ḳ,) the latter mentioned in the O on the authority of Lth, but in the L on the authority of Lḥ, and said by him to be a Greek word, (TA,) [a coll. gen. n.,] n. un. with p {Xab-uwTapN}, and sometimes that with fet-ḥ is without teshdeed, (Ḳ,) i. e. XabuwTapN, mentioned by ISd, but with the expression of a doubt as to its correctness, (TA,) [now applied to A species of cyprinus, or carp: or, accord. to Golius, a fish resembling the alosa, or shad, but three times larger; wont to be brought from the Euphrates to Aleppo:] a species of fish, (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ,) slender in the tail, wide in the middle part, soft to the feel, small in the head, resembling a barobaT [or Persian lute]: (Lth, Ḳ:) the brbT when long, not broad, is likened to this fish; and this fish, to the brbT: the pl. is XabaAbiyTu. (TA.) [See sub-uwHN.]

hom.sense: 1. XabiEa, [aor. _a {yaXobaEu},] inf. n. XibaEN (IDrd, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XiboEN, (IDrd, Mṣb, TA,) which is a contraction of the former, or accord. to some it is a subst., having the signification assigned to it below, (Mṣb,) or it is both, (TA,) and XaboEN, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,) He was, or became, satiated, sated, or satisfied in stomach; XibaEN being the contr. of juwEN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and one of those inf. ns. [which are of a measure often] denoting natural affections or qualities [such as riwFI and simanN, &c.]. (Ṣ.) You say baladN qado XabiEato ganamuhu A country of which the sheep, or goats, have become completely satiated, or satisfied, by abundance of herbage. (TA.) And XabiEotu xubozFA, and laHomFA, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and mino xubozK, and mn laHomK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) I was, or became, satiated, sated, or satisfied, with bread, and with flesh-meat. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Hence, metaphorically, XabiEotu mino hecaA AlOamori warawiytu ‡ I have become, or I became, disgusted [or satiated to loathing] with this thing, or affair. (Ṣ,* TA.)
[See also another metaphorical usage of this verb voce HuzaAnapN.]
XabuEa Eaqoluhu † His intellect was, or became, full, perfect, (Ḳ,) strong, or solid. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. Xab-aEato ganamuhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, [in some copies of the former, erroneously, XabiEato,]) inf. n. taXobiyEN; (Ḳ;) and Xub-iEato; (as in one place in the TA;) ‡ His sheep, or goats, were, or became, nearly, but not quite, satiated, or satisfied. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 4. AXbEhu [signifying It satiated him, sated him, or satisfied his stomach,] is said of food and of abundance of drink. (TA.)

OaXobaEotuhu [I satiated him, sated him, or satisfied his stomach; or] I fed him so that he became satiated, sated, or satisfied. (Mṣb.) And OaXobaEotuhu mina AljuwEi [I fed him so as fully to relieve him from hunger]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [Hence,] OaXobaEotu Alv-awoba (Ṣ, TA) mina AlS-ibogi (Ṣ) ‡ I saturated the garment, or piece of cloth, with the dye. (TA.)

[Hence also,] AXbEhu ‡ He made it (namely anything, TA) full, without lack or defect, or abundant, or copious. (Ḳ,* TA.) It is said of other things beside substances; as, for instance, of blowing, and of reading or reciting, and of any expression. (TA.) You say also, saAqa fiI hecaA AlmaEonaI faSolFA muXobaEFA [He carried on, respecting this idea, a full section]. (TA.) [And AXbE HarakapF He rendered a vowel full in sound, by inserting after it its analogous letter of prolongation. And such a letter of prolongation is said to be inserted, or added, liloUiXobaAEi to render the sound full; as in nukaAtN for nukatN, and OanoZuwru for OanoZuru, and maraADiyEu for maraADiEu. And UiXobaAEFA is also used as signifying For the sake of, or by way of, pleonasm, or giving fulness of expression.]
AXbE Alr-ajulu The man's beasts were, or became, completely satiated, or satisfied, by abundance of herbage. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tXb-E He ate immediately after eating. (Ḳ.)
He feigned himself satiated, sated, or satisfied in stomach, not being so. (Ḳ, TA.)
[And hence,] ‡ He made a boast of abundance or riches, (Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA,) or of more than he possessed; and invested himself with that which did not belong to him. (TA.) [See mutaXab-iEN.]

XiboEN a subst., signifying A thing that satiates one, sates one, or satisfies one's stomach; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) consisting of bread, and of flesh-meat, &c.; (Mṣb;) as also XibaEN↓: (Ḳ:) accord. to some, the former is an inf. n.: (Mṣb:) or it is an inf. n. and also a subst. signifying as above. (TA.) You say, Alr-agiyfu XiboEiI The cake of bread [is that which] satiates me,, &c. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: XibaEN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.].
Also ‡ Thickness in the shanks. (TA.)
See also XiboEN. You say, OaroDN caAtu XibaEK A land having abundance of herbage, and plenty. (Mgh.)

entry.sense: XuboEapN mino TaEaAmK The quantity with which one is satiated, sated, or satisfied, once, of food. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
OaroDN XabiEapN i. q. caAtu XibaEK [q. v.]. (Mgh.)

XaboEaAnu Satiated, sated, or satisfied in stomach; (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) as also XaAbiEN↓, but this is allowable only in poetry: (Ḳ:) fem. of the former XaboEaI, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and XaboEaAnapN (Ṣgh, Ḳ) is sometimes used: (Ṣgh:) the pl. of XbEAn and of XbEI is XibaAEN and XabaAEaI. (TA.) [Hence the saying,] qawomN UicaA jaAEuwA kaAEuwA wataraAhumo sibaAEFA UicaA kaAnuwA XibaAEFA [A people who, when they are hungry, are fearful and cowardly, and thou seest them to be beasts of prey when they are satiated]. (A, TA.)

[And hence,] XaboEaI AlxaloxaAli ‡ A woman who fills up the anklet by reason of her fatness. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) And XaboEaI Als-iwaAri ‡ Who fills up the bracelet by reason of fatness. (Ḳ, TA.) And XaboEaI AlwiXaAHi ‡ A woman large in the belly. (TA.) And XaboEaI Ald-iroEi ‡ A woman bulky in make: (A, O, L, TA:) in the Ḳ erroneously written XaboEaI Alc-iraAEi, and expl. as meaning bulky in the forearm. (TA.)
XabiyEN Food that satiates, sates, or satisfies the stomach. (Fr.)
† An arrow that kills much or many or often. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.)

vawobN XabiyEu Algazoli ‡ A garment, or piece of cloth, [of full texture, or] of many threads: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) pl. viyaAbN XuboEN. (TA.) And HabolN XabiyEN, (Ḳ,) or XabiyEu Alv-al-api, (TA,) † A rope abundant, (Ḳ, TA,) and firm, or strong, in the wool, (TA,) or in the hair, or fur, [of which it is composed:] (Ḳ, TA:) pl. XuboEN. (TA.)

rajulN XabiyEu AlEaqoli † A man full, or perfect, (Ḳ, TA,) and strong, or solid, (TA,) in intellect; (Ḳ, TA;) from IAạr; (TA;) as also muXobaEuhu↓. (Ḳ.) And rajulN muXab-aEN↓ Alqalobi [or perhaps muXobaEu↓ Alqalobi] † A man strong, or firm, in heart. (TA.)
XubaAEapN A portion of food that remains, or is redundant, after one is satiated, or satisfied. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.*)
XaAbiEN: see XuboEaAnN.
bahiymapN XaAbiEN A beast that has attained to eating; an epithet applied to such a beast until it is nearly weaned. (TA.)
fulaAnN fiI riI-i wamaXobaEK [Such a one is in a state in which he is satiated, or satisfied, with drink and food]. (T, A, TA, in art. nZr.) [See manoZarN.]
muXobaEN pass. part. n. of 4 [q. v.]. See also XabiyEN, in two places.
muXab-aEN: see XabiyEN.
AlbaMCu AlmuXab-aEu [or AlmuXab-aEapu] The letter P. (TA in art. bls.)

mutaXab-iEN ‡ One who invests himself with, and makes a boast of, more than he possesses; who invests himself with that which he does not possess; (Ṣ, TA;) who affects goodly qualities more than he possesses; like him who feigns himself satiated, or satisfied in stomach, not being so: (TA:) or he who feigns himself satiated, or satisfied in stomach, not being so: and hence, † a lying person, who affects to be commended or praised for, or boasts of, or glories in, that which he does not possess. (Mgh.) Thus in a trad., (Ṣ, Mgh,) in which it is said, AlmutaXab-iEu bimaA laA yamoliku kalaA bisi vawobaIo zuwrK, (Ṣ, TA,) or bimaA layosa Einodahu, (Mgh,) ‡ [He who invests himself with, and makes a boast of, more than he possesses,, &c., is like the wearer of two garments of falsity: or] accord. to AʼObeyd, it means [that such is like] the hypocrite who wears the garments of the devotees in order that he may be thought to be a devotee, not being so: or, as some say, the person who wears a shirt to the sleeves of which he attaches two other sleeves in order to make it appear that he is wearing two shirts: or [the wearer of the garments of the false witness; for] it is said that there used to be in the tribe the man of goodly exterior, and when false witness was needed, he bore [such] witness, and was not rejected, because of the goodliness of his apparel. (Mgh.) [See also art. zwr, in which this trad, is cited with a small variation.]

1. Xabiqa, (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXobaqu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XabaqN, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, O, Mṣb,) He was, or became, affected with vehement lust, or carnal desire: (Ṣ, M, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) said of a man; (M, Mṣb;) and in like manner one says of a woman; and also, sometimes, of other than human beings. (M, TA.)
And Xabiqa mina All-aHomi He suffered indigestion, or turned away with disgust, from flesh-meat. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
XabiqN Affected with vehement lust or carnal desire; (Mṣb, TA;) applied to a man; and sometimes to other than man: (Mṣb:) fem. with p {XabiqapN}. (Mṣb, TA.)

XuwbaqN A certain wooden implement of the baker, or maker of bread; (Ḳ;) a baker's rolling-pin; (MA;) [thus called, and also Xuwbak, in the present day;] an arabicized word, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ,) from [the Pers.] juwbah [or Juwbaho, or from the Pers. Xuwbajo]. (TA.) [See also kariybo.]

1. Xabakahu, aor. _i {yaXobiku}, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. XabokN; (TA;) and Xb-khu↓, inf. n. taXobiykN; He infixed, (Ḳ, TA,) and inserted, (TA,) one part thereof into another, or parts thereof into others: (Ḳ, TA:) so in the M: (TA:) [but the latter more usually signifies he infixed, and inserted, many parts thereof into others: (see 8, first sentence, respecting its quasi-pass.:) and hence, he made it reticulated, retiform, like a net; and like a lattice, or trellis, or grating, or cage: and both signify also he made it commingled in its several parts, intricate, complicated, perplexed, or confused; either properly, as when the object is a fabric, or anything made by art, or created; or tropically, as when the object is ideal:] primarily, (TA,) AlX-aboku signifies AlxaloTu [i. e. the mixing together a thing or things]; and [implies] Alt-adaAxulu [i. e. the entering of one part of a thing into another part, or of parts of a thing or things into other parts; or the being intermixed, or intermingled]. (Ṣ, TA.) Hence, taXobiyku↓ AlOaSaAbiEi, (Ṣ, TA,) meaning The inserting of some of the fingers [i. e. those of one hand] amid the other fingers; (Mṣb, TA;) which it is forbidden to do in prayer: (TA:) one says, [Xb-k OaSaAbiEahu, or] Xb-k bayona OaSaAbiEihi, He inserted, or interserted, his fingers together [so as to conjoin his two hands]: (MA:) or, as some interpret it, taXobiyku AlOaSaAbiEi which is forbidden in prayer is † the mixing, and entering, into contentions, or altercations. (TA.) [Hence also,] kaAnati Alr-iyHu Xab-akatohumo↓, a saying of Moḥammad Ibn-Zekereeyà, meaning † The wind had made them like the Xabakap [or net], in the interkniting and contraction of the limbs. (Mgh.)
Xabakahu Eanohu, inf. n. as above, means † He, or it, diverted him, or occupied him so as to divert him, from him, or it. (TA.)

hom.sense: 2: see above {1}, in three places:
and see also 8, in two places.

entry.sense: 3. XAbk bayonahumaA, inf. n. muXaAbakapN, [app. † He caused an embroilment between them two,] occurring in a tradition, (TA.)
4. AXbkwA They dug wells (O, Ḳ) such as are called XibaAkN (O) or such as are called XabakapN. (Ḳ.)
And OaXobaka It (a place) had [such] wells dug in it by many persons. (TA.)
5: see 8, in four places.
6: see 8, in three places,
tXAbkt Als-ibaAEu The beasts of prey leaped [the females]; syn. nazato: (Ḳ:) or desired to do so (OaraAdati Aln-izaMCi). (IAạr, TA.)
taXaAbakaA [app. † They became embroiled, each with the other;] quasi-pass. of XaAbaka bayonahumaA. (TA.)

8. AXtbk, quasi-pass. of Xabakahu, It had one part thereof infixed, (Ḳ, TA,) and inserted, (TA,) into another, or parts thereof into others; as also tXb-k↓, quasi-pass. of Xb-khu: (Ḳ, TA:) so in the M: but ↓the latter imports muchness, or multiplicity: (TA:)
[i. e. it signifies it had many parts thereof infixed, and inserted, into others: and hence, it was reticulated, retiform, like a net; and like a lattice, or trellis, or grating, or cage: and both signify also it was, or became, commingled in its several parts, intricate, complicated, perplexed, or confused; either properly, as when said of a fabric, or anything made by art, or created; or tropically, as when said of what is ideal.] One says, AXtbkt Aln-ujuwmu, and tXAbkt↓, and Xab-akat↓, [or the last may be a mistranscription for tXb-kt↓,] The stars were intermixed among themselves, and confused: (TA:) [or were clustered together:] or AiXotibaAku Aln-ujuwmi signifies the stars' being numerous, and being intermixed among themselves; from Xabakapu AlS-aAYidi [“the net of the fisherman” or “sportsman”]: (Mgh:) or their being numerous, and [as though] gathered [or clustered] together: (Mṣb:) or, as some say, the appearing of all the stars [which causes them to appear confused]. (TA.) And AXtbkt AlEuruwqu The veins were knit together, commingled, or intricately intermixed or intermingled; syn. AiXotajarat. (O, TA.) And AXtbk Als-araAbu The mirage became intermixed, or confused. (TA.) And AXtbk AlZ-alaAmu ‡ The darkness became confused. (Ṣ, O, TA.) And AXtkbt AlOumuwru, and tXAbkt↓, and Xb-kt↓, (Ḳ, TA,) and tXb-kt↓, (TA,) † The affairs became intricate, complicated, perplexed, or confused. (Ḳ, TA.) And AXtkbt AlHarobu bayonahumo † The war, or fight, became intricate, and entangled between them; syn. naXibat. (TA in art. nXb.) And AXtbkt OanoyaAbuhu waQxotalafato [His canine teeth locked together, and were dissimilar]; referring to a lion. (O. [See also XaAbikN.]) AiXotibaAku Alr-aHimi means ‡ The close [or intimate] connexion of relationship by birth: (TA:) [and in like manner, taXaAbuku↓ AlOaroHaAmi such connexion of relationships by birth: see an ex. of its part. n., voce muXotabikN.]
XabakN: see XabakapN.
Also The teeth of a comb; (O, Ḳ;) because of their nearness together. (TA.)

bayonahumaA XubokapN, (Ḳ,) or XubokapN nasabK, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) ‡ Between them two is [a close or an intimate connexion of] relationship by birth: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and bayona Alqawomi Xubokapu nasabK ‡ Between the people, or party, is an intermingling [of relationship]. (O, TA.)

hom.sense: XabakapN The Xarakap [meaning net] of the Say-aAd [i. e. fisherman, and fowler or sportsman]; (Ḳ;) the miSoyadap, (Lth, O, TA,) or instrument of AlS-ayod, (Ṣ,) that is used in the water [i. e. for catching fish] and on the land [i. e. for catching fowls or wild animals]; (Lth, O,* TA;) applied by some peculiarly to the miSoyadap of the water; (TA;) and Xub-aAkN↓ signifies the same: (Ḳ:) pl. of the former XibaAkN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XabakaAtN (Mṣb) and [coll. gen. n.] XabakN↓: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) and the pl. of Xub-aAkN↓ is XabaAbiyku (Ḳ.)
And A certain thing for the head; (Lth, O;) [a small net, for the head, a veil of net-work, in order that the face may not be known. (Golius, on the authority of Meyd.)]

Also Wells near together, (Ḳ, TA,) of which the water is near [to the mouths], communicating [app. by filtration] one with another: so accord. to El-Ḳutabee: (TA:) or wells separate, one from another: (M and L in art. mOd:) and, (Ḳ,) or as some say, (TA,) wells (O, Ḳ, TA) that are open to view, (Ḳ, TA,) dug in a rugged place, of the depth of the stature of a man, and twice and thrice that measure, in which the rain-water becomes retained: so called because of their mutual proximity, and confusedness: a single one of them is not called XabakapN; for this is only a name for a plural number; but the pl. XibaAkN is applied to aggregates thereof in sundry places: (O, TA:) or XibaAkN, (Ṣ,) or XabakapN, (Mṣb,) signifies wells that are numerous and near together in a [tract of] land; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) form AiXotibaAku Aln-ujuwmi: (Mṣb:) or, accord. to Aṣ, XabakapN signifies wells, or other pits or hollows dug in the ground, that are numerous; and the pl. is XibaAkN. (IDrd, O.)

And A [tract of] land in which are many wells, (Ḳ, TA,) not tracts that exude water and produce salt, nor such as give growth to plants, or herbage: (TA:) or [the pl.] XibaAkN signifies places, of the earth, that are not such as exude water and produce salt, nor such as give growth to plants, or herbage; such as the XibaAk of El-Basrah. (Lth, O.)
And The burrow of the [field-rat called] jurac: (Ḳ, TA:) or the burrows thereof, which are near together: pl. XibaAkN. (TA.)

entry.sense: XibaAkN, (thus in the ʼEyn and O and L and TA,) or Xub-aAkN↓, (thus in the Ḳ, there said to be like zun-aArN,) but [SM says that] the latter is a manifest mistake, (TA,) A thing, (Ḳ, TA,) or anything, (Lth, O,) composed of canes, or reeds, (Ḳ, TA,) or such as canes, or reeds, (Lth, O,) firmly bound together, (Lth, O, TA,) in the manner of the manufacture of mats: (Lth, O, Ḳ, TA:) a single piece whereof is termed XibaAkapN↓, (Lth, O, TA,) or Xub-aAkapN↓. (So in the Ḳ.)

And likewise, (i. e. XibaAkN, as in the ʼEyn and O and L, but in the Ḳ Xub-aAkN↓, TA,) What is between the curved pieces of wood of the [vehicles called] maHaAmil, [pl. of maHomil, q. v., composed] of net-work of thongs (mino taXobiyki Alqid-i [Alqid- being here used as a coll. gen. n.: see art. qd]). (Ḳ, TA.)
XibaAkapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
XabaAYiku [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] Contentions, or altercations. (TA.)

Xab-aAkN means mano yaEomalu AlX-ibaAka AlwaTiy-aAti [app. A maker of soft netted fabrics of thongs for maHaAmil; (see XibaAkN, latter sentence;) supposing AlwaTiy-aAti to be for AlwaTiyoYaAti, agreeably with a well-known license]. (TA.)

hom.sense: Xub-aAkN: see XabakapN, in two places:
and XibaAkN, likewise in two places:
and Xub-aAkapN, also in two places.
