Applied to a diroE i. q. maHobuwkapN [app. as signifying Woven well, or well and compactly; in which sense this epithet seems to be more properly applicable to a woman's “shift” than to “a coat of mail;” but diroEN in the former of these senses is seldom, if ever, fem.; and in the latter sense, seldom, if ever, masc.]. (TA.)

[It is also a pl., of which the sing., if used, is probably XaAbikN↓, accord. to analogy; as a possessive epithet, meaning cuw XabakapK, like laAbinN meaning cuw labanK, &c.:] one says, raOayotu EalaI AlmaMCi AlX-ub-aAka I saw, upon the water, the fishermen with the nets. (Az, Z, TA.)

entry.sense: Xub-aAkapN, (Ṣ, O, KL,) or Xub-aAkN↓, (Mṣb, TA,) A thing formed of grating, or lattice-work, (maXobakapN↓, Ṣ, O, or muXab-akN, KL, TA,) or iron, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) and of other material [i. e. of wood, &c.]: (TA:) and [particularly] a window so formed: (KL:) pl. XabaAbiyku. (Ṣ, O, TA.) One says, raOayotuhu yanoZuru mina AlX-ub-aAki↓ [I saw him looking from the grated, or latticed, window]. (TA.)
See also XibaAkN.
XaAbikN [app. a possessive epithet, meaning cuw XabakapK]: see Xub-aAkN.
[Also meaning cuw QXotibaAkK.] One says TariyqN XaAbikN A road, or way, that is confused and intricate. (O, Ḳ.)

[Hence,] Oum-u Aln-ujuwmi AlX-awaAbiki may mean The sun; as being the chief of the [confused] stars: or the milky way; [as being composed of confused stars;] AlX-awaAbik [pl. of AlX-aAbikap] meaning AlmuXotabikap↓. (Ḥam pp. 43 and 44.)
And luHomapN XaAbikapN: see muXotabikN.

And XaAbikN applied to a lion, Having the canine teeth locking together, (muXotabiku↓ AlOanoyaAbi, Ḳ, TA, [see 8, near the end, in the CK mutaXab-iku AlAanoyaAbi,]) dissimilar: (TA:) and XAbiku AlOanoyaAbi is applied to a camel, (O, TA,) in like manner. (TA.) [Hence,] AlX-aAbiku is one of the names for The lion. (TA.)
And one says rajulN XaAbiku Alr-umoHi, meaning A man whom one sees, by reason of his skill, thrusting with the spear [indiscriminately] in all the faces. (O, TA.)
muXab-akN: see Xub-aAkapN.
AlmuXab-aku is A certain sort of food. (TA.)
muXotabikN: see XaAbikN, in two places.

raHimN muXotabikapN (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, TA) means ‡ [Relationship by birth] closely, or intimately, connected. (AʼObeyd, TA.) And one says also, bayonahumaA OaroHaAmN mutaXaAbikapN↓ ‡ [Between them two are relationships by birth closely, or intimately, connected]: and luHomapN XaAbikapN↓ [which means the like]. (TA.)
OaroHaAmN mutaXaAbikapN: see what next precedes.

1. Xabala, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXobulu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. XubuwlN, He (a boy, TA) became a youth, or young man, (Ḳ,) or grew up, and became a youth, or young man, (TA,) in a state of ease and plenty. (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, fI niEomapK is erroneously put for fI naEomapK.]) Accord. to Ks, one says, Xabalotu fiI baniI fulaAnK, meaning I grew up, or became a youth, or young man, among the sons of such a one: (Ṣ, TA:) and qado Xabala AlgulaAmu OaHosana XubuwlK The boy has grown up, or become a youth, or young man, in the best manner: (Ṣ:) but accord. to others, it is not said except in the case of being in a state of ease and plenty. (TA.)

4. OaXobalati AlmaroOapu baEoda baEolihaA † The woman bore with her children, [tending them patiently, after the loss of her husband,] without marrying: (Ṣ, O:) [and] AXblt EalaI waladihaA ‡ She (a woman) applied herself constantly to the care of her children, after [the loss of] her husband, (Ḳ, TA,) and bore with them, (TA,) not marrying: (Ḳ, TA:) and the epithet applied to her is muXobilN↓ [without p]. (TA.) One says, hiIa fiI UiXobaAlihaA kaAll-abuwapi EalaI OaXobaAlihaA ‡ [She is, in her constant application of herself to the care of her children,, &c., like the lioness over her whelps]. (TA.)
And AXbl Ealayohi ‡ He inclined to him; affected him; or was, or became, favourably inclined towards him: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) and he aided, helped, or assisted, him. (Ḳ, TA.)

[7. AnXbl is expl. by Golius as signifying “Leviter e loco exivit, effluxit;” as on the authority of the KL; but I do not find it in my copy of that work; and think that it is some other word to which this meaning is there assigned.]

XibolN The whelp, or young one, of the lion: (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb:) or the young one of the lion when it has attained to the seeking, or taking, of prey: (Ḳ, TA:) [and Freytag says, on the authority of Meyd, of any wild beast:] pl. OaXobaAlN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OaXobulN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) [both properly pls. of pauc.] and [pl. of mult.] XubuwlN and XibaAlN. (Ḳ.)

XaAbilN A lion whose canine teeth have become such as lock together, dissimilar; expl. by the words Aal-aciI QXotabakato OanoyaAbuhu. (Ḳ. [Perhaps, in this sense, a mistranscription for XaAbikN, q. v.])
And (Ḳ) † A boy, or young man, full [or plump] in body, by reason of ease and plenty and of youthfulness: (IAạr, O, Ḳ:*) and so XaAbinN, and HiDajorN. (IAạr, O.)
[XaAbilapN, expl. by Golius as signifying “Diminuta lacte camela, pulli septimestris mater,” as on the authority of the KL, is a mistake for XaAYilapN.]
[OaXobalu, expl. by Golius as signifying “Magno veretri præputio camelus,” as on the authority of the KL, is a mistake for Oavoyalu.]
muXobilN A lioness whose whelps, or young ones, accompany her, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) going with her. (Ṣ, O.) And A she-camel whose young one has become strong, and goes with her. (AZ, Ṣ, O.)
See also 4.
maXobuwlN A place in which are lions' whelps or young ones. (Ḥam p. 416.)

hom.sense: 1. Xabima, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXobamu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XabamN, (TA,) It was, or became, cold; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) said of water. (Ṣ.)
Xabama AljadoIa, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXobumu}, inf. n. XabomN, (TḲ,) He put the XibaAm [q. v.] in the mouth of the kid; as also Xb-mhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taXobiymN. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see what next precedes {1}.
XabamN Cold, or coldness; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) accord. to the M, of water: (TA:) but one says gadaApN caAtu XabamK [A morning having coldness]: (Ṣ:) and yawomN cuw XabamK A day having coldness. (Mṣb.)

Jureybeh Ibn-El-Ashyam El-Fak'asee says,
waqado Xab-ahuwA AlEiyra OaforaAsanaA
faqado wajaduwA mayorahaA caA Xabamo
[And they likened our horses to the camels carrying provision of corn; but they found their provision to be something having coldness]; meaning, accord. to Aboo-Riyásh, that they found death; for death is cold; and poison also is cold: but there is another reading, accord. to which the last word is baXamo, meaning “heaviness,” such as results from food. (Ḥam p. 363.) See also the next paragraph.

hom.sense: XabimN Cold, as an epithet, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) applied to water, (Ṣ, TA,) and to rain; and one says gadaApN XabimapN, meaning A cold morning. (TA.) [And] Feeling cold: (Ḳ:) or feeling cold together with hunger. (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also A weapon, or weapons; as being cold: and such has been said to be the meaning [of caA Xabamo↓] in the verse cited above. (TA.)
And Death; because of its coldness:
and Poison; for the same reason. (Ḳ. [But see the verse cited above, and the explanation of it.])
And baqarapN XabimapN A fat ox or cow, or beast of the bovine kind: (Ḳ, TA:) but the epithet commonly known is sanimapN, [meaning “having a large hump,”] with s and n. (TA.)

entry.sense: Xibam-N: see XibaAmN.
XabaAmN A certain plant, (AḤn, Ḳ,) resembling in colour the Hin-aMC [q. v.]. (AḤn, TA.)

XibaAmN A piece of wood which is put crosswise in the mouth of a kid, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or, as in the M, in the two sides of the mouth of a kid or lamb, and tied behind its head, (TA,) in order that it may not suck its mother; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Xibma↓: (Ḳ:) and so HiXaAkN. (IDrd and Ṣ in art. HXk.)

Also, (Ḳ,) or the dual, XibaAmaAni, (Ṣ, TA,) Two threads, or strings, attached to the [kind of face-veil called] buroquE, by which the woman [draws and] binds [the two upper corners of] it to the back of her head: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [also called vibaAtN:] pl. XubumN. (O in art. snbk.)

muXab-amN: see the following paragraph. Applied to a lion, it means Having his mouth tied, or bound; from XibaAmN in the former of the senses expl. above: (Meyd, TA:) thus in the following prov.:
taforaqu mino Sati AlguraA
bi wataforisu AlOasada AlmuXab-amo
[She is frightened at the cry of the crow, or raven, and breaks the neck of the lion whose mouth is tied]: (Meyd, Ḳ, TA:) or, accord. to another relation, AlmuXat-am, [meaning “the grimfaced,”] from XataAmapu Alwajohi: (Meyd:) a saying originating from the fact of a woman's breaking the neck of a lion, and then hearing the cry of a crow, or raven, and being frightened: applied to him who advances boldly to undertake that which is of high account, [or attended with peril,] and fears that which is contemptible. (Meyd, Ḳ.)
maXobuwmN [and muXab-amN↓] A kid, or lamb, having the piece of wood called XibaAm put into its mouth and tied behind its head, in order that it may not suck its mother. (TA.)

2. Xab-ahahu Uiy-aAhu and bihi, (MA, Ḳ,) inf. n. taXobiyhN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, KL,) He made it to be like it, or to resemble it; he assimilated it to it; (MA, KL;) i. q. mav-alahu [meaning thus: and also meaning he likened it to it, or compared it with it; agreeably with the explanation here next following]: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) Xab-ahatu AlX-aIoCa biAlX-aIoCi I put the thing in the place, or predicament, of the [other] thing, by reason of an attribute connecting them [or common to them]; which attribute may be real and ideal; real as when one says, “this dirhem is like this dirhem,” and “this blackness is like this blackness;” and ideal as when one says, “Zeyd is like the lion” or “like the ass” i. e. in his strength or his stupidity, and “Zeyd is like ʼAmr” i. e. in his power and his generosity and similar qualities; and sometimes it is tropical, as when one says, “the absent is like the non-existent,” and “the garment is like the dirhem” i. e. the value of the garment is equivalent to the dirhem. (Mṣb.) Xab-ahu, [app. for Xb-h XayoYFA biXaIoCK,] accord. to IAạr, means He made a thing equal to a thing, or like a thing. (TA.)

[Hence,] Xb-hhu Ealayohi, inf. n. as above, He rendered it confused to him [by making it to appear like some other thing]; (JK,* TA;) he rendered it ambiguous, dubious, or obscure, to him. (MA.) See also 8, [with which it is, in its pass. form, and in its act. form likewise, nearly or exactly syn. in one of the senses,] in two places.

[And Xab-ahatohu Uilayohi Aln-afosu, or AlHaAlu, The mind, or the case, imaged it to him; like xay-alatohu: see art. xyl.] See also 5, [with which, in its pass. form, this verb is nearly or exactly syn. in one sense.]
[taXobiyhN used as a simple subst. means A comparison, simile, similitude, or parable: and has for its pl. taXobiyhaAtN. Hence, EalaI Alt-aXobiyhi By way of comparison.]
3: see the next paragraph {4}, in four places.

hom.sense:
4. AXbhhu, [inf. n. UiXobaAhN;] and XAbhhu↓, [inf. n. muXaAbahapN;] (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He was, or became, like him; he resembled him; syn. maAvalahu. (Ḳ.) One says OaXobaha Alwaladu OabaAhu, and XAbhhu↓, The child [resembled his father, or] shared with his father in some one of his qualities, or attributes. (Mṣb.) And mano OaXobaha OabaAhu famaA Zalama, (Meyd, TA,) or mano yuXaAbihu↓ Obahu famaA Zalama, as some relate it, (TA,) [Whoso resembles his father, he has not done that which is wrong:] a prov., meaning, he has not put the likeness in the wrong place; for there is not any one more fit, or proper, for him to resemble than he: or it may mean that the father has not done that which is wrong. (Meyd. [See also Ḥar pp. 667-8.])
And AXbh Alr-ajulu Oum-ahu, (IAạr, Ḳ,) and XaAbahahaA↓, (Ḳ,) [The man resembled his mother,] meaning † the man became impotent, and weak. (IAạr, Ḳ.) And it is said in a trad. of ʼOmar, Uin-a All-abana yuXobahu Ealayohi [Verily one becomes like by feeding upon milk]: i. e. the infant that is suckled often becomes like the woman who suckles it, because of the milk: (JK:) or Allbn yXbh [app. for All-abanu yuXobahu Ealayohi]: i. e. one acquires a likeness to the natural dispositions of the woman who suckles [him]: or, as it is also related, ytXb-h↓ [app. for yutaXab-ahu Ealayohi]. (TA.)

[AXbh is also a verb of wonder: hence the saying,
maA OaXobaha All-ayolapa biAlbaAriHaho
How like is this night to yesternight! expl. in art. brH.]

entry.sense: 5. tXb-h bihi [He became assimilated to him, or it: and he assumed, or affected, a likeness, or resemblance, to him, or it; he imitated him, or it;] he made himself to be like, or to resemble, him, or it; (MA, KL;*) i. q. tmv-l: (Ṣ,* TA: [in the former, this meaning is indicated, but not expressed:]) said of a man. (Ṣ.) See also 4, last sentence but one.

[Hence,] tXb-h lahu Oan-ahu kacaA It became imaged to him [in the mind, i. e. it seemed to him,] that it was so; syn. taxay-ala, (Ṣ and Ḳ * in art. xyl,) and taxaAyala: (Ṣ in that art.:) and Xub-iha↓ Uilayohi Oan-ahu kacaA [signifies the same; or] it was imaged to him [in the mind] that it was so; syn. xuy-ila. (PṢ in that art.)

6. taXaAbuhN signifies The being equal, or uniform; syn. AisotiwaMCN: (TA:) [or rather the being consimilar.] You say, taXaAbahaA They were like, or they resembled, each other. (MA.) And AlxuTuwTu tataXaAbahu The lines are like one another; the lines resemble one another. (Mgh.)
See also the next paragraph {8}, in two places.

8. AiXotabahaA and taXaAbahaA↓ They resembled each other so that they became confounded, or confused, or dubious. (Ḳ.) And AXtbh (Ṣ, MA) and tXAbh↓ (MA) It (a thing, Ṣ, MA, or an affair, MA) was, or became, ambiguous, dubious, or obscure, (MA,) EalaI-a [to me], (Ṣ,) or Ealayohi [to him]: (MA:) and Xub-iha↓ Ealayohi AlOamoru the thing, or affair, was rendered confused, or dubious, to him: (Ḳ,* TA:) and XabahN↓ AlX-aIoCu, also, [see muXotabihN,] the thing was, or became, confused, or dubious. (IAạr, TA.)

XibohN and XabahN↓ are syn., (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like mivolN and mavalN, and bidolN and badalN, and nikolN and nakalN, the only other instances of the kind, i. e. of words of both these measures, that have been heard, having the same meaning, (Ṣ and TA in art. bdl,) i. q. XabiyhN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) syn. mivolN, (Ḳ,) [i. e.] A like; a similar person or thing; (MA; Mṣb;) [an analogue; a match;] a fellow: (MA:) pl. (of all, TA) OaXobaAhN. (Ḳ, TA.) One says, hecaA Xibohuhu [and Xabahuhu↓], i. e. Xabiyhuhu↓ [meaning This is the like,, &c., of him, or it]. (Ṣ.) And fulaAnN Xibohuka and Xabahuka↓ and Xabiyhuka↓ [Such a one is the like,, &c., of thee]. (JK.) [And bihi↓ This is like him, or it. And hence, in lexicology, AlOaXobaAhu waAln-aZaAYiru The words that are alike in form: generally applied to rare instances.]
See also the next paragraph, in two places.

hom.sense: XabahN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

[Hence,] syn. with XakolN [signifying A likeness, resemblance, or semblance, as meaning something resembling]; (AA, Ḳ and TA in art. Xkl;) and XubohapN↓ is syn. with mivolN [in the same sense]: (Ḳ in the present art.: [see exs. of the latter voce EuqorN:]) pl. of the former [in this sense, as is indicated in the Ṣ,] maXaAbihu↓, contr. to rule, like maHaAsinu and macaAkiyru; (Ṣ, TA;) or this is a pl. having no proper sing. (TA.) One says, bayonahumaA XabahN [Between them two is a likeness,, &c.]. (Ṣ,) And nazaEa UilaI Oabiyhi fiI AlX-abahi [He inclined to his father in likeness]. (Ṣ, in art. nzE.) And a poet cited by IAạr says,
OaSobaHa fiyhi XabahN mino Oum-ihi
mino EiZami Alr-aOosi wamino xuroTum-ihi
[He became so that there was in him a resemblance of his mother, in respect of bigness of the head, and of his nose]. (TA.) And one says also, bihi XubohapN↓ lahu i. e. mivolN [In him is a likeness, or something having a likeness, to him, or it]. (TḲ.)

Also, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) and XibohN↓, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and XabahaAnN↓, (Ḳ, TA, but not in the CK,) [A sort of fine brass;] a metal resembling gold in its colour, the highest in quality of Sufor [or brass]; (Mṣb;) yellow nuHaAs; (Ḳ;) a sort of nuHaAs (JK, T, Ṣ, M *) rendered yellow by the addition of an alloy (lit. a medicament): (T, M,* TA:) so called because resembling gold in its colour: (M, TA:) pl. OaXobaAhu. (Ḳ.) One says kuwzu XabahK and XibohK↓ [A mug of Xbh]. (Ṣ.)
See also XabahaAnN.

entry.sense: XubohapN: see XabahN, in two places.

[Hence,] Confusedness, or dubiousness: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. XubahN (TA) [and XubohaAtN and XubahaAtN and XubuhaAtN: whence the phrase OaSoHaAbu AlX-ubuhaAti Those persons who are of dubious characters; those who are objects of suspicion]. One says, layosa fiyhi XubohapN [There is not any confusedness, or dubiousness, in respect of it]: referring to property. (Mṣb voce XaAYibapN, in art. Xwb.)

hom.sense: XabahaAnN and XabahN↓, (Ḳ accord. to the TA,) the latter on the authority of IB, (TA, [and mentioned also in the M voce sayaAlN on the authority of AA,]) A certain thorny plant, (Ḳ accord. to the TA,) resembling the samur [or gum-acacia-tree], (TA,) having an elegant red blossom, and grains like the XahodaAnaj [or hemp-seed], an antidote for the bite, or sting, of venomous reptiles, beneficial for the cough, lithotriptic, and binding to the bowels. (Ḳ accord. to the TA: but see what here follows.) And XubuhaAnN↓, (Ḳ accord. to the TA,) or XabahaAnN, (so in a copy of the Ṣ,) or both, (so in copies of the Ḳ,) or XabuhaAnN↓, or XubahaAnN↓, (so in different copies of the Ṣ, [the latter of these two I find in one copy only,]) A kind of trees, of the [kind called] EiDAah: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the vumaAm [i. e. panic grass]: (Ḳ, TA, but not in the CK:) or the nam-aAm [now commonly applied to wild thyme, thymus serpyllum], (Ṣ, Ḳ), one of the sweetsmelling plants, (Ṣ,) having an elegant red flower,, &c., as in the next preceding sentence. (So in copies of the Ḳ. [See XahabaAnN.])
See also XabahN.

entry.sense: XabuhaAnN, or XubuhaAnN, or XubahaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XabaAhN (Lth, JK, Ḳ) and XubaAhN (CK [but not in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ nor in the TA]) A certain grain, like that called Hurof (Lth, JK, Ḳ) in colour, [see HurofN and raXaAdN,] which is taken, i. e. swallowed, as a medicine. (Lth, JK.)
XabiyhN: see XibohN, in four places.

OaXobahu [More, and most, like]. OaXobahu mina Alt-amorapi biAlt-amorapi [More like than the date to the date] is a prov.: and so OaXobahu mina AlmaMCi biAlmaMCi [More like than water to water]. (Meyd.)
[And More, or most, suitable. One says, hecaA OaXobahu bika This is more suitable to thee. And hecaA AlOaXobahu This is the most suitable.]
muXab-ahN: [see its verb:]
[and] see muXotabihN.
Also, applied to the plant called naSiI-, Becoming yellow. (TA.)
muXab-ihN: [see its verb:]
[and] see maXotabihN.
maXaAbihu: see XabahN, of which it is said to be an anomalous pl.

muXotabihN [part. n. of 8, q. v.]. muXotabihaAtN, (Ṣ,) and muXab-ihaAtN↓, [thus agreeably with an explanation of its verb by IAạr, (see 8, last sentence,)] (JK,) or OumuwrN muXotabihapN, and muXab-ahapN↓ like muEaZ-amapN, (Ḳ,) Things, or affairs, that are confused or dubious [by reason of their resembling one another or from any other cause]: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) [and uncertain: (see an ex. of muXab-ah in this sense in a verse cited voce sanafa:)] muXotabihFA wagayora mutaXaAbihK↓, in the Ḳur [vi. 99], means resembling one another so that they become confounded, or confused, or dubious, and not resembling one another, &c. (TA.)
mutaXaAbihN Consimilar, or conformable, in its several parts: thus mutaXaAbihFA means in the Ḳur xxxix. 24. (Jel.) And mutaXaAbihaAtN Things like, or resembling, one another. (JK, Ṣ.)
See also muXotabihN.

mutaXaAbihaAtN in the Ḳur iii. 5 means Verses that are equivocal, or ambiguous; i. e. susceptible of different interpretations: (Ksh:) or verses unintelligible; such as the commencements [of many] of the chapters: (Jel:) or the mutaXaAbih in the Ḳur is that of which the meaning is not to be learned from its words; and this is of two sorts; one is that of which the meaning is known by referring it to what is termed muHokam [q. v.]; and the other is that of which the knowledge of its real meaning is not attainable in any way: (TA:) or it means what is not understood without repeated con-
sideration: (TA in art. fsr:) Eḍ-Ḍaḥḥák is related to have explained AlmuHokamaAtu as meaning “what have not been abrogated;” and AlmutaXaAbihaAtu as meaning what have been abrogated. (TA in the present art.)

hom.sense: 1. XabaA, (Ḳ,) [aor. _u {yaXobuwu},] inf. n. XabowN, (TA,) It was or became, high, elevated, or lofty. (Ḳ. [See also 4, first sentence.])

Xabati Alfarasu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) The mare stood upon her hind legs. (Ḳ.) [It is added in the TA that the vulgar say Xb-t: but see art. Xb, where a similar meaning is assigned to Xab-a said of a horse.]
XabaA wajohuhu His face shone after having become altered. (Ḳ.)
XabaA Aln-aAra, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He kindled the fire; or made it to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame; (Ḳ;) as also Xab-ahaA. (TA.)

4. OaXobati AlX-ajarapu, (Ṣ,) or AXbI AlX-ajaru, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UiXobaMCN, (TA,) The tree, (Ṣ,) or the trees, (Ḳ,) became tall, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and tangled and dense, by reason of luxuriance (Ḳ, TA) and sappiness. (TA.)

AXbI said of a man, He begat a boy [sharp] like the point of iron (kaXabaA AlHadiydi): (Yz, TA:) or he had a son born to him sharp in intellect: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or he begat generous, or noble, children, by whom he had sharp means of attack and defence, like the points of spear-heads. (Ḥam p. 384.)
OaXobayotu Alr-ajula i. q. wajadotu lahuXabaApF↓ [app. meaning I found the man to have sharpness]. (Ḥam p. 385.)
And AXbAhu He exalted him, syn. rafaEahu, (Ṣ,) and honoured him; namely, a man. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And He cast him into a well, or into an evil, or a hateful, plight: thus having two contr. meanings. (Ḳ.)

AXbI is also syn. with dafaEa [He impelled, pushed, thrust,, &c.]. (Ḳ. [But perhaps this is a mistake for rafaEa, a syn. of AXbI mentioned before: if not, it may be from XabaApF signifying the “point” of anything.])
And i. q. OaEoTaI [He gave]. (Ḳ. [In this sense, accord. to the TḲ, trans. without a prep.; which I think doubtful.])

And i. q. OaXobala, (Ḳ,) meaning OaXofaqa [i. e. He was, or became, favourably inclined;, &c.]. (TA. [In this sense, also, both AXbI and AXbl, accord. to the TḲ, are trans. without a prep.; but this I think a mistake with respect to both of these verbs, the latter of which is well known to be trans. only by means of EalaI.])
[And i. q. OaXobaha.] One says, AXbI fulaAnFA waladuhu, (Ṣ,) or AXbI zayodFA OawolaAduhu, (Ḳ,) His children resembled such a one, or, Zeyd; syn. OaXobahuwhu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
XabFA: see XabaApN, in two places.
Also The green substance that overspreads stagnant water; syn. TuHolubN. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: XubowN [written in my original Xubw] i. q. AcI [i. e., app., OacFI, A state of annoyance or molestation: or annoyance, molestation, harm, or hurt: or a thing that annoys,, &c.]. (TA.)
XabaApN The point (Ṣ, Ḳ) of the extremity (Ṣ) of anything: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. XabFA↓ [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.] and [the pl. properly so termed is] XabawaAtN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
And The sting of the scorpion; (Ḳ;) [and] so XabFA↓ [mentioned above as having a pl. meaning]. (Sh, TA in art. Xwl; and Ḥam p. 385.)
And The portion with which one cuts, of a sword. (Ḥar p. 17.)
And The two sides of the Oasalap [i. e. toe, or tapering head or foremost part,] of a sandal: pl. as above [app. in all of the senses of the sing.]. (Ḳ.)
[And app. † Sharpness, as a quality of a man:] see 4.
Also The scorpion: (Fr, TA:) or the scorpion when just born: or a yellow scorpion: (Ḳ:) so in the M. (TA.) [See also the next paragraph.]
And A mare raising her head (EaATiyapN) in the bridle. (Ḳ.) And [A mare] standing upon her hind legs. (Ḳ.)

Xabowapu The scorpion; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA; [in the CK, Xabowapu AlEaqorabi is erroneously put for Xabowapu AlEaqorabu;]) a proper name thereof; it may be from AlX-abaA signifying its sting; (Ḥam p. 385;) determinate; (TA;) imperfectly decl.: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, TA:) it is said in the Ḳ, “and [the article] Al is prefixed to it;” but this is a mistake: it should be, “and Al is not prefixed to it: (TA:) [but, although a proper name, it has a pl.;] the pl. is XabawaAtN. (Ṣ.) [See also XabaApN, which signifies “a scorpion,” and of which XabawaAtN is a pl.]
jaAriyapN XabowapN A girl, or young woman, that is bold, much in motion, foul in speech or actions. (TA.)

hom.sense: muXobFI [pass. part. n. of 4,] Honoured [&c.]. (TA.)
See also what next follows.

entry.sense: muXobK [act. part. n. of 4,] A man having a son born to him sharp in intellect; (Th, Ḳ, TA;) and so muXobFI↓, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, maXobiI-N,]) accord. to IAạr, but disallowed by Th. (TA.) And the former, accord. to IAạr, A man who begets generous offspring. (TA.)
And muXobiyapN A woman affectionate, kind, or favourably inclined, to her children. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Xat-a, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaXotitu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. Xat-N (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ *) and XataAtN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,*) or the latter is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and XatyitN (Ḳ, by implication,) and XutuwtN; (MA;) and AnXt-↓, (Ḳ,) and AstXt-↓, and tXt-t↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ; [but the last, app., has an intensive signification;]) It (the state of affairs, Ṣ, or the state of union of a people or party, A, TA) became dissolved, broken up, discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled; syn. tafar-aqa, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) or Ainofaraqa; (CK;) and of the third and fourth verbs, [or rather of all,] AinotaXara. (TA.) And tXt-twA↓ They became separated, disunited, dispersed, or scattered. (A.)
See also 2, in two places.

entry.sense: 2. Xt-t, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taXotiytN; (Ṣ;) and AXt-↓; and Xat-a↓,, aor. _i {yaXotitu}, [which is anomalous in the case of a trans. verb of this class,] inf. n. Xat-N and XataAtN and XatiytN; (Ḳ;) [the first and second mentioned in the Ḳ only with reference to God as the agent;] He dissolved, broke up, discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled, syn. far-aqa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the state of affairs [&c.], (Ṣ,) and the state of union of a people or party. (TA.) And one says also, AXt-↓ biI qawomiI My people, or party, dissolved, broke up,, &c., my state of affairs. (Ṣ, TA.) And Xat-a↓ biqalobiI kacaA wakacaA Such and such things discomposed, or disorganized, (far-aqa, [which may also be rendered frightened,]) my mind, or heart. (Aṣ, TA.) And Xat-atahumu Qll-ehu God separated, disunited, dispersed, or scattered, them. (A.)

hom.sense: 4: see 2, in two places.
[OaXat-a Ealayoka It (a thing) was, or became, distinct, or clear, to thee. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in two places.
7: see 1.

hom.sense: Xat-N an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

And signifying Separation, disunion, or dispersion: so in the saying, AlHamodu lil-ehi Al-aciI jamaEanaA mino Xat-K [Praise be to God who has brought us together from a state of separation, disunion, or dispersion]: (TA:) a saying mentioned by AA, as heard by him from an Arab of the desert: (Ṣ, TA:) and XataAtN↓ is [similar in meaning, being] likewise an inf. n. of 1; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) or it is a subst. from the intrans. verb Xat-a, (Mṣb,) and signifies a state of separation or disunion; as in the saying, OaxaAfu Ealayokumu AlX-ataAta [I fear for you separation, or disunion]. (TA.)

Also i. q. mutafar-iqN [meaning Dissolved, broken up, discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled; and separated, disunited, dispersed, or scattered]; as also XatiytN↓, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) [and XataAtN↓, as will be shown in what follows;] or XatiytN↓ is syn. with mufar-aqN, [which is virtually the same as mutafar-iqN,] and muXat-atN: (Ḳ:) the pl. of Xat-N is OaXotaAtN (Ṣ) [and XutuwtN also, as will be shown by an ex. in what follows]: and Xat-aI↓ is pl. of XatiytN↓, like as maroDaI is of mariyDN; (Jel in xx. 55, and MF;) or, accord. to some, it is a sing. noun. (MF.) One says OamorN Xat-N i. e. mutafar-iqN [A state of affairs dissolved, broken up,, &c.]; (Ṣ;) and [so] OamorN XataAtN↓, the latter word being an inf. n. used as an epithet. (Ḥam p. 176.) And SaAra jamoEuhumo XatiytFA↓ i. e. mutafar-iqFA [Their company, or congregated body, became separated, disunited, dispersed, or scattered]. (A.) And jaAWuwA OaXotaAtFA They came separated, disunited, dispersed, or scattered; syn. mutafar-iqiyna: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and so jAWwA XataAta XataAta↓, (Ḳ,) in one copy of the Ḳ XataAta waXataAta; and MF allows XutaAta↓, like vulaAva and rubaAEa; but there is no apparent reason for the repetition; and accord. to the L, the phrase as transmitted from the authorities worthy of confidence is jaMCa Alqawomu XataAtFA↓ and XataAta i. e. The people, or party, came separated,, &c. (TA.) And qawomN Xat-aI↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) A people, or party, separated,, &c.; syn. mutafar-iquwna: (Mṣb, TA:) or consisting of sundry, or distinct, bodies; not of one tribe. (Ḳ.)
And Uin-a Almajolisa layajomaEu XutuwtFA mina Aln-aAsi, (Ṣ, TA,) and Xat-aI↓ mina Aln-aAsi, Verily the assembly comprises sundry, or distinct, bodies of men; (TA;) or men not of one tribe. (Ṣ TA.) And OaXoyaMCu Xat-aI↓ [Things of sundry, or different, or distinct, kinds or sorts]. (Ṣ.) OazowaAjFA mino nabaAtK Xat-aI↓, in the Ḳur xx. 55, means Sorts, of plants, various, or different, in colours, tastes, &c. (Jel.) Oum-ahaAtuhumo Xat-aI↓ see expl. voce Oum-N. And Xat-aI↓ taWuwbu AlHalabaho, a prov., see expl. voce HaAlibN.

entry.sense: XataAtN and XataAta and XataAtFA: see Xat-N, in five places.
XutaAta: see Xat-N.

XatiytN: see Xat-N, in four places. vagorN XatiytN means [Fore teeth] separate, or wide-apart, one from another. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) Tarafeh says,
mino XatiytK kaOaqaAHi Alr-amoli guro
[meaning From separate fore teeth like white chamomiles of the sands: vagorK being understood, and guro being for gur-K]. (TA.)
Xat-aI: see Xat-N, in seven places:
and see also the last sentence of the following paragraph.

Xat-aAna bayonuhumaA, (Ḳ, TA, but omitted in the CK,) with damm to the n of byn, (TA,) [Different, or distinct, are they two: or widely different or distinct are they two: or how very, or widely, different or distinct, are they two! lit., the union of them two is severed: or the interval between them two is far-extending, or wide: or how greatly is the union of them two severed! as will be shown below.] AZ quotes, in his “Nawádir,” with byn in the nom. case, the following verse:
Xat-aAna bayonuhumaA fiI kul-i manozilapK
hecaA yaxaAfu wahecaA yarotajiI OabadaA
[Different, or widely different,, &c., are they two in every predicament: this fears, and this hopes, ever]. (TA.) The mansoob form, however, is also employed (Ḳ, TA, but omitted in the CK) by some of the Arabs in the above-mentioned phrase, so that one says, Xat-aAna bayonahumaA, maA being understood, as though one said, Xat-a Al-aciI bayonahumaA [meaning, as above explained, Different, or widely different,, &c., are they two: lit., separated, or disunited, or severed, is that which is between them two: or far-extending, or wide, is the interval between them two: or how greatly separated, or severed, is the union between them two!]: Hassán Ibn-Thábit says,
waXat-aAna bayonakumaA fiI Aln-adaI
wafiI AlbaOosi waAlxubori waAlmanoZari
[And different, or widely different,, &c., are ye two in munificence and in valour and internal state and external appearance]. (TA.) In like manner also, [but with mA,] one says, Xat-aAna maA bayonahumaA, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) accord. to Th. (TA.) This [as also, consequently, the same phrase without mA] is disallowed by Aṣ and IḲt: IB, however, says that this phrase occurs in the verses of chaste Arabs: for instance, Abu-l-Aswad Ed-Duälee says,
waXat-aAna maA bayoniI wabayonaka Uin-aniI
EalaI kul-i HaAlK Oasotaqiymu wataZolaEu
[And different, or widely different,, &c., are I and thou: for I, in every case, go erect, and thou haltest]: and similar is the saying of El-Ba'eeth,
waXat-aAna maA bayoniI wabayona Qboni xaAlidK
Oumay-apa fiI Alr-izoqi Al-aciI yataqas-amu
[And different, or widely different,, &c., are I and Ibn-Khálid Umeiyeh, with respect to the supplies for the wants of life that are divided among mankind]. (TA.) One says also, Xat-aAna maA humaA; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and Xat-aAna maA EamorNw waOaxuwhu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) Different, or distinct, or widely different,, &c., are they two; and ʼAmr and his brother: [lit., separate, or distinct, are they two;, &c.: or remote are they two, one from the other;, &c.:] or how greatly, or widely, are they two separated;, &c.! (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) here mA is redundant; and in the former phrase, hmA is the agent of Xt-An; as is the former of the two nouns, to which the latter noun is conjoined, in the latter phrase. (TA.) El-Aạshà says,
Xat-aAna maA yawomiI EalaI kuwrihaA
wayawomu Hay-aAna OaxiIjaAbiri
[Different, or widely different,, &c., are (or were) my day upon her (the camel's) saddle, and the day of Ḥeiyán the brother of Jábir: in which, for yawomiI and yawomu, some read nawomiI and nawomu]. (Ṣ, TA.) And in like manner, [but without mA,] one says, Xat-aAna Oaxuwhu waOabuwhu [Different, or widely different,, &c., are his brother and his father]. (TA.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce daAYimN, in art. dwm.]

Xat-aAna, is a preterite verbal noun, signifying Aifotaraqa, [and so expl. above,] accord. to many authorities, [including most of the grammarians,] and therefore they have made it a condition that its agent must be what denotes more than one: [for AXtrTwA fI fElh Altrd-d, I read AXtrTwA fI fAElhu AltEd-d, which agrees with what is afterwards said in the TA and here; though the former phrase may be so rendered as to convey essentially the same meaning: but this condition is not necessary if we render Xt-An by baEuda:] (TA:) or it signifies tabaAEada and Aifotaraqa; (Ibn-Umm-Kásim;) or baEuda; [and so expl. above;] (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and is inflected from Xatuta; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [which is a verb not used; in the CK, incorrectly, Xatata;] the fet-ḥah of the n being the fet-ḥah originally pertaining to the [final] t [of the verb]; and this fet-ḥah shows the word to be inflected from the preterite verb, like as saroEaAna is from saruEa, and waXokaAna from waXuka: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to Er-Raḍee, it implies wonder, [like several verbs of the measure faEula, as shown in remarks on hayuWa, &c.,] and means how greatly separated, disunited, or severed,, &c.! (TA:) or, accord. to El-Marzookee and Hr and Zj and some others, it is an inf. n.: El-Marzookee says, in his Expos. of the Fṣ, that it is an inf. n. of a verb not used, [namely Xatuta,] and is indecl., with fet-ḥah for its termination, because it is put in the place of a pret. verb, being equivalent to Xat-a, [for Xatuta,] i. e., taXat-ata Oawo tafar-aqa jid-FA [as expl. above]: and Zj says that it is an inf. n. occupying the place of a verb, of the measure faEolaAn, and therefore indecl., because differing thus from others of its class: Aboo-ʼOthmán El-Mázinee says that Xat-aAn and suboHaAn may receive tenween, whether they be substs, or occupying the place of substs.: upon which AAF observes that if Xt-An be in its proper place, it is a verbal noun, meaning Xat-a: if with tenween, it is indeterminate; if without tenween, determinate; and if translated from its office of a verbal noun, and made a subst. answering to Alt-aXotiytu, and determinate, it is similar to sbHAn in the phrase suboHaAna mino Ealoqamapa AlfaAxiri, which is a subst. answering to Alt-anoziyhu. (TA.) The n in Xat-aAn (sometimes, TA) receives kesreh; (Ḳ;) though this is contr. to what is said by AZ and by IDrst: its being sometimes with kesreh is mentioned by Th, on the authority of Fr: and Er-Raḍee seems to infer that its being so was an opinion of Aṣ; and gives two reasons for his disallowal of the expression Xt-An mA byn; first, because Xt-An occurs with kesr to the n; and second, because its agent cannot be otherwise than what denotes more than one: [but see what has been observed above on this point:] IAmb says that one must not say Xat-aAni maA bayona Oaxiyka waOabiyka, because, in this case, Xt-An [virtually] governs only one noun in the nom. case: but that one may say, Xat-aAni Oaxuwka waOabuwka, and Xat-aAni maA Oaxuwka waOabuwka, using Xat-aAni as the dual of Xat-N; though correctly Xt-An is a verbal noun: MF, however, observes that the Expositors of the Fṣ seem to say that Fr makes Xat-aAni to be the dual of Xat-N; but that he only mentions it as a dial. var. of Xat-aAna: the following is adduced as an ex.
laXat-aAna maA OanowiI wayanowiI banuw OabiI
[Different, or widely different,, &c., are that which I intend and that which the sons of my father intend]: in which Xt-An is read with both fet-ḥah and kesreh: and it is said in the O that Xat-aAni is a dial. var. of Xat-aAna. (TA.)

IJ mentions Xat-aI↓ as an accidental syn. of Xt-An; and says that it is not the fem. of the latter: therefore the assertion of some, that it is used by poetical license in the following verse of Jemeel requires consideration:
Ouriydu SilaAHahaA waturiydu qatoliI
waXat-aI bayona qatoliI waAlS-ilaAHi
[I desire to make peace with her, but she desires to slay me: and different, or widely different,, &c., are slaying me and making peace]. (TA.)

hom.sense:
1. Xatira, aor. _a {yaXotaru}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. XatarN; (T, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.;) and Xutira; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He (a man) had an inversion in the eyelid; (T, Ṣ;)
seldom natural: (T:) or an inversion of, (A,) or in, (Mṣb,) the lower eyelid: (A, Mgh, Mṣb:) or an inversion of the eyelid above and below, (M, Ḳ,) or above or below, (Mgh,) and a contraction thereof: (M:) or a cracking thereof, (Ḳ,) so that the edge [for AlxitaAr, in the TA, I read AlHitaAr,] became separate: (Mgh, TA:) or a flaccidity of its lower part. (Ḳ.)

And Xatirati AlEayonu, and Xutirat, (Ḳ,) and AnXtrt↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) The eye had an inversion in the lid: (Ṣ:) [or in, or of, the lower lid:] or an inversion of the lid above and below, (Ḳ,) and a contraction thereof: (TA:) or a cracking thereof, (Ḳ,) so that the edge became separate: (TA:) or a flaccidity of its lower part. (Ḳ.)
And Xatira, (TḲ,) inf. n. XatarN, (Ḳ,) He (a man) had his lower lip cracked. (Ḳ,* TA.)
Xatarahu, and AXtrhu↓, (Ṣ,) or the latter but not the former, (Sh, TA,) He caused him to have an inversion in the eyelid. (Ṣ.)

And Xatara AlEayona, (Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaXotiru}, inf. n. XatorN; (TA;) and AXtrhA↓; and Xt-rhA↓; (Ḳ;) He caused the eye to have an inversion of the lid above and below, (Ḳ,) and a contraction thereof: (TA:) or a cracking thereof, (Ḳ,) so that the edge became separate: (TA:) or a flaccidity of its lower part. (Ḳ.)
XatorN also signifies The cutting off of the lower eyelid: for which a quarter of the whole price of blood must be paid. (TA.)

Xatira bihi He reviled him; (Ḳ;) found fault with him; blamed him; or censured him; in verse or in prose: (TA:) and Xt-r↓ bihi, inf. n. taXotiyrN, he detracted from his reputation; found fault with him; blamed him; or censured him; (Ṣ, TA;) made him to hear what was bad, evil, abominable, or foul: (TA:) Sh says that it is Xn-r, and he disallows Xt-r↓: but IAạr and AA say Xt-r; and AM holds this to be correct. (TA.) [See also Xc-r bh.]

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in three places.
4: see 1, in two places.
7: see 1, second sentence.
OaXotaru A man having the affection of the eyelid described above, voce Xatira: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb:) or having the eyelid slit: (IAạr, TA in art. Xrm:) fem. XatoraMCu. (Mṣb.)
A man having his lower lip cracked: and XafapN XatoraMCu a cracked lip. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Xatamahu, (MA, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaXotimu} (Mṣb, Ḳ) and _u {yaXotumu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XatomN (Ṣ, MA, Mṣb, Ḳ) and maXotamapN and maXotumapN, (Ḳ, TA,) the last of these [written maXotimap in the CK] with damm to the t, or this and the next before it, though said to be inf. ns., may be simple substantives, as AʼObeyd inclines to think them, (TA,) He reviled him, vilified him, upbraided him, reproached him, defamed him, or gave a bad name to him; (Ṣ,* MA, Ḳ, TA;) syn. sab-ahu: (Ḳ, TA:) or, as some say, XatomN signifies [the addressing with] foul speech, without qacof [here meaning the casting an accusation, though commonly used and expl. as syn. with XatomN]: (TA:) and XAtmhu↓ signifies the same as Xatamahu, (MA, Mṣb,) being a rare instance of a verb of the measure faAEala denoting an act of a single agent when it has an unaugmented verb of the same radical letters [and the same signification], as SaAdamahu AlHimaAru meaning Sadamahu, and zaAHimahu meaning zaHamahu. (Mṣb.) Hence the saying, faUino Xutima faloyaEulo Uin-iI SaAYimN [And if he be reviled, let him say, Verily I am fasting], which may mean that he should say this with his tongue, which is the more proper meaning, or mentally: or faUino Xuwtima↓, which is allowable, though the former is the more proper. (Mṣb.)
XAtmhu faXatamahu: see 3.
Xatuma, aor. _u {yaXotumu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. XataAmapN (Ṣ, IB) and XatamN, (IB, TA,) † He (a man, Ṣ) was, or became, displeasing, or hateful, in countenance. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

[Xatima, trans. by means of b, expl. by Golius as meaning He rejoiced at evils, or misfortunes, of an enemy, is, I doubt not, a mistake for Xamita; though it might be supposed to be formed by transposition, like jabaca from jacaba.]

entry.sense: [2. Xt-m, accord. to Reiske, said of a camel when haltered, and of a lion, as mentioned by Freytag, signifies † He was harsh, and surly, in countenance, and uttered a grumbling sound: if used, it must be Xut-ima, agreeably with the part. n., expl. below.]

3. muXaAtamapN is syn. with musaAb-apN, (Ṣ,) signifying The reviling, vilifying, upbraiding, reproaching, defaming, or giving a bad name to, each other: (KL:) and [in like manner] taXaAtumN↓ is syn. with tasaAb-N, (Ṣ,) signifying as above [but used in relation to two persons and more than two]: (KL:) you say, XaAtamaA and taXaAtamaA↓ meaning tasaAb-aA [They reviled, vilified,, &c., each other]: (Ḳ:) and tXAtmwA↓ They reviled,, &c., one another; like tasaAb-uwA. (MA.) [XAtmhu may therefore be rendered He reviled him,, &c., being reviled,, &c., by him: but sometimes it is syn. with Xatamahu:] see 1, in two places.
One says also, XaAtamahu faXatamahu↓, aor. _u {yaXotumu}, meaning [He vied, or contended, with him in reviling, vilifying,, &c.,] and he overcame him [therein, i. e.] in reviling,, &c. (TA.)

[5. tXt-m is said by Freytag to signify He exposed himself to contumelies; on the authority of the Ḥam p. 310: but I there find only the part. n., mutaXat-imN, signifying as expl. below: so that the verb, if used, means he became exasperated by reviling, vilifying,, &c., and addressed, or applied, himself thereto.]
[He also explains it as signifying † He contracted the face very austerely; on the authority of the Deewán of the Hudhalees.]
6: see 3, in three places.
XitaAmN: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: XatiymN: see maXotuwmN.
Also, and XitaAmN↓, An obstruction (sud-ap) of the fauces, combined with foulness, or ugliness, of face. (TA.)

entry.sense: XatiymapN a subst., (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, and Ksh in lxxiv. 41, [by Bḍ, in explaining the same passage of the Ḳur, improperly said to be an inf. n.,]) from Xatamahu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) in the sense of XatomN [meaning The act of reviling, vilifying, or upbraiding; reproach, obloquy, or contumely]; (Ṣ,* and Ksh ubi suprà;) as also maXotamapN↓, and maXotumapN↓, or, as mentioned above, [see 1, first sentence,] these two are inf. ns. (TA.)
Xat-aAmN [One who reviles,, &c., much]. (Ḥam p. 310.)
Xat-aAmapN One who reviles,, &c., [very] much. (TA.)
See also XatiymN.
[XaAtimN act. part. n. of 1, Reviling,, &c.]
[It is also said by Golius, on the authority of the Mirḳát el-Loghah, to signify Rejoicing at another's evils, or misfortunes: but this I believe to be a mistake for XaAmitN: see 1, last sentence.]

AlAXtyAm, with kesr, [which seems to indicate that it is AlUiXotiyaAmu,] is expl. by IB as meaning rYys AlrkAb [app. raYiysu Alr-uk-aAbi The headman, or master, of the riders: but whence this is derived I know not, unless it be arabicized, from the Pers. OusotaA yaAm (if there be such an appellation), meaning “the master of the post-horse”]. (TA.)
maXotamapN and maXotumapN: see XatiymapN.

maXotuwmN Reviled, vilified, upbraided, reproached, defamed, or called by a bad name: and so with p {maXotuwmapN} applied to a female, as also XatiymN↓; (Ḳ, TA;) this last, without p, mentioned on the authority of Lḥ. (TA.)

mutaXat-imN Exasperated by reviling,, &c., and addressing, or applying, himself thereto. (Ḥam p. 310: there expl. by the words mtHkk bAlXtm wmEtrD lh [i. e. mutaHak-ikN biAlX-atomi wamuEotariDN lahu: see 5].)

hom.sense: 1. XataA AlX-itaMCu, aor. yaXotuw, inf. n. Xtw [app. Xutuw-N, The winter commenced: like as one says, rabaEa Alr-abiyEu, inf. n. rubuwEN]. (TA.)
And XataA Alyawomu, aor. as above, The day was, or became, intensely cold. (Mṣb.)

And XataA bihi, (Ḳ,) and Xatawotu bihi, (Ṣ,) and XatawonaA bihi, aor. as above, inf. n. XatowN, (Mṣb,) He, and I, and we, remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) during the XitaMC [or winter,, &c.], (Ṣ,) or during a XitaMC, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) in it, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) namely, a place, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or a country or town; (Ḳ;) as also Xt-I↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taXotiyapN; (TA;) and tXt-I↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) said by AZ to be from AlX-itaMCu, like taSay-afa from AlS-ayofu: (TA:) [and all are also app. trans. in this sense without a prep.:]
or, as some say, XataA AlS-ay-aAna means he remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the Sam-aAn [q. v., meaning a particular place and also a particular sort of place,] in the XitaMC; and taXat-aAhaA↓, he pastured [his cattle] therein in the XitaMC. (TA.)
And XataA Alqawomu, (Ḳ,) aor. as above, (TA,) The people, or party, experienced drought, or barrenness, or dearth, in the XitaMC; as also OaXotawoA↓. (Ḳ.)
See also 4.
XatiIa, like raDiIa [in measure], He was smitten by the XitaMC. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)

entry.sense: 2. Xt-I, inf. n. taXotiyapN: see 1.
One says also, hecaA AlX-aIoCu yuXat-iyniI This thing will suffice me for my XitaMC [or winter,, &c.]. (Ṣ.)

3. EaAmalahu muXaAtaApF (Ṣ, Ḳ) and XitaMCF (Ḳ) [He bargained with him for work by, or for, the season called XitaMC]; and in like manner, AisotaOojarahu [He hired him, or took him as a hireling]: (TA:) from AlX-itaMCu [i. e. the subst.]; (Ṣ;) like muraAbaEapF from Alr-abiyEu, &c.: (TA in art. rbE:) XitaMCF being here in the accus. case as an inf. n., not as an adv. n. [of time]. (TA.)
4. OaXotawoA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and OaXotayonaA, (Mṣb,) They, and we, entered the [season called] XitaMC; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and XatawonaA↓ signifies the same as AXtynA in this sense. (Ḥam p. 117.)
See also 1, near the end.
5: see the first paragraph {1} in two places.
XatFA A rough, or rugged, place. (Ḳ.)
And The Sador [i. e. higher, or upper, part, or front, or fore part,] of a valley. (Az, Ḳ.)
XatowapN: see XitaMCN, in three places.

XatowiI-N and XatawiI-N, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like xarofiI-N and xarafiI-N, (Ṣ,) [signifying Of, or relating to, the season called XitaMC,] are rel. ns. of XitaMCN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) regarded as pl. of XatowapN: (Mṣb:) or it may be that they formed the rel. n. from XatowapN, and discarded that of XitaMCN; as is said in the M: (TA:) or those who regard XitaMCN as a sing. make its rel. n. to be XitaAYiI-N↓ and XitaAwiI-N↓. (Mṣb, TA.)

Also The increase, or offspring, (nitaAj,) of sheep and goats in the [season called] rabiyE [by which is here meant the season called Alr-abiyEu AlOaw-alu and rabiyEu AlkalaOi, commencing in January and ending in March: see the former of the two tables mentioned above]: (Aboo-Naṣr, TA voce SafariI-N [q. v.]:) [and in like manner, of camels; for] XatowiI-N and XatawiI-N and XatiI-N↓ are applied to the young camel brought forth by her that is termed muXotK↓, meaning murobiEN [i. e. that brings forth in the (season called) rabiyE]. (TA.)

XitaMCN a word of well-known meaning [in the sense in which it is most commonly used, i. e. Winter]; (Ṣ;) one of the quarters [of the circle] of the seasons; (Ḳ;) and XaAtaApN↓ signifies the same; (Ṣgh, Ḳ;) [and so does Xatiy-apN↓; (see an ex. voce riboEiI-N;)] and so does maXotaApN↓: (Mṣb, TA:) [also the half-year commencing at the autumnal equinox:] ISk says, Als-anapu is with the Arabs a name for twelve months: then they divided it into two halves, and commenced the sanap [or year] at the commencement of the XitaMC because this word is masc. and the word Sayof [meaning in this case the “half-year commencing at the vernal equinox”] is fem.: then they divided the XitaMC into two halves; the XtwI being the former; and the rbyE, the latter; [but this is a manifest mistake, probably attributable to a copyist; for, as is well known, the former half is called the rabiyE; and the latter, the XitaMC or Xatowap↓;] each consisting of three months; and in like manner the Sayof and the qayoZ consist, each, of three months: (TA:) also one of the six seasons into which the year is divided, each whereof consists of two months; namely, the season [commencing in November and ending in January,] next after that called Alxariyfu: (Ṣ and Ḳ voce rabiyEN: [see this word; and see, again, the former of the two tables mentioned above:]) accord. to Mbr, (Ṣ,) XitaMCN is pl. of XatowapN↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) it is said to be so by IF on the authority of Kh, and by some on the authority of Fr or some other: or XitaMCN and XatowapN↓ signify the same, (Ḳ,) as is said in the M; (TA;) [i. e.] some say that AlX-itaMCu is a proper name for the quarter [&c.]: (Mṣb:) the pl. is OaXotiyapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e. pl. of XitaMCN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) because OafoEilapN, as pl. of fiEaAlN, is peculiar to a masc. [noun]; (Mṣb;) and XutiI-N also, (Ḳ, TA,) originally OuXotuwIN [a mistake for XutuwIN], written in the Tekmileh XitiI-N, as on the authority of Fr.: (TA:) the pl. of its syn. maXotaApN↓ is maXaAtK. (Mṣb.)
Also, i. e. XitaMCN, Hail, syn. baradN, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK barodN,]) that falls from the sky. (TA.)

And Drought, or dearth: (Ḳ, and Ḥam pp. 117 and 150:) this meaning being assigned to the XtMC exclusively of the Sayof because in it the people keep to the tents, not going forth to seek after herbage. (TA.)
XatiI-N: see XatowiI-N, in two places.
Xatiy-apN: see XitaMCN [with which it is syn.].
XitaAYiI-N and XitaAwiI-N: see XatowiI-N.
XaAtK Entering the XitaMC, which, with them, [i. e. the Arabs, and app. in this case,] means [a season of] drought, or dearth. (Ḥam pp. 149-50.)
yawomN XaAtK A day intensely cold: (Mṣb:) or a day in which is barad [i. e. hail (accord. to the CK barod)]; and in like manner gadaApN XaAtiyapN [a morning in which is hail]. (Ḳ, TA.)
XaAtaApN: see its syn. XitaMCN.
maXotFI The place [in which one resides, stays, dwells, or abides, during the season] of the XitaMC [or winter,, &c.]; as also maXotaApN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. maXaAtK. (TA.)
muXotK: see XatowiI-N, last sentence.

It is said in a trad., as some relate it, waAln-aAsu muromiluwna muXotuwna, meaning The people being in a state of straitness, or dearth, and hunger, and paucity of milk: but IAth says that the reading commonly known is musonituwna. (TA.)
maXotaApN: see XitaMCN, in two places:
and maXotFI.

hom.sense: Xav-N A species of tree, (Aṣ, IDrd, ISd, Mṣb,) of those that grow upon the mountains, (Aṣ,) or a certain plant, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of sweet odour, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) but bitter to the taste, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) with which one tans, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) growing in the mountains of El-Ghowr (ADk, Mṣb) and Tihámeh and Nejd; (ADk;) a kind of tree like the dwarf-apple-tree, (AḤn, Mgh,) in size, (AḤn,) the leaves of which are like those of the xilaAf [q. v.], (AḤn, Mgh,) and are used for tanning therewith, (Mgh,) without thorns, and having a small rose-coloured [fruit of the kind called] baramap, in which are three or four black grains, resembling the Xiyniyz [q. v.], which, when scattered, are eaten by the pigeons: n. un. with p {Xav-apN}. (AḤn:) the word occurs in a trad. as the name of a tan: Az says that it is a mistake for Xab-, though he knew not whether the Xav- were used for tanning, or not: (TA:) [Mṭr, however, says that] Xib- is a mistake in this case, for it is a species of zaAj, and is a dye, not a tan: (Mgh:) accord. to some, (TA,) the Xav- is the wild nut (jawozu Albar-i). (Ḳ [in which this last is mentioned as a distinct signification] and TA.) [See also Xab-N.]
The honey-bee. (AA, Ḳ.)
A broken portion of the head of a mountain, remaining in a form like the [kind of acroterial ornament of a wall called] Xurofap: pl. XivaAvN. (Ḳ.)
Also Many, or much, of anything. (TA.)

entry.sense: 1. Xaj-ahu, aor. _u {yaXojuju} and _i {yaXojiju}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former reg., (Mṣb,) [the latter irreg.,] inf. n. Xaj-N, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He broke it, [so as to cleave its skin or its flesh,] namely, another's head: (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA:) or he clave his skin of the face or of the head; or he clave its skin, i. e. the skin of the face or of the head: (Mṣb:) originally he struck it, namely, the head, so as to wound it and cleave it [in the skin or flesh thereof]; and then used in relation to other members: (TA:) or Xaj-ahu fiI raOosihi and fiI wajohihi [he wounded him so as to cleave the skin or the flesh in his head and in his face]. (A.) Accord. to some, [contr. to the authority of the A,] it is from Xaj-ati Als-afiynapu Alb-Hora [expl. below]. (Mṣb.)

[Hence,] it is said in a prov., fulaAnN yaXuj-u biyadK wayaOosuw biOuxoraI [Such a one breaks a head with one hand and cures with another]; meaning † such a one corrupts, or mars, one time, and rectifies, or repairs, another time. (TA.)
And zayodN yaXuj-u mar-apF wayaOosuw mar-apF ‡ Zeyd does, or says, wrong one time, and right one time. (A, TA.)

And Xaj-ati Als-afiynapu AlbaHora ‡ The ship clave the sea: (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb:) and [in like manner] Xaj-a AlbaHora ‡ he clave the sea; (Ḳ, TA;) said of a swimmer. (TA.) And Xaj-a AlmafaAzapa ‡ He traversed the desert. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) And Xaj-a AlOaroDa biraAHilatihi † He traversed the land, with his camel that he rode, at a vehement rate. (TA.)

And Xaj-a AlX-araAba, (Ḳ, TA,) or Xaj-a Alxamora biAlmaMC,, aor. _u {yaXojuju} and _i {yaXojiju}, inf. n. Xaj-N, [as above,] (TA,) ‡ He mixed the beverage, or the wine, (Ḳ, TA,) with water. (TA.) Hence, fakaAna yaXuj-u EalaI-a misokFA, occurring in a trad., means ‡ And it was as though it mixed with her odour of musk the breath of wind that reached my organ of smell. (TA.)
2. taXojiyjN [The breaking of another's head much, so as to cleave the skin or the flesh: or the breaking of heads so as to cleave the skin or the flesh.]
[And hence, perhaps,] † The acting with penetrative energy, vigour, or effectiveness; syn. taSomiymN. (O, Ḳ.)
3. bayonahumo XijaAjN (A, O, Ḳ) and taXaAj-N↓ (A, TA) Between them is a mutual breaking of heads. (A, O, Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, XajaAjN is erroneously put for XijaAjN.])
6: see what next precedes {3}.
Xaj-apN A single act of breaking of one's head [so as to cleave its skin or its flesh]. (TA.)

And A wound by which the head is broken (Ṣ,* A,* L, Mṣb) so as to cleave its skin or its flesh: (L:) and [such] a wound in the face: (A,* Mṣb:) pl. XijaAjN (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb) and Xaj-aAtN. (Mṣb.) What are termed XijaAj are of ten different kinds, (A, L,) distinguished by the following epithets: [1] HaAriSapN, which peels off the [external] skin, but does not bring blood: [2] daAmiyapN, which brings blood: [3] baADiEapN, [which cleaves the flesh slightly, and brings blood, but does not make it to flow: (but in art. dmg, voce daAmigapN, q. v., what are here mentioned as the second and third are transposed:) 4, mutalaAHimapN,] which cleaves the flesh much: [5] simoHaAqN, which leaves between it and the bone only a thin skin: these are five XjAj for which there is no retaliation nor any determinate mulct, but respecting which a judge must give his sentence: [6] muwDiHapN, which reaches to the bone, and for which the mulct is five camels: [7] haAXimapN, which breaks the bone, and for which the mulct is ten camels: [8] munaq-ilapN, from which bone is removed, from one place to another, and for which the mulct is fifteen camels: [9] maOomuwmapN, also called Mm-apN, which leaves between it and the brain only a thin skin, and for which the mulct is one third of the whole price of blood: [10] daAmigapN, which reaches the brain, and for which the mulct is also one third of the whole price of blood. (L.) The Xaj-ap of ʼAbd-El-Hameed, [who was the goodliest man of his age,] the son of ʼAbd-Allah the son of ʼOmar the son of El-Khattáb, was the subject of a prov. on account of its beauty [and is said to have increased his goodliness]. (MF.)
XajajN The mark, or scar, of a wound by which the forehead has been broken. (Ṣ,* A, Ḳ,* TA.)
XajajaI The EaqoEaq [or magpie]; (Ḳ, TA; omitted in the CK;) [and] so XajawojFI↓. (Ḳ and TA in art. Xjw.)
XajiyjN and maXojuwjN↓ A head broken [so that its skin or its flesh is cloven]: or a man having his head [so] broken: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. [of the former] Xaj-aI: you say qawomN Xaj-aI. (AZ, TA.)
Each is also applied as an epithet to a wooden peg or stake [as meaning † Having its head broken, or mangled, by blows]: and so is muXaj-ajN↓, but in an intensive sense. (Ṣ, L.)

And both the first and ↓last signify ‡ A wooden peg or stake; (A, TA;) each as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: because its head is separated, or uncompacted, in its component parts [or fibres by its being battered]. (TA.) One says, maA biAld-aAri XajiyjN and muXaj-ajN↓ ‡ There is not in the house [even] a wooden peg or stake. (A, TA.)
XajawojFI: see XajajaI.
saAbiHN Xaj-aAjN ‡ A swimmer that cleaves the water vehemently. (TA.)
OaXaj-u A man having a mark, or scar, of a wound by which his forehead has been broken. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
muXaj-ajN: see XajiyjN, in three places.
maXojuwjN: see XajiyjN.

hom.sense: 1. Xajiba, aor. _a {yaXojabu}, (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XajabN; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and Xajaba, aor. _u {yaXojubu}, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. XujuwbN; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) He perished: (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or, accord. to AO, he perished in relation to religion or the present worldly state: the former verb said by Ks to be the better: (TA:) or the former, (Ṣ,) or each, (O,) signifies he grieved, or mourned; or was sorrowful, sad, or unhappy. (Ṣ, O.) [See also XajabN, below.]
And Xajaba, aor. _u {yaXojubu}, inf. n. XajobN and XujuwbN, It (a thing) went, went away, or passed away. (TA.)

And Xajaba, aor. _u {yaXojubu}, inf. n. XajobN, said of a raven (guraAb), It uttered the croak that is ominous of separation: (TA:) [or it croaked vehemently: or it (a raven of separation) bemoaned, by its croak, a misfortune: see XaAjibN.]
See also 6.

Xajabahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXojubu}, inf. n. XajobN, (Ṣ,) He (God, Ṣ) destroyed him: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) one says maA lahu Xajabahu Qll-ehu [What aileth him? May God destroy him!]: thus the verb is trans. as well as intrans. (Ṣ.)

And He grieved him; or caused him to mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful, sad, or unhappy: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) [and so, app., OaXojabahu↓; for] one says, OaXojabahu AlOamoru faXajiba lahu, inf. n. XajabN, i.e. Hazina, [which seems to mean The affair grieved him and he grieved at it,] and [in like manner] OaXojabaka AlOamoru faXajibota. (TA,)

And He cast, or shot, at him, namely, a gazelle, (O, Ḳ, TA,) with a spear, (O,) or with an arrow, or some other thing, (TA,) and severed one of his legs, so that he could not move from his place. (O, Ḳ, TA.)

Also He drew, or pulled, him, or it. (O, Ḳ.) One says of a horseman, and of a horse, Xajaba All-ijaAma and yaXojubuhu, He pulled the bit and bridle, and he pulls it. (O.) And Uin-aka lataXojubuniI Eano HaAjatiI Verily thou drawest me from the thing that I want. (As O.)
And He occupied him, or busied him, or occupied him so as to divert his attention [from a thing]. (ISk, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And Xajabahu biXijaAbK He stopped it with a stopper; syn. sad-ahu bisidaAdK. (Ṣ, O, TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see the preceding paragraph {1}.
5. tXj-b i. q. taHaz-ana [app. as meaning He expressed pain, grief, or sorrow, or he lamented, or moaned]. (O, Ḳ.)

6. tXAjb It (an affair, Nh, Mṣb, TA) became confused: (Nh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) and (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) it (a thing, IDrd, TA) became intermixed, or intermingled, one part of it entering into, or within, another; (IDrd, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) as also Xjb [app. Xajaba↓], inf. n. Xjb [app. XajobN]. (IDrd, TA.)

hom.sense: XajobN Want, or a want, syn. HaAjapN: and anxiety: (A, O, Ḳ:) pl. XujuwbN. (TA.)

Also, as an epithet, applied to a skin for water or milk, as though a contraction of XajibN meaning “perishing,” Old, and worn out; (O, TA;*) as also XaAjibN↓: (O:) or the latter, so applied, signifies dry. (TA.)

And [as a subst., or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] A skin for water or milk of which half is cut off and the lower part made into a bucket: (O, Ḳ:) pl. XujubN. (TA.) And A dry skin for water or milk into which pebbles are put and then shaken for the purpose of frightening camels. (L, Ḳ.*) Az says, on the authority of an Arab of the desert, that it signifies An old, worn-out, skin for water or milk, of which, sometimes, the mouth is cut off, and fresh ripe dates are put in it. (TA.) Suh says, in the R, that A water-skin was thus called [app. meaning absolutely]. (MF, TA.) And it is said in a trad. that a man of the Ansár used to cool water for the Prophet fI AXjAbp [app. a mistranscription for fiI OaXojaAbihi, meaning in his water-skins, or worn-out water-skins; and cited to show that OaXojaAbN is a pl. of XajobN, like as OanohaArN is pl. of nahorN]. (TA.)
Also One of the poles of a tent: (A, Ḳ:) pl. XujuwbN [agreeably with an explanation in the Ṣ]. (TA.)
And [as an epithet,] Long, or tall. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: XajabN Grief, or sorrow; and anxiety: (Ḳ, TA:) but the word more commonly known is with n [i.e. XajanN]. (TA.) [The pl. is OaXojaAbN (like OaXojaAnN) occurring in the O, See also Xajiba, of which it is the inf. n.: and see XajobN, first sentence.]
And Distress that befalls a man by reason of disease or of fight. (Ḳ,* TA.)

XajibN and XaAjibN↓ Perishing: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) [accord. to an explanation of their verbs by AO, in relation to religion or to the present worldly state:] or the former, (Ṣ,) or each, (O,) signifies, grieving, or mourning; or sorrowful, sad, or unhappy. (Ṣ, O.)

XujubN Three pieces of wood [set up as a tripod] upon which the pastor hangs his bucket (Ḳ, TA) and his skin for water or milk. (TA.) [See also XijaAbN (voce miXojabN), of which it is said in the TA to be pl.]
XijaAbN: see miXojabN.
Also A stopper; syn. sidaAdN. (Ṣ, O, TA.)
XajuwbN A woman affected with anxiety, whose heart is given up thereto. (O, Ḳ.)
XaAjibN: see XajobN:
and XajibN.

Also A raven (guraAbN) croaking vehemently, or that croaks vehemently: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) a raven uttering the croak that is ominous of separation: a raven of separation that bemoans, by its croak, a misfortune. (TA.)

Also Irrational in talk, and loquacious. (Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., Aln-aAsu valaAvapN XaAjibN wagaAnimN wasaAlimN, i. e. Men are [of] three [sorts;] a speaker of what is bad, or an utterer of foul, or obscene, language, aiding in wrongdoing; and a speaker of what is good, and an enjoiner thereof, and a forbidder of what is disapproved, so that he obtains good fortune; and one who is silent: or, accord. to AʼObeyd, XaAjibN signifies perishing, or in a state of perdition, and sinning. (TA.) [Or] the Prophet said, AlmajaAlisu valaAvapN fasaAlimN wagaAnimN waXaAjibN, meaning [Assemblies are of three sorts;] secure from sin; and acquiring recompense; and perishing, or in a state of perdition, and sinning. (O.)

miXojabN Pieces of wood, (T, Mṣb, Ḳ,) bound together [at the top], upon which clothes are spread, (T, Mṣb,) or upon which clothes are put; as also XijaAbN↓; (Ḳ;) of which latter the pl. is XujubN: (TA: [see this last word above:]) pieces of wood, or sticks, of which the heads are joined together, and the feet parted asunder, upon which clothes are put, and sometimes the water-skins are hung thereon for the purpose of cooling the water: (Nh, TA:) or a piece of wood upon which clothes are put: (Ṣ:) Suh says, in the R, that they used to call the water-skin XajobN, and they used not to hold it otherwise than suspended, so that miXojabN properly signifies the piece of wood, or stick, to which the water-skin is suspended: then they amplified the application of this word so as to call thereby the thing upon which clothes are suspended: (MF, TA:) the pl. is maXaAjibu. (A.)

hom.sense: 1. XajorN is an inf. n. of Xajara, and signifies The being, or becoming, intricate, complicated, perplexed, confused, or intricately intermixed; as also AiXotijaArN↓. (TA.) You say, Xajara AlOamoru bayonahumo, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXojuru}, inf. n. XajorN (Mṣb, TA) and XujuwrN, (Ḳ, TA,) The affair, or case, was, or became, complicated, intricate, or confused, so as to be a subject of disagreement, or difference, between them; syn. AiDoTaraba; (Mṣb;) and so Xajara bayonahumo [in which AlOamoru is understood]; syn. Aixotalafa: (Ṣ:) it was, or became, an occasion of contention, or dispute, or of disagreement, or difference, between them. (Ḳ, TA.) fiymaA Xajara bayonahumo, in the Ḳur iv. 68, means Respecting that which hath become complicated, or intricate, or confused, [so as to be a subject of disagreement, or difference,] between them: and hence the word XajarN, [“trees,” and “shrubs,”] because of the intermixing, or confusion, of the branches: (Bḍ:) or respecting the disagreement, or difference, that has happened between them. (Zj, Mgh.) And it is said in a trad., Uiy-aAkumo wamaA Xajara bayona OaSoHaAbiI Avoid ye the disagreement, or difference, that hath occurred among my companions. (TA.)
Xajarahu, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXojuru}, (TA,) inf. n. XajorN, He tied it; namely, a thing. (Ḳ.)
Xajarahu biAlr-umoHi He thrust, or pierced, him with the spear, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) so that it stuck fast in him. (TA.)

Xajarahu Eanohu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXojuru}, (TA,) inf. n. XajorN, (Ṣ,) He, or it, averted, or diverted, him, from it; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) namely, an affair: (Ḳ:) he removed, or put away, (TṢ, Ḳ,) him, (Ḳ,) or it, (TṢ,) from it: (TṢ, Ḳ:) he withheld, or debarred, and repelled, him from it. (Ḳ.) You say, maA Xajaraka Eanohu What has averted thee, or diverted thee, from it? (Ṣ, A.)

Xajara Albayota, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He propped up the byt [or tent] with a pole. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA. [In some copies of the Ḳ, biEuwdK is erroneously put for biEamuwdK.]) In like manner Xajarotuhu is said of anything as meaning I propped it up with a pole or the like. (TA.) And Xajara AlX-ajarapa, (T, Ḳ, TA,) and Aln-abaAta, (T, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He raised the hanging branches of the tree, or shrub, (T, Ḳ, TA,) and of the plant. (T, TA.) And Xajara Alv-awoba He raised the garment, it having gone down. (T, TA.) And Xujira, inf. n. as above, is said of anything as meaning It was raised, upraised, uplifted, or elevated. (TA.)

Xajara faAhu He opened his mouth (A, Ḳ,* TA) with a stick, or a piece of wood, (A, TA,) by inserting this into the part of the mouth called its Xajor, (TA,) faOawojarahu [and then put, or poured, medicine, or water, &c., into his mouth]. (A, TA.) And Xajara Ald-aAb-apa, (TṢ, Ḳ, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above; or, accord. to one relation of a trad. in which it occurs, AiXotajarahaA↓ bilijaAmihaA; (TA;) He made the beast to open its mouth by jerking its bridle to curb it. (TṢ, Ḳ, TA.)
And Xajara AlX-aIoCa He threw the thing upon the miXojar [q. v.], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. the miXojab. (Ṣ.)

Xajira, aor. _a {yaXojaru}, i. q. kavura jamoEuhu [app. meaning Its aggregate became large in quantity; or it became much in the aggregate]: (TṢ, Ḳ, TA:) but accord. to Aṣ, [it seems to signify it became collected together, and then scattered, or dispersed, by something: for he says that] XajirN↓ [its reg. part. n.] is applied to anything collected together, and then scattered, or dispersed, by something (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. taXojiyru Aln-axoli i. q. taXoxiyruhu, (Ḳ,) The laying of the racemes of the palm-trees upon the branches, lest they should break: (Ḳ in art. Xxr:) this is done when the fruit is much in quantity, and the racemes are large, and one fears for the heart of the tree, and for the base, or lower part, of the raceme. (TA in the present art.)
3. XAjr AlmaAlu The cattle pastured upon Xajar [i. e. trees, or shrubs], (ISk, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) having consumed the herbs and leguminous plants. (ISk, Ṣ, A.*)
XAjr fulaAnN fulaAnFA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muXaAjarapN (Ṣ,) Such a one contended, disputed, or litigated, with such a one. (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA.)
4. AXjrt AlOaroDu The land produced Xajar [i. e. trees, or shrubs]. (Ḳ.)
6: see 8, in three places.
7: see 8, in two places, and see 7 in art. sjr.

hom.sense: 8. AXtjr It was, or became, knit, or connected, together, one part with another; as also AiXotabaka: it was, or became, commingled, one part amid, or within, another; (TA;) and so tXAjr↓: (Ḥam p. 161:) it was, or became, intricate, complicated, perplexed, confused, or intricately intermixed. (TA: see 1, first sentence.) It is said in a trad., relating to conflict and faction (fitonap), yaXotajiruwna fiyhaA QXotijaAra OaTobaAqi Alr-aOosi They become knit together therein, like the knitting together of the bones of the head that interjoin, one with another, one entering into another: or the meaning is, they disagree, or differ, one with another. (TA.) You say, AXtjrwA birimaAHihimo (TA) and tXAjrwA↓ bihaA (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, TA) They became knit together, or commingled, one with another, [in conflict,] with their spears: (TA:) or they thrust, or pierced, one another with their spears. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, TA.) And AXtjrwA (Zj, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and tXAjrwA↓ (Zj, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ) They became commingled, or confused, or embroiled, disagreeing, or differing: (Zj, TA:) they contended, or disputed, together; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb;) or disagreed, or differed. (Ṣ,* A,* Mgh, Mṣb,* Ḳ.)
Also He preceded, outwent, or outstripped; (Ḳ,* TA;) and so AnXjr↓. (Ḳ.)
And, said of sleep, It withdrew, or kept aloof, from one; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also AnXjr↓. (Ḳ.)

Also (Ṣ, Ḳ) said of a man, (Ṣ,) He put his hand beneath his Xajor, against the part beneath his chin: (Ṣ:) or he put his hand beneath his chin and leaned upon his elbow, (Ḳ, TA,) not laying his side upon the bed. (TA.)
[And, said of a horse, He was bridled, reined, or curbed: (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees:) or perhaps the verb in this sense is in the passive form:]
see 1, last sentence but two.
XajorN A discordant, or complicated, or confused, affair, or case. (O, Ḳ.)

Also The part, of a raHol [or camel's saddle], that is between the kar-aAni, (Ḳ, TA, [this word erroneously written in the CK with z,]) which are the qaAdimap and the Mxirap, (TA in art. Xxr,) [i. e. the XaroxaAni,]
the kar- being what conjoins the ZalifataAni [in the fore part of the saddle and in like manner in the hinder part]: the part between the kar-aAni is also called the Xaxor. (TA in the present art. [It is there said that this part is also called the Xarox as well as the Xaxor: but this is a mistake.])

And The chin: (Aṣ, O, Ḳ:) or (TA, in the Ḳ “and,”) the place of opening (maforaj, [as in the Ḳ voce XiynN,] in the Ḳ here erroneously written maxoraj, the meaning being mafotaH,) of the mouth: (Ḳ,* TA:) or the part between the two lower jaws: (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the hinder part of the mouth: or the side of the mouth, where the upper and lower lips unite: or what has opened of the part where the mouth closes [when medicine or the like is put into it]; expl. by maA QnofataHa mino munoTabaqi Alfami: or the place of meeting of the lihozimataAni [q. v., a word variously explained]: (Ḳ:) or the part where the two sides of the lower jaw unite, beneath the hair that grows between the lower lip and the chin: and, in a horse, the part between the upper, main, portions of the two sides of the lower jaw: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaXojaArN and [of mult.] XujuwrN and XijaArN. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: XajarN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and XijarN↓ and XiyarN, (Ḳ,) in which last the j is changed into I, like as the I is changed into j, as in ganij-N, originally ganiI-N, or, accord. to IJ, the I in XiyarN is not changed from j because it remains I in the dim., in which, where it so changed, it should be changed back into j, where as the dim. of XiyarapN is said to be XuyayorapN and XiyayorapN, and because it has kesr instead of fet-ḥ to the X, [whence it appears that IJ knew not XijarN,] (TA,) [as coll. gen. ns., Trees; and shrubs, or bushes; which latter are also called, for distinction, diq-u AlX-ajari; and sometimes applied to plants in general; and, as a gen. n., sometimes meaning the tree,, &c.;] the kind of plant that has a trunk, or stem: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or the kind that has a hard trunk, or stem, (Mgh, Mṣb,) like the naxol &c.: (Mṣb:) or such as produces seed, and does not come to an end in its year: (Mgh:) or such as rises, or rises high, of itself, whether slender or large, and whether it withstand the winter or lack strength to do so: (Ḳ:) called XajarN from Xajara, because of the intermixing, or confusion, of the branches: (Bḍ in iv. 68, and TA:*) n. un. with p {XajarapN}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e. XajarapN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA) and XijarapN↓ and XiyarapN: (TA:) the pl. [of XajarN] is OaXojaArN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and [of XajarapN] XajaraAtN (Mṣb, TA) and [of XiyarapN] XiyaraAtN: (TA:) XajoraMCu↓ also signifies the same as XajarN: (Ḳ:) or it is a pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of XajarapN; a pl. [or quasi-pl. n.] of which there are few other instances; qaSobaMCu of qaSabapN, and TarofaMCu of TarafapN, and HalofaMCu of HalafapN; or, accord. to Aṣ, the sing. [or n. un.] of HlfMCu is HalifapN: and accord. to Sb, XajoraMCu is sing. and pl., and so are qaSobaMCu and TarofaMCu and HalofaMCu: (Ṣ:) or XajoraMCu signifies tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, Xajar: (A:) or a collection of Xajar. (TA.)
Xajarapu Albaq-i, &c.: see in arts. bq, &c.

In the saying in a trad., that the Xajarap and the Saxorap are of, or from, Paradise, by the former is said to be meant The grape-vine: or the tree beneath which allegiance was sworn to the Prophet; and which, it is said, was a Xamurap [or gum-acacia-tree]: (TA:) and by the latter, the Sxrp [or rock] of Jerusalem. (TA in art. Sxr, q. v.)

By AlX-ajarapu AlT-ay-ibapu, mentioned in the Ḳur in xiv. 29, is said to be meant The palm-tree: or a certain tree in Paradise: and by AlX-ajarapu Alxabiyvapu, in the next verse but one, the colocynth, and the kaXuwv: [see art. xbv:] or each may have a more general application. (Bḍ in xiv. 31.) And AlX-ajarapu AlmaloEuwnapu, mentioned in the Ḳur xvii. 62, means The tree called Alz-aq-uwm: and some explain it as meaning the Devil: and Aboo-Jahl: and El-Hakam Ibn-Abi-l-'As. (Bḍ.)

XajarapN also signifies ‡ The stock, or origin, of a man: (O, TA:) [hence,] one says, huwa mino XajarapK Tay-ibapK ‡ [He is of a good stock or origin]; and mino Xajarapi Aln-ubuw-api ‡ [of the prophetic stock, meaning of the stock of the Prophet]. (A.) [And † A genealogical tree; a pedigree.]

Also, (CK,) or XajorapN↓, (O, and Ḳ accord. to the TA, [but probably thus in the TA only because found to be so in the O,]) † A small speck, or speckle, on the chin of a boy: (O, Ḳ:) on the authority of IAạr. (TA.)

And one says, maA OaHosana Xajarapa DaroEihaA, (so in my copy of the A, and accord. to the CK,) or Xajorapa↓ DrEhA, (O, and so accord. to the text of the Ḳ as given in the TA, [but Z has, in the A, distinguished the phrase as tropical, and hence it seems that he held the former reading to be the right,]) ‡ How goodly are the shape, (A,) or the size, (O, Ḳ,) and the appearance, of her udder! (A, O, Ḳ:) or the veins and skin and flesh thereof! referring to a she-camel. (O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: XajirN: see 1, last sentence:
and its fem. XajirapN, see voce XajiyrN.

entry.sense: XajorapN: see XajarN, last two sentences.

hom.sense: XajoraMCu, as a quasi-pl. n.: see XajarN.
Also fem. of OaXojaru as syn. with XajiyrN.

entry.sense: AlHuruwfu AlX-ajoriy-apu [The letters of which the Xajor is the place of utterance; (in the CK, AlX-ajariy-apu;)] the letters j and X and D. (Ḳ.)
XajaArN: see miXojarN, in two places.
XijaArN: see miXojarN, in four places.

Also The wood of a well, (Ṣ, Ḳ, KL,) by means of which the bucket is drawn out therefrom: (KL:) pl. XujurN: (Ṣ:) this pl. occurs in a verse, accord. to J; but the right reading in that instance is sujul, as is shown by the rhyme of the poem. (Ṣgh, TA.)
Also [A wooden bar of a door;] a piece of wood which is put behind a door; called in Pers. mataros, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) written by Az mat-aros. (TA.)
And A piece of wood with which a couch-frame (sariyr) is repaired, by its being affixed as a Dab-ap [q. v.], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) beneath it. (Ṣ.)
And A piece of wood which is put in the mouth of a kid, to prevent its sucking. (TṢ, Ḳ.)
And A certain brand, or mark made with a hot iron, upon camels. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

waAdK XajiyrN, and OaXojaru↓, (Ḳ,) or the former, (Ṣ, A,) but not the latter, (Ṣ,) and muXojirN↓; (Ḳ;) and OaroDN XajiyrapN, (Ṣ, TA,) and XajirapN↓, (A, Ḳ,) and XajoraMCu↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and maXojarapN↓; (AḤn, Ṣ,* Ḳ;) A valley, and a land, abounding with Xajar or OaXojaAr [i. e. trees, or shrubs]. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
XajiyrN also signifies Strange, or a stranger; applied to a man, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and to a camel. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And An arrow that is used in the game called Almayosir, thrown among arrows not from its kind of tree: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or one that is borrowed, and from the winning of which [on former occasions] one augurs good. (TA.)
Also Bad, corrupt, or disapproved. (Kr, Ḳ.)
And A companion: (M, Ḳ:) or a friend: (A:) pl. XujaraMCu. (M, TA.)
And A sword. (Ḳ.)
XajaArapN: see miXojarN.
XawaAjiru [pl. of XaAjirapN fem. of XaAjirN]: see muXotajirN.

Also Withholding, or debarring, and diverting, things. (TA.) You say, XajaratoniI Eanohu XawaAjiru [Withholding, or debarring, or diverting, things withheld, or debarred, or diverted, me from it]. (Ṣ.)
OaXojaru; and its fem., XajoraMCu: see XajiyrN.

Also (Ḳ) Containing more Xajar [i. e. trees, or shrubs]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so in the saying, hecihi AlOaroDu OaXojaru mino hecihi [This land is one containing more trees than this]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*) It has no known verb. (TA.)

maXojarN (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) [and] maXojarapN↓ (Mgh, Mṣb) A place (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) of growth (Mgh, Ḳ) of Xajar or OaXojaAr [i. e. trees, or shrubs]: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or, as some say, the former signifies many Xajar. (TA.)
The former also signifies A place of muXaAjarap [i. e. contending, disputing, or litigating]: pl. maXaAjiru: and, some say, it is an inf. n. (Ḥar p. 473.)
See also miXojarN, in two places.
muXojirN: see XajiyrN.
You say also OaroDN muXojirapN meaning A land giving growth to Xajar [i. e. trees, or shrubs]. (TA. [See also maXojarN.])

miXojarN i. q. miXojabN [i. e. A thing composed of pieces of wood, or sticks, the heads of which are bound together, and the feet parted asunder, upon which clothes, &c. are put]: (Ṣ:) or pieces of wood, or sticks, tied together, like the miXojab, upon which articles of furniture, or utensils, are put: (M, Mṣb:) pl. maXaAjiru. (M, TA.)

And hence, (M,) The wood, (Ḳ,) or pieces of wood, (M,) of the [kind of camel-vehicle for women called] hawodaj; (M, Ḳ;) as also maXojarN↓ and XijaArN↓ and XajaArN↓: (L, Ḳ:) n. un. maXojarapN and XajaArapN↓: (TA:) or a vehicle used by women, smaller than the hawodaj, having the head uncovered; (AA, Ḳ,* TA;) as also maXojarN↓ and XijaArN↓ and XajaArN↓: (Ḳ:) accord. to Lth, XijaArN↓ signifies the wood [or frame-work] of the hwdj, which when covered becomes a hwdj: (TA:)
Aṣ says that maXaAjiru signifies the pieces of wood of a hwdj: AA, that it signifies vehicles smaller than hawaAdij, having the heads uncovered; also called sujurN, of which the sing. is XijaArN↓. (Ṣ.)
maXojarapN: see XajiyrN:
and see also maXojarN.
muXaj-arN Figured work (TA) having the form of Xajar [i. e. trees, or shrubs]: (Ḳ,* TA:) and silk brocade (diybaAj) figured with the forms of Xajar. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
muXotajaru Alr-imaAHi [The place of the commingling of spears; or of the thrusting, or piercing, therewith]. (Ḥam p. 161.)
muXotajirN and mutaXaAjirN↓ Commingled [and confused]: you say rimaAHN muXotajierapN and mutaXaAjirapN↓ and XawaAjiru↓ Spears commingled and confused. (TA.)
mutaXaAjirN: see what next precedes, in two places.

hom.sense: 1. XajuEa, aor. _u {yaXojuEu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n.
