XajaAEapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He (a man, Ṣ) was, or became, courageous, brave, valiant, bold, daring, or stronghearted (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) on the occasion of war, or fight, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) making light of wars, by reason of his boldness. (Mṣb.) AZ says that sajaAEapN sometimes denotes a comparative quality in relation to him who is weaker than the person to whom it is ascribed. (Mṣb.)

XajaEahu, aor. _a {yaXojaEu}, [which in this case is contr. to the general rule, notwithstanding the guttural letter, for by rule it should be _u,] He overcame him, or surpassed him, in XajaAEap [or courage,, &c.]. (Ḳ.) [See 3.]
XajiEa, aor. _a {yaXojaEu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. XajaEN, (IDrd, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He was, or became, tall. (IDrd, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. Xj-Ehu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taXojiyEN, (Ḳ,) He encouraged him; or strengthened his heart; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and emboldened him: (Ḳ:) or he said to him, Thou art XujaAE [or courageous,, &c.]. (Sb, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
3. XaAjaEotuhu faXajaEotuhu [I strove to overcome or surpass him, or contended with him for superiority, in XajaAEap (or courage,, &c.), and] I overcame him, or surpassed him, therein. (TA.)
4. maA OaXojaEahu [How courageous, brave, valiant, bold, daring, or strong-hearted, is he, on the occasion of war, or fight!]. (TA in art bsl.)

5. tXj-E He affected (takal-afa) courage, bravery, valour, boldness, daringness, or strength of heart on the occasion of war, or fight; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [he encouraged himself; made himself, or constrained himself to be, courageous:] and he feigned, or pretended to have, courage,, &c., on the occasion of war, or fight, not having it in him. (TA.)
Penetrating energy; boldness. (Aṣ.)
XajaEN Quickness of the shifting of the legs, in camels, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or, accord. to IB, in horses. (TA.)
XajiEN fem. with p {XajiEapN}: see XujaAEN, in three places.

XajiEu AlqawaAYimi Quick in the shifting of the legs, applied to a he-camel; and so XajiEapN and XajoEaMCu↓, applied to a she-camel. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And qawaAYimu XajiEaAtN Quick, and light, active, or nimble, legs. (TA.)
Mad, applied to a camel. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
XijaEN: see XujaAEN.

hom.sense: XajoEapN: see XujaAEN:
see also XujoEapN:
also Tall, and uncompact in frame:

and crippled by disease; or having a protracted disease: [whence] it is said in a prov., OaEomaI yaquwdu XajoEapF [A blind man leading one crippled by disease, or having a protracted disease: but in Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 119, the last word is written XajaEap, and said to be pl. of XaAjiEN↓, and to signify, app., suffering paralysis]. (TA.)
XujoEapN: see XujaAEN.

Also Cowardly, weak, (Ibn-ʼAbbád,) lacking strength or power or ability, lean, or emaciated, and small in body, having no heart; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ;) as also XajoEapN↓: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) the former seems to have the meaning of a pass. part. n., [i. e. of maXojuwEN, q. v.,] like suxorapN and other words. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.)

entry.sense: XijaEapN: see XujaAEN.
XajaEaMCu [or XijaEaMCu or XajoEaMCu]: see XujaAEN.
XajoEamN A bulky serpent: or a malignant and audacious serpent: regarded by Sb as a quadriliteral-radical word. (TA.) [See also XujaAEN.]
XajaAEN: see what next follows.

XujaAEN and XijaAEN↓ (Lḥ, ISk, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XajaAEN↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is of the dial, of Benoo- 'Okeyl, being made by them to accord with its contr., which is jabaAnN, (Mṣb,) and XajiyEN↓ (Lḥ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OaXojaEu↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and XajiEN↓ (Ḳ) and XijaEN↓, (as in some copies of the Ḳ,) or XijaEapN↓, (as in other copies of the Ḳ and in the TA,) [of all which forms the first is the most common,] Courageous, brave, valiant, bold, daring, or strong-hearted (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) on the occasion of war, or fight, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) making light of wars, by reason of boldness: (Mṣb:) fem. [of the 1st and 2nd and 3rd respectively] XujaAEapN and XijaAEapN (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Ḳ) and XajaAEapN (Mṣb,* Ḳ) and XjAE also [without p] (Mṣb) and [of the 4th] XajiyEapN↓ (Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of the 5th] XajoEaMCu↓ and [of the 6th] XajiEapN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. masc. (of the 1st, Ṣ, Mṣb) XijoEapN [a pl. of pauc.] (AO, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of the first three, and perhaps of the 4th also,] XajaEapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and (of the 1st, Ṣ) XijoEaAnN (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ) and (of the 4th, Ṣ) XujoEaAnN (Lḥ, ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ) [or, accord. to IDrd, XjEAn is a mistake, as is said in the TA, but the word is there written without any syll. signs,] and (of the 4th, Ṣ, Mṣb) XujaEaMCu↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of the 4th, and perhaps of others also,] XijaAEN, (Ḳ,) and also, (but these are quasi-pl. ns., TA,) XajoEapN↓ (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ) and XujoEapN↓ (Ḳ) and XajaEaMCu↓ [app. a mistake for XijaEaMCu or XajoEaMCu]: (TA:) pl. fem. [all of XajiyEapN, or the last of XajoEaMCu or of XajiEapN,] XajaAYiEu and XijaAEN and XujuEN: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) or XujaAEN is [an epithet] peculiar to men: (Ḳ,* TA:) AZ says, “I have heard the Kilábees say, rajulN XujaAEN, but they do not apply this epithet to a woman:” (Ṣ:) XajiEapN↓ and XajiyEapN↓, however, are applied to a woman, and signify bold, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,) longtongued, and vehemently clamorous, towards men; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA;) audacious in her speech, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ, [but these two epithets as applied to a woman and signifying “bold”, &c. are omitted in the CK,]) and in her length of tongue, and vehement clamorousness. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)

XujaAEN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XijaAEN↓ (Ḳ) also signify † The serpent; (Ḳ;) and so does OaXojaEu↓: (TA:) or ‡ the male serpent: (Mgh, Ḳ:) or a certain species of serpent, (Sh, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as also OaXojaEu↓, (Ṣ,) small, (Ḳ,) or slender, and asserted to be the boldest of the serpent-kind: (Sh:) pl. XijoEaAnN (Lḥ, IDrd, Ḳ) and XujoEaAnN, (IDrd, Ḳ,) the former of which is the more common: (IDrd:) the pl. of OaXojaEu is OaXaAjiEu; or, as some say, this is pl. of OaXojiEapN, which is pl. [of pauc.] of XjAE, signifying the serpent. (TA.) [See also XajoEamN, above.]

Also ‡ The serpent called SafarN, that presents itself in the belly (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA) of a man, as the Arabs assert, when he has been long hungry: (Ṣ, TA:) but Aṣ says that XujaAEu AlbaToni signifies † vehemence of hunger. (Az, TA.)
XijaAEN: see XujaAEN, in two places.
XaAjiEN: see XajoEapN.

hom.sense: OaXojaEu; fem. XajoEaMCu: see XujaAEN, in four places. You say also, labuWapN XajoEaMCu A bold lioness. (TA.)

Applied to a man, accord. to some, it signifies, (Ṣ,) or it signifies also, (Ḳ,) In whom is lightness, or unsteadiness, like what is termed hawajN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) by reason of his strength. (Ṣ.) See also XajiEN.

Mad; or possessed by a devil: (TA:) Lth says that, applied to a man, it signifies one who is as though there were in him madness, or diabolical possession; but Az says that this is a mistake; for, were this its meaning, the poets would not have used it in praise. (TA, in another part of the art.)
Tall: (IDrd, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and so the fem. applied to a woman. (IDrd, Mṣb.)
Bulky; big-bodied; or stout: or, as some say, youthful; or in a state of youthful vigour. (TA.)
The lion. (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

It is said in the Ḳ that AlOaXojaEu also signifies Ald-ahoru [i. e. Time; or fortune;, &c.]; and J says that this is what the poet means by the expression, OaXojaEu Oax-aAcN: but this cannot be the correct meaning, for the poet, namely El-Aạshà, says,
biOaXojaEa Oax-aAcK EalaI Ald-ahori Hukomuhu
by AlAXjE meaning himself, or some other thing. (TA.)

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and UiXojaEN, (Ḳ,) or the latter accord. to some, but this was not known to Abu-l-Ghowth, (Ṣ,) sing. of OaXaAjiEu, [in some copies of the Ṣ written OaXaAjiyEu, but the former, which, as is mentioned in the TA, is found in the handwriting of J, is that which is commonly known,]
which signifies [The knuckles nearest to the wrist; this being what is meant by] the bases (OuSuwl) of the fingers, which are connected with the tendons of the outer side of the hand: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) in the T, we find the heads (ruWuws) of the fingers, instead of ASwl: (TA:) or AXjE in the hand and foot [but see what follows] signifies the tendons extended above the sulaAmaI [here meaning the metacarpal and metatarsal bones] from the wrist to the bases (OuSuwl) of the fingers or toes, which are called OaTonaAbu AlOaSaAbiEi, above the outer side of the hand: or the bone which connects the finger with the wrist; [i. e. the metacarpal bone;] every finger having to it a bone thus called: he who says that the OaXaAjiE [so here instead of AXjE as above] are the tendons calls those bones the OusonaAE. (TA.) Aboo-Bekr is described as EaAriI AlOaXaAjiEi Eano mafaASili AlOaSaAbiEi, meaning Having little flesh upon what are thus termed: or having their tendons apparent. (TA.) [See also raAjibapN and burojumapN.]
OaXojaEu mino diykK [More courageous than a cock] is one of the proverbs of the Arabs. (Mgh.)

entry.sense: muXojaEN, like mujomalN, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. having the form of a pass. part. n., (TA,) [in the CK maXojaE, like maHomal,] In the utmost state of madness, or diabolical possession: (Ḳ:) so says Ibn-ʼAbbád; and hence, accord. to him, XujaAEN [but in what sense he does not say]. (TA.)
maXojuwEN Overcome, or surpassed, in XajaAEap [or courage,, &c.]. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Xajina, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXojanu}; (Ḳ;) and Xajuna, aor. _u {yaXojunu}, inf. n. [of the former] XajanN [in some copies of the Ḳ XajonN] and [of the latter, or of both,] XajuwnN; (L, Ḳ;) He grieved, mourned, or lamented; or was sorrowful, sad, or unhappy; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) and was anxious: and tXj-n↓ signifies the same: (L:) or this last signifies, (Ḳ,) or, as Lth says, it seems to signify, (L,) he remembered; syn. tacak-ara. (L, Ḳ.) And Xjnt AlHamaAmapu, [app. both Xajinat and Xajunat,] inf. n. XujuwnN, The pigeon cooed in a wailing and plaintive manner. (L.) [See also XajanN below.]

Xajanahu, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) [aor. _u {yaXojunu}, accord. to the usual rule of the Ḳ,] inf. n. XajonN and XujuwnN, (L, Ḳ,) signifies the same as AXjnhu↓, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) i. e. He, (another person, Ṣ,) or it, (an affair, or an event, or a case, L, Ḳ,) caused him to grieve or mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful or sad or unhappy. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

XajanatoniI AlHaAjapu, (Ṣ, L,) and Xajanatohu, (L, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXojunu}, inf. n. XajonN, (Ṣ, L,) Want, or the want, detained, or withheld, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) me, (Ṣ, L,) or him. (L, Ḳ.) And maA Xajanaka Ean-aA What detained, or withheld, thee from us? (L.)
4. AXjnhu: see the preceding paragraph {1}.
AXjn Alkaromu The grape-vine had a branchlet of a bunch of which all the grapes came to maturity. (L, Ḳ. [See XijonapN.])
5: see 1, first sentence.
tXj-n AlX-ajaru The trees were, or became, tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense. (L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: XajonN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ [in the CK XajanN, but expressly said in the Ṣ to be biAlt-asokiyni]) A road of a valley; (Ṣ, L;) or a road in a valley: or in the upper, or uppermost, part thereof: as also XaAjinapN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. of the former XujuwnN: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) and of XawaAjinu↓: (Ḳ:) or XaAjinapN↓ signifies a valley in which are many trees; (Ṣ, L;) or a place in which are Xujuwn, which means tangled trees; (Ḥam pp. 761-2;) and XawaAjinu is its pl.: (Ṣ, L, and Ḥam p. 762:) or XaAjinapN↓ signifies a sort of valley producing good herbage: or, as some say, XawaAjinu signifies the upper, or uppermost, parts of a valley; and its sing. is XajanN↓ [thus written in the L in this instance], as ISd mentions on the authority of AʼObeyd, but adding that, as such, it is irregular, and that it is more properly to be regarded as pl. of XaAjinapN↓. (L.)

[Hence,] one says, AlHadiyvu cuw XujuwnK, (Ṣ, Meyd, L, Ḳ,) Xujuwn being pl. of XajonN, with the j quiescent; (Meyd;) a prov., (Meyd, L,) meaning † The story is involved, or intricate; (Ṣ, Meyd, L;) or has several ways [in which it may be understood]; (Meyd;) or has several modes, or manners; and objects of aim: (L, Ḳ:) applied to a story by which one calls to mind another: (AʼObeyd, Meyd, L:) the first who said it was Dabbeh Ibn-Udd Ibn-Tábikhah: he had two sons, named Saạd and So'eyd: and some camels belonging to him ran away by night, so he sent his two sons to seek them; and they separated; and Saạd found them and restored them; but So'eyd went on seeking them; and El-Hárith Ibn-Kaab met him; and there were upon the young man two [garments such as are called] burds (burodaAni), which El-Hárith asked him to give to him, but he refused to comply with his desire; whereupon he slew him, and took his two burds: and Dabbeh, when he saw a dark object in the night, used to say, OasaEodN Oamo suEayodN [“Is it Saạd or So'eyd?” (see saEodN)]; and this saying of his became current as a prov.: some time after this, having gone on pilgrimage, he met El-Hárith Ibn-Kaab at 'Okádh, and saw upon him the two burds of his son So'eyd, and asked him respecting them; and he answered that he had met a young man wearing them, and slain him, and taken them: Dabbeh said, “With this thy sword?” and he answered, “Yes:” and he said, “Give it me that I may look at it, for I think it to be sharp:” and El-Hárith gave it him: and he took it, and shook it, and said, Uin-a AlHadiyva cuw XujuwnK; and slew him with it: whereupon it was said to him, “O Dabbeh, in the sacred month?” and he said, sabaqa Als-ayofu AlEacola [“The sword preceded the censure”]: these three provs. he originated. (Meyd.)
XujonN and XijonN: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: XajanN Grief, mourning, lamentation, sorrow, sadness, or unhappiness; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) and anxiety: (L, Ḳ:) pl. OaXojaAnN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and XujuwnN; (L, Ḳ; [in the latter of which these pls. are mentioned after all the explanations of the sing.;]) the former a pl. of pauc., and the latter of mult. (Ḥam p. 404.) [See a verse cited voce EaraDN, in which it means A cause of anxiety.]
And The soul's love, or its inclination, or its blamable inclination: (L:) [or] love that is followed by anxiety and grief. (Kull p. 165.)

And A want, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as also XajiynN↓, (L,) wherever it be: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) pl. XujuwnN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OaXojaAnN; (L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the latter being pl. of XajiynN also. (L.) A rájiz says,
liI XajanaAni XajanN binajodi
waXajanN liI bibilaAdi Als-inodi
[I have two wants; a want in Nejd, and I have a want in the country of Es-Sind]. (Ṣ.)

Also An intricately-intermingling branch of a tree; (L, Ḳ;) and a XuEobap [i. e. branch, or branchlet, or the like,] of anything; (Ḳ;) like XijonapN↓ and XujonapN↓ and XajonapN↓ (L, Ḳ) in the former sense: (L: [accord. to the Ḳ, app., in the latter sense:]) or, accord. to IAạr, one says XujonapN↓ and XujonN↓ meaning a branch of a tree, [or the latter app. means branches, for it seems to be a coll. gen. n.,] and XijonapN↓ and XijonN↓, and [the pl. of XujonapN↓ is] XujonaAtN and XujunaAtN: (L:) or, accord. to J, (L,) XijonapN↓ and XujonapN↓ signify roots of trees intricately intermingling: (Ṣ, L:) [but] the primary signification of XijonapN↓ and XujonapN↓ is a branchlet (a XuEobap of a guSon) of a tree: (L:) or XijonapN↓ signifies tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, trees. (Mṣb.)
See also XijonapN.
And see XajonN.

Also, (Ḳ,) or Xjnp, (L, [thus written without any syll. signs, perhaps fem. of XajanN, i. e. XajanapN, but it seems to be indicated by the context in the L that it is XujonapN↓,]) A she-camel compact in make, of which the several parts are interknit, one with another, (L, Ḳ,*) like the parts of a tree. (L.)

entry.sense: XajonapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: XujonapN: see XajanN, in six places: and XijonapN.
Also, as some say, Leanness; or slenderness, and leanness; or leanness, and lankness in the belly. (L.)

entry.sense: XijonapN: see XajanN, in five places.
Also, i. e. with kesr, (Ḳ,) or XajanN↓ and XajanapN↓, (L,) A branchlet of a bunch of a grape-vine of which all the grapes come to maturity. (L, Ḳ.)

XijonapN signifies also † Relationship closely, or intimately, connected. (L.) One says, bayoniI wabayonahu Xijonapu raHimK, and Xujonapu↓ raHimK, † Between me and him is a relationship closely, or intimately, connected. (Ṣ.) And it is said in a trad., Alr-aHimu XijonapN mina Qll-ehi i. e. ‡ Alr-aHimu is derived from Alr-aHomen: (Ṣ, L: [see raHimN:]) or, accord. to AO, (L,) the meaning is, [Alr-aHim is] relationship, from God, closely, or intimately, connected, like the roots of trees. (Ṣ, L.)
Also A crack, or cleft, in a mountain. (Lḥ, L, Ḳ.)
XajanapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XaAjinatiI↓ Xajuwnu is a saying of the Arabs like their saying EaAbilatiI Eabuwlu [i. e., app., My withholder is death, or shall be death alone; for Xajanatohu Xajuwnu may be rendered Death withheld him, like as Eabalatohu Eabuwlu is rendered “death separated him”]. (L.)
XajiynN: see XajanN.

hom.sense: XaAjinN Grieving, mourning, or lamenting; or sorrowful, sad, or unhappy; (Ṣ, L;) and anxious. (L.)
See also an ex. of its fem., with p {XaAjinapN}, voce Xajuwnu.

entry.sense: XaAjinapN [as a subst.]; pl. XawaAjinu: see XajonN, in five places.

hom.sense: 1. XajiIa, aor. _a {yaXojawu}, inf. n. XajFA, He was choked; or his throat, or fauces, became obstructed; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) bihi by it; i. e. a bone or the like. (Ḳ.) One says, Ealayoka biAlkaZomi walawo Xajiyta biAlEaZomi [Keep thou to self-restraint though thou be choked by the bone]. (TA.)

And, [hence, by a metaphor, (see Ḥar p. 33,)] aor. and inf. n. as above, † He grieved, mourned, or lamented; or was sorrowful, sad, or unhappy: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and he was, or became, anxious, or disquieted in mind. (Ṣ.)
Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, said of a creditor (gariym), He went away, Eanohu [from him]. (Ḳ. [See 4.])
XajaA bayonahumo It was, or became, an occasion of contention, or dispute, or of disagreement, or difference, between them. (Ḳ.)
XajaAhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXojuwu}, inf. n. XajowN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) [app. originally syn. with OaXojaAhu in the first of the senses assigned to the latter in the next paragraph:]

[and hence,] † It (anxiety, Mṣb) grieved him; or caused him to mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful or sad or unhappy; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AXjAhu↓. (Ḳ.) And, said of wealth (AlginaI), inf. n. XajowN, It excited his griefs, mournings,, &c., and his desire. (TA.)

Also, and AXjAhu↓, † It caused him to be mirthful, (Ks, Ḳ, TA,) and excited him. (Ks, TA.) Thus each of these verbs has two contr. significations. (Ḳ.) But MF observes that Tar-abahu, the explanation here given in the Ḳ, is said by the author of the Ḳ [in art. Trb] to denote a lightness arising from joy or grief. (TA.) [Generally, however, it means as rendered above.]

entry.sense: 4. AXjAhu, inf. n. UiXojaMCN, It choked him; or caused his throat, or fauces, to be obstructed; syn. OagaS-ahu; (Ṣ, TA;) said of a bone lying across in the throat, or fauces. (TA.) [This is clearly shown to be the meaning in the Ṣ, as well as in the TA, intended by OagaS-ahu; with which it is also syn. in another sense; for]
It signifies [also] † It, or he, caused him to fall into grief, mourning, lamentation, sorrow, sadness, or unhappiness. (Ḳ.) See also 1, in two places.
Also † He subdued, overpowered, or overcame, him, (Ḳ, TA,) so that he grieved, or was sorrowful. (TA.)
And † He angered him. (Ks, TA.)
And † He made him to go away. (Az, TA.) And OaXojayotuhu Ean-iI † I gave him (i. e. a creditor or petitioner) what contented him, so that he went away. (TA.)

6. taXaAjato Ealayohi, (Aṣ, T, Ḳ,* TA,) said of a woman of the desert with reference to a young man who had been dallying, and holding amorous converse, with her, (Aṣ, T, TA,) † She resisted him, and expressed grief, or unhappiness, to him, or on account of him, [i. e. on account of his advances,] saying, Alas, my grief, or my unhappiness! (Aṣ, T, Ḳ,* TA.) And said of a woman with reference to her husband, meaning † She expressed grief,, &c., as above. (A, TA.)

XajFA A bone, or some other thing (Ṣ, Ḳ) of the like sort, (Ḳ,) sticking fast, (Ṣ,) or lying across, or forming an obstruction, (Ḳ,) in the throat, or fauces, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of a human being, and of a beast; (TA;) a thing in the throat, or fauces, that [chokes one, or] prevents from swallowing: (Ḥar p. 69:) an inf. n. used as a subst. [properly thus termed]. (Ḥar p. 33.)
See also the next paragraph.
XajowN † Anxiety, or disquietude of mind; and grief, mourning, lamentation, sorrow, sadness, or unhappiness; (Ṣ;) [and] so XajFA↓: thus termed because a man is choked thereby. (Ḥar p. 33.)

And † A want; an object of want. (Az, Ḳ, TA.) One says, bakaI fulaAnN Xajowahu [app. meaning † Such a one wept for his object of want]: and daEati AlHamaAmapu XajowahaA [app. † The pigeon called for its object of want]. (TA.)

XajK † Grieving, mourning, or lamenting; or sorrowing, sad, or unhappy; applied to a man; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and XajiyapN, of the measure faEilapN, applied to a woman: one says, wayolN lilX-ajiI mina AlxaliI-i [mentioned and expl. voce xaAlK, in art. xlw, where each of these epithets is written with teshdeed to the I; and likewise in another saying there mentioned]: (Ṣ:) or, in this saying, (TA,) it signifies occupied [by anxiety or grief]; (Ḳ, TA; [in the CK, AlX-ajA is erroneously put for AlX-ajiI;]) and xaliI- means “free [therefrom]:” so says AZ: and in this instance AlX-ajiI may mean occupied by a bone choking, or obstructing, his throat, or fauces, or by anxiety, and not having found a way of escape therefrom; or by his opponent, or adversary, whom he has been unable to withstand: (TA:) and sometimes one says XajiI-N↓, like as one says HazinN and HaziynN; though this is rare; (Mṣb;) it is mentioned in the ʼEyn; but XajK is more known; and is said by Az to be the chaste form: (TA:) Mbr says, the I of AlxlI is with teshdeed, and the I of AlX-ajiI is without teshdeed, (Ṣ,) and sometimes this I is with teshdeed in poetry; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) but if you make it to be from XajaAhu, it is XajiI-N↓ only, syn. with maXojuw-N. [i. e. grieved,, &c.]; (Ṣ;) and so it is said to be by Az and Z: and Az adds, the second way of accounting for it is, that they often lengthen faEilN with a I, saying, fulaAnN qaminN likacaA and qamiynN, and samijN and samiyjN, and karK and kariI-N: and the third way is, that they assimilated one word in measure to another, as in AlgadaAyaA waAlEaXaAyaA, the [proper] pl. of gadaApN being only gadawaAtN. (TA.)
XajiI-N: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
mafaAzapN XajowaMCu [A desert, or waterless desert,] difficult to travel. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
XajawiI-N, with fet-ḥ to the j; rel. n. of XajK. (Ṣ.)

XajawojFI, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the measure faEawoEalN [and therefore with tenween], (Mz 40th nwE, and MF and TA,) like xajawojFI, &c., (Ṣ,* and Mz ibid.,) and XajawojaMCN↓, (Ḳ,) applied to a man, (Ṣ,) Long in the legs: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or very tall: or very tall, with bigness (Dixam, in the CK Daxom,) of the bones: or long in the back, short in the leg; (Ḳ;) thus in the M; but Az says the reverse, i. e. long in the legs, short in the back. (TA.)
Also, (Ḳ,) or the former, (TA,) A bulky horse. (Ḳ.)
And The EaqoEaq [or magpie]; (Ḳ;) [and] so XajajaI; (Ḳ and TA in art. Xj;) fem. with p [i. e. XajawojaApN]. (Ḳ.)
And A wind continually blowing; as also XajawojaApN. (Ḳ.) All this is in the M. (TA.)
XajawojaMCN: see the next preceding paragraph.
OamorN XaAjK An affair, or event, grieving; or causing to mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful or sad or unhappy. (TA.)

1. XaH-a, (Mṣb,) sec. pers. XaHaHota, aor. yaXuH-u and yaXiH-u, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter of these aors. agreeable with analogy as the verb is intrans., and the former deviating therefrom; (MF;) and sec. pers. XaHiHota, aor. yaXaH-u; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [the first of which, having for its aor. yaXuH-u, is the most common;] inf. n. XuH-N (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XiH-N and XaH-N, (ISk, O, Ḳ,) of which three inf. ns. the first is the most approved; (TA;) He was, or became, niggardly, tenacious, stingy, penurious, or avaricious; syn. yaxila: (Mṣb:) or bxl relates to single things, or particulars; and XH-, to things in general: or bxl relates to wealth, or property; and XH-, to wealth, or property, and to kindness, or beneficence: or XH-, signifies he was, or became, niggardly,, &c., as above, in the utmost degree: (TA:) or he was, or became, niggardly,, &c., as above, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) and covetous, or vehemently or greedily or excessively or culpably desirous, (Ḳ,) or with covetousness, or vehement or greedy or excessive or culpable desire. (Ṣ, A, O.) You say, XaH-a bihi and XaH-a Ealayohi; (T, M, Ḳ;) by the former meaning He was, or became, niggardly,, &c., of it, i. e., of his property, or the like; and by the latter, he was, or became, niggardly,, &c., to him, i. e., to an asker, or a beggar, or a seeker, or the like: (MF:) or [in some cases, as will be seen from phrases mentioned below, (see XaHiyHN,)] meaning by the latter the same as by the former. (L.) [Thus] one says, huwa yaXuH-u bimaAlihi [He is niggardly,, &c., of his property; and sometimes, in the same sense, yaXuH-u EalaI maAlihi]. (A.)
And XaH-a baEoDuhumo EalaI baEoDK [Some of them were niggardly,, &c., to some; meaning they were niggardly,, &c., one to another]. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)

3. huwa yuXaAH-uniI bikacaA [He is niggardly, tenacious,, &c., as above, with me, of such a thing]. (A.) [The inf. n.] muXaAH-apN [in the CK erroneously written maXAH-ap] is syn. with Din-apN: (Ḳ, TA:) hence the saying, laA muXaAH-apa fiI AlAiSoTilaAHi [There shall be no acting in a niggardly manner, of one with another, in the making of peace, one with another]. (TA.) And one says, fulaAnN yuXaAH-u EalaI fulaAnK Such a one is tenacious of such a one; syn. yaDan-u bihi. (Ṣ, L.)

6. tXAH- Alqawomu The people, or party, were niggardly, tenacious,, &c., as above, [see 1,] one to another, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) fiI AlOamori [in the affair], (Ḳ, TA,) and Ealayohi [for it], (TA,) and vied in hastening to it, (TA,) fearing lest it should become unattainable. (Ḳ, TA.) And taXaAH-aA EalaI AlOamori laA yuriydaAni Oano yafuwtahumaA (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) They two (i. e. two men, Ṣ, O) contended together for the thing, or affair, each of them being unwilling that it should become beyond his reach, or attainment. (TA.) And taXaAHaHaA AlmaMCa [or taXaAH-aAhu] i. q. tajaAXaEaAhu [i. e. They straitened each other in pressing to the water, and vied, each with the other, in endeavouring to satisfy their thirst]. (TA in art. jXE.)
R. Q. 1. XaHoXaHapN [inf. n. of XaHoXaHa] The being cautious, wary, or vigilant; or fearing. (O, Ḳ.)
The crying of the [bird called] Surad. (Ḳ.) You say, XaHoXaHa AlS-uradu The Srd uttered its cry. (O, TA.)

The camel's reiterating of his voice, [or his being not clear, or his being sparing,] in his braying. (Ḳ.) You say of the camel, XaHoXaHa fiI hadiyrihi [He reiterated his voice, or] he was not clear, (Ṣ,) or he was sparing, (L,) in his braying. (Ṣ, L.)
And The flying swiftly. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nafosN XaH-apN: see XaHiyHN.

OawoSaI fiI SiH-atihi waXiH-atihi means [He made his will during his state of soundness, or health, and] in his state of which he is tenacious [or the state which he is reluctant to quit] (fiI HaAlihi Al-atiI yaXuH-u EalayohaA). (O, Ḳ.)
XaHaAHN: see the next paragraph in four places.

XaHiyHN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XaHaAHN↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and XaHoXaHN↓ and XaHoXaAHN↓ and XaHoXaHaAnN↓, (Ḳ,) applied to a man, Niggardly, tenacious, stingy, penurious, or avaricious: (Mṣb:) or niggardly,, &c., as above, in the utmost degree: (TA:) or niggardly,, &c., as above, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and covetous, or vehemently or greedily or excessively or culpably desirous, (Ḳ,) or with covetousness, or vehement or greedy or excessive or culpable desire: (Ṣ, A:) and nafosN XaH-apN↓ signifies the same as XaHiyHapN [a soul that is niggardly,, &c.]: (IAạr, TA:) the pl. (of XaHiyHN, Ṣ, Mṣb) is OaXiH-apN [a pl. of pauc.] (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XiHaAHN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and OaXiH-aMCu. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, [huwa XaHiyHN biXaIoCK and] XaHiyHN EalaI XaIoCK He is niggardly,, &c., of a thing. (L in art. Xd.) OaXiH-apF EalaI Alxayori, in the Ḳur [xxxiii. 19], means [They being niggardly, or vehemently desirous, of the good things, i. e.] of the wealth and spoils: (TA:) and OaXiH-apN Ealayokumo, in the same verse, means [They being niggardly] of aid [to you]. (Jel.)

[Hence,] UibilN XaHaAYiHu, [in which the latter word is pl. of XaHiyHapN,] (O, Ḳ,) or XiHaAHN, (A,) ‡ Camels that yield little milk. (A, O, Ḳ, TA.) And zanodN XaHaAHN↓ ‡ A piece of stick, or wood, for producing fire, that does not yield fire. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) And maMCN XaHaAHN↓ † Water little in quantity; not copious. (Ḳ.) And OaroDN XaHaAHN↓ † Land that will not flow with water unless in consequence of much rain; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also XaHoXaHN↓: (O, Ḳ:) and also, (ISk, L, TA,) or ↓the latter word, (so accord. to the Ḳ,) † Land that flows in consequence of the least rain; (ISk, Ḳ, TA;) as though it were niggardly of itself to the water: (TA;) like HaXaAdN [in this, or in the former, sense]: (ISk, L:) thus having two contr. meanings. (Ḳ.) And accord. to AḤn, XiHaAHN signifies † [Small water-courses such as are termed] XiEaAb any one of which is made to flow if a skinful of water is poured into it. (TA.)
XaHoXaHN: see XaHiyHN, in three places.
Also Evil in disposition; (O, Ḳ;) and so XaHoXaAHN↓. (TA.)
Very jealous; (Fr, Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also XaHoXaAHN↓ and XaHoXaHaAnN↓. (Fr, O, Ḳ.)
Courageous; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so XaHoXaAHN↓. (TA.)

Also, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) applied alike to a male and to a female, (TA,) and XaHoXaAHN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) or XaHoXaHaAnN↓, (Ṣ,* O,) One who keeps, attends, or applies himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to a thing: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) who strives, labours, or exerts himself, therein: (TA:) or, as some say, (Ṣ, O,) penetrating, sharp, vigorous, or effective, therein: (Ṣ, O, TA:) the first, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and ↓second, (TA,) applied to an orator, or a preacher, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) in this last sense, (Ṣ, O, TA,) or as meaning eloquent (Ḳ, TA) and powerful: (TA:) and both, as epithets of general application, penetrating, sharp, vigorous, or effective, in speech, or in going or journeying: the first is also applied to an orator, or a preacher, as meaning skilful: (TA:) and ↓the last of these three epithets is applied by Dhu-r-Rummeh to a driver of camels, who urges them by singing to them. (Ṣ, O, TA.)
Also the first, applied to a raven, or crow, (guraAb,) That croaks much. (O, Ḳ.)
And Light, or agile; applied to an ass; as also XuHoXuHN↓, (O, Ḳ,) as some say. (O.)
And Swift in flight; applied to a qaTaAp. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
Also, and XaHoXaHaAnN↓, Tall, or long, (Fr, O, Ḳ, TA,) and strong. (TA.)
And the former, applied to a [desert such as is termed] falaAp, Wide; (O, Ḳ, TA;) in which the places of alighting are far apart, and in which is no herbage. (TA.)
XuHoXuHN: see the next preceding paragraph.
XaHoXaAHN: see XaHiyHN:
and see also XaHoXaHN, in five places.
Also, applied to a woman, Resembling a man in her strength, (O, Ḳ,) and her exertion, or energy. (O.)
XaHoXaHaAnN: see XaHiyHN:
and see also XaHoXaHN, in four places.
muXaHoXaHN Niggardly, tenacious, stingy, penurious, or avaricious; [like XaHiyHN;] (TA;) possessing little, or no, good. (O, Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. XaHaba, aor. _u {yaXoHubu}. (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ, &c.) and _a, (A, O, Ḳ, &c.,) but the former more commonly obtains, (TA,) inf. n. XuHuwbN; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and XaHuba, (Fr, Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. XuHuwbapN, (Fr, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) but this form of the verb is disapproved by AZ and ʼIyáḍ; (TA; [in which, however, nine authorities for it are mentioned;]) said of one's body; (Fr, Ṣ, O;) or of one's colour, or complexion, (A, Ḳ,) and so XuHiba, (A, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. XuHuwbN; (A;) [It was, or became, altered for the worse, wan, or haggard], (Fr, Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ, &c.,) in consequence of emaciation, (Ḳ,) or hunger, (A, Ḳ,) or sleeplessness, and the like, (A,) or travel, (Ḳ,) or work, or disease, or impatience, or distress or fatigue: or, accord. to the author of the “Wáʼee,” XuHuwbN signifies emaciation itself: (TA:) in this sense, it is of the dial. of Benoo-Kiláb. (A, TA.)

XaHaba AlOaroDa, (IDrd, O, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXoHabu}, inf. n. XaHobN, (IDrd, O,) He pared the ground, or scraped off its superficial part, with a shovel, (IDrd, O, Ḳ,) or some other thing: of the dial. of El-Yemen. (IDrd, O.)

entry.sense: XaHibN: see what follows.

XaAHibN A man having his colour, or complexion, altered [for the worse, wan, or haggard], (TA,) or so XaAHibu All-awoni, (A,) in consequence of disease, or travel, or the like: (TA: [see 1:]) and emaciated, or lean; (TA, KL;) as also XaHibN↓. (KL.) It is said in a trad., laA taloqaI AlmuWomina Uil-aA XaAHibFA [Thou wilt not find the believer otherwise than wan, or haggard; or emaciated, or lean]; because XuHuwb is one of the effects of fear, and of paucity of food, and of little enjoying of plentifulness and pleasantness or easiness, and softness or delicacy, of life. (TA.)
It is also applied as an epithet to a sword, meaning Altered in its colour by blood that has dried upon it: used in this sense by the poet Taäbbata-sharrà. (TA.)

1. XaHaja, aor. _a {yaXoHaju} and _i {yaXoHiju}, inf. n. XaHiyjN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and XuHaAjN (Aṣ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and XaHajaAnN (O, Ḳ) and taXoHaAjN; (O, L;) and tXH-j↓; and AstXHj↓; (L, TA;) He uttered his voice or cry; [brayed; croaked;]
said of a mule, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, &c.,) and of an ass, (ISd, O,) and of a raven, or crow; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, &c.;) and sometimes, ‡ of a man: (L:) or XaHiyjN is used in relation to a mule; and XaHajaAnN, in relation to a raven, or crow: (T, TA:) or the former of these two signifies the reiterating of the voice or cry of the raven, or crow; and when it stretches forth its head [and croaks], you say naEaba: and accord. to the L, the first and second inf. ns., used in relation to an ass, signify the uttering certain of his voices or cries: Th is thought by ISd to have mentioned also XaHija; but the latter doubts its correctness: and XuHaAjN is also expl. as signifying the raising of the voice; but as used more especially in relation to the mule and the ass. (TA.) XaHaja is also said of a raven, or crow, meaning He, being advanced in age, had a rough, or harsh, voice or cry: (O, Ḳ:) [he croaked roughly, or harshly, by reason of age:] it is said in the M that XaHiyjN and XuHaAjN signify the crying of a raven, or crow, when advanced in age. (TA.)
5: see the preceding paragraph {1}.
10. AstXHj [He desired a raven, or crow, to croak]. One says of ravens, or crows, AusotuXoHijona faXaHajona [They were desired to croak, and they croaked]. (O, Ḳ.)
See also 1.
XaH-aAjN, applied to a mule, an ass, and a raven or crow, that brays, or croaks, or raises its voice, much: and by Er-Rá'ee it is applied to ‡ a muWac-in. (TA.)
banaAtu XaH-aAjK, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) and XaAHijK↓, (L,) Mules: (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ:) and asses. (A, TA.)

And XaH-aAjN and miXoHajN↓ The wild ass: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) in the L said to be the wild pigeon: [but HmAm is evidently there a mistranscription for HimaAr:] each an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (TA.)
banaAtu XaAHijK: see XaH-aAjN.

XawaAHiju [pl. of XaAHijapN] Ravens, or crows: which are also called musotaXoHajaAtN↓ and musotaXoHijaAtN↓, meaning desired to croak and croaking. (O, Ḳ.) Dhu-r-Rummeh uses the phrase musotaXoHijaAtN↓ biAlfiraAqi [Ravens croaking by reason of separation]. (O, TA.)
miXoHajN: see XaH-aAjN.
musotaXoHajaAtN: see the next but one of the preceding paragraphs, in three places.

1. XaHaca, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXoHacu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XaHocN, (Ṣ,) He sharpened (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) a knife, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) and a sword, and the like, (L,) or an iron implement, (Mṣb), with a whetstone or other similar thing; (TA;) as also AXHc↓; (Ḳ;) and XH-c↓, inf. n. taXoHiycN. (KL.)

[Hence,] XaHacota EalayonaA lisaAnaka ‡ [Thou hast sharpened against us thy tongue]. (A and TA in art. rhf.) And AiXoHaco lahu garoba cihonika ‡ [Sharpen thou for it the edge of thine intellect]. (A.) And XaHacahu biEayonihi, (Ḳ,) or bibaSarihi, (A,) ‡ He looked sharply at him. (Ḳ,* TA.) And XaHaca AljuwEu maEidatahu † Hunger made his stomach keen, and strengthened it, (L,) and inflamed it. (L, Ḳ.)

Hence also, i. e. from XaHaca in the sense first expl. above, (Ḥar p. 377,) fulaAnN yaXoHacu Aln-aAsa, (inf. n. XaHocN, Ḳ,) ‡ Such a one begs importunately of men: (A, Ḳ,* and Ḥar ubi suprà:) and XaHacotuhu I begged importunately of him. (Mṣb.)

And XaHacahu † He drove him away; namely, a man; (Ḳ;) as also tXH-chu↓, (CK, and so accord. to the O,) or XH-chu↓, (Ḳ accord. to the TA,) inf. n. taXoHiycN. (TA.) [See also 5 below.] And XaHacotuhu, (O, TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) † I drove him vehemently. (O, Ḳ,* TA.)
XaHocN also signifies † The being angry. (Ḳ.) You say, XaHaca Ealayohi † He was angry with him. (TḲ.)
And i. q. qaXorN [The act of paring, or peeling,, &c.]. (O, Ḳ.) You say, XaHacahu, i. e. qaXarahu [He pared it, peeled it,, &c.]. (TḲ.)
2: see above {1}, in two places.

hom.sense: 3. XaAHacaniI, inf. n. XiHaAcN, He assisted me, by alternating with me, (raAsalaniI,) and did like as I did, in sharpening a sword and the like. (Ḥam p. 533.)
XAHct Aln-aAqapu The she-camel raised her tail, and then twisted it vehemently, when in labour, being near to bringing forth. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1, first sentence.

hom.sense: 5. raOayotuhu yataXaH-acu ‡ [I saw him applying himself to importunate begging]. (A, TA. [In both this meaning is indicated by the context.])
taXaH-acaniI fulaAnN † Such a one drove me away, and subjected me to trouble, or difficulty. (TA.) See also 1.

entry.sense: XaHacaAnN † [Having a keen appetite;] hungry. (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ.)
And † A vehement driver. (Ḳ TA. [See also miXoHacN.])
And † Light, or active, in his work (fiI saEoyihi). (O, Ḳ.)
XuHocuwcN, applied to a man, i. q. naziqN † [Light, and unsteady, or lightwitted;, &c.]. (TA.)
XaHiycN, applied to a knife [&c.], Sharpened; (Lth, A, TA;) as also maXoHuwcN↓. (Lth, TA.)

XaH-aAcN ‡ An importunate beggar: (A, Ḳ:*) one should not say XaH-aAvN: (Ḳ:) the latter is said by IB to be a vulgar corruption; but several authors assert it to be correct, because c is changed into v without any error in speech, as is asserted by El-Khafájee and others; and accord. to the A, both these words signify as above: (TA in art. XHv, and partly repeated in the present art.:) [it is said, however, that] XaH-aAcN meaning a beggar does not occur in the language of the Arabs. (Ḥar p. 377.)
miXoHacN A whetstone; or thing with which, or upon which, one sharpens. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And [hence,] A rough, severe, or violent, driver: (O, Ḳ: [see also XaHacaAnN:]) and applied also as an epithet to a driving. (O.)

maXoHacapN [A cause, or means, of sharpening: a word of the class of majobanapN, &c.]. One says, hecaA kalaAmN maXoHacapN lilofahomi ‡ [This is discourse that is a cause, or means, of sharpening of the understanding]. (A.)

miXoHaAcN An [elevation such as is termed] Oakamap, wide within, (O, Ḳ, TA,) not rough in the stones [thereof], but extending long upon the earth, not having in it trees nor soft ground: (O, TA:) or, accord. to ISh, (O, TA,) level ground, (O, Ḳ, TA,) in which are pebbles like those [that are strewn in the court] of the mosque, and in which is no mountain: but he says that ADk disapproves the word: (O, TA:) accord. to Fr, (O,) the head of a mountain, (O, Ḳ, TA,) when sharp, or pointed: pl. maXaAHicu. (O.)
maXoHuwcN: see XaHiycN.
fulaAnN maXoHuwcN Ealayohi ‡ Such a one is an object of anger. (O, TA.)

hom.sense:
1. XaHaTa, aor. _a {yaXoHaTu}, inf. n. XaHoTN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and XaHaTN (Ḳ) and XuHuwTN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and maXoHaTN; (Ḳ;) and XaHiTa, aor. _a {yaXoHaTu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XaHaTN; (TA;) It was, or became, distant, or remote: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or XaHoTN and XaHaTN signify the being distant, or remote, in all states or circumstances. (TA.) You say, XaHaTa AlmazaAru The place of visiting was, or became, distant, or remote. (Ṣ.) And laA OanosaAka EalaI XaHoTi Ald-aAri I will not forget thee notwithstanding the distance of the dwelling. (TA.) And El-ʼAjjáj says,
waAlX-aHoTu qaT-aAEu rajaMCi mano rajaA
[And distance is the severer of the hope of him who hopeth]. (TA.)
XaHaTa fiI Als-awomi He went far, or far from what was right, and exceeded the due limit, in the demanding of a price. (TA.)

Hence, (TA,) XaHaTa AlbaEiyra fiI Als-awomi, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, and in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, Alb-Eiyru,]) aor. _a {yaXoHaTu}, inf. n. XaHoTN, (TA,) He went to the utmost of the value of the camel in the demanding of a price: (Ḳ, TA:) or he went far from what was right, and exceeded the due limit: (Ḳ:) and XaHiTa signifies the same; (Ḳ;) or is thought to do so by ISd. (TA.) Hence, also, what is said in a trad., by Rabee'ah, respecting a man emancipating a portion of a slave: yakuwnu EalaI AlmuEotiqi qiymapu OanoSibaMCi XurakaMYihi yuXoHaTu Alv-amanu vum-a yuEotiqu kul-ahu [The value of the portions of his copartners shall be imposed upon the emancipater;] the price of the slave shall be carried to the utmost; [then he shall emancipate the whole of him:] or the meaning is, the price of the slave shall be collected; from XaHaTa AlUinaMCa, which see below. (TA.)

XaHaTa fulaAnFA He preceded, outwent, got before, or passed beyond, such a one, and became far from him: (Ḳ, TA:) and in like manner, Alxayola [the horses, or horsemen]. (T, TA.) One says also, XaHaTato banuw haAXimK AlEaraba The sons of Háshim surpassed, and outstripped, the Arabs [in general] in excellence. (TA.)
XaHaTa AlUinaMCa He filled the vessel. (Fr, Ḳ.)
See also 5.

entry.sense: 2. XH-Thu, inf. n. taXoHiyTN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He made him (a slain man) to struggle, or flounder, bidamihi in his blood: (Ṣ:) or he besmeared, bedawbed, befouled, or defiled, him, biAld-ami with blood. (Ḳ.)
4. AXHThu He made him, or caused him, to be, or become, distant, or remote; he put him, sent him, or removed him, far away. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

5. tXH-T He (a slain man) struggled, or floundered, bidamihi in his blood: (Ṣ:) and XaHoTN↓ [inf. n. of XaHaTa] also signifies the struggling, or floundering, in blood: (Lth, ISd, Ḳ:) or the former signifies he struggled, or floundered, and rolled, or wallowed, fiI damihi in his blood: (TA:) or became besmeared, bedawbed, befouled, or defiled, (Mgh, Ḳ,) and he rolled, or wallowed, (Mgh,) or struggled, or floundered, (Ḳ,) fiI damihi in his blood. (Mgh, Ḳ.*) And It (the fœtus) struggled, or floundered, fiI Als-alaI in the membrane enclosing it. (Ḳ.)
XaH-aATN: see what next follows.
XawaAHiTu AlOawodiyapi, [the former word being pl. of XaAHiTapN,] The distant, or remote, parts of the valleys. (TA.)

XawoHaTN Certain trees, (Ḳ,) a species of the trees of the mountains, (Ṣ,) meaning of the mountains of the saraAp, [the mountain-range extending from near 'Arafát to Nejrán in El-Yemen,] for there they grow, (TA,) of which bows are made: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) AḤn says, One acquainted with [the kind of trees called] the XwHT has informed me that it grows in the manner of the Oaroz [or pine-tree], many rods growing from one stem; its leaves are thin and long, and it has a fruit like the long grape, [the word here rendered “grape” is Enbp, but it has been altered in the MṢ., and may therefore be incorrect,] except that its extremity is more slender, and it is soft, and is eaten: (TA:) or i. q. naboEN: (IB:) or a species of the naboE, (Ḳ,) of which bows are made: (TA:) or the XwHT and nbE and XiroyaAn are one; the name varying according to the excellence of their places of growth; what is upon the summit of the mountain being called nbE; what is upon its base, or foot, or lowest or lower part, XryAn; and what is in the depressed tract by its base, XwHT: (Mbr, Az, Ḳ:) IB says the same with respect to the nbE, but that the XwHT is that which is upon the lowest part of the mountain; and this is confirmed by what is said by AZ and others: El-Ghanawee El-Aạrábee says, the nbE and XwHT and saraMC are one: as to the XryAn, no one holds it to be of the nbE except Mbr: Aboo-Ziyád says that bows are made of the XryAn, and they are good, but of a black colour tinged with redness: and AḤn says in one place, that the nbE and XwHT are yellow in the wood, heavy in the hand; and when they become old, they become red: (TA:) the n. un. is with p {XawoHaTapN}. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. XaHuma, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXoHumu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XaHaAmapN, (MA, Mṣb,) He (a man, Ṣ, Ḳ) was, or became, fat; (Ṣ, MA, Ḳ;) as also XaHima, aor. _a {yaXoHamu}: (TA:) or he was, or became, abundant in the fat of his person. (Mṣb.) And XaHumato Uibiluhu (Ḳ) His camels were, or became, fat. (TA.) And XuHimati Aln-aAqapu; and XaHamat, aor. _u {yaXoHumu}; of the classes of EuniIa and naSara; inf. n. XaHomN and XuHuwmN; The she-camel became fat after leanness. (TA.)
XaHima, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXoHamu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XaHamN, (TA,) He was, or became, eagerly desirous of fat. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) And He ate much fat. (TA.)
XaHamahu, (Ḳ,) or XaHama OaSoHaAbahu, (Ṣ,) aor. _a {yaXoHamu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XaHomN, (TA,) He fed him, or his companions, with fat; or gave him, or them, fat to eat. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4. AXHm He had much fat in his possession: like as AlHm signifies “he had much flesh in his possession.” (TA.)

XaHomN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of an animal, (Mṣb,) a word of well known meaning, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) Fat; (MA, KL;) the substance of fatness: (ISd, TA:) XaHomapN is a more special term, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) [i. e. a n. un.,] signifying a piece thereof: (Ḳ:) the pl. of the former is XuHuwmN. (Mṣb, TA.) It is said of the Jews, in a trad., Harumato Ealayohimu AlX-uHuwmu fabaAEuwhaA waOakaluwA OavomaAnahaA [Fats have been forbidden to them; but they have sold them, and have devoured the prices thereof: see Lev. vii. 23]: the fat that is forbidden to them is that of the kidneys and of the stomach and of the intestines into which the food passes from the stomach; but not that of the Oalayop [meaning the “rump,” and also the “tail of a sheep,”] nor of the back. (TA.) One says, laqiytuhu biXaHomi kulaAhu [lit. I met him, or found him, with the fat of his kidneys,] meaning, ‡ in his state of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness. (Ḳ, TA.) And of him who is deemed weak, one says, fulaAnN XaHomN lilomubotaliEi ‡ [lit. Such a one is fat for the swallower]. (Ḥam p. 771.)
Also The hump of the camel: (TA:) heard by Az from the Arabs in this sense. (TA in art. Hm.)
And The whiteness [app. meaning the white part] of the belly. (TA.)

XaHomapu AlOucuni [The lobe, or lobule, of the ear;] the part, of the ear, to which the quroT [i. e. ear-ring or ear-drop] is suspended; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e. the soft portion of the lower part of the ear: or the place of the perforation for the quroT. (TA.)

XaHomapu AlEayoni The muqolap of the eye; (TA;) i. e., what comprises the white and the black of the eye: (Zj in his “Khalk el-Insán;” and Ṣ and Mṣb and Ḳ voce muqolapN:) [this is what is generally meant by it; i. e. the globe of the eye:] in the T it is said to be the Hadaqap [i. e. black, or what is in the middle of the white,] of the eye: and some say that it is the XaHomap [app. meaning the whole substance] that is beneath [or behind] the Hadaqap. (TA.)
XaHomapu AlHanoZali [and XaHomuhu, as in the Ḳ in art. HnZl,] The inner part [i. e. the pulp] of the colocynth, exclusive of its seeds. (Ḳ.)
XaHomapu Alr-um-aAni The thin yellow [pulp] that is amid the seeds of the pomegranate; (Ḳ;) or, as in the M, the substance that separates the seeds of the pomegranate. (TA.)
XaHomu Aln-axoli The heart pith, or cerebrum, (jum-aAr,) of palm-trees: (Ṣ in art. jcb:) and XaHomapu Aln-axolapi the heart (jum-aArap) of the palm-tree. (M, TA.)
XaHomapu Almaroji The xiTomiI- [or marsh-mallow]. (Ḳ.)

XaHomu AlOaroDi The truffle; as a gen. n.; syn. AlkamoCu: (TA in art. kmO:) and XaHomapu AlOaroDi the truffle; as a n. un.; syn. AlkamoOapu: (Ḳ:) or the white truffle; syn. AlkamoOapu AlbayoDaMCu. (Ṣ.) [It should be observed that AlkamoCu is generally held to be a n. un.; and AlkamoOapu, to be a coll. gen. n.; contr. to analogy: but they are here evidently used in the reverse manner.]

XaHomapu AlOaroDi also signifies A certain white worm: or is of (min [which is omitted in some of the copies of the Ḳ]) the [long worms, found in moist earth, and in the mud of rivers, called] xaraATiyn: (Ḳ, TA:) or a white EaZaMCap [n. un. of EaZaMCN, q. v.], not big: or, as some say, it is not of the [species called] EaZaMC; it is more pleasant [to the taste], and better: and [because it dwells in the sand-hills,] they say [i. e. call it] also XaHomapu Aln-aqaA, like as they say banaAtu Aln-aqaA: (TA:) it is the [reptile called] Hulakap, which dives into the sand, and to which the fingers (banaAn) of virgins are likened. (TA in art. ArD. [See HulakapN: and see also XabavN.])
Oabuw XaHomK is an appellation of The small species of what is called HimaAru qab-aAna. (TA in art. qb, q. v.)
[See also XaHomapN below.]
XuHomN, with damm, [as though pl. of OaXoHamu, which I do not find mentioned,] White; applied to men. (IAạr, TA.)
XaHimN Eagerly desirous of fat. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, rajulN XaHimN laHimN A man eagerly desirous of fat and of flesh. (TA.)
EinabN XaHimN Grapes having little juice (Ḳ, TA) and thick skin. (TA.)
And rum-aAnapN XaHimapN A pomegranate having thick XaHomap [or pulp amid the seeds]. (TA.)

hom.sense: XaHomapN [n. un. of XaHomN, which see throughout.]
[Also] A certain bird. (Ḳ. [For TaAYirN, which I regard as the right reading, in the CK, I find in other copies of the Ḳ AlT-aAYiru as an explanation of AlX-aHomapu.])
And A certain game of the children of the Arabs of the desert. (Ḳ,* TA.)

entry.sense: XaHiymN Fat, as an epithet applied to a man: (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or abundant in the fat of his person. (Mṣb.)
XaH-aAmN A seller of fat; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also XaAHimN↓. (Ḳ.)
And One who feeds men much with fat. (TA.)
XaAHimN One who feeds men with fat. (Ṣ, TA.)
And A man having, or possessing, fat; like laAHimN signifying “having, or possessing, flesh:” possessive epithets like laAbinN and taAmirN. (TA.)
See also XaH-aAmN.
muXoHimN, (Ṣ, [so in my copies, see 4, of which it is the part. n.,]) or muXaH-imN↓, like muHad-ivN [in measure], (Ḳ,) [both perhaps correct,] A man having much fat in his house or tent. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And the former, A man whose camels are fat. (Ḳ.)
muXaH-amN: see maXoHuwmN.
muXaH-imN: see muXoHimN.
maXoHuwmN Food, and bread, into which fat has been put; (TA;) [and so muXaH-amN↓, for] one says xubozapN muXaH-amapN [a cake of bread,, &c., into which fat has been put]. (Ḳ in art. rbq.)

hom.sense: 1. XaHana, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXoHanu}, inf. n. XaHonN, (L, Mṣb,) He filled (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) a ship, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) or a house, or chamber, &c.: (Mṣb:) he filled, [or laded,] and completely equipped or furnished, a ship. (L.) And in like manner, It (i. e. what was in it) filled a ship. (L.) And, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) as also AXHn↓, (Ḳ,) He filled a town or city (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) biAlxayoli [with horsemen or the horsemen]. (Ṣ, L.)

Also, (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (L,) and so the inf. n., (L, Mṣb,) He drove away (L, Mṣb, Ḳ) a people, or party, (L,) or him. (Mṣb.) And (L) one says, mar-a yaXoHanuhumo, (Ṣ, L,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) He passed along driving them away, and pursuing them. (Ṣ, L.) AZ heard an Arab of the desert say, AiXoHano Eanoka fulaAnFA, meaning Remove thou, and put far away, from thee such a one. (L.) And one says of a thing that is intensely acid, Uin-ahu yaXoHanu Alc-ubaAba i. e. Verily it drives away the flies. (TA.)

XaHonN also signifies The running vehemently. (L.) And XaHana, He went far, or far away. (Ḳ.) And one says, XaHanati AlkilaAbu, (L,) [and XaHinat, as appears from what follows,] aor. taXoHanu and taXoHunu, (L, Ḳ,) like tamonaEu and taEolamu and tanoSuru, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XuHuwnN, (L,) The dogs went far in pursuit without catching any prey, or game. (L, Ḳ.)

XaHina Ealayohi, aor. _a {yaXoHanu}, (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XaHanN; (L, Mṣb;) and XaHana, aor. _a {yaXoHanu}, inf. n. XaHonN; (Mṣb;) He bore rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, against him; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and (Mṣb) bore, (L,) or showed, (Mṣb,) enmity towards him. (L, Mṣb.)

entry.sense: [2. XH-nhu He made him, or appointed him to the office of, a XiHonap, q. v.; occurring in post-classical works.]

3. XAHnhu, (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. muXaAHanapN, (L, Mṣb, KL,) He regarded him, or treated him, with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; (Mṣb;) or with enmity; being so regarded, or treated, by him: (L, Mṣb, Ḳ, KL:) or, as some say, muXaAHanapN is such reviling, and blaming, upbraiding, or reproaching, reciprocally, as does not amount to fighting one another; from XaHonaMCu meaning “enmity.” (L.)

hom.sense: 4. AXHn: see 1.
Also, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UiXoHaAnN, (L,) He sheathed the sword: (L,* Ḳ:) and he drew the sword: thus having two contr. significations. (Ḳ.)
Also, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, L,) He (a boy, or child, Ṣ, L, and, as some say, a man, L) was ready, or about, to weep: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or his eyes watered at the approach of weeping (L.)
And AXHn lahu bisahomK He prepared himself to shoot him, or to shoot at him, with an arrow. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 6. taXaAHunN The regarding, or treating, one another [with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; (see 1, last sentence; and 3;) or] with enmity. (L.)
XaHonapN [thus written, with fet-ḥ to the X, but I incline to think that it is correctly XiHonapN↓,] The contents of a ship, that fill it. (L.)

hom.sense: XiHonapN: see what next precedes.

[Also] A body of men sufficing for the guarding, controlling, or firm holding, of a province, or city, on the part of the Sultán. (Az, L, Ḳ.*) And (Ḳ) A troop of horsemen keeping post (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) in a country or town. (Ṣ, L.) IB says that the vulgar usage of this word as syn. with OamiyrN [i. e. A commander or commandant,, &c., being used app. only in post-classical times, from the Pers. XaHonaho, meaning in Pers., and hence in Arabic also, a viceroy, prefect, chief of the police, or the like,] is a mistake. (L.)
And The quantity of fodder appointed to beasts as sufficing them for a day and a night. (Az, L, Ḳ.)
See also what next follows.

entry.sense: XaHonaMCu Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite: (L:) or vehement hatred: (Mṣb:) and enmity; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also XiHonapN↓. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) Hence the saying, kaAna bayonahu wabayona Oaxiyhi XaHonaMCu i. e. [There was between him and his brother] enmity. (L.)

XuHuwn in the following verse, cited by ISd,
taOaT-arona fiI AlmiynaMCi vum-a tarakonahu
waqado laj-a mino OaHomaAlihin-a XuHuwnu
may be, accord. to him, an inf. n. of XaHana, or an extr. pl. of XiHonapN: (L:) [but I rather think that it is a pl. of XaAHinN↓, like as XuhuwdN is of XaAhidN; and accordingly I would render the verse (which evidently relates to ships) thus: They kept close in the port, then they left it, and laders had persisted in contention by reason of their burdens, i. e. the burdens of the ships, because of the labour that they occasioned.]

hom.sense: XaAHinN [act. part. n. of XaHana]: see the next preceding paragraph.
See also maXoHuwnN.
Also A dog going far in pursuit without catching any prey, or game: pl. XawaAHinu. (L.)
And Bearing enmity [or rancour, &c. (see 1, last sentence,)] towards another: one says, huwa XaAHinN laka [He is bearing enmity, &c. towards thee]. (L.)

entry.sense: maXoHuwnN A ship (fulokN, so in the Ḳur [xxvi. 119, &c.], S, L, or marokabN, Ḳ [in the L, erroneously, rakabN],) Filled [or laded, and completely equipped or furnished: see 1, first sentence]; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) as also XaAHinN↓, like kaAtimN in the sense of mukotuwmN, (L, Ḳ,) mentioned by Kr. (L.)
muXoHaYin-N Becoming angered; or made angry. (Ḳ.)

Eaduw-N muXaAHinN [An enemy who regards, or treats, another with rancour,, &c., being so regarded, or treated by him: see 3]. (Ṣ, L.) AlmuXaAHinu as used in a trad. means The schismatic innovator in religion: (L, Ḳ:) so says El-Owzá'ee: or the transgressor: (L:) or it means he who has in his heart rancour, &c. (XaHonaMC) towards the Companions of the Apostle of God: or he who forsakes the institutes, or rule and usage, of his prophet; who speaks against his people; who sheds their blood. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. XaHaA, (Ḳ,) or XaHaA faAhu, (Ks, Ṣ,) aor. _a {yaXoHawu}, (Ks, TA,) or _u, (Ṣ,) inf. n. XaHowN, (Ks, Ṣ, TA,) said of a man, (TA,) He opened his mouth; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also AXHI↓ [or app., AXHI faAhu], (Ḳ,) and XH-I↓ faAhu, inf. n. taXoHiyapN. (TA.) XaHaA faAhu [meaning as above] is also said of the ass when about to bray. (TA.) And one says of the bit, XaHaA fama Ald-aAb-api [It opened the mouth of the beast]. (TA.) [See also art. XHI.]
And XaHaA fuwhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) aor. _u {yaXoHuwu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) His mouth opened; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also XH-I↓ fwh; (TA;) but one should not say AXHI fwh. (IAạr, TA.)

And XaHaA, inf. n. as above, He stepped, paced, or walked. (TA.) Hence it is related in a trad. of ʼAlee, that, having mentioned sedition, or conflict and faction, or the like, he said to 'Ammár, lataXoHuwan-a fiyhaA XaHowFA laA yudorikuka Alr-ajulu Als-ariyEu, meaning Thou shalt assuredly go [or step or pace] quickly, and advance, therein [so that the swift man shall not overtake thee]. (TA.) And it is said that XaHaA fiyhi signifies He went far; and took a wide, or an ample, range; in it. (TA. [See also 5.])

entry.sense: 2: see the preceding paragraph {1}, in two places.
4: see 1, first sentence.
5. tXH-I, accord. to Aboo-Saʼeed, primarily signifies He took a wide, or an ample, range in anything. (TA. [See also 1, last explanation.])
[Hence,] tXH-I Ealayhi He spread out, or stretched out, his tongue, [or he gave wide range to his tongue,] respecting him [or against him]. (Ḳ.)
XaHFA, (Ḳ,) thus with the short A, (TA,) Wide; applied to anything: and XaHowaMCu↓, applied to a well, signifies the same: (Ḳ:) or the latter, thus applied, wide in the head [or upper part]. (TA.)

XaHowapN A step, pace, or single act of stepping or pacing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, farasN baEiydu AlX-aHowapi A horse having a far extent of step: (Ṣ, TA:) and ragiybu AlX-aHowapi (Ṣ in art. rgb) a horse wide of step; that takes a large space of ground with his legs. (TA: but there, AlX-aHowi [which is the inf. n.].)
[Hence,] rajulN baEiydu AlX-aHowapi fiI maqaASidihi ‡ [A man who strides along in his pursuits]. (TA.)
And UinaMCN waAsiEu AlX-aHowapi i. e. ‡ [A vessel wide] in the interior. (TA.)
XHMC: see the next paragraph.
XaHowaMCu: see XaHFA.

Also A she-camel wide of step: and it is said in a trad. that the Prophet had a horse named AlXHMC↓, thus related, with medd, [app. AlX-aHaMCu, like AlwasaAEu,] expl. as meaning the wide of step: so says IAth. (TA.)

XaAHK [act. part. n. of 1: fem. XaAHiyapN; pl. of the latter XawaAHK and XaAHiyaAtN].
One says, jaMCati Alxayolu XawaAHiIa The horses came opening their mouths: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,* TA:) and so Oaqobalati Alxayolu XaAHiyaAtK. (M, TA.)
And jaMCanaA XaAHiyFA He came to us stepping along. (TA.)
And † He came to us without any want. (TA.)
AlX-awaAHiI is applied by the vulgar to The large pieces of wood resembling columns: but [SM says,] I have not seen any mention thereof in the [classical] language. (TA.)

1. XaHiIa, like raDiIa, inf. n. XaHoIN, is said by ISd and in the Ḳ to be a dial. var. of XaHaA, inf. n. XaHowN, i. e., as ISd says, meaning He opened his mouth; but the latter, he says, is the better known: this, however, requires consideration: for it is said in the Tekmileh that XaHaI fulaAnN, aor. yaXoHaI, inf. n. XaHoIN, is a dial. var. of [XaHaA, aor.] yaXoHuw, inf. n. XaHowN, on the authority of Lth. (TA.)

1. Xaxaba, (Mgh, TA,) aor. _u {yaXoxubu} [and _a,] inf. n. XaxobN, said of milk, (Mgh,) and of anything, It flowed. (Mgh, TA.) And Xaxabotuhu I made it to flow. (Mgh.) You say, Xaxaba All-abanu, aor. _u {yaXoxubu} and _a {yaXoxabu}, (Ṣ, O, CK,) inf. n. XaxobN, (Ṣ, O,) The milk flowed in an extended stream from the udder when milked; (Ṣ, O, CK;) and † in like manner one says of blood: (O:) or Xaxaba All-abana, aor. _u {yaXoxubu} and _a {yaXoxabu}, he made the milk to flow in a continuous stream from the udder (Ḳ accord. to the TA [and accord. to the context in the Ḳ, in which it is immediately added faQnoXaxaba, showing that AnXxb↓ has the former of these two significations as quasi-pass. of Xaxaba, and the like is said in the A,]) between the vessel and the teat. (TA.) Hence, i. e. from Xaxaba All-abanu, the saying of El-Kumeyt,
wawaHowaHa fiI HiDoni AlfataApi DajiyEuhaA
walamo yaku fiI Aln-ukodi AlmaqaAliyti maXoxabu↓
[And he who lay upon his side with her, or her bedfellow, breathed audibly, by reason of the cold, in the bosom of the young woman, and there was not, among the she-camels that had no young ones living, and that should therefore abound with milk, because not suckling, any flowing of milk in a continuous, or an extended, stream, or any time, or place, thereof, for maXoxabN may be, agreeably with a general rule, an inf. n. or a n. of time or of place]. (Ṣ.) And some expl. XaxobN as signifying The sounding, or sound, of milk when it is being drawn from the udder. (TA.) One says also, Xaxabato OawodaAju Alqatiyli damFA i. e. ‡ [The external jugular veins of the slain person] streamed, or flowed with blood: (Mṣb, TA:* [and the like is said in the Mgh:]) and Xaxabotuhu OanaA † [I made it to stream, or flow]: the verb being intrans. and trans. (Mṣb.) And huwa yaXoxubu damFA † He, or it, flows [or streams] with blood; the last word being in the accus. case as a specificative: and be, or it, pours forth, or makes to flow [or stream], blood; the last word, when this is the meaning, being in the accus. case as an objective complement: but the former is that which is commonly known. (Mgh.) And Xaxabato yadaAhu Hat-aI maAta † [His hands flowed, or streamed, with blood, until he died: or poured forth blood,, &c.]: said, in a trad., of one whose knuckles, or finger-joints, were cut. (TA.) AnXxb↓, also, is said of blood [as meaning † It flowed, or streamed]. (TA.) And AnXxb↓ damFA, said of a vein, means † It flowed, or streamed, with blood. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) And it is said in a trad. respecting the HawoD [or pool (of the Apostle)], yaXoxubu fiyhi miyzaAbaAni mina Aljan-api † [Two spouts will pour forth into it from Paradise]. (TA.) And one says, Xaxabotu All-iqaAHa I milked the milch camels. (A, TA.)
And mar-a yaXoxabu fiI AlOaroDi † He went, or passed by, (O,) or ran, (El-Fáïk, TA,) swiftly [in the land, or upon the ground]. (El-Fáïk, O, TA.)
7: see the preceding paragraph {1}, in three places.
XaxobN: see the next paragraph.
Also † Blood. (Ḳ.)

XuxobN Milk coming forth, (A,) or milk that has come forth, (Ḳ,) from the udder, (A, Ḳ,) when drawn therefrom; (TA;) and so XaxobN↓; (A, Ḳ;) which is also an inf. n.; (TA;) or this latter is an inf. n., (Ṣ, O,) and the former [is a subst. properly so called, and] signifies an extended stream of milk, (Ṣ, A, O,) like a thread, or string, (A,) when it is drawn from the udder; (Ṣ, A, O;) of the measure fuEolN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (A:) or the milk that comes forth from beneath the hand of the milker at each squeeze of the udder of the ewe or she-goat. (TA.) It is said in a prov., XuxobN fiI AlUinaMCi waXuxobN fiI AlOaroDi, (Ṣ, Meyd, A, O,) i. e. One extended stream of milk from the udder into the vessel, and one, &c. upon the ground: (Meyd:) applied to him who hits the mark one time and misses another time (Ṣ, Meyd, A, O) in what he says; or says right one time and wrong another time. (Meyd.) And in another prov., XuxobN TamaHa An extended stream of milk from the udder that has fallen upon the ground so as to be unprofitable; for such is the meaning of TamaHa in this case: applied to a man who has made a slip, or mistake: or it means a good hap that has escaped one's opportunity to avail himself of it. (Meyd.) See also the next paragraph.

XuxobapN A single stream of milk from the udder; (A, Ḳ;) pl. XixaAbN [q. v.]: (Ḳ;) or it signifies, (Ḳ,) or so XuxobN↓, (TA,) an extended stream of milk (Ḳ, TA) when it is drawn (TA) from the udder, streaming continuously (Ḳ, TA) between the vessel and the teat. (TA.)
XixaAbN Milk when it is drawn from the udder: (A, Ḳ: [in which latter it is also said to be pl. of XuxobapN:]) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)
wadajN XaxiybN † [An external jugular vein] cut so that its blood has flowed, or streamed, forth. (TA.)
OuXoxuwbN The sound of the streaming of milk. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

[And it seems to be used as an epithet; for it is added that] one says, Uin-ahaA laOuXoxuwbu AlOaHaAliyli [app. meaning Verily she is one whereof the orifices of the teats produce a sound by the streaming of the milk]. (Ṣ, O.)
maXoxabN: see the verse in the first paragraph {1}.

1. Xaxuta, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXoxutu}, inf. n. XuxuwtapN, (Ḳ,) said of a man, (Ṣ,) [and app., in like manner, of anything,] He [or it] was, or became, thin, or slender, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) lean, and lank in the belly, not in consequence of emaciation. (L, Ḳ.)
2. taXoxiytN The bringing, conveying, or causing to come; syn. UibolaAgN. (Ḳ.) One says, Xx-thu Uilayohi He brought it,, &c., to him. (TḲ.)

XaxotN and XaxiytN↓, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) the former also pronounced XaxatN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) by some, (TA,) applied to a man, (Ṣ,) Thin, or slender, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) lean, and lank in the belly, not in consequence of emaciation: (A, L, Ḳ:) slender in the body: fem. of the first with p {XaxotapN}: (TA:) pl. XixaAtN: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or XaxotN signifies thin, or slender, as applied to anything: thus it is applied to him who is thin, or slender, in the neck, and in the legs: one says, [of a beast,] Uin-ah laXaxotu AljuzaArapi Verily he is thin, or slender, in the legs: (TA:) and qawaAYimuhu XixaAtN His legs are thin, or slender: (A:) and HaTabN XaxotN Slender firewood. (TA.)
[Hence,] Uin-ahu laXaxotu AlEaTaMCi † Verily he is one who gives little. (TA.) And zayodN Xaxotu Alxuluqi ‡ Zeyd is low, ignoble, or mean, in natural disposition. (A, TA.)
Some say that it is arabicized, from the Pers. saxot. (TA.)
XaxatN: see the next preceding paragraph.
XaxiytN: see XaxotN:
sand also what here follows.
Xix-iytN and XaxytN↓ and XixotiytN Dust (gubaArN) rising, or spreading, or diffusing itself. (Ḳ.)
XixotiytN: see what next precedes.

1. Xaxara, aor. _i {yaXoxiru}, inf. n. XaxiyrN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and XaxorN, (Ḳ,) He raised his voice, with snorting; said of an ass: (Ṣ:) he uttered a sound from the fauces: or from the nose: (Ḳ:) or from the mouth, without the nose: (TA:) he (a horse) neighed: (Ḳ:) or uttered a sound after neighing: (TA:) or uttered a sound from his mouth, (Ḳ, TA,) without the nose: (TA:) Aṣ says that among the sounds made by horses are those termed XaxiyrN and naxiyrN and kariyrN; the first of which is from the mouth; the second, from the nostrils; and the third, from the chest: some say that Xaxara is like naxara [he snorted]. (TA.)
XaxorN The first period or stage of youth; (Ḳ, TA;) and the sharpness thereof; like XaroxN. (TA.)

The part, of a raHol [or camel's saddle], that is between the qaAdimap and the Mxirap, (O, Ḳ, TA,) which are the kar-aAni: (TA:) [said to be] also called the Xarox, [which is an evident mistake, perhaps originating from its having been said that XaxorN and XaroxN are syn., meaning in another sense, mentioned above,] (O, TA,) and the Xajor [q. v.]: (TA:) or the space between the upper part of the two extremities [at the fore part and hind part] of the [saddle called] qatab. (JK.)
And The chink of the buttocks. (JK, O. [In the Ḳ, for waXaxoru AlAisoti Xaq-uhaA, the reading in the JK and O, is put waXaxara AlAisota Xaq-ahaA.])

Xix-iyrN That utters much, or often, the sound termed naxiyr: (Ḳ:) or, as in some copies of the Ḳ [and in the O], Xaxiyr: (TA:) [see naxara and Xaxara:] applied to an ass in this sense, (O,) or as signifying vociferous. (TA.)

1. Xaxasa, aor. _a {yaXoxasu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XaxosN, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) It was, or became, conflicting, incongruous, or dissimilar, in its several parts; XaxosN being syn. with AiDoTiraAbN and AixotilaAfN [here used in the same, or nearly the same, sense]. (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ.)

Also, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above; (Lth, O, Ḳ;) or XAxs↓; (so says Lth, TA; and so in a copy of the A;) and tXAxs↓; (O, Ḳ;) said of an ass, (Lth, A, O, Ḳ,) He opened his mouth on the occasion of gaping (Lth, O, Ḳ) and smelling the urine of a she-ass: (Lth, O:) or he opened his mouth, raising his head, after smelling the dung. (A.) It is said that the primary signification of AlX-axosu is The opening of the mouth to gape. (Ḥam p. 196.)

hom.sense: 3. XAxs faAhu, said of time, It caused his teeth to become incongruous; (ISk, A, O;) some of them being long and some of them being broken: (ISk, O:) this is the case in extreme old age: (A, TA:) XixaAsN and muXaAxasapN, [as inf. ns. of the pass. verb,] in relation to the teeth, signify their being in such a condition that some of them incline and some of them have fallen out: (JK, TA:*) one says, [Xuwxisa faAhu, or Xuwxisato OasonaAnuhu, and] tXAxs↓ fuwhu, (A,) or tXAxst OasonaAnuhu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) His teeth became incongruous, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) and some of them inclined and some of them fell out, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) by reason of extreme old age. (Ṣ, A,* O, Ḳ.)
XAxs AlS-adoEa, said of the repairer of a wooden bowl, He made the crack of the bowl to incline, so that it remained not closed up. (O, Ḳ.)
See also 1.

entry.sense: 4. AXxs † He showed a sour, a crabbed, or an austere, face, (Aboo-Saʼeed, O, Ḳ,) lahu to him, (Aboo-Saʼeed, TA,) fiI AlmanoTiqi in speech; as also AXxS. (Aboo-Saʼeed, O, TA.)

And AXxshu, (O, Ḳ,) and AXxs bihi, (TA,) † He spoke evil of him behind his back, or in his absence, or otherwise, with truth, or though it might be with truth; syn. AigotaAbahu; (O, Ḳ, TA;) as also AXxS bh. (TA.)
6. tXAxs: see 1: and 3.
It (a crack in a wooden bowl) was made by the repairer to incline, so that it remained not closed up. (TA.)
tXAxs Alqawomu † The people, or party, became distant, or remote, one from another. (JK.)

tXAxs Oamoru Alqawomi † The state of affairs of the people, or party, became divided, (O, Ḳ,* TA,*) and conflicting, or inconsistent. (TA.) And tXAxs maA bayona Alqawomi † The state between the people, or party, became bad, or corrupt. (ISk, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.*)
XaxiysN † An affair, or a state of affairs, (OamorN,) disorganized, disordered, or unsettled; syn. mutafar-iqN. (Ḳ.)

† Speech in which is a sour, a crabbed, or an austere, look: (JK: [like XaxiySN:]) or ‡ incongruous, or discordant, speech; (O, Ḳ, TA;) as also mutaXaAxisN↓, (AʼObeyd, TA, in art. XxS,) and mutaXaAxiSN. (Ḳ ibid.)
[A man] adverse to that which he is commanded to do. (TA.)
mutaXaAxisN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: 1. XaxaSa, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXoxaSu}, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XuxuwSN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He, or it, rose; or became raised, or elevated. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] It (a star) rose. (Ḳ.) And XaxaSa lahu XaxoSN [A figure seen from a distance rose to his view]. (TA in art. zwl.)

XaxaSa baSaruhu (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, [in some copies of the Ḳ, baSarahu, but this occurs afterwards in that work,]) is said when a man opens his eyes and then does not move his eyelids; [and signifies ‡ His eyes, or lit., his eye, became fixedly open:] (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) or it signifies his eye became raised: (Mṣb:) or his sight became stretched and raised. (Mgh.) [See the Ḳur xiv. 43, and xxi. 97.] You say, XaxaSa Uilayoka baSariI ‡ [My eye, or eyes, became fixedly open, or raised, or my sight became stretched and raised, towards thee]. (A.) And XaxaSa baSaru Almay-iti, (A,) inf. n. as above, (IAth,) ‡ [The eye, or eyes, of the dying man became fixedly open: or] the eyelids of the dying man became raised upwards, and he looked intently, and became disquieted, or disturbed. (IAth.)
saxaSati Alkalimapu mina Alfami † The word, or sentence, rose [from the mouth] towards the palate: this is sometimes natural: i. e., one's raising his voice, and not being able to lower it. (Ḳ.)

XaxaSa Als-ahomu (inf. n. as above, Mṣb,) ‡ The arrow rose [so as to deviate] from the butt, or object of aim: (Ḳ:) or the arrow passed beyond the butt, or object of aim, going above it: (A, Mṣb:) or rose in the sky. (ISh.)

XaxaSa (aor. as above, Mṣb, and so the inf. n., Ṣ, Mṣb,) also signifies He went, or went away, from one town or country to another: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or he went forth from one place to another, (Mṣb,) or from his place of alighting or abiding: (TA:) or [so accord. to the TA, but in the Ḳ “and”] he journeyed upwards. (Ḳ, TA.) You say also, XaxaSa mino qawomihi He went forth from his people: and XaxaSa Uilayohimo he returned to them. (TA.)
Also, (M, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) It (a thing) rose; or swelled; or became swollen: (M:) it (a wound) rose, and became swollen: (M, Ḳ:) [it was, or became, protuberant, or prominent.]

XaxaSa baSarahu, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) or XaxaSa bibaSarihi, (Mgh,) or both, (TA, [in which it is said to be tropical,]) and XaxaSa bibaSarihi UilaI Als-amaMCi, (Mṣb,) or XaxaSa [alone], (so in a copy of the A, [in which it is mentioned among proper expressions,]) † He raised his eye, or sight, (Ḳ, TA,) towards the sky, and did not move his eyelids; said of a dying man: (TA:) or he stretched and raised his sight: (Mgh:) or he opened his eyes, (A, Mṣb,) and did not move his eyelids, (A,) or [looking fixedly,] not moving his eyelids. (Mṣb.)
yaXoxaSu biSawotihi falaA yaqodiru EalaI xafoDihi † [He raises his voice, and is not able to lower it]. (Ḳ.)

XuxiSa bihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) coordinate to EuniIa, (Ḳ,) or XuxiSa [alone], (so in a copy of the A,) or XaxiSa bihi OamorN, coordinate to taEiba, inf. n. XaxaSN, (Mṣb,) ‡ [He was disquieted by a thing that happened to him: or] a thing that disquieted him happened to him: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or a thing happened to him and disquieted him: (Mṣb:) as though he were raised from the ground by reason of his disquietude. (TA.) [See also 4.]

XaxuSa, aor. _u {yaXoxuSu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. XaxaASapN, or this is a simple subst., [for] ISd says, I have not heard a verb of which it may be the inf. n., (TA,) [if used, signifying] He (a man, Ṣ) was, or became, big, bulky, or corpulent. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. Xx-S AlX-aIoCa, (A,) inf. n. taXoxiySN. (TA,) ‡ He individuated the thing; syn. Eay-anahu. (A, TA.) [From XaxoSN, q. v.]

hom.sense: 4. AXxShu [He made him, or it, to rise, or become raised or elevated]. You say, AXxS nafosahu [He raised himself; or drew, or stretched, himself up]. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. Elb.)
AXxS bisahomihi ‡ He made his arrow to pass beyond the butt, or object of aim, going above it. (A.)

And AXxShu He made him to go, or go away, from one town or country to another: (Ṣ:) or to go forth from one place to another: (A,* Mṣb:) or to go, or journey: (A in art. syr:) or to journey upwards. (TA.)
‡ He disquieted him, (Ḳ, TA,) so that he went away from a place. (TA.) [See also 1.]
AXxS ‡ His (an archer's) arrow passed beyond the butt, or object of aim, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) going above it. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb.)
The time of his journeying, going away, or departing, came, or arrived. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

AXxS Uilayohi ‡ He showed him a sour, a crabbed, or an austere, face, or countenance; looked at him in a sour, a crabbed, or an austere, manner; (A, TA;) or so AXxS lahu, (TA in art. Xxs,) fiI AlmanoTiqi in speech; as also AXxs. (Aboo Saʼeed, O and TA in art. Xxs.)

AXxS bifulaAnK ‡ He spoke evil of such a one behind his back, or in his absence, or otherwise, with truth, or though it might be with truth; syn. AigotaAbahu; (Yaạḳoob on the authority of AO, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also AXxs. (AO, Yaạḳoob, Ṣ.)

entry.sense: XaxoSN The body, or bodily or corporeal form or figure or substance, (sawaAd,) of a man, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or some other object or thing, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) which one sees from a distance: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) applying in common to what is termed juv-apN and what is termed TalalN, in relation to a man; i. e., in relation to a man sitting or sleeping [or lying down], and in relation to a man standing erect: (Mṣb, voce juv-apN:) or it is applied only to a body, or material substance, composed, [not simple,] and having height: (El-Khaṭṭábee, Mṣb, TA:) or any body, or material thing or substance, [that is somewhat high, and conspicuous, or] having height and appearance: (IAth, TA:) pl. (of pauc., Ṣ) OaXoxuSN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and (of mult., Ṣ) OaXoxaASN [which is properly another pl. of pauc.] and XuxuwSN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and XixaASN. (TA.)

Then used as signifying † A man himself; a man's self, or person; his caAt; (Mṣb;) [i. e.,] a person; a being; an individual; syn. nafosN [also syn. with caAtN]; (L, TA;) as in the following verse of ʼAmr Ibn-Rabee'ah, cited by Sb:
fakaAna mijan-iI duwna mano kunotu Oat-aqiI
valaAvu XuxuwSK kaAEibaAni wamuEoSiru
† [And three persons, namely, two girls whose breasts were beginning to swell and one who had attained the age of puberty, were my shield against such as I was fearing]: meaning valaAvapu OanofusK: (L:) [the poet making the word in question fem. because it relates here to females: but] Rubeh is related to have said valaAvapu OaXoxuSK, meaning, of women. (M, voce nafosN.) A XaxoS [meaning a person] ceases to be a XxS by its being divided; whereas, when a jisom is divided, no part of it ceases to be a jsm. (Er-Rághib, TA in art. jsm.) It is said in a trad., laA XaxoSa Oagoyaru mina Qll-ehi ‡ [There is not any being more jealous than God]; XxS being here metaphorically used for caAt: or the meaning is, a person (XxS) should not be more jealous than God: but accord. to one relation, the words are laA XaIoCa Oagoyaru mina Qll-ehi [which has the first of the two meanings mentioned above]. (IAth, TA.) [It is also used in a pl. sense: see a verse of Ziyád el-Aajam in art. AlI.]
XaxiySN Big, bulky, or corpulent: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or great in XaxoS [or person] and make: (TA:) applied to a man: (Ṣ:) fem. with p {XaxiySapN}; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) applied to a woman. (Ṣ, A.)
A lord, master, chief, man of rank or quality, or a personage. (AZ, Ḳ.)
manoTiqN XaxiySN ‡ Sour, crabbed, or austere, speech. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, A, Ḳ. [See also XaxiysN.])
XaxaASapN Bigness, bulkiness, or corpulence: or greatness of XaxoS [or person] and make. (TA.) [Said to be a subst.: but see XaxuSa.]

hom.sense: XaAxiSN [part. n. of the intrans. verb XaxaSa]. [Hence,] baSarN XaAxiSN ‡ [An eye fixedly open: or raised: or sight stretched and raised: see 1]: you say, samiEotu biquduwmika faqalobiI bayona janaAHaI-a raAqiSN wabaSariI taHota HijaAjiI XaAxiSN ‡ [I have heard of thy coming, and my heart is throbbing between my two sides, and my eye beneath my bone of the eyebrow fixedly open,, &c.]. (A, TA.) With the pl., OaboSaArN, you say XaAxiSapN, (A, Mṣb, TA,) and XawaAxiSu, (A, TA,) or XuxuwSN [like XuhuwdN as pl. of XaAhidN; if not an inf. n., as which it may be applied, in the place of an epithet, to a pl. subst.]. (Mṣb.)

sahomN XaAxiSN ‡ An arrow passing beyond the butt, or object of aim, going above it. (Ṣ, A.) You say, rumiIa biAlX-aAxiSaAti ‡ [He was shot at with arrows which passed beyond him, going above him: perhaps doubly tropical, meaning he was assailed with invectives which did not harm him]. (A.)
XaAxiSN also signifies A man prosecuting war [during three or more days together,] not on alternate days: and of such it is said in a trad., that he may shorten prayer. (TA.)

XaAxiSN as the act. part. n. of the trans. verb, [for XaAxiSN baSarahu,] (Mṣb,) † [A man raising his eye, or sight, and looking fixedly; as does a dying man: or stretching and raising his sight: (see 1:) or] a man opening his eyes and not moving his eyelids. (Ṣ,* Mṣb.)

entry.sense: [maXoxaSN, as though signifying The place of a XaxoS used in the sense of Suwrapi: accord. to modern usage sing. of] maXaAxiSu deenárs [or pieces of gold] figured [or stamped with effigies]. (TA.)
muXax-aSN ‡ A thing individuated. (A, TA.)
mutaXaAxiSN Discordant; (AʼObeyd, Ḳ;) applied to language, or speech; (AʼObeyd, TA;) and to a thing, or an affair; (TA;) and mutaXaAxisN signifies the same. (AʼObeyd, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Xad-a, as an intrans. verb, aor. _i {yaXodidu}, inf. n. Xid-apN: see 8; and see also Xid-apN.

[Hence,] laXad-a maA is an expression used in the same sense as laEaz-a maA (A and Ḳ in art. Ez) and laHaq-a maA: (A and TA in that art.:) [and in like manner without the l: thus] one says, Xad-a maA Oan-aka caAhibN, meaning Haq-a Oan-aka caAhibN [i. e. It is distressing, or it distresses me, that thou art going away]: and if you please, you may consider Xad-a as similar to niEoma; as when you say, niEoma AlEamalu Oan-aka taquwlu AlHaq-a [Excellent, or most excellent, is the deed, thy saying the truth]. (Sb, TA.) [And it is also used to render intensive a verb following it; as in the saying, laXad-a maA OabogaDaniI Much indeed, or greatly indeed, did he hate me.]
