Xad-a Ealayohi,, aor. _a {yaXodadu} (Ṣ, L) and _i {yaXodidu}, (L,) inf. n. Xad-N (Ṣ, L) and XuduwdN, (L,) He charged, or made an assault or attack, upon him, in war, or battle. (Ṣ, L.) You say, Xad-a EalaI AlEaduw-i Xad-apF waAHidapF, and Xad-aAtK kaviyrapF, He made one charge, or assault, or attack, upon the enemy, and many charges,, &c. (L.) And Xad-a EalaI qironihi bisik-iynK, or biEaSFA, He made an assault, or attack, upon his adversary, with a knife, or with a staff; as also AXtd-↓ Ealayohi. (Mgh.) And Xad-a Alc-iYobu EalaI Alganami The wolf asaulted, or attacked, the sheep or goats. (L.) In the phrase, Xad-uwA AlUigaArapa, the meaning is Xad-uwA liloUigaArapi [They made a charge for the purpose of a sudden attack upon an enemy, or a predatory incursion]; and therefore AlAgArp is put in the accus. case, not as an objective complement. (Ḥam p. 8.)

Xad-a, (Ṣ,) aor. _u {yaXodudu} and _i, (TḲ,) inf. n. Xad-N, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) also signifies He ran; (Ṣ, L,* Ḳ;*) and so AXtd-↓. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) rub-a Xad-K fiI Alkurozi [Many a run is in the sack] is a prov., originating from the fact that a man riding a pregnant mare was pursued by an enemy, and she cast her foal, which ran with its mother, whereupon the horseman alighted, and carried it off in a sack; and the enemy overtook him, and said to him, “Throw to me the foal;” and he replied in these words, meaning that the foal was of generous race: it is applied to him whose internal, or intrinsic, qualities are commended. (Meyd.) And one says, Xad-a fiI AlEadowi, (A, Mgh, L,) inf. n. Xad-N; (L;) and AXtd-↓; (A, Mgh, L;) He hastened, or was quick, in running: (Mgh, L:) and Xad-a AlUiHoDaAra [meaning the same]. (Ṣ in art. Afr.)

Xad-a Aln-ahaAru, (Ṣ, L,) and AlD-uHaI, (L,) inf. n. Xad-N; (L, Ḳ; but in the latter, Aln-aAr is erroneously put for Aln-ahaAr; TA;) and AXtd-↓; (L;) The day, and the morning, became advanced, the sun being high. (Ṣ,* L, Ḳ.*) [See also Xad-N below.]

Xad-ahu, aor. _u {yaXodudu} (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb) and _i, the latter anomalous, for the aor. of a trans. verb of this class, of the measure faEala, should be _u only, and that of an intrans. verb of the same class and measure should be _i, and this is the only instance, or almost the only one, of its kind, with both of these forms of aor., except Eal-a [and bat-a] and nam-a AlHadiyva, but there is one trans. verb of the same class having the latter form of aor. only, namely, Hab-a, (Fr, Ṣ, L,) inf. n. Xad-N, (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He made it, or rendered it, hard; used in relation to substances and attributes: (L:) he made, or rendered, it, or him, firm, compact, or sound; and strong, powerful, or forcible; vigorous, robust, or sturdy; syn. OaHokamahu, (L,) and qaw-aAhu; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;*) as also Xd-dhu↓, [inf. n. taXodiydN,] i. e. as syn. with AHkmhu (L) and qw-Ahu: (Ṣ, A, L:) he bound, or tied, him, or it, firmly, fast, or strongly; syn. Oawovaqahu: [which may also be meant to convey the signification immediately preceding this last:] (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and [simply] he tied, bound, or made fast, him, or it; syn. rabaTahu. (Ṣ and Mṣb and Ḳ, &c. in art. rbT.)
One says, Xad-a EaDudahu i. e. He strengthened [his fore arm, or perhaps his upper arm, but the former is app. here meant]. (Ṣ, L.) And Xad-a EalaI yadihi He strengthened him, [lit. his arm, or hand,] and aided him. (L.) And Xad-a Qll-ehu mulokahu, and Xad-adahu↓, God strengthened, or may God strengthen, his dominion. (Ṣ, L. [See also a similar ex. voce OazorN.]) And Xad-a AlEuqodapa [He tied firmly or fast or strongly, or he pulled tight, or tightened, the knot], (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) and AlwavaAqa [the bond]. (Ḳur xlvii. 4.) [And Xad-a Ald-aAb-apa He bound the saddle on the beast: see an ex. voce daliylN.] Xad-u Alr-iHaAli [lit. The binding of the camels' saddles upon their backs] is a metonymical phrase for ‡ the going a journey. (Mgh, Mṣb.) And Xad-u AlmiYozari, occurring in a trad., [lit. The binding of the waist-wrapper upon the waist] is a metonymical phrase for ‡ the avoiding of women: or the exerting oneself, or employing oneself vigorously or laboriously, in work: or for both of these together. (L.) maA Oamoliku Xad-FA walaA UiroxaMCF [lit. I possess not power to tighten nor to slacken] means I am not able to do anything. (TA.) [And Xad-ahu also signifies He pressed, compressed, or squeezed, it: and he pulled, or strained, it.] waQXodudo EalaI quluwbihimo, in the Ḳur [x. 88], means And put Thou a seal upon their hearts, so that they may not heed admonition, nor be disposed, or directed, to that which is good. (L.)
OaXad-u laqado kaAna kacaA, as also OaXadu without teshdeed, means OaXohadu [q. v.]: (Ḳ:) a strange saying. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see the preceding paragraph {1}, latter half, in two places.

Xd-dhu, inf. n. taXodiydN, also signifies He made it, or rendered it, namely, a beating, and anything, hard to be borne, heavy, vehement, violent, intense, severe, strict, rigorous, or excessive; he intensified it, or aggravated it: (L:) taXodiydN is the contr. of taxofiyfN [in this sense and in other senses here following]. (Ṣ.) [Hence, the objective complement being understood,] one says, Xd-d Ealayohi, (A, Mṣb,) which is the contr. of xaf-afa [i. e. of xaf-afa Eanohu; thus meaning He rendered his burden, suffering, distress, uneasiness, or the like, hard to be borne, heavy, vehement, violent, intense, severe, strict, rigorous, or excessive; intensified it, or aggravated it; or he pressed hard upon him; treated him with hardness, strictness, severity, or rigour]: (Mṣb:) and mano Xad-ada Xad-ada Qll-ehu Ealayohi [Whoso treateth others hardly, God will treat him hardly]. (A. [See also 8.])

[taXodiydN, as opposed to taxofiyfN, also signifies The characterizing of a letter by a lengthened pronunciation equivalent in grammatical analysis and in prosody to doubling, denoted in writing by the sign called Xad-ap↓, i. e. by the sign - over that letter; as also tavoqiylN.]
See also sad-adahu.

3. XAd-hu, (A, L,) inf. n. muXaAd-apN and XidaAdN, (L,) He vied with him, contended with him for superiority, or strove to surpass him, in strength, power, or force. (A, L.) [Hence,] mano yuXaAdidi Ald-iyna yagolibohu, (A,) or mano yuXaAd-a hecaA Ald-iyna bigolibohu, i. e. Whoso contendeth for superiority in strength with this religion, and withstandeth it, or opposeth it, and tasketh himself with religious service beyond his power, it (the religion) will overcome him: a trad. (L.) And lano yuXaAd-a Ald-iyna OaHadN Uil-aA guliba No one shall contend for superiority in strength with religion,, &c. but he will be overcome by the religion. (Ḳ,* TA.)
See also 5.

hom.sense: 4. AXd-, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiXodaAdN, (Ḳ,) He, (a man, Ṣ, L, Ḳ,*) or they, (a company of men, A, L,) had, (A, L,) or had with him, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) [or had with them,] a strong beast, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) or strong beasts. (A, L.)
[maA OaXad-a kacaA How hard, hard to be borne, vehement, violent, intense, or the like, or how great, is such a thing!]

entry.sense: 5. tXd-d He acted, or behaved, with forced hardness, firmness, strength, vigour, hardiness, courage, vehemence, severity, strictness, or rigour; he exerted his strength, force, or energy; strained, or strained himself, or tasked himself severely; syn. taSal-aba; (A and TA in art. Slb;) and jahada nafosahu; (L;) [fiI AlX-aIoCi in the thing; as also XaAd-a↓ fiyhi; for] AlmuXaAd-apu fiI AlX-aIoCi and Alt-aXad-udu fiyhi signify the same: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:* [see an ex. of tXd-d in the first paragraph of art. jld:]) [and] both of these phrases signify the showing hardness,, &c., in the thing. (PṢ.) You say also tXd-d liloOamori He applied himself with hardness, firmness, vigour, hardiness, severity, or rigour, to the affair. (MA.) And taXad-adati Alqayonapu The slavesongstress strained herself, or tasked herself severely, in raising her voice in singing. (L.)

Also He (a man) was, or became, hard, or difficult: you say, saOalonaA fulaAnFA HaAjapF fataXad-ada EalayonaA [We asked of such a one a thing wanted, and he was hard, or difficult, to us]. (TA in art. wEr.)
And He was, or became, niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious. (MA, KL.)
6. tXAd-wA [They vied, contended for superiority, or strove to surpass one another, in strength, power, or force: see 3]. (TA in art. Hms: there coupled with AiqotataluwA.)
See also the next paragraph {8}.

8. AXtd-; (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb;) and Xad-a↓, aor _i, (L, Mṣb,) the only form of its aor., (L,) inf. n. Xid-apN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) whence the former verb; (Ṣ;) and tXAd-↓; (L;) It was, or became, hard, (L, and MA and KL and PṢ in explanation of the first,) said of a substance and of an attribute: (L:) it, or he, was, or became, firm, compact, or sound; (L, &c. as above;) strong, powerful, or forcible; vigorous, robust, or sturdy; (L, and A and MA and KL in explanation of the first, and Mṣb in explanation of the second:) [also it was, or became, bound, or tied, firmly, fast, or strongly:] and the first of these verbs, [and the second also,] it was, or became, hard to be borne, heavy, vehement, violent, intense, pressing, severe, strict, rigorous, tight, strait or difficult, distressing or distressful, afflictive, calamitous, or adverse. (MA, L, KL.) It is said in a trad., laA tabiyEuwA AlHab-a Hat-aI yaXotad-a i. e. [Ye shall not sell grain] until it becomes hard, or firm, or strong. (L.) And you say, AXtd-t AlEuqodapu [The knot became tied firmly, fast, or strongly; or became tight]. (A, Mgh, Mṣb.) And AXtd- Alz-amanu Ealayohimo The time, or fortune, became hard upon them; or severe, rigorous, distressful, afflictive, calamitous, or adverse, to them. (L. [See also 2.]) And AXtd- bihi AlOamoru [The affair, or event, distressed, or afflicted, him; like AXtd- Ealayohi]. (L in art. jd, &c.)
See also 1, former half, in four places.
Xad-N an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Ṣ, L, &c.)

[Hence,] Xad-u Aln-ahaAri, and Xad-u AlD-uHaI, The time when the day, and the morning, is advanced, the sun being high. (L.) One says, jiYotuka Xad-a Aln-ahaAri, and Xad-a AlD-uHaI, (L, and the like is said in the A,) and fiI Xad-i Aln-ahaAri, and fiI Xad-i AlD-uHaI, (L,) I came to thee in the time when the day, and the morning, was advanced, the sun being high. (A,* L.)

hom.sense: Xad-apN [inf. n. of un. of Xad-ahu: as such signifying] A single act [of making, or rendering, hard, firm, compact, or sound; strong, powerful, or forcible: and] of binding, or tying, firmly, fast, or strongly. (Mṣb.)
See also 2, last sentence but one.
Also [inf. n. of un. of the intrans. verb Xad-a: as such signifying] A single charge or assault or attack in war or battle. (Ṣ, A,* Mgh, L, Ḳ.*)

entry.sense:
Xid-apN inf. n. of Xad-a↓ (L, Mṣb) as syn. with AiXotad-a: (L:) [and] a subst. from [i. e. syn. with] AiXotidaAdN: (Ḳ:) The attribute denoted by the epithet XadiydN: (Ṣ:) hardness, (A, MA, L,) in substances and in attributes; (L;) firmness, compactness, or soundness; strength, power, or force; vigour, robustness, sturdiness, or hardiness; (MA, L; see OaXud-N, which, accord. to some, is a pl. of Xid-apN;) courage, bravery, firmness of heart: (L:) niggardliness, tenaciousness, or avarice: (A: [see also 5, last sentence:]) vehemence, violence, intenseness, stress, pressure, severity, strictness, rigour, tightness, straitness or difficulty: (MA:) hardship, rigour of fortune: (MA, L:) famine, dearth, want of victuals; hardness, straitness, or difficulty, of subsistence [&c.]: (L:) trouble, distress, affliction, calamity, or adversity; (MA, L;) as also [Xud-aI↓, in these as well as in some of the preceding senses, and] XadiydapN↓, [rather meaning a hard, or distressing, event, an affliction, or a calamity, and rarely used,] of which, (L,) or of Xid-apN, (MA, L,) the pl. is XadaAYidu, (MA, L,) agreeably with analogy if of XadiydapN, but extr. if of Xid-apN: and this pl. also signifies seditions, discords, or dissensions, whereby men are put into a state of commotion: (L:) and the rigours, or pangs, (gamaraAt,) of death: (Ṣ and Mṣb in art. gmr:) accord. to Sb, the pl of Xid-apN is XidadN, which, he says, preserves its original form [without idghám] because it does not resemble a verb. (L.) One says, qaAsayotu minohu Xid-apF [I endured, from him, hardness,, &c.; or from it, hardship,, &c.]. (A.) And xifotu Xud-aI↓ fulaAnK meaning Xid-atahu [i. e. I feared the hardness,, &c., of such a one]:
so says AZ: and he cites this verse:
faUin-iI laA Oaliynu liqawoli Xud-aI↓
walawo kaAnato OaXad-a↓ mina AlHadiydi
[And, or for, I will not become gentle for a hard saying, (lit. a saying of hardness,) though it should be harder than iron]. (L.) And OaSaAbatoniI Xud-aI↓ meaning Xid-apN [i. e. Hardship,, &c., befell me]. (AZ, Ṣ.) [And Xid-apN also signifies A strong, an intense, or a great, degree of any quality, &c.]
Xud-aI: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

XadiydN Possessing the quality of Xid-ap: (Ṣ, L:) i. e. hard; applied to a substance and to an attribute: firm, compact, or sound: (L:) strong, powerful, forceful; vigorous, robust, sturdy, or hardy; (A, Mgh, L, Mṣb;) applied to a thing, (Mṣb,) and to a man; (A, Mgh, L;) as also Xadiydu AlquwaI: (Mgh:) pl., applied to men, OaXid-aMCu and [applied to things and men] XidaAdN (A, L) and XududN, (Sb, L,) which last preserves its original form [without idghám] because not resembling a verb: (L:) also courageous, brave, firm of heart: (L, Ḳ:*) and niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious; (A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also mutaXad-idN↓: (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ:) and [as is implied by the first explanation above, and shown by frequent usage,] vehement, violent, intense, pressing, severe, strict, rigorous, tight, strait or difficult, hard as meaning hard to be borne, troublesome, distressing or distressful, afflictive, calamitous, or adverse. (L, KL, PṢ, &c.) You say, huwa XadiydN EalaI qawomihi [He is hard, or severe, or rigorous, to his people]. (A.) [And XadiydN EalaI kacaA Niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious, of such a thing.] Aboo-Dhu-eyb says, using Xadiyd in the sense of XaHiyH,
HadaronaAhu biAlOavowaAbi fiI qaEori huw-apK
XadiydK EalaI maA Dum-a fiI All-aHodi juwluhaA
[We lowered him, with the grave-clothes, into the bottom of a cavity in the ground, the sides whereof were tenacious of what was comprised in the lateral hollow which was the place of the corpse]. (L.) And the words of the Ḳur [c. 8], waUin-ahu liHub-i Alxayori laXadiydN, accord. to Zj, mean And verily, on account of the love of wealth, he is niggardly, or tenacious, or avaricious. (L.) Xadiydu AlEayoni applied to a man, and Xadiyodapu jafoni AlEayoni metaphorically applied by a poet to a she-camel, mean Whom sleep does not overcome. (L.) And AlX-adiydu means The lion; (Ḳ;) because of his strength and hardiness. (TA.) [Xadiyd with a subst. or an inf. n. following it in the gen. case, the latter having the article Al prefixed to it, or being prefixed to another noun in the gen. case, supplies the place of an intensive epithet; as in Xadiydu Als-awaAdi Intensely, or very, black; and Xadiydu AlgaDabi Vehemently, or exceedingly, or very, angry; and] misokN Xadiydu Alr-aAYiHapi Strong-smelling musk; (L;) [and rajulN Xadiydu bayaADi AlEayoni A man intensely white in the eye.]

AlHuruwfu AlX-adiydapu [The strong letters] are those letters which, in a state of quiescence, prevent the current of the voice in their utterance; namely O, b, t, j, d, T, q, and k; (TA;) the letters comprised in the words Oajadota Tabaqaka. (Ḳ.)
XadiydapN [as a subst. from XadiydN, rendered such by the affix p]: see Xid-apN.

OaXad-u [Possessing the quality of Xid-ap, in a greater, and in the greatest, degree; i. e. more, and most, hard,, &c.]. See an ex. in a verse cited voce Xid-apN. Halabota biAls-aAEidi AlOaXad-i, or HalabotuhaA Alx, is a prov., expl. in art. Hlb. And baqiIa OaXad-uhu. [The hardest part of it has remained] is another prov., applied to him who attains a part of that which he wants, and is unable to attain the completion thereof. (TA. [See also Freytag's “Arab. Prov.,” i. 169.]) [With an indeterminate subst. or inf. n. following it in the accus. case, it supplies the place of a simple epithet denoting the comparative and superlative degrees; as in OaXad-u sawaAdFA More, and most, black; and OaXad-u gaDabFA More, and most, angry.]
OaXad-u Aln-ahaAri The time when the day is most advanced, the sun being at the highest. (L. [See Xad-u Aln-ahaAri.])

OaXud-N, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, L, Ḳ, &c.,) also pronounced OuXud-N, (Seer, Ḳ,) but the latter form is rare, (TA,) is both masc. and fem., (Zj, TA,) and as used in the Ḳur it has somewhat different meanings: (Az, TA:) in the phrase Hat-aI yaboluga OaXud-ahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and other phrases in the Ḳur, (TA,) OaXud- is expl. as meaning The state of strength; (Ṣ, Mgh, L, Ḳ;) which is from eighteen to thirty years: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or from about seventeen to forty: (Zj:) or from thirty to forty: (Zj in another place:) or puberty: (Az, Mgh, L:) or firmness, or soundness, of judgment, produced by experience: (L:) or puberty together with such maturity as gives evidence of rectitude of conduct or course of life; (Zj, Az, Mgh, L;) which may be at, or before, the age of eighteen years; accord. to most of the men of science, and among them Esh-Sháfiʼee; (Zj, Az, L;) and the extreme term of which is three and thirty years: (Mgh:) or the age of forty years; as in the Ḳur xlvi. 14: (L:) OaXud-N [originally OaXodudN] is a sing. having a pl. form, like MnukN; and these two words are [said to be] the only instances of the kind: (Ṣ, Ḳ: [but see MnukN:]) or a pl. having no proper sing., (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) like MsaAlN and OabaAbiylu and EabaAdiydu and macaAkiyru: (Ṣ:) or its sing. is Xid-apN↓, (AHeyth, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) accord. to Sb; and this is good with respect to the meaning, because one says, balaga AlgulaAmu Xid-atahu; (Ṣ;) but fiEolapN does not form a pl. of the measure OafoEulN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) for as to OanoEumN, (Ṣ,) which is said by AHeyth to be pl. of niEomapN, (TA,) [and respecting which Mṭr says that] OaXud-N is said to be pl. of Xid-apN like as OanoEumN is of niEomapN, formed by regarding the p as elided, (Mgh, [and AHeyth says the like,]) it is only pl. of nuEomN in the phrase yawomu nuEomK: (Ṣ:) or its sing. is Xad-N, like as kalobN is of OakolubN; or Xid-N, like as ciYobN is of OacoWubN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) accord. to some; (Ṣ;) but neither Xad-N nor Xid-N has been heard from the Arabs [as sing. of OaXud-N]; and they are only deduced from analogy: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or it is pl. of OaXad-u; and the O is not regarded in the formation of this pl. (IJ, from AʼObeyd.)
maXad-u AlEiSaAbapi [The place, or part, where the fillet, or the like, is bound, or tied]. (A.)

muXid-N A man having, (A, Mgh, L,) or having with him, (L,) a strong beast, (A, Mgh, L,) or strong beasts; (L;) contr. of muDoEifN. (Mgh, L.) It is said in a trad., yarud-u muXid-uhumo EalaI muDoEifihimo [He among them who has a strong beast, or strong beasts, shall give back a portion of the spoil to him of them who has a weak beast, or weak beasts]; meaning that the strong warrior and plunderer shall share with (yusaAhimu) the weak in the plunder that he gains. (L.)
mutaXad-idN: see XadiydN.

hom.sense: 1. Xadaxa, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, &c.,) aor. _a {yaXodaxu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,*) inf. n. XadoxN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) He broke, or crushed, syn. kasara, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and faDaxa, (TA, and Ḥam p. 363,) or haX-ama, (TA,) a hollow thing, (Ṣ, A, L, TA,) or a soft, or tender, or an easily-broken, thing, (A,) or a moist thing, (Ḳ,) or a moist and soft thing, such as the Earofaj and the like, (L, TA,) a person's head, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, TA,) and a colocynth, and an unripe date, (A,) and any hollow bone, and a rod, (Mṣb,) or, as some say, a dry thing, (Ḳ,) with the hand, or with a stone, &c.: (Ḥam ubi suprà:) or he pressed, or squeezed, syn. gamaza, [app. so as to crush,] a hollow thing, or a soft, or tender, or an easilybroken, thing, as a head, and a colocynth, and an unripe date. (A.)

[Hence,] Xadaxa dimaMCahumo taHota qadamihi ‡ He made their blood (lit. bloods) to go for nothing, or to be of no account. (A, Ḳ.*) And [simply] Xadaxa Ald-imaMCa † He made the blood [of men] (lit. bloods) to go for nothing, unretaliated, or uncompensated by mulcts; or to be of no account. (Ḥam p. 91.) And Xadaxotu Ald-iyaAta taHota qadamaI-a † I made the bloodwits to be of no account [so that they should not be exacted]. (Ḥam ibid.)
And Xadaxahu He hit, or hurt, his muXad-ax, i. e. the part of the neck so called. (Ḳ.)

And Xadaxa aor. _a {yaXodaxu}, (TA,) inf. n. XadoxN (Ḳ, TA) and XuduwxN, (TA,) He, (a man, TḲ,) or it, (a thing, or an affair, TA,) deviated, or declined, (Ḳ, TA,) from the right course, aim, or scope, (TA,) or from the [proper] way. (AO, TA.)

Xadaxati Algur-apu, (Ṣ, TA,) aor. _a {yaXodaxu}, (TA,) inf. n. XadoxN (Ḳ, TA) and XuduwxN, (TA,) The blaze on the horse's forehead spread widely upon the face (Ṣ) [from the forelock to the nose, without reaching to the eyes: see XaAdixapN]: or spread, and extended downwards, (Ḳ, TA,) filling the forehead, without reaching to the eyes: or covered the face from the root of the forelock to the nose. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. Xad-axotu Alr-uWuwsa I broke, or crushed, the heads; or did so much: the verb is with teshdeed to denote muchness, or frequency, or application to many objects. (Ṣ, TA.)
[And Xd-x Albusora He pressed, or squeezed, the unripe dates, so as to crush them: see muXad-axN.]
5: see what next follows {7}.

7. AnXdx It was, or became, broken, or crushed; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) said of a hollow thing, (Ṣ, A, TA,) or a soft, or tender, or an easily-broken thing, (A,) or a moist thing, (Ḳ,) or a moist and soft thing, (TA,) a person's head, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, TA,) a colocynth, and an unripe date, (A,) and any hollow bone, and a rod, (Mṣb,) or, as some say, a dry thing; (Ḳ;) and so tXd-x↓ [but app. implying muchness, or frequency, or relation to many things, as quasi-pass. of 2, q. v., whereas the former verb is quasi-pass. of 1]: (Ḳ:) or it was, or became, pressed or squeezed [app. so as to be crushed; or it was, or became, crushed by being pressed or squeezed: see muXad-axN]. (A.)
XadaxN An abortive fœtus, (L, Ḳ, TA,) in a soft, or tender, state, before it has become firm. (L, TA.)
See also XaAdixN, in two places.
XadoxapN A soft, or tender, or succulent, plant: (Ḳ:) applied in the M as an epithet to the species of plant called Eijolap. (TA.)

hom.sense: XaAdixN A child that is soft, or tender; (Ḳ;) as also XadaxN↓: (IAạr, L:) or gulaAmN XaAdixN signifies a youth: (A:) accord. to IAạr, a boy is called jaforN; then, yaAfiEN; then, XadaxN↓; then, muTab-ixN; and then, kawokabN. (TA. [See also muTab-ixN.])
Also A thing, or an affair, deviating from the right course, aim, or scope, (Ḳ, TA,) or from its [proper] way. (AO, TA.)
See also the next paragraph.

entry.sense: XaAdixapN, [as a subst.,] (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, TA,) or gur-apN XaAdixapN↓, (A,) A blaze on a horse's forehead spreading [widely (see 1)] upon the face, (Ṣ,) or covering the face, (A,) from the forelock to the nose, (Ṣ, A,) without reaching to the eyes: (Ṣ:) or spreading, and extending downwards, (Ḳ, TA,) filling the forehead, without reaching to the eyes: or covering the face from the root of the forelock to the nose: (TA:) or such as is long; such as is round being called watiyrapN. (AO, TA.)

[Hence,] † A notorious, and a bad, or an evil, an abominable, or a foul, deed. (Ṣ, TA.) A rájiz says,
laA hum-a Uin-a AlHaAriva bona jabalaho
zan-aI EalaI Oabiyhi vum-a qatalaho
warakiba AlX-aAdixapa AlmuHaj-alaho
i. e. [O God, (laAhum-a being for Aall-ehum-a,) verily El-Hárith Ibn-Jebeleh straitened, or oppressed, his father, (zan-aI being for zan-aOa,) then slew him,] and committed a bad and notorious deed in slaying him. (Ṣ.)
OaXodaxu A horse having a blaze such as is termed XaAdixapN: fem. XadoxaMCu. (Ḳ, L, TA.)
AlOaXodaxu The lion. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: muXad-axN Unripe dates pressed, or squeezed, (yugomazu, in some copies of the Ṣ and Ḳ and in the L and TA yugomaru, [but the former I think to be evidently the right reading,]) until they become broken or crushed (yanoXadixu), (Ṣ, A,* L, Ḳ,) and dried for the winter, (A,) or then dried in the winter. (L.)
AlmuXad-axu i. q. muqaT-aEu AlEunuqi [app. meaning The part of the neck where it is cut up by the butcher]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: miXodaAxN [A post-classical term] A surgical instrument with which the head of the fœtus is crushed [in the womb]. (Albucasis de Chirurgia, p. 342.)
1. Xadiqa, inf. n. XadaqN, said of a man, He was wide in the Xidoq [q. v.]. (M, TA.*)
And He was eloquent. (TA.)

5. tXd-q He twisted his XidoqaAni, [i. e. the two sides of his mouth, or the quivering flesh of his mouth, inside his cheeks,] in order to affect clearness, or distinctness, of speech, or to be more clear, or distinct, in speech. (Ḳ.) And tXd-q fiI kalaAmihi He opened his mouth and was diffuse in his speech. (M, TA.)
XadoqN: see what next follows.

XidoqN (Lth, Ṣ, M, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XadoqN↓ (Lth, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) The quivering flesh (TafoTafap) of the mouth, inside the two cheeks; (Lth, O, Ḳ;) or so the dual of each: (M:) or the side of the mouth; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) so says Az: (Mṣb:) pl. (of the former, Ṣ, Mṣb) OaXodaAqN (Lth, Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and (of the latter, Mṣb, TA) XuduwqN. (M, Mṣb, TA.) One says, nafaxa fiI Xidoqayohi [He blew in the sides of his mouth so as to distend them]. (Ṣ.) And Uin-ahu lawaAsiEu AlOaXodaAqi, meaning [Verily he is wide] in the Xidoq; using the pl. as a sing.; a phrase mentioned by Lḥ. (M, TA.) XidoqaA Alfarasi means The chink of the mouth of the horse, to the extremity thereof at [the place of] the bit [on each side]. (M.) tarokabu XidoqahaA mina Aln-aXaATi [app. meaning † She goes at random, (like tarokabu raOosahaA,) by reason of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness,] is said of a woman and of a she-camel and of a mare. (Ḳ voce miDoraArN.)
XadaqN [mentioned above as inf. n. of 1] Wideness of the Xidoq: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, as in the T, wideness of the XidoqaAni. (TA.)
And Eloquence. (Ṣ,* TA.)
and † A bending, or winding, in a valley. (TA.)
XidaAqN A certain brand with which a camel is marked upon the Xidoq. (M, TA.)
XadiyqN: see XidoqN, in two places.
XadoqamN and XadoqamiI-N: see the next paragraph; the former in three places: and see also art. Xdqm.

OaXodaqu A man wide in the Xidoq: (M:) or a man wide in the XidoqaAni: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or wide in the Xidoq, and inclining therein in any manner: (TA:) fem. XadoqaMCu: (M, Ḳ:) and pl. XudoqN: (Ḳ:) and XadoqamN↓ and XadoqamiI-N↓ signify the same as OaXodaqu; the m being augmentative, as in fusoHumN and sutohumN; or, accord. to IJ, it is radical: (M, TA:) whence, i. e. from XadoqamN in the sense expl. above, (I’Ab, TA,) one says also XidoqN XadoqamN↓, meaning a wide Xdq: (I’Ab, M, TA:) and XafapN XadoqaMCu means a lip wide in the part where each Xidoq is cleft [by the extremity of the mouth]. (M, TA.)
It is also applied as an epithet to an orator, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) meaning Eloquent; (M, Ḳ, TA;) good and eloquent in speech; (M,* TA;) and so XadoqamN↓. (TA.)
mutaXad-iqN One who twists his XidoqaAni in order to affect clearness, or distinctness, of speech, or to be more clear, or distinct, in speech. (Ṣ. [See 5.])

Diffuse in speech, without preparation, or caution, or precaution: or one who ridicules men, twisting his XidoqaAni with them and against them. (TA.) And mutaXad-iqN fiI manoTiqihi Diffuse in his speech. (TA.)

XadoqamN Wide in the Xidoq [or side of the mouth]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) applied to a man; as also XadoqamiI-N↓; (TA;) and XudaAqimN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) [mentioned under this head in the Ṣ and Ḳ, but] the m is augmentative. (Az, Ṣ.) It has been erroneously said that it is with the pointed c. (MF.)
See also OaXodaqu.
Also The lion; (Ḳ;) and so XudaAqimN↓. (IB, TA.)
And A certain stallion-camel belonging to En-Noamán Ibn-El-Mundhir: whence Xadoqimiy-aAtN↓ Certain camels, so called in relation to that stallion. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
XadoqamiI-N and Xadoqamiy-aAtN: see the preceding paragraph.
XudaAqimN: see the first paragraph, in two places.

1. Xadana, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXodunu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. XuduwnN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) said of a gazelle, and of the young of any cloven-hoofed animal, and camel, and solid-hoofed animal, He became strong, and in no need of his mother: (Ḳ:) or he became strong, and in a good state of body, and active and grown up, and vied with his mother in his faculties [so I render maAlaka Oum-ahu of which I do not find any explanation] so that he went along with her;
and [in this sense] it is said of a colt also: (TA:) or, said of a young gazelle, he became strong, and his horns came forth, and he became in no need of his mother: and sometimes it is said of a colt [in a similar sense]. (Ṣ.) Hence, it is said of a boy, meaning He became strong, and active and grown up. (Ḥar p. 536.)
4. AXdnt She (a gazelle) had a young one that had become such as is termed XaAdin. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

XadonN A kind of tree, (Ḳ, TA,) having weak, or soft, and thick stems, (TA,) the flower of which is like the jasmine (Ḳ, TA) in form, but tinged with redness, and more pleasant [in odour] than the jasmine; said by IB to be of pleasant odour. (TA.)

Xadaniy-aAtN Certain she-camels, so called in relation to a place in El-Yemen, (Ṣ, Ḳ, and EM p. 229,) named Xadan: (TA, EM:) or in relation to a certain stallion. (IAạr, Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, faHolN is erroneously put for faHolK.])

XaAdinN A young gazelle that has become strong, and whose horns have come forth, and that has become in no need of his mother: (AʼObeyd, TA: [see XaSarN:]) when used alone, [not as an epithet, in which quality it seems to be applied also to the young of any cloven-hoofed animal, and camel, and solid-hoofed animal, (see 1,)] it means [simply] a young gazelle. (Ṣ, TA.)

muXodinN [without p] A doe-gazelle whose young one has become such as is termed XaAdin: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or who has a XaAdin following her: and in like manner applied to other animals of the clovenhoofed kind, and of the solid-hoofed, and to a camel: (TA:) pl. maXaAdinu and maXaAdiynu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like maTaAfilu and maTaAfiylu, (Ṣ,) [pls. of muTofilN,] the latter pl. anomalous. (TA.)
maXoduwnapN, applied to a girl, i. q. EaAtiqN [i. e. That has newly attained to puberty, and has not been married; or that is between the periods of puberty and middle age;, &c.]. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. Xudiha, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. XadohN, (Ṣ,) He (a man, JK, Ṣ) became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; or became bereft of his reason or intellect; i. q. duhiXa: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and also, (Ḳ,) or, accord. to AZ, only, (Ṣ,) he was, or became, busied, occupied, or employed; or busied,, &c., so as to be diverted from something; or diverted from a thing by being busied; syn. Xugila: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and he was caused to become confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; (Ḳ;) as also AnXdh↓, or AXtdh↓, (Ḳ, accord. to different copies: the former accord. to the TA.) Accord. to Az, XadohN is not from Ald-ahaXu, as it is thought to be by some [and as is implied by what here follows]. (TA.)

Xadahahu He confounded, or perplexed, him, so that he was unable to see his right course; or bereft him of his reason or intellect; syn. OadohaXahu; (Ḳ;) as also AXdhhu↓: (AʼObeyd, Ḳ:) or the former verb, in the act. form, has not been heard: (Ḥar p. 64:) and [it is asserted that] one does not say AXdhhu↓. (JK.)
Xadaha raOosahu i. q. Xadaxahu [i. e. He broke his head]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4: see the preceding paragraph {1}, in two places.
7: see 1, first sentence.
8: see 1, first sentence.
XadohN: see what next follows.

XudohN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and XadahN↓ (Ṣ, and so in some copies of the Ḳ and in the TA) and XadohN↓ (so in some copies of the Ḳ in the place of the second, and in others together with the second, and in the TA) [app. A state of confusion, or perplexity, so that one is unable to see his right course; or a state of alienation of mind;] substs. from Xudiha: (Ṣ: [but in the Ḳ they are mentioned after Xadahahu and OaXodahahu meaning OadohaXahu, and maXaAdihu meaning maXaAgilu, as being the substs.; so that they may signify as above, and also business, occupation, or employment,, &c.; agreeably with renderings in the TḲ:]) and XudaAhN↓ is a subst. from Xudiha [app. in the former, or in both, of these senses]. (Ḳ.)
XadahN: see the next preceding paragraph.
XudaAhN: see the next preceding paragraph.

maXoduwhN A man confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; or bereft of his reason or intellect. (Ṣ, TA. [But accord. to AZ, it seems to signify only maXoguwlN, i. e. Busied, occupied, or employed,, &c.: see 1, first sentence.])

maXaAdihu [a pl. of which the sing. is app. maXodahapN] Things that cause one to be busied, occupied, or employed; or busied,, &c., so as to be diverted from something; or diverted from a thing by being busied; syn. maXaAgilu [pl. of maXogalapN]. (Z, Ḳ.)
1. XadaA, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) first pers. Xadawotu, (Ṣ,) aor. _u {yaXoduwu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. XadowN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He drove camels: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he collected and drove a detached number of a herd of camels. (Mṣb.)

Hence, (Mṣb,) XadaA, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) † He acquired somewhat of polite literature, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) or of science, and guided himself thereby to the knowledge of somewhat more, (Mṣb,) and likewise of song; (TA;) as though he drove it and collected it: (Ṣ, TA:) or XadaA mina AlEilomi, and mina AlginaMCi, (MA, TA,) XayoYFA, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (MA, TA,) he acquired somewhat of science, and of song: (MA:) or he knew well some sort of science, and of song; and so of other things. (TA.) XadowN signifies † A man's doing well, or knowing well, somewhat of a thing or an affair. (TA.) And Xadawotu minohu baEoDa AlmaEorifapi means I knew [somewhat of] him, or it, [but] not well. (TA.)

Also † He recited a verse, or two verses, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) singing, (Ḳ,) or prolonging, or straining, his voice, as in singing [and as is commonly done in the driving of camels; whence, app., this meaning of the verb]. (Ṣ.) And XadaA XiEorFA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or ginaMCF, (Ṣ,) † He sang poetry, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or a song: (Ṣ:) or he recited it with a trilling, or quavering, or prolonging and modulating of the voice. (Ṣ.)

And XadaA Xadowahu i. q. naHaA naHowahu † [He tended, repaired, betook himself, or directed his course, towards him, or it; agreeably with the explanation in the TḲ: or he purposed his (another's) purpose]. (Ḳ.)
And XadaA fulaAnFA fulaAnFA † He assimilated such a one to such a one; or he likened such a one to such a one; syn. Xab-ahahu Uiy-aAhu. (ISd, Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, fulaAnFA is not repeated.])
4. AXdI † He became a good, or an excellent, modulator of his voice, or maker of melody. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: XadFA A remnant of strength; and a portion, or somewhat, thereof: (Ḳ:) a dial. var. of XacFA. (TA. [See XacaApN, in art. Xcw.]) A remnant, or remainder, of anything. (TA.) A small quantity or number: (TA:) and so XadowN↓, (M, Ḳ,) whatever it be, (M, TA,) of much or many, (M, Ḳ,) whatever the latter be. (Ḳ.) And The extremity of anything: (Ḳ:) a dial. var. of XacFA. (TA.)
Also Heat. (Ḳ.)
And Mange, or scab: (Ḳ: [in the CK, AlHarobu is put for Aljarabu:]) a dial. var. of XacFA. (TA.)

entry.sense: XadowN: see the next preceding paragraph.
XaAdK act. part. n. of 1; signifying Driving, or a driver of, camels:, &c.: (Ḳ,* TA:) pl. XudaApN. (TA.)
[And particularly] † One who acquires somewhat of polite literature, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and of science, and guides himself thereby to the knowledge of somewhat more. (Mṣb.)
Also † A reciter of verses, who sings in reciting, or prolongs, or strains, his voice, as in singing: a singer of poetry: (TA:) [and simply] a singer. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 1. Xac-a, (Ṣ, M, A, &c.,) aor. _i {yaXocicu} and _u {yaXocucu}, (Ṣ, M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former agreeable with analogy, and that which is mentioned by the leading writers on inflection, and the latter anomalous, (TA,) and Esh-Shiháb mentions _a, but this is not known, and there is no reason for it unless faEila be established as a form of the pret., and this has not been mentioned, (MF,) inf. n. XucuwcN (Ṣ, M, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Xac-N, (M, L, Ḳ,) It (a thing, M, L) was, or became, apart, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb,) and it fell, or went, or came, out, or forth, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) from the generality of things, or the general assemblage, main body, bulk, or common mass, (Ṣ, M, A, L, Ḳ,) to which it pertained, (M, L,) or from other things: (Mṣb:) it (anything) was, or became, apart, or alone: and he (a man) was, or became, apart from his companions, or alone: (Lth, L:) and † he [app. a beast] took fright, and ran away. (Mṣb.) You say, Xac-a Eanohu It was, or became, apart,, &c., from it. (Ṣ, L.) And Xac-a Eani AljamaAEapi He was, or became, apart from the collective body [or generality] of people. (Mgh.) And maA yaXic-u Ealayohi XaIoCK † [Nothing is out of his way, or sphere, or compass]. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. Hwc.) And Xac-a AlHaSaI The pebbles became scattered, or dispersed. (L.)

Xac-a,, aor. _i {yaXocicu} and _u {yaXocucu}, inf. n. XucuwcN and Xac-N, also signifies ‡ It (a word, form or measure, construction, or government,) deviated from the common, or constant, course of speech in respect of analogy, or rule; deviated from common, or constant, analogy, or rule; was extraordinary, or exceptional, as to rule; or was anomalous, abnormal, or irregular: and it (the same) deviated from the common, or constant, course of speech in respect of usage; deviated from common, or constant, usage; was extraordinary, or exceptional, as to usage; or was unusual: [the verb is used absolutely to express each of these meanings; the context in general showing clearly which meaning is intended: the former is that which is most frequently intended: and] the former meaning is also expressed by the phrase Xac-a fiI AlqiyaAsi or Eani AlqiyaAsi: and the latter, by the phrase Xac-a fiI AlAisotiEomaAli. (Mz, 12th nwE.) [See also the contr. AiT-arada: and see XaAc-N, below.]
See also 4.

entry.sense: 2: see what next follows {4}.

4. AXc-hu; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and Xc-chu↓; (Ḳ;) and Xac-ahu↓, aor. _u {yaXocucu} only; (M, Ḳ;) but Aṣ disallows this last form of the verb; (IJ, L;) He, or it, caused it to be, or to become, apart, (Ṣ, L,) to fall, or go, or come, out, or forth, from the generality of things, or the general assemblage, main body, bulk, or common mass, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) to which it pertained: (M, L:) and the first signifies he removed it, and put it far away; namely, a thing: (Ḳ:) and he set him, or exposed him, apart from his companions, or alone: (IJ, L:) and he scattered, or dispersed, it. (IḲṭṭ.) A poet says,
faOaXac-aniI limuruwrihimo fakaOan-aniI
guSonN liOaw-ali EaADidK Oawo EaASifi
[And he, or it, (perhaps meaning fortune,) exposed me apart from my companions, to their passing by, or by reason of their passing away, so that I was as though I were a branch that should become a prey for the first lopper or stormy wind]. (IJ, L.) And one says of a she-camel, AXc-t AlHaSaI She scattered, or dispersed, the pebbles [with her feet]. (TA.)
AXc- also signifies jaMCa biqawolK XaAc-K↓ naAd-K † [He said what deviated from the common course of speech]. (Ḳ, TA.)
Xac-aAn: see XaAc-N, in four places.
Xic-aAnN The [species of lote-tree called] sidor. (Ḳ.)

XaAc-N A thing that is, or becomes, apart, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb,) and that falls, or goes, or comes, out, or forth, from the generality of things, general assemblage, main body, bulk, or common mass, (Ṣ, L,) to which it pertains: (L:) anything apart, or alone: and a man apart from his companions, or alone: (Lth, L:) and [app. a beast] taking fright, and running away: (Mṣb:) Xuc-aAnN is a pl. thereof, like as Xub-aAnN is of XaAb-N; [and so is Xuc-aAcN, agreeably with analogy;] and Xac-aAn↓ is used in a similar sense, but is an epithet of the measure fiEolaAn, not a pl. of XaAc-N. (L.) maA yadaEu fulaAnN XaAc-FA walaA naAd-FA Uil-aA qatalahu [Such a one does not leave any one apart from his companions, nor any one taking fright and running away, but he slays him,] is said of a courageous man whom no one encounters without his slaying him. (IAạr, L.) And one says Xuc-aAnu qawomK Those, of a people, who have become apart, or separate, from their companions. (L, from a trad.) And Xuc-aAcu Aln-aAsi Those who are among a people but do not belong to their tribes (Ṣ, L) nor to their places of abode: (L:) and those who are scattered, or dispersed, of people; (A, L;) as also Xac-aAnu↓ Aln-aAsi, (Ṣ, L,) and Xuc-aAnuhumo. (L.) And qawomN Xuc-aAcN A people not among their own tribe nor in their own places of abode: (L, Ḳ:*) or a people among another people, not among their own tribes nor in their own places of abode. (M, TA.) And Xuc-aAcu AlMfaAqi The strangers. (Ḥar p. 352.) And jaAWuwA Xuc-aAcFA They came few in number. (L, Ḳ.*) And Xac-aAnu↓ AlUibili and Xuc-aAnuhaA Those that are scattered, or dispersed, of the camels. (L.) And Xuc-aAnu AlHaSaI (M, L) and Xac-aAnu↓ AlHaSaI (Ṣ, IJ, M, L, Ḳ) What are scatterred, or dispersed, of pebbles; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) what have flown about, and become scattered or dispersed, thereof: (M, L:) and in like manner one says of other things, (L, Ḳ,) or of similar things. (M, L.)

Applied to a word, form or measure, construction, or government, it signifies ‡ Deviating from the common, or constant, course of speech in respect of analogy, or rule; deviating from common, or constant, analogy or rule; extraordinary, or exceptional, as to rule; or anomalous, abnormal, or irregular: such a word, &c., though itself admitted if agreeable with common usage, is not taken as an example to be imitated: also, applied to the same, deviating from the common, or constant, course of speech in respect of usage; deviating from common, or constant, usage; extraordinary, or exceptional, as to usage; unusual: [used absolutely to express each of these significations; the context in general showing clearly which signification is meant: the former is that which is most frequently intended:] a word, &c., may be XAc- in respect of usage but agreeable with common analogy or rule; as the pret. of yacaru and yadaEu; and the regular phrase makaAnN muboqilN, the epithet more commonly heard being baAqilN: and XAc- in respect of analogy, or rule, but agreeable with common usage; as OaxowaSa Alr-imovu, and AisotaSowabotu AlOamora: and XAc- in respect of analogy, or rule, and of usage, together; as vawobN maSowuwnN, and misokN madowuwfN: (Mz, 12th nwE: [and the like is said, but less fully, in the Mṣb:]) the pl. masc. is Xuc-aAcN; and pl. fem. XawaAc-u. (Mz, ib.) See 4, last sentence. [See also the contr. muT-aridN: and see Xac-a, latter part.]

Applied to a tradition, † Having a single ascription, attested by a [single] sheykh, whether he be trustworthy or not: in the latter case, not accepted: in the former case, one hesitates respecting it, and does not adduce it as an argument, or evidence. (KT.)

1. Xacaba, aor. _i {yaXocibu} and _u {yaXocubu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XacobN, (TA,) He stripped off, or removed, the bark of a tree; as also Xc-b↓, inf. n. taXociybN: (Ḳ:) he cut off portions of a tree, or the bark thereof. (TA.) He cut, or cut off, a thing; (O, Ḳ;) aor. _i {yaXocibu}, inf. n. XacobN. (O.) He cut, or lopped, a tree: or he divested it of its bark. (A.) He pruned, or pared, a tree by cutting off its Xacab, i. e. its straggling branches, or its thorns, or its bark; aor. _i {yaXocibu}, inf. n. XacobN; and Xc-b↓ has the like meaning, but importing muchness, or relation to many objects: and Xacaba also signifies he trimmed, or cleared, anything by removing another thing from it: (Mṣb:) or he pruned a tree by lopping off its branches so that it became apparent: (Ḳ, TA:) and he pruned a palm-tree by cutting off from it its Xacab, meaning its branches: (TA:) and [in like manner] Xc-b↓, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. taXociybN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) he pruned a tree by cutting off its Xacab, meaning its straggling branches not in the choice, or best, part thereof: (Ṣ:) or he trimmed a palm-trunk (Ḳ, TA) by lopping off the stumps of the branches: (TA:) taXociybu↓ Alr-ayaAHiyni [likewise] signifies the pruning, or cutting off, the superfluous portions of the straggling extremities of the sprigs of sweet-smelling plants: (Mgh:) and Xuciba Eanohu, said of anything, signifies it was removed from it, namely, another thing. (TA.)
See also 2, in two places.
2. Xc-b, inf. n. taXociybu: see above, in four places.
[Hence,] taXociybN signifies also The shaping an arrow by the first operation: (AḤn, Ḳ:) the second operation is termed tahociybN. (AḤn.)

And Xc-bhu, (Sh, TA,) inf. n. as above, (Sh, Ḳ,) He drove away him, or it, (Sh, Ḳ,* TA,) from a thing; (TA;) as also Xacabahu↓, aor. _i {yaXocibu}, inf. n. XacobN: (Sh, TA:) and Xacaba↓ Eanohu he repelled from him, or defended him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And Xac-abotu AlmaAla, (Ḳṭ, TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) † I dispersed, or scattered, the property. (Ḳṭ, Ḳ,* TA.)
[And accord. to Golius, on the authority of a gloss in a copy of the KL, Xc-b also signifies He made long.]
5. tXc-bwA ‡ They became dispersed, or scattered. (A, Ḳ.)

hom.sense:
XacabN Pieces, or cuttings, of trees; (Aṣ, AʼObeyd, Ḳ;) n. un. with p {XacabapN}: (Aṣ, AʼObeyd:) or bark of trees: (Ḳ:) pieces of bark, and pieces of wood, or sticks, or twigs or branches, in a dispersed, or scattered, state; (O, Ḳ;) pl. OaXocaAbN: (Ḳ:) what fall from, or of, the branches of a tree, [when it is pruned,] in a dispersed, or scattered, state: or, as some say, the thorns: and the bark: (Mṣb:) the stumps of the cut branches upon the trunk of a palm-tree, and other portions, which are lopped off; (O;) [i. e., also] the branches thereof which are lopped off: (TA:) and in like manner, (O,) as pl. of XacabapN, (Ṣ,) [or rather as a coll. gen. n. of which the n. un. is with p {XacabapN},] what are cut off from, or of, the branches of trees, (Ṣ, O,) others than palm-trees, (O,) i. e. of the straggling branches, (Ṣ,) such as are not in the choice, or best, part thereof: (Ṣ, O:)
also the superfluous portions of the straggling extremities of the sprigs of sweet-smelling plants, which are pruned, or cut off. (Mgh.)
Anything in a scattered, or dispersed, state. (Ḳṭ, TA.)

‡ Somewhat remaining of herbage [&c.]: (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ: [in the first and third of which is added wahuwa AlmaOokuwlu, app. referring to the herbage of which the remainder is thus called, meaning, “it being what has been eaten:”]) pl. as above, i. e. OaXocaAbN. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.*) One says, fiI AlOaroDi XacabN mino kalaO ‡ In the land is somewhat remaining of herbage. (A, TA.) And one says also, baqiIa Einodahu XacabN mino maAlK ‡ [There remained in his possession a remnant of property]. (A, TA.) And maA baqiIa lahu Uil-aA XacabN mina AlEasokari ‡ [There remained not to him save a relic of the army]. (A, TA.)
Also † Household goods, or furniture and utensils, consisting of what are termed qumaAX [q. v., perhaps here meaning the meaner sorts thereof,] &c.: (AʼObeyd, O, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (Ḳ,* TA.)
And A dam; or thing constructed, or raised, to keep back the water of a torrent. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
rajulN Xacibu AlEuruwqi † A man whose veins are apparent. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And Xcb [app. XacibN] is syn. with EaZibN, meaning A man alighting, or abiding, in places of dried-up herbage, and in a waterless desert. (TA in art. EZb.)

entry.sense: XaAcibN ‡ Going, or being, away from his home, or place of settled abode. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
‡ Solitary, or alone, and whose prosperity is despaired of; (Ḳ, TA;) as though stripped of good. (TA.)
XawocabN: see muXac-abN, in three places.
miXocabN A pruning-hook. (O,* Ḳ,* TA.)
muXac-abN A palm-trunk pared (Ṣ, O, TA) of its prickles (TA) [or of the stumps of its branches or of its lower branches: see the verb of which it is the pass. part. n.].

‡ Tall; (Ṣ, A;) as also XawocabN↓; (Ṣ;) the former as an epithet applied to a horse, (Ṣ, A,) from the same epithet as applied to a palm-trunk: (A:) and † tall, and goodly in make; (A, Ḳ;) and so XawocabN↓; (Mgh, Ḳ;) as though pruned: (Mgh:) and ↓the latter, applied to anything [meaning any animal], † tall, and excellent or of high breed or strong and light and swift: AʼObeyd says that the former signifies † excessively tall, and is applied in this sense to anything [i. e. a man and any animal]: Kt says, after explaining Xac-abotu AlmaAla as it has been expl. above, that he who is excessively tall is as though his frame were disconnected, and not compact; and therefore he is thus termed: but IAmb says that Ḳṭ has made a mistake in asserting that this epithet signifies † tall, conspicuous for tallness, and that it is from the palm-tree from which the branches have been lopped off, (in consequence of which, as is said in the Fáïk, it becomes taller, MF, TA,) and that he who is † conspicuous for tallness is not thus called unless somewhat deficient in flesh: it is applied to a horse as meaning ‡ tall, and not very fleshy. (TA.)
2. Xc-r Aln-aZoma, inf. n. taXociyrN, He divided the strung beads with other beads. (O. [See XacorN, below.])
Hence, by way of comparison, (TA,) Xc-r kalaAmahu biXiEorK ‡ [He interspersed his language with poetry]: but this is post-classical. (O, TA.)
Xc-r bihi He rendered him notorious, or infamous: or made him to hear what was bad, evil, abominable, or foul: (O, TA:) and in like manner Xt-r bh. (TA.)
5. tXc-r It (a people, or party, TA, or a collected body, Ḳ, and a flock of sheep or a herd of goats, TA) dispersed, or became dispersed, (A, Ḳ, TA,) and went in every direction. (TA.)

tXc-r biAlv-awobi He turned back the extremity of the garment between his legs, and stuck it in the part where it was bound round his waist, behind. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And tXc-r biAlc-anabi He put the tail between his thighs, making it to cleave to his belly. (Ṣ, TA.)
Hence, (TA,) tXc-r farasahu He mounted his horse from behind. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also, tXc-r, He prepared himself for fight, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and for a charge, or an assault; he equipped, or accoutred, himself for it. (TA.)

He threatened; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and became angered: (Ḳ:) AʼObeyd says, I doubt not its being with c; but some, he adds, say tXz-r, with z. (Ṣ.) [See a verse of Lebeed cited among the exs. of the preposition bi.]
He was, or became, brisk, lively, or sprightly. (Ḳ.)
He hastened to do a thing; (TṢ, Ḳ, TA;) or in a thing, or an affair. (So in some copies of the Ḳ.)
tXc-rwA fiI AlHarobi i. q. taTaAwaluwA [app. as meaning They behaved overbearingly in war]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or taXac-urN signifies the protracting of war. (KL.)

tXc-rt Aln-aAqapu The she-camel pastured upon herbage (Ḳ, TA) that rejoiced her, (TA,) and she shook her head by reason of joy thereat. (Ḳ, TA.) And The she-camel drew together her two sides, and raised her tail. (TA.)
And tXc-r Als-awoTu The whip inclined, and became in motion. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: XacorN Pieces of gold that are picked up from the mine (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) without the melting, or smelting, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the ore: (Ṣ:) n. un. with p {XacorapN}: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and pl. XucuwrN. (A.) And Beads made of gold to form divisions between pearls and jewels: (TA:) or beads by means of which other beads of a string are divided: (Ḳ:) or small pearls: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or small things of gold, like the heads of ants, which are affixed to a [ring of the kind called] xawoq: (Sh:) or, as some say, green beads: (Ḥar p. 600:) n. un. with p {XacorapN}. (Ḳ.)
Xcr [app. XacorN] signifies [also, like taXac-urN,] Briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness: and quickness in an affair. (Ḥam. p. 54.)

entry.sense: tafar-aquwA Xacara macara, and Xicara micara, They [dispersed, or became dispersed, or] went, or went away, in every direction: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) it is not said of a people coming: (L:) the m in mcr is sometimes changed into b; or, accord. to some, bcr is the original, being from Alt-abociyru; but MF thinks that mcr is the original, as it is only an imitative sequent, in which no regard is had to the meaning of “dispersion.” (TA.)

XawocarN A [garment of the kind called] miloHafap: an arabicized word; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) from the Pers. jaAdaro [or JaAdaro or JaAdiro]. (Ṣ.) And i. q. UitobN; (A, Ḳ, TA;) i. e. A [garment of the kind called] burod, which is slit [in the middle], and worn by a woman, who throws it upon her neck, [putting her head through the slit;] having neither sleeves nor an opening at the bosom: (TA:) or [a garment] like the SidaAr, [which is said by some to be the same as the Uitob,] worn by a young woman: (Ḥar p. 55:) a garment which a woman wears beneath her vawob: (Fr:) a certain garment which a woman and a girl wear, extending to the extremity of the upper half of the arm. (Lth.) [The modern JAdr of Persia and El-'Irák seems to be generally what is commonly called in Egypt a “miláyeh,” correctly “muláäh” (mulaMCap), figured and described in my work on the Modern Egyptians: or, in some instances, a similar covering of plain white, or dark blue, cotton; the former of which is now called in Egypt an “izár.” (See Dozy's “Dict. des Noms des Vêtements chez les Arabes,” pp. 216-219.)]
XiycaArapN A very jealous man; (Ḳ;) as also XinocaArapN and XibocaArapN. (TA.)
AlmutaXac-iru The lion: (Ḳ:) because of his briskness, or quickness to act, or readiness to leap. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. XacaA, aor. _u {yaXocuwu}: see 4.
Also He perfumed himself (taTay-aba) with musk, (Ḳ, TA,) which is termed XacowN, or, as in copies of the M, XicowN. (TA.)

And XacaA biAlxabari, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. XacowN; or, accord. to the Tekmileh, Xc-I↓ bAlxbr, there written with teshdeed; (TA;) ‡ He knew the information, or story, and made it known, or understood. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see the preceding paragraph {1}.

4. AXcI He annoyed, molested, harmed, or hurt: or he did what annoyed, molested, harmed, or hurt: syn. McI: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) and (TA) so XacaA↓, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXocuwu}, inf. n. XacFA, (TA,) or XacowN. (TḲ [accord. to which the latter verb is trans.].)
And AXcAhu Eanohu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UiXocaMCN, (TA,) He put aside, or away, and removed far off, him, or it, from him, or it. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: XacFA Annoyance, molestation, harm, or hurt; or a thing that annoys, molests,, &c.: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and evil, or mischief; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also XacaApN↓; as in the saying Uin-iI laOaxoXaI XacaApa fulaAnK i. e. [Verily I fear, or dread,] the evil, or mischief, of such a one. (TA.)

Dog-flies; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) which also sometimes light upon the camel: (Ṣ:) or flies in general: (Ḳ:) or large blue flies that light upon beasts, and annoy, or molest, or hurt, them: (TA:) n. un. XacaApN↓. (Ṣ. [It is said in the Mṣb that XacFA, of which the n. un. is XacaApN, is also with kesr (i. e. XicFA↓); but in what sense is not specified.]) One says of him who is vehemently hungry, Darima XacaAhu [lit. His flies have become vehemently hungry, or burning with hunger]. (Ṣ.)
And [app. because of the annoyance that it occasions,] Mange, or scab: (ISd, Ḳ:) and so XadFA. (Ḳ in art. Xdw.)
And [app. because of its pungency,] Salt: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) said in the M to be pl. [but properly coll. gen. n.] of XacaApN↓, which signifies a piece of salt. (TA.)
See also XacowN.
Also Fragments of aloes-wood (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA) with which one perfumes himself. (TA. [The same is also indicated in the Ṣ.])
And Sharpness, (Ṣ,) or strength, (Fr, T, Ḳ,) of pungency of odour; (Fr, T, Ṣ, Ḳ;) accord. to the M, of sweet odour. (TA.)
See also XacaApN.
Also The extremity of anything: (TA:) and so XadFA. (Ḳ and TA in art. Xdw.)
And A sort of trees, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) used for masaAwiyk [i. e. sticks with which the teeth are cleansed], (Ḳ,) growing in the Saráh (Als-araAp) and having gum. (TA.)

And A sort of ships or boats: (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ:) n. un. XacaApN↓: (Lth, Ṣ:) [or] XacaAwapN↓ signifies one of a sort of small ships, or boats, like those called zabaAzibu [pl. of zabozabN]: and its pl. is XacaAwaAtN. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: XicFA: see the next preceding paragraph.

XacowN, so accord. to the Ḳ, but written in copies of the M with kesr [i. e. XicowN↓], (TA,) Musk; (IAạr, Ḳ, TA;) as also XacFA↓: (IJ, TA:) or the odour thereof: (Aṣ, T, Ṣgh, Ḳ:) or the colour thereof. (Ḳ.)
XicowN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: XacaApN: see XacFA, in three places.
Also Sharpness. (TA.)
And Strength, and boldness, of a man. (Lth, TA.)
[Or] A remnant of strength: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. XacawaAtN (TA) and [coll. gen. n.] XacFA↓. (Ṣ,* TA. [See also XadFA, in art. Xdw.])

As an epithet applied to a man, (TA,) Evil in disposition, (Ḳ, TA,) sharp in temperament, that annoys, or molests, or hurts, by his evil, or mischief: in some of the copies of the Ḳ, AlX-aIoCu Alxalaqu is erroneously put for Als-aI-iCu Alxuluqi. (TA.)
See again XacFA, last sentence.

entry.sense: XacaAwapN: see XacFA, last sentence.

hom.sense: 1. Xar-a, (L, Ḳ,) sec. pers. Xarirota, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, MF,) aor. yaXar-u; (L, Mṣb, MF;) and sec. pers. Xarurota, (Ṣ accord. to some copies, L, Mṣb, Ḳ, MF,) aor. yaXur-u; (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,* MF;) and sec. pers. Xararota, (Ṣ accord. to some copies, M, Ḳ, MF,) aor. yaXir-u; (M, Ḳ, MF;) of which three vars. the first is the best known; and the last is strange, and disallowed by most authorities; (MF;) inf. n. [of the first or third] Xar-N (Ṣ, Ḳ) and [of the first] XararN (Ṣ) and [of the second or third] XaraArapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Xir-apN also is an inf. n. [syn. with Xar-N]; (Ṣ;) He (a man) was, or became, evil, a wrongdoer, unjust, bad, corrupt, wicked, mischievous, vitious, or depraved. (Ṣ,* L, Mṣb, Ḳ,*, &c.) The manner in which the Ḳ mentions Xar-a with the two aors. yaXur-u and yaXir-u [only, omitting the most common aor., i. e. yaXar-u,] obviously demands consideration. (MF.) One says, Xarirota yaA rajulu [Thou hast been evil, or a wrongdoer,, &c., O man], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and so Xarurota and Xararota. (Ṣ accord. to different copies, and Ḳ.)

Xar-a, aor. yaXar-u, also signifies He increased in evil, wrongdoing,, &c. (L.) It is said in a prov., kul-amaA takobaru taXar-u [In proportion as thou growest old, thou increasest in evil,, &c.]. (AZ, L.)
maA Xar-ahu: see 4, last sentence.

Xar-ahu, (O, Ḳ,) aor. yaXur-u, (O, TA,) inf. n. Xur-N, (O, Ḳ,) with damm, (Ḳ, [which is said in the TA to indicate that the aor., not the inf. n., is with damm, but this is inconsistent with the common practice of the author of the Ḳ, and is evidently wrong,]) He blamed him; found fault with him; attributed or imputed to him, charged him with, or accused him of, a vice, fault, defect, blemish, or something amiss. (O, Ḳ,* TA. [See also 4.]) One says, maA qulotu caAka liXur-ika waUin-amaA qulotupu ligayori Xur-ika I said not that to find fault with thee, but I only said it for a different purpose than that of finding fault with thee: (Ṣ, TA:) or this has a different meaning, which see below, voce Xur-N. (TA.) One says also, qado qabilotu EaTiy-ataka vum-a radadotuhaA Ealayoka mino gayori Xur-ika walaA Dur-ika, meaning [I have accepted thy gift; then I have given it back to thee] without rejecting it to thee or blaming thee [and without injuring thee]. (IAạr, TA.)

Also Xar-ahu, (Ṣ,) or Xar-ahu fiI AlX-amosi, (A,) [aor. and inf. n. as in the next sentence;] and Xr-rhu↓, (A,) inf. n. taXoriyrN; (Ṣ;) and AXr-hu↓; and XaroXarahu↓; (A;) He spread it (i. e. a garment, or piece of cloth, Ṣ, or some other thing, TA) in the sun: (Ṣ, A, TA:) this is the primary signification. (TA.) And [hence,] Xar-ahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yaXur-u. (Ṣ,) inf. n. Xar-N; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and AXr-hu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UiXoraArN; (TA;) and Xr-rhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) and Xar-aAhu [or XaraAhu without teshdeed?]; (Ḳ;) He put it (i. e. [the preparation of curd called] OaqoT, and flesh-meat, Ṣ, Ḳ, and the like, and salt, Ṣ, and a garment, or piece of cloth, and the like, Ḳ) upon a xaSafap, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. a mat, (TA,) or some other thing, (Ḳ,) to dry. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And Xr-hu He sprinkled it; namely, salt. (R, MF.)
2. Xr-rhu inf. n. taXoriyrN, He rendered him notorious, or infamous, among men. (Yz, Ḳ.)
See also 1, latter part, in two places.

entry.sense: 3. XAr-hu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muXaAr-apN, (Ṣ,) He acted with him in an evil manner; (Ḳ;) he treated him with enmity, or hostility: (L, TA:) he contended, or disputed, with him: (Ṣ, L, TA:) he did evil to him, obliging him to do the like in return. (L, TA.) [See also 3 in art. XrI: and see an ex. voce jaAr-a.]

hom.sense: 4. AXr-hu He attributed, or imputed, to him evil, wrongdoing, injustice, or the like: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) but some disallow this. (Ṣ. [See also 1.])
OaXar-uwhu They banished him, or drove him away, and caused him to be alone. (TA.)
See also 1, latter part, in two places.

[Hence, app.,] AXr-hu signifies also ‡ He manifested it, revealed it, published it, or made it known. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) Thus in a verse of Imra-el-Ḳeys, where he says, lawo yuXir-uwna maqotaliI † [that they might publish, or make known, my slaughter]; as related by Aṣ; but it is better with s. (Ṣ.)

maA OaXar-ahu, and maA Xar-ahu↓, [the latter of which is extr. with respect to form, but more commonly used than the former, meaning How evil, wrongdoing, unjust, bad, corrupt, wicked, mischievous, vitious, or depraved, is he!] phrases similar to maA Oaxoyarahu and maA xayorahu [which have the contr. meaning]. (TA in art. xyr.)

entry.sense: 8. AXtr-, said of a camel, [and of any clovenhoofed animal,] i. q. Ajtr-, i. e. He ruminated, or chewed the cud: j and X being from one place of utterance. (IAth, TA.)
10. AstXr- He became possessor of a great herd, such as is termed UiXoraArap, of camels. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. XaroXarahu, (AʼObeyd, Ḳ,) inf. n. XaroXarapN, (Ṣ,) He split it, or clave it: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ:) and cut it much, or in many pieces. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
He bit it, and then shook it; namely, a thing. (O, Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, naqaDahu is erroneously put for nafaDahu.])
XaroXaratohu AlHay-apu The serpent bit him. (L, Ḳ.*)
XrXrt AlmaAXiyapu Aln-abaAta The cattle ate the herbage. (Ḳ.)
XrXr Als-ik-iyna He sharpened, (Ḳ,) or rubbed, (O,) the knife upon a stone, (O, Ḳ, TA,) so that its edge became rough. (O, TA.)
See also 1, latter part.
XaroXara, inf. n. as above, It (a bird) expanded and flapped its wings, without alighting; like raforafa. (TA in art. frX.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 2. taXaroXara It became separated, or scattered. (A.)

hom.sense: Xar-N (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and Xur-N↓, (Kr, Ḳ,) the former of which is the more chaste, (TA,) and Xir-apN↓ (Ḥam p. 629) Evil, [moral and physical;] (L, Mṣb;) wrongdoing, injustice, badness, corruptness, wickedness, mischievousness, vitiousness, or depravity: (Mṣb:) [and evil fortune, misfortune, woe, or unhappiness:] contr. of xayorN: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) pl. XuruwrN. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., in a form of prayer, (TA,) used by the Prophet, (Mṣb,) waAlxayoru kul-uhu biyadayoka waAlX-ar-u layosa Uilayoka, (Mṣb,* TA,) meaning [And all good is in thy hands, and evil i. e.] wrongdoing, or injustice, or corruptness, is not imputable to Thee: (Mṣb, TA:) or evil is not a means of advancement in thy favour, or of obtaining thine approval: or evil speech does not ascend to Thee. (Nh, L.)
Xar-N also signifies † Poverty. (Ḳ.)
And † Fever. (Ḳ.)

It is also an epithet, applied to a man, (Yoo, Ṣ,) and so is XariyrN↓, (Akh, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) meaning Evil, wrongdoing, unjust, bad, corrupt, wicked, mischievous, vitious, or depraved: (Yoo,* Akh,* Ṣ,* A,* Mṣb, Ḳ:*) [fem. of the former Xar-apN, like as xayorapN is fem. of its contr. xayorN; and Xur-aI, fem. of OaXar-u, is used in the same sense, as will be shown in what follows:] the pl. of Xar-N, (Yoo, Ṣ,) or of XariyrN↓, (Akh, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) is OaXoraArN, (Yoo, Akh, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of the former XiraArN; (Ḥam p. 514;) and you say qawomN OaXir-aMCu [pl. of Xar-N or of XariyrN↓]. (Ṣ.) A woman of the Arabs, (Ṣ, L,) who, accord. to some, was of the Benoo-'Ámir, (L,) is related to have said, OuEiycuki biQll-ehi mino nafosK Har-aI waEayonK Xur-aI↓, meaning [I charm thee by invoking God, against a thirsty soul, and] an evil, or a malignant, eye: (Ṣ, L:) or an eye that looks at one with vehement hatred. (TA.)
And AlX-ar-u [The evil one] is an appellation of Iblees. (Ḳ.)

[It is also used to denote the comparative and superlative degrees; like the contr. xayorN.] You say, huwa Xar-N minoka [He is worse, or more evil or wrongdoing, &c., than thou]. (Ḳ.) And hecaA Xar-N mino caAka [This is worse,, &c., than that]. (Mṣb.) And fulaAnN Xar-u Aln-aAsi [Such a one is the worst,, &c., of mankind]; (Ṣ;) and OaXar-u↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) this latter being the original, (Mgh, Mṣb,) but rare, (Ḳ,) or bad, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) peculiar to the dial. of the Benoo-'Ámir, (Mṣb,) or unused. (Mgh.) The fem. [of Xar-N] is Xar-apN, [like as the fem. of its contr., xayorN, is xayorapN,] (Ḳ,) and (of OaXar-u, Ṣ,* or of Xar-N, which is used for OaXar-u, Kr) Xur-aI↓. (Ṣ, Kr, Ḳ.) And [using the dim. form of Xar-N,] you say, huwa XurayorN↓ minoka [He is a little worse,, &c., than thou]. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA in art. xyr. [See xayorN.])
maA Xar-a for maA OaXar-a: see 4.

entry.sense: Xur-N A vice, fault, defect, blemish, or something amiss: (TA:) a thing disapproved, disliked, or hated. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, maA radadotu hecaA Ealayoka mino Xur-K bihi I did not give this back to thee on account of any fault, &c., in it, but I preferred to give it to thee. (TA.) And maA qulotu caAka liXur-ika I said not that on account of a thing that thou disapprovest,, &c.: (Ḳ, TA:) or this has a different meaning, expl. above in the first paragraph. (TA.)
See also Xar-N, first sentence.
Xir-apN: see Xar-N, first sentence.

Also The inordinate desire, or eagerness, (Ṣ,) and sprightliness, of youth: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and in an absolute sense, inordinate desire, or eagerness; and [simply] desire; and sprightliness: (TA:) [and] sharpness, and angriness. (Ḥar p. 35.) It is said in a trad., Uin-a lihecaA AlquroMni Xir-apF vum-a Uin-a liln-aAsi Eanohu fatorapF [Verily there is an eagerness for this Ḳur-án: then men have a weariness of it]. (L.)

XaraArN, (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, TA,) accord. to the Ḳ XiraArN, but this is a mistake, (MF,) and XararN↓, (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is a contraction of XaraArN, (Mṣb,) Sparks of fire: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) n. un. of each with p {XaraArapN and XararapN}. (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb,* Ḳ.) See an ex. voce Xar-aArN.

hom.sense: XariyrN: see Xar-N, in three places.

Also The side of the sea, or of a great river; (AḤn, Ḳ;) the shore thereof: (Kr, TA:) or the part that is near to a sea or great river: pl. OaXir-apN: (AA, TA:) which signifies also seas or great rivers [themselves]. (TA.)
And (as some say, TA) A kind of tree that grows in the sea, or in a great river. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: XurayorN dim. of Xar-N: see the latter, last sentence but one.
XariyrapN A [large needle such as is termed] misal-ap (Ḳ, TA) of iron. (TA.)
Xir-aArN [Emitting many sparks]. One says, Oabuwka naArN Xar-aArapN waOatota minohaA XaraArapN↓ [Thy father is a fire that emits many sparks, and thou art a spark from it]. (A.)

Xar-aAnN Certain insects (Ḳ) resembling baEuwD [or gnats], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which cover the face of a man, but do not bite; sometimes called AlOacaI: (Ṣ:) of the dial. of the people of Es-Sawád: (T, TA:) [it is with tenween; for] the n. un. is with p {Xar-aAnapN}. (Ḳ.)
Xir-iyrN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) Abounding in Xar- [or evil or wrongdoing, &c.; very evil, &c.]; applied to a man: (Ṣ, A:) pl. Xir-iyruwna (Ḳ) and OaXoraArN, which latter is anomalous. (Ḥam. p. 699.)

hom.sense: XaroXarN, (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or (so in the Ṣ, but in the Ḳ “and”) XiroXirN↓, (Ibn-Ziyád, Ṣ, Ḳ,) A certain plant, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which extends along the ground like ropes, (Ibn-Ziyád, AḤn, Ḳ,) in the same manner as the quTob, but having no thorns that hurt any one: (Ibn-Ziyád, AḤn:) Az says that it is a well-known plant, seen by him in the desert; that it fattens the camels, and makes their milk plentiful; and that it is mentioned by IAạr and others among the plants of the desert: XiroXirapN↓ is expl. in the Ḳ as though it were the name of another plant; but it is not so; for XiroXirN is the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] thereof: it is a herb smaller than the Earofaj, having a yellow flower, and twigs, or shoots, and large dust-coloured leaves: it grows in plain, or soft, ground; and spreads wide, as though it were ropes, by reason of length, of the measure of a man in a standing posture; and has berries (Hab-), like those of the haraAs. (TA.)
XiwaMCN XaroXarN Roasted flesh-meat, of which the grease, or gravy, drips; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like XaloXalN and raXoraAXN. (TA.)

entry.sense: XiroXirN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XaroXarapN, ('Ináyeh, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or XuroXurapN↓, (so in other copies of the Ḳ, accord. to the TA,) sing. of XaraAXiru, (Ḳ,) which signifies The fringe-like extremities of a tail; (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* A, TA;) and of wings. (TA.)

Hence, metaphorically, [or synecdochically,] the pl. is used as signifying ‡ The whole: and hence the saying, OaloqaI Ealayohi XaraAXirahu ‡ He betook himself altogether to it; as though, says Aṣ, by reason of his eagerness, he threw himself altogether upon it: accord. to EshShiháb, it means he betook himself [to it], openly or secretly: or XaraAXiru signifies † the whole body; (Ḳ;) and AlqI Elyh XrAXrh and OajoraAnahu and OajoraAmahu, provs. mentioned by Meyd, all signify the same [app. † he threw upon it the weight of his body: see Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 409 and 410: and see art. jrm]: or the first of these means † he loved it so that he courted death, or destruction, (Aisotaholaka,) in his love of it: (TA:) or he loved it with a love that he would not give up, because of his necessity: (Lth, TA:) or ‡ he desired it inordinately, or eagerly, and loved it. (A.) [See also OaloqaI Ealayohi OarowaAqahu, voce rawoqN. Accord. to different authorities,] XaraAXiru also signifies † Burdens, or weights; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) sing. XaroXarapN: (Ṣ:) and it is so expl. as used in the saying mentioned above: or it there signifies † weight, and whole person: or the reduplication implies intensiveness; as though this word originally signified weight of evil: but F, in his comments on the Preface of the Ksh, objects to this, as the word does not imply the contr. of xayorN, but dispersion. (TA.) Also ‡ Self: (Ḳ, TA:) and the saying mentioned above is expl. as meaning ‡ He threw himself upon it, through inordinate, or eager, desire, and love. (Ṣ, TA.) And † Love: (Ḳ:) or † love of self. (Kr, TA.)
XuroXurapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: XiroXirapN A piece of anything. (Ḳ.)
See also XaroXarN.

entry.sense: XuroXuwrN A certain bird, (Ḳ, TA,) of small size; said by Aṣ to be thus called by the people of El-Ḥijáz; and by the Arabs of the desert, baroqaX [a mistranscription for biroqiX]: it is said to be dustcoloured; in elegance, like the Hum-arap; and to be a little larger than the EuSofuwr [or sparrow]. (L, TA.) [Freytag, on the authority of Dmr, says that it is the same as is called Abw brAqX: (but see biroqiXN:) and describes it as being of an ashy colour, with some mixture of redness; and of the passerine kind.]
OaXar-u; and its fem., Xur-aI: see Xar-N, latter half, in three places.
Xur-aI is also applied to a woman as meaning A great imputer of vices, faults, or the like, to others. (AA, L.)

hom.sense: UiXoraArapN A xaSafap, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. mat, (TA,) upon which [the preparation of curd called] OaqiT (Ṣ, Ḳ) and other things (Ṣ) are spread (Ṣ, Ḳ *) to dry; (TA;) [as also maXar-u↓ or miXar-N↓, as written in different copies of the Ṣ voce Eabavat:] or a piece of cloth, of those whereof a tent is composed, used for that purpose: (TA:) or a tablet of stone or wood, upon which flesh-meat is dried: (Lth, IAạr:) pl. OaXaAriyru: or this pl. signifies pieces of flesh-meat cut into strips and dried: (Ṣ:) or the sing. signifies also flesh-meat cut into strips and dried. (Ḳ, TA.)
Also A great herd of camels: (Ḳ:) because scattered. (TA.)

entry.sense: maXar-N or miXar-N: see the next preceding paragraph.
AlmuXaroXiru The lion: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) from AlX-aroXarapu “the biting” a thing “and then shaking” it. (Ṣgh, TA.)

hom.sense:
1. Xariba, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _a {yaXorabu}, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. XurobN and XarobN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and XirobN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) agreeably with three different readings of the Ḳur lvi. 55, (Ṣ, TA,) the first of which (with damm) is that generally obtaining, (Fr, TA,) and is the only one admitted by Jaạfar Ibn-Moḥammad, notwithstanding which the second form (with fet-ḥ) is said by MF to be the most chaste as well as the most agreeable with analogy, (TA,) or the second (with fet-ḥ) is an inf. n., and the first is a simple subst., (AO, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and so is the third, (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ,)
and maXorabN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is also a n. of place [and of time], (Ṣ,) and taXoraAbN, (Ṣ Ḳ, TA,) a form used when muchness of the act is meant, (TA,) and tiXoraAbN, which is anomalous, (TA voce bay-ana, q. v.,) He drank, (KL, PṢ, TḲ,) or he swallowed, syn. jariEa, (A, Ḳ, [but the former meaning is evidently intended by this explanation, and such I shall assume to be the case in giving the explanations of the derivatives in the A and Ḳ., &c.,]) water, &c., (Ṣ,) or a liquid, properly by sucking in, or sipping; and otherwise tropically; (Mṣb;) [generally, gulping it; for] you say, Xariba AlmaMCa fiI kar-apK [He drank the water at once, or at a single draught]; and tXr-bhu↓ fiI muholapK [He drank it leisurely, or gently, or slowly]: (Mgh:) XurobN signifies the conveying to one's inside, by means of his mouth, that in the case of which chewing is not practicable: (KT:) [but] Es-Sarakustee says, one does not say of a bird Xariba AlmaMCa, but HasaAhu. (Mṣb.) In the saying of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, describing clouds,
Xaribona bimaMCi AlbaHori vum-a taraf-aEato
[which is evidently best rendered They drank of the water of the sea, then rose aloft, agreeably with what has been stated respecting bi in the sense of mino in p. 143, it is said that] the b is redundant, or, as rawiyna is rendered trans. by means of bi, [though I do not think that this is the case unless bi be used as meaning “by means of,” and I do not remember to have met with an instance of it,] Xaribona is thus rendered trans. (TA.) [See a similar ex. in the 28th verse of the Mo'allakah of 'Antarah, EM p. 232. One says also, Xariba fiI UinaMCK, meaning He drank out of a vessel; agreeably with an explanation of miXorabapN, in the Ṣ and Ḳ, as meaning UinaMCN yuXorabu fiyhi.] And one says, Uin-iI laOamokuvu Alyawomayoni maA OaXorabuhumaA maMCF, meaning maA OaXorabu fiyhimaA maMCF [i. e. Verily I tarry the two days not drinking in them water]. (O.)

[Xariba Ald-awaMCa, in the conventional language of the physicians, as is indicated in the Mgh, voce banojN (q. v.), on the phrase Xariba Albanoja, and as is shown in many instances in the Ḳ, &c., means He took, i. e. swallowed, the medicine, whether fluid or solid.]
[And in the present day, they say, Xariba Ald-uxaAna, meaning He inhaled, properly imbibed, smoke of tobacco; or he smoked tobacco, or the tobacco.]

One says of seed-produce, or corn, when its culms have come forth, qado Xariba Alz-aroEu fiI AlqaSabi † [The seed-produce, or corn, has imbibed into the culms]: (O, TA:) and when the sap (AlmaMC) has come into it, Xariba qaSabu Alz-aroEi † [The culms of the seed-produce, or corn, have imbibed]. (TA.) And one says, Xariba Als-unobulu Ald-aqiyqa ‡ [The ears of corn imbibed the farina; or] became pervaded by the farina; (En-Naḍr, A, O;) or had in them the alimentary substance; as though the farina were water which they drank. (TA.) And waqado Xariba Alz-aroEu Ald-aqiyqa, occurring in the story of Ohod, (O, TA,) as some relate it, or Xur-iba↓ as others relate it, means ‡ [And the seed-produce, or corn, had imbibed, or had been made to imbibe, the farina, or] had become hardened in its grain, and near to maturity. (TA.) [And OuXoriba↓ means the same: for one says,] OuXoriba Alz-aroEu ‡ [The seed-produce, or corn, was made to imbibe the farina; or] became pervaded by the farina: and in like manner, OuXoriba Alz-aroEu Ald-aqiyqa, i. e. ‡ [The seed-produce, or corn, was made to imbibe the farina, or] its alimentary substance. (TA.)

One also says, Oakala ganamiI waXaribahaA ‡ [He ate the flesh of my sheep, or goats, and drank the milk of them]. (TA in art. Akl.) And [in like manner] Oakala fulaAnN maAliI waXaribahu ‡ [Such a one fed upon, devoured, or consumed, my property]. (A.) And Oakala Ealayohi Ald-ahoru waXariba ‡ [Time wasted him, or wore him away; as though it fed upon him]. (A.)

And OaXorabotaniI↓ maA lamo OaXorabo [lit. Thou hast made me to drink what I have not drunk,] meaning ‡ thou hast charged against me, or accused me of doing, what I have not done; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) like Oak-alotaniI maA lamo Mkulo. (Ṣ in art. Akl.)

Xariba also signifies He was, or became, satisfied with drinking: (TA:) and in like manner Xaribat is said of camels. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, TA.) And He was, or became, thirsty; (Ḳ, TA;) thus having two contr. significations; (TA;) as also OaXoraba↓. (Ḳ, TA.)

Also, and OaXoraba↓, His camels were, or became, satisfied with drinking: and, i. e. both these verbs, his camels were, or became, thirsty: (Ḳ, TA:) or the former verb signifies, or signifies also, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,) his camel was, or became, weak. (Ḳ, TA.)
Xariba bihi, and OaXoraba↓ bihi, He lied against him. (Ḳ.)

Xaraba, aor. _u {yaXorubu}, (O, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. XarobN, (O, TA,) He understood: (O, Ḳ, TA:) on the authority of AA. (TA.) [In a copy of the A, the verb in this sense is written Xariba; and app. not through the fault of the transcriber, for it is there mentioned as tropical: but in the O, it is said to be like kataba, aor. _u {yaXorubu}, inf. n. katobN; and in the Ḳ, to be like naSara.] One says, Xaraba maA OuloqiIa Uilayohi, i. e. He understood [what was told to him]. (TA.) And one says to a stupid person, AuHolubo vum-a QXorubo Kneel thou; then understand. (O, TA. See also 1 in art. Hlb.)

entry.sense: 2. [Xr-bhu, inf. n. taXoriybN, He made him to drink water, &c.; and so, as is indicated in the Ṣ and Ḳ, &c., and as is well known, OaXorabahu↓: and] Xar-abotu AlmaMCa I gave to drink the water; as also OaXorabotuhu↓. (TA.)

[Hence,] one says, Zal-a maAliI yuWak-alu wayuXar-abu [lit. My cattle passed the day made to eat and made to drink,] i. e. † pasturing as they pleased. (Ṣ, TA.) And Xar-aba maAliI waOak-alahu [lit. He made people to drink my property, and made them to eat it; or to drink the milk of my cattle, and to eat the flesh thereof;] i. e. † he fed people, (Ṣ,) or gave people to drink and to eat, (TA,) [of] my property, or cattle. (Ṣ, TA.)
And Xr-b AlOaroDa waAln-axola † He gave drink to the land and the palm-trees. (TA.)
And Xr-b luqomapF biAld-asami † [He imbued, or soaked, a morsel, or mouthful, with grease, or gravy]. (TA in art. rwg.)

And Xar-abotu Alqirobapa, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ,) inf. n. taXoriybN, (AʼObeyd, Ḳ,) † I rendered the water-skin sweet; (Ḳ;) I put into the water-skin, it being new, clay and water, in order to render its savour sweet. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ.)
And Xur-iba Alz-aroEu Ald-aqiyqa: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.
3. XArbhu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. muXaArabapN and XiraAbN, He drank with him; namely, a man. (TA.)
[And He watered his camels,, &c. with his, i. e. with another's: or he drew water with him for the watering of camels, &c.:] see an ex. of the latter inf. n. in a verse cited voce XariybN.

hom.sense: 4: see 2, in two places. One says, OaXorabotu AlUibila Hat-aI Xaribato [I made the camels to drink until they were satisfied with drinking; or I watered the camels, or gave them to drink,, &c.]; (Ṣ, TA;) [for] OaXoraba is syn. with saqaI. (Ḳ.)

[Hence,] Alv-awobu yuXorabu AlS-Kboga: see 5. And OuXoriba Alv-awobu HumorapF ‡ The garment, or piece of cloth, was imbued, or saturated, with redness. (A.) And OaXoraba All-awona ‡ He saturated the colour [with dye]. (Ḳ, TA.) And OuXoriba lawonFA † It was intermixed with a colour; as also AiXoraAb-a↓. (TA.) And OuXoriba AlOaboyaDu HumorapF † The white was suffused, or tinged over, with redness. (Ṣ, TA.)

[Hence, OuXoriba is also said of a sound, as meaning † It was mixed with another sound; as appears from the words here following:] His-u AlS-awoti fiI Alfami mim-aA laA UiXoraAba lahu mino Sawoti AlS-adori † [The faint, or gentle, sound of the voice in the mouth, of such kind as has no mixture of the voice of the chest]. (Ḳ in art. hms.)
[Hence also,] OuXoriba Alz-aroEu: see 1, latter half.
