And OuXoriba fiI qalobihi Hub-ahu, (Ṣ,) or OuXoriba Hub-a fulaAnK, (Ḳ,) or Hub-a fulaAnapa, (A,) ‡ [He was made to imbibe into his heart the love of him, or of such a man, or of such a female;] meaning that the love of him, or of her, pervaded, or commingled with, his heart, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) like beverage. (TA.) Whence, in the Ḳur [ii. 87], waOuXoribuwA fiI quluwbihimu QloEijola, for Hub-a AlEijoli, (Ṣ, TA,) i. e. † And they were made to imbibe [into their hearts] the love of the calf.. (Zj, TA.)

And rafaEa yadahu faOaXorabahaA AlhawaMCa vum-a qaAla bihaA EalaI qacaAlihi ‡ [He raised his hand, and made the air to swallow it up, (i. e. raised it so high and so quickly that it became hardly seen,) then gave a blow with it upon the back of his head]. (A, TA.)
And OaXorabotaniI maA lamo OaXorabo: see 1, latter half.

And one says to his she-camel, laOuXoriban-aki AlHibaAla ‡ [I will assuredly put upon thee the ropes, or cords], and AlEiqaAla [the cord, or rope, with which the fore shank and the arm are bound together]. (A.) [Or] AXrbhu means ‡ He put the rope, or cord, upon his neck; namely, a man's, (Ḳ, TA,) and a camel's, and a horse's or the like: (TA:) and AXrb Alxayola he put the ropes, or cords, upon the necks of the horses. (Ḳ,) And AXrb Uibilahu ‡ He tied his camels, every one to another. (Ḳ, TA.)
AXrb as an intrans. verb: see 1, last quarter, in two places.
Also He (a man, TA) attained to the time for the drinking of his camels. (Ḳ,* TA.)
AXrb bihi: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

entry.sense: 5: see 1, first sentence.

Hence one says, (Mgh,) tXr-b Alv-awobu AlEaraqa, (Ṣ, Mgh,* Ḳ,) and AlS-iboga, (A, Mgh, L,) ‡ The garment, or piece of cloth, imbibed, or absorbed, (Ṣ, A, Mgh,* L, Ḳ,) the sweat, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) and the dye; (A, Mgh, L;) as though it drank it by little and little: (Mgh:) and [in like manner] one says, Alv-awobu yXrb AlS-iboga [app. yuXorabu↓, (like as one says yuXorabu HumorapF, as shown in the next preceding paragraph,) meaning † The garment, or piece of cloth, is made to imbibe, or absorb, the dye]. (TA.) [It is said that] the verb is not used intransitively in the [proper] language of the Arabs. (Mgh.) [But] one says, tXr-b AlS-ibogu fiI Alv-awobi, meaning ‡ The dye pervaded the garment, or piece of cloth: (Ḳ,* TA:) and AlS-ibogu yataXar-abu Alv-awoba ‡ [The dye pervades the garment, or piece of cloth]. (TA.) [See also the explanation of a verse cited voce tasaq-aI.]
10. AstXrb lawonuhu † His, or its, colour became intense. (Ḳ.) And AstXrbt Alqawosu HumorapF † The bow became intensely red: such is the case when it is made of the [tree called] XaroyaAn. (AḤn, TA.)
11. AiXoraAb-a: see 4, near the beginning.

Q. Q. 4. AiXoraOab-, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. AiXoriYobaAbN, (Ṣ, O,) ‡ He raised his head like the camel that has satisfied his thirst on the occasion of drinking: (A:) or he stretched forth his neck to look: (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ:) not improbably, from AlX-urobu in its well known sense, as though he did so when preparing to drink: (O:) or, as is said in the L, from maXorabapN as syn. with gurofapN: (TA:) you say, AiXoraOab-a lahu, (Ṣ, A,) or Uilayohi, (Ḳ,) or both; (TA;) [the former of which may be rendered He raised his head at it, or he stretched forth his neck at it to look; or, as also the latter, he stretched forth his neck to look at it;] namely, a thing: (Ṣ:) or AXrOb- originally means he stretched forth his neck in preparing to drink water: and then, in consequence of frequency of usage, he raised his head, and stretched forth his neck, in looking; and hence is trans. by means of UilaI: (Ḥar p. 152:) or he raised, or exalted, himself. (Ḳ,* TA.) yaXoraYib-uwna liSawotihi, occurring in a trad., means ‡ They will raise their heads at his voice to look at him. (TA.) And AiXoraOab-a Aln-ifaAqu waQrotad-ati AlEarabu, in another trad., means ‡ Hypocrisy exalted itself [and the Arabs apostatized, or revolted from their religion]. (TA.)

hom.sense: XarobN an inf. n. of Xariba [q. v.]. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.)
And a pl., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or [rather] a quasi-pl. n., (ISd, TA,) of XaAribN, q. v. (Ṣ, ISd, Mṣb, TA.)
[Golius assigns to it also the meaning of “Linum tenue,” as on the authority of Meyd.]
XurobN an inf. n. of Xariba [q. v.]; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.;) like XirobN↓: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or a simple subst. [signifying The act of drinking]; (AO, Ṣ Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also XirobN↓. (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

In the phrase Oaxuwka XurobN it is used as [an epithet,] meaning cuw XurobK [which may be regarded as virtually syn. with XaAribN or as similar to this latter but intensive in signification]. (Ḥam p. 194.)

entry.sense: XirobN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

Also Water, (Ḳ, TA,) itself; so some say; (TA;) as also miXorabN↓, (Ḳ, accord. to the TA,) with kesr, (TA,) or maXorabN↓, (so in the CK and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,) i. e. water that one drinks; so says AZ: pl. of the former OaXoraAbN. (TA.) [See also XaraAbN.]
[And A draught of milk: see an ex. in a verse cited in art. slf, conj. 4.]

And A share, or portion that falls to one's lot, of water: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or so XirobN mino maMCK. (ISk, TA.) It is said in a prov., MxiruhaA Oaqal-uhaA XirobFA [The last of them is the one of them that has the least share of water]: originating from the watering of camels; because the last of them sometimes comes to the water when the watering-trough has been exhausted. (Ṣ. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 61.])
As a law-term, it means The use of water [or the right to use it] for the watering of sown-fields and of beasts. (Mgh.)
Also A wateringplace; syn. maworidN: (AZ, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (TA.)

And † A time of drinking: (Ḳ:) but they say that it denotes the time only by a sort of tropical application; and they differ respecting the connexion of this meaning with the proper meaning. (MF, TA.)
XarabN: see XarabapN, in two places.

hom.sense: XarobapN A single act of drinking. (Ṣ.)

And A single draught, or the quantity that is drunk at once, of water. (Ṣ.) It is said in a prov., niEoma miEolaqu AlX-arobapi hecaA [Excellent, or most excellent, is the traveller's drinking-cup, or bowl, that will hold a single draught, namely, this!]: the miEolaq is said by Aṣ to be a drinking-cup or bowl which the rider upon a camel suspends [to his saddle]: (Meyd:) it is said in describing a camel: (TA:) and it means that, to the place of alighting to which he desires to go, he is content with a single draught, not wanting another: (Meyd, TA:) the prov. is applied to him who, in his affairs, is content with his own opinion, not wanting that of another person. (Meyd.) Xarobapu OabiI Aljahomi [The draught of Abu-l-Jahm] is said of a thing that is sweet, or pleasant, but in its result unwholesome: (MF, TA:) Abu-l-Jahm was a frequent visiter of the Khaleefeh El-Manṣoor El-'Abbásee, who, finding him troublesome, ordered that a poisoned draught should be given to him, in his presence: which having been done, Abu-l-Jahm, pained by the draught, rose to depart; and being asked by the Khaleefeh whither he was going, he answered, Whither thou hast sent me, O Prince of the Faithful. (MF.)
In the Mo'allakah of Tarafeh, it is applied to A draught of wine. (EM p. 87.)
[In the conventional language of the physicians, it is a term applied to A dose of medicine, such as is drunk and also such as is eaten.]

Also A palm-tree that grows from the date stone: (Ḳ:) pl. XarabaAtN. (TA. [It seems to be there added that XaraAYibu and XaraAbiybu are also its pls.: the former may be like DaraAYiru pl. of Dar-apN: the latter is app. a mistranscription, and should perhaps be XaraAYiybu, for XaraAYibu; like maHaAmiyru for maHaAmiru, &c.])

entry.sense: XurobapN, (Ḳ,) or XurobapN mino maMCK, (Ṣ,) The quantity of water that satisfies thirst. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

XurobapN is also syn. with UiXoraAbN↓ [originally an inf. n.] meaning † A colour tinged over with another colour; as in the saying, fiyhi XurobapN mino HumorapK † [In him is a colour tinged with redness]: (Ṣ, TA:) [and] ‡ somewhat of redness; as in the phrase, fiyhi XurobapN ‡ [In him is somewhat of redness]: (A:) or † a redness in the face: (Ḳ:) or † whiteness mixed with redness. (IAạr, TA voce HusobapN.)

hom.sense: XarabapN [The act, or habit, of] much drinking. (Ḳ.) One says, Uin-ahu lacFw XarabapK, meaning Verily he is one who drinks much. (AA, AḤn, TA.)
It is also allowable as a pl. of XaAribN [q. v.]. (Mṣb.)

Also A small trough, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) made, (Ṣ,) or dug, (TA,) around a palm-tree, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and around any other kind of tree, and filled with water, (TA,) holding enough to irrigate it fully, (Ḳ, TA,) so that it is plentifully irrigated thereby: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. XarabN↓ [or rather this is a coll. gen. n., of which the former is the n. un.,] and [the pl. properly so termed is] XarabaAtN. (Ṣ.)

And i. q. kurodu daborapK, (Ḳ, TA,) which is syn. with masoqaApN: (TA:) [from a comparison of the explanations of all of these words, it seems to mean A channel of water for the irrigation of a plot, or tract, of sown land: or, if the explanation msqAp, in the TA, be conjectural, the meaning may be a portion of such land, having a raised border to retain the water admitted upon it:] pl. XarabaAtN and [coll. gen. n.] XarabN↓ [as above]. (TA.)

Also Thirst. (Lḥ, T, O, Ḳ.) One says, lamo tazalo bihi XarabapN Alyawoma He has not ceased to have thirst to-day. (Lḥ, TA.) And jaMCati AlUibilu wabihaA XarabapN The camels came thirsty. (T, O.) And TaEaAmN cuw XarabapK Food wherewith one has not sufficient water to satisfy thirst. (O, TA.) Accord. to the L, XarabapN signifies The thirst of cattle after the being satisfied with fresh pasture; because this invites to drink. (TA.)
And Vehemence of heat. (Ḳ.) One says, yawomN cuw XarabapK A day of vehement heat, in which is drunk more water than at other times. (TA.)

entry.sense: XurabapN One who drinks much; (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also XaruwbN↓ and Xar-aAbN↓. (Ṣ.) One says rajulN OukalapN XurabapN A man who eats and drinks much. (ISk, Ṣ.)
XurobubN, applied to herbage, i. q. gamolaI; (O, Ḳ;) i. e. Tangled and dense, one part above another. (O.)

hom.sense:
Xarab-apN, [said to be] the only word of this form except jarab-apN, (Ḳ,) [but to this should be added bagat-apN, inf. n. of bagatahu,] A way, mode, or manner, of being, or acting, &c. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
One says, maA zaAla fulaAnN EalaI Xarab-apK waAHidapK Such a one ceased not to be [employed] upon one affair. (Ṣ, O.)
And A tract of land, (Ḳ, TA,) soft, or plain, (TA,) producing herbs, but having in it no trees. (Ḳ, TA.)
[And] The side of a valley. (Mgh.)

entry.sense: XaraAbN A beverage, or drink, (Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of any of the liquids, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or of anything that is not chewed, (L,) or of whatever kind and in whatever state it be; thus in a copy of the Ḳ: (TA:) and syn. with XaraAbN are XariybN↓ and XaruwbN↓, (Ḳ,) accord. to a saying attributed to AZ: (TA:) or these two have another meaning, expl. in the next paragraph: (Ḳ:) the pl. of XaraAbN is OaXoribapN; (Mgh, TA;) or it has no pl., as is said in the Ḳ in art. nhr [accord. to one or more of the copies; but see nahaArN, where it is shown that in copies of the Ḳ, as well as in the Ṣ, the word to which this statement relates is saraAbN, with the unpointed s]. (TA.) The lawyers [and generally the post-classical writers, and sometimes others,] mean thereby [Win, and] such beverage as is forbidden. (Mgh.) [Also Sirup: pl. XaraAbaAtN: so in the language of the present day.]

hom.sense: XaruwbN and XariybN↓ are syn. with XaraAbN, q. v.: or both signify Water inferior to the Eacob [or sweet]: (Ḳ:) or [brackish water; i. e.] water between the salt and the sweet: (AO, Ṣ:) or water drinkable, or fit to be drunk, but in which is disagreeableness: (Mṣb:) or the former signifies water that has some degree of sweetness, and is sometimes drunk by men notwithstanding what is in it; and ↓the latter, water inferior to what is sweet, and not drunk by men save in cases of necessity, but sometimes drunk by cattle: (IḲṭṭ, TA:) or ↓the latter, the sweet: and the former is said to signify water that is drunk: (TA:) or ↓the latter, water that has no sweetness in it, but is sometimes drunk by men notwithstanding what is in it; and the former, water inferior to this in sweetness, and not drunk by men save in cases of necessity: (AZ, T, M, TA:) or, accord. to Lth, XariybN↓ and Xir-iybN↓ signify water in which are bitterness and saltness, but not abstained from as drink: and maMCN XaruwbN and TaEiymN are syn.: and maMCN miXorabN↓ is syn. with XaruwbN: this last word is used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. and pl. (TA.) It is said in a prov., originally in a trad., juroEapu XaruwbK OanofaEu mino EacobK muwbK [expl. in art. wbO]. (TA.)
Also, XaruwbN, A man who drinks vehemently. (TA.) See also XurabapN: and Xir-iybN.
And † A she-camel desiring the stallion. (Ḳ.)
XariybN: see XaraAbN: and XaruwbN; the latter in five places.

Also One who drinks with another: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and one who waters his camels with those of another: of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mufaAEilN: (Ṣ:) and one who draws water, or is given to drink, with another. (IAạr, Ḳ.) You say, huwa XariyibiI [He is my companion in drinking; or in watering his camels with mine:, &c.]. (TA.) And a rájiz says,
rub-a XariybK laka ciI HusaAsi
XiraAbuhu↓ kaAlHaz-i biAlmawaAsiI
[Many a one who waters his camels with thine, or who draws water with thee for the watering of camels, having an evil disposition, his watering, &c. is like the cutting with razors]: i. e., thy waiting for him at the watering-trough is [a cause of] killing to thee and to thy camels. (TA.)

entry.sense: XariybapN is expl. in the Ṣ as meaning A sheep, or goat, which one drives back, or brings back, from the water, when the sheep, or goats, are satisfied with drinking, and which they follow: but in some of the copies in a marginal note stating that the correct word is sariybapN, with the unpointed s. (TA.)
XaraAbiI-N A cup-bearer: or a butler: and a seller of wine or of sirup. (MA.)

XuraOobiybapN a subst. (Ḳ) from AiXoraOab-a [q. v.; as such signifying ‡ A raising of the head like the camel that has satisfied his thirst on the occasion of drinking:, &c.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) like TumaOoniynapN [from AiTomaOan-a]. (Ḳ, TA.)
Xar-aAbN: see XurabapN: and what here next follows.

hom.sense: Xir-iybN Addicted to XaraAb [i. e. drink, or wine]; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) like xim-iyrN; (Ṣ;) as also Xar-aAbN↓ and XaruwbN↓ and XaAribN↓. (TA.)
See also XaruwbN.

entry.sense: [Xur-aAbapN A tassel: so in the language of the present day: probably post-classical: pl. XaraAriybu.]

hom.sense:
XaAribN Drinking, or a drinker: pl. XaAribuwna (Mṣb) and XarobN↓, like as SaHobN is of SaAHibN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or, accord. to ISd, (TA,) XarobN, which signifies people drinking, (Ḳ, TA,) and assembling for drinking, is a quasi.-pl. n. of XaAribN, being like rakobN and rajolN; and XuruwbN, which is said by IAạr [and in the Ṣ] to be pl. of XarobN, is pl. of XaAribN, like as XuhuwdN is of XaAhidN; (TA;) XarabapN also is allowable as a pl. of XaAribN, like as kafarapN is pl. of kaAfirN; (Mṣb;) and OaXorubN is pl. of XarobN, or it may be an anomalous pl. of XaAribN: (MF:) the pl. Xuruwb occurs in the saying of El-Aạshà,
huwa AlwaAhibu AlmusomiEaAti AlX-uruw
ba bayona AlHariyri wabayona Alkatano
[He is the giver of female singers to the drinkers, some clad in silk and some in linen]. (Ṣ.)
See also Xir-iybN.

[Hence, The mustache; i. e.] the defluent hair over the mouth; (Mṣb;) or so XawaAribu, (Lḥ, A, Ḳ,) which is the pl., (Lḥ, Ṣ, Mṣb,) as though the sing, applied to every distinct part: (Lḥ:) the two [halves] are called XaAribaAni: (Ṣ, TA:) or, as some say, only the sing. is used, and the dual is a mistake: (TA:) accord. to AḤát (Mṣb, TA) and AAF, (TA,) the dual is is scarcely ever, or never, used; but accord. to AO, the Kilábees say XaAribaAni, with regard to the two extremities: (Mṣb, TA:) and the pl., (A, Ḳ,) or, accord. to the T, &c., the dual, (TA,) signifies the long portions [of the hair] on the two sides of the sabalap [q. v.]: (T, A, Ḳ, TA:) or (Ḳ, TA) XaAribN signifies the sabalap altogether, (A, Ḳ, TA,) as some say; but this is not correct. (TA.) One says, Tar-a XaAribu AlgulaAmi [The mustache of the boy, or young man, grew forth]. (Ṣ.)

And hence, as being likened to the two long portions of hair on each side of the sabalap, the XaAribaAni of the sword, (T, TA,) i. e. ‡ Two long projections (OanofaAni TawiylaAni) at the lower part of the hilt, (A,* Ḳ, TA,) [extending from the guard,] one on one side and the other on the other side of the blade, (T,* TA,) the gaAXiyap [or leathern covering of the scabbard] being beneath them: so says ISh. (TA.)

AlX-awaAribu also signifies ‡ The Euruwq [or ducts] of the Huloquwm [or windpipe]: (A:) or certain ducts (Euruwq) in the Haloq [i. e. fauces or throat], (Ḳ, TA,) that imbibe the water [or saliva?], being the channels thereof: (TA:) and, (Ḳ,) or, as some say, (TA,) the channels of the water [or saliva?] (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) in the Haloq [i. e. fauces or throat] (Ṣ) or in the neck: (Ḳ, TA:) or certain ducts (Euruwq) adhering to the windpipe, and the lower parts thereof to the lungs: so says IDrd: or rather, some say, the hinder part thereof [adhering] to the watiyn [or aorta], having tubes from which the voice issues, and in which choking takes place, and whence the saliva issues: and those of the horse are said to be [certain ducts] by the side of the OawodaAj [or external jugular veins], where the veterinary surgeon draws blood by cutting the AwdAj: the sing. seems by implication to be XaAribN. (TA.) Hence the phrase HimaArN Saxibu AlX-awaAribi † An ass that brays vehemently. (Ṣ, TA.) And Saxibu AlX-awaAribi ‡ [A man] having a disagreeable voice: thus likened to an ass. (A, TA.)
Accord. to IAạr, AlX-awaAribu signifies [also] majaAriI AlmaMCi fiI AlEayoni, which AM supposes to mean The channels of water in the spring, or source; not in the eye. (L, TA.)
sunobulN XaAribu qamoHK means ‡ Ears of corn becoming, or being, pervaded by the farina: (A, TA:) or, in which the grain has hardened, and nearly come to maturity. (TA.)

Also † Weakness, or feebleness, in any animal: (Ḳ,* TA:) or a strain (Eiroq) thereof; as in the saying, niEoma AlbaEiyru hecaA lawolaA Oan-a fiyhi XaAriba xawarK † [Excellent, or most excellent, were the camel, this one, were there not in him a strain of weakness or feebleness]. (TA.)

entry.sense: XaAribapN [a subst. from XaAribN, made such by the affix p,] A people, or party, dwelling upon the side (Daf-ap, in some copies of the Ḳ Suf-ap,) of a river, (Ṣ,* A, Ḳ,) and to whom belongs the water thereof. (Ṣ.)
UiXoraAbN as syn. with XurobapN: see the latter.

maXorabN is a noun of place, [and of time,] as well as an inf. n.: [i. e.] it signifies [A place, and a time, of drinking: or] the quarter (wajoh) whence one drinks: (Ṣ, TA:) and a place to which one comes to drink at a river or rivulet: (TA:) and maXorabapN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) not, as is implied in the Ḳ, maXorubapN also, (TA,) signifies [the same, as is indicated in the A; or] a place whence people drink; (Mṣb, TA;*)
i. q. maXoraEapN; (Ḳ;) or like a maXoraEap. (Ṣ, TA.) One says, hecaA maXorabu Alqawomi and maXorabatuhumo↓ [This is the people's, or party's, drinkingplace, or place whence they drink]. (A.) And it is said in a trad., maloEuwnN mano OaHaATa EalaI maXorabapK↓, (Ṣ, TA,) i. e. [Cursed is he] who takes entirely to himself, debarring others from it, a place whence people drink. (TA.)
See also XirobN.
muXorabN HumorapF ‡ A man whose complexion is tinged over [or intermixed] with redness. (TA.) [See 4: and see also muXar-abN.]

rajulN muXoribN A man whose camels have drunk [until satisfied with drinking: see OaXoraba near the end of the first paragraph]. (TA.) And A man whose camels are thirsty, or who is himself thirsty. (TA.) AisoqiniI faUin-aniI muXoribN is a saying mentioned by IAạr, and expl. by him as meaning EaToXaAnu: it means [Give thou me to drink, for] I am thirsty or my camels are thirsty. (TA.)
miXorabN: see XirobN: and see also XaruwbN.

hom.sense: maXorabapN: see maXorabN, in three places.

Hence, (A, TA,) An upper chamber; syn. gurofapN; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) and Eil-iy-apN; (Ṣ,* Ḳ;) both of which signify the same; (MF, TA;) because people drink therein; (A, TA;) as also maXorubapN↓: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) pl. maXaAribu, (TA,) syn. with EalaAliI-u, (Ṣ,) and maXorabaAtN. (TA.)

And the former, (Ḳ, TA,) not, as is implied in the Ḳ, the latter also, (TA,) A Suf-ap [i. e. roofed vestibule or the like]: (Ḳ, TA:) or the like of a Suf-ap in the front of a gurofap [expl. above]. (TA.)
Also the former, (Ḳ, TA,) not, as is implied in the Ḳ, both words, (TA,) Soft, or plain, land, in which is always herbage, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. green and juicy herbage. (TA.)
See also miXorabapN.

[Also A cause of drinking: a word of the class of maboxalapN, &c.] One says TaEaAmN maXorabapN Food [that is a cause of drinking, or] upon which one drinks much water: (T, TA:) or TaEaAmN cuw maXorabapK food upon which the eater drinks. (A.)

entry.sense: maXorubapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

miXorabapN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and MF says that maXorabapN↓ is allowable in the same sense, mentioning it as on the authority of Fei, [in my copy of whose lexicon, the Mṣb, I do not find it,] (TA,) A drinkingvessel. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
muXar-abN HumorapF ‡ A man whose complexion is much tinged over [or much intermixed] with redness. (TA.) [See also muXorabN.]

muXar-abapN is an epithet applied to Certain letters the utterance of which, in pausing, is accompanied with a sort of blowing, but not with the same stress as the [generality of those that are termed] majohuwrap: they are zaAI and ZaMC and caAl and DaAd: [and Lumsden (in his Ar. Gr. p. 47) states that raMC belongs to the same class, likewise: and, as some say, nuwn when movent:] Sb says that some of the Arabs utter with more vehemence of voice than others. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Xaraja: see 4.

Also, (Ṣ, A, O, TA,) [aor. _u {yaXoruju},] inf. n. XarojN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) He put, or set, together bricks (labin), in order, side by side, or one upon another, compactly; (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ, TA;) and (O) so Xr-j↓, (O, Mgh, Mṣb,) with teshdeed, (Mṣb,) inf. n. taXoriyjN. (O, Mgh.)
And He collected together, (O, Ḳ,) or put together, or joined, (L,) any thing or things, one part to another, or one thing to another; (O, L;) as also Xr-j↓. (L.)
And He mixed (A, O, Ḳ) beverage, or wine: and in like manner Xr-j↓ he mixed honey, &c. with water. (O.)
And Xarajahu fiI AlOamori, aor. _u {yaXoruju}, (TḲ,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ, TḲ,) He was, or became, a partner, or sharer, (Ḳ, TḲ,) with him in the affair. (TḲ.)
Also, (O,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) He lied; (O, Ḳ;) like saraja and sadaja. (O.)
Xarija, (O, TA,) with kesr to the r, (O,) He was, or became, beautifully fat. (O, TA.)
2. Xr-j, inf. n. taXoriyjN: see above, in three places.

Also, said of pasture, or herbage, It caused the flesh of an animal to be intermixed with fat. (L.) And Xur-ija, said of the flesh of an animal, It was intermixed with fat: (Ṣ, O:) or was made to be of two colours by reason of the fat and the flesh: (TA:) and tXr-j↓ biAlX-aHomi it (the flesh) became intermixed with fat. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And taXoriyjN also signifies The sewing with stitches far apart. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ)
See also 4.

entry.sense: 3. muXaArajapN The being like, one to another. (O, Ḳ.) One says, XArjhu He was like to him; or it, to it: and XaArajaA They two were like, each to the other. (TḲ.)

4. AXrj, (AZ, Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb,) inf. n. UiXoraAjN; (Ḳ;) and Xr-j↓, (AZ, O,) inf. n. taXoriyjN; (Ḳ;) and Xaraja↓, (AZ, O,) inf. n. XarojN; (Ḳ;) He closed, or made fast, the [leathern receptacle called] xariyTap (AZ, O, Ḳ) or Eayobap, (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb,) by inserting its OaXoraAj [or loops] one into another. (Ṣ, A,* O, Mṣb.)
[Hence,] AXrj Sadorahu Ealayohi ‡ [He closed his bosom upon it]. (A, TA.)
5: see 2.
7. AnXrj, (Ḳ,) or AnXrjt, said of a bow, (ISk, Ṣ, O,) It split. (ISk, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: XarojN A place in which water flows from a [stony tract such as is termed] Har-ap to a soft, or plain, tract; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also XarojapN↓: (TA:) or the latter signifies [simply] a place in which water flows; and some elide the p, saying XarojN: (Mṣb:) pl. XiraAjN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, expl. in the Mgh agreeably with the former explanation above, and said in the Mṣb to be pl. of XarojapN,) and XuruwjN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Also A party, or distinct body or class [of men]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, OaSobaHuwA fiI hecaA AlOamori Xarojayoni i. e. [They became, in this affair,] two parties. (Ṣ.) And it is said in a trad., OaSobaHa Aln-aAsu Xarojayoni fiI Als-afari [The people, or men, became two parties in the journey]; meaning, half of them fasting, and half of them breaking the fast. (TA.)

And The like of another; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also XariyjN↓: (O, Ḳ:) the latter from the same word as meaning “a piece of wood [or a branch] that is split into two halves;” each of which is the Xryj of the other. (O.) One says, hecaA Xaroju hecaA This is the like of this. (Ṣ.)
And A sort, or species. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, humaA XarojN waAHidN They two are one sort, or species. (Ṣ.)

And XarojaAni Any two different colours: (Ṣ:) [and] XariyjaAni↓ signifies [the same, i. e.] two different colours (Ḳ, TA) of anything; or, accord. to IAạr, two mixed colours, not black and white: (TA:) and ↓this latter, also, the two lines of the nayraAni [or two ornamental borders] of a [garment of the kind called] burod, (O, Ḳ,) one of which is OaxoDar [here meaning of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour], and the other white or red. (O.)
And AlX-aroju, like falos [in measure, not to be confounded with AlX-araju], signifies The [perinæum, or] part between the anus and the testicles. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)

XarajN The loops (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) of the [leathern receptacle called] Eayobap, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb,) and of the [tent called] xayomap, (O, TA,) and the like, and of the muSoHaf [or copy of the Ḳur-án, &c.]: (TA:) [the loops here meant being such as are inserted one into another, to close a bag, &c.: see 4:] pl. OaXoraAjN. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) [And it seems also, from what here follows, to signify A single loop.]
† The anus: (Mṣb, TA:) or hence Xaraju Ald-uburi signifies † the anus. (Mgh.)
And † The vulva of a woman: (O, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (TA.)
And Xaraju Ald-araAhimi [The purse for money]. (M and Ḳ in art. Sr: in the CK, Xaroj.)
Also A place of expanding of a valley: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (Ṣ.)
And The Milky Way in the sky: (Ṣ:) or so AlX-araju. (Ḳ.)
Also A splitting, or cracking, (AinoXiqaAqN, Ṣ, and so in some copies of the Ḳ, or XuqaAqN, so in other copies of the Ḳ and in the O,) in a bow. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And in a beast, The having one of the two testicles larger than the other. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: XarojapN: see XarojN.
Also A hollow dug in the ground, in which a piece of skin is spread, and from which camels are watered, (O, Ḳ,) water being poured upon the skin. (O.)

XariyjN A branch, or rod, that is split into two halves: and XariyjapN↓, a bow that is made thereof: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or the former, a branch, or rod, from which are split two bows: and either of the bows thus made: or a split bow: pl. XaraAYiju: accord. to AA, a bow that is split from a branch, or rod, in two halves; also called filoqN:
accord. to Lḥ, a bow in which is a splitting (Xaq-N, used as an inf. n.), and [such as is] a Xiq-, by which is meant the subst. [i. e. half of a branch or rod divided lengthwise]; Xryj being used by him as an epithet: and some say that XariyjapN↓ signifies a bow that is not [made] from a sound, or whole, branch; like filoqN. (TA.)
Also An arrow used in the game called Almayosir belonging to the person who plays with it, not borrowed. (TA in art. Xjr.)
See also XarojN, in three places.
AlmaroCu bayona XariyjaIo gam-K wasuruwrK is a tropical saying [app. meaning ‡ Man is between the two different conditions of grief and happiness]. (A, TA.)

XariyjapN A thing (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) that is woven (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) of palm-leaves (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and the like, (Mṣb,) in which are carried melons and other things (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) of the like kind: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) pl. XaraAYiju. (Mṣb.)
A door, (Mgh,) or a thing like a door, (Mṣb,) made of reeds, or canes, for a shop. (Mgh, Mṣb.)

A cage, or coop, (jadiylap,) of reeds, or canes, (O, Ḳ, TA,) made (TA) for pigeons. (O, Ḳ, TA. [The explanation in the Ḳ is strangely misunderstood and rendered by Freytag as meaning “Zona ex arundine facta, qua utuntur in balneo.”])
And The sinew with which the feathers of an arrow are attached: (O, Ḳ:) if it is feathered by means of glue, the glue is called ruwmapN. (O.)
[Also, accord. to Golius, as on the authority of Meyd, The tie, or band, (“ligamentum”) of a book.]
See also XariyjN, in two places.

XayorajN, (Mṣb, TA,) or XiyrajN, (so in my copy of the Mgh,) or the latter is not allowable, (Mṣb, TA,) vulgarly pronounced siyraj, [q. v.,] with s and kesr, (TA,) an arabicized word, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) from [the Pers.] Xiyraho, (Mgh, Mṣb,) Oil of sesame, or sesamum: (Mṣb, TA:) and white oil (Mgh, Mṣb, TA) is sometimes thus called: (Mṣb, TA:) and expressed juice (EaSiyr), (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) or [beverage of the kind called] nabiyc, (Mgh,) before it alters; (Mgh, Mṣb, TA;) as being likened to oil of sesame because of its clearness. (Mṣb, TA.)
OaXoraju A beast having one of his testicles larger than the other. (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ.)
A man having one testicle. (A, TA.)
[sahomN muXar-ajN An arrow having cracks. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]
fatayaAtN mutaXaArijaAtN [in the CK, erroneously, mutaXaArajAt,] Young women equals in age. (O, Ḳ.)
1. XaraHa, aor. _a {yaXoraHu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XaroHN, (Ṣ, O,) He uncovered, laid open, displayed, exposed to view, discovered, revealed, or disclosed. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

[Hence,] one says, XaraHa Oamorahu ‡ He showed, discovered, disclosed, or made apparent, his affair, or case. (A, TA.) And XaraHa masoOalapF (A, TA) ‡ He explained a question; (TA;) he explained, or made manifest, the answer to a question. (A.) And XaraHa AlgaAmiDa † He expounded, explained, or interpreted, what was obscure, recondite, or abstruse. (Ṣ, O.) And XaraHa AlHadiyva, inf. n. as above, † He expounded, explained, or interpreted, the tradition; showed, or made apparent, its meaning. (Mṣb.)
And XaraHa, aor. as above, (Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (O, TA,) He opened (O, Ḳ, TA) a thing of any kind, of any substance or material. (TA.)

‡ He defloured a virgin: (O, Ḳ, TA:) or ‡ he compressed a woman, (A, L,) or a virgin, (Ḳ,) lying on her back; (A, L, Ḳ;) or he threw, or laid, upon her back, and then compressed, his female slave, or young woman. (O, L.)
He widened, or dilated, a thing. (Ḳ.)

Hence, (TA,) XaraHa Qll-ehu Sadorahu, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, O, Mṣb, TA,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (Mṣb, TA,) † God dilated his bosom, (Mgh, O, Mṣb, TA,) liqabuwli Alxayori [for the acceptance, or favourable acceptance, of what was good], (O, TA,) and liloUisolaAmi (Mgh, Mṣb, TA) for the acceptance, or favourable acceptance, [of El-Islám, or] of the truth, (Mṣb, TA,) as in the Ḳur [xxxix. 23]. (TA. [Said in the TA to be tropical; but not so in the A, being mentioned in the latter as proper.]) [And hence, an objective complement being app. understood,] fulaAnN yaXoraHu UilaI Ald-unoyaA ‡ Such a one manifests desire for the things of the present world: (A:) or such a one becomes dilated in the bosom at the prospect of the things of the present world, and desirous of acquiring them, with large desire. (O,* L.) And maA liI OaraAka taXoraHu UilaI kul-i riybapK ‡ What aileth me that I see thee manifesting desire for everything occasioning doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion? (A, TA.)
Also, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (O,) He understood (O, Ḳ) speech, or language. (TḲ.)
2. The inf. n. taXoriyHN signifies The expounding, explaining, or interpreting, well, language, or discourse. (KL.)
See also 1, latter half, in four places.
[Also The dissecting, or anatomizing, a body.]
7. AnXrH Sadoruhu (Ṣ, A, O) His bosom became dilated, (O,) [with joy or the like, or] liloUisolaAmi [for the acceptance, or favourable acceptance, of El-Islám]. (Ṣ.)
10. AstXrH He asked for language to be expounded, explained, or interpreted, to him: or for flesh-meat to be cut for him in the manner termed XaroHN. (O.)
XaroHN inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ, O, &c.)

[An exposition, explanation, or interpretation, in the form of a running commentary, comprising the entire text of the work which it expounds; distinguished from a HaAXiyap, which is a commentary only on particular words and passages: pl. XuruwHN.]
XaroHapN: see XariyHapN.

XaroHapN mina AlZ-ibaMCi Flesh-meat of gazelles cut in the manner termed XaroH [i. e. into oblong slices], (TA,) such as is brought in a dry state, just as it was, not muqad-ad [which means cut into strips and then dried by exposure to the sun]. (ISh, O, Ḳ, TA.)

XaraAHN The discovery, disclosure, or explanation, of an affair or a case: so in the prov., Aln-ajaAHu maEa AlX-araAHi [The accomplishment of one's want is with the discovery, or disclosure, or explanation, thereof]; meaning, discover thou, or disclose, or explain, to me my affair, or case, for the doing so is one of the means of accomplishing my want: thus expl. by Aṣ. (Meyd. [In the TA, mn is put in the place of mE. See a similar prov. voce saraAHN.])
XariyHN, applied to flesh-meat, i. q. maXoruwHN↓ [i. e. Cut into oblong slices]. (O.)
See also XariyHapN, in two places.

XurayoHN The vulva of a woman; (O, Ḳ;) and (Ḳ) so maXoraHN↓: (A, Mgh, Ḳ:) or a proper name for the vulva of a woman; like as rumayoHN is a proper name for “the penis.” (TA in art. rmH. [Golius appears to have found in the Ḳ AlHar-u in the place of AlHiru.])

XariyHapN A cut piece of flesh-meat, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) as also XariyHN↓ and XaroHapN↓, (Ḳ,) such as is maXoruwH [or cut into oblong slices]; (O;) [i. e. an oblong slice of flesh-meat:] or a thin piece, or slice, of flesh-meat: (L, TA:) and any extended piece of fat flesh-meat; (Ṣ, O;) as also XariyHN↓: (Ṣ:) pl. of the first XaraAYiHu. (A.)
XaAriHN [An expositor, explainer, or interpreter, of a book or the like.]
[And] A keeper, or guardian. (TA.) In the dial. of El-Yemen, (O, TA,) A guardian of seed-produce from the birds (O, Ḳ, TA) amp;c. (O, TA.)
maXoraHN: see XurayoHN.
[Also] The saAfilap [i. e. podex, or anus,] of a man. (O.)

hom.sense: maXoruwHN: see XariyHN.
Also The saraAb [or mirage]: (Ḳ: [In the CK, AlX-araAbu is put in the place of Als-araAbu:]) mentioned on the authority of Th: and masoruwHN [q. v.] is a dial. var. thereof. (TA.)

entry.sense: 1. Xaraxa, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXoraxu}, (L,) inf. n. XaroxN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and XuruwxN, (L, Ḳ,) said of the naAb [or tush] of a camel, It clave the flesh, (Ṣ, A,* L, Ḳ,) and came forth. (L.)
And Xaraxa, inf. n. XuruwxN (Ṣ, L) and XaroxN, (L,) said of a boy, He became a youth, or young man, such as is termed XaArixN. (Ṣ, L.)

hom.sense: XaroxN The rising, protruding, prominent, or projecting, extremity or edge of a thing. (L, Ḳ.) [Hence,] XaroxaA Alfuwqi, (ISh, Ṣ, A, TA,) or XaroxaA Als-ahomi, (Mṣb, TA,) both alike in meaning, (TA,) The zanamataAni, (ISh, A, Mṣb, TA,) or two edges or extremities [or cusps], (Ṣ, TA,) of the arrow, (ISh, TA,) [i. e.] of the notch of the arrow, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, TA,) between which is the place of the bow-string. (ISh, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, TA.) And in like manner, (Ṣ,) XaroxaA Alr-aHoli signifies The Mxirap and waAsiTap of the camel's saddle; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb;) the two extremities of the camel's saddle; or, as some say, [more precisely,] its two [upright] pieces of wood, [corresponding to the qarabuwsaAni of the horse's saddle, rising from it] behind and before [or at the fore and hind parts]: (L, TA:) [whence] one says of him who journeys much, laA yazaAlu fulaAnN bayona XaroxaIo raHolihi [Such a one ceases not to be between the two uprights of his camel's saddle: for between them the rider sits: see Mxirapu Alr-aHoli, voce MxirN]. (A, TA.)
The naAb [or tush] of a camel. (L.)
A sword-blade (naSol) that has not yet been tempered (lamo yusoqa baEodu), nor had its hilt affixed to it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. XuruwxN. (Ṣ.)
The origin, source, or root, syn. OaSolN and EiroqN, (L, Ḳ,) of anything; like sinoxN(L.)

The beginning, commencement, or first period or state, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a thing, or an affair, and also, (Ṣ, A,) of youth; (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the prime and best part or period of youth, (A,) and its beauty and brightness, and its strength. (L. [See also XaxorN.])

A youth, or young man, such as is termed XaAb-N; and youths, or young men; originally an inf. n., and [therefore, when used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] applied to one and to two and to a pl. number: (L:) or it is a pl. of XaArixN↓ in the sense of XaAb-N, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) or [rather] a quasi-pl. n., (L,) like as SaHobN is of SaAHibN, (Ṣ,) [i. e.] a noun used as a pl. in the sense expl. above: (Sh:) or, accord. to some, it signifies strong young men, profitable for service: and accord. to others, young children: (AʼObeyd, L:) it has also for pls. XuruwxN and Xur-axN: (L:) and XuruwxN Xur-axN is an expression used in an intensive sense. (L, Ḳ.)
The offspring of a man: (Ḳ, TA:) or the sperma by which offspring is produced, (TA.)

The increase, or offspring, or brood, syn. nitaAj, (AO, Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of camels, (Mṣb,) [i. e.] consisting of the young ones of camels, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in any year, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or of camels, &c., of one year, while they continue small. (L.) One says, hecaA mino Xaroxi fulaAnK This is of the increase (nitaAj) [of the camels, &c.] of such a one. (AO, L.)

An equal in age, a contemporary in birth; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) an equal, a match, fellow, peer, or compeer; pl. XuruwxN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, huwa XaroxiI He is my equal in age, (A, TA,) or my equal or match. (TA.) And humaA XaroxaAni They two are equals [in age,] or matches. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[The pl.] XuruwxN also signifies [Trees of the kind called] EiDaAh. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: XaArixN: see the next preceding paragraph. You say SabiI-N XaArixN, meaning A young boy. (A.)

1. Xarada, aor. _u {yaXorudu}, inf. n. XuruwdN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XiraAdN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and XuraAdN (Ḳ) and XarodN, (L,) said of a camel, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb,) and of a horse or the like, (L,) He took fright, or shied, and fled, or ran away at random; or became refractory, and went away at random, or ran away, or broke loose, and went hither and thither by reason of his sprightliness; syn. nafara, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and nad-a: (Mṣb:) and [simply] he fled, or ran away; said of a camel, &c. (Aboo-Bekr, TA.) The saying of the Prophet, OamaA yaXorudu bika baEiyruka ‡ [Does not thy camel take fright and run away with thee?], addressed by him to Khowwát, who answered, OamaA munocu qay-adahu AlUisolaAmu falaA [As to the period since El-Islám shackled him, no], mentioned in the A, points to a story related of Khowwát Ibn-Jubeyr, (TA,) that, being found by the Prophet sitting by some strange women, he endeavoured to excuse himself by saying that he had a camel which took fright and ran away, and he was seeking for something wherewith to shackle him: the Prophet used afterwards to taunt him by inquiring of him respecting the running-away of his camel: what Kr says, and J in the Ṣ [in art. nHI], is incorrect. (IAth, L.) You say also, Xarada Ean-iI fulaAnN Such a one fled, or went away or aside or apart or to a distance, from me; syn. nafara. (A.) [Or] Xarada said of a man, inf. n. XuruwdN, means He departed, driven away. (L.) And you say, Xarada EalaI Qll-ehi, meaning He departed from obedience to God, and seceded, or separated himself from the community [of the faithful]. (L.)

2. Xr-dhu, (L, Mṣb,) inf. n. taXoriydN, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He made him to take fright, and flee, or run away at random; or to become refractory, and to go away at random, or run away, or break loose, and go hither and thither by reason of his sprightliness; namely, a camel [and a horse or the like: see 1]: (Mṣb:) or he drove him away, or expelled him; (Ṣ,* L, Ḳ;*) as also AXrdhu↓; (L;) [and so Xr-d bihi; for] you say Xar-adotuhu Ean-KI and Xar-adotu bihi [I drove him away from me]. (A.) And taXoriydN signifies also The act of dispersing, or scattering. (Ḳ.) [Hence,] Xar-ido bihimo mano xalofahumo, in the Ḳur [viii. 59], means Disperse thou, or scatter thou, by them, those [who shall come] after them: (Ṣ, L:) or terrify thou, by them, those [who shall come] after them: or make thou them notorious to those [who shall come] after them: (L:) [for]
Xr-d bihi (inf. n. as above, TA) signifies He rendered him notorious by exposing his vices or faults. (L, Ḳ.)
4. AXrdhu He made him to be driven away, or expelled, (L, Ḳ,) and not received into a place of refuge, covert, or lodging. (L.) See also 2.
5. tXr-d Alqawomu The people, or party, went away, or departed. (L.)
XaradN: see XaAridN.

XiraAdN an inf. n. of Xarada [q. v.]: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or a simple subst. from Xarada [and as such signifying A taking fright, or shying, and fleeing, or running away at random;, &c.: or a disposition thereto]. (Mṣb.) You say, of a camel, bihi XiraAdN [He has a disposition to take fright, or shy,, &c.]. (A.)
XaruwdN: see XaAridN, in five places.
XariydN Driven away, or expelled: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or, accord. to Aboo-Bekr, when following TariydN, it signifies fleeing, or running away: or, as Aṣ says, alone, or solitary. (TA.)

Also A remainder of anything; as of water in a vessel, and as of property, or camels and the like; pl. XaraAYidu, deviating from rule: or XariydapN is a syn. [or rather fem.] of XariydN [and XaraAYidu is its reg. pl.]. (L.)

XaAridN and XaruwdN↓, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) applied to a camel, (Ṣ, A, L,) and to a horse or the like, (L,) Taking fright, or shying, and fleeing, or running away at random; or refractory, and going away at random, or running away, or breaking loose, and going hither and thither by reason of sprightliness: or that takes fright, or shies,, &c.: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) [or] the latter [signifies wont to take fright, or shy,, &c.: and] is applied to a male animal and to a female: (L:) [the fem. of the former is with p {XaAridapN}:] pl. of the former Xur-adN (A,* L) and XaradN↓, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) [or rather this is a quasi-pl. n.,] like as xadamN is of xaAdimN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [and the pl. of XaAridapN is Xur-adN and XawaAridu;] and the pl. of XaruwdN↓ is XurudN, like as zuburN is of zabuwrN. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.*) You say farasN XaruwdN↓ A horse, or mare, refractory towards the rider: and naAqapN XaruwdN↓ A she-camel that runs away, or breaks loose and goes hither and thither by reason of her sprightliness. (L.)
[Hence,] qaAfiyapN XaruwdN↓ ‡ A rhyme, or verse, or poem, current through the countries, lands, or regions, or through the cities, or towns. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

And qawaAfK XawaAridu (Ṣ in art. Abd) and qawaAfK Xur-ado (Ḳ ibid.) [pls. of qaAfiyapN XaAridapN] ‡ Strange, unusual, unfamiliar, or extraordinary, rhymes or verses or poems; syn. OawaAbidu. (Ṣ and Ḳ ibid.)
And [in like manner] lafoZapN XaAridapN, in lexicology, signifies † A barbarism; or a strange, or an uncouth, unusual, unfamiliar, or extraordinary, word or expression or phrase; as also lfZp gariybapN and waHoXiy-apN and HuwXiy-apN; opposed to lfZp faSiyHapN. (Mz, 13th nwE.)
XirodimapN: see the art. here following.

XirocimapN A party, or company, (TaAYifapN,) of men, or people: (Ṣ:) or a small company: (TA:) or a small number of men, or people: (Ḳ:) and so XirodimapN, with the unpointed d, on the authority of AA: (IB, TA:) the former occurring in the Ḳur xxvi. 54. (TA.)
A piece, or portion, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of a thing, (Ṣ,) of a quince, &c.: pl. XaraAcimu and XaraAciymu. (Ḳ.)
[Hence,] vawobN XaraAcimu, (Ṣ,) or viyaAbN XaraAcimu, (Ḳ,) A garment, or garments, old and worn out, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) much rent. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. Xarisa, aor. _a {yaXorasu}, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. XarasN (Mṣb, TA, TḲ) and XaraAsapN and XariysN, (TḲ, the first and second also mentioned and explained, but not said to be inf. ns., in the Ṣ and O and Ḳ, and the third in like manner in the Ḳ,) or the second is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) or an inf. n. of which the verb is with damm [to the medial radical letter, as shown below], (TA,) He was, or became, evil in disposition, or illnatured, (Ṣ,* A,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA,) and very perverse or cross or repugnant, (Ṣ,* A,* Ḳ,* TA,) and averse. (TA.) And Xarisato nafosuhu, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. XarasN; (TA;) and Xarusato, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. XaraAsapN; (TA;) [His mind was, or became, evil in disposition,, &c.:] ISd and others make this distinction [in respect of the inf. ns.] in the usages of the two verbs. (TA.)
And Xarisa He showed, or manifested, or he made himself an object of, love, or affection, to men. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.) [Thus it has two contr. meanings.]
Also, Xarisa, He kept continually, or constantly, to the pasturing upon the trees called Xiros. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.)

And Xarasati AlmaAXiyapu, (AZ, AḤn, O, Ḳ,*) aor. _?, (AZ, O, Ḳ,) or, as written by El-Umawee and AḤn, _i {yaXorisu}, (TA,) inf. n. XaraAsapN, The cattle ate vehemently: (AZ, AḤn, O, Ḳ:) thus expl. without the particularizing of the Xiros [as the pasture eaten]. (TA.)
And Xarasahu, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O,) inf. n. XarosN, (Ḳ,) He pained him, or distressed him, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ,*) namely, his companion, (Ḳ,) with speech, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O,) [i. e.,] with rough speech. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. XArshu, (A, TA,) inf. n. XiraAsN (A, O, Ḳ) and muXaArasapN, (O, Ḳ,) He treated him, or behaved towards him, or dealt with him, with hardness, (A, O,* Ḳ,* TA,) or harshness, or illnature. (A, TA.)
6. tXArswA They treated one another [with hardness, or harshness, or illnature, (see 3,) or] with enmity, or hostility, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and contrariety, or perverseness. (TA.)

makaAnN XarosN, (Ṣ, O, TA,) and XarisN↓, (Ṣ, [both of these forms I find in my two copies of the Ṣ, the former in a poetical ex., and therefore it may perhaps be contraction of the latter by poetic license,]) and XaraAsN↓, (TA,) A place that is rugged, or rough, (Ṣ, O, TA,) and hard: or, as in the M, rough to the fell. (TA.) And OaroDN XarosaMCu↓, and XaraAsK↓, and XaraAsN↓, (O, Ḳ, TA, [the last written by Freytag Xur-aAsN,]) Land that is rugged, or rough, (O,) or hard, (Ḳ,) or hard and rugged or rough. (TA.)

XirosN Such as are small, of thorny trees; (Mgh,* Ḳ;) as also XarasN↓; (Ḳ;) the latter word thus expl. by AḤn: (O:) or the EiDaAh of the mountain, which are the small kind of thorny trees, (Ṣ, O, TA,*) having yellow thorns, or, as some say, such as have slender thorns, growing in depressed tracts, and in the deserts (AlS-aHaAraI), but not in the plain, or soft, tracts of valleys; (TA;) such as the Xuborum and HaAj (Ṣ, O) and XukaAEaI and qataAd. (O. [See EiD-N.]) See also OaXorasu.
XarasN: see next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: Xarisa (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XariysN↓ (A, O, Ḳ) and OaXorasu↓ (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) A man (Ṣ, O) evil in disposition, or illnatured, (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and very perverse or cross or repugnant, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) and averse: (TA:) and XarisapN and XariysapN↓ [both fem.] abounding in evilness of disposition or illnature, and in excessive perverseness, &c. (TA.) One says also nafosN XariysapN↓ A mind evil in disposition,, &c. (A, TA.) And naAqapN XariysN↓, (TA,) or caAtu XariysK, (O,) or the latter also, (TA,) i. q. XarisapN [A she-camel evil in disposition,, &c.]. (O.) See also OaXorasu.
Xarisu AlOakoli, (O, Ḳ,) or, accord. to AḤn, Xariysu↓ AlOakoli, (TA,) Vehement in respect of eating. (AḤn, O, Ḳ.)
See also XarosN.
XarisapN and XariysapN↓ [A land (OaroDN)] abounding with Xaras [or Xiros, i. e. the trees thus called]; (TA;) [and] OaroDN muXorisapN↓ a land abounding with Xiros. (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ.)

entry.sense: XaraAsN: see XarosN, in two places.
XaraAsK: see XarosN.
XariysN: see XarisN, in six places: and OaXorasu.
OaXorasu: see XarisN. Hence, (O,) AlOaXorasu The lion; (O, Ḳ;) as also AlX-arisu↓, (O,) or AlX-ariysu↓; (Ḳ;) because of his evil disposition. (O.)
And Bold, or daring, in fight: (O, Ḳ:) or this is a mistranscription for OaXowasu, mentioned in the T as having this meaning. (TA.)
Also i. q. OafaZ-u [More, and most, evil in disposition or illnatured, &c.]. (TA in art. fZ.)

Eavara biOaXorasi Ald-ahori, meaning † [He stumbled upon, or chanced to meet with,] hardship, calamity, or adversity: a prov. (O, Ḳ. [In Meyd (and so in Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 96,) EavaronaA biXirosi↓ Ald-ahori, and expl. as lit. meaning the trees called Xiros.])
See also XarosN.
muXorisN Whose camels pasture upon the [trees called] Xiros. (Ṣ.)
OaroDN muXorisapN: see XarisN.
XarosafapN Badness of natural disposition; illnature. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: XurosuwfN The guDoruwf [or cartilage] attached to each rib; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) like the guDoruwf of the scapula: (Ṣ, O:) or the extremity of the rib, projecting over the belly: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or the head of the rib, next the belly: (IAạr, O:) or a rib having a guDoruwf [or cartilage] at its extremity: (ISd, TA:) pl. XaraAsiyfu. (Ṣ, O.)
A camel shackled. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.)
And A camel hocked, or hamstrung, in one of his legs. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.)
And A captive having his arms bound behind his back. (IAạr, O.)
Calamity, or misfortune: and the commencement of hardship. (Ḳ.) One says, OaSaAbati Aln-aAsa AlX-araAsiyfu The commencements of hardships befell the people. (IF, O.)

entry.sense: XaApN muXarosafapN A sheep, or goat, having in its sides a whiteness covering the XaraAsiyf [pl. of XurosuwfN, q. v.,] (Lth, O, Ḳ) and the XawaAkil [pl. of XaAkilapN, q. v.]. (Lth, O.)

hom.sense: 1. XaraTa Ealayohi kacaA, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaXoriTu} and _u {yaXoruTu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. XaroTN; (Mṣb;) and AXtrT↓ Elyh kcA; (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Ḳ,* TA;) both signify the same; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [He imposed such a thing as a condition, or by stipulation, upon him;] he made such a thing a condition against him. (TḲ.) And XaraTa Ealayohi fiI AlbayoEi He imposed a thing as obligatory upon him in the sale, and took it upon himself as such. (TḲ.)

XaraTa, aor. _i {yaXoriTu} and _u {yaXoruTu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XaroTN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) He (a cupper) scarified; syn. bazaga; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Xr-T↓, inf. n. taXoriyTN. (JK in art. bzg, and TA.*) [Hence, and from the verb in the sense first mentioned, the saying,] rub-a XaroTi XaAriTK OawojaEu mino XaroTi XaAriTK [Many a condition of one making a condition is more painful than the scarifying of a scarifier]. (TA.)
He slit the ear of a camel. (TA.)
He slit. and then twisted, [or wove together, (see XariyTN,)] palm-leaves. (TA.)
XariTa He fell into a momentous, or formidable, case. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see the next preceding paragraph {1}.

3. XArThu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muXaAraTapN, (TA,) He made a condition, or conditions, or he stipulated, with him, mutually; each of them made a condition, or conditions, or each of them stipulated, with the other. (O, L, Ḳ.) And tXArT↓ Ealayohi is like XaAraTa [app. meaning He made a condition, or conditions, with another, or others; or they (a party of persons) made a condition, or conditions, together; against him]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. AXrT nafosahu He marked himself, and prepared himself, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) likacaA (Ḳ) or liOamori kacaA [for such an affair]. (Ṣ.)
He (a courageous man) marked himself for death. (TA.)
AXrT nafosahu wamaAlahu fiI hecaA AlOamori He put forward, or offered, himself and his property in this affair. (TA.)

AXrT Uibilahu He made known that his camels were for sale. (Ḳ.) And AXrT TaAYifapF mino Uibilihi waganamihi He set apart a portion of his camels, and of his sheep, or goats, and made known that they were for sale. (TA.) And AXrT mino Uibilihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and ganamihi, (Ṣ,) He prepared for sale some of his camels, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of his sheep, or goats. (Ṣ.)
OaXoraTotu fulaAnFA liEamali kacaA I prepared such a one for such a work, or such an agency or employment, and made him to have the charge, or management, thereof. (AA.)
AXrT Uilayohi Alr-asuwla He hastened to him the messenger, (Ḳ,* TA,) and sent him forward: from OaXoraATN signifying the “beginnings” of things. (TA.)
AXrT bihaA, and fiyhaA, He held it to be, or made it, a thing of mean account, and perilled, hazarded, or risked, it. (TA.) [It is not said to what the pronoun refers.]

entry.sense: 5. tXr-T fiI Eamalihi He acted, or performed, well, soundly and skilfully, or, nicely and exactly, in his work, (O, L, Ḳ,) and constrained himself to observe whatever conditions were imposed upon him. (L.)
6: see 3.
8: see 1, first signification.
[AuXoturiTa It was made conditional, or a condition. And He, or it, was made to be conditionally intended, in, or by, a saying, duwna gayorihi exclusively of any other..]
10. AstXrT AlmaAlu The camels, or the like, became in a bad state after having been in a good state. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) [See XaraTN.]

hom.sense: XaroTN [A condition; a term; a stipulation; said to signify] the imposition of a thing as obligatory [upon a person], and the taking it upon oneself as such, in a sale and the like; (Ḳ;) [but this is a loose explanation, as is observed in the TḲ; the meaning being a thing imposed upon a person as obligatory, and taken upon oneself as such: in the Ṣ, it is merely said to be well known:] and XariyTapN↓ signifies the same: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. of the former, XuruwTN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and of the latter, XaraAYiTu. (Mṣb, TA.) It is said in a trad., laA yajuwzu XaroTaAni fiI bayoEK [Two conditions in a sale are not allowable]; as when one says, “I sell to thee this garment, or piece of cloth, for ready money for a deenár, and on credit for two deenárs.” (TA.) And it is said in a prov., AlX-aroTu Oamolaku Ealayoka Oamo laka (TA) The condition is most valid, or binding, [whether it be against thee or in thy favour:] (Mgh in art. mlk:) relating to the keeping of conditions between brothers. (Ṣgh, TA.) [XaroTN also relates to other things beside sales and the like: for instance, you say, XaroTu AlmaSodari kacaA wakacaA, meaning What is required to justify the application of the term mSdr is such a thing, and such a thing.]
XaroTaA nahorK The two banks of a river. (TA.)
[The pl.] XuruwTN also signifies Roads leading in different directions. (TA.)
See also XaraTN, in two places.

XaraTN A sign, token, or mark, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which men appoint between them; (TA;) as also XaroTN↓: (TA:) pl. of the former, OaXoraATN. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) And hence, (Mṣb,) OaXoraATu Als-aAEapi The signs of the resurrection, or of the time thereof; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) mentioned in the Ḳur [xlvii. 20]: or the small events prior thereto, which men deny: (El-Khaṭṭábee:) or the means thereof, exclusive of the main circumstances thereof, and of the event itself. (TA.)

[Hence also,] AlX-araTaAni The two stars [a and b] which are the two horns of Aries; (Ṣ, Ḳ, Ḳzw;) the brighter whereof is called Aln-aATiHu; (Ḳzw;) [and the other, Aln-aToHu;] the First Mansion of the Moon: (Ḳzw:) to- wards the north of them is a small star which some of the Arabs reckon with those two, saying that it (namely this mansion, Ḳ) consists of three stars, and calling them AlOaXoraATu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) IAạr mentions an instance of the use of the sing., AlX-araTu; but the dual is more approved, and more commonly known: (TA:) the two stars above mentioned are the first asterism of the spring. (ISd, Z.) [See manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.] Hassán Ibn-Thábit says,
fiI nadaAmaI biyDi Alwujuwhi kiraAmK
nub-ihuwA baEoda hajoEapi AlOaXoraATi
meaning [Among fair-faced, generous cup-companions, roused from sleep after] the setting of the AXrAT: though another meaning, which see below, has been assigned to the last word. (Ṣgh.)

And hence, (ISd, Z,) XaraTN also signifies † The beginning of a thing; (ISd,* Z,* Ḳ;) as also miXoraATN↓: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:) pl. of the former, OaXoraATN, which is applied to the beginnings of any event that happens because the XaraTaAn are the first asterism of the spring: (ISd, Z:) the pl. of mXrAT↓ in the sense here expl. is maXaAriyTu. (Ḳ.) Hence, accord. to some, OaXoraATu Als-aAEapi, expl. above. (TA.)

The refuse, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) such as the galled in the back, and the emaciated, (TA,) and the young, (Ḳ,) and the bad, (AʼObeyd,) of camels or the like, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or of goats, (Mṣb,) or of goats also: (Ṣ:) used alike as sing. and pl. and masc. and fem.: and applied particularly to the young of camels, as a pl. and as a sing.: also, to a she-camel and to a he-camel: and to such, of camels, as is brought, or driven, from one place to another for sale; as the aged she-camel, and the camel that is galled in the back: (TA:) also the same, not XaroTN↓ as in the Ḳ, [without restriction of its application,] low, base, vile, or mean; (Ḳ,* TA;) and so OaXoraTu↓: (TA:) pl. OaXoraATN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and pl. pl. OaXaAriyTu. (Ṣ,* TA.) You say, Alganamu OaXoraATu AlmaAli [Sheep, or goats, are the refuse, or meanest sort, of beasts that people possess]. (Ṣ.) And XaraTN is also applied to men; (Ṣ, TA;) XaraTu Aln-aAsi signifying The refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, pf mankind or people. (TA.) In the verse of Hassán Ibn-Thábit cited above, AlOaXoraAT is said to mean The guards, or watchmen, and the lowest or basest or meanest sort of people; (Ṣ, Ṣgh;) [so that hajoEap must be understood in the sense of “a light sleep in the first part of the night;”] but the correct meaning is that expl. before. (Ṣgh.)
Also OaXoraATN, The noble, eminent, or honourable, sort of men: thus the word has two contr. significations. (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And A small water-course coming from a space of ten cubits: (AḤn, O, Ḳ:) or what flows from even tracts of ground into the [larger water-courses called] XiEaAb. (TA.)

entry.sense: XaroTapN A single act of scarifying; a scarification. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: XuroTapN A thing which one has made a condition. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) You say, xuco XuroTataka Take thou that which thou hast made a condition. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

Also, and XuraTapN↓, (Mgh,) or XuraTN, (Ḳ,) which is the pl. (Mgh, Ḳ) of the former, (Ḳ,) The choice men of the army: (Mgh:) and such as compose the first portion of the army that is present in the war or fight, (Mgh, Ḳ,) and prepare for death; (Ḳ;) [the braves of an army;] they are the Sultán's choice men of the army; and the term XuroTapN is applied in a trad. to a party making it a condition to die, and not return, unless victorious: (TA:) or this appellation, and XuraTapN↓, which is a rare form, are applied to a body of soldiers; and the pl. is XuraTN: and the pl. is applied to the aids (OaEowaAn [here app. meaning guards]) of the Sul- tán: (Mṣb:) XuroTapN, also, is applied to a wellknown body of the aids (OaEowaAn [here meaning armed attendants, officers, or soldiers,]) of the prefects [of the police]; (Ḳ;) pl. XuraTN: (TA:) the XuraT, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb,) or the XuroTap, (Ḳ,) are so called because they assumed to themselves signs, or marks, whereby they might be known (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) to the enemies: (Mṣb:) or the XuraT are so called because they were prepared: (AO, Ṣ:) or as being likened to the XaraT, or “refuse,” of goats; because they were low persons: (Mṣb:) [or, probably, because they were prepared, or exposed, to be slain:] a single person of the XuraT is called XuroTapN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and XuraTiI-N↓: (Ṣ:) or XuroTiI-N↓ and XuroTiI-N↓ are applied to a single person of the XuroTap: (Ḳ:) XuroTiI-N↓ is a rel. n. from XuroTapN; and such also is XuraTiI-N↓ from XuraTapN; not from XuraTN, because this is a pl. (Mgh.) SaAHibu AlX-uroTapi signifies The governor, or prefect, (Mgh, Mṣb,) [of the police, or] of a town, or city, or district, or province; to whom formerly pertained both religious and civil affairs; but now it is not so. (Mgh. [See ridofN.]) [In later times, this title has been commonly applied to The chief, or prefect, of the police.]
Also The best, best part, or choice, of anything; as also XariyTapN↓: the latter occurring in a trad., as related by Sh; but Az thinks it should be the former word. (TA.)

entry.sense: XuraTapN: see XuroTapN, in two places.

XaraTiI-N Of, or relating to, [the asterism called] the XaraTaAn and the OaXoraAT;
as also OaXoraATiI-N↓; the latter being formed from the pl., (IB, TA,) because the stars thus called are regarded as composing one thing. (TA.) You say, rawoDapN OaXoraATiy-apN↓, meaning [A garden, or meadow,, &c.,] rained upon by the nawoC [q. v.] of the XaraTaAn. (Ṣ. TA.) In the A we find nawoCN XiraATiI-N↓: but probably it should be XaraTiI-N. (TA.)
XuroTiI-N and XuraTiI-N: see XuroTapN, in five places.

XariyTN A rope, or cord, of twisted palm-leaves: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and threads of wool and of fibres of the palm-tree [twisted together]: (TA:) or palmleaves twisted together, with which is woven (yuXoraTu, as in the Ḳ, or, as in the O, accord. to the TA, yuXoraHu, [app. a mistake for yuXoraju,]) a couch, or bier, [app. meaning the part thereof upon which a man or corpse lies,] and the like: (O, Ḳ:) so called because its palm-leaves are split, and then twisted together: if of fibres of the palm-tree, it is called disaArN: (TA:) or a wide rope [or flat plait] woven of fibres or leaves of the palm-tree: (Mgh in art. qmT:) or a rope of any kind: pl. XaraAYiTu and XuruTN. (TA.) Also Threads of silk, or of silk and of gold, twisted together [or woven, so as to form a kind of flat lace, like tape]: so called as being likened to the threads of wool and of fibres of the palm-tree [twisted together]. (TA.)

Also The [sort of basket, or small box, called] Eatiydap in which a woman puts her perfumes (IAạr, O, Ḳ) and her utensils or apparatus. (IAạr, O.) And The [sort of receptacle called] Eayobap [q. v.]. (IAạr, O.)

hom.sense: XariyTapN: see XaroTN:
and see also XuroTapN, last sentence.
Also A she-camel having her ear slit: (Ḳ, TA:) of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN. (TA.)

And A sheep or goat having a slight scar made upon its throat, like the scarification of the cupper, without the severing of the [veins called] OawodaAj, and without making the blood to flow copiously: thus they used to do in the Time of Ignorance, cutting a little of the animal's throat, (Ḳ, TA,) and then leaving it to die; (TA;) and they considered it a lawful mode of slaughtering it; but the eating of such an animal is forbidden in a trad.: (Ḳ, TA:) or one scarified on account of some disease; and when such died, they said that they had slaughtered it. (TA.)

entry.sense: XiraATiI-N: see XaraTiI-N.

XirowaATN, applied to a man, Tall: (O, Ḳ:) and, applied to a camel, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O,) or to a he-camel, (Kudot;,) swift: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ:) or it is applied in the former sense to a man, and is also applied to a camel, male and female alike, (ʼEyn, Ṣ,) as meaning tall and slender: (ʼEyn:) or it means tall, spare of flesh, slender; applied to a man and to a camel, and to the female likewise, without p. (L.)

Alganamu OaXoraTu AlmaAli Sheep, or goats, are the vilest sort of beasts that one possesses: an instance of a noun of superiority without a verb; which is extr.: (Ḳ, TA:) this is from the “Isláh el-Alfádh” of ISk: but in some of the copies of that work, we find OaXoraAT in the place of OaXoraT. (ISd, TA.) See XaraTN.
OaXoraATiI-N: fem. OaXoraATiI-apN: see XaraTiI-N, in two places.
miXoraTN A lancet (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) with which the cupper scarifies; (TA;) as also miXoraATN↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: miXoraATN: [pl. maXaAriyTu:] see miXoraTN:
and see XaraTN, in two places.
Oaxaca liloOamori maXaAriyTahu He took his apparatus, [or prepared himself,] for the thing, or affair. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

1. XaraEati Ald-awaAb-N fiI AlmaMCi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXoraEu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. XaroEN and XuruwEN, [the latter of which is the more common,] and maXoruwEN↓, (TA, [there said to be syn. with XuruwEN, like as mayosuwrN is with yusorN,]) The beasts entered into the water, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and drank of it: (TA:) and XaraEa, aor. as above, and so the inf. ns., he (one coming to water to drink) took the water with his mouth: (TA:) or XaraEotu fiI AlmaMCi, inf. ns. as above, I drank the water with my hands: or I entered into the water: and XaraEa AlmaAlu the cattle came to the water to drink: (Mṣb:) and Xar-aEati↓ Ald-aAb-apu [if not a mistranscription for Xur-iEat] the beast was, or became, at the watering-place. (TA.)
[Hence,] XaraEa fiI AlOamori, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Mṣb,) inf. n. XuruwEN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He entered into the affair; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) he entered upon, began, or commenced, the affair. (Mṣb.)

XaraEa AlbaAbu UilaI AlT-ariyqi, inf. n. XuruwEN, The door, or entrance, communicated with the road. (Mṣb.) And XaraEa Almanozilu The dwelling was upon, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or had its door [opening] upon, (TA,) a road that was a thoroughfare. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
XaraEa said of a spear, It pointed directly [towards a person: see an explanation of the trans. verb in what follows]. (Ṣ, Ḳ: but in the latter, XaraEat, said of spears.) See also XaroEN.
And, said of a road, (Mgh,) and of an affair, or a case, (TA,) It was, or became, apparent, manifest, or plain. (IAạr, Mgh, TA.)

XaraEa AlmaAla, aor. as above, [inf. n., app., XaroEN,] He brought the cattle to the watering-place; a also AXrEhu↓: (Mṣb:) and the former is trans. in this sense by means of bi: (Ḥar p. 21:) or XaraEa (TA) and Xr-E↓, inf. n. of the latter taXoriyEN, (Ṣ, TA,) he made the beasts, (Ṣ,) or his camels, (TA,) to enter into the water [to drink]: (Ṣ, TA:*) and AXrE↓ naAqatahu he made his she-camel to enter into the watering-place: (TA:) or taXoriyEN↓ signifies the bringing camels to the wateringplace to drink without requiring in doing so to draw with the pulley and its appertenances nor to give them to drink in a watering-trough or tank. (O, Ḳ.) It is said in a prov, (Ṣ,) Oahowanu Als-aqoIi Alt-aXoriyEu↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) The easiest mode of watering is the making of the camels to enter into the water: applied to him who takes an easy way of performing an affair, and does not exert himself therein. (Meyd. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 889.])

XaraEa AlbaAba UilaI AlT-ariyqi He made the door, or entrance, to communicate with the road: (Mṣb:) and AXrEhu↓ AlI AlTryq (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) signifies the same; (Mṣb, TA;) or he opened it (i. e. the door, or entrance,) to the road. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) And AXrE↓ AljanaAHa UilaI AlT-ariyqi He put the jnAH [meaning projecting roof] towards the road. (Mṣb.)

And XaraEa (Ḳ) and AXrE↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and Xr-E↓ (TA) He directed (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) a spear, (Ṣ, TA,) or spears, (Ḳ,) and a sword, (TA,) qibalaha (Ṣ) or naHowahu (TA) [i. e. towards him]: or AXrE↓ signifies he inclined a spear. (Mṣb.)

And XaraEa, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) aor. as above, (Mṣb,) inf. n. XaroEN, (TA,) He made apparent, manifest, or plain, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) a road; (Mgh, TA;) as also AXrE↓; and Xr-E↓, inf. n. taXoriyEN: (Ḳ, TA:) and in like manner, an affair, or a case; and religion. (TA.) Accord. to Az, this meaning of XaraEa is from XaraEa AlUihaAba [which see in what follows]. (TA.) One says, XaraEa Qll-ehu lanaA kacaA God made apparent, manifest, or plain, to us, such a thing. (Mṣb.) And XaraEa fulaAnN Such a one made apparent, manifest, or plain, the truth, or right. (TA.)

And XaraEa lahumo i. q. san-a [i. e. He instituted, established, or prescribed, for them, or to them, a religious ordinance, a law, &c.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ) whence [accord. to some,] XariyEapN and XiroEapN. (TA.)

XaraEa AlUihaAba, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. as above, inf. n. XaroEN, (Ṣ,) He stripped off the hide: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, accord. to Yaạḳoob, as heard by him from Umm-El-Homáris El-Bekreeyeh, he slit the hide in the part between the two hind legs, (Ṣ, TA,) and then stripped it off: or he slit the hide, [and then stripped it off,] not making of it a ziq- [q. v.], nor stripping it off [entire] by commencing from one hind leg. (TA.)

XaraEa AlHabola He loosed, or undid, the rope, or cord, or the slip-knot thereof, (OanoXaTahu,) [then, app., doubled it in the middle, to put that part round something to be carried,] and inserted its two halves (quTorayohi) into the loop. (O, Ḳ.)
And XaraEa AlX-aIoCa He raised, or elevated, the thing much; (Ḳ;) as also AXrEhu↓. (TA.)
2: see 1, in six places.
Xr-E Als-afiynapa, inf. n. taXoriyEN, He made, or put, a sail (XiraAE) to the ship, or boat. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1, former half, in two places.

[Hence,] one says, AXrE yadahu UilaI AlmiToharapi † He put his hand [to and] into the mThrp [or vessel for purification]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. (respecting the [ablution termed] wuDuwoC), Hat-aI OaXoraEa fiI AlEaDudi meaning Until, or so that, he made the upper half of the arm to reach to (lit. to enter) the water. (TA. [This ex. is elliptical and inverted; for Ht-I AXrE AlEaDoda fiI AlmaMCi.])
And OaXoraEaniI Alr-ajulu † The man sufficed me; or gave me what sufficed me: and AXrEnI AlX-aIoCu † The thing sufficed me. (TA.)
And OaXoraEa said of a plant, or of herbage, [app. for OaXoraEa AlUibila,] † It became full-grown, and satiated the camels. (TA.)
See, again, 1, latter half, in six places.

8. fulaAnN yaXotariEu XiroEatahu [meaning Such a one originates, or embraces, or follows, his way of religion] is similar to the phrases yafotaTiru fiToratahu and yamotal-u mil-atahu; from XiroEapu Ald-iyni and fiToratuhu and mil-atuhu. (TA.)
XaroEN, originally an inf. n.:
then applied as a name for A manifest, a plain, or an open, track, or road, or way:
and then, metaphorically, to The divine way of religion; so says Er-Rághib; (TA;) syn. with XariyEapN, q. v. (Mṣb.)

In the saying mararotu birajulK XaroEika, (so in the Ḳ,) or mrrt birajulK XaroEuka mino rajulK, (so in the Ṣ and O, [for huwa XaroEuka,]) with kesr and with damm to the E [of XrEk], (TA,) i. e. [I passed by a man] sufficing thee [as a man], (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) the meaning is, of the sort to which thou directest thyself and which thou seekest (taXoraEu↓ fiyhi wataTolubuhu): (Ṣ, O:) and the word in this sense is used alike as sing. and pl. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and dual, because it is [originally] an inf. n. (Ṣ, O.) You say, XaroEuka hecaA [and hecaAni and heWulaMCi] i. e. Sufficient for thee [is this and are these two and are these]. (Ṣ: and the like is said in the Mgh.) And it is said in a prov.,
XaroEuka maA bal-agaka AlmaHal-aA
thus correctly, for it is a hemistich; not AlmaHal-a, as in the Ṣ and Ḳ; (TA;) i. e. Sufficient travel-ling-provision for thee is that which will cause thee to reach the place [of alighting] to which thou repairest: (Ḳ, TA:) applied to the case of being content with little. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also XaraEN, in two places.
And see XiroEapN.

hom.sense: XiroEN [in the CK, erroneously, XaroE,] The like of a thing; as also XiroEapN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) [but the former is masc. and ↓the latter is fem.; for] one says, hecaA XiroEu hecaA This is the like of this; and so hecihi XiroEapu↓ hecihi: and hecaAni XiroEaAni these two are likes. (Ṣ, O, TA.) [The pls., or rather coll. gen. ns. and pls., following this meaning in the Ḳ belong to XiroEapN and XaroEapN in another sense; as is shown by exs. in the O and TA.]
Also The chords of the barobaT, (O, Ḳ, TA,) which is the [Persian] Euwd [or lute]. (TA.) [In this sense, a coll. gen. n.:] see its n. un. XiroEapN.

And hence, as being likened thereto, (TA,) ‡ The [thong called] XiraAk of a sandal. (O, Ḳ, TA.) It is related in a trad. that a man said, Uin-iI OuHib-u AljamaAla Hat-aI fiI XiroEi naEoliI (O, TA) i. e. ‡ [Verily I love elegance, even] in the XrAk of my sandal. (TA.)
XaraEN: see XariyEapN.

One says, Aln-aAsu fiI hecaA AlOamori XaraEN and XaroEN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter a contraction of the former, (Mṣb,) allowed by Kr and Ḳz, but disallowed by Yaạḳoob, (IDrst, TA,) The people are in this affair equals: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) in this sense, used alike as sing. and pl. and fem. (Ṣ, TA) and masc.: (TA:) [of XaraEN] Az says that it seems to be pl. [or quasi-pl. n.] of XaAriEN↓, like as xadamN is of xaAdimN; i. e., [the phrase means] the people enter into this affair (yaXoraEuwna fiyhi) together. (TA.) One says also, Aln-aAsu XaraEN waAHidN and XaroEN↓ wAHd, meaning The people are one sort. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: XaroEapN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

hom.sense: XiroEapN: see XariyEapN, in two places.
Also A custom. (TA.)
See also XiroEN, first sentence, in three places.
Also A snare for the birds called qaTFA, (Lth, O, Ḳ, TA,) with which to capture them, (O, TA,) made of sinews: (Lth, O, TA:) pl. XiraEN. (O.)

Also, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and XaroEapN↓, (Ḳ,) A string, or chord: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) or such as is slender: or while continuing stretched upon the bow; (TA;) and so XiraAEN↓; (Lth, O, Ḳ;) or upon the lute; and so XiraAEN↓: (TA:) the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] (of XiroEapN↓, Ṣ, O, [i. e. of this n. un. meaning the “chord of a lute,” as is shown by exs. in the O and TA,]) is XiroEN↓ (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and (that of XaroEapN↓, TA) XaroEN↓, (O, Ḳ, TA,) like as tamorN is of tamorapN, (O, TA,) and [the pl. properly so termed] (of XiroEapN, Ṣ, O) XiraEN, and pl. pl. XiraAEN: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and the pl. of XiraAEN↓ as a sing. syn. with XiroEapN is XuruEN. (TA.)

entry.sense: XaraEapN i. q. saqiyfapN [i. e. A roof, or covering, such as projects over the door of a house, &c.; or a place roofed over]: pl. OaXoraAEN. (O, Ḳ.)
[XaroEiI-N Of, or relating to, the religion or law.]
[And Accordant to the religion or law; legal, or legitimate.]
XuraAEN A plant, or herbage, full-grown, (O, Ḳ, TA,) that satiates the camels. (TA.)

hom.sense: XiraAEN: see XariyEapN.

The XiraAEN of a ship or boat (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb) is called in Pers. baAdobaAn [i. e. A sail]; (MA, Mgh, KL;) i. q. qiloEN; (MA, TA;) a thing like a wide mulaMCap [q. v.], (O, Ḳ, TA,) of cloth or of matting, (TA,) [raised, or attached,] upon a piece of wood [i. e. a mast or a yard]; which is beaten upon by the wind (tuSaf-iquhu Alr-iyHu,) and causes the ship, or boat, to go along: (O, Ḳ, TA:) so called because it is raised (yuXoraEu i. e. yurofaEu) above the ship, or boat: (TA:) pl. OaXoriEapN and XuruEN; (O, Ḳ;) the former a pl. of pauc. (O.)

And hence, as being likened thereto, (TA, [and the same is implied in the Ṣ and O,]) ‡ The neck of a camel. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.) Sometimes they said of a camel, rafaEa XiraAEahu, meaning ‡ He raised his neck: (Ṣ, O, TA.)
One says also rajulN XiraAEu AlOanofi, meaning † A man having the nose extended, and long. (TA. [See OaXoraEu.])
See also XiroEapN, in three places.
XariyEN Courageous; (O, Ḳ, TA;) applied to a man. (O, TA.)
Also Good, or excellent, flax. (Ḳ.)

And The lyf [or fibres that grow at the base of the branches of the palm-tree] of which the prickles (Xawok) are strong, and such as, by reason of their thickness, are fit for the sewing of leather therewith. (TA.)

entry.sense: XaraAEapN Courage; (O, Ḳ;) as an attribute of a man. (O.)

XariyEapN and maXoraEapN↓ (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and maXoruEapN↓ (Mṣb, Ḳ) and maXoraEN↓ (TA) and XaraEN↓ (O, TA *) and XiraAEu↓ maMCK (TA) A watering-place; a resort of drinkers [both men and beasts]; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) a place to which men come to drink therefrom and to draw water, (Mṣb,* TA,) and into which they sometimes make their beasts to enter, to drink: (TA:) but the term mXrEp↓, (Az, Mṣb,) or XryEp, (TA,) is not applied by the Arabs to any but [a watering-place] such as is permanent, and apparent to the eye, (Az, Mṣb, TA,) like the water of rivers, (Mṣb,) not water from which one draws with the well-rope: (Az, Mṣb, TA:) the pl. of XariyEapN is XaraAYiEu; and that of maXoraEapN↓ or maXoraEN↓ [or of both] is maXaAriEu; which is also expl. as meaning gaps, or breaches, in the banks of rivers or the like by which men or beasts come to water: (TA:) and [in like manner it is said that] XariyEapN signifies a place of descent to water: (Lth, TA:) or a way to water. (Bḍ in v. 52.)

And hence, (Lth, Kr, Mṣb, TA, and Bḍ ubi suprà,) AlX-ariyEapu, (Lth, Kr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) as also AlX-iroEapu↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) and AlX-aroEu↓, (Mṣb,) signifies likewise Ald-iynu; (Mṣb, and Bḍ ubi suprà;) because it is a way to the means of eternal life; (Bḍ ibid.;) or because of its manifestness; (Mṣb;) [i. e.] The religious law of God; (Lth, Kr, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,* TA;) consisting of such ordinances as those of fasting and prayer and pilgrimage (Lth, Kr, TA) and the giving of the poorrate (Kr, TA) and marriage, (Lth, TA,) and other acts (Lth, Kr, TA) of piety, or of obedience to God, or of duty to Him and to men: (Kr, TA:) pl. as above. (Mṣb.) XariyEapN signifies also [A law, an ordinance, or a statute: and] a religion, or way of belief and practice in respect of religion: (Fr, TA:) and a way of belief or conduct that is manifest (Ibn-ʼArafeh, Mgh, Ḳ) and right (Ibn-ʼArafeh, Ḳ) in religion; (Mgh;) and so XiroEapN↓. (Ḳ.)

XuraAEiI-N, as an epithet applied to A spear-head and a spear, of Shuráa, (TA,) which was the name of a certain man who made spear-heads and spears, (Ḳ, TA,) as they assert: but IAạr says that it may be a reg. rel. n. from XuraAEN, or an irreg. rel. n. from some other name of which the radical latters are XrE: and [SM says also that,] applied to a spear, it signifies long: (TA:) or XiraAEiI-N↓, thus applied, has this meaning, a rel. n. [from XiraAEN]. (Ṣ, O.) XuraAEiy-apN and XiraAEiy-apN↓ [in the CK without teshdeed], applied to a she-camel, signify ‡ Long-necked; (O, Ḳ, TA:)
thus expl. by ISh: but Az thinks the latter to be the more probably correct; the neck being likened to the XiraAE of the ship or boat, because of the height thereof. (O.)
Xar-aAEN A seller of the flax called XariyE. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: XaAriEN Entering into water [to drink]: pl. Xur-aEN and XuruwEN: (KL:) these pls. are applied in this sense to camels. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] Entering into an affair (fiI OamorK). (Az, TA.) See XaraEN.

And sing. of Xur-aEN in the phrase HiytaAnN Xur-aEN, (TA,) which means Fishes lowering their heads to drink: (Aboo-Leylà, TA:) or raising their heads: (Ḳ, TA:) or directing themselves, or repairing, (XaAriEaAtN,) from the deep water to the bank, or side: (Ṣ, TA:) and HytAn XuruwEN signifies the same: (TA:) or Xur-aEFA in the Ḳur vii. 163, referring to fish, means appearing upon the surface of the water. (Bḍ, Jel.*)

Also, applied to a place of alighting, or an abode, (manozilN,) Situate upon a road that is a thoroughfare: and XaAriEapN applied to a house (daArN) signifies the same; (Ḳ;) or having its door [opening] upon such a road; (TA;) or near to the road and to the people [or passengers]: (Mgh,* TA:) and duwrN XaAriEapN houses having their doors opening into the streets: or duwrN XawaAriEu, as expl. by IDrd, houses upon one open road. (TA.) It is said in a trad., kaAnati AlOabowaAbu XaAriEapF UilaI Almasojidi The doors were opening towards the mosque. (TA.)

And Anything near (Ḳ, TA) to a thing, or overlooking it: whence XaAriEapN applied to a house (daArN) near to the road and to the people, as expl. above. (TA.) [Hence,] nujuwmN XawaAriEu Stars near to setting. (Ḳ.)

[Also Pointing directly towards a person; applied to a spear.] One says rimaAHN XaAriEapN and XawaAriEu (Ḳ, TA) and Xur-aEN as in some of the copies of the Ṣ (TA) Spears pointing directly: and rimaAHN maXoruwEapN↓ and muXoraEapN↓ spears directed. (Ḳ, TA.)

Also [used as a subst.] A main road: (Ṣ, O:) or it signifies, (Mgh, TA,) or so TariyqN XaAriEN, (Mṣb,) ‡ a road, or way, into which people enter (yasolukuhu Aln-aAsu, Mṣb, or yaXoraEu fiyhi Aln-aAsu, Mgh, TA) in common, or in general; (Mgh, Mṣb, TA;) by a tropical attribution; (Mgh;) [i. e.] XaAriEN in this case has the meaning of maXoruwEN [or maXoruwEN fiyhi]; (Mṣb;) or as meaning cuw XaroEK mina Alxaloqi [having an entering of people]: (TA:) or it signifies a manifest, plain, or conspicuous, road or way: (Mgh, TA:) [in the present day, XaAriEN commonly signifies any great street that is a thoroughfare:] the pl. is XawAriEu. (Mṣb.)

AlX-aAriEu also means The learned man who practises what he knows and instructs others: (Ḳ, TA:) or so AlX-aAriEu Alr-ab-aAniI-u. (O.) And hence it is applied to designate the Prophet: [or as meaning The legislator: or the announcer of the law:] or because he made manifest and plain the religion, or religious law of God. (TA.)

entry.sense: OaXoraEu A nose of which the end is extended (Ḳ, TA) and elevated, and long. (TA.)
maXoraEN: see XariyEapN, in two places.
muXoraEN: see its fem., with p {muXoraEapN}, voce XaAriEN.
maXoraEapN and maXoruEapN: see XariyEapN, in four places.
bayotN muXar-aEN A high, or lofty, house or tent. (TA.)

hom.sense: maXoruwEN: see its fem., with p {maXoruwEapN}, voce XaAriEN:
