And A certain eruption upon the body, resembling dirhems: (TA:) or small pimples or purulent pustules, having a burning property: (Ṣ:) or small pimples or purulent pustules, red, itching, and distressing, generally originating at once, (Ḳ, TA,) but sometimes gradually, (TA,) and becoming [more] severe by night in consequence of a hot vapour breaking forth at once upon the body: (Ḳ, TA:) thus in the “Kánoon” of Ibn-Seenà [or Avicenna]. (TA.)
cuw AlX-araI A certain idol of [the tribe of] Dows (dawos), (Ḳ, TA,) in the Saráh (Als-araAp): so says Naṣr. (TA.)

entry.sense: XarK Having the eruption termed XarFI, described in the next preceding paragraph. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

XirFI, (Ṣ, TA,) an inf. n. of XaraI, aor. yaXoriI, (TA,) [when used as a simple subst., signifying A sale and also a purchase,] has OaXoriyapN for its pl., which, as pl. of a sing. of the measure fiEalN, is anomalous. (Ṣ, TA.)
XaraApN: see XarFI, in two places.
XaraMCN: see XarFI.
XariI-N Sold: and also bought: applied in this sense to a male slave; and Xariy-apN to a female slave. (Mṣb.)

Also A horse that persists, or perseveres, in his pace, or going: (Ṣ:) or that exceeds the usual bounds therein, (Ḳ, TA,) and goes on without languor: (TA:) or a choice horse: (A, TA:) or an excellent, choice horse. (TA.)

hom.sense: Xariy-apN A way, course, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like: and a nature; or a natural, a native, or an innate, disposition or temper or the like. (Ḳ.)
Also, of women, Such as bring forth females. (Ḳ.) One says, tazaw-aja fiI Xariy-api nisaMCK He married among women such as bring forth females. (TA.)

entry.sense: XarowaI, in which the w is a substitute for I, as it is in taqowaI and the like, (TA,) The like (Ṣ, Ḳ) of a thing: (Ṣ:) because a thing is sometimes bought with the like thereof: (TA:) [used alike as sing. and pl.: and, accord. to the TA, it seems that XaroIN↓ signifies the same.] It is said of Shureyh, kaAna yuDam-inu AlqaS-aAra XarowaI Alv-awobi Al-aciI Oaholakahu [He used to make the washer responsible for the like of the garment, or piece of cloth, that he destroyed]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. of ʼOmar, relating to the [collecting of the] poorrate, falaA yaOoxucu Uil-aA tiloka Als-in-a mino XarowaI Uibilihi [i. e. And he shall not take any save of that age, of the likes of his camels]. (TA.)

XirawiI-N, in which the w is a substitute for I, and XiraAYiI-N↓, [both signifying Of, or relating to, selling, and also of, or relating to, buying,] are rel. ns.; the former, of the inf. n. XirFI; and the latter, of the inf. n. XiraMCN. (Mṣb, TA.)
XaroyaAnN see XaroIN:
and see what next follows.

XiroyaAnN and XaroyaAnN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the former of which is the more in repute, (TA,) the former said to be quasi-quadriliteral, like jiroyaAlN, [and therefore mentioned also in the TA in art. Xrn,] but held by IB to be of the measure fiEolaAnN, (TA in art. Xrn,) A kind of tree, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) of the EiDaAh [q. v.] of the mountains, (TA,) of which bows are made: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) n. un. with p {XiroyaAnapN}: the tree thus called grows in the manner, and of the height and width, of the [species of lote-tree called] sidor, and has a yellow, sweet nabiqap [or drupe]: so says AḤn: and he adds, Aboo-Ziyád says, bows are made of the XryAn, and the bow made thereof is good, but black tinged with redness; its wood being of those woods of which good bows are [commonly] made; and they assert that it seldom, or never, becomes crooked: Mbr says that the naboE and XawoHaT [q. v.] and XryAn are one kind of tree, but differing in name and estimation according to the places of growth; such thereof as is upon the summit of the mountain being the nbE; and such as is at the base, or foot, or lowest or lower part, thereof, the XryAn. (TA. [But see XawoHaTN.])

Also sing. of XaraAyiynu signifying The arteries; i. e. the pulsing veins; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) which spring from the heart: (Ṣ:) but the anatomists assert that they spring from the liver, and pass by the heart. (TA.)
XiroyaAnN, with kesr, signifies also A crack, or fissure, [in a rock,] such as is termed vat-N. (Az, TA.)
XiraAYiI-N: see XirawiI-N.

XaArK Selling, or a seller: (Mgh, TA:) and buying, or a buyer: as also muXotarK↓ [in both senses, but generally in the latter sense; whereas XaArK is generally used in the former sense]: (TA:) pl. of the former XuraApN. (Mgh.)

Also, (Ṣ, TA,) and XaAriI-N↓, in which latter the I is not the I of a rel. n. but is an affix corroborative of the epithet, as in the cases of OaHowaru and OaHowariI-N [or OaHomaru and OaHomariI-N] and Sul-abN and Sul-abiI-N, (TA,) One of the people to whom is applied the appellation AlX-uraApu, (Ṣ, TA,) which means the [heretics, or schismatics, commonly known by the name of] xawaArij [pl. of xaArijiI-N, q. v.]: (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ, &c.:) so called because they said, We have sold ourselves in obedience to God, i. e., for Paradise, when we separated ourselves from the erring Imáms: (Ṣ:) or because they sold themselves for the sake of what they believed: or because they said, Verily God has purchased us and our possessions: (Mgh:) but ISk says, because of their vehement hatred of the Muslims: and the author of the Ḳ says that it is from XariIa signifying “he was angry,” and “he persisted, or persevered;” and he charges J with error in his explaining it as above, from their saying “we have sold ourselves”, &c.; but this charge is senseless, for J has followed herein more than one of the leading authorities: the author of the Ḳ has followed ISd, who, however, adds, as to themselves, they say “We are the XuraAp” because of the saying in the Ḳur ii. 203 [cited in the first paragraph of this art.], and the saying [in ix. 112] “Verily God hath purchased, of the believers, themselves” [&c.]; and the like is said in the Nh, with this addition, that XuraApN is the pl. of XaArK; i. e., it is from XaraI, aor. yaXoriI; or it may be from AlmuXaAraApu meaning AlmulaAj-apu: moreover, the part. n. of XariIa is XarK; and this has not XuraApN for its pl. (TA.)
XaAriI-N: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: muXotarK: see XaArK.
AlmuXotariI A certain star, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) well-known; (Ḳ;) [Jupiter;] one of the Seven Stars. (TA.)
And A certain bird. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 1. Xazaba, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) and Xazuba, (O, Ḳ,) aor. of each _u, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XuzuwbN (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ) and XazobN, (Ḳ,) He was, or became, such as is termed XaAzibN meaning as expl. below: (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ:) [mostly] said of a horse. (Ṣ, A, O, TA.)

2. Xz-bhu, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. taXoziybN, (Ḳ,) He, or it, caused it (a rod, O) to wither: (O, Ḳ, TA:) and he, or it, made him to become lean, or light of flesh; slender, and lean; or lean, and lank in the belly. (TA.)
XazobapN: see what follows.

XaAzibN Lean, or light of flesh; slender, and lean; or lean, and lank in the belly; applied to a horse: (Ṣ, O:) [or] XazobapN↓ signifies thus, applied to a she-ass, (Ḳ, TA,) and a she-camel: (so accord. to the CK:) and XaAzibN, lean,, &c., as above; and tough; (A, Ḳ;) applied to a horse, (A, TA,) and to a man, &c.: (TA:) or lean, or light of flesh, though not emaciated: (Aṣ, TA:) and, applied to a man, very slender or slim or spare: (A:) pl. Xuz-abN, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) applied to horses, (Ṣ, A, O,) and [as also of XaAzibapN] XawaAzibu. (Ḳ.) And XaAzibapN A she-gazelle lean, or light of flesh; or slender, and lean; or lean, and lank in the belly; in consequence of her having come from after: pl. XawaAzibu. (TA.)
And Rough; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) applied to a place. (Ṣ, TA.)

1. Xazarahu, and Xazara Uilayohi, aor. _i {yaXoziru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XazorN, (TA,) He looked askew, or sideways, at him, (IAmb, Ḳ,) not turning his face towards him, (TA,) [or with a slight turning of the face, (see laHaZahu,)] by reason of hatred or of awe: (IAmb:) or he looked at him with a look of aversion: or he looked at him from the right and left: (Ḳ:) or from the outer angle of the eye: generally, in anger: or with hatred and anger: (TA:) or, (Ḳ,) as also naZara Uilayohi XazorFA, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) he looked at him from the outer angle of the eye, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with anger, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or with aversion, like as one looks who hates another, (A, Mgh,) or like one who is averse and angry: (Mṣb:) or Xazarahu signifies he looked at him with the look of an enemy. (TA.) The saying of ʼAlee, AiloHaZuwA AlX-azora waQToEunuwA Alyasora, is expl. as signifying Look ye from the right and left [and thrust ye straight forward]. (TA.)
Also Xazarahu, (Fr, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Fr,) He smote him with the [evil] eye. (Fr, Ḳ.)
Also Xazarahu He thrust him, or pierced him, (Ḳ,) with a spear-head. (TA.) And TaEanahu XazorFA He thrust him, or pierced him, sideways. (A.)

Xazara Aljabola, aor. _i {yaXoziru} and _u {yaXozuru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XazorN, (TA,) He twisted the rope, or cord, from the left [by rolling it against his body from left to right]: (ISd, Ḳ:) or he twisted it upwards [by rolling it upwards against his thigh or body]: (Aṣ, AM:) or he twisted it from without [by rolling it against his thigh], and turned it towards his belly [contrarily to the usual manner, which is termed yasorN, and which is the twisting downwards, by rolling the rope or cord downwards either against the body or against the thigh]; (ISd, Ḳ;) as also AstXzrhu↓. (Ḳ.) [See also XazorN, below.]
3. XAzrhu, inf. n. muXaAzarapN, He treated him, or regarded him, with enmity, or hostility: whence [the manner of looking termed] AlX-azoru. (AA.)
4. AXzrhu Qll-ehu God cast him into an evil case from which he could not extricate himself. (TA.)
5. tXz-r He was angry. (Ḳ.) [See also tXc-r.]
He prepared himself, liloqitaAli for fight, (Ḳ,) and lils-ujuwdi [for prostration in prayer]. (Mgh.)
6. tXAzrwA They looked, one at another, in the manner termed XazorN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) from the outer angle of the eye. (TA.) [See 1.]

hom.sense: 10. AstXzr: see 1, last sentence but one.
Also It (a rope or cord) was twisted in the manner described above, in the explanation of Xazara AlHabola. (Ḳ.)
TaEonN XazorN A thrusting, or piercing, from the right and from the left: (Ṣ, M, TA:) or with the right hand and the left. (TA.)
fatolN XazorN A twisting upwards, contrarily to the manner in which the spindle [usually] turns. (Ṣ.) [See 1.]
gazolN XazorN Spun thread [app. twisted in a manner the reverse of that which is usual: (see 1; and see also radonN:) or] that is uneven. (Ḳ.)

TaHana biAlr-aHaI XazorFA, [in which XazorFA appears to be an inf. n., though its verb is not mentioned,] He ground with the hand-mill turning it from his right: [i. e., making it to revolve in the same course as do the hands of a watch:] (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:*) the contrary [which is the common way] is termed bat-FA (A, TA.)
And maA zaAla XazorFA He ceased not to be taking the wrong way. (IAạr, TA.)
XazorN also signifies Difficulty (Ḳ) in an affair. (TA.)

entry.sense: fiI laHoZihi XazarN [In his glance is a sidelong and angry look, from the outer angle of the eye: see 1]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
XazarN signifies [also] Disquietude. (Mgh.)
OataAhu Ald-ahoru biXazorapK laA yanoHal-u minohaA [Time, or fortune, brought him a calamity from which he was not to be extricated;] meaning, destroyed him. (TA.)
XuzorapN ‡ Redness in the eye, and, or with, (so in the Ḳ accord. to the TA, but in the CK “or,”) what is termed XazarN in the glance thereof. (Ḳ.)
labanN OaXozaru ‡ Red milk. (TṢ, Ḳ.)
EayonN XazoraMCu ‡ An eye that is red, and (so in the Ḳ accord. to the TA, but in the CK “or,”) with what is termed XazarN in the glance thereof. (Ḳ.)

HabolN maXozuwrN A rope, or cord, twisted from the left; (Lth, A, Mṣb, TA;) which is the stronger way: (Lth, A:) or upwards: (Aṣ, T, Ṣ:) [see 1:] and gadaAYiru musotaXoziraAtN↓, (Ṣ, TA,) and musotaXozaraAtN↓, (TA,) [Pendent locks of hair] so twisted. (Ṣ, TA.)
musotaXozarN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: 1. XasaEa Aln-aEola, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXosaEu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XasoEN, (O, Ḳ,) He put a XisoE [q. v.] to the sandal; (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Ḳ;) as also Xas-aEahaA↓, and OaXosaEahaA↓. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
XasiEati Aln-aEolu, aor. _a {yaXosaEu}, The sandal had its XisoE broken. (Ibn-Buzurj, O, Ḳ.)
XasiEa Alfarasu, aor. as above, inf. n. XasaEN, The horse had a gap, or space, between his central incisor and the tooth next to it. (Aboo-Málik, IDrd, O, Ḳ.*)

XasaEa, aor. as above, inf. n. XasoEN and XusuwEN, It was, or became, distant, or remote; said of a place of alighting, or abode. (Ḳ.) And, said of anything, i. q. tanaMCaI [It was or became, far from another thing]: and XaxaSa [it rose,, &c.]. (TA.)
XasaEa He put, or sent, or removed, him, or it, away, or far away; as also AXsEhu↓. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see the preceding paragraph {1}.
4: see 1, first and last sentences.

XisoEN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and XisiEN (Ḳ) and XisoEan-N↓, so in some of the copies of the Ḳ, (TA,) [thus in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, and also in the O,] with an augmentative n, (O, TA,) The qibaAl of the sandal; (Ḳ;) [i. e.] the appertenance of the sandal that is attacked, or tied, to its zimaAm; (Ṣ;) [meaning] one of the thongs, or straps, or strips of leather, of the sandal, being that which passes between two toes, of which the [lower] end enters the hole, or perforation, that is in the fore part of the sandal, and which is attacked [at its upper end] to the zimaAm [or, as it is also called, the XiraAk, a thong, or strap, or strip of leather, extending towards the ankle, and having two arms, (its EaDudaAni,) which are attacked to the OucunaAni (q. v.), or pass through these and unite behind the foot]: (IAth, TA:) a poet says, referring to camels,
OaHoduw bihaA munoqaTiEFA XisoEan-iI↓
[I urge them on by singing to them, with the interdigital thong of my sandal broken]: (Lth, O, TA:) the pl. of XisoEN is XusuwEN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) and OaXosaAEN: (O, Ḳ, TA:) ISd and Z affirm that it has only the former pl.; but AḤei contradicts this: (TA:) the latter pl. [a pl. of pauc.] occurs in the saying of ʼObeyd Ibn-Eiyoob El-'Amberee,
yudiyru naEolayohi liYal-aA tuEorafaA
yajoEalu OaXosaAEahumaA naHowa AlqafaA
[He turns round his sandals, in order that they may not be known by their prints upon the ground; putting the interdigital thongs thereof in the direction of the back of the neck]. (O, TA.)
[Hence,] qibaAlu AlX-isoEi signifies † The serpent; mentioned by IAạr with qibaAlu AlX-ibori. (TA.)
And XisoEN also signifies † The extremity of a place. (O, Ḳ.) One says, HalalonaA XisoEa Ald-ahonaMCi † [We alighted in the extremity of the sandy desert, or of the desert called Ed-Dahnà]. (O.)
And † A narrow tract of land. (O, Ḳ.)

And ‡ Somewhat remaining of property or cattle. (IAạr, O, Ḳ, TA.) And (Ḳ) ‡ A small quantity or number of property or cattle. (Mohárib, O, Ḳ, TA.) One says, lahu XisoEu maAlK ‡ He has a small quantity of property, or a small number of cattle; (Mohárib, O, Ḳ, TA;) or a small collection of camels and of sheep or goats: (Ḳ, TA:) and Fr adds XasiyEu↓ maAlK [app. in the same sense: but see another explanation of XisoEu maAlK in what follows]. (O.)

And ‡ The greater portion or number of property or cattle. (El-Mufaddal, O, Ḳ, TA.) Thus it has two contr. [?] significations. (Ḳ.) One says, cahaba XisoEu maAlihi ‡ The greater portion of his property, or the greater number of his cattle, went, or passed, away. (El-Mufaddal, O, TA.)

And fulaAnN XisoEu maAlK ‡ Such a one is a good manager of cattle or camels, &c.; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) one who keeps assiduously to the tending, or pasturing, thereof: (A, TA:) and Fr says, XasiyEu↓ huwa maAlK, as syn. with XisoEu maAlK. (TA: [but see above.])
XisoEan-N: see XisoEN, in two places.
XasuwEN: see XaAsiEN.
XasiyEu maAlK: see XisoEN, in two places.
XaAsiEN A man having his XisoE broken. (O, Ḳ.)

Also Distant, or remote; and so XasuwEN↓: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) both applied to a place of alighting, or abode: (O, Ḳ:) pl. [of either, irreg.,] XusoEN. (Ḳ.) One says bilaAdN XaAsiEapN [Distant countries or towns]. (Mṣb.) And rajulN XaAsiEu Ald-aAri A man whose house, or abode, or country, is distant. (TA.) And XafarN XaAsiEN A far journey. (TA.)
XawoXabN, mentioned in the Ḳ under this head and in art. Xb: see the latter art.

hom.sense: 1. XaSara, (AʼObeyd, O,) aor. _u {yaXoSuru}, (O,) inf. n. XaSorN, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) He sewed (a garment, or piece of cloth, AʼObeyd) with wide stitches, or with stitches far apart, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) as in the manner termed baXokN. (AʼObeyd.)
XaSara Eayona AlbaAziI, (Ṣ, O,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) He sewed up the eye of the hawk. (Ṣ, O.)

XaSara Aln-aAqapa, (M, O, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXoSuru} and _i {yaXoSiru}, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) He transfixed the sides of the she-camel's vulva with small sharp-pointed pieces of wood, or prickles, (M, O,* Ḳ,*) and twisted round behind them sinews, (M,) or a string made of hairs from her tail, (M, O,* Ḳ,*) on account of the protruding of her womb on the occasion of her bringing forth; (M, O, Ḳ;) syn. of the inf. n. tazoniydN. (Ṣ.) See also XiSaArN, below.
And XaSara Aln-aAqapa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) signifies also He inserted the piece of wood called XiSaAr between the nostrils of the she-camel; and so XS-rhA↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taXoSiyrN. (TA.)
XaSaratohu XawokapN, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) A thorn pricked, or pierced, him. (O, Ḳ.)
XaSarahu biAlr-umoHi, (O,) inf. n. as above, He pierced him (O, Ḳ *) with the spear. (O.)
XaSorN also signifies A bull's, (O, Ḳ,) and a gazelle's, (TA,) smiting (O, Ḳ, TA) a man (O, TA) with his horn. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
And XaSara, (IAạr, O,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) He leaped, or leaped upwards; syn. Tafara. (IAạr O, Ḳ.*)

XaSara baSaruhu, aor. _i {yaXoSiru} (O, Ḳ, in the L _u,) inf. n. XuSuwrN, His eye, or eyes, became fixedly open, or raised, or stretched and raised, or his eyelids became raised and he looked intently and became disquieted or disturbed, (syn. XaxaSa,) and the eye became inverted; at the time of death: (O, Ḳ:) thus, nearly in the same words, expl. by Lth and IF and Ibn-ʼAbbád: (O:) or the correct word is XaSaA, or XaTara; (so accord. to different copies of the Ḳ, the latter being the reading in the TA;) or both; for Az says that this explanation of XSr bSrh is in his opinion a mistake, and that it is correctly XaSaA baSaruhu and XaTara, meaning that he was as though he looked at thee and at another. (O, TA.*)

entry.sense: 2: see the preceding paragraph {1}.
XiSorN, and its dual: see XiSaArN.

XaSarN (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ) and XaASirN↓ (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ) and XawoSarN↓ (Ḳ) The young one of the gazelle, when he has become strong and active: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, L, &c.:) in the Ḳ, when he has become strong, but not active; but this is a mistake: (TA:) or that has become old enough to smite with his horn: or that has become a month old: or that has not yet cropped the herbage [but only sucked his mother]; expl. by Al-aciI lamo yaHotaniko: (Ḳ:) AʼObeyd states that it is said by more than one of the Arabs of the desert that the young one of the gazelle is called TalFA; then, xiXofN; and when his horns come forth, XaAdinN; and when he has become strong and active, XaSarN, of which the fem. [as is also said in the Ḳ] is XaSarapN;
then, jacaEN; and then, vaniI-N, which name he continues to have until he dies: (Ṣ:) [perhaps correctly corresponding to our six terms which are as follows: a fawn (applied to a buck or doe of the first year), a pricket (to a buck of the second year), a sorel (to a buck of the third year), a sore (to a buck of the fourth year), a buck of the first head (to one of the fifth year), and a great buck (to one of the sixth year):] or XaASirN↓ is applied to a young gazelle when his horn has come forth: (Lth:) pl. [of XaSarN,] OaXoSaArN. (Ḳ.)
XaSarN also signifies A certain bird, smaller than the EuSofuwr [or sparrow], (AA, O, Ḳ,) of the colour thereof. (AA, O.)

XiSaArN The small sharp-pointed piece of wood, or prickle, (Ḳ,) or the small sharp-pointed pieces of wood, or prickles, (IDrd, Ṣ,) with which the operation termed tazoniydN [which is that described above in the explanation of XaSara Aln-aAqapa] is performed; (IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also XiSorN↓: (Ḳ:) or XiSoraAni↓, or XiSaAraAni, is a term applied to two pieces of wood, which are thrust through the edge of the rectum of a she-camel, and then bound with a strong string of the fibres of the palm-tree, behind them: this is done when they desire to make a she-camel affect the young one of another: they take a stuffed durojap [q. v.], and insert it into her rectum, and transfix the rectum with two sharp-pointed pieces of wood, which they bind as above described: this operation is termed XaSorN↓ and tazoniydN. (ISh.) [See also 1.]
Accord. to the T, A piece of wood, which is bound between the two edges of a she-camel's vulva. (TA.)
And A piece of wood, which is inserted between the nostrils of a she camel. (Ḳ.)
XaSiyrN A prick of a thorn. (O, Ḳ.)
XaASirN: see XaSarN, in two places.
XawoSarN: see XaSarN.
XaASirapN One of the snares with which beasts of prey are caught. (O, Ḳ, TA.)

1. XaSaA baSaruhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. XuSuw-N, (Ṣ, TA, and so in copies of the Ḳ, accord. to the CK XaSowN, [and this, though wrong, is agreeable with a rule generally observed in the Ḳ, as it is not there followed by any indication of the form,]) like Euluw-N, (TA,) His eye, or eyes, became fixedly open, or raised, or stretched and raised, or his eyelids became raised and he looked intently and became disquieted or disturbed, syn. XaxaSa, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) [at the time of death, (see XaSara,)] as though he looked at thee and at another. (TA.)
And XaSaA Als-aHaAbu The clouds rose, or rose high, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) in their first appearing. (T, TA.) And XaSaA said of anything, It rose, or rose high. (T, TA.)

[Hence,] XaSati Alqirobapu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) The water-skin being filled with water, (Ḳ, TA,) and in like manner, being inflated, (TA,) its legs became raised, or raised high. (Ḳ, TA.) And thus also, XaSaA Alz-iq-u, The wine-skin being filled with wine, its legs became raised or raised high. (TA.)
And XaSaI birijolihi He raised, or raised high, his leg. (TA.)
4. AXSI baSarahu [He made his eye, or eyes, to become fixedly open, or raised,, &c.: see 1, first sentence: or] he raised, or he raised high, his eye, or eyes. (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA.)

hom.sense: XaSowN i. q. Xid-apN [app. as meaning Hardship, distress, or adversity]. (Az, Ḳ.)
And A siwaAk [or piece of stick with which the teeth are cleansed]. (IAạr, Az, TA. [See also XawoSN.])

entry.sense:
XaASK; fem. XaASiyapN, pl. of the latter XaASiyaAtN and XawaASK; part. n. of 1 (Ṣ, TA) as said of the eyes [i. e. Fixedly open, or being raised,, &c.]: (TA:) and of a water-skin, meaning Filled, or inflated, so that its legs are raised; and of a wine-skin, meaning filled, so that its legs are raised: and of a corpse, meaning Inflated,, &c. (Ṣ, TA.) It is said in a prov.,
UicaA QrojaHan-a XaASiyFA faQrofaEo yadaA
[expl. in art. rjHn, q. v.]. (Ṣ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. XaT-a, aor. _i {yaXoTiTu} and _u {yaXoTuTu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [the latter contr. to analogy,] the pret. like Daraba and qatala, (Mṣb, [and the like is said in the TA,]) inf. n. XaT-N and XuTuwTN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) It (a house, or dwelling, Ṣ, Mṣb, TA, and a place of visitation, TA) was, or became, distant, remote, or far off. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

XaT-a fiI Als-awomi, (Mṣb, Ḳ,)) aor. _i {yaXoTiTu} and _u {yaXoTuTu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. XaT-u and XaTaTN; (TA;) or OaXaT-a↓ fiyhi; (Ṣ;) or both, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) but the latter is the more common; (Ḳ;) and AXtT-↓; (Ṣ;) He went far, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or beyond the due bounds, in offering a thing for sale and demanding a price for it, or in bargaining for a thing: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the verb in this phrase is also followed by Ealayohi [against him]. (TA.) IB says that XaT-a signifies baEuda [meaning He, or it, was, or became, distant,, &c.]: and that OaXaT-a↓ signifies OaboEada [meaning he went far,, &c.]. (TA.) You say also, OaXaT-uwA↓ fiI TalabiI They went far, or very far, or to a great or an extraordinary length, in seeking me. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*) And OaXaT-a↓ Alqawomu fiI TalabinaA The people, or company of men, sought us walking and riding. (TA.) And OaXaT-a↓ fiI AlmafaAzapi He went away in the desert: (Ḳ:) as though he went far in it. (TA.) And XaT-a fiI siloEatihi, inf. n. XaTaTN, He exceeded the due bounds, and went far from what was right, in respect of his commodity, or article of merchandise. (Ḳ.) And XaT-a fiI Hukomihi, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor _i, (Ḳ, TA,) only, (TA,) or _i and _u, (Mṣb,) the latter aor. is mentioned in the L, (TA,) inf. n. XaTaTN, (Mṣb, TA,) in the Ḳ, erroneously, XaTiyTN, (TA,) and XuTuwTN also; (Mṣb;) and AXT-↓; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and AXtT-↓; (Ḳ;) or AXT-↓ fiI AlqaDiy-api; (Ṣ;) He acted unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in his judging, or exercising jurisdiction or rule, or passing sentence, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or in judging,, &c., (Ṣ,) Ealayohi against him. (Ḳ.) And XaTaTotu Ealayohi, (Ṣ, L,) aor. _u {yaXoTuTu}, (L,) and OaXoTaTotu↓; (Ṣ, L;) I acted unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically, against him: mentioned by AʼObeyd. (Ṣ, L.) It is said in the Ḳur [xxxviii. 21], walaA taXoTuTo, or tuXoTiTo↓, or tuXaT-iTo↓, or tuXaATiTo↓, accord. to different readings, And go not thou far from what is right: (Ḳ, TA:) all having this meaning: (TA:) or exceed not the due bounds. (Bḍ.) XaTaTN signifies The exceeding the due bounds (AA, Ṣ, Mgh) in selling, and in demanding or seeking, and in exercising jurisdiction, &c., (AA,) or in everything. (Ṣ.) It is said in a trad. lahaA mahoru mivolihaA laA wakosa walaA XaTaTa [She shall have the dowry of her like:] there shall be no falling short nor exceeding. (Ṣ.) And you say of a just sale, laA baxosa fiyhi walaA XaTaTa, (Ṣ in art. bxs,) or wlA XuTuwTa, (T and TA in that art.,) [There is no deficiency in it nor excess.] You also say XaT-a fiI Alqawoli, aor. _i {yaXoTiTu} and _u, inf. n. XaTaTN and XuTuwTN, He was rough, harsh, or coarse, in speech. (Mṣb.)
XaT-a used transitively, [aor. _u {yaXoTuTu},] He passed, or passed beyond, [or, probably, passed far away from,] a place. (TA.)

XaT-a fulaAnFA, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXoTuTu}, (TA,) inf. n. XaT-N and XuTuwTN, (Ḳ,) He distressed, or afflicted, such a one, and treated him, or used him, unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically: (Ḳ:) so say AZ and Aboo-Malik. (TA.)
XaAT-ahu faXaT-ahu: see 3.

entry.sense: 2. XT-T, inf. n. taXoTiyTN, He strove, laboured, exerted himself, or did his utmost, in acting unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically, and exceeding the due bounds. (Ḳ,* TA.) See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

3. XAT-hu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muXaAT-apN, (TA,) He vied with him in AiXotiTaAT [i. e. going far, or beyond the due bounds, in offering a thing for sale and demanding a price for it, or in bargaining for a thing; or acting unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically, in judging, &c.]. (Ḳ.) You say, XAT-hu faXaT-ahu↓ [He vied with him in so doing, and surpassed him, or overcame him, therein]. (TA.) See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.
4: see 1, in nine places.
8: see 1, in two places.

XaT-N The bank, or side, of a river: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and of a valley: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or, of the latter, the rising ground next the bottom: (AḤn:) pl. XuTuwTN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and XuT-aAnN; (Ḳ;) the latter occurring in a verse, accord. to one relation; but accord. to another relation, it is XuToMnN, pl. of XaATiYN, which is syn. with XaT-N. (TA.)
‡ The side of a camel's hump; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) any side thereof: (Ṣ:) or the half thereof: (Ḳ:) pl. XuTuwTN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
XaT-apN: see XaAT-N.
XiT-apN: see XaTaATN, in two places.

XaTaTN, for OamorN cuw XaTaTK, (Mgh,) and qawolN cuw XaTaTK, (Bḍ in lxxii. 4,) An action, or affair, (Mgh,) and a saying, (Bḍ,) that is extravagant, or exorbitant, or exceeding the due bounds. (Mgh, Bḍ.) [See 1, of which it is an inf. n.]

hom.sense: XaTaATN Distance; remoteness; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also XiTaATN↓ and XiT-apN↓, with kesr, (Ḳ,) and maXaT-apN↓. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Aall-ehum-a OaEuwcu bika mino waEovaMCi Als-afari wakaMbapi AlX-iT-api↓ wasuwoCi Almunoqalabi i. e. [O God, verily I seek protection by Thee from trouble of travel, and grievousness] of distance of the space to be journeyed over, [and evilness of return to my home.] (TA.)

And Distance, or farness, between the two extremities of a man; as also XiTaATN↓ and XaTaATapN↓. (Ḳ.) And Tallness, and beauty of stature: (Ḳ:) or justness of stature: (IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ:) as also XiTaATN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in either sense. (Ḳ.)
Also, and XiTaATN↓, Fragments of baked bricks. (Ḳ.)
[Freytag erroneously assigns the first and last meanings in this paragraph to XaT-apN: and he adds, from Reiske, a meaning belonging to XiZaAZN.]

entry.sense: XiTaATN: see XaTaATN, in four places.
XaTuwTN A she-camel having a large hump; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also XaTawoTaI↓: (Ḳ:) or large in the two sides of the hump: (TA:) pl. XaTaAYiTu. (Ḳ.)
XaTaATapN: see XaTaATN.
XaTawoTaI: see XaTuwTN.
XaToXaATN A certain bird: (Ḳ:) IDrd says that it is asserted to have this meaning; but is not of established authority. (O.)

hom.sense: XaAT-N Anything Distant, remote, or far. (TA.)
A man whose two extremities are far from each other. (Ḳ.)
jaAriyapN XaAT-apN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and XaT-apN↓, (Ḳ,) A girl tall, and of beautiful stature: (Ḳ:) or of just stature. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Uin-aka laXaAT-iI Verily thou art acting unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically, towards me in judging: occurring in a trad. (AʼObeyd, Az, Ṣ.)

entry.sense: maXaT-apN: see XaTaATN.
Also Difficulty, distress, affliction, trouble, or inconvenience. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. XaTaOa: see 4.
Also He walked on the XaATiY, i. e. bank, or side, of the river. (Ḳ,* TA.)
And He cut lengthwise [into slices, or strips,] the hump of a camel, and a skin, or hide. (TA.)
He subdued, overcame, overpowered, or mastered, a man. (Ḳ.)
He compressed his wife. (Ḳ.) [And saTaOa and TaXaOa signify the same.]
And XaTaOa biAlHimoli He burdened heavily, or overburdened, the camel with the load; (Ḳ;) inf. n. as above. (TA.) [But see what follows.]
Accord. to ISk, (TA,) this last phrase signifies also, (Ḳ,) or XaTaOato biAlHimoli, as in the L, (TA,) He, (a man, Ḳ,) or she, (a camel, L, TA,) had strength, or power, to bear the load. (L, Ḳ, TA.)
XaTaOato bihi She (his mother) cast him forth [from her womb]. (Ḳ.) One says, laEana Qll-ehu Oum-FA XaTaOato bihi, and so faTaOato bh, May God curse a mother who cast him forth [from her womb]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. XT-O, inf. n. taXoTiIoCN, It (a valley) had its two sides (XaATiYaAhu, TA) flowing [with water]. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
3. XaATaOotuhu I walked upon one XaATiY [i. e. bank, or side, of a river or valley,] while he walked upon the other XATY. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

4. AXTO; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) or XaTaOa↓, aor. _a {yaXoTaOu}, inf. n. XaToCN and XuTuwoCN; (Ḳ;) or both; (TA;) It put forth its XaToC [or sprouts,, &c.]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) syn. far-axa; (Mṣb;) said of seed-produce; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and in like manner said of palm-trees (naxol); and the former verb, said of trees (Xajar), they put forth sprouts around their bases, or stems. (Ḳ.) And AXTOt AlX-ajarapu biguSuwnihaA The tree put forth its branches. (TA.)
And the former verb, † He (a man) had a son who had attained to manhood and become like him; (AḤn, Ḳ;) like OaSoHaba. (TA.)
Q. Q. 1. XaToyaOa, (Ḳ, TA,) said of a man, (TA,) i. q. rahoyaOa, (Ḳ, TA,) meaning He was weak (TA) in his opinion, or judgment, (Ḳ, TA,) and in his affair. (TA.)

hom.sense: XaToCN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and XaTaON↓ (TA as from the Ḳ [but not in the CK nor in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, though a known dial. var. of the former as will be shown in what follows,]) The firaAx [or sprouts] of seed-produce, (IAạr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of plants, or herbage, (Ṣ,) and of palm-trees: or the leaves thereof; (Ḳ. TA;) i. e. of seed-produce: (TA:) and the shoots that come forth (Mṣb, Ḳ) from, (Mṣb,) or around, (Ḳ,) the bases, or stems, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) of plants, or herbage, (Mṣb,) or of trees: (Ḳ:) pl. OaXoTaMCN, (Ṣ,) or XuTuwoCN. (Ḳ.) Oaxoraja XaToOahu, in the Ḳur xlviii. last verse, means That has put forth its firaAx [or sprouts]: (Bḍ, Jel:) or, accord. to Akh, its extremity: (Ṣ:) or its ears, (Mṣb, TA,) accord. to Fr; each grain, he says, producing ten, or eight, or seven: or, accord. to Zj, its plants: (TA:) and some read XaTaOahu↓, (Bḍ, Jel,) which is a dial. var.; and XaTaAhu, and XaTaMCahu, and XaTahu, and XaTowahu. (Bḍ.)
[See also XaToOapN.]
And see XaATiYN.

entry.sense: XaTaON: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
XaToOapN [app. a n. un. of XaToCN, q. v.]
[Also] A green palm-branch: one says, lahaA qad-N kaAlX-aToOapi She has a figure like the green palm-branch. (A, TA.)
And A slice, or strip, i. e. a piece cut lengthwise, of a camel's hump, and of a skin, or hide. (A, TA.)

XaATiYN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XaToCN↓ (Ḳ) The bank, or side, (XaT-, Ṣ, Ḳ, and jaAnib, Ṣ, Mṣb,) of a valley (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and of a river: (Ḳ:) and some say that the former signifies the extremity, or edge, or side, (Taraf,) of a river; and the shore of the sea: the pl. of the latter is XuTuwoCN; and of the former, XawaATiYu and XuToMnN; (Ḳ, TA;) or this last, as is said in the M, may be pl. of XaToCN. (TA.) Accord. to the Ṣ, one says also XaATiYu AlOawodiyapi [meaning The sides of the valleys]; not assigning to XATY any pl.: but the truth is that the pl. is as stated above. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. XaTaba, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. _u {yaXoTubu}, (TA,) inf. n. XaTobN, (AZ, TA,) He cut (Ḳ, TA) into oblong pieces, or strips, flesh-meat, and a camel's hump, and a hide, or leather: (TA:) or he cut into strips, but without separating them, a camel's hump. (AZ, TA.)

And XaTabati Aljariyda, [aor. _u {yaXoTubu},] inf. n. XaTobN, She (a woman) split the palm-sticks, or palmbranches stripped of their leaves, to make of them mats: which being done, says AʼObeyd, [or when they have been peeled,] the XaATibap [q.v.] throws them to the munaq-iyap. (Ṣ.) [Or] XaTabat, aor. _u {yaXoTubu}, inf. n. XuTuwbN, She removed the upper peel of the XaTob, or [fresh, green] palm-branches. (ISk, TA.)

XaTaba also signifies It inclined, or declined, turned aside or away, deflected, or deviated, and became distant, or remote; (Aṣ, O, Ḳ;) and so XaTafa; and both signify it went away. (Aṣ, TA.) One says, XaTaba Eanohu It turned aside or away, and became distant, or remote, from him, or it. (Ḳ.) Thus, in a trad., XaTaba Alr-umoHu Eano maqotalihi The spear deflected from, and failed to reach, his vital part. (O, TA.*) And one says also, XaTabati Ald-aAru The dwelling was, or became, distant, or remote. (O.)

entry.sense: 7. AnXTb It flowed; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) said of water, &c. (Ḳ.)

XaTobN pl. of XaTobapN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) [or rather a coll. gen. n., of which the latter is the n. un.,] like as tamorN is of tamorapN; (Mṣb;) Fresh, (A,) or green, (Mṣb,) or green and fresh, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) palm-branches (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) stripped of their leaves: (A:) or they are less than what are termed XaTaAYibu, of which the sing. is XaTiybapN↓; and the XTAYb are less than the karaAniyf: [i. e. the kironaAf is the thickest part of the palm-branch; next is the XaTiybap; and next to this, the XaTobap:] or XaTobapN↓ signifies a green palm-branch. (Ḳ.)
kamasal-i XaTobapK↓, in a trad. of Umm-Zarạ, [as expl. in art. sl, q. v.,] means Like a green palm-stick drawn forth from its skin: or like a sword drawn forth [from its scabbard]: (TA in art. sl:) [for]
XaTobapN↓ signifies also A sword. (Aboo-Saʼeed, Ḳ.)

[Hence, app.,] XaTobN is used also as an epithet, meaning ‡ Tall, and well made; (A, Ḳ, TA;) applied to a man and to a horse. (TA.) And, applied to a boy, or young man, ‡ Plump; or fat, soft, thin-skinned, and plump: and so XaTobapN↓ applied to a girl, or young woman: (A:) or the former, applied to a boy, or young man, well made, and neither tall nor short: (TA:) or, so applied, light, or active, in body, and sharpheaded: (IAạr, TA in art. EDb, voce EaDobN:) or it means, so applied, long and even (sabiTN) in the bones, light of flesh; likened to the palm-stick that is split: but this epithet is mostly used with p, i. e. XaTobapN↓, which is applied to a mare: (Ḥam p. 298:) or this epithet, XaTobapN, applied to a mare, means lank (sabiTapN) in flesh; (Ḳ, TA;) or tall; (TA;) as also XiTobapN↓ in the former sense, (Ḳ, TA,) or in the latter; and the masc. is not thus used, applied to a horse: (TA:) and XaTobapN↓, (Ṣ,) or XiTobapN↓, (Ḳ,) or both, but the former is the more approved, (TA,) beautiful; plump; or fat, soft, thin-skinned, and plump; (Ḳ, TA;) and tall: (Ḳ:) or simply tall; (Ṣ, TA;) as also maXoTuwbN↓ and muXaT-abN↓ applied to a man. (TA.)
XaTobapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in seven places:
and see what next follows.

XuTobapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and XiTobapN↓ (Ḳ) and XaTobapN↓ (TA) and XuTabapN↓, (Ḳ,) which last is said by some to be a n. un. of XuTabN [mentioned in what follows as a pl.], (MF,) A [raised] line (Tariyqap, Ṣ, O, or Tariyq, Ḳ, [meaning a ridge, and sometimes also a depressed line, as shown voce muXaT-abN, i. e. a channel,]) in the maton [i. e. broad side, or middle of the broad side, of the blade] (Ṣ, O) of a sword: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) pl. XuTabN and XuTubN, (Ṣ, O,) or XuTuwbN and XuTabN and XuTubN: (Ḳ: [in which it is said that the pl. is XuTuwbN and XuTabN like gurafN and kutubN: but I think that XuTuwbN is a mistranscription, and that the right reading is XuTabN and XuTubN like gurafN and kutubN:]) hence it would seem that XuTabN and XuTubN are pls. of one sing.; but Ibn-Hishám El-Lakhmee expressly states that the former is pl. of XuTobapN; and the latter, of XaTiybapN↓; (MF;) of which XaTaAYibu also is a pl.; (L in art. Emd;) and which signifies [the same as XuTobapN, i. e.] the rising Eamuwd [i. e. the ridge] in the maton of a sword. (ISh, TA.) [See also muXaT-abN: and see EamuwdN and matonN.]
XaTobapN: see XaTobN (near the end) in two places:
and see also XuTabapN:
and XaTiybapN, in three places.
XuTabapN: see XuTobapN.
XiTaAbN The instrument with which a barocaEap [or cloth put beneath a camel's saddle] is quilted. (Ḳ.)

XaTiybapN A slice, or strip, of flesh-meat: (TA:) or a piece cut lengthwise of a camel's hump; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) as also XiTobapN↓: (O, Ḳ:) or a piece cut in the form of a strip, but not separated, of a camel's hump; and so ↓the latter word: pl. of the former XaTaAYibu. (AZ, TA.)
And A piece cut lengthwise of a hide or of leather; (Ṣ, O;) as also XiTobapN↓. (O.)
And A piece of [the tree called] naboE of which a bow is made. (Ṣ, O.)
See also XaTobN.
And see XuTobapN.
Also, applied to a she-camel, Tough; syn. yaAbisapN. (Ḳ.)
And [the pl.] XaTaAYibu Different, or various, parties, sects, or classes, (Ḳ, TA,) and sorts, of men, &c. (TA.)
And Difficulties, or distresses; (Abu-l-Faraj, O, Ḳ;) as also XaSaAYibu. (Abu-l-Faraj, O, TA.)
XaTiybiy-apN, (as in the TA,) or muXaT-abapN↓, (as implied in the Ḳ,) A quilted barocaEap [or cloth that is put beneath a camel's saddle]. (Ḳ, TA.)
XaT-aAbN A butcher. (Fr, TA in art. sTr.)

hom.sense: XaATibN [act. part. n. of the trans. verb XaTaba].

[Hence,] XawaATibu [the pl. of XaATibapN] signifies Women who cut skin, or leather, into strips, after having shaven it or measured it: so accord. to different copies of the Ḳ; i. e. baEoda maA yaHoliqonahu or yaxoluqonahu. (TA.)

And Women who split palmleaves, and peel the [palm-branches stripped of their leaves, or the portions thereof termed] Easiyb, to make of them mats, and then throw them to the munaq-iyaAt: (TA:) or the sing., XaATibapN, signifies a woman who peels the Easiyb, (Aṣ, TA,) or who splits the palm-sticks, to make of them mats, (Ṣ,) and then throws them to the munaq-iyap, (Aṣ, Ṣ, TA,) who removes all that is upon them with her knife until she has made them slender, when she throws them back to the XaATbp: (Aṣ, TA:) or a woman who makes mats of XaTob, i. e. [green, fresh] palm-branches [stripped of their leaves]: (ISk, TA:) the pl. occurs in a verse cited voce tacar-aEa. (Ṣ, TA.)
Also, [from the intrans. verb XaTaba,] TariyqN XaATibN A road inclining, declining, or turning aside or away. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And ramoyapN XaATibapN A shot, or throw, that deflects, or deviates, from a vital part; as also XaATifapN. (TA.)
And rajulN XaATibu AlmaHal-i i. q. XaATinN [i. e. A man remote, or distant, in respect of the place of alighting or abode]. (TA.)

entry.sense: muXaT-abN A sword (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) having XuTab [pl. of XuTobapN], (A, Ḳ,) i. e. (A, TA) having TaraAYiq [here meaning ridges, as expl. above, voce XuTobapN], (Ṣ, A, TA,) in its maton; [or ridges and channels,] these being in some cases elevated and depressed [lines]; (TA;) as also maXoTuwbN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) said by some, [but not so accord. to the A,] to be tropical, as being likened to pieces of a camel's hump cut in strips. (TA.) And in like manner, A garment, or piece of cloth, having TaraAYiq [as meaning lines, or streaks, or stripes]. (Ṣ, TA.) And OaroDN muXaT-abapN ‡ Land that is furrowed (A, Mṣb, Ḳ) a little, (Ḳ,) not much, (Mṣb,) by a torrent. (A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
And † Flowing [water, &c.; because of the streaks, or lines, with which its surface is diversified]. (TA.)
See also XaTiybiy-apN.
And see XaTobN, last sentence.
maXoTuwbN: see the next preceding paragraph.

farasN maXoTuwbu Almatoni waAlkafali means A horse swollen with fat in the two portions of flesh and sinew next the back bone, on each side, [and in the rump,] (O, Ḳ,) and whose creases of the skin are far apart. (O.)
See also XaTobN, last sentence.

hom.sense: 1. XaTarahu, (A, MA, O, TA,) [aor. _u {yaXoTuru},] inf. n. XaTorN; (MA;) and XT-rhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taXoTiyrN; (TA;) He halved it; divided it into halves. (A, MA, O, Ḳ, TA.)

XaTarahaA, aor. _u {yaXoTuru}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. XaTorN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He milked one XaTor of her, (namely, a camel, or a ewe or goat, Ṣ, [i. e., in the former case one pair of teats, and in the latter case one teat,]) and left the other XaTor. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

XaTarato and XaTurato, aor. _u {yaXoTuru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XiTaArN, (TA,) She (a ewe or goat) had one of her teats dried up: or had one teat longer than the other. (Ḳ.) [XiTaArN seems to be also Syn. with HiDaAnN as expl. in this Lex.: see also the latter word in Freytag's Lex.: Reiske, as cited by Freytag, explains the former word as meaning “quando latus unum vulvæ præ altero propendet.”]

XaTara baSaruhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA, and so in the O voce saSara, q. v., [in some copies of the Ṣ and Ḳ and in a copy of the A, erroneously, baSarahu,]) aor. _u {yaXoTuru}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. XuTuwrN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and XaTorN, (TA,) He was as though he were looking at thee and at another: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) on the authority of Fr. (TA.)
XaTara XaTorahu He repaired, or betook himself, in the direction of him, or it: or AlX-aToru in the sense of Aljihapu and Aln-aAHiyapu has no verb belonging to it. (Ḳ.)
XaTarati Ald-aAru The house, or abode, was distant, or remote. (Mgh, Mṣb.)

XaTara, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXoTuru}; (Ḳ;) and XaTura, aor. _u {yaXoTuru}; inf. n. XaTaArapN, of both verbs, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or this is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and XuTuwrN; (L;) [and tXATr↓; (A in art. Ecr;)] He was, or became, or acted, like a XaATir [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And XaTara EalaI Oaholihi, (A, Mṣb,) or XaTara Eanohumo, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXoTuru}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. XuTuwrN and XuTuwrapN and XaTaArapN, (Ḳ,) or this last is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) He withdrew far away (Ṣ,* A, Ḳ *) from his family; or broke off from them, or quitted them, in anger: (A, Ḳ:) or he disagreed with his family, and wearied them by his wickedness (Mṣb, TA) and baseness. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first sentence.
XT-r naAqatahu, (Ṣ,) or binaAqatihi, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taXoTiyrN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He bound two of the teats of his she-camel with the SiraAr [q. v.], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) leaving (the other) two (unbound). (Ḳ.)
3. XaATarotuhu maAliI I halved with him my property; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) I retained half of my property and gave him the other half. (M, TA.)
And XaATarotu Taliy-iI I left for my lamb, or kid, one teat [of the mother], having milked the other teat and bound it with the SiraAr [q. v.]. (Ṣ.)
6: see 1, last sentence but one.

XaTorN The half of a thing; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also XaTiyrN↓: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaXoTurN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and [of mult.] XuTuwrN. (Ḳ.) It is said in a prov., AuHolubo HalabFA laka XaToruhu [Milk thou a milking of which half shall be for thee]. (Ṣ.) And one says XaEarN XaToraAni Hair [half] black and [half] white. (A.) Accord. to Ibráheem El-Ḥarbee, (O,) the saying of the Prophet, mano manaEa SadaqapF faUin-aA MxicuwhaA waXaTora maAlihi [Whoso refuses to render a poor-rate, verily we take it from him, and half of his property], thus related by Bahz, is a mistake, and the right wording is, waXuTira maAluhu, meaning and his property shall be divided into two halves, and the collector of the poor-rate shall have the option given him and shall take that rate from out of the better of the two halves, as a punishment for the man's refusal of the rate; (O, Ḳ;) but it is said that this law was afterwards abrogated: (O:) Esh-Sháfiʼee, however, says that, in the old time, when one refused the poor-rate of his property, it was taken from him, and half of his property was taken as a punishment for his refusal; and he adduces this trad. as evidence thereof; but says that in recent times, only the poor-rate was taken from him, and this trad. was asserted to be abrogated. (TA. [More is there said on this subject, but I omit it as unprofitable.])
It occurs in two trads. as meaning Half a mak-uwk [q. v.], or half a wasoq [q. v.], of barley. (TA.)
[In prosody, Half a verse.]

Also ‡ A part, or portion, or somewhat, of a thing; (Mgh, Ḳ;) and so XaTiyrN↓. (TA.) In the trad. of the night-journey, fawaDaEa XaTorahaA means † [And He remitted] part, or somewhat, thereof; (Ḳ;) i. e., of the prayer. (TA.) And similar is the saying in another trad., AlT-ahuwru XaToru AlUiymaAni † [Purification is part of faith]. (TA.)

Either the fore pair or the hind pair of the teats of a she-camel: she has two pairs of teats, a fore pair and a hind pair, and each pair is thus called: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and either of the two teats of a ewe or she-goat: (IAạr, TA:) pl. OaXoTurN. (Ṣ, TA.) Hence the saying, (Ṣ,) fulaAnN Halaba Ald-ahora OaXoTurahu ‡ Such a one has known, or tried, varieties of fortune: (Ṣ,* TA:) has experienced the good and evil of fortune; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) its straitness and its ampleness: being likened to one who has milked all the teats of a camel, that which yields plenty of milk and that which does not; the fore pair being the good; and the hind pair, the evil: or, as some say, OaXoTur means streams, or flows, of milk: and [in like manner] one says, Halaba Ald-ahora XaTorayohi. (TA.) And, as is said in the “Kámil” of Mbr, one says of a man experienced in affairs, fulaAnN qado Halaba OaXoTurahu ‡ Such a one has endured the difficulties and [enjoyed] the ampleness of fortune, and managed his affairs in poverty and in wealth: lit., has milked his pairs of teats, one pair after another. (TA.)

Also A direction in which one looks or goes or the like. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) One says, qaSada XaTorahu He went in his, or its, direction; towards him, or it. (Ṣ, A.) And it is said in the Ḳur [ii. 139 and 144 and 145], fawal-i wajohaka XaTora Qlomasojidi QloHaraAmi Then turn thou thy face in the direction of the Sacred Mosque. (Fr, Ṣ.) The noun in this sense has no verb belonging to it: or one says, XaTara XaTorahu [expl. above: see 1]. (Ḳ.)
Also Distance, or remoteness. (TA.)
XuTurN: see XaTiyrN [of which it is both a syn. and a pl.].
waladu fulaAnK XiTorapN The offspring of such a one are half males and half females. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ. [In the Ḥam p. 478, it is written XaTorp.])
XaToraAnu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) fem. XaToraI, (Ḳ,) A bowl, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or vessel, (A, Ḳ,) half full. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

XaTuwrN A ewe, or she-goat, having one teat longer than the other; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) like HaDuwnN in this sense [and perhaps in others also, agreeably with what is said of XiTaArN in the first paragraph of this art.]: (Ṣ in art. HaDn:) and (so in the Ṣ and O, but in the Ḳ “or”) one having one of her teats dried up: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and a she-camel having two of her teats dried up; for she has four teats. (Ṣ, O.) And A garment, or piece of cloth, having one of the two extremities of its breadth longer than the other. (O, Ḳ.)
See also the next paragraph.

hom.sense: XaTiyrN: see XaTorN, in two places.

Also Distant, or remote; (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) applied to a town, or country, (Aṣ, Ṣ,) an abode, (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) and a tribe. (A.) And so XuTurN↓ in the phrase nawFI XuTurN [A distant tract, or region, towards which one journeys]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so too XaTuwrN↓ in the phrase niy-apN XaTuwrN [which may mean as above, (like niy-apN XaTuwnN,) or a remote, or farreaching, intention, or aim, or purpose]. (TA.)
Also A stranger; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because of his remoteness from his people; (TA;) as in a verse cited voce UicFA: (Ṣ, O:) or one who is alone, or solitary: (A:) pl. XuTurN. (TA.)

entry.sense: XaATirN [One who withdraws far away from his family; or breaks off from them, or quits them, in anger: (see 1, last sentence:) or] one who disagrees with his family, (Mṣb,) and who wearies them by his wickedness (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and baseness (Mṣb) and guile: (TA:) i. q. xaliyEN [meaning as above, and having other similar meanings; generally vitious, or immoral; bad, evil, wicked, or mischievous]: (A:) accord. to some, it is post-classical: Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ says that it signifies one who takes a wrong course: it is also expl. as signifying one who outstrips; like the [messenger called] bariyd, who takes a long journey in a short space of time: and hence, [as a conventional term of the mystics,] it is applied to one who outstrips, and is quick, in attaining nearness to God: or as meaning one who has wearied his family, and withdrawn far from them [n spirit], though with them [bodily], because of their inviting him to carnal lusts, and accustomed ways [of the world]: (TA:) [in the present day, it is applied to a sharper, or clever thief: and to any clever, or cunning, person:] pl. XuT-aArN. (TA.)

hom.sense: maXoTuwrN [Halved.]
[And hence,] A verse of the metre termed Alr-ajaz, (O, Ḳ,) and of that termed Als-ariyE, (TA,) having three of its six feet wanting; (O, Ḳ;) properly, having half thereof taken away. (O.)
Also Bread done over with [the seasoning, or condiment, called] kaAmax. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: humo muXaATiruwnaA They are persons whose houses adjoin ours. (O, Ḳ.).

XiToranojN (O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XaToranojN; (L, Mṣb;) some say the former; and some, the latter; (Mṣb;) the latter said to be of established authority, as a dial. var., though disallowed in the Ḳ [and in the O]; but the former is the more approved on account of its being conformable with Arabic words, (Mṣb, TA,) such as jirodaHolN, (TA,) which the latter is not; (Mṣb, TA;) and sometimes it is pronounced with the unpointed s, (O,) this being a dial. var.; (Ḳ;) A wellknown game; [namely, chess:] (O, L, Ḳ:) a Pers. word, (TA,) arabicized; (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) [said to be] from Sado ranoG “a hundred stratagems;” or from Xudo ranoj “trouble departed,” meaning that trouble departs from him who plays at it; (TA;) [or from XaAho ranoj “the royal care or sorrow;” or from XaXo ranoG “six species or ranks,” because the pieces are of so many species: (Richardson's Pers. Arab. and Engl. Dict., Johnson's ed.:)] or [accord. to some] it is from AlX-aTaArapu, (O, Ḳ,) or AlmuXaATarapu, referring to the word XTrnj; (TA;) or from Alt-asoTiyru, (O, Ḳ,) referring to the word sTrnj; so says Ibn-Hishám El-Lakhmee: but, as IB and others have said, these derivations are only partial, making the n and the j to be augmentative letters, and are manifestly incorrect. (MF, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. XaTana, (Ṣ, TA,) [aor. _u {yaXoTunu},] inf. n. XuTuwnN, (PṢ,) He was, or became, distant, or remote, (Ṣ, TA,) Eanohu [from him, or it]. (Ṣ.) And XaTanati Ald-aAru, (Mṣb, TA,) aor. as above, (Mṣb,) and so the inf. n., The abode, or dwelling, was distant, or remote. (Mṣb, TA.)
And † He was, or became, remote, or far, from the truth, and from the mercy of God. (Mṣb.)

And XaTana fiI AlOaroDi, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) It entered into the earth, either raAsixFA [app. as meaning becoming firmly fixed therein], or waAgilFA [app. as meaning penetrating, and becoming concealed]. (Ḳ.)

XaTanahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXoTunu}, inf. n. XaTonN, (Ṣ,) He turned away in opposition to him (namely, his companion, Ḳ) from his design, or aim, or his direction that he was pursuing, and his way, or course; expl. by the words xaAlafahu Eano niy-atihi wawajohihi. (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And XaTanahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXoTunu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. XaTonN, (TA,) He bound him with the XaTan [or rope, or long rope, &c.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4. AXTnhu He made him, or caused him, to be, or become, distant, or remote. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Q. Q. 1. XayoTana He acted as a XayoTaAn [i. e., as implied in the context, a devil; or one excessively, or inordinately, proud or corrupt or unbelieving or rebellious, or one insolent and audacious in pride and in acts of rebellion]; (Ḳ;) and taXayoTana↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) both signify the same; (Ḳ, TA;) he became, and acted, like the XayoTaAn. (TA.)
Q. Q. 2. taXayoTana: see what next precedes.

XaTanN A rope, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in a general sense: (Ḳ:) or a long rope: (Kh, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a long and strongly-twisted rope by means of which one draws water: (TA:) pl. OaXoTaAnN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) Mention is made, in a trad., of a horse as being marobuwTN biXaTanayoni [i. e. Tied with two ropes, or long ropes,, &c.,] because of his strength. (TA.) And one says of a strong-spirited horse, Uin-ahu layanozuw bayona XaTanayoni [Verily he leaps between two ropes, or long ropes,, &c.]: a saying applied as a prov. to him who exults, or exults greatly, or excessively, and behaves insolently and ungratefully, and is strong. (TA.) An Arab of the desert described a horse (Ṣ, Mṣb) that did not become abraded in the sole of his hoof (so in a copy of the Ṣ) by saying, kaOan-ahu XayoTaAnN fiI OaXoTaAnK [As though he were a devil in ropes, or long ropes, &c.]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

nawFI XaTuwnN (Ṣ) or niy-apN XaTuwnN (Ḳ) [A place to which one purposes journeying] that is distant, or remote. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And gazowapN XaTuwnN [A warring and plundering expedition] that is distant. (Ḳ.) And HarobN XaTuwnN [Distant war: or] † war that is difficult [because distant]. (TA. See an ex. in a verse cited voce jub-apN.) [See also XaTiynN, and XaATinN.]

biYorN XaTuwnN ‡ A deep well, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) curving in its interior: (TA:) or a well from which the bucket is drawn out by means of two ropes, from its two sides, wide in the upper part and narrow in the lower part; (Ḳ, TA;) so that if one draws out the bucket from it by means of one rope, one draws it against the casing, and it becomes rent. (TA.) And rumoHN XaTuwnN † A long and crooked spear. (TA.)
XaTiynN Distant, or remote. (TA. [See also XaTuwnN, and XaATinN.])
XaATinN [Distant, or remote, in respect of the place of alighting or abode]; i. q. XaATibN [q. v.]. (TA in art. XTb. [See also XaTuwnN, and XaTiynN.])
And † Far from the truth [and from the mercy of God: see 1]. (TA.)

And i. q. xabiyvN † [Bad, corrupt,, &c.; like saATinN]. (Ḳ.) Umeiyeh (Ṣ, TA) Ibn-Abi-s-Salt, referring to Solomon, (TA,) says,
Oay-umaA XaATinK EaSaAhu EakaAhu
vum-a yuloqaI fiI Als-ijoni waAlOagolaAli
[Whatever bad one disobeyed him, he bound him in irons; then he was cast into the prison and the shackles for the neck and hands]. (Ṣ, TA.)

XayoTaAnN a word of well-known meaning [i. e. A devil; and with the article Al, the devil, Satan]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) any that is excessively, or inordinately, proud or corrupt or unbelieving or rebellious, or that is insolent and audacious in pride and in acts of rebellion, of mankind, and of the jinn, or genii, and of beasts; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as is shown in relation to the first and second of these by what is said in the Ḳur vi. 112, and ii. 13 and 96: (TA:) the n is radical, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) the word being of the measure fayoEaAlN, from XaTana, (Mṣb, TA,) signifying “he was, or became, distant, or remote,” (TA,) or signifying “he was, or became, remote, or far, from the truth, and from the mercy of God;” (Mṣb;) as is indicated by the pl. XayaATiynu; [for] the reading of El-Ḥasan in the Ḳur xxvi. 210, AlX-ayaATuwna, is anomalous, [like basaAtuwna for basaAtiynu,] and is said by Th to be a mistake: (TA:) or, as some say, the n is augmentative, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,*) and the I is radical, so that the word is of the measure faEolaAn, (Mṣb,) from XaATa, aor. yaXiyTu, (Mṣb, TA,) signifying “it was, or became, null, void, of no account,” and the like, and “it burned,” or “became burnt,” (Mṣb,) or signifying “he burned with anger:” but the former opinion is the more common: (TA:) [in the Ḳur, the word is always perfectly decl.; and so it is said to be by SM, in art. XyT of the TA; unless used as a proper name: but J says,] if you make it to be of the measure fayoEaAl from taXayoTana said of a man, [or rather because they say of a man tXyTn,] you make it perfectly decl.; but if you make it to be from Xay-aTa [“he burned” a thing], you make it imperfectly decl., because it is of the measure faEolaAn. (Ṣ.)
Also The serpent: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a certain species of serpents; (Fr, Ṣ, TA;) having a mane, of foul aspect: or, as some say, a slender, light, or active, serpent. (TA.)

Respecting the saying in the Ḳur [xxxvii. 63], TaloEuhaA kaOan-ahu ruWuwsu AlX-ayaATiyni [Its fruit is as though it were the heads of the XyATyn], Fr says that there are three ways in which it may be explained: one is, that the TlE is likened to the heads of the XyATyn [meaning devils] in respect of foulness, or ugliness, because these are described as foul, or ugly: (Ṣ:) or it is likened to the evil in disposition of the jinn, because these are imagined as foul, or ugly: Zj says, in explaining it, that one says of a thing deemed foul, or ugly, kaOan-ahu wajohu XayoTaAnK [as though it were the face of a devil], and kaOan-ahu raOosu XayoTaAnK [as though it were the head of a devil]; for though the XyTAn is not seen, he is conceived in the mind as the foulest, or ugliest, of things: (TA:) the second is, that [the meaning is foul, or ugly, serpents; for] the Arabs apply the name XyTAn to a sort of serpents, having a mane, foul, or ugly, in the head and face: (Ṣ, TA:*) the third is, that a certain foul, or ugly, plat is named ruWuwsu AlX-ayaATiyni; (Ṣ, TA;) which is expl. in the Ḳ only as meaning a certain plant. (TA.)
XayoTaAnu AlfalaA [lit. The devil of the waterless deserts] means † thirst. (Ḳ.)

XayoTaAnN signifies also † Any blamable faculty, or power, [or propensity,] of a man. (Er-Rághib, TA.) One says, rakibahu XayoTaAnuhu i. e. † [His anger got the ascendency over him; or] he was, or became, angry. (TA.) And nazaEa XayoTaAnahu † He plucked out his pride. (TA.)

Also, [probably as being likened to a serpent,] † A mark made with a hot iron in the upper part of the haunch of a camel, perpendicularly, upon the thigh, extending to the hock; (Ḳ, TA;) from the “Tedhkireh” of Aboo-ʼAlee; (TA;) likewise called muXayoTanapN↓. (AZ, Ḳ, TA.)

AlX-ayoTaAniy-apu A certain sect of the extravagant zealots of [the schismatics called] the XiyEap; so named from [their founder] XayoTaAnu AlT-aAqi, (TA,) an appellation of Moḥammad Ibn-En-Noaman. (Ḳ and TA in art. Twq.)
muXaATinN One who draws out the bucket from the well biXaTanayoni, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. with two ropes. (TA.)
muXayoTanapN: see XayoTaAnN, last sentence.

1. XaZ-a AljuwaAliqa, (Ṣ,) or AlwiEaMCa, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXoZuZu}, inf. n. XaZ-N, (TA,) He fastened its XiZaAZ [q. v.] upon the sack: (Ṣ:) or he put the XiZaAZ into the bag; [meaning into its loop, or handle;] as also AXZ-hu↓: (Ḳ:) or the latter signifies he put to it, or made for it, (namely the sack,) a XiZaAZ. (Ṣ.)
4: see the preceding paragraph {1}.

XiZaAZN The stick, or piece of wood, which is inserted into the loop, or handle, of a sack; (Ṣ;) a curved piece of wood, (Ḳ, TA,) with a pointed extremity, (TA,) which is put into the two loops, or handles, of a pair of sacks, (Ḳ, TA,) when they are bound upon the camel: (TA:) there are two such pieces of wood: (Ṣ,* TA:) pl. OaXiZ-apN. (Ḳ.) And A piece of wood, or peg, with which they make fast the rope of a burden. (Ibn-Maạroof, as cited by Golius.)

hom.sense: XaZiyZN A sack made fast, or bound. (Fr. Ḳ.)
A stick, or piece of wood, split in several places. (Fr, Ḳ.)

1. XaZufa AlX-ajaru, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXoZufu}; (Ḳ;) and XaZifa, (O, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXoZafu}; (Ḳ;) inf. n. XaZaAfapN, (O, Ḳ,) of the former verb; (O;) The trees, not being sufficiently watered, became hard, without losing their moisture. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And XaZifato yaduhu His hand became rough, or coarse. (Ḥar p. 70.)
And XaZifa AlEayoXu The means of subsistence became dry and hard. (Ḳ,* TA.)
XaZifN Als-ahomu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXoZafu}, (Ḳ,) The arrow entered between the skin and the flesh. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, Omitted in the TA.)
XaZafotuhu Eani AlX-aIoCu, (O, TA,) inf. n. XaZofN, (O, Ḳ,) I withheld, restrained, or debarred, him from the thing. (O, Ḳ,* TA.)

And XaZofN signifies also The drawing forth the testicles of a ram: (O, Ḳ:) or the compressing them between two pieces of wood, or stick, and binding them with sinew (biEaqabK, in the CK [erroneously] bEaqibK,) so that they wither. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. tXZ-f He subjected himself to a hard, or difficult, life. (L in art. mEd.)
XaZofN A splinter, or piece split off, of a staff, or stick. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.)
XiZofN Dry bread. (O, Ḳ.)
And A small piece of wood, or stick, like a peg: pl. XiZafapN. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)

XaZafN and XaZaAfN↓ Straitness; and hardness, or difficulty, or distress; (AZ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) like DafafN: (AZ, Ṣ, O:) ISd thinks that the second is a dial. var. of the first; and IB mentions that, in a verse of El-Kumeyt, as related by some, it is with kesr, i.e. XiZaAf [which see in what here follows]: (TA:) and (Ḳ) as some say, (TA,) dryness, and hardness, of the means of subsistence: (Ḳ:) or XaZafN signifies hardness, and straitness, of the means of subsistence: (Mṣb:) or hardness, and coarseness, or roughness, thereof; from XaZifato yaduhu [expl. above]: (Ḥar p. 70:) pl. XiZaAfN. (Ḳ.)
Also A disintegration of the flesh, separating it from the border around the nail. (TA.)
XaZifN Dry and hard means of subsistence. (Ḳ,* TA. [See 1.])
Evil in disposition. (O, Ḳ.)
Vehement in fight. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
A man alighting, or taking up an abode, in places where the herbage is dried up, and in a desert where is no water (falaAp). (TA in art. EZb.)
baEiyrN XaZifu AlxilaATi [A stallion-camel] vehement in leaping, or compressing, the she-camels. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
OaroDN XaZifapN Rough, or rugged, land or ground. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
XiZofapN Bread that has become burned. (IAạr, O.)
XZaAfN: see XaZafN.
XZaAfN Distance, or remoteness. (O, Ḳ.)
XajarN XaZiyfN Trees that, not being sufficiently watered, have become hard, without losing their moisture. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
miXoZafN One who utters oblique, indirect, or ambiguous, speech or language, deviating from the right way or course. (O, Ḳ. Omitted in the TA.)

hom.sense: 1. XaZiIa, [aor. and inf. n. as in the next sentence,] said of a stick, or branch, or piece of wood, [&c.,] It was, or became, split. (AḤn, TA.)

Said of a horse, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXoZaIu}, inf. n. XaZFI, (Ḳ,) His XZI, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) i. e. the small bone called AlX-aZaI, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh,*) moved from its place, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh,) or became displaced, syn. zuwiIa, (A, TA,) or became unsteady, or wabbling: (Ḳ:) and so tXZ-I↓, (Ḳ, TA,) this latter on the authority of ISd: (TA:) or [the inf. n.] XaZFI, accord. to some, signifies the sinews' becoming split, or slit: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh:) or XaZFI has this meaning also; (Ḳ;) and so taXaZ-↓. (ISd, Ḳ, TA.)

Accord. to the Ḳ, XaZiIa, said of a corpse, is syn. with XaSiIa: but correctly, the former verb is XaZaI, aor. _i {yaXoZiIu}, inf. n. XuZiI-N, and the latter verb is XaSaA [q. v.], as they are said to be by Az: and in like manner, XaZiI, aor. _i {yaXoZiIu}, is said of a siqaMC [or skin for water or milk], meaning It being filled, its legs became raised, or raised high. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. XZ-I, (TA,) inf. n. taXoZiyapN, (Ḳ, TA,) He separated into several, or many, portions or divisions; or dispersed, or scattered; (Ḳ,* TA;) [a thing; or] ‡ a company of men. (TA.)
And He made [a horse] to be such that his XZI (XaZaAhu) became unsteady, or wabbling. (TA.)
4. AXZAhu He, or it, hit, or hurt, his XZI (XaZaAhu): (Ḳ:) Ṣgh says, by rule it should be XaZaAhu [i. e. the verb should be thus, being derived from AlX-aZaI, like qafaAhu from AlqafaA]. (TA.)

5. tXZ-I, said of a stick, or branch, or piece of wood, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) or of a thing, (Ṣ, TA,) It split, or became split, in pieces, or in several or many places: (A, Mṣb, TA:) or it became scattered, or dispersed, in splinters, or pieces split off: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and it [i. e. anything, nothing in particular being specified,] became separated into several, or many, portions or divisions; or dispersed, or scattered. (TA.) One says also, tXZ-I All-uWoluWu Eani AlS-adafi ‡ [The pearls became separated, or scattered, from the oyster-shells]. (A, TA.) See also 1, in two places.
7. AnXZI It broke, or became broken. (TA.) One says, AnXZt Alr-abaAEiyapu The [tooth called the] rbAEyp broke, or became broken. (TA.)

XaZFI, of a staff, or stick, The like of a liyTap [i. e. a piece, or sharp piece, of the exterior portion], that enters into the hand, and wounds it. (Ḥam p. 474. [But XaZiy-apN is more commonly used in this and similar senses.])

A small bone, (EuZayomN, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK EaZomN, i. e. a bone, and so in my copy of the Mgh,]) or a slender small bone, (Aṣ, Ṣ,) adhering to the ciraAE [here app. meaning the arm-bone of a horse], (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or to the bone of the ciraAE, (Mgh,) which sometimes moves from its place; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh; [see XaZiy-apN;]) or to the knee; (Ḳ;) thus in the M; (TA;) or to the waZiyf [app. here meaning the fore shank of a horse]; (Ḳ;) thus in the A: (TA:) or certain small sinews (EaSab) therein; (Ḳ;) i. e. in the wZyf; thus in the T. (TA.) AO says that taHar-uku AlX-aZaI [i. e. The motion of the XZI from its place (see 1)] is like what is termed AinotiXaAru AlEaSabi, except that the horse has more power of endurance of the latter than of the former. (T, TA.)
And Portions of a thing that are separated, or dispersed, or scattered. (Ḥar p. 160.) It is said by ISd to be a pl. [or rather it is a coll. gen. n.] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is XaZaApN. (TA.)

Also A portion of fur upon the mark left by a gall, or sore, on the back [of a camel], such as reaches the utmost extent thereof: (Ḳ, accord. to the TA: [AlX-aZaI being there expl. by the words Alwbrp ElI Avr Aldbrp HtI tblg AqSAhA: in the CK, and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, Ald-abarapu ElI Oavari Ald-abarapi fI AlmazoraEapi Hat-aI taboluga OaqoSaAhaA; which Freytag renders “sulcus ad latus alterius in arvo ductus, ut ejus extremum attingeret;” but which, I think, evidently presents a mistranscription and an interpolation:]) the pl. is OaXoZiyapN: and sometimes there are ten [?] portions of fur [of this description, app. meaning, upon one camel: the word that I here render “ten” is more like EXh than EXr; but the final letter, as is often the case in the MṢ. of the TA, is written in a form differing little from a common form of r]: mentioned by ISh, from Et-Táïfee; as is said in the T. (TA.)
Also † The followers, and incorporated confederates, of a people, or party; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) contr. of the Samiym thereof: (Ṣ:) or the freedmen and followers. (M, TA.)
XaZiI-N and XiZiI-N: see the next paragraph.

XiZiy-apN A splinter, or piece split off, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a staff, or stick, and the like, (Ṣ,) or of wood, (T, Mgh, Mṣb,) and the like, (Mṣb,) or of a reed, or cane, (T, Mgh,) or of silver, (T, TA,) or of bone, (T, Mgh,) or of anything: (M, Ḳ:) pl. XaZaAyaA (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and XaZiI-N↓, (Ḳ,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] like as rakiI-N is of rakiy-apN, (TA,) or a quasi-pl. n., like EabiydN, improperly said by IAạr to be pl. of XaZFI, (ISd, TA,) and XiZiI-N↓, (Ḳ, TA, [in the latter as omitted in the Ḳ, with kesr to the X on account of the same vowel-sound following,]) mentioned by Ṣgh, from Ks. (TA.) AO terms the Uiborap [q. v.] at the head of the elbow [of the horse] a XaZiy-ap adhering to the ciraAE, but not [forming a portion] of it. (TA. [See XaZFI.])
Also A bow: (Ḳ:) because its wood is split: on the authority of AḤn. (TA.)
And The shankbone. (Ḳ.)

And A great mass of rock wrenched from the side of a mountain; (Ḳ, TA;) as though it were a piece split off, broken [off] but not parted so as to form an interstice, or a gap: and also a piece cut from a mountain, like a house or a tent: and it is said in the copies of the Ḳ that XiZoyapN, with kesr, signifies the same; but the word is correctly XinoZiyapN↓, with an augmentative n as in the T, and mentioned also by Hr in the “Ghareebeyn:” pl. of the former XaZaAyaA. (TA.)
See also XanoZaApN.
XaAZK part. n. of XaZiIa [q. v.] said of a horse. (TA.)

XanoZaApN The head, or top, of a mountain, (Ḳ, TA,) [and so XaZiy-apN↓, (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees,)] resembling the Xurofap [q. v.] of a mosque: pl. XanaAZK:
and XawaAZiI↓ AljibaAli [likewise] signifies the heads, or tops, of the mountains. (TA.)
XinoZiyapN: see XaZiy-apN, near the end.
XawaAZiI AljibaAli: see XanoZaApN.
[maXoZFI, pl. maXaAZiI, A fragment of wood: (Freytag, from the Deewán of Jereer:) but the pl., when indeterminate, is correctly maXaAZK.]

hom.sense: 1. XaE-a, (O, Ḳ, TA,) aor. _i {yaXoEiEu}, (O, TA,) inf. n. XaEaAEN (Ṣ,* O,* Ḳ,* TA) and XaE-N, (TA,) It became scattered, or dispersed; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) said of a thing; like XaAEa, aor. yaXiyEu; (TA;) of the urine of a camel; (O, Ḳ;) and of a people, or party; (IAạr, O, Ḳ;) [like Xag-a;] and [in like manner] XaEaAEN is used in relation to blood, &c., as meaning the being scattered. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA. [See also XaEaAEN, below; and XuEaAEN.])

And XaE-a AlgaArapa, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. XaE-N; and XaEoXaEahaA↓; (TA;) He poured upon them the horsemen making a sudden attack and engaging in conflict, or urging on their horses; (Ḳ, TA;) and in like manner, Alxayola. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1.
AXE-t AlX-amosu The sun spread, or diffused, its XuEaAE [or beams], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or its light. (TA.)
AXE- Alz-aroEu The corn put forth its XaEaAE, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) i. e., its awn. (TA.)
And AXE- Als-unobulu The ears of corn became compact in their grain, (Ḳ, TA,) and dry therein. (TA.)
7. AnXE- Alc-iYobu fiI Alganami The wolf made an incursion among the sheep or goats. (O, Ḳ, TA.)

R. Q. 1. XaEoXaEahu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. XaEoXaEapN, (TA,) He mixed it, namely, wine, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) with water. (O.) And He mixed one part of it, namely, a thing, with another part, (O,* Ḳ,) like as one mixes wine with water. (O.) And XaEoXaEa Alv-ariydapa He mixed the vrydp [or mess of crumbled bread] with olive-oil: (O:) or he put much clarified butter to it, (ISh, O, Ḳ,) and much grease, or gravy: (Ḳ:) or he raised its head; (O, Ḳ;) as some say: (Sh, O:) or he made its head high; (O, Ḳ;) as some say; from XaEoXaAEN as an epithet applied to a man, meaning “tall.” (O.) But the verb is used more in relation to wine than to vryd. (TA.)
See also 1.

R. Q. 2. taXaEoXaEa, said of a man, is from XaEoXaAEN↓ applied to a man as meaning HulowN xafiyfN [i. e. “such as is excited to briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, and esteemed pleasing in the eye, and is light, or active;” so that the verb may be rendered He was, or became, such as is excited to briskness,, &c.: or he was, or became, such as is termed XaEoXaAEN, q. v.]. (Ḥam, p. 246.)

Said of the month It nearly came to an end; little remained of it: (Ḳ, TA:) occurring in a trad.: but accord. to one relation thereof, it is taXaEosaEa; from AlX-usuwEu “the being distant, or remote:” and accord. to another, taXaEosaEa, with two s s. (TA.)

hom.sense: XaE-N: see XaEaAEN, first and last sentences.
Also Haste: (IAạr, Ḳ, TA:) and so XaEiyEN accord. to the Ḳ; but this is wrong; the meaning of the latter word being only that given below, voce XaEaAEN. (TA.)

entry.sense: XuE-N A spider's web. (AA, Ḳ.)
See also XuEaAEN.

hom.sense:
XaEaAEN [an inf. n. (see 1) used as an epithet, and therefore as masc. and fem. and sing. and pl.;] Scattered, or dispersed; and disordered, or unsettled; syn. mutafar-iqN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also XaE-N↓, [likewise an inf. n. used as an epithet,] applied [like the former] to anything, (Ḳ, TA,) such as blood, and an opinion, and a purpose, or an intention; (TA;) and XaEiyEN↓, which is wrongly expl. in the Ḳ as syn. with XaE-N in another sense, as stated above; (TA;) and XaEoXaAEN↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, cahaba damuhu XaEaAEFA His blood went scattered, or dispersed: (TA:) or XaEaAEN applied to blood signifies spirtling from a wound made with a spear or the like; as in a verse cited voce nafacN. (Az, TA. [See also XuEaAEN.]) And cahabuwA XaEaAEFA They went away scattered, or dispersed. (Ḳ.) And Oum-apN XaEaAEN A nation, or people, scattered, or dispersed. (TA, from a trad.) And taTaAyarati AlEaSaA XaEaAEFA The staff, or stick, broke into scattered pieces; as when one has broken it by striking with it upon a wall: and in like manner, AlqaSabapu the reed, or cane. (TA.) And raOoIN XaEaAEN A disordered, or an unsettled, opinion. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And nafosN XaEaAEN A mind of which the purposes, or intentions, (himamuhaA, as in the Ṣ [and O], for which, in the Ḳ, humuwmuhaA is erroneously substituted, TA,) and the opinions, (Z, TA,) are disordered, or unsettled, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) so that it is not directed to a decided affair. (Z, TA.) And TaAra fuWaAduhu XaEaAEFA [His mind fled in a disordered, or an unsettled, state, as though dissipated; expl. as] meaning tafar-aqato humuwmuhu [a mistranscription, as before: correctly tfr-qt himamuhu i. e. his purposes, or intentions, became disordered, or unsettled: see also Ḥam p. 44, and Ḥar p. 366]. (Ḳ.) And a rájiz says,
Sadoqu All-iqaMCi gayoru XaEoXaAEi↓ Algadaro
meaning [Firm, or steady, in encounter, or conflict,] not disordered, or unsettled, in respect of purpose, or intention. (Ṣ.)
Hence, app., (TA,) Milk mixed with much water; (ISh, O;) syn. DayaAHN. (ISh, O, Ḳ, TA.)

Also [as a subst.] The awn, or beard, of the ears of corn; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and so XuEaAEN↓ and XiEaAEN↓ (Ḳ) and XaE-N↓: (TA:) or the awn, or beard, when it has become dry, as long as it remains on the ears; as also XuEaAEN↓. (Lth, O.)

entry.sense: XaEaAEN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and XuE-N↓ (AA, Ḳ) [The rays, or beams, of the sun; or] what one sees, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) of the light, like rods, (Ṣ,) or extending like spears, (O, Ḳ,) at the rising, or the beginning of the rising, (Ṣ,) or a little after the rising, (O, Ḳ,) of the sun; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) or what one sees, like cords coming towards him, when looking at the sun; or the dispersing light of the sun: (Ḳ:) n. un. with p {XaEaAEapN}: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) [and Freytag states that XiEoXiEapN↓ is said by Jac. Schultens to signify rays: but this I do not find in any lexicon:] the pl. (of XuEaAEN, O) is OaXiE-apN, (O, Ḳ,) accord. to analogy, (O,) [a pl. of pauc.,] and XuEuEN (O, Ḳ) and XiEaAEN↓; (Ḳ;) the last anomalous. (TA.) Hence, in a trad. respecting [the night called] layolapu Alqadori, it is said, Uin-a AlX-amosa taToluEu mino gadi yawomihaA laA XuEaAEa lahaA [Verily the sun will rise on its morrow having no rays]. (Ṣ: in the O, mino gadihaA.)

In the verse cited voce nafacN, Aṣ is related to have read AlX-uEaAEu instead of AlX-aEaAEu, as meaning The light, [or brightness] and redness, and scattered state, of the blood: ISd says, I know not whether he said it meaning by original application or by way of comparison. (TA.)
See also XaEaAEN, last sentence, in two places.
XiEaAEN: see XaEaAEN, last sentence:
and see also XuEaAEN.
XaEiyEN: see XaEaAEN, first sentence.
XaEoXaEN, (Ṣ, O,) or XaEoXaAEN↓, (Ḳ,) or both, (TA,) and muXaEoXaEN↓, (Ṣ, TA,) Shade that is not thick, or dense; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) or which has not wholly shaded one, having in it interspaces. (TA.)
See also XaEoXaAEN, in two places.
XuEoXuEN: see the next paragraph but one, in two places: and see XuloXulN.
XiEoXiEapN: see XuEaAEN.

hom.sense: XaEoXaAEN: see XaEaAEN, in two places: and XaEoXaEN.

Also, (Ṣ, O, Ṣ,) and XaEoXaEN↓ (O, Ḳ) and XaEoXaEaAnN↓ (IDrd, Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and XaEoXaEaAniI-N↓, (O, Ḳ,) in which last the relative I is without cause, as in OaHomariI-N and daw-aAriI-N, (TA,) applied to a man, (Ṣ,) Tall: (O, Ḳ:) or tall and goodly (Ṣ, TA) and light of flesh; applied to a man as being likened to the thin [or much diluted] wine termed muXaEoXaEap: or the first signifies long-necked; and so ↓the third, and ↓the fourth; applied to anything, or the last, accord. to the R, applied to a man only: and the first, long applied to a neck: (TA:) and light, or active: (O, Ḳ:) or so in journeying; as also XuEoXuEN↓ like hudohudN, applied to a man, or, accord. to Th, to a boy, or young man: or light in spirit: (TA:) see also R. Q. 2: and (Ḳ) as some say, (O,) the first signifies goodly, or beautiful, (O, Ḳ, TA,) in face: (TA:) and XaEoXaEN↓, (so in the O,) or XuEoXuEN↓, with damm to the X, (TA,) a boy, or young man, goodly, or beautiful, in face, light in spirit; (O, TA;) on the authority of AA. (TA.)
Also Certain trees; or a kind of tree. (TA.)

entry.sense: XaEoXaEaAnN: see XaEoXaAEN, in two places. With p, applied to a she-camel, meaning Tall: (Ṣ,* O:) or large in body: (TA:) pl. XaEoXaEaAnaAtN. (Ṣ, O. [In the TA, XaEoXaEaAnaAtN is said to be mistranscribed in the Ṣ XaEoXaEaAnaAn: but it is not so in either of my copies.])
XaEoXaEaAniI-N: see XaEoXaAEN, in two places. Also Long and thin; applied to a camel's lip. (TA.)
muXaEoXaEN: see XaEoXaEN.
With p, applied to wine (xamorN), Mixed with water: (O,* EM p. 183:) accord. to some, [much diluted; i. e.] mixed so as to be thin. (TA.)

hom.sense:
1. XaEaba, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. _a {yaXoEabu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. XaEobN, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He collected; brought, gathered, or drew, together; or united; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) a thing, (Ṣ,) any thing or things, and a people or party: (Mṣb:) and he separated; put apart, or asunder; divided; disunited; or dispersed or scattered; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) a thing, (Ṣ,) any thing or things, and a people or party: (Mṣb:) thus having two contr. significations: (Ṣ:) so expressly state AʼObeyd and Aboo-Ziyád: (TA:) but accord. to IDrd, it has not two contr. significations [in one and the same dial.]: he says that the two meanings are peculiar to the dials. of two peoples, (Mṣb, TA,*) each meaning belonging to the dial. of one people exclusively. (TA.) [Hence, as it seems to be indicated in the Ṣ and A, or from XaEobN meaning “a tribe,” as it seems to be indicated in the Ḥam p. 538,] one says, tafar-aqa XaEobuhumo, (Ṣ,) or Xat-a XaEobuhumo, (A, Ḥam,) ‡ [Their union became dissolved, or broken up; or their tribe became separated;] meaning they became separated after being congregated: (Ṣ, Ḥam:) and AilotaOama XaEobuhumo (Ṣ, A, Ḥam) ‡ [Their separation became closed up, or their tribe drew together;] meaning they drew together after being separated. (Ṣ, Ḥam.) And XaEabatohumu Almaniy-apu Death separated them: (Ṣ:) and XaEabatohu XaEuwbu [Death separated him from his companions]; (TA;) said of a man when he has died. (O in art. Ebl: in the Ḳ, in that art., AiXotaEabatohu↓ [perhaps a mistranscription].) And it is said in a trad., maA hecihi AlfutoyaA Ql-atiI XaEabota bihaA Aln-aAsa i. e, [What is this judicial decision] with which thou hast divided the people? (Ṣ. [In the TA, on the authority of IAth, AltI Xagabato fiI Aln-aAsi, which means, “which has excited evil among the people.”]) One says also, XaEaba Alr-ajulu Oamorahu † The man broke up, discomposed, deranged, or disorganized, [or rendered unsound, impaired, or marred, (agreeably with another explanation of the verb in what follows,)] his state of affairs: (Aṣ, AʼObeyd, TA:) whence the saying of ʼAlee Ibn-El-'Adheer El-Ghanawee,
waUicaA raOayota AlmaroCa yaXoEabu Oamorahu
XaEoba AlEaSaA wayalaj-u fiI AlEiSoyaAni
† [And when thou seest the man break up his state of affairs as with the breaking up of the staff, and persevere in disobedience, or rebellion]. (AʼObeyd, TA.)
