Also, aor, as above, (Mṣb,) and so the inf. n., (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He repaired a cracked thing [such as a wooden bowl or some other vessel, by closing up its crack or cracks, or by piecing it: see 2, which has a similar signification, but implying muchness]: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and [in a general sense,] he repaired, mended, amended, adjusted, or put into a right, or proper, state: (A, Ḳ, TA:) and it signifies the contr. also [of the former meaning and] of this, in the same, or in another, dial.: (TA:) [i. e.] he cracked a thing [such as a wooden bowl, &c.]: (A, Mṣb:) and he corrupted, rendered unsound, impaired, or marred. (A, Ḳ, TA.) XaEobN SagiyrN mino XaEobK kabiyrK, occurring in a trad. of ʼOmar, means A little repairing, of, or amid, much impairing. (TA.)
[He gave a portion of property; as though he broke it off.] One says, AiXoEabo liI XuEobapF mina AlmaAli Give thou to me a portion of the property. (TA.)
He (the commander, or prince, Ṣ) sent a messenger (Ṣ, Ḳ) Uilayohi [to him], (Ḳ,) or UilaI mawoDiEi kacaA [to such a place]. (Ṣ.)

He turned, or sent, him, or it, away, or back: (Ḳ, TA:) aor. and inf.n. as above. (TA.) And XaEaba All-ijaAmu Alfarasa The bridle turned away or back, or withheld, or restrained, the horse from the direction towards which he was going. (Ḳ.)
He, or it, diverted a man by occupying him, busying him, or engaging his attention. (Ḳ, TA.) One says, maA XaEabaka Ean-iI [What diverted thee, or what has diverted thee,, &c., from me?]. (TA.)
It is also intrans.: see 4.

[Thus it signifies He quitted his companions, desiring others.] One says, XaEaba Uilayohimo (Ḳ, TA) fiI Eadadi kacaA (TA) He yearned towards them [with such a number of men], and quitted his companions. (Ḳ, TA.)
And He, or it, appeared [distinct from others]: (Ḳ, TA:) whence the month [XaEobaAn, q. v.,] is [said to be] named. (TA.)
Also, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) said of a camel, He cropped (AihotaDama) the upper, or uppermost, parts of trees [or shrubs]. (Ḳ, TA.)

XaEiba, aor. _a {yaXoEabu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XaEabN, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA,) He (a goat, Ṣ, TA, and a gazelle, TA) was wide, (Ḳ,) or very wide, (Ṣ,) between the horns, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and between the shoulders. (Ḳ,* TA.) [See also XaEabN, below.]
2. XE-b [app. signifies He collected several things; or he collected much: and] he separated several things; or he separated much. (O.)

Also He repaired a cracked wooden bowl [or some other vessel] in several places [by closing up its cracks, or by piecing it]: (Ṣ, O:) [and app., in a general sense, he repaired, mended, amended, adjusted, or put into a right, or proper, state, several things; or he repaired,, &c., much: and it seems to signify also the contr. of these two meanings: i. e. he cracked several things; or he cracked in several places: and he corrupted, rendered unsound, impaired, or marred, several things; or he corrupted,, &c., much.]
It is also intrans.: see 4.

Thus, said of seed-produce, It branched forth, or forked, after being in leaf, or blade; (TA;) like tXE-b↓. (Ḳ,* TA.) [Hence,] one says, Uin-iI OaraI AlX-ar-a XaE-aba † [Verily I see the evil to have grown like seed-produce when it branches forth]; like as one says, qaS-aba, and nab-aba. (TA in art. nb.)

entry.sense: 3. XAEbhu He became distant, or remote, from him; (Ḳ, TA;) namely, his companion. (TA.) [Hence,] XAEb AlHayaApa † [He quitted life]. (TA.) And XaAEabato nafosuhu (Ḳ, TA) His soul [departed, or] quitted life; (TA;) meaning he died; (Ḳ, TA;) as also AnXEb↓ [i. e. AnXEb huwa]. (Ḳ.) [See also what next follows {4}.]

4. AXEb He died: (Ṣ, Ḳ: [see also 3:]) or (so in the Ṣ and TA, but in the Ḳ “and”) he separated himself from another or others, never to return; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also XE-b↓ or XaEaba↓, accord. to different copies of the Ḳ, the latter as in the L. (TA.) A poet says, (Ṣ,) namely, En-Nábighah El-Jaadee, (IB, TA.)
wakaAnuwA OunaAsFA mino XuEuwbK faOaXoEabuwA , (Ṣ, IB, TA,) or wakaAnuwA XuEuwbFA mino OunaAsK, accord. to different readings: [app. meaning, And they were men of divided races or tribes, or were divided races or tribes of men; so they perished; or separated, never to return:] IB says, after mentioning the former reading, i. e. they were of men who should perish; so they perished: having previously mentioned the latter reading, and added, i. e. they were of those whom XEwb should overtake. (TA. [IB's explanations seem at first sight to indicate that he read XaEuwba and XaEuwbFA; neither of which is admissible: each of his explanations app. relates to both readings; as though he understood the poet to mean, they were men separated from different tribes, to be overtaken by others; so they perished.])

5. tXE-b and AnXEb↓ are quasi-pass. verbs, the former of XaE-aba and the latter of XaEaba: (TA:) [the former, therefore, is most correctly to be regarded and used as intensive in its significations, or as relating to several things or persons: but it is said that] both signify alike: [app. It became collected; it became brought, gathered, or drawn, together; or it became united: and also] it became separated, put apart or asunder, divided, disunited, or dispersed or scattered: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and it, or he, became distant, or remote. (Ḳ.) One says, taXaE-abuwA fiI Talabi AlmiyaAhi [They became separated,, &c., or they separated themselves,, &c., in search of the waters], and fiI AlgaAraAti [in predatory excursions]. (TA.) And AnXEb↓ Ean-iI fulaAnN Such a one became distant, or remote, from me; or withdrew to a distance, or for away, from me. (TA.) And AnXEb↓ AlT-ariyqu [and tXE-b] The road separated. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb.) And AnXEb↓ Aln-ahoru and tXE-b The river separated [or branched forth] into other rivers. (TA.) And AnXEbt↓ OagoSaAnu AlX-ajarapi (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) and tXE-bt (TA) The branches of the tree separated, divided, straggled, or spread out dispersedly; (Ṣ, TA;)
or branched forth from the stem, and separated, divided,, &c. (Mṣb.) See also 2. One says also, tXE-b Oamoru Alr-ajuli † [The state of affairs of the man became broken up, discomposed, deranged, disorganized, or (agreeably with another explanation of the verb in what follows) rendered unsound, impaired, or marred]. (A.)

Also ↓the latter verb, [or each,] It became closed up; [or repaired by having a crack or cracks closed up, or by being pieced;] said of a cracked thing: (TA:) and ↓both verbs, i. q. AinoSalaHa [which means, in a general sense, it became rectified, repaired, mended, amended, adjusted, or put into a right, or proper, state;, &c.; but I have not found this verb (AnSlH) in its proper art. in any of the Lexicons]: (Ḳ, TA:) and ↓the latter signifies also it became cracked; (A;) [and in like manner the former, said of a number of things; or it became cracked in several places when said of a single thing: and hence ↓both signify, in a general sense, it became corrupted, rendered unsound, impaired, or marred; a meaning which may justly be assigned to the former verb in the phrase mentioned in the next preceding sentence.]
7: see 5, in nine places: and see also 3.
8: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph.

hom.sense: XaEobN inf. n. of XaEaba [q. v.]. (Mṣb.)

[Used as a simple subst., it signifies Collection, or union: and also separation, division, or disunion; and] a state of separation or division or disunion; (Ḳ, TA;) as also XuEobapN↓: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. of the former XuEuwbN. (TA.)

And [hence, perhaps, as implying both union and division,] Such as is divided [into sub-tribes], of the tribes of the Arabs and foreigners: (Ṣ: [in my copy of the Mṣb, mA Anqsmt fyh qbAYl AlErb, as though it meant the tribes of the Arabs collectively, agreeably with another explanation to be mentioned below; but I think that there may be a mistranscription in this case:]) pl. XuEuwbN: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or it signifies, as some say, (Mṣb,) or signifies also, (Ṣ,) a great tribe; syn. qabiylapN EaZiymapN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or HaI-N EaZiymN; (Mṣb;) the parent of the [tribes called] qabaAYil, to which they refer their origin, and which comprises them: (Ṣ:) or, as some say, a great tribe (HaI-N EaZiymN) forming a branch of a qabiylap: or a qabiylap itself: (TA:) A' Obeyd says, on the authority of Ibn-El-Kelbee, on the authority of his father, that the XaEob is greater than the qabiylap; next to which is the faSiylap; then, the EamaArap; then, the baTon; then, the faxic: (Ṣ, TA:) but IB says that the true order is that which Ez-Zubeyr Ibn-Bekkár has stated, and is as follows: (TA:) [i. e.] the genealogies of the Arabs consist of six degrees; (Mṣb;) first, the XaEob; then, the qabiylap; then, the EamaArap, (Mṣb, TA,) with fet-ḥ and with kesr, to the E; (Mṣb;) then, the baTon; then, the faxic; and then, the faSylap: thus, Khuzeymeh is a XEb; and Kináneh, a qbylap; and Kureysh, an EmArp; and Kuseí, a bTn; and Háshim, a fxc; and El-ʼAbbás, a fSylp: (Mṣb, TA:) and Aboo-Usámeh says that these classes are agreeable with the order obtaining in the structure of man; the XEb is the greatest of them, derived from the XaEob [or suture] of the head; next is the qbylp, from the qbylp [which is a term applied to any one of the four principal bones] of the head; then, the EmArp, which is the breast; then, the bTn [or belly]; then, the fxc [or thigh]; and then, the fSylp, which is the shank: to these some add the EaXityrap, which consists of few in comparison with what are before mentioned: (TA:) and some add after this the rahoT: some also add the jicom before the XEb: (TA in art. bTn:) the pl. is as above. (TA.) It signifies also A nation, people, race, or family of mankind; syn. jiylN; as expl. by IM and others: in the Ḳ, [and in a copy of the A,] erroneously, jabal [a mountain]: (TA:) but it is [strangely] said by Aboo-ʼObeyd El-Bekree that accord. to all except Bundár, the word in this sense is XiEobN↓, with kesr. (MF.) And the pl., XuEuwbN, is [said to be] especially applied to denote the foreigners (AlEajam): (TA:) [thus it is said that] the phrase, in a trad., Uin-a rajulFA mina AlX-uEuwbi Oasolama means [Verily a man] of the foreigners (AlEajam) [became a Muslim: but see AlX-uEuwbiy-apu]. (Ṣ.)
Also, [as implying separation,] Distance, or remoteness. (A, Ḳ.) So in the phrase XaEobu Ald-aAri [The distance, or remoteness, of the abode, or dwelling]. (TA.)
And A crack (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA) in a thing, (Ṣ,) which the XaE-aAb repairs. (Ṣ,* TA.)

And The place of junction [i. e. the suture] of the qabaAYil [or principal bones] of the head; (Ḳ;) the XaOon which conjoins the qbAYl of the head: the qbAYl in the head being [the frontal bone, the occipital bone, and the two parietal bones; in all,] four in number. (Ṣ.)
[Hence, perhaps,] humaA XaEobaAni † They two are likes [or like each other]. (Ṣ.)
See also XiEobN.
Also Distant, or remote; (Ḳ;) as in the phrase maMCN XaEobN [Distant, or remote, water]: pl. XuEuwbN. (TA.)

entry.sense: XuEobN: see the dual XuEobaAni voce XuEobapN.

XiEobN A road: (Mṣb:) or a road in a mountain: (Ṣ, A, O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) primarily a road in a mountain (Ḥar p. 29) and in valleys: (Id. p. 72:) afterwards applied to any road: (Id. p. 29:) [see also maXoEabN:] pl. XiEaAbN. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb.) And A water-course, or place in which water flows, in [a low, or depressed, tract, such as is called] a baTon of land, (ISh, A, O, Ḳ,) having two elevated borders, and in width equal to the stature of a man lying down, and sometimes between the two faces, or acclivities, of two mountains. (ISh, O.) Or it signifies, (Ḳ,) or signifies also, (A,) A ravine, or gap, [or pass,] between two mountains. (A, Ḳ.)

Also [A reef of rocks in the sea: so in the present day: or] a zirobap or zarabap (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ in art. jhn [but neither of these two words do I find in their proper art. in any Lex.]) in the sea, such as is connected with the shore: if not connected with the shore, a bowshot distant, it is called juhonN. (Ḳ and TA in art. jhn.)

And A brand, or mark made with a hot iron, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) upon camels, (Ḳ,) peculiar to the Benoo-Minkar, in form resembling the [hooked stick called] miHojan: (Ṣ:) or a brand upon the thigh, lengthwise, [consisting of] two lines meeting at the top and separated at the bottom: (ISh, TA:) or a brand united [at the upper part and] at the lower part separated: (Aboo-ʼAlee in the “Tedhkireh,” TA: [but there is an omission here, so that the reverse may perhaps be meant:]) or a brand upon the neck, like the miHojan: (Suh in the R, TA:) in a marginal note in the copy of the L, it is said that XEb signifying a brand is with kesr to the X and with fet-ḥ [i. e. XiEobN and XaEobN↓]. (TA.)
See also XaEobN.
[And see the pl. XiEaAbN below.]

XaEabN Width, or distance, (A, Ḳ,) or great width or distance, (Ṣ,) between the horns (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) of a goat (Ṣ, TA) and of a gazelle, (TA,) and between the shoulders, (A, Ḳ,) and between two branches. (A.) [See also 1, last signification.]
XuEobapN: see XaEobN, second sentence.
Also The space, or interstice, between two horns: and between two branches: (Ḳ:) pl. XuEabN and XiEaAbN, (Ḳ,* TA,) in this and all the following senses. (TA.)
And A cleft in a mountain, to which birds (AlT-ayoru, for which AlmaTaru is erroneously substituted in [several of] the copies of the Ḳ, TA) resort: pl. as above. (Ḳ, TA.)

Also A branch of a tree, (Ṣ, A,* Mgh,* Mṣb, TA,) growing out a part, or divaricating, therefrom: (Mṣb,* TA:) or the extremity of a branch: (Ḳ, TA: [said in the latter to be tropical in this latter sense; but why, I see not:]) pl. XuEabN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA) and XiEaAbN, as above. (TA.) And XuEabu AlguSoni The divaricating, or straggling, [branchlets, or] extremities [or shoots or stalks] of the branch. (TA.) And [hence] EaSFA fiI raOosihaA XuEobataAni [A staff having at his head two forking portions or projections]; (A, TA;) and Az mentions, as heard by him from the Arabs, XuEobaAni↓, without t, instead of XuEobataAni in this phrase. (L, TA.) And XuEobapN mino rayoHaAnK [A sprig, spray, bunch, or branchlet, of sweet basil, or of sweet-smelling plants]: and XuEobapN mino XaEarK [and mino SuwfK A lock, or flock, of hair and of wool]. (JK in art. Twq.) And OanaA XuEobapN mino dawoHatika ‡ [I am a branch, or branchlet, of thy great tree]. (A, TA.) And masoOalapN kaviyrapu AlX-uEabi † [A question having many branches, or ramifications]. (Mṣb.) And [the pl.] XuEabN [as meaning] ‡ The fingers: (Ḳ, TA:) one says, qabaDa Ealayohi biXuEabi yadihi ‡ He laid hold upon it with his fingers. (A, TA.) And qaEada bayona XuEobatayohaA ‡ He sat between her two legs: (A:) and bayona XuEabihaA AlOarobaEi ‡ [He sat (in the Mgh qaEada, as implied in the A, and in the Mṣb jalasa,)] between her arms and her legs; (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or between her legs and the XuforaAni [dual of XuforN, q. v.,] of her faroj; (A, Mgh, Ḳ;) occurring in a trad.; (Mgh, Mṣb;) an allusion to jimaAE. (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And XuEobataA Alr-aHoli † The XaroxaAni [or two upright pieces of wood] of the camel's saddle; its qaAdimap and its Mxirah. (Mgh.)
And Aigorizi All-aHoma fiI XuEabi Als-af-uwdi ‡ [Infix thou the flesh-meat upon the prongs of the roastinginstrument]. (A, TA.) And XuEobapu minojalK † [A tooth of a reaping-hook]. (Ḳ in art. sn.) And XuEobapN mino XuEabi Als-iyni † [A tooth, or cusp, of the teeth, or cusps, of the s]; the XuEab of the s being three. (Ṣ and L in art. s.) And XuEabu Alfarasi ‡ The outer parts, or regions, of the horse (OaqoTaAruhu, A, or nawaAHiyhi, Ḳ); all of them: (Ḳ:) or the prominent parts (Ṣ, Ḳ) of them, (Ḳ,) or of him; (Ṣ, and so in some copies of the Ḳ;) as the neck, and the minosaj [or withers,, &c.], (Ṣ, TA,) and the crests of the hips, (TA,) or such as his head, and his HaArik [or withers,, &c.], and the crests of his hips. (A.)

Also A small water-course, or channel in which water flows; as in the phrase XuEobapN HaAfilN a small water-course filled with a torrent: (Ṣ:) or a water-course in sand; (Ḳ;) or in the elevated part of a depressed tract into which sand has poured and remained. (TA.) And A small portion of a [water-course such as is called] taloEap; or what is smaller than a taloEap; accord. to different copies of the Ḳ; AlX-uEobapu being expl. as meaning maA Sagura mina Alt-aloEapi, and, in one copy, Eani Alt-aloEapi. (TA.) And Such as is large, of the channels for irrigation of valleys: (Ḳ, TA:) or, as some say, a branch from a taloEap, and from a valley, or torrent-bed, taking a different course therefrom: pl. as above. (TA.)

And A portion, part, or piece, of a thing; or somewhat thereof: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) pl. as above. (TA.) One says, AiXoEabo liI XuEobapF mina AlmaAli Give thou to me a portion of the property. (TA.) And fiI yadihi XuEobapu xayorK † [In his hand is somewhat of good, or of wealth]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., AlHayaMCu XuEobapN mina AlUiymaAni † Modesty is a part of faith: and in another, AlX-abaAbu XuEobapN mina Aljunuwni † [Youth is a part of insanity]. (TA.) In explanation of the phrase, in the Ḳur [lxxvii. 30], UilaI Zil-K ciI valaAvi XuEabK [Unto a shade, or shadow, having three parts, or divisions], it is said that the fire [of Hell], on the day of resurrection, will divide into three parts; and whenever they shall attempt to go forth to a place, it will repel them: by Zil- being here meant that the fire will form a covering; for [literally] there will be no Zil- in this case. (Th, L.)
And A piece such as is called ruWbap, with which a wooden bowl [or the like] is repaired. (Ṣ.)

Accord. to Lth, (T, TA,) XuEabu Ald-ahori means ‡ The changes, or vicissitudes, of time or fortune; (T, A, TA;) and he cites the saying of Dhu-r-Rummeh,
walaA tuqas-imu XaEobFA waAHidFA XuEabu
which he explains by saying, i. e. I thought that one thing, or state of things, would not be divided into many things, or states: [i. e. Nor did I think that the vicissitudes of fortune would divide one whole body of men into many parties:] but Az disapproves of this explanation, and says that XuEab here means Intentions, designs, or purposes: he says that the poet describes tribes assembled together in the [season called] rabiyE, who, when they desired to return to the watering-places, differed in their intentions, or designs; wherefore he says, Nor did I think that various intentions would divide [one whole body of men who before had] a consentient intention. (L, TA.)
[See also the pl. XiEaAbN below.]

XaEobaAnu, imperfectly decl., (Mṣb,) The name of a month [i. e. the eighth month of the Arabian year]: pl. XaEobaAnaAtN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XaEaAbiynu: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) so called from taXaE-aba “it became separated;” (Ḳ, TA;) because therein they used to separate, or disperse themselves, in search of water [when the months were regulated by the solar year; this month then corresponding partly to June and partly to July, as shown voce zamanN, q. v.]; or, as some say, for predatory expeditions [after having been restrained therefrom during the sacred month of Rejeb]; or, accord. to some, as Th says, from XaEaba “it appeared;” because of its appearance between the months of Rejeb and Ramadán. (TA.)
gazaAlu XaEobaAna A certain insect, (Ḳ,* TA,) a species of the junodab, or of the juxodub. (TA.)
XiEaAbN pl. of XiEobN: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) and of XuEobapN. (Ḳ, TA.)

Xagalato XiEaAbiI jadowaAIa is a prov., [expl. as] meaning The abundance of the food [that I have to procure for my family] has occupied me so as to divert me from giving to people: (Ṣ, TA:) [Z considers XEAb, here, as pl. of XuEobapN “a branch,” and as meaning duties, and relations: (Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 653:)] but El-Mundhiree says that XiEaAbiI is a mistranscription: the other reading is saEaAtiI, meaning “my expending upon my family.” (Meyd. [See also saEaApN, in art. sEw and sEI.])

XaEuwbu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) without the article Al, and imperfectly decl., (Mṣb,) and AlX-aEuwbu, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with the article, and perfectly decl., (Mṣb,) but several authors disallow this latter, accounting it wrong; (TA;) a name for Death; (Ṣ, A,* Mṣb, Ḳ;*) so called because it separates men: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) the former is a proper name: (Mṣb:) J says [in the Ṣ] that it is determinate, and does not admit the article Al: in the L, it is said that XaEuwbu and AlX-aEuwbu both signify as above; and that in either case it may be originally an epithet, being like the epithets qatuwl and Daruwb; and if so, the article in this case is as in AlEab-aAsu and AlHasanu and AlHerivu: and this opinion is confirmed by what is said of its derivation: but he who says XaEuwb, without the article, makes the word a pure substantive, and deprives it literally of the character of an epithet; wherefore the article is not necessarily attached to it, as it is not to Eab-aAs and Heriv; yet the essence of an epithet is in it still, as in the instance of jaAbiru bonu Hab-apa, a name for “bread,” so called because it reinvigorates the hungry; and as in waAsiT, [a certain town] so called, accord. to Sb, because midway between El-'Irák ['Irák el-'Ajam] and El-Basrah: thus in the L. (TA.) One says of a person when he has been at the point of death and then escaped, OaqaS-atohu XaEuwbu [Death became near to him]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., famaA zilotu waADiEFA rijoliI EalaI xad-ihi Hat-aI Oazarotuhu XaEuwba, i. e. [And I ceased not putting my foot upon his cheek until] I made death to visit him. (TA.)

XaEiybN A [leathern water-bag such as is called] mazaAdap [q. v.]; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also raAwiyapN and saTiyHapN: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ:) or one that has been repaired, or pieced: (TA:) or one that is made of two hides: (Ḳ:) or one that is made of two hides facing each other, without fiYaAm at their corners; fYAm in [the making of] mazaAyid being the taking of the hide and folding it, and then adding at the sides what will widen it: or one that is pieced (tufoOamu) with a third skin, between the two skins, that it may be rendered wider: or one that is made of two pieces joined together: (TA:) or one that is sewed (maxoruwzap, Ḳ and TA, in the CK maHozuwzap,) on both sides: (Ḳ:) called thus because one part is joined to another: (L, TA:) pl. XuEubN. (Ḳ,* TA.)
Also An old, worn-out skin for water or milk: (Ḳ:) because it is pieced, or repaired: (TA:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.)

And A camel's saddle; syn. raHolN: because it is joined, part to part: so in the saying of El-Marrár, describing a she-camel,
UicaA hiIa xar-ato xar-a mino Eano yamiynihaA
XaEiybN bihi UiHomaAmuhaA waluguwbuhaA
[When she falls down, or fell down, there falls down, or fell down, from her right side a saddle by reason of which was her fevered and jaded state]. (TA.)
And rajulN XaEiybN i. q. gariybN [A man who is a stranger,, &c.]. (AA, TA voce gariybN.)
XiEaAbapN The art, or craft, of repairing cracks [in wooden bowls, &c., by piecing them]. (TA.)
XuEuwbiI-N: see what next follows.

AlX-uEuwbiy-apu A sect which does not prefer, or exalt, the Arabs above the 'Ajam [or foreigners or Persians]: (Ṣ:) or a sect which prefers, or exalts, the 'Ajam above the Arabs: (Mṣb:) or those who despise the circumstances, or condition, of the Arabs; (A,* Ḳ;) one of whom is called XuEuwbiI-N↓; (A, Ḳ;) a rel. n. formed from the pl., (IM, Mṣb, TA,) XuEuwbN being predominantly applied to the 'Ajam; (IM, TA;) like OanoSaAriI-N [from AlOanoSaAru]. (IM, Mṣb,* TA.) In the phrase Uin-a rajulFA mina AlX-uEuwbi Oasolama, occurring in a trad., [and mentioned before, voce XaEobN,] AlXEwb may mean AlEajam; or it may be [used as] a pl. of AlX-uEuwbiI-u, like as Alyahuwdu and Almajuwsu are [used as] pls. of AlyahuwdiI-u and AlmajuwsiI-u. (IAth, TA.)
XaE-aAbN A repairer of cracks [in wooden bowls, &c., by piecing them]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.)
AlX-aAEibaAni The two shoulders: (Ḳ:) because wide apart: of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

hom.sense: OaXoEabu A goat, (Ṣ, TA,) and a gazelle, (A, TA,) wide, (A,) or very wide, (Ṣ, TA,) between the horns: (Ṣ, A, TA:) [and app., between the shoulders: (see XaEiba:)] fem. XaEobaMCu: (TA:) and pl. XuEobN. (Ṣ, A, TA.)

It is also the name of a certain very covetous man [who became proverbial for his covetousness, and hence it is used as an epithet]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so in the saying, laA takuno OaXoEaba fatatoEaba [Be not thou an Ash'ab, for in that case thou wilt become fatigued, or wearied, by thy endeavours]; (Ḳ;) a prov.: (TA:) and so in the prov., OaTomaEu mino OaXoEaba [More covetous than Ash'ab]. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: maXoEabN A way, road, or path, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [in an absolute sense, or] branching off from another. (Mṣb.) maXoEabu AlHaq-i means The way [of truth, or] that distinguishes between truth and falsity. (Ḳ.)

miXoEabN An instrument by means of which a crack in a [wooden bowl or some other] thing is repaired [by piecing it]; an instrument used for perforating, a drill, or the like, (Ḳ, TA,) by means of which the XaE-aAb repairs a vessel. (TA.)
qaSoEapN muXaE-abapN [A wooden bowl] repaired in several places [by closing up its cracks, or by piecing it]. (Ṣ.)
See also what follows.
maXoEuwbN applied to a camel, (Ḳ,) and muXaE-abapN↓ applied to a number of camels, (TA,) Marked with the brand called XiEob. (Ḳ, TA.)
Q. 1. XaEobaca, and its inf. n. XaEobacapN: see XaEowaca and XaEowacapN in art. XEc.
muXaEobicN: see muXaEowicN in art. XEc.

1. XaEiva, aor. _a {yaXoEavu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. XaEavN, (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) It (hair) was, or became, shaggy, or dishevelled, (A, Mgh,) and frouzy, or altered in odour, (Mgh,) in consequence of its being seldom dressed: (A, Mgh:) or it was, or became, defiled with dust, and matted, or compacted, in consequence of its being seldom anointed: (Mṣb:) or, accord. to El-Ghooree, it wanted oil, or ointment: (Ḥar p. 50:) and tXE-t↓ signifies [the same: or] it was, or became, matted, or compacted, (Ḳ, TA,) and dusty. (TA.) And the former verb, [and app. ↓the latter also,] It (the head) was, or became, dusty, not being renovated [by dressing or anointing], nor cleansed. (Mṣb.) Also the former verb, aor. as above, (L, Ḳ, and Ḥam p. 469,) inf. n. XaEavN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, and Ḥam) and XuEuwvapN, (L and Ḥam,) He was, or became, shaggy, or dishevelled, in the hair, (JM, PṢ,) and frouzy, or altered in odour, in consequence of its being seldom dressed: (JM:) or it signifies (or signifies also, JM) he had a dusty head, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, JM,) and plucked hair, unanointed; (L;) or he had matted, or compacted, and dusty, hair: (L, and Ḥam p. 469:) and in like manner tXE-v↓. (L.)

XaEavN, (Mṣb,) or taXaE-uvN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) [or each,] also signifies ‡ The being separated, or disunited, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) and spread out, (Mṣb,) and uncompacted, (TA,) like as is the head of the siwaAk [or tooth-stick, by its being bruised, or battered, or mangled by blows]. (Mṣb, TA.) You say, tXE-v↓ raOosu Als-iwaAki, (Mṣb, TA,) and Alwatidi, (A, TA,) ‡ The head of the tooth-stick, and of the wooden peg or stake, became disintegrated; or separated, disunited, or uncompacted, in its component parts [or its fibres; or rendered brushy; by its being bruised, or battered, or mangled by blows]. (TA.) And tXE-vwA↓ ‡ They [meaning men] became separated, disunited, dispersed, or scattered. (A.)

And XaEiva, aor. as above, (TḲ,) inf. n. XaEavN, said of the state of affairs, † It was, or became, dissolved, broken up, discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled. (Ṣ,* A,* Ḳ,* TA, TḲ. [In the Ṣ and A and Ḳ, this is placed as the first of all the meanings in this art.; and in the A, it is mentioned among the meanings that are proper, not tropical; but in my opinion it is tropical. See also XaEavN below.])

2. XaE-vhu, inf. n. taXoEiyvN, He rendered it (i. e. hair) [shaggy, or dishevelled, and frouzy: (see 1:) or] matte, or compacted, and dusty: or he rendered him [shaggy, or dishevelled, and frouzy, in his hair: or] matted, or compacted, and dusty, in his hair. (TA.)

taXoEiyvN also signifies † The separating, disuniting, dispersing, or scattering, a thing. (Ṣ.) And † The making to separated like as do rivers and branches. (L.) [Hence,] XE-v raOosa Als-iwaAki ‡ [He made the head of the tooth-stick to become disintegrated; or separated, disunited, or uncompacted, in its component parts or its fibres; or rendered it brushy; by bruising it, battering it, or mangling it by blows: see 1]. (A.)
XE-v Als-anaA ‡ He took of the straggling branches, or sprigs, of the senna, without pulling it up by the roots. (TA, from a trad.)
See also 5, in two places.

XE-v Aln-aAsu fiI AlT-aEoni Ealayohi † The people took, or began, to impugn his character, censure him, reproach him, or speak against him, by befouling his reputation (bitaXoEiyvi EiroDihi). (TA, from a trad.)

And XE-v minohu † He detracted from his reputation; syn. gaD-a minohu and tanaq-aSahu: from AlX-aEavu [as inf. n. of 1 in the last of the senses assigned to it above,] meaning AinotiXaAru AlOamori. (L.)
And also, inf. n. as above, † He repelled from him, or defended him: (Ḳ:) or he defended his reputation. (TA.) [Thus it has two contr. meanings.]

4. AXEv min-iI fulaAnN ‡ Such a one was angry by reason of me; syn. gaDiba. (A. [But this I have not found elsewhere; and I almost think that AXEv, in my copy of the A, may be a mistranscription for XE-v; and gaDiba, for gaD-a.])

hom.sense: 5: see 1, in six places.

taXaE-uvN also signifies † The act of taking; syn. OaxocN; (Ḳ, TA;) and so taXoEiyvN↓. (TA.) One says, tXE-vhu Ald-ahoru † Time, or fortune, took him. (TA.) And tXE-v maAlahu He took his property. (TḲ.)
And † The eating little of food; (Ḳ, TA;) and so taXoEiyvN↓: whence one says, XaE-avotu mina AlT-aEaAmi I ate little of the food. (TA.)

entry.sense: XaEovN: see the next paragraph.
XaEavN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (L, Mṣb, &c.)

[Hence,] lam-a Qll-ehu XaEavaka, (Ṣ,) and XaEavakumo, (A,) i. e. ‡ [May God rectify, or repair, and consolidate, what is discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled, of thy, and your, affairs; (see art. lm;) or] consolidate thy, and your, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled, state of affairs: (Ṣ, A:* [in the latter expressly distinguished as tropical:]) [and so XaEovaka↓, and XaEovakumo; perhaps by poetic license; for] Kaab Ibn-Málik El-Anṣáree says,
lam-a QloUilehu bihK XaEovFA waram-a bihi
Oumuwra Oum-atihi waAlOamoru munotaXiru
† [God rectified and consolidated, by him, a discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled, state of affairs, and repaired, by him, the affairs of his people, when the state of affairs was broken up]. (TA.) It is said in a trad., as a form of prayer, OasoOaluka raHomapF talum-u bihaA XaEaviI i. e. ‡ [I ask of Thee mercy] whereby thou shalt consolidate what is discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled, of my state of affairs. (TA.)

XaEivN, applied to hair, Shaggy, or dishevelled: (MA:) [or shaggy, or dishevelled, and frouzy, or altered in odour, in consequence of its being seldom dressed: (see 1, first sentence:)] or defiled with dust, and matted, or compacted, in consequence of its being seldom anointed. (Mṣb.) And in a similar sense applied to the head of a misowaAk [or tooth-stick, meaning † Disintegrated; or separated, disunited, or uncompacted, in its fibres; or rendered brushy; by its being bruised,, &c.; and so as applied to the head of a wooden peg or stake; as indicated by an explanation of its verb]. (MA.) [And in the TA it is applied to a plant, as meaning † Straggling.] See also OaXoEavu.
And † A man dirty in the body. (Mṣb.)
XaEavapN A place of [or in] the hair that is XaEiv [or shaggy, or dishevelled,, &c.]. (TA.)
XaEovaAnu, and XaEovaAnu Alr-aOosi: see what next follows.

OaXoEavu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and OaXoEavu Alr-aOosi, (Ḳ,) and XaEivN↓, (Mgh, TA,) [and XaEivu Alr-aOosi,] and XaEovaAnu↓, (TA,) and XaEovaAnu Alr-aOosi, (Ḳ,) applied to a man, (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) Having the hair shaggy, or dishevelled, and frouzy, or altered in odour, in consequence of its being seldom dressed: (Mgh:) or having the hair defiled with dust, and matted, or compacted, in consequence of its being seldom anointed: (Mṣb:) or having the head dusty, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) and the hair plucked, and unanointed: (TA:) fem. of the first XaEovaMCu, applied to a woman: (A, Mṣb:) and XuEovN [is its pl., and] is applied to horses, as meaning [having shaggy coats,] not curried: (Ṣ:)
or dusty by reason of long journeying. (Ḥam p. 130, [See and ex. from a poet, voce MyapN.]) The first [or each] is also applied to a head, as meaning Dusty, not renovated [by dressing or anointing], nor cleansed. (Mṣb.)

AlOaXoEavu ‡ The wooden peg or stake: (A, Ḳ, TA:) so in a verse of El-Kumeyt cited in the first paragraph of art. Hf: an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant: (TA:) so called because its head is disintegrated; or separated, disunited, or uncompacted, in its component parts [or its fibres; by its being battered by blows]. (A,* TA.)
And † What has dried up of the [barley-grass called] buhomaI: (Ḳ, TA:) [or] it is so called when its prickles have dried. (TA.)

Q. Q. 1. XaEowaca, (A, Mṣb,) inf. n. XaEowacapN, (A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He practised the art termed XaEowacap, expl. below: (A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) as also XaEobaca, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XaEobacapN: (A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) so some say. (Mṣb.) [See what here follows.]

XaEowacapN Legerdemain, or sleight-of-hand, (A, L, Ḳ,) and false miracles, (TA,) and fascinations, (Ḳ,) or fascination, (A, L,) or a kind of play, (Mṣb,) like siHor, (A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) making a thing to appear different from what it really is, (L, Ḳ,) or showing a man what has no real existence: (Mṣb:) or making what is false to assume the form of what is true: (TA:) as also XaEobacapN: (A, Mṣb:) vulgarly termed XaEobavapN. (TA.)
Also Quickness: or lightness, or agility, in any affair. (L.)
It is not a word of the language of the people of the desert. (Lth, L, Mṣb.)

XaEowaciI-N A messenger of princes or governors, (L, Ḳ,) who journeys on affairs of importance for them (L) upon post-horses or other beasts appointed for their conveyance: (L, Ḳ:) so called because of his quickness. (L.) It is not a word of the language of the people of the desert. (Lth, L.)
See also what follows.

muXaEowicN and muXaEowacN A man who practises the art termed XaEowacap; (L, Ḳ;) as also XaEowaciI-N↓: (TA in art. Ejb:) improperly called muXaEobicN, and surnamed Oabuw AlEajabi. (Eth-Tha'álibee, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. XaEara bihi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) and XaEura bihi, (Ḳ,) which latter is disallowed by some, but both are correct, though the former is the [more] chaste, (TA,) aor. _u {yaXoEuru}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XiEorN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and XaEorN (Ḳ, TA) and XaEarN, (TA, and so in the CK in the place of XaEorN,) but the first is the most common, (TA,) and XiEorapN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and XaEorapN and XuEorapN, (Ḳ,) of which last three the first is the most common, (TA,) and XiEoraI and XuEoraI (Ḳ) and XaEoraI (TA) and XuEuwrN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and XuEuwrapN, (Ḳ,) which is said to be the inf. n. of XaEura, (TA,) and maXoEuwrN and maXoEuwrapN (Lḥ, Ḳ) and maXoEuwraMCu, (Ḳ,) which is of extr. form, (TA,) He knew it; knew, or had knowledge, of it; was cognizant of it; or understood it; (Ṣ,* A, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) as also XaEara lahu: (Lḥ, TA:) or he knew the minute particulars of it: or he perceived it by means of [any of] the senses. (TA.) Lḥ mentions the phrase OaXoEuru fulaAnFA maA Eamilahu and OaXoEuru lifulaAnK maA Eamilahu [I know what such a one did or has done], and maA XaEarotu fulaAnFA maA Eamilahu [I knew not what such a one did], as on the authority of Ks, and says that they are forms of speech used by the Arabs. (TA.) [See also XiEorN, below.]

XaEara, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXoEuru}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XiEorN and XaEorN, (Ḳ, TA,) or XaEarN, (so accord. to the CK instead of XaEorN,) He said, or spoke, or gave utterance to, poetry; spoke in verse; poetized; or versified; syn. qaAla XiEorFA; [for poetry was always spoken by the Arabs in the classical times; and seldom written, if written at all, until after the life-time of the author;] (A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also XaEura: (Ḳ:) or the latter signifies he made good, or excellent, poetry or verses; (Ḳ, MF;) and this is the signification more commonly approved, as being more agreeable with analogy: (MF:) or the latter signifies he was, or became, a poet; (Ṣ;) as also XaEira, aor. _a {yaXoEaru}. (TA.) One says, XaEarotu lifulaAnK I said, or spoke, poetry,, &c., to such a one. (TṢ, O, TA.) And lawo XaEura binaqoSihi lamaA XaEara [Had he known his deficiency, he had not spoken poetry, or versified]. (A.)
XaAEarahu faXaEarahu: see 3.
XaEara as a trans. verb syn. with AXEr: see 4.
As syn. with XAEr: see 3.

XaEira, aor. _a {yaXoEaru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XaEarN, (TA,) His (a man's, TA) hair became abundant (Ḳ, TA) and long: (TA:) and said likewise of a goat, or other hairy animal, his hair became abundant. (TA.)
Also † He possessed slaves. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. XE-r as an intrans. verb: see 4:
and as a trans. verb also: see 4.

hom.sense: 3. XaAEarahu faXaEarahu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. of the latter _a, that is with fet-ḥ, (Ṣ, MF,) accord. to Ks, who holds it to be thus even in this case, where superiority is signified, on account of the faucial letter; or, accord. to most, _u, agreeably with the general rule; (MF;) He vied, or contended, with him in poetry, and he surpassed him therein. (Ṣ, Ḳ, MF.)

And XAErhu, (Ṣ,) and XAErhA, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and XaEarahaA↓, (A, Ḳ,) He slept with him, and with her, (naAwamahu, Ṣ, and naAma maEahaA, Mṣb, Ḳ, or DaAjaEahaA, A,) in one XiEaAr [or innermost garment]. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
[Reiske, as mentioned by Freytag, explains XAEr as signifying also Tractavit, prensavit, vellicavit: but without naming any authority.]

4. AXErhu He made him to know. (Ṣ.) You say, AXErhu biAlOamori and AlOamora, (Ḳ,) the latter of which is less usual than the former, because one says XaEara bihi but not XaEarahu, (MF,) He aquainted him with the affair; made him to know it. (Ḳ.) And OaXoEarotu Oamora falaAnK I made known the affair of such a one. (A.) And OaXoEarotu fulaAnFA I made such a one notorious for an evil deed or quality. (A.)

Also, (inf. n. UiXoEaArN, Mṣb,) He marked it, namely a beast destined for sacrifice at Mekkeh, (Ṣ,* Mgh, Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA,) by stabbing it in the right side of its hump so that blood flowed from it, (Ṣ,) or by making a slit in its skin, (Ḳ,) or by stabbing it (Ḳ, TA) in one side of its hump with a miboDaE or the like, (TA,) so that the blood appeared, (Ḳ, TA,) or by making an incision in its hump so that the blood flowed, (Mṣb,) in order that it might be known to be destined for sacrifice. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

[Hence, app.,] † He wounded him so as to cause blood to come. (TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting the assassination of ʼOthmán, OaXoEarahu miXoqaSFA † He wounded him so as to cause blood to come with a mXqS [q. v.]: (TA:) and in another trad., OaXoEira Oamiyru AlmuWominiyna † [The Prince of the Faithful was wounded so that blood came from him]. (Ṣ.)

And ‡ He pierced him with a spear so as to make the spearhead enter his inside: and AXErhu sinaAnFA ‡ he made the spear-head to enter into the midst of him: [but this is said to be] from AXErhu bihi “he made it to cleave to it.” (TA.) OaXoEira is said specially of a king, meaning He was slain. (A, TA.)
Also He made it to be a distinguishing sign: as when the performance of a religious service is made, or appointed, by God to be a sign [whereby his religion is distinguished]. (TA.)
And AXErwA They called, uttering their XiEaAr [whereby they might know one another]: or they appointed for themselves a XiEaAr in their journey. (Lḥ, Ḳ, TA. [See also 10.])
maA OaXoEarahu [How good, or excellent, a poet is he!]. (TA in art. xzI: see muxozK in that art.)

AXEr [from XaEorN or XaEarN signifying “hair”] It (a fœtus, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, in the belly of its mother, TA) had hair growing upon it; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also tXE-r↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and XE-r↓, inf. n. taXoEiyrN; and AstXEr↓. (Ḳ.)
And AXErt She (a camel) cast forth her fœtus with hair upon it. (Ḳṭr, Ḳ.)

And AXEr He lined a boot, (A, Ḳ,) and a jub-ap, (A,) and the miyvarap of a horse's saddle, and a qalanosuwap, and the like, (TA,) with hair; (A, Ḳ;) as also XaEara↓; (Lḥ, A, Ḳ;) and XE-r↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taXoEiyrN: (TA:) or, said of a myvrp, he covered it with hair. (A.)

And AXErhu He clad him with a XiEaAr [i. e. an innermost garment]. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) And He put on him a garment as a XiEaAr, i. e., next his body. (TA.) [Hence,] AXErhu fulaAnN Xar-FA ‡ Such a one involved him in evil. (Ṣ, A.) And AXErhu AlHub-u maraDFA † [Love involved him in disease]. (Ṣ.) And AXErhu bihi † He made it (i. e. anything) to cleave, or stick, to it, [like the XiEaAr to the body,] i. e., to another thing. (Ḳ.)

[And † It clave to him, or it, as the XiEaAr cleaves to the body. Hence,] AXErhu Alham-u ‡ [Anxiety clave to him as the XiEaAr cleaves to the body]. (A.) And AXEr Alham-u qalobiI ‡ Anxiety clave to my heart (Ḳ, TA) as the XiEaAr cleaves to the body. (TA.) And OaXoEara Alr-ajulu ham-FA ‡ The man clave to anxiety as the XiEaAr cleaves to the body. (Ṣ, TA. [In one of my copies of the Ṣ, OuXoEira, accord. to which reading, the phrase should be rendered The man was made to have anxiety cleaving to him, &c.])
AXEr Als-ik-iyna ‡ He put a XaEiyrap [q. v.] to the knife. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.*)

entry.sense: 5: see 4, in the latter half of the paragraph.
[6. tXAEr He affected, or pretended, to be a poet, not being such. (See its part. n., below.)]

hom.sense: 10. AstXErt Albaqarapu The cow uttered a cry to her young one, desiring to know its state. (A, TA.)
And AstXErwA They called, one to another, uttering the XiEaAr [by which they were mutually known], in war, or fight. (TA. [See also 4.])
AstXEr as syn. with AXEr and tXE-r: see 4, in the latter half of the paragraph.

Also, (A,) or AstXEr XiEaArFA, (Ḳ,) He put on, or clad himself with, a XEAr [i. e. an innermost garment]. (A, Ḳ.) [Hence,] AisotaXoEiro xaXoyapa Qll-ehi ‡ Make thou the fear of God to be XiEaAra qalobika [i. e. the thing next to thy heart]. (TA.) And AstXEr xawofFA ‡ He conceived in his mind fear. (Ṣ, A.*)

entry.sense: XaEorN and XaEarN↓, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ, but only the latter in my copies of the Ṣ and in the O,) two wellknown dial. vars., the like being common in cases of this kind, in which the medial radical letter is a faucial, (MF,) [but the latter I have found to be the more common,] Hair; i. e. what grows upon the body, that is not Suwf nor wabar; (Ḳ;) it is an appertenance of human beings and of other animals: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) [when spoken of as used in the fabrication of cloth for tents, &c., the meaning intended is goats' hair: (see 4 in art. bnI:)] of the masc. gender: (Mṣb, TA:) pl. (of the former, Mṣb) XuEuwrN and (of the latter, Mṣb) OaXoEaArN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and (of the latter also, TA) XiEaArN: (Ḳ, TA:) and OuXayoEaArN↓, properly dim. of OaXoEaArN, is used, accord. to Aboo-Ziyád, as dim. of XuEuwrN: (TA:) the n. un. is with p: (Ṣ, A,* Mṣb, Ḳ:) and this, i. e. XaEorapN [or XaEarapN], is also used metonymically as a pl. (Ḳ, TA.) One says, bayoniI wabayonaka AlmaAlu Xaq-u AlX-aEorapi and Xaq-u AlOubolumapi † [The property is, or shall be, equally divided between me and thee]. (TA.) And raOaI fulaAnN AlX-aEorapa Such a one saw, or has seen, hoariness, or white hairs, (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, A, TA,) upon his head. (TA.)
[The n. un.] XaEorapN is also used, metonymically, as meaning ‡ A daughter. (TA.)
And XaEarN↓ (Ḳ, and so accord. to the TA, but in the CK XuEorN↓,) signifies also ‡ Plants and trees; (Ḳ, TA;) as being likened to hair. (TA.)
And the same, (A, Ḳ, TA, but in the CK XuEorN↓,) ‡ Saffron (A, Ḳ) before it is pulverized. (A.)
XuEorN: see the next two preceding sentences.

XiEorN [an inf. n., (see 1, first sentence,) and used as a simple subst. signifying] Knowledge; cognizance: (Ḳ, TA:) or knowledge of the minute particulars of things: or perception by means of [any of] the senses. (TA.) One says, layota XiEoriI fulaAnFA maA SanaEa, (Ks, Lḥ, Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Ḳ,*) and layota XiEoriI lahu maA SanaEa, and layota XiEoriI Eanohu maA SanaEa, (Ks, Lḥ, Ḳ,*) i. e. Would that I knew what such a one did, or has done; (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* Mṣb,* TA;) for would that my knowledge were present at, or comprehending, what such a one did, or has done; the phrase being elliptical: (TA:) accord. to Sb, layota XiEoriI is for lyt XiEoratiI, the p being elided as in huwa Oabuw EucorihaA [for hw Abw EucoratihaA], (Ṣ, TA,) the elision of the p in this latter instance, as Sb says, being peculiar to the case of the words being preceded by Abw; [but see EucorapN;] and as in UiqaAmap when used as a prefixed noun; though layota XiEoratiI is not now known to have been heard. (TA.) One says also, layota XiEoriI maA kaAna Would that I knew what happened, or has happened. (A.)

The predominant signification of XiEorN is Poetry, or verse; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) because of its preeminence by reason of the measure and the rhyme; though every kind of knowledge is XiEorN: (Ḳ:) or because it relates the minute affairs of the Arabs, and the occult particulars of their secret affairs, and their facetiæ: (Er-Rághib, TA:) it is properly defined as language qualified by rhyme and measure intentionally; which last restriction excludes the like of the saying in the Ḳur [xciv. 3 and 4], Aal-aciI OanoqaDa Zahorako warafaEonaA laka cikorako, because this is not intentionally qualified by rhyme and measure: (KT; and the like is said in the Mṣb:) and sometimes a single verse is thus termed: (Akh, TA:) pl. OaXoEaArN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also † Falsehood; because of the many lies in poetry. (B, TA.)
XaEarN: see XaEorN, in two places.
XaEirN: see OaXoEaru.

[The fem.] XaEirapN signifies [particularly] A sheep or goat (XaApN) having hair growing between the two halves of its hoof, which in consequence bleed: or having an itching in its knees, (Ḳ, TA,) and therefore always scratching with them. (TA.)
XaEorapN and XaEarapN ns. un. of XaEorN [q. v.] and XaEarN.

XiEorapN The hair of the pubes; (T, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also XiEoraMC↓, [accord. to general analogy with tenween,] or XaEoraMC↓, [and if so, without tenween,] accord to different copies of the Ḳ; (TA;) of a man and of a woman; and of the hinder part of a woman: (T, Mṣb:) or the hair of the pubes of a woman, specially: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) and the pubes (EaAnap) [itself]: (Ḳ:) and the place of growth of the hair beneath the navel. (Ḳ,* TA.)
Also A portion of hair. (Ḳ,* TA.)

AlX-iEoraI [The star Sirius;] a certain bright star, also called Almirozamu; (TA; [but see this latter appellation;]) the star that rises [aurorally] after AljawozaMC [by which is here meant Gemini], in the time of intense heat, (Ṣ, TA,) and after AlhaqoEap [app. a mistranscription for AlhanoEap]: (TA:) [about the epoch of the Flight, it rose aurorally, in Central Arabia, on the 13th of July, O. Ṣ.: (see Aln-avorapu; and see also manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl:) on the periods of its rising at sunset, and setting aurorally, see dabarN and dabuwrN:] the Arabs say, UicaA TalaEati AlX-iEoraI jaEala SaAHibu Aln-axoli yaraI [When Sirius rises aurorally, the owner of the palm-trees begins to see what their fruit will be]: (TA:) there are two stars of this name; AlX-iEoraI AlEabuwru and AlX-iEoraI AlgumayoSaMCu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) together called AlX-iEorayaAni: the former is that [above mentioned] which is in [a mistake for “after”] AljawozaMC, and the latter is [Procyon,] in the ciraAE [by which is meant Alc-iraAEu AlmaqobuwDapu, not Alc-iraAEu AlmabosuwTapu]; (Ṣ;) and both together are called the two Sisters of Suheyl (suhayol [i. e. Canopus]): (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the former was worshipped by a portion of the Arabs; and hence God is said in the Ḳur-án to be Lord of AlX-iEoraI: (TA:) it is called AlEabuwr because of its having crossed the Milky Way; and the other is called AlgumayoSaMC because said by the Arabs to have wept after the former until it had foul thick matter in the corner of the eye: (Ḳ in art. gmS:) the former is also called AlX-iEoraI AlyamaAniy-apu [the Yemenian, or Southern, XErI]; and the latter, AlX-iEoraI AlX-aAmiy-apu [the Syrian, or Northern, XErI]. (Ḳzw.)
XaEoraMCu fem. of OaXoEaru [q. v.: under which head it is also mentioned either as a subst. or as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant].
See also XiEorapN.
XiEoraMC [app., if correct, with tenween]: see XiEorapN.

hom.sense: XiEoriI-N [Of, or relating to, poetry; poetical.]
[And also † False, or lying]. One says Oadil-apN XiEoriy-apN † False, or lying, evidences or arguments: because of the many lies in poetry. (B, TA.)

[And Of, or relating to, AlX-iEoraI, i. e. Sirius.] You say, raEayonaA XiEoriI-a AlmaraAEiI We pastured our cattle upon the herbage of which the growth was consequent upon the nawoC [i. e. the auroral rising or setting] of AlX-iEoraI [or Sirius]. (A.)

entry.sense: XaEariy-aAtN The young ones of the raxam [i. e. vultur percnopterus]. (Ḳ.)
XaEoraAnu: see OaXoEaru.

XaEoraAn [app. without tenween, being probably originally an epithet, also] signifies † The [shrub called] rimov, (Ḳ,) or a species thereof, (Tekmileh, TA,) green, inclining to dust-colour: (Tekmileh, Ḳ, TA:) or a species of [the kind of plants called] HamoD, dust-coloured: (TA:) or HamoD upon which hares feed, and in which they [make their forms, i. e.] lie, cleaving to the ground; it is like the large OuXonaAnap [here app. used as the n. un. of OuXonaAnN, i. e. kali, or glasswort], has slender twigs, and appears from afar black. (AḤn, TA.)

hom.sense: XuEoruwrN [A poetaster]: see XaAEirN.

Also, accord. to analogy, sing. of XaEaAriyru, which is † Syn. with XuEorN [as pl. of XaEoraMCu, q. v. voce OaXoEaru], meaning the flies that collect upon the sore on the back of a camel, and, when roused, disperse themselves from it. (TA.) [Hence the saying,] cahaba Alqawomu XaEaAriyra † The people dispersed themselves, or became dispersed: (Ṣ:) and cahabuwA XaEaAriyra biquc-aAna, (Ḳ,) or biqac-aAna, and biqic-aAna, (TA,) and biqinodaHorapa, (Ḳ,) and biqinocaHorapa, (TA,) † They went away in a state of dispersion, like flies: (Ḳ:)
XEAryr thus used being pl. of XuEoruwrN; (TA;) or having no sing. (Fr, Akh, Ṣ, TA.) And OaSobaHato XaEaAriyra biqirodaHomapa, and biqirocaHomapa, and biqinodaHorapa and biqid-aHorapa, and biqic-aHorapa, † They became beyond reach, or power. (Lḥ, TA.)

And the same pl. XaEaAriyru, having no sing., also signifies † A certain game (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) of children. (TA.) You say, laEibonaA AlX-aEaAriyra [We played at the game of AlXEAryr]: and hecaA laEibu AlX-aEaAriyri [This is the game of AlXEAryr]. (Ṣ.)
And † A sort of women's ornaments, like barley [-corns], made of gold and of silver, and worn upon the neck. (TA.)
And XuEoruwrapN [n. un. of XuEoruwrN] signifies A small qiv-aMC [or cucumber]: pl. XaEaAriyru [as above]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
XaEoraAniI-N: see OaXoEaru.
OaronabN XaEoraAniy-apN A hare that feeds upon the XaEoraAn [q. v.], and that [makes its form therein, i. e.] lies therein, cleaving to the ground. (AḤn, TA.)

entry.sense: XaEaArN ‡ Trees; (ISk, Er-Riyáshee, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also XiEaArN↓: (Aṣ, ISh, Ḳ:) or tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, trees; (T, Ḳ;) as also XiEaArN↓: (Sh, T, Ḳ:) or (TA, but in the Ḳ “and”) trees in land that is soft (Ḳ, TA) and depressed, between eminences, (TA,) where people alight, (Ḳ, TA,) such as is termed dahonaMC, and the like, (TA,) warming themselves thereby in winter, and shading themselves thereby in summer, as also maXoEarN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) or this last signifies any place in which are a xamar [or covert of trees,, &c.,] and [other] trees; and its pl. is maXaAEiru. (TA.) One says, OaroDN kaviyrapu AlX-aEaAri † A land abounding in trees [&c.]. (Ṣ.)
See also the next paragraph, latter half.

hom.sense: XiEaArN A sign of people in war, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and in a journey (Ḳ), &c., (TA,) i. e. (Mṣb) a call or cry, (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) by means of which to know one another: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb:) and the XiEaAr of soldiers is a sign that is set up in order that a man may thereby know his companions: (TA:) and XiEaAr signifies also the banners, or standards, of tribes. (TA in art. brm.) It is said in a trad. that the XiEaAr of the Prophet in war was yaA manoSuwru Oamito Oamito [O Manṣoor, (a proper name of a man, meaning “aided”, &c.,) kill thou, kill thou]. (TA.) And it is said that he appointed the XiEaAr of the refugees on the day of Bedr to be yAbaniI Eabodi Alr-aHomeni: and the XEAr of El-Khazraj, yA baniI Eabodi Qll-ehi: and that of El-Ows, yaA baniI Eubayodi Qll-ehi: and their XEAr on the day of El-Ahzáb, HemL laA yunoSaruwna. (Mgh.)
And Thunder; (Tekmileh, Ḳ;) as being a sign of rain. (TḲ.)

XiEaAru AlHaj-i means The religious rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage; and the signs thereof; (Ḳ;) and, (TA,) as also AlXaEaAYiru↓, (Ṣ,) the practices of the pilgrimage, and whatever is appointed as a sign of obedience to God; (Ṣ, Mṣb,* TA;) as the halting [at Mount 'Arafát], and the circuiting [around the Kaabeh], and the saEoI [or tripping to and fro between Es-Safà and El-Marweh], and the throwing [of the pebbles at Minè], and the sacrifice,, &c.; (TA;) and XaEiyrapN↓ and XiEaArapN↓ and maXoErN↓ signify the same as XiEaArN: (L:) XaEiyrapN↓ is the sing. of XaEaAYiru meaning as expl. above; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb;) or, as some say, the sing. is XiEaArapN↓: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or XaEiyrapN↓ and XiEaArapN↓, by some written XaEaArapN↓, and maXoEarN↓, signify a place [of the performance] of religious rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage; expl. in the Ḳ by muEoZamuhaA, which is a mistake for mawoDiEuhaA; (TA;) and maXaAEiru↓, places thereof: (Ṣ:) or XaEaAYiru↓ AlHaj-i signifies the maEaAlim [or characteristic practices] of the pilgrimage, to which God has invited, and the performance of which He has commanded; (Ḳ;) as also AlmaXaAEiru↓: (TA:) and XaEaAYiru↓ Qll-ehi, all those religious services which God has appointed to us as signs; as the halting [at Mount 'Arafát], and the saEoI [or tripping to and fro between Es-Safà and El-Marweh], and the sacrificing of victims: (Zj, TA:) or the rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage, and the places where those rites and ceremonies are performed; (Bḍ in v. 2 and xxii. 33;) among which places are Es-Safà and El-Marweh, they being thus expressly termed; (Ḳur ii. 153;) and so accord. to Fr in the Ḳur v. 2: (TA:) or the obligatory statutes or ordinances of God: (Bḍ in v. 2:) or the religion of God: (Bḍ in v. 2 and xxii. 33:) the camels or cows or bulls destined to be sacrificed at Mekkeh are also said in the Ḳur xxii. 37, to be mino XaEaAYiri Qll-ehi, i. e. of the signs of the religion of God: (Bḍ and Jel:) and [hence the sing.] XaEiyrapN↓ signifies [sometimes] a camel or cow or bull that is brought to Mekkeh for sacrifice; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) such as is marked in the manner expl. voce OaXoEara; (Mṣb;) and XaEaAYiru is its pl.; (Ḳ;) and is also pl. of XiEaArN: and the [festival called the] Eiyd is said to be a XiEaAr of the XaEaAYir [i. e. a sign of the signs of the religion] of El-Islám. (Mṣb.)
XiEaAru Ald-ami is said to mean ‡ The piece of rag: or ‡ the vulva: because each is a thing that indicates the existence of blood. (Mgh.)

Also The [innermost garment; or] garment that is next the body; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) the garment that is next the hair of the body, under the divaAr; as also XaEaArN↓; (Ḳ;) but this is strange: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaXoEirapN and [of mult.] XuEurN. (Ḳ.) [Hence,] one says, labisa XiEaAra Alham-i ‡ [He involved himself in anxiety]. (A.) And jaEala Alxawofa XiEaArahu † [He made fear to be as though it were his innermost garment], by closely cleaving to it. (TA in art. drE.) [Hence, also,] it is said in a prov., humu AlX-iEaAru duwna Ald-ivaAri, meaning † They are near in respect of love: and in a trad., relating to the Ansár, Oanotumu AlX-iEaAru waAln-aAsu Ald-ivaAru † Ye are the special and close friends [and the people in general are the less near in friendship]. (TA.)
Also A horse-cloth; a covering for a horse to protect him from the cold. (Ḳ.)

And † A thing with which wine [app. while in the vat] is protected, or preserved from injury: (L, Ḳ: [for Alxamoru, the reading in the CK, the author of the TḲ has read Alxumuru (and thus I find the word written in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ) or Alxumoru, pls. of AlximaAru; and Freytag has followed his example: but Alxamoru is the right reading, as is shown by what here follows:]) so in the saying of El-Akhtal,
fakaf-a Alr-iyHa waAlOanodaMCa EanohaA
mina Alz-arajuwni duwnahumaA AlX-iEaAru [evidently describing wine, and app. meaning † And the XEAr of the wine, (AlX-iEaAru mina Alz-arajuwna, i. e. XiEaAru Alz-arajuwni,) while yet in the vat, intervening as an obstacle to them, kept off the wind and the rains, or dews, or day-dews, from it, namely, the wine]. (L.)
See also XaEaArN, in two places.
Also Death. (O, Ḳ.)

Also An accompanying associate; syn. EaXiyrN muSaAHibN: on the authority of En-Nawawee: (Ḳ, TA:) said to be formed by transposition: but it may be from XaEarahaA meaning “he slept with her in one XiEaAr;” [see 3; and so originally signifying a person who sleeps with another in one innermost garment;] then applied to any special companion. (TA.)

entry.sense: XiEaArapN, and, as written by some, XaEaArapN: see XiEaArN, in four places.

hom.sense: XaEiyrapN A sign, or mark. (Mgh.)
See this word, and the pl. XaEaAYiru, voce XiEaArN, in seven places.
Also n. un. of XaEiyrN [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And [hence,] ‡ The iron [pin] that enters into the tang of a knife which is inserted into the handle, being a fastening to the handle: (Ṣ:) or a thing that is moulded of silver or of iron, in the form of a barley-corn, (Ḳ, TA,) entering into the tang of the blade which is inserted into the handle, (TA,) being a fastening to the handle of the blade. (Ḳ, TA.)
[And † A measure of length, defined in the law-books, &c. as equal to six mule's hairs placed side by side;] the sixth part of the UiSobaE [or digit]. (Mṣb voce miylN.)
[And † The weight of a barley-corn.]

entry.sense: [XuEayorapN dim. of XaEorapN and XaEarapN: pl. XuEayoraAtN.]

hom.sense: XuEayoraMCu [dim. of XaEoraMCu fem. of OaXoEaru.]
[Also] A kind of trees; (Ṣgh, Ḳ;) in the dial. of Hudheyl. (Ṣgh, TA.)
See also OaXoEaru, last signification but one.

entry.sense: XaEiyriI-N A seller of XaEiyr [or barley]: one does not use in this sense either of the more analogical forms of XaAEirN and XaE-aAr. (Sb, TA.)

XaAEirN A poet: (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) so called because of his intelligence; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) or because he knows what others know not: (T, TA:) accord. to Akh, it is a possessive epithet, like laAbinN and taAmirN: (Ṣ:) pl. XuEaraMCu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) deviating from analogy: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) Sb says that the measure faAEilN is likened in this case to faEiylN; and hence this pl.: (TA:) or, accord. to IKh, the pl. is of this form because the sing. is from XaEura, and therefore should by rule be of the measure faEiylN, like XariyfN [from Xarufa]; but were it so, it might be confounded with XaEiyr meaning the grain thus called, therefore they said XaAEirN, and regarded in the pl. the original form of the sing. (Mṣb.) A wonderful poet is called xinociycN: one next below him, XaAEirN: then, XawayoEirN↓ [the dim.]: (Yoo, Ḳ:) then, XuEoruwrN↓: and then, mataXaAEirN↓. (Ḳ.)
Also † A liar: because of the many lies in poetry: and so, accord. to some, in the Ḳur xxi. 5. (B, TA.)

XiEorN XaAEirN Excellent poetry: (Sb, T, Ḳ:) or known poetry: but the former explanation is the more correct. (TA.) One also says, sometimes, kalimapN XaAEirapN, [by klmp] meaning qaSiydapN: but generally in a phrase of this kind the two words are cognate, as in wayolN waAYilN and layolN laAYilN. (TA.)
XuwayoEirN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: OaXoEaru [More, and most, knowing or cognizant or understanding: see 1, first sentence.]
[And,] applied to a verse, (T,) or to a poem, (Ṣ,) More [and most] poetical. (T, Ṣ.*)

Also, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and XaEirN↓, (A, Ḳ,) and XaEoraAniI-N↓, (Ḳ,) which last (SM says) I have seen written XaEaraAniI-N, (TA,) A man having much hair upon his body: (Ṣ, A:) or having hair upon the whole of the body: (IAth, L voce Oajoradu [q. v.], in explanation of the first:) or having much and long hair (Ḳ, TA) upon the head and body: (TA:) and the first and second, a goat having much hair: fem. of the first XaEoraMCu: (TA:) and pl. of the first XaEorN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says OXoEavu OaXoEaru, meaning Having his head unshaven and not combed nor anointed. (TA.) And fulaAnN OaXoEaru Alr-aqabapi [lit. Such a one is hairy in the neck] is said of a man though he have not hair upon his neck, as meaning ‡ such a one is strong, like a lion. (A,* TA.)
[The fem.] XaEoraMCu also signifies A testicle, or scrotum, (xuSoyapN,) having much hair: (TA:) and the sawoCap [or pudendum]: thus used as a subst. (IAạr, TA in art. mET.) See also XiEorapN.
And A furred garment. (Th, Ḳ.)

And as an epithet, ‡ Evil, foul, or abominable: [as being likened to that which is shaggy, and therefore unseemly:] (Ḳ,* TA:) in the Ḳ, AlxaXinapu is erroneously put for Alxabiyvapu. (TA.) One says, daAhiyapN XaEoraMCu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and waboraMCu, (Ṣ, A,) and zab-aMCu, (TA in art. zb,) ‡ An evil, a foul, or an abominable, (TA,) or a severe, or great, (Ḳ,) calamity or misfortune: pl. XuEorN. (Ḳ, TA.) And one says to a man when he has said a thing that one blames or with which one finds fault, jiYota bihaA XaEoraMCa caAta wabarK ‡ [Thou hast said it as a foul, or an abominable, thing]. (Ṣ, A.*)

And OaXoEaru signifies also The hair that surrounds the solid hoof: (Ṣ:) or [the extremity, or border, of the pastern, next the solid hoof; i. e.] the extremity of the skin surrounding the solid hoof, (Ḳ, TA,) where the small hairs grow around it: (TA:) or the part between the hoof of a horse and the place where the hair of the pastern terminates: and the part of a camel's foot where the hair terminates: (TA:) pl. OaXaAEiru, (Ṣ, TA,) because it is [in this sense] a subst. (TA.)

Also The side of the vulva, or external portion of the female organs of generation: (Ḳ:) it is said that the OaXoEaraAni are the UisokataAni, which are the two sides [or labia majora] of the vulva of a woman: or the two parts next to the XuforaAni, which are the two borders of the UisokataAni: or the two parts between the UisokataAni and the XuforaAni: (L, TA:) or the two parts next to the XuforaAni, in the hair, particularly: (Zj, in his “Khalk el-Insán:”) the OaXaAEir of the HayaMC [or vulva of a camel, &c.] are the parts where the hair terminates: (TA:) and the OaXaAEir of a she-camel are the sides of the vulva. (Ṣ, L, TA.)
And A thing that comes forth from [between] the two halves of the hoof of a sheep or goat, resembling a vuWoluwl [or wart]; (Lḥ, Ḳ;) for which it is cauterized. (Lḥ, TA.)
And Flesh coming forth beneath the nail: pl. XuEurN, (Ḳ, TA,) with two dammehs, (TA,) or XuEorN. (So in the CK.)

And [the fem.] XaEoraMCu also signifies ‡ Land (OaroD) containing, or having, trees: or abounding in trees: (A, Ḳ:) [and so, app., XaEoraAnu↓; for] there is a mountain in [the province of] El-Mowsil called XaEoraAnu, said by AA to be thus called because of the abundance of its trees: (Ṣ:) or XaEoraMCu signifies many trees: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ:) or i. q. OajamapN [i. e. a thicket, wood, or forest;, &c.]: (TA:) and a meadow (rawoDapN, AḤn, A, Ḳ, TA) having its upper part covered with trees, (AḤn, Ḳ * TA,) or abounding in trees, (TA,) or abounding in herbage: (A:) and a tract of sand (ramolapN) producing [the plant called] naSiI- (Ṣgh, L, Ḳ) and the like. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

And † A certain tree of the kind called HamoD, (Ḳ, TA,) not having leaves, but having [what are termed] hadab [q. v.], very eagerly desired by the camels, and that puts forth strong twigs or branches; mentioned in the L on the authority of AḤn, and by Ṣgh on the authority of Aboo-Ziyád; and the latter adds that it has firewood. (TA.)

And † A certain fruit: (AḤn, TA:) a species of peach: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) sing. and pl. the same: (AḤn, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a single peach: (IḲṭṭ, MF:) or AlOaXoEaru is a name of the peach, and the pl. is XuEorN. (Mṭr, TA.)

Also † A kind of fly, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) said to be that which has a sting, (Ṣ,) blue, or red, that alights upon camels and asses and dogs; (Ḳ;) as also XuEayoraMCu↓: (TA:) a kind of fly that stings the ass, so that he goes round: AḤn says that it is of two species, that of the dog and that of the camel: that of the dog is well known, inclines to slenderness and redness, and touches nothing but the dog: that of the camel inclines to yellowness, is larger than that of the dog, has wings, and is downy under the wings: sometimes it is in such numbers that the owners of the camels cannot milk in the day-time nor ride any of them; so that they leave doing this until night: it stings the camel in the soft parts of the udder and around them, and beneath the tail and the belly and the armpits; and they do not protect the animal from it save by tar: it flies over the camels so that one hears it to make a humming, or buzzing, sound. (TA. [See also XuEoruwrN, under which its pl. XuEorN is mentioned.])
And [hence, perhaps, as this kind of fly is seen in swarms,] † A multitude of men. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: OuXayoEaArN: see XaEorN.

hom.sense: maXoEarN i. q. maEolamN [meaning A place where a thing is known to be]. (TA.)
And hence, A place of the performance of religious services. (TA.) See this word, and its pl. maXaAEiru, voce XiEaArN, in four places.
[The pl.] AlmaXaAEiru also signifies The five senses; (Ṣ,* A,* TA;) the hearing, the sight, the smell, the taste, and the touch. (Ṣ and Mṣb in art. Hs.)
See also XaEaArN.

entry.sense: diyapu AlmuXoEarapi The bloodwit that is exacted for killing kings: it is a thousand camels. (A, TA. [See 4.])
mutaXaAEirN One who affects, or pretends, to be a poet, but is not. (Ṣ,* L,* Ḳ,* TA.) See XaAEirN.

1. XaEafa, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXoEafu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XaEafN, though it is implied in the Ḳ, by its being said that the verb is like manaEa, that it is XaEofN, (TA,) He smeared, anointed, or overspread, a camel [suffering from the mange, or scab], with tar, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, and Bḍ in xii. 30,) and burned him by so doing. (Bḍ ibid.) Imra-el-Ḳeys says,
liyaqotulaniI waqado XaEafotu fuWaAdahaA
kamaA XaEafa AlmahonuwoCapa Alr-ajulu AlT-aAliI
[That he should slay me, I having overspread her heart with love of me, like as the man anointing overspreads her (meaning the camel) that is smeared with tar]: but it is also related otherwise, i. e. qaTarotu fuWaAdahaA kamaA qaTara: (O, TA:) Aboo-ʼAlee El-Ḳálee says that she [the camel] that is smeared with tar experiences, by reason of the tar, a pleasurable sensation with a burning. (TA.)

Hence, [as indicated above,] qado XaEafahaA Hub-FA [He has overspread and burned her heart with love]; as some read in the Ḳur xii. 30; others reading XagafahaA: (Bḍ:) [or he has burned her heart with love; for] XaEafahu AlHub-u means love burned his heart: (Ṣ:) there are two readings of the words of the Ḳur above; (O, Ḳ;) [as well as two other readings mentioned in art. Xgf;] qado XaEafahaA Hub-FA, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) one, a reading of El-Ḥasan (Ṣ, O) and others; meaning [as above: or], accord. to AZ, he has diseased her heart with love, (Ṣ,* O,) and melted it: (O:)
or, accord. to El-Ḥasan, he has penetrated into her with love: (Ṣ:) the other reading is qado XaEifahaA Hub-FA, (O, Ḳ,) meaning he has become attached to her with love, and loved her excessively: (O:) [but it is also said that] XaEafaniI Hub-uhu means The love of him overspread my heart from above; (O, Ḳ;) from XaEafapN signifying the “head” of the heart, “at the place of suspension of [or from] the niyaAT;” (O,* Ḳ;) and in like manner, XuEifotu bihi and biHub-ihi, (O, and so in the CK,) or XaEifotu: (so in other copies of the Ḳ, in which, and in the CK, the verb in this case is said to be like fariHa: [but this I regard as a mistake:]) and XaEafa Alqaloba He, or it, struck, or smote, the XaEafap, or uppermost part, of the heart: (Ḥam p. 545:) Az, however, says, I know not any one that has assigned to the heart a XaEafap, except Lth; and vehement love takes possession of the core (sawaAd) of the heart; not of its extremity: [but] accord. to Fr, XuEifa bifulaAnK, like EuniIa, means The love of such a one rose to the highest places of his heart: others say that AlXEf [app. AlX-aEafu] signifies the being frightened, and disquieted, like the beast when it is frightened; and that the Arabs transferred its attribution from beasts to human beings: (TA:) Abu-l-ʼAlà says that AlX-aEafu signifies a thing's falling into the heart: (IB, TA:) one says also, XaEafahu AlmaraDu Disease melted him: (TA:) and accord. to AZ, XuEifa bikacaA means He became diseased by such a thing. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: XaEafN: see XaEafapN, in two places.

Also The upper, or uppermost, part of the hump of the camel: (O, Ḳ:) Lth says that it is like the heads of truffles, and the three stones upon which the cooking-pot is placed, that are round in their upper, or uppermost, parts. (O.)
Also Vehemence of love: (L:) [or simply love: for] one says, OaloqaI Ealayohi XaEafahu, meaning [He cast] his love [upon him, or it]; as also Xagafahu. (TA.)

entry.sense: XaEafapN The head [or summit] of a mountain: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and the upper, or uppermost, part of anything: (Ḥam pp. 130 and 545:) pl. XaEafN↓ [or rather this is a coll. gen. n., and accord. to Freytag it is used as a sing., in the two senses above mentioned, in the Deewán of Jereer,] and [the pl. is] XuEuwfN and XiEaAfN and XaEafaAtN: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and XaEafN↓ is also expl. as signifying an elevated part of the earth or ground. (TA.)

Also A lock of hair (xuSolapN) upon the head, (Ḳ,) or upon the upper, or uppermost, part of the head. (O, TA.) And XiEaAfN (its pl., TA) signifies The hair of the head: so in the phrase rajulN Suhobu AlX-iEaAfi [A man whose hair of the head is red, or red in the outer part and black beneath, or of a red colour tinged over with blackness,, &c.]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And The [pendent lock of hair termed] cuWaAbap of a boy, or young man. (Ṣ.)
And XaEafapu Alqalobi signifies The head of the heart, at the place of suspension of [or from] the niyaAT [q. v.]. (O, TA. [But see, in the first paragraph, what Az says respecting this meaning.])
XaEaAfN, like saHaAbN, Love's making away with the heart. (TA.)
XuEaAfN Insanity, or madness. (O, Ḳ.)

[XuEayofapN dim. of XaEafapN: pl. XuEayofaAtN.] One says, maA EalaI raOosihi Uil-aA XuEayofaAtN There is not upon his head aught save some small hairs of the [pendent lock of hair termed] cuWaAbap. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

maXoEuwfN [Burned in the heart by love: (see 1:) or] diseased [therein]: (AZ, Ṣ:) or struck, or smitten, in the XaEafap of his heart by love, or by fright, or by insanity, or madness. (O, Ḳ.) Insane, or mad. (O, Ḳ.) Bereft of his heart. (TA.) [See also maXoguwfN.]

hom.sense: 1. XaEalati Aln-aAru: see 8.
And XaEala fiyhi, aor. _a {yaXoEalu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XaEolN, (TA,) † He went far in it; (Ḳ;) namely, an affair. (TḲ.)
XaEala Aln-aAra:
and AlHaroba: see 4.

XaEila, aor. _a {yaXoEalu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XaEalN, (TA,) He (a horse) had the whiteness termed XaEalN and XuEolapN [expl. below]; (Ḳ;) as also AXEAl-↓, (Mgh, Ḳ, TA,) which occurs in poetry with the A made movent, i. e. AiXoEaOal-a↓, inf. n. AiXoEiylaAlN; (TA; [in my copy of the Mgh written AiXoEilaAl;]) or AXEl-↓, (Ṣ,) or this last also, (TA,) inf. n. AiXEilaAlN. (Ṣ, TA.) Among the faults in the “Khizánet el-Fik-h” is AlUiXoEaAlu↓, [expl. as meaning The having] a whiteness of the OaXofaAr [or edges of the eyelids]. (Mgh.)

entry.sense: 2. XE-l Aln-aAra: see what next follows {4}.

hom.sense: 4. AXEl Aln-aAra; (AZ, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and XaEalahaA↓, (AZ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXoEalu}, inf. n. XaEolN; (TA;) and [in an intensive sense] XE-lhA↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taXoEiylN; (TA;) He kindled the fire; or made it to burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame; syn. OaDoramahaA, (Ṣ, O, TA,) or OawoqadahaA, (Mṣb, by implication,) or OalohayahaA; (Ḳ, TA;) fiI AlHaTabi [in the firewood]. (Ṣ, O, TA.)

[Hence,] one says also, OaXoEalotu AlHaroba † [I kindled war, or the war; or made it to burn fiercely, or to rage]; and XaEalotuhaA↓; mentioned by Abu-l-ʼAlà. (Ḥam p. 715.) ʼAmr Ibn-El-Itnábeh says,
layosuwA biOanokaAsK walaA miylK UicaA
maA AlHarobu Xub-ato OaXoEaluwA biAlX-aAEili↓ , (Ṣ, O, and Ḥam ubi suprà,) † They are not persons in whom is no good, nor such as are not firm on their horses: [when war is kindled,] they make to burn fiercely, and excite, that which is slightly burning: such may be the meaning; for it may be that the b in bAlXAEl is pleonastically inserted, and AlXAEl may mean as above: or bAlXAEl may mean by him who makes it to burn fiercely, [as is implied in the Ṣ and O,] or by that which does so. (Ḥam.)
And OaXoEalotuhu gaDabFA (O, TA, and Ḥam p. 194) ‡ I excited him, or inflamed him, with anger. (TA.)

And AXEl Uibilahu biAlqaTiraAni † He smeared his camels much with tar; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) [which has a burning effect;] smearing them generally, and not merely the scattered scabs exclusively of the other parts of the body. (TA.)

And AXEl Alxayola fiI AlgaArapi ‡ He spread, or dispersed, the horsemen in the hostile, or predatory, incursion: (O, Ḳ, TA:) and [in like manner] one says AXElwA AlgaArapa † [They spread, or dispersed, themselves, or their horsemen, in the hostile, or predatory, incursion]. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. XEw.) And OaXoEalotu jamoEahumo † I dispersed or scattered, their congregation. (O, TA.) And AXEl AlUibila † He dispersed the camels. (Lḥ, Ḳ, TA.)
And AXEl Als-aqoIa † He made [the water-ing or] the water [of the irrigation] abundant. (IAạr, Ḳ, TA.)
OaXoEalati AlgaArapu † The horsemen making a hostile, or predatory, incursion became dispersed, or dispersed themselves. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

AXElt AlT-aEonapu † The spear-wound, or the like, emitted its blood in a scattered state. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.) And AXElt Alqirobapu, and AlmazaAdapu, † The water-skin, and the leathern water-bag, shed its water in a scattered state. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And AXElt AlEayonu † The eye shed its tears copiously. (O, Ḳ.)
See also 1, last sentence.

entry.sense: 5: see what next follows {8}.

8. AXtElt Aln-aAru; (Lḥ, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) and XaEalat↓, aor. _a {yaXoEalu}; (Mṣb;) and [in an intensive sense] tXE-lt↓; (Ḳ, TA;) The fire became kindled; or it burned up, burned brightly or fiercely, blazed, or flamed; syn. taOaj-ajat, (Lḥ, TA,) or AiDoTaramat, (Ṣ, O, TA,) or tawaq-adat, (Mṣb,) and Ailotahabat; (Ḳ,* TA;) fiI AlHaTabi [in the firewood]. (Lḥ, TA.)
Hence, AiXotaEala gaDabFA ‡ He became excited, or inflamed, with anger: (TA:) or he became filled with wrath. (Mṣb.)

Hence also, AXtEl AlX-ayobu fiI Alr-aOosi ‡ Whiteness of the hair became glistening in the head; including the hair of the beard. (TA.) And AXtEl Alr-aOosa XayobFA [in the Ḳur xix. 3, expl. in art. Xyb]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
9: see 1.
AXEAl- raOosuhu, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. AiXoEiylaAlN, (TA,) His hair became separated, or loosened, and ruffled, or bristling up. (O, Ḳ.)
Q. Q. 4. AiXoEaOal-a: see 1.
XaEolN † A man light, agile, or active, and clever, ingenious, acute, or sharp: (O, Ḳ:) and so maEolN. (O, TA.)

XaEalN [inf. n. of XaEila (q. v.)] and XuEolapN↓ [properly a subst. as distinguished from an inf. n.] † A whiteness in the tail of a horse, and the forelock, and the qacaAl [or place where the EicaAr, i. e. each of the two cheek-straps of the headstall, is tied, behind the forelock]: (Ḳ:) or in some part of the forelock; or, as some say, in a side thereof:
and sometimes in the qcAl: but mostly in the tail: (TA:) or the former signifies a whiteness in the extremity of the tail of a horse: or, accord. to Lth, a whiteness in the forelock and the tail: or, as some say, in the head and the forelock: [or the quality of having such whiteness: for it is added that] the subst. [app. signifying such whiteness itself] is XuEolapN↓: (Mgh:) or the former, a whiteness in the side of the tail: [or,] accord. to Aṣ, XuEolapN↓ is a term applied to a whiteness of the tail when it intermixes with any other colour; and the horse is said to be bay-inu AlX-aEali [i. e. one that exhibits the quality of having such whiteness]. (Ṣ.)

XuEolapN A firebrand; a piece of wood in which fire is kindled; (Az, Ḳ,* TA;) like jicowapN and qayasN and XihaAbN: (Az, TA:) [this is what is meant by its being said that] what is termed XuEolapN mino naArK [the only indication of the meaning in the Ṣ and O] is well known: (Mṣb:) pl. XuEalN; (Ṣ, O, TA;) erroneously said in the Ḳ to be like kutubN. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, fulaAnN XuEolapu naArK † [Such a one is a firebrand]. (Er-Rághib, TA voce cakaMCN, q. v.)

And [A lighted wick: so in the present day: (see also XaEiylapN:) or] the burnt [or lighted] extremity of a wick. (Ṣ voce qiraATN. [And the same meaning is intended there in the Ḳ; and also in the TA voce jicowapN.])
And The flame of fire; as also XuEoluwlN↓. (Ḳ,* TA. [In the CK XuEuwl; as though it were a second pl. of XuEolapN.])
And XuEolapu, (O, Ḳ, TA,) without Al, (Ḳ, TA,) is the name of A mare of Keys Ibn-Sebáa; (O, Ḳ, TA;) likened to the kindling of fire, because of her swiftness. (TA.)
See also XaEalN, in three places.

hom.sense: XuEoluwlN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Also A party, division, sect, or distinct body or class, of men, &c. (TA.) [See XaEaAliylu, below.]

entry.sense: XaEiylN The like of stars, at the bottom of a cooking-pot; and in tinder, or burnt rag into which fire has fallen. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, TA.)
See the next paragraph.
And see also OaXoEalu.

XaEiylapN [A lighted wick; i. e.] a wick in which is fire; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) a wick soaked with oil or grease, in which is fire, used for giving light, and not thus called unless kindled with fire: (TA: [see also XuEolapN:]) or the fire that is kindled in a wick: (Ḳ:) pl. XuEulN, like as SuHufN is pl. of SaHiyfapN; (T, Ṣ, O, TA;) in the Ḳ erroneously said to be XaEiylN↓ [which, however, may be correct as a coll. gen. n.]. (TA.)

XaEaAliylu [a pl., of which the sing. is app. XuEoluwlN, q. v.; Things, and persons, scattered, or dispersed]. Aboo-Wejzeh says,
Hat-aI UicaA maA danato minohu sawaAbiquhaA
walil-ugaAmi biEiTofayohi XaEaAliylu
[Until, or until when, those of them that outstripped approached him, and there were scattered portions of foam upon his two sides]. (TA.) And one says, cahabuwA XaEaAliyla, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) like XaEaAriyra, i. e., (Ṣ, O,) [They went away] in a state of dispersion; (Ḳ;) [or] they dispersed themselves, or became dispersed. (Ṣ, O.)

XaAEilN as used in a verse cited above (see 4) [may be the part. n. of the intrans. verb in the phrase XaEalati Aln-aAru, and thus] may mean [Burning, &c.; or] slightly burning: (Ḥam p. 715:) [or] it signifies cuw UiXoEaAlK [having the quality of kindling,, &c.; being said to be a possessive epithet], (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) like taAmirN and laAbinN, having no verb: (Ṣ, O: [but see 4, first sentence:]) or it may be for cuw XaEolK, meaning muXoEilN. (Ḥam ubi suprà. [See, again, 4.])
See also the next paragraph.
OaXoEalu A horse having the whiteness termed XuEolapN (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ) or XaEalN [q. v.]; (Mgh, Ḳ;) as also XaEiylN↓ and XaAEilN↓: (O, Ḳ:) fem. of the first XaEolaMCu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And gur-apN XaEolaMCu [A blaze on a horse's forehead or face] taking in, i. e. including, one of the eyes. (Mgh, TA.)
maXoEalN A [lamp of the kind called] qinodiyli [q. v.]. (Ḳ.)
See also maXoEalapN.

muXoEalN [pass. part. n. of 4, q. v.]. One says naArN muXoEalapN [A fire kindled,, &c.; or] burning up, burning brightly or fiercely, blazing, or flaming. (Lḥ, TA.) And jaMCa fulAanN kaAlHariyqi AlmuXoEali i. e. [Such a one came like the fire that is] kindled,, &c. (Ṣ, O.) See also the next paragraph.

jaraAdN muXEilN ‡ Locusts that are numerous, (Ḳ, TA,) spreading, (Ṣ, O,) in a state of dispersion, (Ḳ,) running in every direction. (Ṣ, O.) One says, (Ṣ, O, TA,) of an army, (TA,) jaAWuwA kaAljaraAdi AlmuXoEili (Ṣ, O, TA) ‡ They came [like locusts numerous and spreading,, &c.,] coming forth from every direction: thus the last word is written accord. to Az [and J] and Ṣgh; and thus, and also AlmuXoEali↓, accord. to Z. (TA.) And katiybapN muXoEilapN † [A military force] spreading, or in a state of dispersion. (Ṣ, O.)
