Xufiha, [said of a water, † It had many lips of drinkers applied to it; i. e. it had many drinkers: (see its part. n.:) and] said of food, ‡ It had many eaters: (Ḳ, TA:) or [as a consequence thereof] it became little in quantity. (TA.)
And [hence], said of property, † It had many seekers. (Ḳ.)

And, said of a man, † He had many askers, or beggars, (Ḳ, TA,) so that they consumed what he had, or possessed. (TA.) [Or † He was importuned by begging, so that what he had, or possessed, was consumed: as pass. of what next follows.]

Xafahahu † He importuned him by begging, so that he consumed what he had, or possessed. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And one says, kaAda AlEiyaAlu yaXofahuwna maAliI ‡ The family, or household, almost consumed my property. (Ḳ,* TA.)

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. XafohN, (Ṣ,) i. q. Xagala. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, XafahaniI Eano kacaA † He, or it, occupied me so as to divert me from such a thing; syn. XagalaniI. (Ṣ.) And naHonu naXofahu Ealayoka AlmarotaEa, and AlmaMCa, meaning † We occupy the place of pasturage so as to keep it from thee, and the water, (naXogaluhu Eanoka,) i. e. it is sufficient for us without being more than sufficient. (Ṣ, TA.) And Xufiha Eanoka maA EinodanaA † What we had was employed so as to be kept from thee; syn. Xugila Eanoka. (JK.)

IAar mentions the phrase Xafahotu naSiybiI, with fet-ḥ, without explaining it; but Th says that it is sfht, [i. e. safihotu, with s, and with kesr to the f,] meaning “I forgot [my share, or portion].” (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. XAfhhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muXaAfahapN, (TA,) He put his lip (Xafatahu) near to his [another's] lip. (Ḳ, TA.) And kal-amahu muXaAfahapF (Mṣb, TA) and muXaAfaApF (Mṣb) He spoke to him putting his lip near to his lip: (TA:) [or mouth to mouth; for,] accord. to J, (TA,) muXaAfahapN signifies the talking with another mouth to mouth: (Ṣ, TA:) but the usage of the inf. n. of a verb different from that which it is thus made to qualify is, as Sb says, restricted to instances that have been heard: the phrase kal-amahu mufaAwahapF [has not been heard, and therefore] is not allowable. (TA.)
[Hence,] XAfh Albalada, and AlOamora, ‡ He was, or became, or drew, near to the town, or country, and the affair. (A, Ḳ, TA.)

XafapN, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) also pronounced XifapN↓, (Ḳ,) is a word of which the third, i. e. the final, radical letter is elided; (T, Mṣb;) and accord. to some, (Mṣb,) this letter is h, (T, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) so accord. to all of the Basrees, (TA,) the word being originally Xfhp↓, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) i. e. XafahapN, (so in copies of the Ṣ,) or XafohapN, like kalobahN and sajodapN, (Mṣb,) because it has the former of the dims. mentioned below, and the first of the pls. mentioned below, with h, (Ṣ, Mṣb,*) and it is sometimes pronounced Xfhp; (T, TA;) or, as some assert, the deficient letter is w, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) the word being originally XafowapN, like XahowapN, (Mṣb,) because it has the last of the pls. mentioned below, (Ṣ, [but omitted in one of my copies,] and Mṣb,*) and the latter of the two dims. mentioned below; (Mṣb;) both of which assertions are stated on the authority of Kh; (IF, Mṣb;) [The lip of a human being;] XafataA AlUinosaAni meaning the two covers of the mouth of the human being: (Ḳ:) it is [properly] only of a human being: (Mṣb:) but it is sometimes, metaphorically, of the horse: and in like manner, of the dalow [or leathern bucket] as used by AʼObeyd; but ISd has expressed a doubt whether he had heard this from the Arabs: (TA:) the pl. is XifaAhN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and XafahaAtN (Lth, Mṣb, TA) and XafawaAtN, (Lth, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the second of which is said by Lth to be more agreeable with analogy than the third, though the third is more common, as being likened to sanawaAtN [pl. of sanapN]: (Az, Mṣb, TA:) and Ks mentions the phrase, Uin-ahu lagaliyZu AlXifaAhi [as meaning Verily he is thick in the lip], as though the term XafapN applied to every portion of the Xafap: (TA:) the dim. is Xufayohapu↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb) and Xufay-apN. (Mṣb.)
[Hence,] humo Oaholu AlX-afapi † They are those who have the right of drinking with their lips (biXifaAhihimo) and of watering their beasts. (Mgh.)

And binotu XafapK ‡ A word; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) as also caAtu XafapK. (TA.) One says, maA kal-amotuhu bibinoti XafapK † I spoke not to him a word: (Ṣ:) or maA kal-amaniIbinota XafapK † He spoke not to me a word: (TA:) and maA samiEotu minohu binota XafapK † I heard not from him a word: (Mṣb:) and maA kal-amotu fulaAnFA caAta XafapK † I spoke not to such a one a word. (AZ, T voce cuw.)

And fulaAnN xafiyfu AlX-afapi ‡ Such a one is a person who asks, or begs, little of people: (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA:) and also, ‡ importunate, (Ḳ, TA,) one who asks, or begs, much of people: (TA:) thus having two contr. meanings. (Ḳ.)

And lahu fiI Aln-aAsi XafapN † He has praise, or commendation, among the people: (Ṣ:) and lahu fiynaA XafapN HasanapN ‡ He has a good report, or reputation, among us. (A, Ḳ, TA.) And Uin-a Xafapa Aln-aAsi Ealayoka laHasanapN ‡ Verily the people's speaking of thee is good. (Lḥ, TA.) And maA OaHosana Xafapa Aln-aAsi Ealayoka ‡ How good is the people's speaking of thee! (Ḳ, TA.)
See also XafFA, in art. Xfw and XfI.
XifapN, and see the next preceding paragraph.
XafahapN or XafohapN: and see the next preceding paragraph.

XafahiI-N and XafiI-N are both allowable as rel. ns. of XafapN [i. e. as meaning Labial: and so, accord. to some, is XafawiI-N]. (Ṣ.) AlHuruwfu AlX-afahiy-apu (Kh, T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and AlX-afawiy-apu, (Kh, T, Mṣb,) or the latter is not allowable, (Ṣ,) [i. e. The labial letters,] are b and f and m: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) [or, accord. to Lumsden (Ar. Gr. p. 28), b and m and w: and, it seems, accord. to some, (see De Sacy's Gr. Ar. sec. ed. i. 27,) j and X and D, which is strange:] so called because their place of utterance is from the Xafap, without any action of the tongue. (T, TA.)
XufayohapN: dim. of XafapN, q. v.
XufaAhiI-N A man (Ṣ, Mgh) large [in some copies of the Ṣ thick] in the XafataAni [or lips]; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) as also OaXofahu↓. (Mgh. [But see this latter below.])
XaAfihN Thirsty, (Ḳ, TA,) not finding water enough to moisten his lip: like saAfihN, mentioned in art. sfh. (TA.)
OaXofahu: see XufaAhiI-N.
[Accord. to some,] OaXofaI signifies A man whose lips do not close together: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) but there is no proof of its correctness: (Ṣ:) the fem. in this sense is XafoyaMCu. (TA in art. XfI.)

maXofuwhN ‡ A water at which there are many lips (XifaAh TA, and Ḥar p. 669,) of those coming to drink, (Ḥar,) so that it has become little in quantity; (TA;) or water at which are many people: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) or water that is sought: or, as some say, forbidden to those who come to drink of it because of its being little in quantity. (TA.)
And hence, (Ḥar ubi suprà,) ‡ Food upon which are [put] many hands; (Ḳ, TA, Ḥar;) having many eaters: or that has become little in quantity. (TA.)
And † Property sought by many: (TA:) [or little in quantity; for] one says, OataAnaA waOamowaAlunaA maXofuwhapN ‡ He came to us when our possessions were little in quantity. (Ḳ, TA.)

And † A man of whom people have asked, or begged, much, (Ṣ,) or importuned by begging, (Ḳ,) so that all that he had, or possessed, is consumed: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) like mavomuwdN, and maDofuwfN, and makovuwrN Ealayohi: (so in one of my copies of the Ṣ:) and sometimes it means † one whose household and guests have consumed his property. (IB, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Xafati AlX-amosu, aor. _u, [inf. n. app. XafFA, but said in the TḲ to be XafowN,] The sun was, or became, near to setting: (Ḳ in art. Xfw:) and Xafat, (Ḳ in art. XfI,) [aor. _i,] inf. n. XafFA, (TA,) it (the sun) set; as also Xafiyat: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to IḲṭṭ, set save a little; and the like is said in the T. (TA.) qubayola AlX-afaA means A little before the setting of the sun. (TA.) [See also XafFA below.]

And XafaA said of the hilaAl [or moon a little after or before the change], It rose. (Ḳ.) And said of a XaxoS [or bodily form or figure seen from a distance, or a person], It, or he, appeared, or became apparent. (Ḳ.)

XafaAhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XifaMCN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He (God, Ṣ, Mṣb) recovered him, or restored him to convalescence, syn. OaboraOahu, so in the M, but in the Ḳ baraAhu, (TA,) namely a sick person, (Mṣb,) mino maraDihi [from his disease, or sickness]. (Ṣ, TA.)

[Hence, Xafayotuhu, in art. bDE in the Ṣ, said by a person respecting one who asked him concerning a question, as meaning † I relieved him from doubt: and XafaAhu Eani AlmasoOalapi in the same art. in the Ḳ, as meaning † He relieved him from doubt respecting the question. See 8 as quasi-pass. of the verb thus used.]
And yaXofiyka Uino qaAla † [He will please thee if he speak; i. e.] his speech will please thee. (Ḥar p. 433.)
XafaAhu also signifies He sought, or demanded, or desired, for him, recovery, or restoration to convalescence; and so OaXofaAhu↓: (Ḳ, TA:) thus in the M. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. Xf-Ahu bikuli XaIoCK, inf. n. taXofiyapN, He treated him medically, or curatively, with everything whereby he might attain recovery, or restoration to convalescence. (TA.)

maA Xaf-aI fulaAnN OafoDalu mim-aA Xaf-ayota i. e. maA QzodaAda and rabiHa [meaning The gain of such a one (mA being here what is termed maSodariy-ap, as AizodaAda and rabiHa are intrans.,) is more excellent than thy gain] is said to be an instance of substitution, [originally Xaf-afa and Xaf-afota,] like [qaS-aI and taqaS-aI and] taqaD-aI [for qaS-aSa and taqaS-aSa and taqaD-aDa]. (TA.)
3. muXaAfaApN [an inf. n. of which the verb, if used, is XaAfaI]: see 3 in art. Xfh.

hom.sense: 4. AXfI Ealayohi He was, or became, on the brink of it; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) namely, a thing; and death: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) mostly used in relation to evil, but also in relation to good: so says IḲṭṭ. (TA.) [See XafFA.]
And AXfI [alone] † He was, or became, at the point of [giving or receiving] a charge or an injunction, or a trust or deposit. (TA.)
And † He was, or became, in the last part of the night; which is termed XafaA All-ayoli. (TA.)
OaXofaI nafosahu EalaI hulokK (Ḳ and TA in art. xTr) and AXfI bihaA (TA in the same) i. e. EalaI XafaA hulokK [meaning † He caused himself to be on the brink of destruction]. (TA ibid.)

AXfAhu He gave him a remedial medicine. (Az, TA.) And He prescribed for him a remedy in which should be his recovery, or restoration to convalescence. (TA.) And OaXofayotuka AlX-aIoCa (Ṣ, Ḳ *) I gave thee the thing in order that thou shouldst attain, or seek, recovery, or restoration to convalescence, thereby. (Ṣ: in two copies thereof, taXotafiI↓ bihi: in two other copies thereof, and in like manner in the Ḳ, tasotaXofiI↓ bihi.) And AXfAhu Qll-ehu EasalFA God made honey to be his remedy. (AO, Ṣ: and the like is said by IḲṭṭ as cited in the TA.)
See also 1, last sentence.
AXfI also signifies † He gave [a person] something. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tXf-I: see 8 [with which it is syn.].

[Hence,] tXf-I mino gayoZihi (Ṣ, MA, Ḳ) † He recovered from his anger, wrath, or rage. (MA.) And tXf-I mino Eaduw-ihi, (T, TA,) or biAlEaduw-i, and AXtfI↓ bh, (Mṣb,) † He inflicted injury upon his enemy [or the enemy] in a manner that rejoiced him [or relieved him from his anger]: (T, TA:) [or he attained what he desired from his enemy or the enemy, and so appeased his anger:] because latent anger is like a disease; and when it departs by reason of that which one seeks to obtain from his enemy, he is as though he became free, or recovered, from his disease. (Mṣb.)
6. taXaAfayotu AlmaMCa a phrase mentioned by IAạr as meaning I exhausted the water: said by ISd to be originally taXaAfafotu. (TA in art. Xf.)

8. AXtfI bikacaA (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) He attained recovery, or restoration to convalescence, by means of such a thing: (TA;) and so tXf-I↓: (TḲ:) and AstXfI↓ mino Eil-atihi [if not a mistranscription for AXtfI] he became free from his disease, sickness, or malady; recovered from it; or became convalescent. (TA.) See 4, latter part.
And see also 5.

[Also † He was, or became, content with such a thing; or relieved from doubt thereby: and] † he profited by such a thing. (MA.) One says, AiXotafayotu bimaA OaxobaraniI fulaAnN † I was, or became, content with that which such a one told me, [or relieved from doubt thereby,] because it was true. (IB in art. Hk, from Az.) And Oaxobarahu fulaAnN faQXotafaI bihi † [Such a one gave him information] and he profited by his veracity. (TA.)
10. AstXfI He sought, or demanded, a remedy, or cure. (TA.) See 4, latter part.
And see also 8.

XafFA The point or extremity, verge, brink, or edge, of anything; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.;) like XafapN↓; for XafaA AlHuforapi (Ksh in iii. 99) or XafaA AlbiYori (Bḍ ibid.) and XafatuhaA both signify the same, (Ksh, Bḍ,) i. e. HarofuhaA (Ksh) or TarafuhaA; (Bḍ;) but the final w in the former is changed into A, and in the latter [accord. to those who hold XafapN to be originally XafowapN] it is elided; (Ksh, Bḍ;) XafFA being originally XafawN: (Bḍ:) [but XafFA generally signifies as expl. above; and XafapN almost always signifies the “lip” of a human being:] the dual is XafawaAni; this being known, as Akh says, by the fact that UimaAlap in the word XafFA is not allowable: (Ṣ:) and the pl. is OaXofaMCN. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [iii. 99], wakunotumo EalaI XafaA HuforapN mina Qln-aAri faOanoqacakumo minohaA [And ye were on the verge, or brink, of a pit of the fire of Hell, and He saved, or rescued, you from it]. (Ṣ.) And one says, huwa EalaI XafaA AlhalaAki ‡ [He is on the brink of destruction]. (TA.)

Also ‡ A little; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA;) a small part, or portion; somewhat; (A, TA;) somewhat remaining of the moon when near the change, (Ḳ, TA, [AlhalAk in the CK is erroneously put for AlhilaAl,]) and of the sight (AlbaSar), and of the day, and the like, as in the T. (TA.) One says of a man on the occasion of his dying, and of the moon at [the last period of the month called] its muHaAq, and of the sun at its setting, (Ṣ,) maA baqiIa minohu Uil-aA XafFA [and minohaA when said of the sun] † There has not remained of him, or it, save a little: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) and [in like manner] mina AlEumuri [of life]. (Ṣ.) And one says, Oatayotuhu biXafFA mino DawoCi AlX-amosi † [I came to him in a time when there was little remaining of the light of the sun]. (TA.) El-ʼAjjáj says,
wamirobaOK EaAlK limanN taXar-afaA
OaXorafotuhu bilaA XafFA Oawo biXafaA
meaning [Many an elevated place of observation, high to him who ascends it, I have ascended] when the sun had set or when there was somewhat of it remaining. (Ṣ.) One says also, SaAra fiI XafaA Alqamari meaning † He was, or became, in the last part of the night. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., (in relation to [the temporary marriage termed] AlmutoEap,) falawo laA nahoyuhu EanohaA maA QHotaAja UilaI Alz-inaA Uil-aA XafFA, accord. to the T meaning [Were it not for his (i. e. God's) forbidding it, none would need having recourse to fornication,] save a small number of men: (T, TA:) or, accord. to ʼAṭà, it means, but would be on the brink thereof, without falling into it; XafFA being thus used in the place of the inf. n. UiXofaMC: so says IAth, as from Az. (TA.)

XafapN, in which the deficient letter is w, (Ḳ, TA,) for it has for pl. XafawaAtN, (TA,) or h, (Ḳ, TA,) for it has [also] for pl. XifaAhN, (TA,) has been mentioned before, (Ḳ, TA,) in art. Xfh [q. v.]. (TA.)
See also XafFA above, first sentence.
XifaMCN, (Ḳ, TA,) like kisaMCN, (TA,) [in the CK erroneously written XafAC,] primarily signifies The becoming free from disease, sickness, or malady; recovering therefrom; or becoming convalescent:
and then, Medical, or curative, treatment: (TA:) the giving of health; (KL:) inf. n. of XafaAhu [q. v.]: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:)
and [then], (TA,) A medicine, or remedy: pl. OaXofiyapN, and pl. pl. OaXaAfK. (Ḳ, TA.) [Hence, daAru AlXifaMCi The hospital.]
[And hence,] one says, XifaMCu AlEiI-i Als-uWaAlu ‡ [The remedy of inability is the asking information]. (TA.)
XafiI-N: see art. Xfh.
Xufay-apN: see art. Xfh.
XafawiI-N: see art. Xfh.
XaAfK [Recovering, or restoring to convalescence; remedial;] health-giving. (KL.)
[Hence, jawaAbN XaAfK † An answer that relieves from doubt.]

hom.sense: OaXofaI More [and most remedial or] healthgiving. (KL.)
Also A man whose lips do not close together: fem. XafoyaMCu. (TA.) See OaXofahu, in art. Xfh.

entry.sense: UiXofFI An instrument for perforating; (Ḳ;) a thing pertaining to the makers or sewers of boots or shoes or sandals, &c.; (Ṣ;) [i. e.] the awl used by them: (MA, KL:) and the instrument with which leather, or skin, is sewed: (Mgh, Ḳ:) or, accord. to ISk, it is [an instrument used] for water-skins and water-bags and the like; and the mixoSaf is for sandals: (Ṣ:) [see also art. AXf:] masc. and fem.: (Ḳ,* TA:) pl. OaXaAfK. (Mgh, TA.)
Th mentions the saying, Uino laATamotahu laATamota AlUiXofaI [if thou contend with him in slapping, thou wilt do so with the AXfI]; meaning that when one does so, it will be against himself. (TA.)
And UiXofaI Almirofaqi, a phrase used by a poet, means † Sharp in the elbow. (TA.)

hom.sense:
1. Xaq-ahu, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXoququ}, (M, Mṣb,) inf. n. Xaq-N, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,)
He cut it [or divided it] lengthwise; (TA in art. qd;) [i. e.] he clave it, split it, rived or rifted it, or slit it; so as to separate it; [i. e. he clave, split, rived or rifted, slit, rent, ripped, tore, broke, or burst, it asunder;] or without separating it; [i. e. he cracked, chapped, incided or incised, gashed, slashed, furrowed, or trenched, it; or clave, split,, &c., or cut, it open;] syn. SadaEahu; (Ḳ;) or [more explicitly] AlX-aq-u signifies AlS-adoEu AlbaAYinu [the cleaving, &c. that separates]; or gayoru AlbaAYini [that which does not separate]; or AlS-adoEu [the cleaving,, &c.,] in a general sense: (M:) and in like manner, [but with an intensive signification, or implying frequency or repetition of the action, or its application to several objects, generally meaning he clave it,, &c., much, or in pieces, or in several places,] Xq-qhu↓: (M, Ḳ:) you say, Xq-q AlHaTaba (Ṣ, Ḳ) wagayorahu (Ṣ) i. e. Xaq-ahu [but properly meaning He clave in pieces the firewood, &c.]. (Ḳ. [In the CK, Xaq-a AlHaTaba is erroneously put for Xq-q AlHTb.])
[Xaq-a raOosahu generally means He clave his head, or his pericranium: and sometimes, as in an instance in the Ḳ voce XaqaOa, he divided the hair of his head.]

Xaq-a AlEaSaA [lit. He split the staff] means ‡ he separated himself from the community; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and particularly, that of the Muslims: because the staff is not thus called but when it is whole, not when it is split: accord. to Lth, yaXuq-u EaSaA Almusolimiyna and yuXaAq-uhumo↓ signify alike: but they differ in meaning, as will be shown hereafter. (TA.) Xaq-a EaSaA Almusolimiyna, (Ḳ, TA,) said of a xaArijiI- [i. e. heretic or schismatic], also means † He effected disunion and dissension in the body of the Muslims. (TA.) And one says also, Xaq-a EaSaA AlT-aAEapi † [He broke the compact of allegiance, or obedience; became a rebel]. (M.)

laA waAl-aciI Xaq-a Alr-ijaAla liloxayoli waAljibaAla lils-ayoli [app. meaning † No, by Him who clave men for the riding upon horses, and the mountains for the flowing of the torrent,] is a saying mentioned by IAạr, but not expl. by him. (M. [It is there added, waEinodiI Oan-ahu jaEala Alr-ijaAla waAljibaAla jumolapF waAHidapF vum-a xaraqahumaA fajaEala Alr-ijaAla lihecihi waAljibaAla lihecaA: an expression of opinion which is, to me, by no means clear, though reconcilable with my rendering.])

AlmaAlu bayonanaA Xaq-a AlOabolamapi and AlOubolumapi [The property is divided between us as in the dividing of the Ablmp; or the cattle are divided, &c.;] means we are equal in respect of the property, or cattle: for the Ablmp means the [kind of leaf called] xuwSap, which, when it is split lengthwise, splits in halves: (M:) or, accord. to Aboo-Ziyád, the Ablmp is a herb, or leguminous plant, (baqolapN,) to which there come forth pods, like [those of] the bean; and when you split them lengthwise, they split in halves, equally, from the first part to the last thereof: Xaq-a is in the accus. case as an inf. n., maXoquwqN being understood. (Ḥar p. 639.) [See also Xiq-N.]

Xaq-a, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yaXoququ}, inf. n. XuquwqN, (M,) said of the canine tooth of a camel, ‡ It [clave the gum and] came forth: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA:) [said to be] a dial. var. of XaqaOa: (Ṣ:) and said of the canine tooth of a child, (M, TA,) in like manner, (TA,) meaning it made its first appearance: (M:) and said also of a plant, [as meaning it came forth] on the ground's first cleaving open from it. (M, TA.)
Also, aor. _u {yaXoququ}, inf. n. Xaq-N, said of the dawn, ‡ It rose; as though it clave the place of its rising and came forth therefrom. (TA.)

Also, aor. _u {yaXoququ}, (TA,) inf. n. Xaq-N, said of lightning, ‡ It [clave the clouds, and] extended high, into the midst of the sky, without going to the right and left: (Ḳ, TA:) so says AʼObeyd: (TA: [see XaqiyqN:]) and AnXq-↓ and tXq-q↓, said of lightning, signify AinoEaq-a [probably meaning the same; (see EaqiyqapN;) or, as expl. in the Ṣ and also in the O, in art. Eq, it was, or became, in a state of commotion, (taDar-aba,) in the clouds]: (M, TA:) or tXq-q↓ said of lightning means it spread wide and long. (JK.)
Xaq-a Als-abiyla (Ḳ in art. Ebr) † He passed along the way; as though he cut it, or furrowed it. (TḲ in that art.) And Xaq-a Aln-ahora † He crossed the river by swimming. (TA in art. qTE.)
Xaq-a AlmaMCa † He opened a way, passage, vent, or channel, for the water to flow forth; syn. bajasahu. (A and Ḳ in art. bjs.)

Xaq-a Oamorahu, aor. _u {yaXoququ}, inf. n. Xaq-N, † He, or it, discomposed, deranged, or disordered, so that it became incongruous, or inconsistent, his affair, or state of affairs. (M, TA.) [A phrase similar to Xaq-a AlEaSaA, mentioned above. And so, app., what next follows.]

Xaq-a AlkalaAma, i. q. qad-ahu [also expl. as syn. with qaTaEahu, which generally means † He cut short, or broke off, the speech; or ceased from speaking; but sometimes, and perhaps in this case, he articulated speech, or the speech: compare a signification of 2.]. (M and L in art. qd.)
See also 8.

Xaq-a baSaru Almay-iti i. q. XaxaSa [i. e. † The eye, or eyes, of the dying man became fixedly open; or his eyelids became raised upwards, and he looked intently, and became disquieted, or disturbed]: (M, TA:) and (TA) the dying man looked at a thing, his sight not recoiling to him: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) said of him to whom death is present: (Ṣ, TA:) or [simply] the eyes of the dying man became open: (TA:) one should not say Xaq-a Almay-itu baSarahu: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and Xuq-a, with damm to the X, is not approved. (IAth, TA.)

Xaq-a Ealayohi, (M, Ḳ, in the Ṣ EalaI-a, and in the Mṣb EalayonaA,) aor. _u {yaXoququ}, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) inf. n. Xaq-N (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and maXaq-apN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [or the latter is a simple subst., as seems to be indicated in the M and Mṣb,] † It (a thing, Ṣ, or an affair, or event, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) affected him severely; had a severe effect upon him; distressed, afflicted, troubled, molested, inconvenienced, fatigued, or wearied, him: (M:) it was difficult, hard, distressing, grievous, or severe, to him; (Ḳ, TA;) and onerous, burdensome, oppressive, or troublesome, to him. (TA.) And Xaq-a Ealayohi, [inf. n., app., Xaq-N only,] † He caused him to fall into a difficult, hard, distressing, grievous, or severe, case: (Ḳ, TA:) imposed upon him that which was onerous, burdensome, oppressive, or troublesome. (TA.) And Xaq-ati Als-aforapu † The journey was [difficult, hard, or] far-extending. (Mṣb.)
Xuq-a, said of the solid hoof, and of the pastern of a horse or the like, It was, or became, affected with the disease termed XuqaAq, occasioning cracks. (M, TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first sentence.

Xq-q AlkalaAma, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. taXoqiyqN, (TA,) ‡ He uttered, or pronounced, speech, or the speech, in the best manner: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and he sought with repeated efforts, in speaking, to utter, or pronounce, the speech in the best manner. (TA.)

3. XAq-hu, (M, Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. muXaAq-apN (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XiqaAqN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter inf. n. occurring in the Ḳur ii. 131 and iv. 39 [&c.], (TA,) † He acted with him contrariously, or adversely, (Ṣ,* M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and inimically; (Ḳ;) properly, each of them doing to the other that which was distressing, grievous, or troublesome, so that each of them was in a Xiq- [or side] other than that of his fellow; (Mṣb;) or as though he became in a Xiq-, i. e. side, in respect of him: (Mgh:) accord. to Er-Rághib, the inf. n. signifies the being in a Xiq- [or side] other than that of one's fellow: or it is from Xaq-u AlEaSaA bayonaka wabayona SaAHibika [meaning “the effecting disunion and dissension between thee and thy fellow”], so that it is tropical: (TA:) or the primary meaning of AlX-iqaAqu is the being [mutually] remote. (Ḥam p. 326.) See also 1, in the first quarter of the paragraph.
4. AXq- Aln-axolu The palm-trees put forth their XawaAq-, pl. of XaAq-apN [q. v.]: mentioned by Th, on the authority of some one or more of the BenooSuwáäh. (M.)
5. tXq-q quasi-pass. of 2: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) said of firewood (Ṣ, Ḳ), &c. (Ṣ) [as meaning It became cloven in pieces]. See 7, in two places.
Said of lightning: see 1, in two places, in the latter half of the paragraph.
Said of a horse, ‡ He was, or became, lean, or light of flesh; slender and lean; or lean, and lank in the belly. (AʼObeyd, TA.)

6. taXaAq-aA, said of two adversaries, or litigants, as also AiXotaq-aA↓, They wrangled, quarrelled, or contended, each with the other, (M, TA,) and took to the right and left in contention; (TA;) fiI AlX-aIoCi [in respect of the thing]. (M.)

7. AnXq- quasi-pass. of Xaq-ahu as expl. in the first sentence of this art.: [i. e. it signifies It became divided lengthwise, cloven, split, riven or rifted, slit, rent, ripped, torn, broken, or burst, asunder; or it became cracked, chapped, incided or incised, gashed, slashed, furrowed, or trenched; or cloven, or split,, &c., or cut, open: or it clave, split,, &c.:] (Ṣ, M:) and in like manner, tXq-q↓ is quasi-pass. of Xaq-aqahu: [i. e. it signifies it became cloven or split, &c., or it clave or split, &c., much, or in pieces, or in several or many places:] (M:) or the former signifies [sometimes] it opened so as to have in it an interstice. (Mṣb.) waQnoXaq-a Alqamaru, in the Ḳur liv. I, means And the moon hath been cloven (Bḍ, Jel) in twain, (Jel,) as a sign to the Prophet: (Bḍ, Jel:)
or shall be cloven on the day of resurrection: but the former is confirmed by another reading, waqadi QnoXaq-a Alqamaru: (Bḍ:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, the meaning is, † the case hath become manifest. (TA.) One says, AnXq- AlX-aIoCu biniSofayoni [The thing became cloven,, &c., in halves]. (Ṣ.) [And AnXq- minohu It became cloven,, &c., from it: and it branched off from it; as a river from another river, and the like. And AnXq- Eanohu It clave asunder from over it, so as to disclose it: see also 8.]
[Hence,] AnXq- flaAnN mina AlgaDabi † Such a one was as though his interior were filled with anger so that he split. (TA.)

And AinoXaq-ati AlEaSaA † The affair, or state of affairs, became discomposed, deranged, or disordered: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and AnXq-t AlEaSaA biAlbayoni, and tXq-qt↓, (Lth, M, TA,) † the affair, or state of affairs, became discomposed, deranged, or disorganized, by separation: (Lth, TA:) and AnXq- AlOamoru † the affair, or state of affairs, became discomposed, deranged, or disorganized, being incongruous, or inconsistent. (M, TA.) And AnXq-t EaSaA AlT-aAEapi † [The compact of allegiance, or obedience, became broken]. (M.)
AnXq- said of lightning: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.
8. AiXotiqaAqN signifies The taking the Xiq- of a thing, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. the half thereof. (Ṣ.) One says, AXtq- AlX-aIoCa He took the Xiq- [or half] of the thing. (TḲ.)

And † The taking [or deriving] a word from a word, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with the condition of reciprocal relation in meaning and [radical] composition, and of reciprocal difference in form: [and it is of three kinds:] AlAiXotiqaAqu AlS-agiyru is that derivation in which there is a reciprocal relation between the two words in the letters and in the order [thereof]; as in Daraba from AlD-arobu: AlAXtqAq Alkabiyru is that in which there is a reciprocal relation between the two words as to the letter and the meaning, exclusively of the order; as in jabaca from Aljacobu: AlAXtqAq AlOakobaru is that in which there is a reciprocal relation between the two words in the place [or places] of utterance; as in naEaqa from Aln-ahoqu. (KT.) [You say, AXtq- HarofFA or kalimapF or lafoZFA, and QsomFA, He derived a word, and a name, mino Mxara from another; and Xaq-ahu↓ sometimes signifies the same, as is shown by a citation voce raHimN.]
[And, as syn. with AixotiraAEN, (see 8 in art. xrE,)] The constructing, or founding, (bunoyaAn,) of a thing of, or from, what is originated without premeditation. (M.)

And ‡ The taking to the right and left, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) not pursuing the right, or direct, course, (Ṣ, TA,) in speech, and in contention, or disputation, or litigation: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or AiXotiqaAqu AlkalaAmi signifies the taking to the right and left in speech: (so in a copy of the M: [but I think that the right reading is AlAiXotiqaAqu fiI AlkalaAmi, agreeably with what here follows:]) you say, AXtq- fiI AlkalaAmi, and fiI AlxuSuwmapi. (TḲ.) See also 6. And [in like manner] one says of a horse, AXtq- fiI Eadowihi † He went to the right and left in his running. (M. [See also OaXaq-u.])
AXtq- AlT-ariyqu fiI AlfalaApi ‡ The road went [or branched off] into the desert. (TA. [See also 7.])
10. AstXq- biAljuwaAliqi He turned the sack upon one of his two sides (EalaI OaHadi Xiq-ayohi), in order to pass through a door. (TA.)
[AstXq-, as stated by Freytag, is expl. by Jac. Schultens, but on what authority is not said, as signifying “Prodiit, manifestus evasit.”]

R. Q. 1. XaqoXaqa, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. XaqoXaqapN, (Ṣ,) said of a stallion [camel], He brayed [in his XiqoXiqap, or faucial bag]. (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.) [It is said that] the primary meaning of XaqoXaqapN is Loudness of voice; or the being loud in voice. (JK.)
And said of a sparrow, It uttered a cry: (Ḳ, TA:) or one says of a sparrow, yuXaqoXiqu fiI Sawotihi [app. meaning It makes a loud twittering in its cry]. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: Xaq-N sing. of XuquwqN; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) originally an inf. n.; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) An opening forming an interstice in a thing: (Mṣb:) or a fissure, cleft, chink, split, slit, rent, crack, or the like, syn. SadoEN, in wood or a stick, or in a wall, or in a glass vessel [&c.]: (T, TA:) [or] a place that is maXoquwq [i. e. cloven or cleft, split,, &c.: (see 1, first sentence: and see also maXaq-N:) and often signifying an incision, a gash, or a furrow, or trench]: (M, Ḳ:) as though an inf. n. used as a subst. in this sense: pl. as above, XuquwqN: (M:) it differs from XuqaAqN, (Ṣ, Mgh,) by having a general signification: (Mgh:) accord. to Yaạḳoob, one says, biyadi fulaAnK XuquwqN (Ṣ, Mgh) and birijolihi (Ṣ) [i. e. In the hand, or arm, of such a one are cracks, or the like, and in his foot, or leg]: but [it is asserted that in this case] one should not say XuqaAqN: (Ṣ, Mgh: [see, however, this word:]) and hence, Xaq-u Alqabori The trench, or oblong excavation, in the middle of the grave: and accord. to Aṣ, XuquwqN signifies SuduwE [i. e. fissures,, &c.,] in mountains, and in the earth, or ground. (Mgh.)
The rima vulvæ of a woman; i. e. the gap [or chink] between the two edges, or borders, of the labia majora of her vulva: as also maXaq-N↓. (M, Ḳ.)
And ‡ The daybreak. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
See also the next paragraph, first and fifth sentences.
And see the last two sentences of the same paragraph.

Xiq-N The half (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) of a thing (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) of any kind; as also Xaq-N↓: (Ḳ:) or the half of a thing when it is cloven, or split, or divided lengthwise; (M;) as also Xiq-apN↓. (AḤn, Ṣ,* M, Ḳ.) One says, Oaxacotu Xiq-a AlX-aApi and Xiq-apa↓ AlX-aApi I took the half of the sheep or goat: (Ṣ, TA:) the vulgar pronounce the X with fet-ḥ. (TA.) And xuco hecaA AlX-iq-a Take thou this Xiq-ap↓ [i. e. half] of the sheep or goat. (TA.) Hence the trad., taSad-aquwA walawo biXiq-i tamorapK i. e. [Give ye alms though it be but] the half of a date; meaning deem not anything little that is given as alms. (TA.) And AlmaAlu bayoniI wabayonaka Xiq-a AlX-aEarapi and Xaq-a↓ AlX-aEarapi, (O, Ḳ,* [in the CK and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ Xq-u, but the former reading appears to be the right, Xaq-a being an inf. n. as in a similar saying in the former half of the first paragraph of this art., and Xiq-a being a subst. used as an inf. n. or for kaXiq-i,]) meaning [The property is between us] two halves, equal [in division]. (Ḳ.)
[Hence,] A certain kind of the jinn, or genii; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ;) a species of diabolical beings having the form of the half of a human being. (Ḳzw in his Descr. of the Jinn.)

The lateral half, or half and side; as when one says that a person paralyzed has a Xiq- inclining; and as when one speaks of the Xiq- of a maHomil [meaning either of the two dorsers, or panniers, or oblong chests, which are borne, one on either side, by a camel, and which, with a small tent over them, compose a maHomil: see this last word, and maHaArapN]. (Mgh.)

The side of the body; as when one says of a person that his left Xiq- was grazed, or abraded. (Mgh.) [Hence,] one says of a horse, yamiylu EalaI OaHadi Xiq-ayohi [He inclines, or leans, upon one of his two sides]. (O.) [And maXaI EalaI Xiq-K and fiI Xiq-K He went, or walked, inclining upon one side.]

The side, or lateral part, (Lth, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) of a thing; the two sides of a thing being called Xiq-aAhu: (Lth, TA:) or, as some say, (TA,) the side of a mountain. (Ṣ, TA.) [Hence,] one says, fulaAnN mino Xiq-i AlEaXiyrapi laA mino SamiymihaA † [Such a one is of the collateral class of the kinsfolk, or tribe, not of the main stock thereof]. (Mgh in art. ErD.)
I. q. XaqiyqN↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [which primarily signifies The cloven-off half of a thing; i. e.,] when a thing is cloven in halves, each of the halves is called the Xaqiyq of the other. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

[And hence, † The counterpart of a person or thing: and this appears to be meant by J, and accord. to SM in the Ḳ, where it is said that Xiq-N is syn. with XaqiyqN↓; for they add immediately after:] one says huwa OaxiI waXiq-u nafosiI ‡ [He is my brother, and the counterpart of myself]; (Ṣ, TA;) as though he were cloven from me, because of the resemblance of each of us to the other. (TA.) One says also, hcaA Xaqiyquhu↓, meaning † This is the like of him, or it. (TA.) And [hence] it is said in a trad., Aln-isaMCu XaqaAYiqu Alr-ijaAli, [in which XaqaAYiqu is the pl. of XaqiyqN↓ as fem., or of XaqiyqapN in the same sense,] meaning † Women are the likes of men in natural dispositions; as though they were cloven from them; or because Eve was created from Adam. (TA.)

And ‡ A man's brother; (M;) and so XaqiyqN↓; (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ, TA;) meaning a brother by the father and mother; (TA;) from XaqiyqN as meaning “either half of a thing that is cloven in halves;” (Ṣ, TA;) or as though the relationship of one were cloven from that of the other: (IDrd, O, Ḳ:) pl. of the latter OaXiq-aMCu. (M, Mṣb.)

And a name for A thing at which one looks: (Lth, O, Ḳ:) [but this is app. taken from the following saying of Lth, in which I think AlX-iq-u is a mistranscription for AlX-aq-u, meaning “the crack,”, &c.:]
AlX-aq-u is the inf. n. of Xaqaqotu, and AlX-iq-u is a name for that at which one looks [i. e. for the visible effect of the act signified by the verb], and the pl. is AlX-uquwqu [which is well known as the pl. of AlX-aq-u]. (JK.)

Also i. q. maXaq-apN↓ (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) i. e. Difficulty, hardship, distress, affliction, trouble, inconvenience, fatigue, or weariness; (M, TA;) and languor, or lack of power, that overtakes the mind and the body; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and so Xaq-N↓; (IJ, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ;) thus it is sometimes pronounced with fet-ḥ; mentioned by AʼObeyd; (Ṣ;) and by AZ; (M;) or this is an inf. n., and Xiq-N is the subst.; (O, Ḳ;) and Xuq-apN↓ and Xiq-apN↓ also signify the same as maXaq-apN, (Ḳ,) or such as overtakes a man in consequence of travel; (TA;) and the pls. of these two are XuqaqN, (Ḳ, TA,) mentioned by Fr, (TA,) and XiqaqN, (Ḳ, TA,) mentioned on the authority of some one or more of [the tribe of] Keys: (TA:) the pl. of maXaq-apN↓ is maXaAq-u and maXaq-aAtN. (TA.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xvi. 7], lamo takuwnuwA baAligiyhi Uil-aA biXiqi QloOanofusi [Which ye would not reach save with difficulty, or distress,, &c., of the souls]; where some read biXaq-i↓. (Ṣ,* TA.)

entry.sense: Xuq-apN primarily signifies The half of a garment [consisting of two oblong pieces sewed together, side by side]: then it was applied to [such] a garment as it is [when complete: in both of these senses it is used in the present day]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or a piece (qiToEapN) of a garment: (Mgh:) or the Xuq-ap of viyaAb [thus, and thus only, in the Ṣ, meaning of garments and of cloths, for it is of both,] is an oblong piece; syn. sabiybapN musotaTiylapN: (M, Ḳ:) [it is often applied to an oblong piece of cloth of those pieces of which a tent is composed:] pl. XuqaqN and XiqaAqN. (M, Mgh, TA.) One says, fulaAnN yabiyEu XiqaAqa Alkat-aAni [Such a one sells pieces, or oblong pieces,, &c., of linen]. (Mgh.)
Also A piece of a mazaAdap [q. v.]. (B, TA in art. bSr.)
And A piece, or portion, [or tract,] of Hell; likewise pronounced Xiq-apN↓. (Ḥam p. 816.)

And A far journey; as also Xiq-apN↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) sometimes thus pronounced with kesr: (Ṣ:) a far, long journey: a far-extending space: (TA:) or a road difficult to him who travels it: (Mgh:) or [simply] a journey: and i. q. vnyA [so in my copy of the Mṣb, app. a mistranscription for vaniy-ap, i. e. a mountain-road,, &c.]: pl. XuqaqN. (Mṣb.)

And A part, region, quarter, or tract, (Ibn-ʼArafeh, Er-Rághib, Ḳ, TA,) towards which one draws near, (Ibn-ʼArafeh, TA,) or towards which the traveller directs himself, (Ḳ, TA,) [like Xuk-apN,] or in the reaching of which one is overtaken by difficulty, or distress; (Er-Rághib, TA;) And Xiq-apN↓ signifies the same. (Ḳ.)
And Distance; and so Xiq-apN↓. (Ḳ.)
See also Xiq-N, last sentence but one.

Xiq-apN A splinter (Ṣ, Ḳ) that splits off, (Ṣ,) or a piece (M, Mgh, TA) split off, (M, TA,) of a plank, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) or of wood, (TA,) or of a piece of wood, (Ṣ, Mgh,) or other thing: (M, TA:) a piece split, or divided, lengthwise, of a staff, or stick, and of a garment, or piece of cloth, &c.: (IDrd, O, Ḳ:) and a piece split (Ḳ, TA) from anything; such as the half: (TA:) pl. XiqaqN. (O, TA.) One says of him who is angry, AiHotad-a faTaArato minohu Xiq-apN fiI AlOaroDi waXiq-apN fiI Als-amaMCi † [He became excited by sharpness of temper, or angriness, and he was as though a bit flew from him upon the ground, and a bit into the sky]. (Ṣ,* M, TA: in the Ṣ, fI AlArD, &c. is omitted.) See also Xiq-N, first three sentences.
See also Xuq-apN, in four places.
And see Xiq-N, again, last sentence but one.
XaqaqN The quality, in a horse, (M, Ḳ,) and in a man, (M,) denoted by the epithet OaXaq-u [q. v.]. (M, Ḳ.)
XaqaqapN [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] Enemies. (TA.)

XuqaAqN A cracking in several places, (taXaq-uqN, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or cracks, (Mgh,) or a certain disease occasioning cracks, (M,) in the pasterns of horses or the like, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) and in their hoofs, (M, Mgh,) and sometimes rising to their shanks: so says Yaạḳoob: (Ṣ:) and, accord. to Lth, (Mgh,) and Az, (TA,) a cracking in several places (taXaq-uqN) of the skin, from cold or some other cause, in the hands or arms, and the face: (Mgh, TA:) or it signifies also any crack, or slit, in the skin, from disease: (M, TA:) Aṣ says that it is in the hand or arm, and the foot or leg, of a human being, and in the fore leg and kind leg of an animal: (Mgh, TA:) but this is inconsistent with what is said by Yaạḳoob [as stated voce Xaq-N, first sentence]. (Mgh.) See also OasoEadu: and XarajN.

hom.sense: XaqiyqN: see Xiq-N, in five places.

Xaqiyqu Albaroqi [so in a copy of the M, but the right reading may be Xaqiyqapu Albaroqi, which occurs in the next sentence of the M,] i. q. Eaqiyqatuhu [expl. in the Ṣ, in art. xfw, as meaning Lightning that cleaves the clouds, and extends high, into the midst of the sky, without going to the right and left: but see XaqiyqapN]. (M.)

Also A calf that has become firm, or strong: (O, Ḳ:) and applied likewise to † a man [that has become so; by way of comparison]: (O:) or a bull such as is termed jacaEN [i. e. in his second, or third, year]. (JK.)

entry.sense: XaquwqapN A certain bird; also called XaqiyqapN↓: (M, Ḳ:) and Xuqay-iqapN↓ is the dim. thereof: (Ḳ:) AḤát says, the Xaquwqap↓ is a very little thing, grayish (zurayoqaMCu), of the colour of ashes; ten and fifteen of what are thus called congregate; and I think it to be the Xuqay-iqap↓, which is a dux-alap of the dux-al [q. v.]; it is somewhat dusky; and its form is the form of these, but it is smaller than they: it is called Xuqay-iqap↓ becanse of its smallness: IDrd, in the class of fuEayoEil, mentions AlX-uqay-iqu↓ as signifying a certain species of birds [app. as a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p]. (O, TA.)

hom.sense: XaqiyqapN [accord. to Golius, A fissure; as from the KL; but not so expl. in my copy of that work.]

An intervening space or tract between two elongated, or extended, tracts of sand, (Ṣ, M,* O, Ḳ,* [in the last of which Aljabalayoni is erroneously put for Aljabolayoni,]) thus expl. to AḤn by an Arab of the desert, (TA,) producing herbage: (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ:) or a rugged tract between two elongated, or extended, tracts of sand, producing good herbage; (M, TA;) so in the T, as expl. to its author by an Arab of the desert: (TA:) pl. XaqaAYiqu, (T, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) expl. by some as meaning sands themselves: (TA:) or a great piece of sand: or a piece of sand between two pieces thereof. (Ḥam p. 282.)
[In the A and TA voce qiT-u, it is used as meaning A slice cut off of a melon, &c.]
A rain, (M,) or a violent rain, consisting of large drops, (Ḳ, TA,) wide in extent: so called because the clouds cleave asunder from it: (M, Ḳ, TA:) pl. as above. (TA.)
The pl., XaqaAYiqu, is expl. by Az as signifying Clouds that have cloven asunder with copious rains. (O, TA.)

Xaqiyqapu baroqK, (O, Ḳ,) and Eaqiyqatuhu, both as expl. by Aboo-Saʼeed, (O,) A flash of lightning that has spread (O, Ḳ) in the horizon, (O,) or from the horizon: (Ḳ: [but see Xaqiyqu Albaroqi:]) or XaqiyqapN signifies a flash of lightning that has spread in the breadth of the clouds, and filled the sky: pl. as above. (Ḥam p. 557.)

A headache, (JK, T, TA,) or a pain, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or a certain disease, (M,) in the half of the head, (JK, T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) [i. e. hemicrania,] and of the face: (JK, T, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or, accord. to IAth, a sort of headache in the fore part of the head and towards the sides thereof. (TA.)

XaqaAYiqu Aln-uEomaAni, used alike as sing. and pl., (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) having no proper sing., (Mṣb,) or its sing. is XaqiyqapN; (M, O, Mṣb;) [The red, or blood-coloured, anemone;] a certain plant; (M;) a certain red flower; (Lth, O;) well known; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the Xaqir; (Mṣb;) or, as AḤn says, on the authority of AA and Aboo-Naṣr and others, it is the Xaqirap [n. un. of XaqirN]; and the sing. of XqAYq is XaqiyqapN: (O, TA:) it is called XqAYq AlnEmAn because of its redness, as being likened to the Xaqiyqap of lightning: (M, Ḳ:) or from Aln-uEomaAn as meaning “blood,” as resembling blood in colour; (Mṣb, TA;) so that it signifies “pieces of blood:” (TA:) or in relation to En-Noamán Ibn-El-Mundhir, because he prohibited to the public a piece of land in which it abounded: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or because he alighted upon XaqaAYiq of sand that had produced red Xaqir, and he deemed them beautiful, and commanded that they should be prohibited to the public; so the Xaqir were called the XqAYq of En-Noamán, by the name of the place of their growth. (TA.)
See also XaquwqapN.

entry.sense: Xuqay-iqN and with p {Xuqay-iqapN}: see XaquwqapN, in four places.
Xaq-aAqN, meaning One who glories, or boasts, vainly, and praises himself for that which is not in him, is not of the [classical] language of the Arabs. (L, TA.)
Xaq-iI-N A horse with which his rider experiences difficulty in striving to master him. (JK.)
Xiq-iy-apN A certain mode of jimaAE, (Ḳ, TA,) in which the woman lies upon her Xiq- [or side]. (TA.)

XiqoXiqapN [The bursa faucium, or faucial bag, which is placed behind the palate of the he-camel, and which, when excited, he inflates, and blows out from the side of his mouth;] a thing resembling the lungs, or lights, which the he-camel protrudes from his mouth when he is excited by lust; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) a skin in the fauces of the Arabian camel, which he inflates with wind, and in which he brays; whereupon it appears from the side of his mouth; so says En-Naḍr; and he adds that it does not pertain to any but the Arabian camel, [as is said in the M, and] as Hr says; but this requires consideration; (TA;) [also expl. as] the lahaAp [q. v.] of the he-camel, (M, and Ḥar p. 16,) which he protrudes from his mouth when he brays: (Ḥar ubi suprá:) pl. XaqaAXiqu. (TA.)

To this is likened the tongue of the chaste, or eloquent, and able speaker; himself being likened to the braying stallion-camel: (O:) and hence they say of an orator, or a preacher, that he is cuw XiqoXiqapK: (Ṣ:) one says likewise of an orator, or a preacher, that is loud in voice and skilful in speech, huwa Oahoratu AlXiqoXiqapi [lit. He is wide, or ample, in respect of the XqXqp]: (TA:) and one says, hadarato XiqoXiqatuhu † [meaning His utterance was sonorous and fluent]. (A and TA in art. hdr.) Orators, or preachers, are also termed XaqaAXiq [for cawuw XaqaAXiqa]: and one says, fulaAnN XiqoXiqapu qawomihi, meaning † Such a one is the noble, and the chaste in speech, or eloquent, of his people. (M.) And in a trad. of ʼOmar, (M, O, TA,) accord. to AʼObeyd and others, or of ʼAlee accord. to Hr, (TA,) XaqaAXiq are assigned to the Devil, in his saying, Uin-a kaviyrFA mina AlxuTabi mino XaqaAXiqi AlX-ayoTaAni [lit. Verily many of the orations, or harangues, are from the XqAXq of the Devil]; because of the lying introduced into them. (M, O,* TA.*)

AlxuTobapu AlX-iqoXiqiy-apu an appellation applied to a certain xuTobap [i. e. oration, or harangue, or sermon,] of ʼAlee, because of his saying to Ibn-ʼAbbás, (O, Ḳ,) on his having cut short his speech, (O,) in reply to a remark of the latter person upon his not having continued his speech uninterruptedly, tiloka XiqoXiqapN hadarato vum-a qar-ato [That was a XqXqp that uttered a braying, then became still]. (O, Ḳ.)

XaAq-N Difficult, hard, distressing, grievous, afflicting, troubling, molesting, fatiguing, or wearying. (KL.) One says OamorN XaAq-N [An affair, or event, that is difficult,, &c.]; from Xaq-a EalayonaA AlOamoru. (Mṣb.) And Xuq-apN XaAq-apN (Ṣ, Mṣb) A long journey [that is difficult,, &c.]. (Mṣb.)
XAf-apN The spadix of a palm-tree, that has become a span in length; so called because it cleaves the envelope: pl. XawaAq-u. (M.)

OaXaq-u, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) fem. Xaq-aMCu, and pl. Xuq-N, (Ḳ,) applied to a horse, Wide between the hind legs: (IAạr, Th, T, O,* Ḳ,* TA:) and the fem. signifies wide in the OarofaAg [or groins, or similar parts]; (TA;) and is applied to a mare: (IDrd, O, TA:) and wide in the vulva; (IAạr, O, Ḳ;) applied in this sense to a woman. (IAạr, O, TA.) And OaXaq-u Almanoxirayoni, applied to a horse, Wide in the nostrils. (Lth, O, TA.)
Also, (O, Ḳ,) Tall, or long; (T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ;) applied to a horse; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) thus expl. by Aṣ; (T, TA;) and so too applied to a man: (M, TA:) and the fem., as above, applied to a mare. (Ṣ.)

And, applied to a horse, That goes to the right and left in his running, (JK,* O, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, yasobiqu is erroneously put for yaXotaq-u, and in like manner in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, with the additional mistranscription of mn Eadowihi for fiI Eadowihi,]) as though (O, TA) leaning upon one of his sides: (JK, O, TA:) so says Lth; and he cites as an ex.,
watabaAzayotu kamaA yamoXiI AlOaXaq-u
[as though meaning And I moved my posteriors in walking, like as goes the horse that inclines to the right and left in his running: but this may be rendered and I stepped wide, like as does the tall, or long-bodied, horse]. (O, TA.)
maXaq-N [properly A place of cleaving, splitting,, &c.: and hence a fissure, cleft,, &c., like Xaq-N: pl. maXaAq-u]: see Xaq-N.
maXaq-u AlEayoni [The slit of the eye]. (TA in art. HwS.)
maXaq-apN [said in the Ṣ and Ḳ to be an inf. n. of Xaq-a trans. by means of EalaI]: see Xiq-N, in the last quarter of the paragraph, in two places.

hom.sense: 1. XaqaOa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXoqaOu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. Xaqo N and XuquwoCN, said of the naAb [or tush] (Ṣ, Ḳ) of a camel, (Ṣ,) It grew forth; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) it appeared; (TA;) as also XakaOa. (Ḳ in art. XkO.) [See also Xaq-a.] XaAqiI, with the C softened [or changed into I], occurs in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh [for the part. n. XAqY]. (TA.)

XaqaOa raOosahu He divided his head; syn. Xaq-ahu: [meaning, his hair:] or he separated it (far-aqahu) [i. e. his hair] with the miXoqaMC [or comb]: (Ḳ:) or XaqaOa XaEarahu biAlmuXoTi, inf. n. XaqoCN, he separated his hair with the comb. (AZ, Ṣ.)
And XaqaOahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. XaqoCN, (Ṣ,) He hit his maXoqaO, i. e. the place of the parting of the hair of his head, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with a staff, or stick. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: UibilN XuwayoqiYapN Camels of the age when the naAb [or tush] grows forth: and so XuwayokiYapN: (Aṣ, TA:) [or Xuwayokiy-apN, q. v. in art. Xwk.]
maXoqaON (Ṣ, Ḳ) and maXoqiYN↓, (Fr, O, TA,) like maforaqN and maforiqN, (O, TA,) The place of the parting of the hair of the head. (Fr, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
miXoqaON A comb; (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also miXoqaMCN↓ and mXoqaOapN↓, and miXoqFA [or miXoqFI]. (Ḳ: the last also mentioned in the Ḳ in art. Xqw.)
maXoqiYN: see maXoqaON.
miXoqaOapN: see miXoqaON.

Also i. q. midoraApN; (Ḳ;) [i. e. A thing, or an iron instrument, with which the head is scratched; or a thing like a large needle, with which the female hair-dresser adjusts, or puts in order, the locks of a woman's hair;] or a piece of wood, or stick, [like a skewer,] which a woman inserts in her hair; or a horn prepared for that purpose (TA) [or for adjusting the locks of a woman's hair: see midoraApN].
miXoqaMCN: see miXoqaON.

hom.sense: 1. XaqaHa Aln-axolu, and Xq-H↓, The palm-trees were, or became, goodly with their fruit. (TA.) [See also 4.]

XaqaHa Qll-ehu fulaAnFA, [inf. n. XaqoHN,] accord. to AZ, is syn. with qabaHahu Qll-ehu [i. e. God removed such a one far from good, or prosperity,, &c.; or may God remove, &c.]: (TA:) [or, as may be inferred from what follows, the former of these verbs is used by some as an imitative sequent to the latter of them:] and accord. to Sb, (TA,) XaquHa, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. [XuqoHN and] XaqaAHapN, (TA,) is syn. with qabuHa [i. e. He, or it, was, or became, bad or evil, foul or ugly,, &c.]: (Ḳ, TA:) [but in this case also it seems that the former of these verbs may be used by some as an imitative sequent to the latter of them: for] one says, qaboHFA lahu waXaqoHFA [May removal far from good, or prosperity,, &c., betide him], (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) in which XaqoHFA is an imitative sequent to qaboHFA, or syn. therewith; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and [in like manner] quboHFA lahu waXuqoHFA; (O, Ḳ;) and, of a man, qabuH waXaquHa, inf. n. of the latter as above and in like manner of the former; (Ṣ;) and jaMCa biAlqabaAHapi waAlX-aqaAHapi [He did, or said, what was bad or evil,, &c.]: (Ḳ:) and huwa qabiyHN XaqiyHN↓ [He is bad or evil, foul or ugly,, &c.]: (Ṣ,* O, Ḳ:*) and qaEada maqobuwHFA maXoquwHFA↓ [He sat, or remained, far removed from good, or prosperity,, &c.]: in like manner: (Ḳ:) but Sb intimates that XaqyiHN↓ is not an imitative sequent, by his stating that the Arabs say XaqiyHN wacamiymN [Bad, or evil,, &c., and blamed,, &c.; or, more probably, XaqiyHN wadamiymN, meaning foul and ugly]: (L, TA:) and [it is said that] XaqiyHN↓ signifies Recovering (naAqihN [for which Freytag appears to have read naAqap]) from disease; (O, Ḳ, TA;) and hence one says, fulaAnN qabiyHN XaqiyHN [as though meaning Such a one is unsightly, being just recovering from disease]: (TA:) and accord. to AZ, maXoqawHN↓ is [not an imitative sequent, but] syn. with maqobuwHN: (L, TA:) in the phrase abovementioned, maXoquwHFA is said in the 'Ináyeh to mean broken: or far removed: (TA:) or it means reviled. (O.)

[As indicated above,] XaHaqahu, aor. _a {yaXoqaHu}, (Lḥ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. XaqoHN, (Lḥ, O,) also signifies He broke it. (Lḥ, O, Ḳ.)
One says, laOaXoqaHan-aka XaqoHa Aljawozapi biAljanodali, i. e. I will assuredly break [or crush] thee [as in the breaking of the walnut] with stones: (O, TA:*) or I will assuredly extract all that thou hast [as in the extracting of the contents of the walnut by means of stones]: for XaqaHa Aljawozapa, inf. n. as above, means He extracted what was in the walnut. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first sentence: and see also 4, in three places.
3. XAqHhu He reviled him; or contended with him in reviling; (Ḳ, TA;) and contended with him in annoyance. (O, TA.)

hom.sense: 4. AXqH Aln-axolu; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, O, Ḳ;) as also Xq-H↓, (Ṣ,* A, Mgh, O,) inf. n. taXoqiyHN; (Ṣ;) i. q. OazohaI [meaning The palm-trees showed redness, or yellowness, in their fruit]: (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ:) or their dates became altered from greenness to yellowness: (Mgh:) the former is said by Aṣ to be of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz: and ↓the latter verb is also said of the [kind of tree called] OaraAk, meaning it became coloured in its fruit. (TA.) And AXqH Alt-amoru, (O,) or Albusoru, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UiXoqaAHN; (TA;) and Xq-H↓, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) The dates, or the unripe dates, became coloured, (O, Ḳ,) red, or yellow: (O, TA:) or, as some say, became sweet. (TA.) The Prophet forbade the selling of dates before their becoming in this state. (Ṣ,* A,* O, TA.)
AXqHhu He removed him far away. (O, Ḳ.*)

OaqobiHo bihi waOaXoqiHo [app. How foul, or ugly, or the like, is he! as seems to be shown by what here follows]: IDrd cites,
OaqobiHo bihi mino waladK waOaXoqiHo
mivolu juraI-i Alkalobi laA balo OaqobaHo
[How foul is he, as offspring, and how ugly! like the little whelp of the dog; nay, rather, more foul!]. (O.)

entry.sense: XuqoHN [and inf. n. of XaquHa, q. v.]
[And,] accord. to AZ, i. q. XuH-N [i. e. Niggardliness,, &c.; or the being niggardly,, &c.: see 1 in art. XH]. (TA.)
XaqoHapN: see what next follows.
XuqoHapN and XaqoHapN↓ An unripe date altering in redness, (Ḳ,) or altered to redness. (Aṣ, TA.)
And the former signifies The [ruddy] colour termed Xuqorap. (O, Ḳ.)
Hul-apN XuqaHiy-apN A red [dress, or garment, such as is termed] Hul-ap: (Ḳ:) the latter word being a rel. n. from XuqoHapN meaning “an unripe date altering to redness.” (TA.)
XaqiyHN: see 1, in three places.
OaXoqaHu Red; (TA;) or [of a ruddy colour;] i. q. OaXoqaru: (O, Ḳ, TA:) so says AḤát. (TA.)
[Hence,] ragowapN XaqoHaMCu [Forth, app. of milk,] that is not of a pure white hue, (O, Ḳ, TA,) but coloured. (TA.)
maXoquwHN: see 1, in two places.

1. Xaqica, aor. _a {yaXoqacu}, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. XaqacN, (Ṣ, M, L,) He scarcely ever, or never, slept, and had a malignant eye, affecting, or hurting, others, therewith: (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ:*) or he had a strong, or powerful, eye, quickly affecting or hurting [others therewith]. (M, L, Ḳ.)
And Xaqica, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXoqacu}; (Ḳ;) and Xaqaca, aor. _i {yaXoqicu}; (L, Ḳ;) He went away, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) and went far off, (Ṣ, L,) being driven away. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
3. XAqchu, (Ṣ, L,) inf. n. muXaAqacapN, (Ḳ,) He regarded him, or treated him, with enmity, or hostility. (Ṣ L, Ḳ.)
4. AXqchu, (inf. n. UiXoqaAcN, L,) He drove him away. (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ.)
XaqocN: see XaqacaAnN, in three places.
XufocN: see XaqacaAnN, in four places:
and see also XaqacN.
XiqocN: see XaqacaAnN, in three places.
XaqacN: see XaqacaAnN.
maA bihi XaqacN walaA naqacN There is not in him any motion. (IAạr, Ṣ, L.)

And, (L, Ḳ, in the CK mA bh XaqocN wlA naqocN,) as also mA bh XuqocN↓ wlA nuqocu, (Ḳ,) There is not in it (namely, a commodity, or household furniture, L) any fault, or defect: and there is not in it (namely, language, or speech, L) any defect, imperfection, or unsoundness. (L, Ḳ.*)
And maA lahu XaqacN walaA naqacN He possesses not anything. (L, Ḳ.)
And maA duwnahu XaqacN walaA naqacN There is not anything to be feared, nor anything to be disliked, in the way to the attainment thereof. (Meyd, TA.)
XaqicN: see XaqacaAnN, in six places.
XuqacN: see XaqacaAnN, in two places.
XiqacN: see XaqacaAnN, in the latter half.
XiqocapN and XaqicapN: see XaqacaAnN, near the end; the latter, in two places.
XaqacaI: see what next follows.
EuqaAbN XaqocaMCu An eagle vehemently hungry, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) and eager in seeking food; (M, L;) as also XaqacaI↓. (Ḳ.) A poet likens a horse thereto. (M, L.)
XiqocaAnN, as a sing. n.: see XaqacaAnN (of which it is also a pl.), in two places, near the end.

hom.sense: XaqacaAnN One who scarcely ever, or never, sleeps; (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ;) as also XaqicN↓; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and who has a malignant eye, (Ṣ, M,) affecting, or hurting, others therewith; as also XaqicN↓ (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, in the TA XaqocN,) and XaqiycN↓: (M:) or who has a strong, or powerful, eye, quickly affecting or hurting [others therewith]; (M, L, Ḳ;) as also XaqicN↓ and XaqiycN↓: (M:) and Xaqicu↓ AlEayoni one who scarcely ever, or never, sleeps; whom drowsiness does not overcome. (T, L.)
Also Driven away, and remote; and so XaqicN↓. (L.)
And XaqacaAnapN A light-spirited woman: (Th, M, L:) foul, or obscene, in her speech; clamorous, and foul-tongued. (T, L.)

Also The male chameleon; (M, L, Ḳ;) and so XaqicN↓ and XiqocN↓ and XuqocN↓: or all these words signify a slender and compact male chameleon, with a small head, that cleaves to the trunk of the kind of tree called EiDaAh: (M, L:) pl. XiqocaAnN (M, L, Ḳ) and XaqaAcaI: (M:) the former pl. like kirowaAnN, pl. of karawaAnN; (L;) and also used as a sing., meaning a male chameleon; (Th, M;) thus used by a poetess; (M:) also XiqocN↓ (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ) and XuqocN↓ (M, L) and XuqacN↓ (M, L, Ḳ) and XaqocN↓ (Ḳ) the young one of a chameleon: (Lḥ, Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ:) pl. XiqocaAnN (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ) and XaqaAcaI: (M, L, Ḳ:) the former pl. like SinowaAnN, pl. of SinowN. (Ṣ.) A poet says, describing asses,
faraEato bihaA Hat-aI UicaA
raOati AlX-aqaAcaI taSoTaliI
And they pastured therein until the heat became vehement and they saw the male chameleons thirsty, desiring to go to water, and repairing to the sun: some say, that XqAcI here signifies moths, (faraAX), but this is a mistake. (M, L.) XiqocaAnN also signifies The animals called Dab- and waral and TuHan and saAm-u OaboraS and das-aAsap: and the sing. is XiqocapN↓: (M, L:) or any small animals that creep or walk upon the earth, and venomous or noxious reptiles and the like: (M, L, Ḳ:) sing. XaqicapN↓ (M, L) and XiqacN↓, (M,) or XaqicN↓, (L,) and XuqacN↓, (M,) or XaqacN↓; (L;) but it does not appear how XaqicapN↓ can be a sing. of XiqocaAnN unless the augmentative letter be regarded as elided. (M, L.)
Also The wolf; (M, L, Ḳ;) and so XaqocaAnN↓ (Th, M, L, Ḳ) and XuqocN↓, (M, L,) or XiqocN↓, (Ḳ,) or XaqocN↓. (TA.)
Also The hawk; syn. SaqorN; (M, L;) and so XaqocaAnN↓ (Th, M, L) and XuqocN↓, (M, L,) or XaqocN↓. (TA.)
And XiqocaAnN [the pl.] also signifies The young ones of the kinds of birds called HbaAraI and qaTFA (M, L, Ḳ) and the like. (M, L.)

entry.sense: XaqiycN: see XaqacaAnN, in two places.
TarodN miXoqacN A driving far away. (M, L.)

1. Xaqira, aor. _a {yaXoqaru}, inf. n. XaqarN (M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ [in the CK and TA XaqorN, which is evidently wrong,]) and XuqorapN, (Lth, Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (M;) and Xaqura; and AiXoqar-a↓; (M, Ḳ;) He was, or became, of the colour termed XuqorapN. (M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
9: see 1.
XaqorN: see XuquwrN.

XaqirN [The red, or blood-coloured, anemone;] i. q. XaqaAYiqu Aln-uEomaAni: (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) it is not a sweet-scented flower: (Mṣb:) n. un. with p {XaqirapN}; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) pl. [of the n. un.] XaqiraAtN: (Ḳ:)
as also Xuq-aArN↓ and XaqiraAnN↓, (so in some copies of the Ḳ,) the latter so written by IDrd and Ṣgh, and thought by IDrd to be a place or a plant, (TA,) or XuqoraAnN↓, (so in some copies of the Ḳ and in the TA,) and Xuq-aAraI↓ and XuqaAraI↓: (Ḳ:) or XaqirN is the name of a certain other plant, not the XqAYq, but red like it: (M,* Ḳ,* TA:) or it signifies cinnabar: (A:) or XaqirapN has this signification, (T, Ḳ,) as well as that first assigned to it above: (Ḳ:) and accord. to AḤn, (M, TA,) Xuq-aAraI↓ is the name of a certain plant (Ṣ, M, TA) that grows is sands, having a pungent odour, which is tasted in the flavour of milk: and he adds that, accord. to some, it is the same as the Xaqir; but that this opinion is not well founded: (M, TA:) it is also said that it is a certain plant having a flower of a dingy red colour, the seed, or grain, of which is called ximoximN: (TA:) and that Xuq-aAraI↓ (M, TA) and XuqaAraI↓, (M,) or Xuq-aArN↓, (TA,) are names of a certain plant, having a flower of a colour somewhat of that termed XukolapN, with slender, or delicate, dust-coloured leaves, which grows in the manner of qaDob [a kind of trefoil], is approved in pasturage, and grows only in fruitful years. (M, TA.)
jaMCa biAlX-uqari waAlbuqari: see jMC biAlS-uqari waAlbuqari, in art. Sqr.
XuqorapN The colours described in the explanations of the epithet OaXoqaru, below. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, &c.)
XaqiraAnN, or XuqoraAnN: see XaqirN.
Xaqir-aAqN and its vars.: see in art. Xqrq.
XaquwrN: see the next paragraph, in four places.

XuquwrN (AHeyth, Fr, AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ) and XaquwrN↓ (AHeyth, Aṣ, Abu-l-Jarráh, Ṣ, Ḳ) A want; or a needful, or requisite, thing, affair, or business: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the former signifies wants: (Ḥam p. 716:) AʼObeyd says that the former word is the more correct, because XuquwrN signifies things, or affairs, that cleave to the heart, disquieting it; and is pl. of XaqorN↓; and that XaquwrN↓, with fet-ḥ, has the signification of an epithet [meaning cleaving to the heart and disquieting it]: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to some, this latter signifies grief, mourning, sorrow, or sadness; disquietude of mind: or disquietude of mind that causes one to be sleepless: the former is also expl. as signifying a man's case, and his secret: and ↓both are also said to signify tidings: and a man's state, or condition. (TA.) One says, Oaxobarotuhu biXuquwriI I acquainted him with my want; like as one says OafoDayotu Uilayohi biEujariI wabujariI: (Ṣ:) or I acquainted him with my tidings. (TA.) And OafoDayotu Uilayohi biXuquwriI I acquainted him with my case, and with what I kept secret from others; (TA;) and so nafaDotu lahu XuquwriI: (Ḥam p. 716:) or I revealed to him my secret, and acquainted him with all my affairs. (Mgh.) And bav-ahu Xaquwrahu↓, and Xuquwrahu, He complained to him of his state, or condition. (M, TA.)

hom.sense: XuqaAraI: see XaqirN, in two places:
and see also jaMCa biAlS-uqari waAlbuqari, in art. Sqr.

entry.sense: Xuq-aArN: see XaqirN, in two places.
Xuq-aAraI: see XaqirN, in three places.

OaXoqaru, applied to a man, [Of a ruddy complexion combined with fairness: or] of a clear ruddy complexion, with the outer skin inclining to white: (Ṣ:) or having a red, or ruddy, tinge, over a white, or fair, complexion: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and applied to a horse, [of a sorrel colour;] of a clear red colour, (Ṣ, IF, Mṣb,) or of a red colour inclining to [the dull red hue called] mugorapN, (M, Ḳ,) with a red mane and tail: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) when the mane and tail are black, the epithet kumayotN [meaning bay, or dark bay, or brown,] is applied to the horse: (Ṣ:) the AXqr is said to be the best of horses: (IAạr, M: [but it is said in Ḥar p. 399 to be regarded by the Arabs as of evil omen:]) and applied to a camel, intensely red: (Ṣ:) or of a colour resembling that of a horse thus termed: (M:) fem. XaqoraMCu: and pl. XuqorN. (Mṣb.)
Also, applied to blood, That has become thick, (maA SaAra EalaqFA, M, Mṣb, TA,) and not been overspread with dust. (Mṣb, TA.)
And the fem., XaqoraMCu, is used as [a subst.] signifying Fire. (Ḥam p. 718.)

Xaqir-aAqN and Xiqir-aAqN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former accord. to IAạr, (Th, TA,) the latter accord. to Fr, (TA,) but disallowed by IḲt, and asserted by him to be a mispronunciation of the vulgar, (Mṣb,) and XiqoraAqN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and XaqoraAqN, (accord. to the CK,) and, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) as they sometimes said, (Ṣ, O,) XiriqoraAqN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and XaraqoraAqN, and XaraqoraqN, (Ḳ,) [the first and second now applied to The green wood-pecker, picus viridis: and to the common roller, coracias garrula:] a certain bird, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) well known, (Ḳ,) among the Arabs, (Fr, TA,) called Oaxoyal, (Fr, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, TA,) [a name likewise now applied to the green wood-pecker,] and regarded by the Arabs as of evil omen; (Ṣ;) less than the pigeon, the colour of which is green, and the beak black, and having blackness in the extremities and exterior of its wings: (Mṣb:) accord. to IAạr, the Xaqir-aAq is with the Arabs the OaxoTab [q. v.]: (TA:) accord. to the Ḳ, or Xqr-Aq and XrqrAq accord. to Lth, (TA,) a certain bird speckled, or spotted, with green and red and white (Ḳ, TA) and black, (TA,) and found, accord. to the copies of the Ḳ, in the land of the Haram, but correctly, as in the words of Lth, bArD Aljrm, thus, with j, [perhaps rightly biAlOaroDi Aljaromi, in the land that is hot, or very hot,] in the places in which palm-trees grow; of the size of the hudohud [or hoopoe]: accord. to Lḥ, Xqr-Aq is of the measure fEl-Al: XrqrAq is mentioned by J and Ṣgh [as well as in the Ḳ] in the present art.; but should, properly, be mentioned under the head of Xrqrq, as it is in the L. (TA.)

2. Xq-Shu, (L, TA,) inf. n. taXoqiySN, (L, Mgh, Ḳ,) He divided it into parts, or portions: (Mgh:) or he cut it up, and separated its members (A, L, Ḳ *) into just portions among the sharers; (L, Ḳ;*) namely, a slaughtered animal, (Ḳ,) or particularly a slaughtered sheep or goat, and a pig: (L, A, TA:) or he divided it (namely, a pig,) into parts or portions, and members, for eating and selling. (Mgh.) Hence the trad. mano baAEa Alxamora faloyuXaqiSi AlxanaAziyra (L, A) He who sells wine, let him cut up swine and divide their members, as is done to a sheep or goat when its flesh is sold: meaning, he who holds the selling of wine to be lawful, let him hold the selling of swine to be so; for they are equally forbidden. (L, TA.)

XiqoSN A piece, or part, of a thing; (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb;) as also XaqiySN↓: (M, Mgh:) or a little, of much; (M, TA;) as also ↓the latter: (IDrd, M, Ḳ:) and ↓the latter, a little, or paltry, thing: (TA:) and the former, a piece of land: (Ṣ:) or a share; syn. sahomN, (A, Ḳ,) or HaZ-N, (M,) and naSiybN, (A, Mgh, Ḳ,) and XirokN, (A, Ḳ,) which signifies the same as naSiybN; (Sh, on the authority of Khálid;) as also XaqiySN↓; (Sh, M, Mgh, Ḳ;) like niSofN and naSiyfN: (M:) as, for instance, in property; (IDrd;) and of a slave: (TA:) or a certain share not divided: (EshSháfi'ee, TA:) or if divided it may also be thus called: (Az, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaXoqaASN (M, Mṣb) and [of mult.] XiqaASN. (M, TA.)

hom.sense: XaqiySN: see XiqoSN, throughout.
Also A sharer, or partner. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) You say, huwa XaqiySI He is my sharer, or partner, (Ṣ, A,) in a piece of land. (Ṣ.)
And A fleet, or swift, and excellent horse: (Ḳ:) but an epithet not known to Lth. (TA.)

entry.sense: miXoqaSN A broad naSol [or iron head] (IDrd, Mṣb, Ḳ) of an arrow: (IDrd:) or an arrow having such a nSl, (Lth, IF, Ḳ,) with which wild animals are shot; (Lth;) but Az says that this explanation is at variance with what has been heard from the Arabs: (TA:) or it signifies, (M,) or signifies also, (Ḳ,) a long nSl; (M, Ḳ;) not a broad one: (M:) or an arrow having such a nSl; (M;) with which wild animals are shot: (Ḳ:) or a long and broad nSl: (Ṣ:) or it is of half the size of a nSl, and is worthless; children play with it, and it is the worst kind of arrow [-head], and is used for shooting at objects of the chase and any other thing: (TA:) pl. maXaAqiSu. (Ṣ.)
muXaqiSN A butcher. (A, Ḳ.)

hom.sense:
1. XaqiIa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) originally Xaqiwa, (Ṣ, TA,) aor. _a {yaXoqawu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) dual thereof yaXoqayaAni, (Ṣ,) inf. n. XaqaAwapN and XiqaAwapN, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) the latter accord. to a reading of the Ḳur xxiii. 108, (Ṣ,) and XaqaMCN and XiqowapN and XaqowapN (Ṣ,* Ḳ) and XaqFA, (Ḳ.) or the last of these is the inf. n., and XaqaAwapN and XiqowapN [and the rest, none of which is expressly specified as an inf. n. in the Ṣ,] are simple substs., (Mṣb,) He was, or became, unprosperous, unfortunate, unhappy, or miserable; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;)
XaqiIa being contr. of saEida; (Mṣb;) and XaqaAwapN, &c. contr. of saEaAdapN: (Ṣ, TA:) or he was, or became, in a state of straitness, distress, adversity, or difficulty. (Az, Ḳ, TA.) [See also XaqaAwapN below.]
Also † He suffered, or experienced, fatigue, (TA, and Ksh and Bḍ and Jel in xx. 1,) fiI kacaA [in such a thing]. (TA.)
XaqaAhu: see 3:
and 4.

entry.sense: 3. XAqAhu, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. muXaAqaApN (Ṣ, TA) and XiqaMCN, (TA,) He laboured, strove, or struggled, with him, to prevail, or overcome, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) in war, or battle, and the like; (Ḳ, TA;) so in the T; (TA;) he struggled, or contended, with, or against, the difficulty, or trouble, or inconvenience, that he experienced from him; (Ṣ,* TA;) syn. EaAlajahu; (Ḳ, TA;) or maArasahu; and EaAnaAhu. (Ṣ,* TA.)

And XAqAhu faXaqaAhu↓, aor. of the latter verb _u, He endeavoured to surpass him in mutual labouring, or striving, or struggling, to prevail, or overcome,, &c., (gaAlabahu fiI AlX-iqaMCi, [in the CK, fI AlX-aqACi, but the former seems to be the right reading, and may be best rendered in the mutual striving against difficulty,]) and he surpassed him [therein]. (Ḳ. [In the Ṣ, XaAqaAniI fulaAnN faXaqawotuhu, aor. OaXoquwhu; and only the latter verb as thus used is there explained.])
muXaAqaApN signifies also † The treating [one] with hardness, harshness, or illnature. (TA.)

And ‡ The vying, one with another, in patience, or endurance: a rájiz says,
UicaA yuXaAqiI AlS-aAbiraAni lamo yarivo
yakaAdu mino DaEofi AlquwaI laA yanobaEivo
[When the two patient ones vie in endurance, he does not lag behind, almost, by reason of the weakness of powers, failing to hasten in pace]: he means a camel vying with the attendant thereof in endurance of going. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. AXqAhu Qll-ehu God caused him to be unprosperous, unfortunate, unhappy, or miserable; contr. of OasoEadahu: (Ṣ,* Mṣb, TA:) or God caused him to be in a state of straitness, distress, adversity, or difficulty: and so XaqaAhu↓. (Ḳ.)
And AXqI He combed. (AZ, Ḳ. [See miXoqFI.])

entry.sense: XiqowapN an inf. n. of XaqiIa, as also XaqowapN: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) or a simple subst. (Mṣb.)

XaqiI-N Unprosperous, unfortunate, unhappy, or miserable: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) [or in a state of straitness, distress, adversity, or difficulty: (see its verb:)] pl. OaXoqiyaMCu. (TA.) walamN Oakuno biduEaAYika rab-i Xaqiy-FA, in the Ḳur [xix. 4, And I have not been, in supplicating Thee, my Lord, unprosperous], means I have been one whose prayer has been answered. (TA.)

XaqaAwapN an inf. n. of XaqiIa; (Ṣ,* Ḳ;) or a simple subst.; (Mṣb;) signifying Unprosperousness,, &c.; [see its verb {1};] contr. of saEaAdapN: (Ṣ, Er-Rághib, TA:) it is of two kinds; OuxoraAwiy-apN [relating to the world to come] and dunoyaAwiy-apN [relating to the present world]: and the latter is of three kinds; nafosiy-apN [relating to the soul] and badaniy-apN [relating to the body] and xaArijiy-apN [relating to external circumstances]. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
Also † Fatigue; syn. taEabN; but the latter has a more general signification; every XqAwp being tEb, but every tEb is not XqAwp. (TA.)
OaXoqaI [More, and most, unprosperous,, &c.]
[And] ‡ More [and most] fatigued. (TA.)
miXoqFI A comb: a dial. var. of miXoqaON. (AZ, Ḳ.)

1. XaqaI, inf. n. XaqoIN, said of the naAb [or tush] of a camel, It grew forth: a dial. var. of XaqaOa. (Ḳ in art. Xqw [but belonging to the present art.: mentioned in the TA, as not in the Ḳ, on the authority of ISd].)
[Freytag states, as on the authority of Abu-l-ʼAlà, that XaqaI is used for Xaq-a He clave, or split,, &c.:]
[and that Reiske has explained it as signifying He opened the mouth with a wide grinning (“amplo rictu”).]

XaAqK A long prominence, or projecting portion, or ledge, (HayodN TaAliEN TawiylN,) of a mountain, (Ḳ, TA,) that cannot be ascended: (TA:) by rule it should be with C [i. e. XaAqiYN, as being derived from XaqaOa]: (Ṣgh, TA:) pl. XawaAqiI (Ḳ [correctly XawaAqK]) and XuqoyaAnN. (TA. [Mentioned in the Ḳ in art. Xqw, but belonging to the present art.])

hom.sense: 1. Xak-a is intrans. by itself, and trans. by means of the particle fI:
one says Xak-a AlOamoru, aor. yaXuk-u [contr. to analogy in the case of an intrans. verb of this class], inf. n. Xak-N, The thing, or case, or affair, was, or became, dubious, or confused: (Mṣb:)
Xak-a EalaI-a AlOamoru means Xaq-a [i. e. The case, or affair, was difficult, hard, distressing,, &c., to me]: (O, TA:) or, as some say, [was such that] I doubted (Xakakotu) respecting it. (TA.)

Xak-a said of a camel, (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) He limped, or halted; or had a slight lameness, (IAạr, Ṣ, TA,) of his hind leg: (IAạr, TA:) or his arm stuck to his side, (Ḳ, TA,) and he had a slight lameness in consequence thereof: (TA:) and AXtk-↓, likewise said of a camel, he had a slight lameness; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, TA;) like Xak-a. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O.)

Xak-N also signifies The cleaving or sticking [of a thing to another thing]. (Ṣ, O, TA.) So in a verse of Aboo-Dahbal El-Jumahee cited voce yalabN. (Ṣ.) And one says, Xak-ati Alr-aHimu The relationship was, or became, closely united. (O, TA. [See raHimN XaAk-apN, voce XaAk-N.])

Xak-a fiI Als-ilaAHi, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He put on [or around him,] or attired himself with, the arms, or weapons, completely, not leaving any of them; (TA;) [as though] he entered amid them. (Ḳ, TA.)

Xakakotuhu biAlr-umoHi, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, in the Ḳ Xak-ahu,) and biAls-ahomi, and the like, aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (Mṣb, TA,) I pierced, or transpierced, him, or it, (TaEanotuhu, Mṣb, or xazaqotuhu, O, and in like manner in the TA, but in my copies of the Ṣ xaraqotuhu [meaning I made a hole in him, or it], and thus in one place in the TA, and AinotaZamotuhu, Ṣ O, and in like manner in the Ḳ,) with the spear, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and with the arrow,, &c.: (TA:) but IDrd says that, accord. to some, Xak-N is only by the conjoining two things with an arrow or a spear: (O, TA:) [thus,] faXak-a rijolahu maEa rikaAbihi means And he clave and transpierced his leg, or foot, together with his stirrup. (Mgh.)
[Hence,] Xakakotu Uilayohi AlbilaAda I traversed, or crossed, or cut through, the countries, or districts, to him. (O, TA.)
And Xuk-a Ealayih Alv-awobu The garment was put [or drawn] together upon him, and fastened with a thorn or a wooden pin: or was let down, or made to hang down, upon him. (TA.)
Xak-uwA buyuwtahumo They placed their tents in one row, or series, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in one regular order, (T, TA,) near together. (Mṣb.)
Hence; Xak-uwA AlOaroHaAma They made the relationships to be closely connected. (Mṣb.) And Xuk-a He was made, or asserted, to be connected with the lineage of another. (IAạr, O.)
And Xakakotuhu said of anything means I drew and joined, or adjoined, it [to another thing]. (Mṣb.) [And I infixed it in, or thrust it into, another thing.]

maA Xak-a kafiI xaliyluhaA, [or, more probably, mA Xuk-a,] a phrase in a verse of El-Farezdaḳ, [in which it forms an apodosis,] means maA qaArana [i. e., app., Its friend (the sword, or the spear, both of which are meanings of Alxaliyl,) would not be conjoined (or grasped) with my hand]. (TA.)
Xak-a Alv-awoba He (the sewer) made the stitch-holes far apart [in sewing the garment, or piece of cloth]. (O, TA.) [Thus the verb has two contr. meanings.]

Xakikotu Uilayohi, with kesr, and Xakikotuhu, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, and so in the Ḳ accord. to the TA, as also in the TḲ, in the CK and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ Xakakotuhu and Alyh,) I inclined to him, or it; or trusted to, or relied upon, him, or it, so as to be, or become, easy, or quiet, in mind; or leaned, rested, or relied, upon him, or it; syn. rakanotu. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. Xk-knI fiyhi, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,*) inf. n. taXokiykN, (O,) He made me to doubt, to waver or vacillate in opinion, or to be uncertain, respecting it; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) he threw me, or made me to fall, into doubt,, &c., respecting it. (O.)
5: see the first paragraph {1}.
8: see the first paragraph {1}.

hom.sense:
Xak-N [used as a subst.] signifies Doubt; (Mṣb; [see 1;]) or the contr. of yaqiynN; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;)
by which explanation is meant a wavering or vacillation in opinion between two things, whether they be equal [in probability] or such that one of them outweighs [therein] the other; or, as the expositors explain its meaning in the Ḳur x. 94, uncertainty: (Mṣb:) or a wavering or vacillation in opinion, between two inconsistent things, without making either of them to outweigh the other in the estimation of him who conceives the Xak-: or, as some say, a pausing, or hesitation, between two extremes that are equal [in probability], without the mind's inclining to either of them: when one of them is made to outweigh, without the other's being rejected, it is Zan-N: (KT:) accord. to Er-Rághib, it is the alternation, or confusedness, of two inconsistent things, in the judgment of a man, and their being equal: this is sometimes because of there being two indications, equal in his judgment, of the two inconsistent things; or of there being no indication thereof: and sometimes it relates to the question whether a thing be, or be not; and sometimes, to the question of what kind it is; and sometimes, to some of its qualities; and sometimes, to the accident that is the cause of its being: it is a species of jahol; but is more special than this; for jhl is sometimes the utter nonexistence of knowledge of the two inconsistent things; so that every Xk- is jhl, but every jhl is not Xk-: (TA:) accord. to some, the primary meaning is a state of commotion, or disturbance, of the heart and mind: (Mṣb:) pl. XukuwkN. (Ḳ.)

[Hence, yawomu AlX-aki The day of which one doubts whether it be the last of one month or the first of the next month: and generally, whether it be the last of Shaabán or the first of Ramadán; and to fast on this day is forbidden.]
Also A small crack in a bone. (Ḳ.)
And A seam, or line of sewing, of a garment. (L in art. SwH.)
[And accord. to Freytag, A coat of mail composed of narrow rings: but he names no authority for this.]

And [Arsenic;] a certain medicament, that destroys rats; brought from Khurásán, from the mines of silver; (Ḳ, TA;) of two kinds, (TA,) white and yellow; (Ḳ, TA;) now known by the name of sam-u AlfaOori [ratsbane]. (TA.)

entry.sense: Xik-N A covering (Hul-ap) that is put upon the backs of the two curved extremities of the bow: (Ḳ:) so says ISd. (TA.)
Xak-apN [an inf. n. of un.] A single piercing through two men on a horse. (Ḥam p. 271.)
Xuk-apN i. q. Xuq-apN: (O, Ḳ:) so in the saying, Uin-ah labaEiydu AlX-uk-api [Verily he is one whose region to which he directs himself is far distant]. (O.)

hom.sense: Xik-apN Arms, or weapons, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) that are worn. (TA.)

And A broad piece of wood, (Ḳ,) or small broad piece of wood, (Ṣ, O,) that is put into the hole (xurot) [in which is inserted the end of the handle] of the axe, or adz, and the like, in order to narrow it. (IDrd, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
rajulN muxotalifu AlX-ik-api means A man discordant in natural dispositions. (TA.)

entry.sense: XakikN A camel having a slight lameness; that limps, or halts. (TA.)

hom.sense: XukukN, with two dammehs, [a pl. of which the sing., in the sense here indicated, is not mentioned,] i. q.
