[See also 10.] Accord. to IAạr and several others, one says, OaXolayotu Alkaloba EalaI AlS-ayodi, meaning I incited, or urged, the dog [against the object, or objects, of the chase]; like Oagorayotuhu in measure and in signification: (Mgh, ast; Mṣb, TA:) but this is disallowed by ISk, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) and by Th; (Ṣ, Mgh, TA;) and in like manner, AXlythu biAlS-ayodi in the same sense; though they are allowed by others: one says, however, [by common consent,] OaXolayotu Alkaloba lilS-ayodi, meaning I called the dog to the chase. (Mgh.)
8: see the next paragraph {10}, in two places.

hom.sense: 10. AstXlAhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AXtlAhu↓, (Ṣ,* Ḳ, [accord. to my copies of the former, OaXolaAhu, but a verse immediately following as an ex. shows the right reading,]) He called him in order to save him, or rescue him, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or to make him come forth, (Ṣ,) from straitness, or perdition, (Ḳ,) or from a place: (Ṣ:) this is the primary signification. (TA.)
And [hence] the former, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and ↓the latter also, (Ṣ, TA, i. e. AXtlAhu, [thus in this instance in the copies of the Ṣ,]) ‡ He saved him, or rescued him. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
And AstXlI He (a man, TA) was, or became, angry. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: XalFA: see the next paragraph.

XilowN A limb, or member; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also XilowapN↓: (TA:) or a limb, or member, of flesh-meat: whence, in a trad., AytiniI biXilowihaA AlOayomani [Bring thou to me its right limb]: (Ṣ:) pl. OaXolaMCN (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) and OaXolK, [originally OaXoluwN,] like OadolK pl. of dalowN. (TA.)

And The body of anything [i. e. of any animal]: as also XalFA↓; (Ḳ;) which latter is expl. by ISd as signifying the skin and body of anything; and is applied in a trad. to the inner side of a haunch as meaning having no flesh upon it: (TA:) [or,] accord. to IDrd, Xilowu AlUinosaAni signifies the body of the man after its wasting, or decaying: (Mṣb, TA:) [or] OaXolaMCu AlUinosaAni means the members, or limbs, of the man after wasting, or decaying, and becoming dissundered: (Ṣ, TA:) and (hence, Mṣb) one says, banuw fulaAnK OaXolaMCN fiI baniI fulaAnK, meaning † The sons of such a one are remains among the sons of such a one: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and huwa mino OaXolaMCi Alqawomi † He is of the remains of the people: [for] XilowN signifies † a remain, or remaining portion: and XlI- [app. XuliI-N, said to be like gnI-, but this is, I doubt not, a mistranscription for EuniI-N, i. e. originally of the measure fuEuwlN, is another pl. of XilowN, and] signifies † remains of any thing. (TA.) [See also Xaliy-apN.]

Also Any skinned animal of which somewhat has been eaten and a portion remains: (Ḳ:) or a portion remaining, whether much or little, of a sheep or goat of which part has been eaten: (L voce saliyxN:) pl. OaXolaMCN. (Ḳ.)

And OaXolaMCu All-ijaAmi † The straps, or thongs, of the bit or bridle: (A, Ḳ:) or such as have become old, and of which the iron appertenance has become slender, (Ḳ, TA,) or, as in the M, [of which] the iron appertenances [have become slender], without straps, or thongs: app. likened to limbs, or members, of flesh-meat. (TA.)
XilowapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Xaliy-apN A piece, or portion, of flesh-meat, &c. (Ḳ,* TA.)

And † A remnant, or remaining portion; (Ḳ, TA;) only of property: (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA:) pl. XalaAyaA. (Ṣ, TA.) One says, cahabato maAXiyapu fulaAnK wabaqiyato lahu Xaliy-apN † [The cattle of such a one went away, but a remnant remained to him]. (AZ, Ṣ.) [See also XilowN.]
muXal-FI Lean, or light of flesh: (Ḳ, TA:) an epithet applied to a man. (TA.)
maXaAlK, in the dial. of El-Ḥijáz, The Things, or instruments, with which scarification is performed upon the cheeks: app. pl. of miXolaApN. (TA.)

AlX-aloyaAqu A certain northern constellation, [namely, Lyra,] consisting of ten stars, the bright star [alpha] of which is called Aln-asoru AlwaAqiEu: the Arabs liken it to a vulture (nasor) which has contracted its wings to itself, as though it had alighted upon a thing: the vulgar call [the three chief stars in] it AlOavaAfiI: and before the bright star is a dim star which the Arabs call AlOaZofaAr [i. e. the talons]. (Ḳzw. [Not in any of my Lexicons.])

hom.sense: 1. Xamimotu, aor. OaXam-u; and Xamamotu, aor. OaXum-u; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the latter mentioned by AO; (Ṣ, TA;) third pers. of each Xam-a; (Mgh;) inf. n. Xam-u (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XamiymN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which are of both verbs, (TA,) and Xim-iymaI, mentioned by Z (Ḳ, TA) alone; (TA;) I smelt, i. e. perceived by the nose, (Ḳ,) a thing, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) or an odour; (Mgh;) and AiXotamamotu↓ signifies the same; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA; [AaXomamotuhu in the CK is a mistranscription for AiXotamamotuhu;]) and taXam-amotu↓ also, (Ḳ,) and Xam-ayotu↓, thus in the copies of the Ḳ, but correctly Xam-amotu↓: (TA: [both, however, are mentioned in the CK: the former like qaS-ayotu for qaS-aSotu:]) or taXam-amotu↓ AlX-aIoCa signifies Xamimotuhu fiI muholapK [I smelt the thing leisurely, or gently]: (Ṣ, TA:) or tXm-m↓ AlX-aIoCa and AXtm-hu↓ both signify he put the thing near to his nose in order that he might draw in its odour. (AḤn, TA.)
See an ex. in a prov. mentioned voce ximaArN.
[Hence,] Xum-a † He was tried, or proved by trial or experiment or experience; syn. Auxotubira. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
Xam-a, see. pers. Xamimota, aor. yaXam-u, (Mṣb,) inf. n. XamamN, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,*) He (a man) was high, or elevated, in the nose. (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ.*)
[And hence,] Xam-a, (Ḳ,) [sec. pers. Xamimota,] inf. n. XamamN, (TA,) ‡ He (a man, TA) magnified himself; or behaved proudly, or haughtily. (Ḳ, TA. [And AXm- has a similar meaning.])
[This verb is also probably used in other senses, said of a mountain, &c.: see XamamN below.]
See also 4, near the end.

entry.sense: 2. Xam-amotu and Xam-ayotu: see above {1}, in two places.
3. XaAm-aA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muXaAm-apN, (Ṣ, TA,) They smelt each other; (Ṣ,* Ḳ;) as also tXAm-A↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taXaAm-N. (Ṣ.)

[Hence,] XaAmimohu ‡ Look thou to see what is with him, or in his mind, (maA Einodahu, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and draw near to him, (Ḳ, TA,) and seek after the knowledge of what is with him, or in his mind, (mA Endh,) by means of informations and disclosure; as though each smelt what was with the other in order to act according thereto. (TA.) And hence the saying, XaAmamonaAhumo vum-a naAwaXonaAhumo ‡ [We endeavoured, or looked, to ascertain their condition; then we engaged them in near, though not close, conflict]. (TA.) You say also, XaAmamotu Alr-ajula meaning [simply] † I drew near to the man. (Ṣ.) muXaAm-apN [used tropically] signifies † The looking into a thing. (KL.) And † The approaching the enemy so that the two parties see each other. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 4. AXm-hu Uiy-aAhu He made him to smell it, or perceive it by the nose. (Ḳ.) You say, OaXomamotuhu AlTiyba [I made him to smell the perfume]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

And [hence] one says to the prefect, or governor, or prince, or commander, OaXomimoniI yadaka Ouqab-ilohaA † [Suffer me to approach thy hand that I may kiss it]; (Ṣ,* TA;) a phrase like naAwiloniI yadaka, (TA,) but better than the latter phrase: so says Kh. (Ṣ.)

And AXm- AlxitaAna, and AXm-t AlbaZora, ‡ He, and she, i. e. the operator, took, (Ḳ, TA,) or cut off, (TA,) a small portion of the prepuce, and of the baZor [q. v.]: (Ḳ, TA:) or the latter signifies she cut off a portion of the nawaAp [q. v.], not extirpating it. (TA.)

And AXm- AlHarofa, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) inf. n. UiXomaAmN, (Ṣ,) † He made the consonant to have a smack of the ḍammeh or the kesreh, (lit., made it to smell, Ṣ, or to taste, Ḳ, the ḍammeh or the kesreh,) in such a manner (Ṣ, Ḳ) that the UiXomaAm, (Ṣ,) or that the ḍammeh or kesreh, (Ḳ,) was not heard, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) what is termed UiXomaAmu AlHarofi being less than what is termed rawomu AlHarakapi, the former being apparent only by the motion of the lip, (Ṣ,) or of the upper lip, (so in one of my copies of the Ṣ,) no account being taken of it, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. of the ḍammeh or kesreh, (Ḳ,) it not being reckoned as a Harakap because of its feebleness, the consonant in this case being quiescent or like that which is quiescent, (Ṣ,) and the prosodical measure not being broken thereby: (Ḳ:) for ex., in the following verse,
mataI OanaAmu laA yuWar-iqoniI AlkariI
layolFA walaA OasomaEu OajoraAsa AlmaTiI
[meaning AlkariI- and AlmaTiI-, (as is said in one of my copies of the Ṣ,) i. e. When I sleep, he who lets beasts on hire will not render me wakeful by night, nor do I hear the bells of the camels on which people ride], the Arabs [or, as is said in the TA, some of the Arabs] make the q [in yWr-qnI] to have a smack of the ḍammeh; but if you took account of the Harakap of the UiXomaAm [in this case,] the measure of the verse would be broken, [the foot] rqnI AlkrI becoming, in the scanning, mutafaAEiluno, which may be only in the kaAmil; whereas this verse is of the rajaz: (Sb, Ṣ:) another case of UiXomaAm is that of the I in duwayob-apN, [in which that letter is quiescent, but made to have a smack of kesreh,] as is the same letter in every similar case, in a dim. noun, when followed by a doubled letter. (Zj, T in art. db.) Also He pronounced the consonant with a Harakap [or vowel-sound] between damm and kesr, apparent only in utterance, not in writing; as in qiyla and giyDa in the Ḳur xi. 46. (I’Aḳ pp. 130 and 131.) [See also rawomu AlHarakapi, voce raAma.]
[Golius explains AXm- as signifying also “Reduxit, fecit ut converteret se ab aliqua re;” as on the authority of the KL; in my copy of which, however, I do not find this meaning.]

AXm-, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiXomaAmN, [as an intrans. verb,] said of a man, (Ṣ,) also signifies He passed by, or along, raising his head; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and magnified, or exalted, himself; behaved proudly, or disdainfully; or elevated his nose, from pride. (TA. [See also 1, near the end.])

And He turned away from a thing. (Ḳ.) One says bayonaA humo fiI wajohK Uico OaXam-uwA, i. e. [While they were in a certain direction, lo,] they turned away; (Ṣ, TA, as from AA;) or Xam-uwA↓. (Thus in one of my copies of the Ṣ [but I think it to be a mistranscription].) And AXm- Alqawomu The people, or party, deviated in their directions to the right and left: a phrase heard in this sense by AA. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in three places.
6: see 3, first sentence.
8: see 1, in two places.
10. AstXm- He desired to smell. (KL.)
And He perceived a smell, or an odour, from a thing. (KL.)

daxala AlmuxaATu Oanofahu faQsotaXam-ahu faOadoxalahu fiI Haloqihi, said of a man, means AisotanoXaqahu [i. e. ‡ The mucus entered his nose, and he snuffed it up, and made it to pass into his fauces]; the verb being metaphorically thus used, like as AlAisotinoXaAqu is metaphorically used for AlX-am-u. (Mgh.)
XamamN inf. n. of the intrans. verb Xam-a [q. v.]. (Mṣb, TA.)

[Used as a simple subst.,] Highness of the nose: (Mṣb:) or highness of the bone of the nose, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and beauty thereof, (Ḳ,) with evenness, or straightness, of its upper part, (Ṣ, Ḳ, when there is in it a gibbousness it is termed qanFA, Ṣ,) and uprightness of the end, or lowest part: (Ḳ:) or, as some say, this last quality [alone]: (TA:) or length of the end, or lower part, of the nose, so that it extends over the middle of the mustache, (wuruwdu AlOaronabapi,) with beautiful evenness, or straightness, of the bone, and highness thereof greater than the highness that is termed calafN: or length and slenderness of the nose, and a downward extending of its rawovap [i. e. end or tip, or part where the blood that flows from the nostrils drops or drips]: (Ḳ:) or [simply] length in the nose. (Ḥam p. 789.)
And, in a man, The quality of having what is termed XamamN of the nose. (Ṣ.)
[And hence, ‡ Self-magnification, or pride, or haughtiness: see 1, near the end.]
And ‡ Generosity. (Ḥam p. 728.)
Also Highness, (Ḳ,) or tallness of the head, (Ṣ,) of a mountain. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And ‡ Nearness: and ‡ remoteness: thus having two contr. meanings. (Ḳ, TA.) It has both of such meanings in the phrase daAruhu XamamN ‡ [His house, or abode, is near: and, remote]: (Ḳ, TA:) and in the phrase raOayotuhu mino XamamK ‡ [I saw him, or it, from within a short distance: and, from afar]. (TA.)
XamuwmN A thing [odorous, fragrant, or] fit to be smelt. (KL.)
XamiymN High, or elevated: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) applied in this sense to a [camel's saddle such as is called] qatab. (Ṣ.)

Xam-aAmN A sort of melon resembling a small colocynth, [or rather a small melon resembling a colocynth,] streaked with redness and greenness and yellowness: called in Pers. dasotanobuwyah [i. e. “perfume”]; (Ḳ;) originally dasoto buwI [or dasoto buwyaho]: (TA:) its odour is cool, pleasant, lenitive, and narcotic; and the eating of it is laxative to the bowels: (Ḳ:) [The cucumis dudaïm of Linn.; called by Forskål cucumis schemmam: the latter thus describes it (Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. 169): “Caules 5-sulcati, setis rigidis, scandentes, cirrhosi: folia cordato-oblonga, acuta, subsinuata, dentato-repanda, hispida: calyces villosi, molles: flores flavi, conferti in alis: fructus globosoovatus, glaberrimus, magnitudine citri, flavus, maculis inæqualibus, fulvo-ferrugineis, versus polos in lineas confluentibus; pulpa aquosa, seminibus tota plena: fructus juvenis villosus; maturus glaber: odor, fortis nec ingratus; eamque ob caussam cultus; non edulis:” in the present day, the same appellation is applied in Egypt to several species of melon, of pleasant odour and taste; but this application I believe to be of very late origin: see also luf-aAHN: and see De Sacy's “Rel. de l'Égypte par Abd-allatif,” pp. 126-7.]
Xam-aAmaAtN Sweet odours that one smells. (Ḳ.)
XamaAXimu Ripe dates remaining upon the raceme. (AZ, Ḳ.)
[XaAm-N Smelling, or perceiving by the nose.]
yaA Qbona XaAm-api Alwacorapi [O son of her who smells the wacorap] is an expression of reproach. (Ṣ.)
OaXam-u, applied to a man, (Mṣb,) Having that quality of the nose which is termed XamamN; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) or so OaXam-u AlOanofi, thus applied: (Ṣ:) fem. Xam-aMCu: (Mṣb, TA:) and pl. Xum-N. (TA.)
And [hence, ‡ Self-magnifying, or proud, or haughty: or] a chief characterized by disdainfulness, scornfulness, or disdainful and proud incompliance, (Ḳ, TA,) and high-minded. (TA.)
Also A mountain tall, (Ṣ, TA,) or high, (TA,) in the head. (Ṣ, TA.) [And High, as applied to a place of ascent in a mountain: see an ex. of the pl. in a verse cited voce taSad-afa.]
And A shoulder high in the head of its bone. (Ḳ.)
[Freytag mentions two other meanings:]
[“Ventus ex alto veniens, qui penetrantioris est odoratus:”]
[and fem. Xam-aAC “Jugum extensum in monte:” from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.]
muXim-N [Turning away, or averse]. One says, EaraDotu Ealayohi kacaA faUicaA huwa muXim-N laA yuriyduhu [I offered to him such a thing, and lo, he was averse, not desiring it]. (Ṣ.)
[miXam-N An instrument of smelling; like as misomaEN signifies “an instrument of hearing.”]
[Hence, its pl.] maXaAm-u signifies Noses. (KL.)
[This pl. is expl. by Jac. Schultens, as meaning Perfumes (odoramenta): so says Freytag.]
maXomuwmN A thing that is smelt; such as any sweet-smelling plant: like as maOokuwlN signifies “a thing that is eaten:” (Mṣb:) [and] musk: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [pl. maXomuwmaAtN.]

1. Xamita, aor. _a {yaXomatu}, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XamaAtapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and XamaAtN, (Ḳ,) or the former is a simple subst., (Mṣb, [in which no inf. n. is mentioned,]) He (an enemy) rejoiced: (TA:) or he (a man, TA) rejoiced at the affliction of the enemy: (Ḳ, TA:) you say, Xamita bihi He rejoiced at his [an enemy's] affliction. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb.)
2: see 4.

taXomiytN is syn. with tasomiytN: [i. e.] taXomiytu AlEaATisi signifies The uttering a prayer for the sneezer; (Ṣ;) when he has, in obedience to an injunction of the Prophet, said AlHamodu lil-ehi [Praise be to God]: (Ḥar p. 250:) you say, Xam-ata AlEaATisa, (ISd, A, TA,) and Xm-t Ealayohi, meaning [as expl. in art. smt: or] He prayed for the sneezer that he might not be in a state in which his enemy might rejoice at his affliction: (ISd, TA:) Xm-t is better and more common than sm-t: (AʼObeyd, TA in art. sm-t and in the present art.:) but the latter is said by Th to be the original word: or the meaning is, he said to the sneezer, May God put away, or avert, from thee that on account of which one would rejoice at thy affliction: or it is from AlX-awaAmitu as signifying “the legs” of a quadruped, as though meaning he prayed for the sneezer that he might be firm, or steadfast, in his obedience to God. (L and TA from the Fáïk, &c.) And Xm-t lahu and Ealayohi, inf. n. as above, He prayed for what was good for him; prayed for a blessing upon him; as also sm-t, but the former is the better and the more common. (L and TA from the T and Fáïk, &c.)

Also i. q. taxoyiytN: (Ḳ:) you say, Xm-thu fulaAnN, meaning xay-abahu [Such a one disappointed him; or caused him to be disappointed of attaining what he desired or sought: or denied him, refused him, prohibited him from attaining, or debarred him from, that which he desired or sought]. (TA.)
And i. q. jamoEN [The act of collecting,, &c.]. (Ḳ. [But SM says that he had searched to the utmost for this meaning without finding it in any other lexicon.])

4. AXmthu Qll-ehu bihi God made him (i. e. the enemy, A, Mṣb) to rejoice at his affliction. (A,* Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) For falaA tuXomito biIa QloOaEadaMCa [Therefore make not thou the enemies to rejoice at my affliction], in the Ḳur [vii. 149], Mujáhid is related to have read flA tuXam-ito↓: but the correctness of this is doubted. (TA.)
5. taXam-utN signifies A people's returning disappointed of attaining their desire, without spoil. (Ḳ.)
8. AiXotimaAtN [A camel's] beginning to be fat. (Ḳ. [See the part. n., below.])
XimaAtN Disappointment; frustration of one's endeavour or hope: (IB, TA:) a subst. from taXomiytN as signifying taxoyiybN. (TA.)

Also, thus written in copies of the Ḳ, [and in the Ṣ,] with kesr, (TA,) [but in the CK XamAt,] and XamaAtaI↓, (Ḳ,) Persons suffering disappointment; or failing of attaining their desire; (Ḳ, TA;) without spoil: (TA:) [pls.] without any sing.; (Ḳ:) or the latter has no sing. known to ISd: (TA:) [but] XaAmitN↓ has this meaning as a sing. part, n., and XmAt [app. XimaAtN] is its pl. (IB, TA.) One says, rajaEuwA XamaAtaI↓, (IAạr, TA,) or XimaAtFA, (Ṣ,) They returned suffering disappointment; or failing of attaining their desire; (IAạr, Ṣ, TA;) without spoil; and so muXam-atiyna↓ and mutaXam-itiyna↓. (TA.)
[XamiytN Reproach (“convicium”): so Golius, as from the KL; but I do not find it in my copy of that work.]
XamaAtaI: see XimaAtN, in two places.

hom.sense: XaAmitN One rejoicing at the affliction of an enemy: [fem. with p {XaAmitapN}: pl. masc. Xum-aAtN and fem. XawaAmitu; or the latter may be anomalously masc., like fawaArisu, &c.; and as such it is evidently used in the L, in one place; but in another place, where it cites an explanation by AO, as fem.: both are mentioned in the M and L and TA, and the latter in the Ṣ and A also.] One says, Aall-ehum-a laA tuTiyEan-a liI XaAmitFA [O God, comply not with the desire of one who is to me a rejoicer at my affliction]; meaning, do not with me that which one who rejoices at my affliction likes, or approves; for in that case, Thou wouldst be as though Thou obeyedst him. (ISk, L, TA.) And baAta fulaAnN balayolapi AlX-awaAmiti Such a one passed a night such as would make to rejoice those, or those females, that would rejoice at the affliction of an enemy; (Ṣ, A, L, TA;) i. e., a distressing night. (A.) [And a verse cited in the next paragraph presents, as some read it, a similar ex. of AlX-awaAmit.]
See also XimaAtN.
XaAmitapN [fem. of XaAmitN, q. v.]

[Also], as a subst., sing. of XawaAmitu (Ṣ, TA) which signifies The legs of a beast. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA.) One says, laA taraka Qll-ehu lahu XaAmitapF, i. e. [May God not leave to him] a leg of a beast. (AA, Ṣ, A, TA.)
And En-Nábighah [Edh-Dhubyánee] says,
faQrotaAEa mino Sawoti kal-aAbK fabaAta lahu
TawoEa AlX-awaAmiti mino xawofK wamino Saradi
[And that has been frightened at the voice of a huntsman with his dogs,] and passed the night in consequence thereof standing, (lit. obeying the legs,) by reason of fear and [also] of cold; the poet describing a [wild] bull: (AO, L, TA:) but some read TawoEu (instead of TawoEa); and accord. to this reading, the meaning is, and passed the night having, of fear and of cold, what was agreeable with the desire of such as would rejoice at his affliction; the phrase being like the saying Aall-ehum-a laA tuTiyEan-a liI XaAmitFA meaning as expl. in the next preceding paragraph: (ISk, L, TA:) or he passed the night having [of fear and of cold] what would rejoice the XawaAmit that heard thereof: (AO, L, TA:) [and in like manner, Z says,] baAta TawoEa AlX-awaAmiti [without lahu, and with TwE in the accus. case, lit. he passed the night obeying those, or those females, that rejoiced at his affliction,] means, as those that rejoiced at his affliction liked, or approved. (A.)
muXam-atN A king prayed for (Ḳ, TA) with the prayers that are offered for kings. (TA.)
See also XimaAtN, last sentence.

entry.sense: muXam-itN Any one praying, or who prays, for what is good; as also musam-itN. (Ṣ.)
UibilN muXotamitapN Camels beginning to be fat. (TA.)
mutaXam-itN: see its pl. voce XimaAtN, last sentence.
1. Xamaxa, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXomuxu}, inf. n. XumuwxN, (L,) It (a mountain) was high, or lofty. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

Hence, (Ḥar p. 442,) Xamaxa biOanofihi, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) and Xamaxa Oanofuhu, aor. and inf. n. as above, (L,) He (a man) magnified, or exalted, himself; was proud; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) behaved proudly, or disdainfully; elevated his nose, from pride. (L.) [See also zamaxa.]
mafaAzapN XamuwxN A desert, or waterless desert, farextending; (Ḳ;) as also zmuwxN. (TA.)
See also XamaxN.
Xam-aAxN: see what follows, in two places.
jabalN XaAmixN A high, or lofty, mountain; (Ṣ, A, L;) as also Xam-aAxN↓ [but in an intensive sense, i. e. a very high or lofty mountain]: (L:) pl. jibaAlN XawaAmixu (Ṣ, A) and Xum-axN. (A.)

Hence, XaAmixN signifies also Proud; (L, TA;) elevating the nose, from pride, or disdain: [like zaAmixN:] pl. Xum-axN: (L, Ḳ:) and Xam-aAxN↓ a man who magnifies, or exalts, himself much; or elevates his nose much, from pride. (L.)
And OunuwfN Xum-axN [Noses elevated, from pride]; like zum-axN. (Ṣ.)
And nasabN XaAmixN ‡ [A proud, or high, lineage]. (TA.)
1. Xamara, aor. _u {yaXomuru}, inf. n. XamorN: see the next paragraph {2}, in five places.

2. Xm-r, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taXomiyrN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He raised, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or tucked up, or contracted, (A,) his garment, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or his waist-wrapper, (Ṣ,) [or his sleeve,] or his skirts. (A.) One says, Xm-r Eano saAqihi [He raised, or tucked up, his garment, or waist-wrapper, or skirts, from his shank]. (Ṣ.) [And in like manner, tXm-r↓ signifies He raised, or tucked up, his garment,, &c.: for] one says also, tXm-r Eano saAEidayohi [He tucked up his sleeves from his fore arms]. (TA.) It is said in a prov., Xam-ara cayolFA waQd-araEa layolFA i. e. [lit.] He contracted, or drew up, his [or a] skirt [and clad himself with night as with a tunic]: (TA:) or Xamiro cayolFA waQd-ariEo layolFA, meaning ‡ Use thou prudence, or precaution, or good judgment, and journey all the night. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. drE.)

[Hence,] † He strove, or laboured, exerted himself or his power or ability, employed himself vigorously or laboriously or with energy, or took extraordinary pains, (AA, Mṣb, TA,) and was quick, (AA, TA,) fiI AlOamori [in the affair]; as also Xamara↓, inf. n. XamorN: (TA:) and fiI AlEibaAdapi [in religious service]: (Mṣb:) and fiI sayorihi [in his pace, or journeying]; like tajar-ada and Ainojarada. (L and TA in art. jrd.) Also, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) and Xamara↓, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXomuru}, inf. n. XamorN; (TA;) and AnXmr↓, and tXm-r↓; (Ḳ;) † He passed along striving, or exerting himself, or vigorously: or he passed along with a proud and self-conceited gait; (Ḳ;) [and] mar-a yaXomuru↓, inf. n. as above, has the latter meaning. (Ṣ.) And Xm-r fiI AlOamori † He was, or became, light, or active, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and quick, (Mṣb,) in, or for, the affair: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and Xm-r liloOamori, and Xm-r liloOamori OacoyaAlahu, (A, TA,) and Xm-r Eano saAqihi, (TA,) ‡ He was, or became, light, or active, and he rose, or hastened, to do the thing, or affair. (A, TA.) And Xm-rt AlHarobu and Xm-rt Eano saAqihaA ‡ [The war, or battle, became vehement; like kaXafato Eano saAqK]. (A.)

Also He contracted a thing; syn. qal-aSa; (TA;) [and so, perhaps, Xamara↓; for] AlX-amoru signifies taqoliySu AlX-aIoCi, like Alt-aXomiyru: (Ḳ:) [or the author of the TA may have misunderstood this explanation in the Ḳ, and the meaning may be it (a thing) contracted, or became contracted; for qal-aSa is trans. and also (like qalaSa) intrans.: that Xm-r has this latter meaning, whether it have also, or have not, the former, is shown by the statement that] one says, Xam-arati AlX-afapu meaning qalaSat [i. e. The lip became contracted, or became contracted upwards]: (M in art. qlS:) and tXm-r↓ [in like manner] signifies it (a thing) contracted, or became contracted; syn. taqal-aSa. (TA.)

Also, (inf. n. as above, Aṣ, Ṣ,) ‡ He launched forth a ship, or boat; let it go; let it take its course; (Aṣ, IAạr, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and in like manner, a hawk; (A;) and he discharged, or shot, an arrow: (Aṣ, IAạr, Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) and hence, (Aṣ, Ṣ,) ‡ he sent, sent forth, or sent away, (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) a thing. (M, A.) [See also sam-ara.] And Xm-r AlUibila, inf. n. as above; (TA;) and AXmrhA↓; (Ḳ;) † He hastened the camels; made them to hasten; syn. OakomaXahaA, [which seems to be either syn. with, or a mistranscription for, kam-aXahaA, (see sam-ara,)] and OaEojalahaA. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
And Xam-arotu Aln-axola ‡ I cut off the fruit of the palm-trees; syn. Saramotuhu; (A, TA;) or so Xamarotuhu↓, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O,) [for] AlX-amoru signifies SiraAmu Aln-axoli. (Ḳ.)
4. AXmr AlUibila: see 2, last sentence but one.
AXmr Aljamalu Taruwqatahu The he-camel impregnated the she-camel covered by him. (O, Ḳ.)
AXmrhu biAls-ayofi He destroyed him with the sword; syn. Oadorajahu. (O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 5. tXm-r: see 2, third sentence.

[Hence,] tXm-r liloOamori, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or liloEamali (A,) and AnXmr↓ lalAmr, (Ṣ,) † He prepared himself (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) for the affair, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or for the work. (A.) [Freytag mentions AXmr llAmr in a similar sense, “Paratus fuit ad rem peragendam,” as on the authority of J; but I do not find it in the Ṣ,]
See also 2 as syn. with 1 and 7.
[Also, app., as quasi-pass. of 2, It (a garment, &c.,) was, or became, raised, or tucked up, or contracted; and so signifies AnXmr↓.]
See 2 again, in the latter part of the paragraph.

entry.sense: 7. AnXmr: see 5, in two places.
See also 2 as syn. with 1 and 5.
Also He (a horse) hastened, or went quickly. (Ṣ, O. [Accord. to Freytag, the verb in this sense in the Ṣ is AXtmr; but this is a mistake.])
And i. q. maDaI and nafaca [app. as meaning † It, or he, acted with a penetrative force or energy (see XimorN and Xam-ariI-N)]; and so AXtmr↓. (TA.)
And It (the water of a wall) went away. (A, TA.)
8: see the next preceding paragraph {7}.

XimorN, applied to a man, † Light, agile, or active; acute, or sharp, or quick, in intellect; clever, knowing, or intelligent; syn. zawolN; and baSiyrN; (El-Muärrij, O, Ḳ;) and naAqidN; (O, Ḳ;) thus accord. to the copies of the Ḳ [probably from the O]; but in the Tekmileh, &c., naAfic, [which I regard as the right reading, meaning one who acts with a penetrative energy, or who is sharp, vigorous, or effective,] (TA,) in everything. (O, TA.) See also Xam-ariI-N.
Also † Liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous; (O, Ḳ;) and courageous. (TA.)
XamarN: see XamaArN.
XimorapN The gait, or manner of walking, of a vitious, or depraved, man; (O, Ḳ;) or, accord. to IAạr, of a man who goes to and fro, and round about. (TA.) [See also XanorapN.]

Xar-N Ximir-N Severe evil. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) It is said in a prov., OalojaOahu Alxawofu UilaI Xar-K Ximir-K, (TA,) or OajaMCahu, (so in a copy of the A,) [Fear compelled him to betake himself to that which was a severe evil:] i. e. he feared an evil, and fear reduced him to a greater evil. (A.)

XamaArN i. q. raAziyaAnajN, in the dial. of Egypt, (O, Ḳ, TA,) also [and more commonly] called XamarN↓ [applied to the Anethum graveolens, or common garden-dill, and to its seed; and also to the anethum fœniculum, or fennel: see also san-uwtN]. (TA.)

Xam-ariI-N [in the CK XamariI-N, without teshdeed to the m,] ‡ A man, (Ṣ,) penetrating, or acting with a penetrative energy, or sharp, vigorous, and effective, in the performing of affairs, and expert, or experienced; (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA;) mostly with respect to travel; (TA;) as though it were a rel. n. from Xam-ara; (Ṣ;) as also Xim-ariI-N (Ṣ, Ḳ) and Xim-iriI-N [in the CK XimiriI-N] and Xum-uriI-N [in the CK XumuriI-N] and XimorN↓ and Xim-iyrN↓, (Ḳ,) the last an intensive form, (TA,) and muXam-irN↓: (Ḳ:) or clever in the performing of affairs, and quick: (Fr, TA:) or one who strives, labours, or exerts himself, and is clever and skilful: (Aboo-Bekr, TA:) or quick in evil, and in what is vain, or false; who strives, labours, or exerts himself, therein; from Xam-ara meaning “he strove, laboured, or exerted himself, and was quick:” (AA, Aboo-Bekr, TA:) or one who goes his own way, or pursues a headlong, or rash, course, and will not refrain. (Aboo-Bekr, TA.)

naAqapN Xam-ariy-apN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Xim-ariy-apN, and Xim-iriy-apN, and Xum-uriy-apN, (Ḳ, TA,) [all in the CK without teshdeed to the m,] and Xim-iyrN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) † A she-camel that is quick (Ṣ, Ḳ) in pace. (TA.)

Xam-uwrN, occurring in a trad. respecting 'Ooj Ibn-'Unuk, [or Ibn-'Ook,] as meaning something with which a mass of rock was hollowed out according to the size of his head, (TA,) Diamond: (Ḳ:) thought by El-Khaṭṭábee to have this meaning; but he says, “I have not heard respecting it anything upon which I place reliance.” (IAth, TA.)
Xim-iyrN † One who strives, labours, or exerts himself; who employs himself vigorously, laboriously, or with energy; (Ḳ, TA;) in the performance of affairs. (TA.) See also Xam-ariI-N, in two places.
XaApN XaAmirN, and XaAmirapN, A ewe or she-goat, having her udder drawn up to her belly: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) an epithet having no verb. (TA.)
XafapN XaAmirapN, and mutaXam-irapN↓, A contracted lip. (TA.)
livapN XaAmirapN, (A, Ḳ,) and mutaXam-irapN↓, (Ḳ,) or muXam-irapN↓, (so in a copy of the A,) A gum cleaving to the roots of the teeth. (A, Ḳ.)
muXam-irN: see Xam-ariI-N:
and see also XaAmirN.
mutaXam-irN: see its fem. voce XAmirN, in two places.

Q. 1. Xamoraxa Aln-axolapa He stripped off the unripe dates of the palm-tree. (L.) And Xamorixi AlEicoqa Strip thou the XamaAriyx [or fruit-stalks] of the raceme of the palm-tree with the mixolab, cutting off [the dates]. (L,* Ḳ. [In the former, in the place of qaToEFA, the last word in the explanation in the Ḳ, is put qaEoTFA, app. by a mistake of the copyist.])

XimoraAxN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XumoruwxN↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) A [fruit-] stalk of the raceme of a palm-tree; (Mgh;) the EivokaAl, (Ṣ, L,) or thing, (Mṣb,) upon which are the dates; (L, Mṣb;) [i. e. any one of the stalks that branch off from the main stem of the raceme, and on which hang the dates; each of these stalks comprising a number of dates, one below another:] pl. of both XamaAriyxu: (Mṣb:) the Eicoq, or kibaAsap, [q. v.,] comprises the XamaAriyx: (Mṣb voce EicoqN:) or an EivokaAl upon which are unripe dates, or grapes: (Ḳ:) originally relating to a raceme of dates; but sometimes, to grapes: (L:) and the former word [or each] signifies a small bunch of grapes, growing apart, but attached to the lower portion of the stalk of a larger bunch. (T, TA.)

Also, XimoraAxN, The head of a mountain: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a round, tall, slender head, or peak, of a mountain: (L:) accord. to Aṣ, [the pl.] XamaAriyxu signifies the heads of mountains: (TA:) or it signifies the upper, or uppermost, part [or parts] of a mountain; and in like manner, of trees. (Ḥam p. 786.) And † The upper, or uppermost, parts of clouds: (Ḳ:) or [the pl.] XamaAriyxu is metaphorically applied to the upper, or uppermost, parts of clouds. (Ḥam ubi suprà.)

And A blaze upon the face of a horse, when it is narrow, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and long, (TA,) and extending so as to cover the [part of the nose called] xayoXuwm, but not reaching to the lip: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or a blaze, upon the face of a horse, extending downwards on the nose. (Lth, TA.) [See gur-apN saAYilapN, in art. syl.] Accord. to J, The horse itself [that has such a blaze] is also thus called; but this is a mistake: (Ḳ:) it seems that he meant to have said cuw XimoraAxK; but this, in a verse which he cites, is the name of a horse of Málik Ibn-'Owf En-Nadree, as is said in the Ḳ. (MF.)
[The pl.] AlX-amaAriyxu is also a name applied by the Arabs to † The stars of Centaurus (qanoTuwrus) and Lepus (Als-abuEu) collectively. (Ḳzw.)
XumoruwxN: see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence.
Also A slender, and soft or tender, branch, that has grown forth, within a year, upon the upper part of a thick branch. (L.)
AlX-imoraAxiy-apu A sect of the heretics, or schismatics, (AlxawaArij,) the companions [or followers] of ʼAbdAllah Ibn-Shimrákh. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

XamarodalN A youth, strong and hardy; and in the like sense applied to a camel: (Lth, TA:) or tall; as also XamarodaliI-N↓: (Ḥam pp. 728 and 789:) or a bulky camel: (IAạr, TA:) or, of camels, &c., (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) the swift; (Ṣ, O;) or youthful, swift, and goodly in make: (Ḳ:) and with p {XamarodalapN}, a she-camel goodly, beautiful in make. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
XamarodaliI-N: see the preceding paragraph.
XamarocalN a dial. var. of XamarodalN [q. v.]. (Lth, O, Ḳ.)
1. Xamazato nafosiI minohu, aor. _u {yaXomuzu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. XamozN, (IAạr, Ḳ,) My soul shrank from it in dislike or hatred. (IAạr, Ḳ, TḲ.) [See also 5, and Q. Q. 4.]
5. tXm-z wajohuhu His face became changed, or altered, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) by anger, (Ḳ,) and contracted. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ.) See also what next follows.

Q. Q. 4. AiXomaOaz-a, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. AiXomiYozaAzN, (Ṣ,) He (a man, Ṣ) shrank, or became contracted; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also tXm-z↓: (TA:) he quaked, or shuddered: (IAạr, Ḳ:) or he was frightened (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ) at a thing. (AZ, Ṣ.) It is said in the Ḳur xxxix. 46, waUicaA cukira Qll-ehu waHodahu QXomaOaz-ato quluwbu Ql-aciyna laA yuWominuwna biQloMxirapi And when God is mentioned alone, the hearts of those who will not believe in the world to come become contracted, and shrink with aversion: (Bḍ, Jel:) or quake, or shudder. (Zj, TA.) And you say, qulotu lahu kacaA faQXomaOaz-a minohu [I said to him such a thing, and he shrank from it; or quaked, or shuddered, at it; or was frightened at it]. (A.) And AXmOz- AlX-aIoCa, (Ḳ,) without a prep., accord. to Kr, (TA,) He disliked, or hated, the thing. (Ḳ.) [See also 1, and 5.]

XumaOoziyzapN [a subst.] from Q. Q. 4, [A shrinking, or contraction: a quaking, or shuddering: or fright: and dislike, or hatred.] (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA.) You say, rajulN fiyhi XumaOoziyzapN [A man in whom is a shrinking,, &c.] (TA.)
muXomaYiz-N Shrinking with aversion; syn. naAfirN: (Ḳ:) disliking, or hating, (Ḳ,) a thing: (TA:) frightened, or afraid. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. Xamasa, aor. _u {yaXomusu} and _i {yaXomisu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XumuwsN; (TA;) and Xamisa, aor _a (Ḳ) and _u also, like faDila, aor. yafoDulu, accord. to the lexicologists, as ISd says, but he holds the aor. of Xamisa to be _a [only]; (TA;) and AXms↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) It (a day) was, or became, sunny, or sunshiny; it had sun, or sunshine: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or it had sun, or sunshine, all the daytime: or it was, or became, clear, or unobscured: (TA:) or its sun was, or became, vehement. (IF, Mṣb.)

Xamasa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXomusu} (Mṣb, TA) and _i {yaXomisu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. XumuwsN and XimaAsN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He (a horse) refused to be ridden or mounted: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or took fright and broke loose and ran away, refusing to be ridden, by reason of the vehemence of his force of resistance, [for liXid-api mtEbh in the TA, I read lXd-p manaEatihi,] and his sharpness of temper, so that he would not remain still: (TA:) or became rebellious against his rider. (Mṣb.)
[Hence,] Xamasati AlmaroOapu † The woman abstained from looking at men, and from exciting their desire. (TA.)

And Xamasa liI fulaAnN ‡ Such a one showed enmity to me: (Ḳ:*) or showed his enmity to me, (T, Ṣ, A,) and almost made it to take effect, (A,) or as though he purposed to act: (T, TA:) or Xamasa fiI fulaAnK signifies, [unless fI be a mistake for liI, and fulaAnK for fulaAnN,] he showed his enmity [towards such a one], and could not conceal it. (M in TA.) [See also 3.]
And Alxamoru taXomusu biSaAHibihaA † Wine overcomes, and runs away with, its drinker. (TA.)
2. Xm-s, (TḲ,) inf. n. taXomiysN, (Ḳ,) He worshipped the sun. (Ḳ, TḲ.)
And He spread a thing in the sun, or sunshine, (Ḳ, TḲ,) in order that it might dry. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. XAmshu, inf. n. muXaAmasapN and XimaAsN, He opposed him, and treated him with enmity or hostility. (Th, TA.) [See also 1.]
4: see 1, first signification.
[Also He ascended a mountain towards the sun. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]

hom.sense: 5. tXm-s He (a man) sat in the sun, or sunshine: (TA:) he set himself up [or exposed himself standing] to the sun. (Ṣ, TA.)
tXm-s Ealayohi He was niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious, to him. (TA.) [See also the part. n., below.]

AlX-amosu [The sun;] the body of the solar light, that runs its course in the firmament: (Lth,* TA:) it is fem.: (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ:) and has neither dual nor pl.: (Mṣb:) or it has a pl., [though this is not used in a pl. sense,] namely, XumuwsN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as though they called every part of it a Xms, like as they said mafaAriqu for maforiqN. (Ṣ.) When it is made determinate without the article Al, [as] in the name Eabodu Xamosa, meaning The Servant of the Sun, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e., of this luminous object, (Mṣb,) the Xms of heaven, because they used to worship it, (Ḳ,) it is imperfectly decl., (Aboo-ʼAlee, Mṣb, Ḳ,) because it is determinate and of the fem. gender, (Aboo-ʼAlee, Ḳ,) or because it is a proper name and of the fem. gender and altered from AlX-amos: (Mṣb:) and a poet says,
kal-aA waXamosa lanaxoDiban-ahumu damFA
[Nay verily, by the sun, we will assuredly dye them with blood], making Xms imperfectly decl. because he means the art. Al to be understood: (IAạr, TA:) but some say that in the former instance, (Mṣb, TA,) and in the latter, (TA,) the word in question has a different signification, which will be shown below: (Mṣb, TA:) and Sb says that none of the Arabs made Xms determinate without the art. Al, except in the proper name mentioned above, in which all of them made it so. (TA.) The dim. is XumayosapN↓. (Ṣ, TA.)
[Also The sun, or sunshine.] You say, qaEada fiI AlX-amosi [He sat in the sun, or sunshine]. (TA.)

Also, (Ḳ, TA,) or XamosN, (Mṣb,) A certain ancient idol. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) Accord. to Ibn-El-Kelbee, it is this that is meant by the proper name mentioned above; and if so, it is perfectly decl.: (Mṣb:) and some say that it is this also that is meant in the words of the poet cited above, and that he makes the word imperfectly decl. because he uses it as a proper name of the image (AlS-uwrap). (TA.)

XamosN also signifies A kind of necklace or collar: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a pendant, or suspended ornament, (miEolaAq,) of the necklace or collar upon the neck: or the collar of a dog: (TA:) or a kind of women's ornament: of the masc. gender: (Lḥ, TA:) pl. XumuwsN. (TA.)
And A kind of comb, (Ḳ,) with which women in the first age used to comb themselves; (TA;) as also XamosapN↓. (IDrd, TA.)
yawomN XamosN: see XaAmisN.

entry.sense: yawomN XamisN: see XaAmisN.
XamosapN: see XamosN, last sentence but one.
XamosiI-N [Of, or relating to, the sun; solar]. Als-anapu AlX-amosiy-apu The solar year. (Mgh.)
It is also a term applied by some of the Arabs to The first [annual] increase [of sheep and goats]. (Aboo-Naṣr, TA voce SafariI-N, q. v.)
XamaAsN The disposition, in a horse, of refusing to be ridden, or mounted. (Ṣ.)
[And hence,] † The disposition, in a woman, of abstaining from looking at men, and from exciting their desire: a subst. from XamasatN. (TA.)

XamuwsN A horse that refuses to be ridden or mounted; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also XaAmisN↓: (Ḳ:) or that takes fright and breaks loose and runs away, refusing to be ridden, by reason of the vehemence of his force of resistance and his sharpness of temper, so that he will not remain still: (TA: [see 1:]) or that will hardly remain still: (A:) or that rebels against his rider: (Mṣb:) or that refuses to be ridden or mounted, and will hardly remain still: (Mgh:) also applied to a she-camel: (TA:) XamuwSN, with S, applied to a horse is not allowable: (Mṣb:) pl. XumusN (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XumosN. (Ḳ.)

Hence also, (Mṣb,) ‡ A man refractory, untractable, perverse, stubborn, or obstinate, in disposition: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) and a man hard, harsh, or illnatured, in his enmity, vehement in contrariousness to him who opposes him: (TA:) XamuwSN [with S] is not allowable. (Ṣ.)
[Hence too,] AlX-amuwsu † Wine: (AḤn, Ḳ:) because it overcomes, and runs away with, its drinker, like the horse to which this epithet is applied. (AḤn.)

Xam-aAsN One of the heads of the Christians, who shaves the middle of his head, and keeps to the church: (Lth, A, Mgh, Ḳ:) [in the present day, a deacon: see jaAvaliyqu:] not pure Arabic, (IDrd,) or not sound Arabic: (M:) [probably, as Golius says, from the Chaldee שַמָש:] pl. XamaAmisapN. (Mgh, Ḳ: [in the TA, XmAsp; and in a copy of the A, Xam-aAsap; but the right reading is that in the Mgh.])

hom.sense: XaAmisN A sunny, or sunshiny, day; a day having sun, or sunshine: or having sun, or sunshine, all the daytime: or clear; unobscured: and in like manner, XamosN↓ and XamisN↓, a clear, cloudless, day: and XaAmisN also signifies intensely hot: (TA:) and muXomisN↓, applied to a day, signifies the same as XaAmisN; (A;) and so maXomuwsN↓. (Th, TA.)
A neck having [ornaments of the kind called] Xumuws [pl. of XamosN, q. v.]: a possessive epithet. (TA.)
See also XamuwsN, in two places.

entry.sense: OaXomasu More, and most, incompliant or resisting. (Ḥam p. 324.)
muXomisN: see XaAmisN.
Made muXam-asN [or spread to dry (see 2)] in the sun, or sunshine. (Ṣ.)
muXam-isN A worshipper of the sun. (O, TA.)
maXomuwsN: see XaAmisN.

hom.sense: mutaXam-isN [Sitting in or] setting himself up to [or exposing himself standing to] the sun. (Ḳ.)

A man who defends what is behind his back: (ISh, TA:) a man strong (ISh, Ḳ, TA) in that which sustains or supports him; syn. qawiI-N Xadydu Alquwmiy-api: (ISh, TA:) Ṣgh says Xadydu Alquw-api; but the former is the right reading: (TA:) and niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious, to the utmost degree. (Ḳ.)

1. XamiTa, aor. _a {yaXomaTu}, inf. n. XamaTN, He (a man, Ṣ, TA) was, or became, grizzled in the hair of his head; he had whiteness in the hair of his head, mixed with its blackness: (Ṣ, Mgh,* Ḳ:) as also OaXomaTa↓, (Ḳ, but wanting in one copy,) and AiXomaT-a↓, and AiXomaAT-a↓, and AiXomaOaT-a↓: (Ḳ:) [or he had hair of two different colours, black and white: or he had whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, mixed with the blackness of youth: or he had whiteness, or hoariness, in his beard: but XamiTato, said of a woman, she had whiteness, or hoariness, in the head: see XamaTN, below.]

XamaTa, aor. _i {yaXomiTu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. XamoTN, (Ṣ,) He mixed a thing; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) he mixed together any two things: (Ṣ, Mgh:) and OaXomaTa↓ signifies the same. (AZ, Ḳ.) You say, XayaTa bayona AlmaMCi waAll-abani He mixed together the water and the milk. (TA.) And OaXomiTo↓ Eamalaka biSadaqapK † Mix thou thy work with alms. (AZ.)
And Aboo-ʼAmr Ibn-El-ʼAlà used to say to his companions, AXomiTuwA, [i. e. either AiXomiTuwA or OaXomiTuwA↓,] meaning † Betake yourselves at one time to reading, or reciting, somewhat of the Ḳur-án, and another time to some tradition, and another time to something strange [that is to be elucidated], and another time to poetry, and another time to lexicology; i. e., mix ye these [subjects of study]: (TA:) or, accord. to one relation, Xam-iTuwA↓. (Ḥar p. 177; where it is expl. in a similar manner).

entry.sense: 2: see above {1}, last sentence.
4: see 1, in four places.
9: see 1, first sentence.
11: see 1, first sentence.
Q. Q. 4: see 1, first sentence.

XamaTN Whiteness of the hair of the head mixed with its blackness: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) or difference in the hair by being of two colours, black and white: (M, TA:) or mixture of whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, with the blackness of youth: (Mgh:) or in a man, whiteness, or hoariness, of the beard: (Lth, Mgh, TA:) but in a woman, whiteness, or hoariness, of the head. (Lth, TA.) [See 1.]
Also XamaTaAtN, which is its pl., White hairs that are in the head. (TA.)

canabN XamiyTN; in the Ḳ, ciYobN, which is a mistake; (TA;) A tail (TA) in which are blackness and whiteness. (Ḳ, TA.) And farasN XamiyTu Alc-anabi A horse in whose tail are two colours. (TA.) And TaAYirN XamiyTu Alc-unaAbaI A bird having a whiteness (Lth, Ḳ) and blackness (Lth) in the tail. (Lth, Ḳ.)
nabotN XamiyTN A plant of which part is dried up, or dried up and yellow, (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and part green. (Lth, Ḳ.)

AlX-amiyTu, [in a copy of the Mgh, XumayoTN↓, which is probably a mistranscription,] ‡ The dawn: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) because of the mixture of its whiteness with the remains of the darkness of night: (Ṣ, Mgh:) or because its colour is a mixture of darkness and whiteness. (TA.)
labanN XamiyTN ‡ Milk which is such that one knows not whether it be sour or what has been collected in a skin, and had fresh milk poured upon it, by reason of its pleasantness. (Ḳ, TA.)
waladN XamiyTN ‡ Children of whom half are males and half are females. (L, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: XumayoTN: see XamiyTN.
See also SuradN.

entry.sense: OaXomaTu A man (Ṣ) having the hair of his head grizzled; having whiteness in the hair of his head, mixed with its blackness: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [or whose hair is of two different colours, black and white: or having whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, mixed with the blackness of youth: or having whiteness, or hoariness, in his beard: see XamaTN, above:] or whose hair of his head is white in one place, the rest being black: (Mgh:) fem. XamoTaMCu: (Lth, Ṣ, Mgh:) one should not apply to a woman the epithet XayobaMCu: (Lth, Mgh:) pl. XumoTaAnN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and XumoTN. (Ḳ.)
naAqapN XamoTaMCu A she-camel having white lips. (TA.)
laHumN OaXomaTu [Flesh-meat marbled with fat]. (Az, TA in art. krX.)
maXomuwTN: see XamiyTN.

1. XamaEa, aor. _a {yaXomaEu}, inf. n. XamoEN and XumuwEN and maXomaEapN, He played, sported, gamed, jested, or joked: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or he was mirthful, and laughed: and XamaEatN, aor. as above, inf. n. XamoEN and XumuwEN, She cheered by her discourse. (TA.) It is said in a trad., mano yat-abiEi AlmaXomaEapa yaXomaEi Qll-ehu bihi (Ṣ,* O) He who follows the practice of play, or sport, or unprofitable play or sport, with men, (Ṣ, O,) and derision and laughter and enjoyment with them, God will requite him for that, (O,) or God will cause him to be in a state in which the like shall be done with him. (Ṣ, O.)
And XamaEa, inf. n. XumuwEN, It was, or became, scattered, or dispersed. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 2. Xm-Ehu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taXomiyEN, (O, Ḳ,) He, or it, made him to play, sport, game, jest, or joke. (O,* Ḳ.)
Xm-E Alv-awoba He dipped the garment, or piece of cloth, in liquified XamoE [i. e. wax]. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4. AXmE Als-iraAju The lamp, or lighted wick, diffused its light. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

XamoEN and XamaEN, both chaste accord. to ISd: (TA:) accord. to Fr, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, TA,) the former is post-classical; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) but ISd says that this is a mistake: (TA:) accord. to ISk one should say the latter, and not the former: (TA:) or accord. to him, the word is with fet-ḥ to the m, and some of the Arabs make the m quiescent: accord. to Th, it is with fet-ḥ to the m; and if you will, you may make it quiescent: accord. to IF, the m is sometimes with fet-ḥ; so that he gives one to understand that it is more frequently made quiescent: (Mṣb:) A kind of thing with which one lights himself: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or i. q. muwmN [which, or rather muwmo, in Pers., signifies both wax and the wax-candle; both of which or rather the former and wax-candles, are meant by XamoEN and XamaEN]: (ISk, TA:) or the muwm of honey [i. e. bees' wax]: (Lth, Ḳ:) the n. un., (CK,) or what denotes a piece, or portion, thereof, (so in copies of the Ḳ and in the TA,) is with p, (Ḳ, TA,) XamoEapN and XamaEapN, (TA,) [i. e.] XmEp has a more particular signification. (Ṣ, O.)

XamoEiI-N or XamaEiI-N (Ḳ [as there mentioned app. meaning A dealer in wax or wax-candles, like Xam-aAEN↓ in the present day,]) a rel. n. from XamoEN or XamaEN. (TA. [The latter said in the Ḳ to be the correct form.])
XimaAEN Mirth and laughter and jesting or joking; as also XimaAEapN↓. (TA. [Not mentioned there as inf. ns.])

XamuwEN, applied to a woman, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) That jests, or jokes, much; (Ḳ, TA;) pleasant in discourse; that kisses one, and will not comply with one's desire otherwise than by doing thus: (TA:) [or] playful, sportful, or gamesome, and wont to laugh; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and in this sense applied also to a man: or, applied to a woman, that cheers by her discourse. (TA.)
XimaAEapN: see XimaAEN.
Xam-aAEN A manufacturer of XmE [meaning waxcandles]: (TA:) or a melter of XmE [meaning wax]. (KL.) See also XamoEiI-N.
miXomaEapN A candlestick: pl. maXaAmiEu. (MA.)
muXam-aEN A garment, or cloth, dipped in liquified XamoE [i. e. wax]. (TA.)
misokN maXomuwEN Musk mixed with ambergris. (O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: Q. 1. XamoEala, (O, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK taXamoEala,]) inf. n. XamoEalapN, (TA,) It became scattered or dispersed. (O, Ḳ, TA.)

And XamoEalapN signifies The reading, or reciting, of the Jews, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) when they assemble fI mhrhm: (TA: [but I know not what this means:]) one says of them XamoEalat [i. e. XamoEalati Alyahuwdu]. (TA.)
Q. 4. AiXomaEal-a He hastened, made haste, or went quickly; syn. OasoraEa: this is the primary signification. (Ḥam p. 282.) One says of a she-camel AXmEl-t meaning She hastened,, &c. (Ṣ.)

And AXmEl-t AlUibilu The camels went, or went away, and scattered or dispersed themselves, by reason of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness: (Kh, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or spread themselves, or became scattered or dispersed; as also AXmET-t: (Aboo-Turáb, TA:) or became scattered or dispersed, going [away] quickly. (TA.) And in like manner, (Kh, Ṣ, O,) AXmEl-t AlgaArapu fiI AlEaduw-i, (Kh, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) meaning The horsemen making a sudden attack upon the enemy scattered, or dispersed, themselves; (Aboo-Turáb, Ḳ,* TA;) and so AXmET-t. (Aboo-Turáb, TA.) And AXmEl- Alqawomu fiI AlT-alabi The people, or company of men, hastened, and scattered or dispersed themselves, in seeking; (Aboo-Turáb, Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also AXmET-. (Aboo-Turáb, TA.)
And i. q. OaXorafa [q. v.]. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: XamoEalN and with p {XamoEalapN}: see the following paragraph.

muXomaEil-N A swift she-camel; (Az, Ṣ;) or so muXomaEil-apN: (O:) and XamoEalN↓ and XamoEalapN↓ (O, Ḳ) and muXomaEil-N (Ḳ) a she-camel brisk, lively, or sprightly, (O, Ḳ,) and swift, (Ḳ,) and light, active, or agile. (TA.) muXomaEil-apN in the first of these senses is [said to be] from the phrase qirobapN muXomaEil-apN A water-skin of which the water flows out. (Ḥar p. 111.)

Also A man quick and penetrating or having a penetrative energy: and with p {muXomaEil-apN}, a very active woman. (TA.) A man light, active, or agile; excellent, or elegant, in mind, manners,, &c., or clever, ingenious, or acute in mind: or tall. (Ḳ.) A man vigorous, strenuous, or energetic, and light, active, or agile. (Ḥam p. 384.)
Also applied to milk, meaning Sour, (Ḳ, TA,) overcoming by its sourness. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Xamilahumu AlOamoru, aor. _a {yaXomalu}; and Xamalahum, aor. _u {yaXomulu}; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) but the latter verb was unknown to Aṣ, (Ṣ, TA,) and is said by Lḥ to be rare; (TA;) inf. n. XamalN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is of the former, (Mṣb,) and XumuwlN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and XamolN; (Ḳ;) i. q. Eam-ahumo [i. e. The event, or case, included them in common, in general, or universally, within the compass of its effect or effects, its operation or operations, its influence, or the like]: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or Xamilahumo xayorFA or Xar-FA, or xayorFA and Xar-FA, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,) like fariHa, (in the CK, or like fariHa,) [app. means he, or it, caused that] good or evil, or good and evil, betided them [in common, in general, or universally]: and OaXomalahumo↓ Xar-FA [means] Eam-ahumo bihi [i. e. he, or it, included them in common, in general, or universally, with, or by, evil]: (Ḳ:) but one should not say, AXmlhm xayorFA. (TA.) [Whether what precedes, or what next follows, should be regarded as giving the primary signification of Xamila, is uncertain.]

Xamilahu, aor. _a {yaXomalu}, inf. n. XamolN and XumuwlN, He covered [or enveloped] him with the Xamolap, (Ḳ, TA,) or, with the miXomalap: such is thought by ISd to be meant by the explanation given by Lḥ, which is, gaT-aI Ealayohi AlmiXomalapa. (TA.)

hecihi XamolapN taXomaluka means tasaEuka [i. e. This is a Xmlp sufficient in its dimensions, or sufficiently large, for thee]. (TA.) You say, AiXotarayotu XamolapF vaXomaluniI [I bought a Xmlp sufficient in its dimensions,, &c., for me]. (ISk, Ṣ, O.)

Xamilato liqaAHFA, aor. _a {yaXomalu}, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. XamalN, (Ṣ, O,) said of a she-camel, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) She admitted impregnating seed, (Ḳ,) or she conceived, mino faHoli fulaAnK, [from the stallion of such a one]. (Ṣ, O.)
Xamilato Uibilukumo baEiyrFA lanaA Your camels concealed among them a he-camel belonging to us, by his entering amid their dense multitude: (Ḳ, TA:) so in the M and the Moḥeeṭ. (TA.)

Xamala AlX-aApa, aor. _u {yaXomulu} (Ṣ, Ḳ) and _i {yaXomilu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XamolN, (Ṣ,) He suspended upon the ewe, or she-goat, the kind of bag called XimaAl, and bound it upon her udder: (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA:) and some say, Xamala Aln-aAqapa, he suspended a XimaAl upon the she-camel. (T, TA.) Also and AXmlhA↓, He put to the ewe, or she-goat, (Ḳ, TA,) or he made for her, (TA,) a XimaAl. (Ḳ, TA.)

Xamala bihi, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. XamolN, (TA,) He took [in it, i. e. in travelling it, (see the pass. part. n.,)] the direction of the left hand; syn. Oaxaca caAta AlX-imaAli: (Ḳ, TA:) so expl. by IAạr. (TA.)

Xamalati Alr-iyHu, aor. _u {yaXomulu}, inf. n. XumuwlN (Ṣ, O, TA) and XamaAlN, (O,) or XamolN, (TA,) The wind shifted to a northerly direction (XamaAlFA); (Ṣ, TA;) so expl. by Lḥ: (TA:) or the wind blew northerly; syn. hab-ato XamaAlFA; as also OaXomalat↓. (O. [In the TA, I find OaXomalat AlryH chbt XmAlyl mvl Xam-alt: but this, I doubt not, is a mistranscription of the passage in the O, which I have here followed; i. e. OaXomalati AlriyHu hab-at XamAlFA mivl Xamalat; or of a similar passage in which UicaA hab-ato is put instead of hab-ato alone.]) One says of two persons when they are separated, Xamalato riyHuhumaA † [Their wind has become north, or northerly]. (TA voce januwbN, q. v. [See also maXomuwlN.])
Xamala Alxamora, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXomulu}, inf. n. XamolN, (TA,) He exposed the wine to the XamaAl [i. e. north, or northerly, wind], so that it became cold, or cool. (Ḳ.)

And XumiluwA, (Ṣ, and in like manner in the Ḥam p. 595,) or XamiluwA, [expressly said to be] like fariHuwA, (Ḳ, [but this I think to be a mistake, the weight of authority, and the form of the part. n., which is maXomuwlN, being against it,]) They were smitten, or blown upon, by the wind called the XamaAl. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Xamala Aln-axolapa, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXomulu}, inf. n. XamolN, (TA,) He picked the ripe dates that were upon the palm-tree; as also AXmlhA↓, and XamolalahaA↓: (Ḳ:) or this last (which is mentioned on the authority of Seer), accord. to some, signifies he took of the XamaAliyl of the palmtree; i. e., of the few dates remaining upon it. (TA.)
2. taXomiylN [properly inf. n. of Xam-ala]: see 5, of which it is an anomalous inf. n. (TA.)
And for its proper verb see 7.
Also The taking by the XimaAl [or left hand]. (TA.)
And Xm-l Aln-axolapa He bound pieces of [the garments called] Oakosiyap [pl. of kisaMCN] beneath the racemes of the palm-tree, because of its shaking off its fruit. (TA.)
4. OaXomalahumN Xar-FA: see 1, first sentence.

AXml AlfaHolu Xawolahu, (AZ, Ṣ, O,) inf. n. UiXomaAlN; (Ṣ;) or AXml Xawolahu liqaAHFA; (Ḳ;) The stallion-camel got with young from half to two thirds of the number of his Xawol [or she-camels that had passed seven or eight months since the period of their bringing forth]: (AZ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) when he has got them all with young, one says, Oaqam-ahaA; (AZ, Ṣ, O, TA;) and of the Xwl one says, qam-ato, inf. n. qumuwmN. (TA.)
AXml fulaAnN xaraAYifahu Such a one picked the ripe dates that were upon his xrAYf [or palm-trees of which he gathered the fruit for himself and his household], except a few. (Ṣ, O.)
See also 1, last sentence.
AXmlhu He gave him a Xamolap [q. v.]. (Ḳ, TA.)
AXml AlX-aApa: see 1.
AXml He became possessor of a miXomalap, (Lḥ, TA,) or, of a miXomal. (Ḳ.)
AXmlwA They entered upon [a time in which blew] the [north, or northerly,] wind termed AlX-amaAl: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) like as they say, AjnbwA in the case of the januwb. (TA.)
OaXomalati Alr-iyHu: see 1, latter half.
See also 7.

entry.sense: 5. tXm-l biAlX-amolapi, [and tXm-l AlX-amolapa, (see 5 in art. drs,)] inf. n. taXam-ulN and taXomiylN↓; (Ḳ;) the former reg.; the latter, which is mentioned by Lḥ, irreg., an instance like that in the saying [in the Ḳur lxxiii. 8], watabat-alo Uilayohi tabotiylFA; (TA;) He covered himself with the Xamolap [q. v.]. (Ḳ.) [See also 8.]

7. AnXml i. q. Xam-ara, (Ḳ, TA,) or AinoXamara, (O, TA,) [both of which signify He passed along striving, or exerting himself; and the latter signifies also he acted with a penetrative force or energy; and he hastened, or went quickly;] fiI HaAjatihi [in his needful affair]. (O, TA.) And i. q. OasoraEa [He hastened; went quickly; or was quick, swift, or fleet]: (Ḳ:) or so OaXomala↓: (thus in the O, as on the authority of IDrd:) or so AXtml↓, inf. n. AXtmAl: (thus accord. to my copy of the Mṣb:) and likewise (O, Ḳ) Xamolala↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. XamolalapN: (Ṣ:) and so Xm-l↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taXomiylN. (TA.) And i. q. AinoXamara (O, TA) and AinoDam-a, (TA,) [both meaning It became contracted,] as used by a poet in relation to a she-camel's udder. (O, TA.)

8. AXtml bivawobihi He wrapped, or inwrapped, himself with his garment; syn. talaf-afa: (Ṣ, O:) or AXtml biAlv-awobi signifies he wrapped the garment around the whole of his body so that his arm, or hand, did not come forth from it: (Ḳ:) or, as some say, he wrapped himself with the garment, and threw [a part of] it upon his left side. (TA.) [See also 5.] AiXotimaAlu AlS-am-aMCi, which is forbidden by the Prophet, is, accord. to Aṣ, The wrapping oneself with the garment so as to cover with it his body, not raising a side thereof in such a manner that there is in it an opening from which he may put forth his hand, or arm: (O:) this is also termed Alt-alaf-uEu: and sometimes one reclines in the state thus described: (TA:) but AʼObeyd says, accord. to the explanation of the lawyers, it is the wrapping oneself with one garment, not having upon him another, then raising it on one side and putting it upon his shoulders: [so says Ṣgh; and he adds,] he who explains it thus has regard to the dislike of one's uncovering himself and exposing to view the pudenda; and he who explains it as do the lexicologists dislikes one's covering his whole body for fear of his becoming in a state in which his respiration would become obstructed so that he would perish: (O:) or it is one's covering his whole body with the kisaMC or with the UizaAr; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) to which some add, not raising aught of the sides thereof. (Mṣb.) [See also art. Sm.] One says also, yaXotamilu EalaI Als-ayfi [He wraps his garment over the sword; or] he covers the sword with his garment. (Ṣ, O.)

[Hence, AXtml EalaI kacaA It comprehended, or comprised, such a thing.] One says, Alr-aHimu taXotamilu EalaI Alwaladi † The womb comprises [or encloses] the young. (TA.) [And in like manner one says of a woman, AXtmlt minohu EalaI waladK † She became with child by him. And AlkitaAbu yaXotamilu EalaI kacaA wakacaA † The book, or writing, comprises such and such things. And hence the phrase in grammar, badalu QXotimaAlK † A substitute for an antecedent to indicate an implication therein.]

One says also, AXtml Ealayohi AlOamoru, meaning ‡ The event [such as a misfortune or an evil of any kind beset him, or beset him on every side, or] encompassed him; (Ḳ, TA;) like as the kisaMC encompasses the body. (TA.)

One says of wine, taXotamilu EalaI AlEaqoli fatamolikuhu watacohabu bihi † [It compasses the intellect, and so takes possession of it, and makes away with it]: (Ḥam p. 555:) or taXotamilu EalaI Eaqoli AlUinosaAni fatugay-ibuhu † [It compasses the intellect of the man, and conceals it]; and thus one says of the present world or its enjoyments (Ald-unoyaA). (TA.) [AXtml EalaI XaIoCK often means † He took, or got, possession of a thing; got it, or held it, within his grasp, or in his possession.]
[Hence,] one says, AXtml EalaI naAqapK facahaba bihaA † He mounted a she-camel and went away with her. (AZ, O.)
And AXtml Ealayohi † He shrouded, covered, or protected, him with himself, or his own person. (TA.)

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. Xamolala: see 1, last sentence:
and see also 7.

XamolN A state of union or composedness: and a state of disunion or discomposedness: thus having two contr. significations: (MF, TA:) or a united, or composed, state of the affairs, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) and of the number, (TA,) of a people, or company of men: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) and a disunited, or discomposed, state of the affairs [&c.] thereof. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.) In imprecating evil upon enemies, (O, TA,) [or upon an enemy,] one says, Xat-ata Qll-ehu Xamolahumo, (O, TA,) or far-aqa Qll-ehu Xamolahumo, (Mṣb,) or fr-q Qll-eh Xamolahu, (Ṣ,) i. e. [May God dissolve, break up, discompose, derange, disorganize, disorder, or unsettle,] their, (Mṣb,) or his, (Ṣ,) united, or composed, state of affairs; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and Xat-a Xamoluhumo i. e. [May their united, or composed, state of affairs, &c.] become dissolved, broken up, discomposed,, &c.: (O, TA:) and [in the contr. case] one says, jamaEa Qll-ehu Xamolahumo, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, TA,) or Xamolahu, (Mgh,) i. e. [May God unite, or compose,] their, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or his, (Mgh,) disunited, or discomposed, state of affairs [&c.]. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.) And XamalN↓ signifies the same: El-Ba'eeth says,
qado yanoEaXu Qll-ehu AlfataI baEoda EavorapK
waqado yajomaEu Qll-ehu AlX-atiyta mina AlX-amalo
[Sometimes, or often, God raises the young man after a stumble: and sometimes, or often, God unites, or composes, what is dissolved, or broken up, of the state of affairs previously united, or composed]: (Ṣ, O:) AZ cites this ex. in his “Nawádir:” (Ṣ:) but Aboo-ʼOmar El-Jarmee says that he had not heard the word thus except in this verse: (Ṣ, O:) Ibn-Buzurj, however, cites another verse as presenting an ex. of the same. (TA.)

daxala fiI XamolihaA and XamalihaA↓, said of a he-camel that has become concealed among a herd of [she-] camels, means He entered amid their dense multitude: (Ḳ, TA:) so in the M and the Moḥeeṭ. (TA.)

Also, (AḤn, O, Ḳ,) and so XimolN↓, and Ximil-N↓, (Ḳ,) A raceme of a palm-tree: (AḤn, O, Ḳ:) Et-Tirimmáh likens thereto a camel's tail: (TA:) or such as has little fruit: (Ḳ:) or of which some of the fruit has been plucked: but AO used to say that it is the produce [or spadix] of the male palm-tree, while not abundant and large. (TA.)
See also XamaAlN.
And XamolN mino junuwnK signifies Fear, or fright, like insanity: and so XamalN↓ [used alone, and thus written]. (TA.)

entry.sense: XimolN: see the next preceding paragraph, near the end.

hom.sense: XamalN: see XamolN, in two places.

Also i. q. kanafN [as meaning Quarter, or shelter or protection]: Alkatifu in the copies of the Ḳ being a mistake for Alkanafu: one says, naHonu fiI Xamalikumo i. e. fiI kanafikumo [We are in your quarter,, &c.]. (TA.)

And A small quantity (Ṣ, Ḳ) of dates upon a palm-tree (Ṣ) or of ripe dates: (Ḳ:) and of rain: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and a small number (Ṣ, Ḳ) of men and of camels (Ṣ) or of men, &c.: pl. OaXomaAlN: and in like manner XumoluwlN↓ [app. in all of these applications]; (Ḳ;) [or] as meaning a light quantity of fruit of the palm-tree; (TA;) and the pl. of the latter is XamaAliylu: (Ḳ:) one says, maA EalaI Aln-axolapi Uil-aA XamalN and XamalapN↓ and XamaAliylu↓ There is not upon the palm-tree save a small quantity remaining of its fruit: (Ṣ, TA:) or maAbaqiIa fiI Aln-axolapi Uil-aA XamalapN↓ and XamaAliylu↓ There remained not upon the palm-tree save somewhat in a sparse state [of its fruit]: (TA:) and OaSaAbanaA XamalN mino maTarK A small quantity of rain fell upon us: and raOayotu XamalFA mina Aln-aAsi waAlUibili I saw a small number of men and of camels. (Ṣ.)
See also XamaAlN, in two places:
And see XamolN, last sentence.
XamilN Wrapping, or inwrapping, himself (muXotamilN↓) with a Xamolap [q. v.]. (TA.)
And Thin; syn. raqiyqN: thus expl. by Sh, as applied in this sense by Ibn-Mukbil to a she-camel's tail, which he terms liyf. (TA.)

entry.sense: XamolapN A [garment of the kind called] kisaMC, with which one wraps, or inwraps, himself (yuXotamalu bihi), (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) smaller than the qaTiyfap; as also miXomalN↓ (Ḳ) and miXomalapN↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the last two expl. by Lth as a kisaMC having a sparse villous substance, with which one wraps himself, smaller than the qaTiyfap: (TA:) or the first signifies a small kisaMC which one wears in the manner of the UizaAr [or waist-wrapper]: (Mṣb:) or with the Arabs it is a miYozar [or waist-wrapper] of wool or of [goats'] hair, which one wraps round him: and miXomalapN↓, such as is made of two pieces sewed together, with which a man wraps himself when he sleeps by night: (Az, TA:) and this last, accord. to Meyd, signifies a kisaMC comprising the steel with which one strikes fire, with the apparatus of this latter: (Ḥar p. 628:) the pl. of the first is XimaAlN (Mṣb, TA) and XamalaAtN. (Mṣb.) [See also miXomaAlN.]
[Hence the saying,] Dam-a Ealayohi All-ayolu Xamolatahu ‡ [The night contracted upon him its covering of darkness]. (TA.)
And Oum-u Xamolapa ‡ The present world, or its enjoyments; syn. Ald-unoyaA: (IAạr, Ḳ, TA:) so called because compassing the intellect of a man (taXotamilu EalaI Eaqolihi), and concealing it. (TA.)
And † Wine: (AA, Ḳ, TA:) so called for the same reason. (TA.)
And The sun. (Z, TA; and T in art. Am).

XimolapN A mode, or manner, of AiXotimaAl [or wrapping oneself with a garment as expl. above: see 8]. (Ḳ, TA.) AlXimolapu AlS-am-aMCu is That [mode of wrapping oneself] which is without a shirt and without drawers beneath; in the case of which, prayer is disliked. (TA. [See 8, and see also art. Sm.])
XamalapN: see XamalN, in two places.
Xamal-N: see XamaAlN.

hom.sense: Ximil-N: see XamolN, near the end of the paragraph.

Also, (TA,) and Ximil-apN; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) the former applied to a he-camel; (TA;) and the latter to a she-camel, as also XimolaAlN↓ and XimoliylN↓, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) which are likewise applied to a he-camel, (TA,) and XimaAlN↓; (Ḳ;) Light, active, or agile; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or swift. (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) Hence the phrase TaOoTaOotu XimolaAliI↓ [I hastened my light one, or my swift one]: or, accord. to AA, he means his hand, or arm, called the XimaAl; [i. e. I lowered my left hand or arm;] XimolaAlN and XimaAlN meaning the same. (Ṣ, O.)

entry.sense:
XamaAlN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) the most common form of the word, (Mṣb,) and XimaAlN↓, [a form which I think objectionable as likely to cause confusion, though it is probably the original form,] (Ḳ,) and XamoOalN↓, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and XamoOal-N↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, [in one place in the O erroneously written XaOmal-,]) and XaOomalN↓, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which last is formed by transposition, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) and XaAmalN↓, without C, (MF, TA,) and XawomalN↓, and XayomalN↓ and XamuwlN↓, (O, Ḳ,) and XamiylN↓, (Ḳ,) and XamalN↓, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and XamolN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the last said by ISd not to have been heard except in the poetry of El-Ba'eeth, (TA,) and Xamal-N↓, (MF, TA,) [every one of these] used as a subst. and as an epithet, (Ḳ,) [so that one says riyHu AlX-amaAli, &c. as well as riyHN XamaAlN, &c. and XamaAlN, &c. alone; The north wind: or a northerly wind:] the wind that is the opposite to the januwb: (Mṣb:) the wind that blows from the direction of the quTob [or pole-star]: (Ṣ:) or the wind that blows from the direction of the Hijor [which is on what is called the north, but what is rather to be called the north-west, side of the Kaabeh]: (M, Ḳ:) or the wind that blows from the direction of the right hand of a person facing the Kibleh [by which is meant the angle of the Black Stone; i. e., correctly speaking, from the north]: (Th, M, Ḳ:) or, correctly, the wind that blows from between the place of sunrise and the constellation of the Bear (banaAt naEoX): or from between the place of sunrise and the place of setting of the constellation of the Eagle (Aln-asor AlT-aAYir): (IAạr, Ḳ:)
[i. e. the wind that blows from some point of the north-east quarter, or nearly so: but it was probably thus named as being the wind that blows from the direction of the XimaAl (or left side) of a person facing the rising sun; and therefore the north wind or a northerly wind:] it seldom, or never, blows in the night: (Ḳ:) when it blows for seven days upon the people of Egypt, they prepare the graveclothes, for its nature is deadly: it is cold and dry: (TA:) [see also nakobaMCu:] the pl. of XamaAlN is XamaAlaAtN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and XamaAYilu, which is anomalous, as though pl. of XamaAlapN: (Ṣ, O:) AlOaXaAmil also occurs, coupled with AlOajaAnib, in a verse of Et-Tirimmáh; and [as OajaAnibu is a reg. pl. of OajonubN, which is a pl. of januwbN,] ISd thinks that they formed from XamolN the pl. OaXomalN; and then from this last, the pl. OaXaAmilu. (TA.)
[Hence,] one says, OaSabotu mino fulaAnK XamalFA↓ i. e. riyHFA [† I perceived from such a one an odour, app. meaning a foul odour]. (TA.)

hom.sense: XimaAlN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) applied to one of the hands or arms, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) The left; contr. of yamiynN; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also XiymaAlN↓, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, AlX-amAl and AlX-mAl are erroneously put for AlX-imaAl and AlX-iymaAl,]) the latter thought by ISd to be used only by poetic license, for XimaAlN, (TA,) and XimolaAlN↓, (AA, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) this last not known to Ks nor to Aṣ: (TA:) of the fem. gender: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) pl. [of pauc.] OaXomulN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) because it is fem., (Ṣ, O,) and [of mult.] XamaAYilu, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is anomalous, (Ṣ, O,) and XumulN, and XimaAlN like the sing. (Ḳ.)

And The direction [or side] of the hand so called: you say, Ailotafata yamiynFA waXimaAlFA i. e. [He looked, or turned his face,] in the direction of the ymyn and in the direction of the XmAl: and the pl. in this sense also is OuXomulN and XamaAYilu: (Mṣb:) you say, cahaba UilaI Oayomuni AlUibili waOaXomulihaA He went to the right sides of the camels and the left sides thereof. (TA in art. ymn.)

[Hence,] ‡ Ill luck, unluckiness, or evil fortune. (Ḳ, TA.) Tayoru AlX-imaAli means ‡ Birds of ill luck: (A, TA:) every bird from which one augurs evil. (O, TA.) One says, jaraI lahu guraAbu XimaAlK, meaning † What was disliked, or hated, happened to him: as though the bird [to which this is likened] came to him from the XimaAl [or direction of the left hand]. (TA.) And when the place that a person occupies is rendered evil, one says, fulaAnN EinodiI biAlX-imaAli † [Such a one is with me, or in my estimation, in an evil plight]. (TA.)
See also XamaAlN.
Also Every handful of corn, or seedproduce, which the reaper grasps [app. because grasped with his left hand]. (Ḳ.)

And A sort of bag that is put upon the udder of the ewe or goat (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) when it (i. e. the udder, TA) is heavy [with milk]: (Ḳ,* TA:) or it is peculiar to the she-goat: (Ḳ:) pl. XumulN. (Ḳ voce EaraAbapN.)

And A similar thing that is put to the raceme of a palm-tree, made with pieces of [the garments called] Oakosiyap [pl. of kisaMCN], in order that the fruit may not be shaken off. (Ṣ, O.) [In this sense it may perhaps be from the same word as pl. of XamolapN.]
And A mark made with a hot iron (simapN) upon the udder of a ewe or goat. (Ḳ.)

Also A nature; or a natural disposition or temper or the like: (O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) accord. to Er-Rághib, so called because [it is as though it were a thing] inwrapping the man [and restricting his freedom of action], like as the [garments called] XimaAl [pl. of XamolapN] inwrap the body: (TA:) the pl. is XamaAYilu, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and XimaAlN, also, [which seems to be rarely used as a sing. in this sense,] may be a pl., like dilaASN. (TA; and Ḥam p. 489, q. v.) ʼAbd-Yaghooth El-Hárithee says,
Oalamo taEolamaA Oan-a AlmalaAmapa nafoEuhaA
qaliylN wamaA lawomiI OaxiImino XimaAliyaA
[Know not ye two that the utility of censure is little, and my censuring my brother is not of my nature, or of my natural dispositions?]: (O, TA:) here it may be a pl., of the class of hijaAnN and dilaASN: or it may be [XamaAliyaA,] an instance of transposition, for XamaAYiliI. (TA.)
See also Ximil-N.

entry.sense: XamoOalN and XamoOal-N: see XamaAlN.
XamuwlN: see XamaAlN.

Also Wine: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or wine that is cool (Ḳ, TA) to the taste; but this is not of valid authority; (TA;) as also maXomuwlapN↓: [wine is said to be] thus called because it envelops (taXomalu) men with its odour: or because it has a strong puff (EaSofap), [when opened,] like that of the [wind called] XamaAl [in the CK XmAl]. (Ḳ, TA.)
XamiylN: see XamaAlN.
XmAlp [thus in my original, without any syll. signs, probably XimaAlapN, like sitaArapN, &c.,] The lurkingplace (qutorap) of a hunter or sportsman: pl. XamaAYilu. (TA.)
XamaAliI-N Of, or relating to, the quarter of the XamaAl [or north, or northerly, wind]. (KL.)
And A cold day. (KL.)

hom.sense: XimolaAlN: see Ximil-N, in two places:
and see XimaAlN.

entry.sense: XumoluwlN; and its pl. XamaAliylu: see XamalN, in three places.
XamaAliylu also signifies The shoots that divaricate at the heads of branches, like the fruitstalks of the raceme of the palm-tree. (Ṣ, O.)
[Hence,] cahabuwA XamaAliyla They went away in distinct parties: (Ḳ:) or they dispersed themselves. (Ṣ, O.)
And vawobN XamaAliylu A garment, or piece of cloth, rent, or slit, in several places; (O, TA;) like XamaATiyTu. (Ṣ, O.)
XamaAliylu AlnwI means baqaAyaAhu [i. e. The remains of AlnwI: but I doubt whether this word be correctly transcribed]. (TA.)
XimoliylN: see Ximil-N.
XaAmalN and XaOomalN: see XamaAlN.

OamorN XaAmilN i. q. EaAm-N [i. e. An event, or a case, that includes persons or things in common, in general, or universally, within the compass of its effect or effects, its operation or operations, its influence, or the like; or that is common, general, or universal, in its effect, &c.]. (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb, TA.)
lawonN XaAmilN A black colour overspread with another colour. (O, TA.)
XawomalN: see XamaAlN.
XayomalN: see XamaAlN.
XiymaAlN: see XimaAlN.
miXomalN: see XamolapN.
Also A short sword, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or a short and slender sword, like the migowal, (TA,) over which a man covers himself with his garment. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
maXomalapN The place [or quarter] whence blows the [north, or northerly, wind called] XamaAl. (Ḥam p. 628.)
miXomalapN: see XamolapN, in two places.
miXomaAlN A [garment of the kind called] miloHafap, (Ḳ, TA,) with which one wraps, or inwraps, himself (yuXotamalu bihi). (TA.) [See also XamolapN.]

maXomuwlN A man smitten, or blown upon, by the [north, or northerly,] wind called XamaAl: (Ṣ, O:) and in like manner, a meadow, and a pool of water left by a torrent; (O;) or, applied to this last, smitten by the wind thus called so as to become cool: (Ṣ:) and hence, with p {maXomuwlapN}, wine ‡ cool to the taste; (Ṣ, O, TA;*) or wine exposed to the XamaAl and so rendered cool and pleasant: (TA: see also XamuwlN:) and fire upon which the wind called the XamaAl has blown: (Ṣ, O:) and a night cold, with [wind that is called] XamaAl. (TA.)

[Hence,] ‡ One whose natural dispositions are liked, approved, or found pleasant: (Ḳ:) from [the same epithet applied to] water upon which the XamaAl has blown, and which it has cooled: or, as ISd thinks, from XamuwlN [q. v.]: (TA:) or maXomuwlu AlxalaAYiqi a man whose natural dispositions are commended; as being likened to wine that is commended: and also whose natural dispositions are discommended; as though from AlX-amaAlu, because they do not commend it when it disperses the clouds: (Ḥar p. 285:) [for] OaxolaAqN maXomuwlapN [sometimes] means discommended, evil, natural dispositions. (IAạr, ISk, TA.) The saying of Aboo-Wejzeh,
maXomuwlapu AlOunosi majonuwbN mawaAEiduhaA
is expl. by IAạr as meaning † Her familiarity passes away with the XamaAl, and her promises pass away with the januwb [which is the opposite of the XamaAl]: or, as some relate it,
majonuwbapu AlOunosi maXomuwlN mawaAEiduhaA
[meaning in like manner, as is said in the TA, on the authority of IAạr, in art. jnb: or,] accord. to ISk, meaning her familiarity is commended, because the jnwb, with rain, is desired for abundance of herbage; and her promises are not commended. (TA.)

nawFI maXomuwlapN, a phrase used by Zuheyr, is expl. as meaning † [A tract, or place, towards which one journeys,] that separates friends; because the [wind called] XamaAl disperses the clouds: (TA:) or it means quickly [or soon] becoming exposed to view; (ISk, O, TA;) from the fact that when the wind called the XamaAl blows the clouds, they delay not to become cleared away, and to depart: (O:) or, accord. to IAạr, it means maOoxuwcN bihaA caAtu AlX-imaAli [in which the direction of the left hand is taken]. (TA.)

In the saying,
Hamalato bihi fiI layolapK maXomuwlapN
the meaning is, fariEapN [i. e. One in a state of fright became pregnant with him in a certain night]. (TA, referring to the phrase XamolN mino junuwnK.)
muXotamilN: see XamilN
One says, jaMCa muXotamilFA bisayofihi like as one says murotadiyFA [i. e. He came having his sword hung upon him]. (TA.)
And jaMCa fulaAnN muXotamilFA EalaI daAhiyapK ‡ [Such a one came conceiving a calamity]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Xan-a AlmaMCa, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXonunu}, inf. n. Xan-N, (Mgh, TA,) He scattered the water; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or poured it scatteringly; (Mgh;) or poured it and scattered it; or, as some say, poured it in a manner like that which is termed naDoHN [i. e. sprinkling]; (TA;) EalaI AlX-araAbi [upon the wine, or beverage]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) san-ahu signifies “he poured it gently.” (TA.) And Xan-ati AlEayonu damoEahaA The eye poured forth its tears; (TA;) or sent forth [or shed] its tears; like Xal-at, (Lḥ, TA in art. Xl,) which is asserted by Yaạḳoob to be formed by substitution [of l for n]. (TA in that art.)

And, from the former, Xan-a AlgaArapa, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Mṣb,) ‡ He scattered, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) or poured, (Ḳ, TA,) the horsemen making a raid, or sudden attack, and engaging in conflict, or the horsemen urging their horses, AlgaArapa meaning Alxayola Almugiyrapa, (Mgh, Mṣb,) from every direction, Ealayohimo [upon them]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AXn-hA↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the latter mentioned in the Mj, (Mṣb,) by IF, but disapproved by the people of chaste speech. (TA.)

And Xan-a bisaloHihi (AA, Ṣ,* TA) He cast forth his excrement, or dung, in a thin [and scattered] state: and one says of the HubaAraI [or bustard] taXun-u bicaroqihaA [It casts forth its dung in a thin and scattered state]. (AA, TA.)
And Xan-a Ealayohi diroEahu He put (lit. poured) on him his coat of mail. (TA.)
Xan-a Aljamalu mina AlEaTaXi, [aor. accord. to general rule _i,] The camel became dried up [like a Xan-, q. v.,] from thirst. (TA.) And Xan-ati Alxiroqapu The rag became dried up. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. taXoniynN and taXonaAnN [inf. ns. of Xn-n] The dripping, or dropping by degrees, of water from the Xan-ap [or old and worn-out water-skin or the like]. (TA. [See also XaniynN.])
4: see 1:
and see also what next follows {5}.
