5. taXan-anati Alqirobapu, and tXAn-t↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AXn-t↓ and AstXn-t↓, (Ḳ,) The water-skin became old, and worn out: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or tXAn-↓, said of skin, or a skin, does not signify thus, but signifies, (AA, Ṣ,) or signifies also, (Ḳ,) and so tXn-n, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) said of the skin of a man, in extreme old age, (Ṣ,) it contracted, shrank, shrivelled, or wrinkled; or became contracted or shrunk, &c.; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and dried up: (Ṣ, TA:) and AstXn-↓ is likewise said of the skin of a man, meaning it became old, and worn out, like the old, and worn-out, Xan-. (Ḥar p. 675.) It is said in a trad., AlquroMnu laA yatofahu walaA yataXaAn-u↓ [expl. in art. tfh]. (TA.) See also a tropical usage of AstXn-↓ in a trad. cited in the first paragraph {1} of art. bl.
tXn-n is also said of the skin of a man as meaning It became altered [for the worse] in odour, in extreme old age. (TA.)
6. taXaAn-a: see 5, in three places.
Also It was or became, mixed. (Ḳ.)
7. [AnXn- It became poured out, or forth; it flowed. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]
[Hence,] AnXn- Alc-iYobu fiI Alganami † The wolf made an incursion among the sheep or goats; as also AnXl-: mentioned by Az in art. nXg. (TA.)
10. AstXn-: see 5, in three places.

Also, (Kh, Ṣ, Ḳ,) said of a man, (Kh, Ṣ, TA,) and of a camel, (TA,) ‡ He became lean, or emaciated, (Kh, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) like the water-skin that has become old, and worn out: so says Aboo-Kheyreh: (TA:) or, said of an animal, he became dried up, and lean, or emaciated. (Ḥar p. 530.)
And AstXn- UilaI All-abani i. q. EaAma, (Ḳ,) i. e. He betook himself to milk, or the milk, and desired it eagerly, or longed for it. (TA.)

R. Q. 1. XanoXanapN [an inf. n., of which the verb, if it be used, is XanoXana,] The motion of paper, and of a new garment: [or rather the making a kind of crackling sound by the motion thereof:] mentioned by Az in art. fqE: (TA:) and naXonaXapN signifies the same: both thus expl. by IAạr. (TA in art. qE.)

hom.sense: Xan-N A skin, (Mṣb,) or a water-skin, (Ṣ, Mgh,) or a small water skin, (Ḳ,) or, as some say, any vessel made of skin, (TA,) applied by a poet to a dalow [or leathern bucket], (Ḥam p. 602,) that is old, and worn out; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) and so Xan-apN↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) but app. one that is small: (Ṣ: [in which this addition to the explanation seems to relate peculiarly to the latter word: see an ex. of this latter word in some verses cited in the first paragraph {1} of art. sqI:]) or both signify an old water-skin; as also miXan-N↓: (MA:) and XananN↓, also, signifies an old, worn-out, water-skin: (TA:) pl. (of the first, Mgh, Mṣb) XinaAnN: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and Lḥ mentions the phrase qirobapN OaXonaAnN, as though they applied the term Xan-N to every portion of the qrbp and then pluralized it thus; but he says that he had not heard OaXonaAnN as a pl. of Xan-N except in this case: (TA:) the water in a Xan- is cooler [than that in a skin not so old]. (Mgh.) It is said in a prov., laA yuqaEoqaEu liI biAlX-inaAni [A confused and clattering noise will not be made to me with the old and worn-out water-skins to frighten me]: (Ṣ in the present art.: [in the Ṣ and Ḳ in art. qE, with maA in the place of lA; and in the Ḳ in that art., with lahu in the place of lI:]) maA yuqaEoqaEu lahu biAlX-inaAni is applied to him who will not be abased by misfortunes, nor frightened by that which has no reality: (Ṣgh and Ḳ in art. qE:) or it means, he will not be deceived nor frightened: XinaAn being pl. of Xan-N, a dried up skin, which is shaken to a camel to frighten him. (L and TA in art. qE.) An old man is likened to the skin thus termed. (Ḥar p. 675.) And Xan-apN↓ signifies also ‡ A worn-out old woman; as being likened to the skin thus termed. (IAạr, TA.) And one says, rafaEa fulaAnN AlX-an-a, meaning † Such a man raised himself bearing upon the palm of his hand. (IKh, TA.)
Also i. q. grD [app. garaDN, i. e. A butt, at which one shoots or casts: probably because an old water-skin was sometimes used as a butt]: pl. as above. (Mṣb.)
[And, as Freytag states, on the authority of Meyd, † Dry herbage.]
Also Weakness. (TA.)

entry.sense: Xan-apN: see Xan-N, in two places.
XananN: see Xan-N, first sentence.
XanaAnN a dial. var. of XanoMnN [inf. n. of XaniYa], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) signifying Hatred; [or the hating of another;] (Ṣ;) mentioned by AO. (Ṣ in art. XnO.)
XunaAnN Water in a scattered state, or being scattered. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And (Ḳ) Cold water: (Aṣ, Skr, ISd, Ḳ:) this explanation is preferred by Aboo-Naṣr. (TA.)
And Clouds (saHaAb) pouring (yaXun-u i. e. yaSub-u) water. (Skr, TA.)

XanuwnN A camel in a state between that of the lean, or emaciated, and that of the fat; (Ṣ;) so called because some of his fatness has gone: (Aboo-Kheyreh, TA:) one says mahozuwlN; then munoqK, when he has become a little fat; then XanuwnN; then saAH-N; and then muvaroTimN, when fat in the utmost degree: (Lḥ, TA:) so says Aboo-Ma'add El-Kilá- bee. (TA in art. sH.) [But it is said that] it signifies also Lean, or emaciated; (Ḳ;) applied to a beast: (TA:) and fat: thus having two contr. meanings. (Ḳ.)
Also Hungry: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) applied in this sense by Et-Tirimmáh to a wolf, because this animal is not described as fat or lean. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: Poured forth: applied in this sense by the Hudhalee poet ʼAbd-Menáf to thick blood (Ealaq). (TA.)
XaniynN And Pure milk upon which cold water has been poured: (IAạr, TA:) or any milk, whether fresh or collected in a skin at different times, upon which water is poured. (Ḳ, TA.)
And The dropping (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) by degrees, (TA,) of water (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) from a skin, (TA,) and of tears. (Ṣ, TA. [See also 2, and see XinoXinapN.])

entry.sense: Water that drops (Ṣ, Ḳ) from a skin, or from a tree. (Ṣ.)

XaAn-apN The [channel called] madofaE [q. v.] of a small valley: or a small madofaE of a valley: (TA: [the want of a vowel-sign in my original renders it doubtful which of these meanings is the right one:]) or XawaAn-u, its pl., signifies the channels of water, of mountains, that pour forth into valleys from a rugged place. (AA, TA.)

hom.sense:
XinoXinapN A nature; or a natural, a native, or an innate, disposition or temper or the like; syn. TabiyEapN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) and xuluqN, (Ṣ,) and sajiy-apN: (TA:) and a custom, habit, or wont: (Mgh, Ḳ:) [pl. XanaAXinu.] One says fiyhi mino Oabiyhi XanaAXinu In him are habits [or natural dispositions inherited] from his father. (TA.) Hence,
XinoXinapN OaEorifuhaA mino Oaxozamo
[A natural disposition, or a habit, which I know, as inherited from Akhzam]: (Ṣ, Meyd, Mgh:) or, accord. to one relation, niXoniXapN, which is app. formed by transposition from XinoXinapN: (Meyd:) a prov.: (Meyd, Mgh:) [of its origin there are different explanations: see Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 658, and Ḥar pp. 591 and 596:] Oaxozamu is the proper name of a man: (Meyd, Mgh, &c.:) or accord. to Lth, it is an epithet applied to a penis; one says kamarapN xazomaMCu “a glans of a penis having a short frænum,” and cakarN Oaxozamu; and XnXnp means the dropping of water [i. e., in this case, of the seminal fluid]: (Meyd:) the prov. is applied in relation to nearness of resemblance. (Meyd, Mgh.)
Also A bit of flesh-meat, as much as is chewed at once; syn. muDogapN: or a piece of flesh-meat; (Ḳ, TA;) and so niXoniXapN: on the authority of AA. (TA.)
And [the pl.] XanaAXinu signifies Bones; like sanaAsinu. (IAạr, L in art. sn.)

entry.sense: miXan-N: see Xan-N, first sentence.
miXan-apN A thing like the mikotal: [in the present day, a round shallow basket is thus called: pl. maXaAn-u.] (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. XaniYahu, (Th, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) and XanaOahu, (Ḳ,) but this is said by AHeyth to be a bad dial. var. of the former, (TA,) aor. _a {yaXonaOu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XanoCN (AO, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XinoCN and XunoCN (Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybánee, Ṣ, Ḳ) and XanoOapN (Ḳ, TA, in the CK XanACap [i. e. XanaMCapN, which is afterwards added in the TA, not as in the Ḳ, and mentioned in the Ṣ but not there said to be an inf. n.,]) and XanaON (TA from Es-Safákusee) and XanaMCN (TA [as from J, but perhaps from Az, for I do not find it in the Ṣ,]) and maXonaON (Ṣ, CK, and TA as from Es-Safá- kusee, not as from the Ḳ,) and maXonaOapN and maXonuWapN (Ḳ, TA, the last in the CK maXonuwCap [i. e. maXonuwoCapN],) and maXoniYapN (TA from Es-Safákusee) and XanaMnN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is anomalous as being of a measure regularly employed [only] for the inf. n. of a verb signifying motion and agitation, as DarabaAnN and xafaqaAnN, (Ṣ, TA,) for though it has been said that [hatred (which it signifies) is attended by anger and] anger is accompanied by agitation of the heart, there is no necessary connection between hatred and anger, and it is anomalous also as being of a measure not proper to [the inf. n. of] a trans. verb, (TA,) and XanoMnN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is also anomalous, and [said to be] the only instance of its kind (Ṣ, TA) except lay-aAnN, though some few others have been mentioned, as zayodaAnN, but this is not well known, [and xaXoyaAnN, of which the same may be said,] and waXokaAnN [perhaps a simple subst.], and jawolaAnN which is said to occur in a verse [perhaps contracted from jawalaAn by poetic license], (TA,) and AO mentions XanaAnN, without C, as being like XanoMnN; (Ṣ;) these inf. ns. being fourteen, which is said by IḲṭṭ to be the greatest number of inf. ns. to any one verb, only seven other verbs, he says, having this number, namely, qadara, laqiIa, warada, halaka, tam-a, makava and galaba; but Es-Safákusee makes the inf. ns. of XaniYa to be fifteen, [though the fifteenth form (which is perhaps maXonuwoCapN) I do not find mentioned,] and this is the greatest number known; (TA;) He hated him: (IḲooṭ, IF, Ṣ, ISd, IḲṭṭ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.:) or, as some say, he hated him vehemently. (TA.) yXnI, [app. yuXonaI, for yuXonaOu,] with the hemzeh changed into I, occurs in a trad. (TA.) And XuniYa signifies He (a man, Ṣ) was hated, (Ṣ, and so accord. to some copies of the Ḳ,) or was rendered hateful, or an object of hatred, (so accord. to other copies of the Ḳ,) even if beautiful or comely. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

XaniYa lahu Haq-ahu, (Ḳ,) so says AʼObeyd, or, accord. to Th, XanaOa Uilayohi, like manaEa [in form], and this is the more correct, aor. of each _a, (TA,) He gave him his right, or due. (AʼObeyd, Th, Ḳ, TA.) And XaniYa bihi He acknowledged it: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he gave him (Ḳ) his right, or due, (TA,) [or the meaning in the Ḳ may be he gave it,] and declared himself clear, or quit, of him or it; as also XanaOa: (Ḳ:) [but accord. to SM, this is wrong, for he says that] the author of the Ḳ should have said, or XaniYa Uilayohi, like XanaOa, aor. _a {yaXonaOu}, he gave him, and declared himself clear, or quit, of him or it. (TA.) And XaniYa AlX-aIoCa He produced the thing: (Ḳ, TA:) or, as AʼObeyd says, XaniYa Haq-ahu he acknowledged his right, or due, and produced it from his possession. (TA.)

entry.sense: 6. taXaAnaWuwA They hated one another. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

XanoCN and XinoCN and XunoCN [all mentioned above as inf. ns., when used as simple substs. signify Hatred; and thus XanaMCapN↓, likewise mentioned above as an inf. n., signifies accord. to the Ṣ; and so XaniyoYapN↓ accord. to Freytag, as on the authority of Meyd; and app. also XanuwoCapN, q. v.; or all signify] vehement hatred; in which sense the first is expl. by AO: (TA:) or XanaMCapN↓ signifies hatred mixed with enmity and evilness of disposition. (Ḥam p. 108)
XanuWapN: see XanuwoCapN, in three places.

hom.sense: XanaMCapN: see XanoCN, in two places.

Also, and XanaAYiyapN↓, epithets applied to a man, Rendered hateful, or an object of hatred, evil in disposition. (Lth, O, TA.) [See also the latter word voce XanoMn; and see maXonuwoCN, and miXonaMCN.]

XanuwoCapN The removing oneself far, or keeping aloof, from unclean things; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and the continual doing so, or the continual purification of oneself; as also XanuWapN↓; and accord. to the Ḳ, XunuwoCapN, but this is not found elsewhere. (TA.)

Hence, (Ṣ,) Oazodu XanuwoCapa, the appellation of a tribe of El-Yemen; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) sometimes called Oazodu Xanuw-apa: (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ:) [or] this tribe was so called because of XanoMn among them; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e. because of mutual hatred that occurred among them: (TA:) [whence it seems that XanuwoCapN signifies also Hatred:] or because of their removing far from their [original] district: or, accord. to El-Khafájee, because of their high lineage, and good deeds; from the phrase rajulu XanuwodapK, meaning A man of pure lineage and of manly virtue; and AO says the like. (TA.)
[And accord. to Reiske, as stated by Freytag, (who has written it XanuWapN↓ in all its senses,) it is expl. by Meyd as meaning What is esteemed sordid, of words and of actions.]
Also One who removes himself far, or keeps aloof, from unclean things; (Ḳ, TA;) and so XanuWapN↓. (TA.) Thus both of these words are epithets, as well as substs. (TA.)

entry.sense: XaniyoYapN: see XanoCN.

XanoMn, of which the fem. is XanoMnapN and XanoOaI, [so that one may say either XanoMnN or XanoMnu,] is an epithet applied to a man; (Ḳ;) [signifying either Hating or (like maXonuwoCN) hated; the former meaning seeming to be indicated by what immediately precedes it in the Ḳ; but the latter appears from what here follows to be the right meaning, and perhaps it may be that which is meant in the Ḳ;] as also XanaAniYapN↓ or XanaAYiyapN↓ [q. v. voce XanaMCapN]: so accord. to different copies of the Ḳ. (TA.)

In the Ḳur v. 3 and 11, it is accord. to some an inf. n., and some read there XanaMn: [see 1, first sentence:] accord. to others, it is an epithet, signifying mubogaDN or bagiyDN [i. e. Hated or odious]. (TA.)

XanoMnu AlX-itaMCi, in a trad. of Kaab, is said to be a metaphorical expression for barodu AlX-itaMCi ‡ [The cold of winter]; because it is hated: or, as some say, by the barod thereof is meant ease and repose: and the meaning intended is either mutual hatred or ease and repose. (TA.)
XanaAYiyapN: see XanaMCapN, and XanoMn.
XanaAniYapN: see XanoMn.
XaAniYN Hating, or a hater, (Fr, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) and an enemy: (Fr, TA:) fem. with p {XaAniYapN}. (Mgh, Mṣb.)

laA OabaA liXaAniYika, as also laA Oaba liXaAniYika, (Ṣ, O, [but in my two copies of the Ṣ liXaAniyka, which perhaps expresses the general pronunciation, and in the TA lA AbA lXAnYk and lA AbA lXAnyk,]) means limubogiDika [i. e., lit., May there be no father to thy hater];
and is said by ISk to be a metonymical expression for laA OabaA laka [q. v., lit. an imprecation, but generally meant as an expression of praise]. (Ṣ, O, TA.)

XawaAniYu AlmaAli means [Camels, or the like,] not avariciously retained; as though hated, and therefore liberally given away: (IAạr, Ḳ, TA:) XwAnY being app. an act. part. n. [in the pl.] used in the sense of a pass. part. n., like the instances in maMCN daAfiqN and EiyXapN raADiyapN. (MF, TA.)

maXonaON, applied to a man, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, O,) like maXonaEN [in form, and perhaps in meaning], (AʼObeyd, TA,) Foul, or ugly, in aspect; as also miXonaMCN↓: (Ṣ, O:) or foul, or ugly, (Ḳ, TA,) in face, (TA,) even if made an object of love [by good qualities]: (Ḳ, TA:) [originally an inf. n., and therefore] used alike as sing. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and dual (Ṣ, O) and pl. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and masc. and fem.: (Ḳ:) so says Lth: (TA:) or one who hates men; (Ḳ;) and so miXonaMCN↓, accord. to ʼAlee Ibn-Hamzeh El-Iṣbahánee: (TA:) or ↓this last signifies one whom men hate: or it may be well rendered one who does much for which he is to be hated; for it is one of the measures of the act. part. n. [used in an intensive sense]. (AʼObeyd, Ḳ.)
miXonaMCN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

maXonuwoCN, applied to a man, (Ṣ,) Hated, (Ṣ, and so in some copies of the Ḳ, [see also XanoMn,]) or rendered hateful, or an object of hatred, (so accord. to other copies of the Ḳ,) even if beautiful, or comely; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and maXonuw-N and maXoniI-N signify the same. (Ḳ in art. Xnw.)

maXoniyoYapN, occurring in a trad. of ʼÁïsheh, [A kind of food that is supped, or sipped;] i. q. HasaMCN and talobiynapN: [see these two words:] said by IAth to be irregularly formed from maXonuwoCapN, by changing the C into I [so that the word becomes maXonuwyapN, and then, by rule, maXoniy-apN, which is mentioned in the TA, in art. Xnw, as occurring thus in a trad.,] and then by restoring the C [in the place of the second I], the meaning being hated. (TA.)
1. Xaniba, aor. _a {yaXonabu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XanabN, (TA,) He had the quality termed XanabN meaning as expl. below. (Ḳ.)
And It (a day) was, or became, cool, or cold. (A, Ḳ.)

XanabN Lustre, and fineness, or delicacy, or thinness, and coolness, and sweetness, in the teeth: (A, Ḳ:) or lustre, and fineness, or delicacy, or thinness, in the fore teeth: (TA:) or these two qualities, together with coolness and sweetness, in the mouth, accord. to Aṣ, or in the teeth: (TA:) or coolness and sweetness in the teeth: or sharpness of the teeth: (Ṣ:) or sharpness of the canine teeth, like garobN, so that they appear like a saw: (Ḳ:) or white specks in the teeth: (A, Ḳ:) or the state of the teeth when they appear somewhat tinged with blackness, like the appearance of blackness in hail; guruwbN signifying the “lustre” of the teeth; and ZalomN, their “whiteness that is as though there were over it a blackness:” (ISh, TA:) Abu-l-ʼAbbás says, It is variously expl., as a serrated state of the teeth: and their clearness and cleanness: and their being separate, or apart, one from another: and the sweetness of their odour: (TA:) El-Jarmee says, I heard Aṣ say that this word signifies coolness of the mouth and teeth; and I said, Our companions say that it is their sharpness when they come forth; by which is meant their new, or recent, and fresh state; for when they have undergone the lapse of years, they become abraded, or worn: but he said, It is nothing but their coolness: and the saying of Dhu-r-Rummeh,
wafiI All-ivaAti wafiI OanoyaAbihaA Xanabu [which should be rendered And in the gums, and in her canine teeth, is coolness], corroborates the assertion of Aṣ; for there is no sharpness in the gum: (Ṣ, L, TA:) it is also related of Aṣ that he said, I asked Ru-beh respecting the meaning of XanabN, and he took a grain of pomegranate, and pointed to its lustre: (Mz, TA:) [and XunobapN↓ signifies the same:] a poet says,
munaS-abuhaA HamoXN OaHam-u yaziynuhu
EawaAriDu fiyhaA XunobapN waguruwbu
[Her even set of front teeth are slender and white, side teeth in which are coolness and lustre adorning them]. (O, TA.)
[In the present day, it signifies The mustache.]
XanibN and XaAnibN↓, (A, Ḳ,) the former regular, the latter on the authority of usage, (TA,) A cool, or cold, day. (A, Ḳ.)
XunobapN Coolness, or coldness, of a day. (O, Ḳ.)
See also XanabN, near the end.
XaniybN: see OaXonabu.
XaAnibN: see XanibN:
and what here follows.

OaXonabu Having the quality termed XanabN meaning as expl. above; (A, O, Ḳ;) as also XaAnibN↓, (Ḳ,) which is irregular, (TA,) and XaniybN↓, (Ḳ,) [which is likewise irregular;] but the first of these three is the most common: (TA:) applied to a man, (O,) and to the vagor [or front teeth], (A,) [and to the mouth, as in a verse cited voce zaronabN:] fem. XanobaMCu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) applied to a woman, (Ṣ, O,) and also written XamobaMCu, (Ḳ,) the n being changed into m because of the following b, and in like manner [the pl. XunobN is also written] XumobN. (TA.)
XanobaMCu also signifies A pomegranate (rum-aAnapN) such as is termed Uimoliysiy-apN, having no grains, but only juice within the rind, (A, Ḳ, TA,) in the form of grains without stones. (TA.)
miXonabN A young boy whose teeth are sharp and serrated by reason of his youthfulness. (IAạr, O.)
maXaAnibu Sweet mouths. (O, Ḳ.)
Q. 1. Xanobava AlhawaI qalobahu, (Ṣ and L in art. Xbv, as Q. Q., and Ḳ in the present art.,) inf. n. XanobavapN, (Ṣ, L,) Love clave to his heart. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
XunaAbivN Thick, gross, big, bulky, coarse, or rough; syn. galiyZN. (Ḳ.)
See also AlX-anobavu.
xiyaAru Xanobara: see the former word in art. xyr.

1. Xanija, aor. _a {yaXonaju}, inf. n. XanajN; and tXn-j↓, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) and AnXnj↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AXnj↓; (TA;) said of the skin (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) in consequence of the touch [or proximity] of fire [&c.], (Mgh,) and of the face, and of a member or limb, (A,) of a finger, &c., (TA,) It contracted, shrank, shrivelled, or wrinkled; or became contracted or shrunk, &c. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ, TA.) [taXan-ujN↓ is often used as meaning Spasmodic contraction of a muscle, &c.] And one says, fiI OaEoDaAYihi taXan-ujN↓ and taXoniyjN↓ [In his limbs, or members, is a contraction]. (A.)

2. Xn-jhu, inf. n. taXoniyjN, He [or it] contracted, shrunk, shrivelled, or wrinkled, it; namely, the skin [&c.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See 1, last sentence. One says also, Xn-j Alxay-aATu AlqabaMCa [The tailor puckered the tunic]. (A. [In the Mgh, the wrinkling around the anus is said to be like the taXoniyj of the qabaMC.])
4: see 1.
5: see 1, in three places; and see muXan-ajN.
7: see 1.

hom.sense: XanajN inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ, &c.)

Also A camel: (Lth, IDrd, Ḳ:) or a heavy camel. (L in art. gnj.) ganajN EalaIXanajK is a phrase of the tribe of Hudheyl, meaning A man upon a camel: (Lth, IDrd, O:) or a man, or an old man, upon a heavy camel. (L in art. gnj.)
It is also said, in the L, that it signifies An old man, in the dial. of Hudheyl. (TA.)

entry.sense:
XanijN, applied to the skin, &c., Contracted, shrunk, shrivelled, or wrinkled. (TA.) And, applied to a man, Contracted,, &c., in the skin, and in the arm, or hand; as also OaXonaju↓. (M, TA.) And yadN XanijapN means Day-aqapu Alkaf-i [i. e. An arm contracted, or narrow, in the hand; or a hand contracted,, &c., in the palm, or in the palm and fingers]. (TA.) Xaniju Aln-asaA means Contracted in the Eiroq called AlnsA [app., in this instance, the sciatic nerve]: (TA:) it is an epithet of commendation applied to a horse; because, when he is contracted therein, his hind legs are not relaxed: (Ṣ, Ḳ:)
or it is an epithet of commendation applied to a horse of good breed; but not so when applied to a hackney: it is also applied to some other animals, that do not walk with freedom; to a gazelle, and to a wolf: (T, TA:) and sometimes to the raven, or crow, (T, Ṣ,) which hops as though it were shackled. (T, TA.)

hom.sense: OaXonaju: see XanijN.

XanijN OaXonaju and XanijN muXan-ajN↓ are expressions sometimes used; [OaXonaju being syn. with XanijN, as shown above, and in this case a corroborative; and] muXan-ajN↓ [when thus used] meaning Intensely contracted or shrunk, &c. (Lth, TA.)
Also Having one of his testicles smaller than the other; like OaXoraju, which is more approved. (TA.)

entry.sense: muXan-ajN: see OaXonaju, in two places.

qabaMCN muXan-ajN [A puckered tunic: see 2]. (A, Mgh.) saraAwiylu muXan-ajapN, mentioned in a trad., in which they are forbidden, are said to be Such [drawers, or trousers,] as are so ample that they fall down upon the boot so as to cover half of the foot; as though meaning that, being ample and long, they cease not to rise, and become puckered (fatataXan-aju↓). (TA.)

2. Xn-r Ealayohi, inf. n. taXoniyrN, He blamed him; found fault with him; attributed or imputed to him, or accused him of, a vice, or fault: (Ḳ:) or the same, (Ḳ,) or Xn-r bihi, (O,) or Xn-rhu, (TA,) he rendered him infamous; exposed his vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions; disgraced him; or put him to shame. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
XanorapN The gait, or manner of walking, of a righteous man. (O, Ḳ.) [See also XimorapN.]

XanaArN A vice, or fault: (Ṣ, O:) or the foulest vice or fault: (Ḳ:) and a disgrace, or shame, or thing that occasions one's being reviled: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or a disgraceful vice or fault: seldom used unless conjointly with EaArN: (TA:) accord. to Sh, (O,) a thing, or an affair, notorious for badness or foulness: (O, Ḳ:) pl. XanaAYiru. (TA.)
XunaAraI one of the names of The cat. (O, Ḳ.*)
Xun-aArN A certain white bird, found in water: of the dial. of Syria. (TA.)
Xin-iyrN and Xin-iyrapN↓, (O, Ḳ,) [the latter having an intensive meaning,] applied to a man, (O,) Abounding in evil or mischief, and in vices, or faults; bad in disposition. (O, Ḳ.)
Xin-iyrapN: see what next precedes.
maXonuwrapN A liberal, bountiful, or generous, woman: as also manoXuwrapN. (IAạr, T in art. nXr, TA.)

XuwniyzN, (Mgh, Ḳ,) so called by the Persians, (TA,) [and generally by the Arabs in the present day,] and XawoniyzN, as in the “Towsheeh” of El-Jelál Es-Suyootee, (TA,) and XiynyzN, (AḤn, L, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) without hemz, (AḤn, L,) the proper form, for so the Arabs called it, (IAạr, TA in art. swd,) or XiYoniyzN, (as in some copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA,) with hemz, (TA,) and XuwnuwzN, or XuWonuwzN, (as in different copies of the Ḳ,) and XihoniyzN, (ADk, Ḳ,) A kind of seed, (L,) or grain; (Mgh;) the same as AlHab-apu Als-awodaMCu [the black aromatic seed of a species of nigella; a sort of all-spice]; (Ḳ;) or said to be so: (Mgh:) or it is of Persian origin: (Ḳ:) so it is accord. to Ed-Deenäwaree [AḤn]: (TA:) but some say that AlHb-p AlswdAC is the same as AlHab-apu AlxaDoraMCu. (TA in art. swd.)

hom.sense: 1. XanuEa, aor. _u {yaXonuEu}, inf. n. XanaAEapN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XanaEN and XanaAEN, but this last, occurring in a verse, may be used by poetic license for XanaAEapN, (TA,) It (a thing, Ṣ) was, or became, bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly; (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) syn. qabuHa. (Mṣb. [In the Ṣ and O and Ḳ, it is said that XanaAEapN signifies the same as faZaAEapN; but the latter seems to import more than the former.])

XanaEa fulaAnFA He regarded such a one as bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly, (AisotaqobaHahu, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA, in the CK Asotaxaf-ahu,) and reviled, or vilified, him, (Xatamahu, O, Ḳ, TA, and so accord. to one of my copies of the Ṣ,) or loathed him, (saYimahu,) thus in some of the lexicons, [and accord. to one of my copies of the Ṣ,] but [SM says that] Xatamahu is shown to be the right reading by the saying of IAạr that XanaEahu, inf. n. XanoEN, means sab-ahu. (TA.) [See also 10.]
Also, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. XanoEN, (TA,) He disgraced such a one; put him to shame; or exposed his vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions. (O, Ḳ, TA.)

And XanaEa Alxiroqapa He frayed the torn-off piece of cloth so that it became shaggy (XaE-avahaA Hat-aI tanaf-aXa): (O, Ḳ: [in the CK, in the place of the last word of the explanation, which is for tatanaf-aXa, is put tanofaX-a:]) and in like manner one says of a thing similar to a xiroqap. (O.)
XaniEa bihi: see 10.

2. Alt-aXoniyEu signifies takoviyru AlX-anaAEapi [app. meaning The uttering, or saying, much, or often, what is bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly: and the doing what is bad, &c. much or often]: (Ḳ:) or the uttering, or saying, what is bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly, (KL, PṢ,) against any one: (PṢ:) and the representing, or regarding, as bad,, &c.: (KL, PṢ:*) and the committing [an action that is bad,, &c., or] a fault, or vitious action. (KL.) You say, Xan-aEotu Ealayohi, inf. n. taXoniyEN, (Ṣ, O,) I uttered, or said, what was bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly, against him: (PṢ:) from AlX-anaAEapu. (O.) And Xn-E Ealayohi AlOamora, inf. n. as above, He showed, or declared, to him that the affair was bad, evil,, &c.: (TA: [see also 5:]) or characterized the affair to him as bad, evil,, &c. (Mṣb.)

And The striving, labouring, or exerting oneself, and being quick, and vigorous, or energetic, syn. Alt-aXomiyru, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, Alt-aXohiyru,]) and AlAinokimaAXu, and Aljid-u, (O, Ḳ,) in pace, or going; (O,* Ḳ;) as also Alt-aXan-uEu↓ (Ḳ) [and AlUiXonaAEu↓]: thus Xn-E is said of a man, meaning He strove, laboured, or exerted himself, and was quick: (TA:) and in like manner Xan-aEato is said of a she-camel, (Aṣ, AʼObeyd, Ṣ, O,) and of camels, (O,) as also tXn-Et↓, (Ṣ,* O, expl. in the former by jad-ato only,) and AXnEt↓; (O;) in pace, or going: (Ṣ, O:) or AXnEt↓ said of a she-camel means she was quick, or swift. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4: see the next preceding sentence {2}, in three places.

hom.sense: 5. tXn-E Alqawoma He showed, or declared, the case of the people, or party, to be bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly, by reason of their disagreement, and the unsound, or unsettled, state of their opinion. (TA.)
And tXn-E He (a man) purposed to do a bad, an evil, an abominable, a foul, or an unseemly, thing or affair. (TA.)
See also 2, last sentence, in two places.

Hence, (IAạr, TA,) He prepared himself for fight: (IAạr, Ḳ, TA:) or, said of a party of men, they prepared themselves for fight: (O:) and accord. to AA, tXn-E lilX-ar-i He prepared himself for evil, or mischief. (O, TA.)
And It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) became rent, or slit. (O, Ḳ.)
tXn-E AlgaArapa He spread, or dispersed, the horsemen making a raid, or sudden attack, upon an enemy. (AA, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.)
And tXn-E Alfarasa He mounted the horse. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And tXn-E Als-ilaAHa He put on the weapon, or weapons. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 10. AstXnEhu He reckoned it bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly. (O, TA.) And accord. to Lth, (O, TA,) one says, raOaI OamorFA XaniEa↓ bihi, meaning AstXnEhu, (O, Ḳ, TA,) i. e. [He saw a thing] which he regarded as bad, evil,, &c. (TA.)
And accord. to him, one says also, qadi QsotaXonaEa bifulaAnK jaholuhu, (O, TA,) meaning His ignorance has rendered such a one light, inconstant, or unsteady. (TA.)
XaniEN: see XaniyEN.

XunoEapN the subst. from XanuEa; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) [i. e.] Badness, evilness, abominableness, foulness, or unseemliness; syn. quboHN; (Ḥar p. 196;) as also XunuwEN↓: (O, Ḳ:) thus in the saying, fiI fulaAnK XunuwEN↓ [In such a one is unseemliness, or ugliness]; as also naZorapN and rad-N [or rather rad-apN]: (TA:) and one says also, fiI wajohihi XunoEapN and rad-apN and naZorapN [app. meaning In his face is unseemliness, or ugliness]. (IAạr TA voce XufoEapN.)
Also Diabolical, or demoniacal possession; or madness, or insanity. (IAạr, TA.)
XunuwEN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

XaniyEN Bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;)
as also XaniEN↓ (O, Ḳ) and OaXonaEu↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) the last like Oakobaru in the phrase Aall-ehu Oakobaru, meaning kabiyrN, accord. to one of the two interpretations of this phrase: (O, TA:) pl. of the first XunuEN. (Mṣb, TA.*) It is applied to a day, in this sense: or as meaning disliked, or hated: (TA:) and so is OaXonaEu↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) in the former sense, (TA,) or in the latter. (O, Ḳ, TA.) And you say manoZarN XaniyEN and muXan-aEu↓ [An aspect that is bad, evil,, &c.] and AimoraOapN muXan-aEapN↓, meaning qabiyHapN [i. e. An unseemly, or ugly, woman]. (TA.) And AisomN XaniyEN [An evil, or abominable, name]: and qawomN XunuEu AlOasaAmiI [A people, or party, having evil, or abominable, names]. (A, TA.) And qiS-apN XanoEaMCu↓ [An evil, or abominable, or a foul, story]. (TA.) And gayorapN XanoEaMCu↓ Abominable, excessive jealousy: (O, Ḳ, TA:) in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, erroneously, gbrp. (TA.)

XanaEonaEN Incongruous, unsound, weak, or faulty, [and therefore unseemly,] in make; (IDrd, O, Ḳ, TA;) as also OaXonaEu↓ Alxaloqi; applied to a man: the former is from AlX-unuwEu: and some say that it signifies tall. (TA.)
OaXonaEu; and its fem. XanoEaMCu: see XaniyEN, in four places: and see also XanaEonaEN.
maXonaEN: see maXonaON, in art. XnO.
maXonuwEN i. q. maXohuwrN [Well, or commonly, known; notorious;, &c.]. (O, L, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. Xanafotu UilaI AlX-aIoCi, (Ṣ,) aor. _i {yaXonifu}, (O, Mṣb,) inf. n. XanofN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) I looked in a state of opposition, or resistance, (fiI QEotiraADK,) at the thing; like Xafanotu: (Ṣ, O:*) or AlX-anofu signifies the looking at a thing, (O,) or the looking at a thing like him who is opposing it, or resisting it, (kaAlmuEotariDi Ealayohi, Ḳ, TA,) and the raising of the eyes in looking at a thing, (TA,) like him who wonders at it, or like him who dislikes it, or hates it; (O, Ḳ, TA;) and so AlX-afonu, as AZ says. (TA.) [See also 2.]

Xanifa lahu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and bihi also, or, correctly, accord. to ISd, this verb is trans. in the sense here next following without any particle, (TA,) [but two exs. are cited in the O from trads. in which it is trans. by means of l,] aor. _a {yaXonafu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. XanafN, (Ṣ, O,) He hated him, (OabogaDahu,) and met him in a morose manner: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ: [in the Ḳ, the latter meaning is expressed by tanak-arahu, for tanak-ara lahu: in the Ṣ and O, the former meaning is expressed as above, on the authority of ISk; and it is also said that AlX-anofu is syn. with AlbugoDu and Alt-anak-uru:]) in the former of these two senses it is like XaYifahu, with C: (Ṣ, O:) or AlXnf [i. e. AlX-anafu] is a subst. signifying vehemence of enmity. (Ḥam p. 108.)
And Xanifa lahu, (IAạr, ISd, O,* Ḳ, TA,) and bihi, (ISd, TA,) i. q. faTina [i. e. He knew it; knew, had knowledge, or was cognizant, of it; or knew it instinctively;, &c.]. (IAạr, ISd, O, Ḳ, TA.)

And Xanifa, (Ḳ, TA, [in the former of which it is erroneously implied that the verb is followed by lahu,]) His upper lip turned upwards; (Ḳ, TA;) inf. n. XanafN; (TA;) or this is a subst., signifying a turning upwards of the upper lip: so says AZ. (O.)

2. Xan-afahaA, inf. n. taXoniyfN, He adorned her (i. e. a woman, Ṣ, or a girl, or young woman, O, Ḳ) with the [ornament called] Xanof; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) like as one says, qar-aTahaA; (Ṣ, TA;) as also OaXonafahaA↓. (Zj, O, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] Xan-afa kalaAmahu waqar-aTahu ‡ [He adorned and embellished his language]. (TA.)
Xn-f Uilayohi, inf. n. as above, He looked at him, or it, from the outer corner of the eye. (Yaạḳoob, TA.) [See also 1.]

entry.sense: 4: see the next preceding paragraph {2}.
5. tXn-ft She adorned herself with the [ornament called] Xanof; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) like as one says, tqr-Tt. (Ṣ.)

XanofN (incorrectly pronounced with damm, IDrd, O, Ḳ, i. e. XunofN, O, TA) The upper quroT [i. e. ear-ring or ear-drop]: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or a pendant (miEolaAqN) in [or suspended from] the quwf [app. meaning the upper part, or perhaps, the helix, in the CK erroneously written fawoq,] of the ear; (Lth, O, Ḳ;) and likewise such as is attached to necklaces: (Lth, O:) or such as is suspended from the upper part of the ear; what is suspended from the lower part [or lobe] thereof being termed quroTN; (IDrd, O, Ḳ;) or this latter is termed ruEovapN: (IAạr, TA:) or, as some say, i. q. quroTN: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] XunuwfN (IDrd, Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and [of pauc.] OaXonaAfN. (TA.)

XanifN Hating, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and meeting in a morose manner. (Ḳ.) IB cites, as an ex.,
walano tudaAwiI Eil-apa Alqalobi AlX-anifo
[And thou will not cure the hating heart]. (TA.)
XafapN XanofaMCu [A lip, meaning an upper lip] turning upwards: (O:) or XaApN XanofaMCu [A sheep or goat] having the upper lip turning upwards. (TA.)
XaAnifN Turning away, or averse. (O, Ḳ.) One says, maA liI OaraAka XaAnifFA Ean-iI What ails me that I see thee turning away, or averse, from me? (O.)
And Uin-ahu laXaAnifN Ean-aA biOanofihi ‡ Verily he is raising his nose [in aversion] from us. (O,* Ḳ.)
maXonuwfapN † A she-camel having a zimaAm [or noserein] attached to her. (AA, O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. Xanaqa AlbaEiyra, aor. _u {yaXonuqu} (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _i {yaXoniqu}, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. XanoqN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) He curbed the camel by means of his zimaAm [or nose-rein], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or pulled the xiTaAm [or halter, or leadingrope,] of the camel, (M,) while riding him, (Ṣ, M,) in the direction of his [own] head, (M,) so as to make the prominences behind his [the camel's] ears cleave to the upright piece of wood rising from the fore part of the saddle: (M, Ḳ:) or he raised the camel's head (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) by pulling his zimaAm, (M, Mṣb,) while riding him, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) like as the rider of the horse does with his horse: (Mṣb:) and AXnqhu↓ signifies the same: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or AXnq↓ is intrans.; you say, Xanaqa AlbaEiyra and AXnq↓ huwa, the reverse of the usual rule; (IJ, M;) or the latter is intrans. also; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) signifying he (the camel) raised his head. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.*)

Hence, XanaqotuhaA, occurring in a trad., referring to a female hare, inf. n. as above, means, as implying restraint, I cast, or shot, at her, or I struck her, so as to render her incapable of motion. (O.)
And Xanaqa AlbaEiyra, or Aln-aAqapa, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (M,) He bound the he-camel, or the she-camel, with the XinaAq [q. v.]. (M, Ḳ.)

And Xanaqa raOosa Ald-aAb-api, (M,) or raOosa Alfarasi, (Ḳ,) ‡ He bound (M, Ḳ) the head of the beast, (M,) or the head of the horse, (Ḳ,) to the upper part of a tree, (M,) or to the head of a tree, or to a tree, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,) or to a peg, (M,) or to an elevated peg, (Ḳ,) so that his neck became extended and erect. (M, TA.)

And Xanaqa Alqirobapa, (IDrd, O, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXonuqu}, (IDrd, O,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) † He bound the mouth of the water-skin with the bond called wikaMC, and then bound the extremity of its wikaMC to its fore legs: (IDrd, O, Ḳ, TA: [in the CK, OawokaOahA is erroneously put for OawokaAhaA, or, as in some copies of the Ḳ, wakaAhaA:]) or he suspended it: and [in like manner] AXnq↓ Alqirobapa, inf. n. as above, he suspended the water-skin to a peg: (TA:) or the latter signifies he put a XinaAq to the water-skin: (M:) or he bound the water-skin with a XinaAq, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) i. e. a cord with which its mouth is bound. (Ṣ.)

[Hence Xanaqahu, as used in the present day, and in post-classical works, meaning † He hanged him by the neck, till he died: (see the pass. part. n., below:) whence miXonaqapN↓, meaning A gallows; pl. maXaAniqu.]

Xanaqa Alxaliy-apa, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaXonuqu}, inf. n. XanoqN; (M;) and Xn-qhA↓, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. taXoniyqN; (TA;) He put a piece of wood, which is called XaniyqN↓, (M, Ḳ,) pared for the purpose, (M,) into the hive, and with it raised a portion of the honey-comb in the width of the hive, (M, Ḳ,*) having fixed the Xynq beneath it; and sometimes two portions of the honey-comb, and three: (M: [accord. to which one says also, Xanaqa fiI Alxaliy-api AlquroSayoni waAlv-alaAvapa:]) this is done only when the bees are rearing their young ones. (M, Ḳ.*)

Accord. to Aboo-Saʼeed, OaXonaqotu↓ AlX-aIoCa and Xanaqotuhu signify the same: (TA: [in which the meaning is not expl.; but it is immediately added, app. to indicate the meaning here intended;]) El-Mutanakhkhil El-Hudhalee says, describing a bow and arrows,
Xanaqotu bihaA maEaAbila murohafaAtK
i. e. I put its string into [the notches of] arrows [broad and long in the heads, made sharp or pointed]. (O,* TA.)

Xaniqa, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXonaqu}; (Ḳ;) and Xanaqa, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaXoniqu}; (Ḳ;) He loved a thing, and became attached to it; (M, Ḳ, TA;) said of a man: (TA:) and Xaniqa, inf. n. XanaqN, is said of a man's heart, (O, TA,) meaning as above: (O:) or XanaqN signifies the heart's yearning towards, or longing for, or desiring, a thing. (Mṣb.)

XanaqN also signifies The being long: (M:) or the being long in the head, (JK, Ṣ, TA,) as though it were stretched upwards: (TA:) one says of a horse, Xaniqa inf. n. XanaqN, meaning He was long in the head. (JK.)

Xanaqu AlmaroOapi, signifies AisotinaAnuhaA mina AlX-aHomi [app. meaning The woman's becoming sleek, like masaAn- (or whetstones) by reason of fat: see Aisotan-ati AlfiSaAlu, in art. sn]: and the epithet applied to her is XaniqapN↓, pl. XaniqaAtN. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, TA.)

entry.sense: 2. Xn-q Alxaliy-apa, inf. n. taXoniyqN: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.
taXoniyqN also signifies The cutting [a thing] in pieces. (O, Ḳ. [See the pass. part. n.])
And The adorning [a person or thing]. (Ḳ. [See 5.])
See also the next paragraph {3}, near the end.

3. XAnqhu, inf. n. muXaAnaqapN and XinaAqN, He mixed his cattle with his [i. e. another's] cattle: (Ḳ, TA:) this is when [contributions to the poor-rate such as are termed] OaXonaAq [pl. of XanaqN] are incumbent on a man, or two men, or three, when their cattle are separate, and one says to another, XaAniqoniI, i. e. Mix thou my cattle and thy cattle; for if they are separate, a Xanaq will be obligatory, or incumbent, on each of us; and if they are mixed, the case will be light to us: so the XinaAq signifies the sharing in the Xanaq or in the XanaqaAni. (L, TA.) [See also what follows in this paragraph: and see XanaqN.] One says also laA taXaAnaquwA↓ [for laA tataXaAnaquwA] Ye shall not put together what are separate [of cattle]; Alt-aXaAnuqu being syn. with AlmuXaAnaqapu. (TA.)

XinaAqN signifies also The taking somewhat from the Xanaq: and hence the trad., laA XinaAqa: (Ḳ, TA:) this means There shall not be taken from the Xanaq [any contribution to the poorrate] unless it is complete [in number]: (A' Obeyd, Ṣ, TA:) the Xanaq being, of camels, such as exceed five, up to ten; and what exceed ten, up to fifteen: (AʼObeyd, TA:) Aboo-Saʼeed Ed-Dareer says, up to nine; and up to fourteen: but this is pronounced in the L to be wrong: (TA:) [Mṭr also says,] it means there shall not be taken aught of what exceed five, up to nine, for example: or, accord. to Aboo-Saʼeed Ed-Dareer, it is like the mixing; but this requires consideration: (Mgh:) Aboo-Saʼeed says that laA XinaAqa means a man shall not adjoin (laA yuXoniqu↓ [thus written here and thus expl. in the TA]) his sheep or goats, and his camels, to the sheep or goats [and the camels] of another person, in order to annul what is obligatory, or incumbent, on him, of the poor-rate: this is [for instance] in the case in which each of them has forty sheep or goats; so that it is incumbent on them to give two sheep or goats; but when one of them adjoins (faUicaA Xan-aqa↓ OaHaduhumaA [thus in this instance in the TA, perhaps a mistranscription for OaXonaqa,]) his sheep or goats to those of another, and the collector of the poorrate finds them in his [the latter's] possession, he takes from them one sheep or goat. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. AXnq: see 1, in five places.
UiXonaAqN [as inf. n. of OuXoniqa, from OaXonaqa Alqirobapa expl. in the first paragraph,] also signifies The having the hand attached to the neck by means of a gul- [q. v.]. (AA, TA.)
See also 3, in the latter half.

Accord. to IAạr, (O, TA,) AXnq also signifies He took (O, Ḳ, TA) the Xanaq, i. e., (O, TA,) the [fine termed] OaroX: (O, Ḳ, TA:) or it was, or became, obligatory, or incumbent, on him to give the OaroX; thus having two contr. meanings [assigned to it]: (Ḳ:) or it signifies also, accord. to IAạr, it was, or became, obligatory on him to give what is termed a Xanaq; and this is the case until his camels amount to five and twenty, when what is due of them is [a she-camed such as is termed] Aibonap maxaAD. (O.) A man of the Arabs said, min-aA mano yuXoniqu, which may mean Of us is he who gives the Xunuq, i. e. cords, pl. of XinaAqN: or it may mean, who gives the Xanaq, i. e. OaroX. (O.)
AXnq Ealayohi He exalted himself above him; domineered over him; or oppressed him. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. tXn-q He adorned himself; or was, or became, adorned: (JK, O:) and he clad himself with garments. (JK.)
6: see 3.

hom.sense: XanaqN What is between one fariyDap and the next fariyDap, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) [meaning a number that is between two other numbers whereof each imposes the obligation of giving a due termed fariyDap,] of camels, and of sheep or goats, (M, TA,) in relation to the poorrate: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, TA:) so called because nothing is taken therefrom; so that it is adjoined (OuXoniqa i. e. OaDiyfa) to that [number] which is next to it [of the numbers below it]: (JK:) accord. to some, it is syn. with waqaSN; (Mgh, Mṣb;) but some say that it relates peculiarly to camels; (M, Mgh, Mṣb;) and waqaSN, to bulls and cows: (Mgh, Mṣb:) used in relation to sheep or goats, it is what is between forty and a hundred and twenty; and in like manner as to other numbers [that impose the obligation of giving a fryDp]: (K, TA:) Aḥmad Ibn-Hambal is related to have said that the Xanaq is what is above the fryDp, absolutely; as, for instance, what is above forty sheep or goats: (TA: [I here render the word duwna “above,” though it also means “below,” because nothing is due from sheep or goats fewer than forty:]) as AʼObeyd says, it is, of camels, such as exceed five, up to ten; and what exceed ten, up to fifteen: (O,* TA: [see also 3:]) Ks states, on the authority of some one or more of the Arabs, that it is up to twenty-five; and says that it is what does pot impose the obligation of the fryDp; meaning what is between five and twenty-five: (Fr, TA:) [but it is also expl. as applied to the due itself that is to be contributed to the poorrates for certain numbers of camels: thus] Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybánee says, the Xanaq for five camels is a sheep or goat; for ten, two sheep or goats; for fifteen three sheep or goats; and for twenty, four sheep or goats; the term XanaqN being applied alike to the sheep or goat, and to the two sheep or goats, and to the three sheep or goats, and to the four sheep or goats; what exceeds this last being termed fariyDapN: (TA:) or, in the case of the poor-rate, the lowest Xanaq (AlX-anaqu AlOasofalu) is a sheep or goat for five camels; and the highest Xanaq (AlX-anaqu AlOaEolaI) is a binot maxaAD for five and twenty: (O, Ḳ:) the pl. of XanaqN is OaXonaAqN (M, Mṣb, TA) and XinaAqN. (M.)

Also What is above the bloodwit (maA duwna Ald-iyapi): (Aṣ, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the term OaXonaAq, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) pl. of XanaqN, (M,) being applied to the fines, for wounds, that are sent with the complete bloodwit (Ṣ, M,* O, Mṣb) by him upon whom rests the obligation to send such; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb;) as though they were attached to the main, or greatest, fine: (Ṣ, M,* O:) and an addition, in the bloodwit, (M, Mṣb,) of five, (M,) or of six, (M, Mṣb,) or of seven, (Mṣb,) to the hundred camels [which constitute the complete bloodwit], (M, Mṣb,*) in order that it may be described as ample: (Mṣb:) [for,] as IAạr and Aṣ and El-Athram say, the man of rank or quality, when he gave [the bloodwit], used to add to it five [or more] camels, to show thereby his excellence and his generosity: (TA:) a redundancy [in the case of the bloodwit]; (O, Ḳ;) one of the explanations of the term given by Aṣ: (O:) or in the case of bloodwits (diyaAt), the lowest Xanaq (AlX-anaqu AlOasofalu) is twenty camels whereof every one is a binot maxaAD; and the highest Xanaq (AlX-anaqu AlOaEolaI) is twenty camels whereof every one is a jacaEap: (O, Ḳ:) and some say that OaXonaAqu Ald-iyaAti means the sorts of bloodwits; the bloodwit for purely-unintentional homicide being a hundred camels, which those who are responsible for it undertake to give in fifths, consisting of twenty whereof every one is an Aibonap maxaAD, and twenty whereof every one is an Aibonap labuwn, and twenty whereof every one is an Aibon labuwn, and twenty whereof every one is a Hiq-ap, and twenty whereof every one is a jacaEap; these also being termed OaXonaAq. (TA.)

It signifies also A fine, or mulct, for a wound or the like; (O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as, for instance, for a burn, (O, TA,) or such as a wound on the head that lays bare the bone, (Mṣb, TA,) and other wounds, (Mṣb,) and for a tooth [knocked out], and for an eye blinded, and for an arm or a hand vitiated, or rendered unsound and motionless, or stiff; and for anything short of what requires the complete bloowit: (TA:) or, as some say, a fine for that which does not render obnoxious to retaliation; as a scratch, or laceration of the skin, and the like: (M:) pl. OaXonaAqN. (M, Mṣb.)

Also A burden borne on one side of a beast, equiponderant to another borne on the other side; syn. EidolN: (Ḳ, TA: [in the CK and my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, AlEadolu is erroneously put for AlEidol:]) AlX-anaqaAni signifies AlEidolaAn. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, TA.*)
And A rope, or cord. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)

And A bow-string; (O, TA;) as also XinaAqN↓; (O, Ḳ,* TA;) so called because it is bound to the head of the bow: (O, TA:) or, accord. to Sh, a good bow-string, i. e. strong and long. (TA.) [See what follows.]

AlX-anaqu also signifies AlEamalu [The making a thing]: (Ḳ:) thus accord. to some in the saying of Ru-beh, describing a sportsman [and his bow],
saw-aI lahaA kabodaMCa tanozuw fiI AlX-anaqo
[as though meaning He prepared for it, or them, a bow such that the part whereby it was held filled the hand, springing in the making by reason of its elasticity and strength: but the word which I have written tanozuw, and which is thus in one place in the TA, and in another place in the same, where the verse is repeated, tanozuwA, is illegible in the copy of the O, and may be a mistranscription]: accord. to others, however, the last word, AlX-anaqo, here means the bow-string. (O, TA.)

entry.sense: XaniqN, applied to a heart, Loving intensely, or very passionately or fondly; syn. hayomaAnu. (M, TA.) Accord. to Lth, qalobN XaniqN miXonaAqN↓ signifies TaAmiHN UilaI kul-i XaIoCK [app. meaning A heart aspiring to everything]: (O, L, TA:) in the Ḳ, qalobN XaniqN kakatifK muXotaAqN TaAmiHN UilaI kul-i XaIoCK; but the right reading is qalobN XaniqN miXonaAqN kakatifK wamiHoraAbK, and the signification as above; primarily relating to the eye. (TA.)
Applied to a man, Cautious; or fearful. (TA.)
XaniqapN, applied to a woman: see 1, last sentence.

hom.sense: XinaAqN A rope, or cord, with which the head of a he-camel and of a she-camel is pulled: [see 1, first sentence:] pl. [of pauc.] OaXoniqapN and [of mult.] XunuqN. (M, TA.)

A cord, (A' Obeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or thong, (A' Obeyd, Ḳ,) with which the mouth-of a water-skin is bound, (A' Obeyd, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) and that of a leathern water-bag, and which is untied in order that the water may pour forth: (A' Obeyd, TA:) or the suspensory cord of a water-skin: and any cord by which a thing is suspended. (M.)
See also XanaqN, in the last quarter of the paragraph.

As an epithet, Tall: (ISh, Ṣ, Ḳ:) used alike as masc. and fem. (ISh, Ḳ) and dual (ISh) and pl., (ISh, Ḳ,) not dualized nor pluralized: (ISh:) applied to a man, (Ṣ, TA,) and to a woman, and to a he-camel, and to a she-camel: applied to a she-camel as meaning tall, and longnecked; as also XanoqaMCu↓: and to a he-camel as meaning tall and slender: (ISh, TA:) also, and maXonuwqN↓, applied to a horse as meaning tall. (T, TA.) See also OaXonaqu.

XaniyqN One whose origin is suspected; syn. daEiI-N: a poet says,
OanaA Ald-aAxilu AlbaAba Al-aciI laA yaruwmuhu
daniIoCN walaA yudoEaI Uilayohi Xaniyqu
[I am he who enters the door that the ignoble seeks not, and to which one whose origin is suspected is not invited]. (Ṣ.)
See also 1, latter half.

entry.sense: Xan-iyqN A man evil in disposition: (M, L:) or a self-conceited young man. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.) And Xan-iyqapN, like sik-iynapN, [in some copies of the Ḳ XaniyqapN, like sakiynapN,] A woman talking, or conversing, or who talks, or converses, in an amorous and enticing manner. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)

XiniqonaAqN a name for A calamity or misfortune (daAhiyap): (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ:*) or, as some say, a name of The chiefs of the Jinn, or Genii: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O:) or also a certain chief of the Jinn. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: OaXonaqu Long; applied to a neck. (M.) And, as also maXonuwqN↓, Long in the head; applied to a horse and to a camel; and so XanoqaMCu [the fem. of the former] and XinaAqN↓ applied to the female. (M.) For the fem., see also XinaAqN.
[The fem.] XanoqaMCu signifies [also] A female bird that feeds her young ones with her bill, ejecting the food into their mouths. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: miXonaqapN: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.
muXan-aqN Flesh-meat (Ks, Ṣ) cut in pieces: (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ:) applied to flesh-meat, (M,) it is from the OaXonaAq [pl. of XanaqN] of the diyap [or bloodwit]. (Ks, Ṣ, M.)

And Dough cut into pieces, and prepared with oil of olives: (El-Umawee, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or dough cut into lumps, or pieces, upon the table, before it is spread out; also called farazodaqN and EajaAjiyru. (IAạr, TA.)
miXonaAqN: see XaniqN.

hom.sense: maXonuwqN [as pass. part. n. of Xanaqa means Curbed by means of his nose-rein,, &c.]
[And] † Hanged: one says, qutila maXonuwqFA † He was put to death [by being] hanged. (TA.)
See also XinaAqN: and OaXonaqu.

entry.sense: maXonuw-N and maXoniI-N: see maXonuwoCN, in art. XnO.
maXoniy-apN: see maXoniyoYapN, in art. XnO.

hom.sense: 1. Xahiba, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXohabu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XahabN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) It (a thing, Ṣ) was, or became, of the colour termed Xuhobap, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e. of a [gray] colour in which whiteness predominated over blackness, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) or in which whiteness was interrupted by blackness; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also Xahuba, aor. _u {yaXohubu} and AXhb-↓; (Ḳ;) the last, inf. n. AiXohibaAbN, said in the former sense of a horse; as also AXhAb-↓, inf. n. AiXohiybaAbN; (Ṣ;) and this last verb, said of the head, its whiteness predominated over its blackness; (TA;) as also AXthb↓. (Ṣ, TA.)

Xahabahu, aor. _a {yaXohabu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XahobN, (TḲ,) said of heat and of cold, It altered his colour; as also Xh-bhu↓: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to A' Obeyd, (TA,) Xh-b↓ AlX-ajara, (O, TA,) inf. n. taXohiybN, (O,) said of cold, It altered the colour of the trees: and Xh-b↓ Aln-aAsa is likewise said of cold [as meaning It altered the colour of the men or people]. (O, TA.)

And Xahabati Als-anapu Alqawoma The year of drought destroyed the cattle (OamowaAl) of the people or party: (so accord. to the CK and my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ:) or the verb in this sense is OaXohabat↓. (So accord. to the text of the Ḳ as given in the TA.)
[Freytag erroneously assigns to this verb, as from the Ḳ, another meaning, belonging to 4.]

entry.sense: 2: see the preceding paragraph {1}, in three places.

4. AXhb, said of a stallion, He had offspring of the colour termed Xuhobap born to him: so accord. to the Ḳ: but accord. to IM and the other lexicologists, it is said of a man, meaning the offspring of his horses were of the colour termed Xuhobap: IAạr says that there are not, among horses, such as are termed XuhobN [pl. of OaXohabu]: A' Obeyd, however, [as will be seen below,] explains Xuhobap as meaning a colour of horses. (TA.)
See also 1, last sentence but one.
8: see 1, first sentence.
9: see 1, first sentence.
11: see 1, first sentence.

Also, said of seedproduce, ‡ It dried up, or became yellow, (Ṣ, A,) but with somewhat green remaining in its interstices: (Ṣ:) or was near to yielding, and became white, and dried up, but with a little greenness remaining in its interstices. (TA.)
Accord. to the L, one says also AXhAb-t maXaAfiruhu [app. meaning His lips became of an ashy hue]. (TA.)

hom.sense: XahobN A mountain overspread with snow. (O, Ḳ.)
And a boy, or young man, light, or active, in body, and sharp-headed. (IAạr, TA voce EaDobN. [See also XihaAbN.])

entry.sense: XahabN: see what next follows.

XuhobapN A [gray] colour in which whiteness predominates over blackness, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or in which whiteness is interrupted by blackness; as also XahabN↓; (A, Ḳ;) which latter is [properly] an inf. n., of Xahiba: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or whiteness mixed with blackness: (Ḥar p. 150:) not pure whiteness, as some have imagined it to be. (TA.) And in horses, A colour in which the main hue is interrupted by a hoariness, or by some white hairs, whether the horse be [in his general colour] kumayot or OaXoqar or Oadoham. (A' Obeyd, TA.)
XahabaAnN A kind of plant (XajarN), resembling the vumaAm [or panic grass]; (Ḳ;) like XabahaAnN. (TA. [But see this last word.])

XahaAbN (AḤát, Ṣ, Ḳ) and XuhaAbapN↓ (AḤát, Kr, Ḳ) Milk mixed with much water: (AḤát, Ṣ:) or a mixture of which one third is milk and the rest water: (Ḳ, TA:) Az heard several of the Arabs apply the former term to milk mixed with water: so called on account of the alteration of its colour. (TA.)

XihaAbN, in its primary acceptation, A XuEolap [i. e. either brand or flame (app. the former, agreeably with what follows,)] of fire: (TA:)
or a XuEolap of fire gleaming or radiating: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) accord. to ISk, a firebrand; i. e. a stick in which is fire: or, accord. to AHeyth, originally, a piece of wood, or stick, in which is fire gleaming or radiating: (Az, TA:) pl. XuhubN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and some allow XuhobN, (TA,) and XuhobaAnN (Akh, Ṣ, Ḳ) and XihobaAnN, (Ḳ,) which is strange, (TA,) and OaXohubN, (Ḳ,) which last is [a pl. of pauc., but] thought by IM to be a quasi-pl. n. (TA.) The reading biXihaAbi qabasK, instead of biXihaAbK qabasK, in the Ḳur [xxvii. 7], is an instance of a word prefixed to another identical therewith. (Fr. L.)

Hence, [A shooting, or falling, star;] a star, or the like of a star, that darts down [or is hurled] by night; and particularly after a devil; as occurring in the Ḳur [xv. 18 and] xxxvii. 10; and in a trad.; respecting the attempt of a devil to hear, by stealth, words uttered in heaven. (TA.)

[Hence also,] AlX-uhubu signifies The shining, or brightly-shining, stars: (Ḳ:) or the seven stars [or planets; meaning, not the Pleiades (which are called Aln-ajomu), but the Moon, Mercury, Venus, the Sun, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn: the first three of which are said by Freytag to be called SigaAru AlX-uhubi]. (TA.)
For another meaning assigned in the Ḳ to AlX-uhubu, see AlX-uhobu, voce OaXohabu.

XihaAbN also signifies ‡ One who is penetrating, sharp, or energetic, in an affair; (Ḳ, TA;) as being likened to the [shooting] star. (TA.) One says, Uin-a fulaAnFA laXihaAbu HarobK ‡ Verily such a man is one who is penetrating, sharp, or energetic, in war. (Ṣ, A.*) And heWulaMCi XuhobaAnu AljayoXi ‡ [These are the braves, or heroes, of the army]. (A.)
Also the name of A certain devil: occurring in a trad.: hence the Prophet changed the name of a certain man [originally] thus named. (TA.)
XuhaAbapN: see XahaAbN.
katiybapN Xah-aAbapN: see OaXohabu.
XaAhibN: see OaXohabu, first sentence.
XawohabN The hedge-hog; syn. qunofucN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

OaXohabu Of the colour termed XuhobapN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also XaAhibN↓, (Ḳ,) occurring in the poetry of Hudheyl: (TA:) fem. of the former XahobaMCu: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:*) and pl. XuhobN: (O:) the former epithet is applied to a horse, (Ṣ,) [contr. to an assertion of IAạr, (see 4,)] and to a he-mule, (Mṣb,) and XahobaMCu to a she-mule. (Mgh, Mṣb.) [Golius, on the authority of Meyd, explains OaXohabu Oadohamu, applied to a horse, as meaning Subniger, spadiceus: and OaXohabu OaxoDaru as meaning lucide leviterve viridis: the correct meaning of the former seems to be of a blackish, or brownish, gray: and that of the latter, of a dark dustcoloured gray: see Oadohamu and OaxoDaru.] AlX-ahobaMCu was the name of a mare belonging to El-Kattál El-Bejelee. (O, Ḳ; in the CK El-Bejlee.) Applied to a she-goat, XahobaMCu signifies Of a white colour intermixed with black: thus applied, it is like maloHaMCu applied to a ewe. (Ḳ.) Applied to a gur-ap [or blaze on a horse's forehead], it means In which are hairs differing from the whiteness [of the blaze]. (Ṣ.) And AlOaXaAhibu is [a pl. formed from AlOaXohabu as though this were a subst.] applied to the Benu-l-Mundhir, (Ḳ,) or one of the troops of En-Noamán Ibn-El-Mundhir, consisting of the sons of his paternal uncle and his maternal uncles, and their brethren; (TA;) so called because of their comeliness, (Ḳ,) or because of the whiteness of their faces. (TA.)

Applied to ambergris, (Ḳ, TA,) † Of an excellent colour, i. e., (TA,) inclining to whiteness. (Ḳ, TA.) And applied to an iron head or blade of an arrow or of a spear, &c., ‡ That has been filed so that its blackness has gone: (Ṣ, A, TA:) or that has been filed lightly, so that all its blackness has not gone. (AḤn, TA.) [Hence,] katiybapN XahobaMCu † A great troop having numerous weapons; (Ḳ;) so called because of the iron; (Ṣ;) or because of the whiteness of the weapons and iron, intermixed with blackness: or a troop of which the iron [of the weapons and armour] is white and bright: (TA:) or, as also katiybapN Xah-aAbapN↓, a troop upon which is [seen] the whiteness of the iron [weapons, &c.]. (T, TA. [See also katiybapN maloHaMCu, voce OamolaHu.]) And jayoXN OaXohabu A strong army [app. because of its numerous weapons]. (TA.)

OaroDN XahobaMCu † A land in which is no verdure, by reason of the paucity of rain. (TA.) And [hence,] sanapN XahobaMCu ‡ A year of drought, or sterility, white in consequence thereof, (TA,) in which is no verdure, or in which is no rain: (Ḳ, TA:) next in degree is the bayoDaMC; then, the HamoraMC, which is more severe than the bayoDaMC; (TA;) and then, the sawodaMC: (TA in art. Hmr:) or a year that is white by reason of the abundance of snow and the want of herbage: (IB, TA:) or a year of drought, or sterility; because the seedproduce dries up therein, and becomes yellow: and EaAmN OaXohabu signifies the same. (Ḥar p. 150.) And OaXohabaAni † Two white years (EaAmaAni OaboyaDaAni) between which is no verdure (Ḳ, TA) of herbage. (TA.) And yawomN OaXohabu ‡ A cold day: (A, Ḳ:) or a day of cold wind; thought to be so called on account of the snow and hoar frost and hail therein: (L, TA:) or a day of hoar-frost: (Az, TA:) a day of cold wind and hoar frost; and [in like manner] the night (All-ayolapu) is termed XahobaMCu. (Ṣ.) In the following verse, cited by Sb,
fidFI libaniI cuholi boni XayobaAna naAqatiI
UicaA kaAna yawomN cuw kawaAkiba OaXohabu
[May my she-camel be a ransom for the sons of Dhuhl Ibn-Sheybán when there is a day of difficulties, or distresses, …] the meaning may be AXhb [or whitish] by reason of the whiteness of the weapons, or by reason of the dust. (TA.) And AlX-uhobu [pl. of OaXohabu], (O,) or AlX-uhubu↓ [pl. of XihaAbN], (Ḳ,) [but the former, I think, is evidently the right,] † The white nights; (All-ayaAliI AlbiyDu;) [i. e. the thirteenth and fourteenth and fifteenth nights of the lunar month; so called because lighted by the moon throughout, (see art. byD;)] (O;) three nights of the month; (Ḳ, TA;) because of the alteration of their colour. (TA.)

OaXohabu [or OamorN OaXohabu] also signifies † A hard, or difficult, affair or case, (Ḳ, TA,) such as is disliked, or hated. (TA.) And OaXohabu baAzilN † A hard, or difficult, affair or case, that is beyond one's power [of accomplishment or endurance]: termed bAzl because the camel thus termed is one that has attained its utmost strength. (O, TA. [See also art. bzl.])
And AlOaXohabu signifies The lion. (O, Ḳ.) [And in the Deewán of Jereer, it is applied to The swine. (Freytag.)]

1. Xahida, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXohadu}; (Ḳ;) and Xahuda, aor. _u {yaXohudu}; (Ḳ;) also pronounced and written Xahoda, (Akh, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Xihoda, and Xihida, accord. to a rule applying to all verbs of the measure faEila of which the medial radical letter is a faucial; (MF;) inf. n. XahaAdapN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Xhd; (TA; [there written without any syll. sign, and not found by me in any other Lex.;]) He told, or gave information of, what he had witnessed, or seen or beheld with his eye: (Mgh, L, Mṣb:) this is the primary signification: (L:) he declared what he knew: he gave testimony, attestation, or evidence; he bore witness: (L:) he gave decisive information. (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.) [See also XahaAdapN below.] You say, Xahida bikacaA, inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He told, or gave information of, such a thing, as having witnessed it, or seen or beheld it with his eye; (Mgh, Mṣb;) or declared such a thing as knowing it; (L;) or gave his testimony, attestation, or evidence, respecting it; or bore witness of it, or to it; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) Einoda AlHaAkimi [in the presence of the judge]; lifulaAnK [for, or in favour of, such a one], (Ṣ, Mgh, L, Ḳ,) and EalaI fulaAnK [against, or in opposition to, such a one]. (Mgh.) And Xahida EalaI kacaA He gave decisive information [respecting such a thing (as in the Ḳur xlvi. 9, and in many other instances); he testified respecting it]. (Ṣ, L. [See also another meaning of this phrase in what follows.]) [Hence,] Xahida Qll-ehu Oan-ahu laA UilaAha Uil-aA huwa, in the Ḳur [iii. 16], means God hath given evidence that there is no deity but He: (Abu-l- ʼAbbás, IAmb, Jel:) or God knoweth, &c.; (Ah- mad Ibn-Yaḥyà, Ḳ;) and so Xahida Qll-ehu throughout the Ḳur-án: (Aḥmad Ibn-Yaḥyà:) or God saith, &c.: or God hath written, &c. (Ḳ.) And OaXohadu Oano laA UilaAha Uil-aAQll-ehu I know, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) [or acknowledge,] and I declare, [or testify, that there is no deity but God:] (Ḳ:) [Fei says,] the verb is trans. in this phrase by itself [i. e. without the intervention of a prep.] because it is used in the sense of OaEolamu. (Mṣb.) [And hence, kalimapu AlX-ahaAdapi means The sentence declaring that there is no deity but God and that Moḥammad is God's apostle.]

Xahida biQll-ehi, (Mgh,* Mṣb,) aor. _a {yaXohadu}, inf. n. XahaAdapN, (Mgh,) means He swore by God: (Mgh, Mṣb:) and OaXohadu bikacaA I swear by such a thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) OaXohadu biQll-ehi laqado kaAna kacaA I swear by God that such a thing happened, or took place, combines the meaning of witnessing with that of swearing and that of informing at the time of uttering these words;
as though the speaker said, I swear by God that I witnessed such a thing, and now I inform of it. (Mṣb.) Accord. to some, when one says only OaXohadu, not adding biQll-ehi, it is an oath. (TA.)

Xahida EalaI kacaA, a phrase of which one meaning has been expl. above, means also He became a witness (XaAhid) of, or to, such a thing; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) he had knowledge of such a thing, and witnessed it, or saw it or beheld it with his eye: (Mṣb:) and Xahidahu, (Mgh, L,) inf. n. XahaAdapN, (L,) [likewise] signifies he witnessed it; or saw, or beheld, it, or him, with his eye; (Mgh, L;) and (Mgh, L, Mṣb) so XAhdhu↓, (A, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. muXaAhadapN. (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb.) [Hence,] one says, Xuwhidato↓ minohu HaAlN jamiylapN [A comely, or pleasing, state, or condition, of him was witnessed]. (A.)

And Xahidahu, (aor. _a {yaXohadu} K,) inf. n. XuhuwdN, He was, or became, present at it, or in it; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, L, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) namely, a place, (Mgh,) or an assembly. (Mṣb.) Hence the saying, (Mṣb,) famano Xahida minokumu QlX-ahora faloyaSumohu, in the Ḳur [ii. 181], Therefore whosoever of you shall be present in the month, and stationary, not journeying, he shall fast therein (Mgh, Mṣb) as long as he shall remain present and stationary: (Mṣb:) AlXhr being here in the accus. case as an adv. n. of time. (Mgh, Mṣb.) [And hence,] Xahida AljumoEapa He attained to [the being present at] the jumoEap [here meaning, as in many other instances, the prayer of Friday]: (Mgh:) and Xahida AlEiyda he attained to [the being present at] the Eiyd [or festival, or the prayer thereof]. (Mṣb.) [Hence also,] it is said in a trad., yaXohadu bayoEakumu AlHalifu waAll-agowu [Swearing, and unprofitable speech, attend your selling]. (TA in art. Xwb: see 1 in that art.)
2: see 4.
3: see 1, latter half, in two places.

hom.sense: 4. OaXohadotuhu EalaI kacaA I made him to be a witness (XaAhid) of, or to such a thing: (Ṣ, Mgh, L:) [and in like manner,] OaXohadotuhu AlX-aIoCa I made him to have knowledge of the thing, and to witness it, or see it or behold it with his eye. (Mṣb.) See also 10. UiXohaAdN in relation to criminal matters means [The causing one to take notice of a thing that threatens to occasion some injury, with a view to the prevention of such injury; as, for instance,] the saying to the owner of a house, “This thy wall is leaning, therefore demolish it,” or “feared, therefore repair it.” (Mgh.)
AXhdhu also signifies He caused him to be present. (Ḳ.) You say, OaXohadaniI UimolaAkahu He caused me to be present [at, or on the occasion of, his being put in possession]. (Ṣ.)
OuXohida: see 10.

AXhd [as intrans.] † Humorem tenuem e pene emisit vir propter lusum amatorium vel osculum; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Xh-d↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taXohiydN: (TA:) [from XahodN signifying “honey;” for] EusayolapN is a term for macoIN. (Ṣ.) † He rendered his miYozar [or waist-wrapper] of a reddish hue and of a dark dust-colour (OaxoDar) [by the act above-mentioned]. (L.) † He (a boy) attained to puberty. (Th, TA.) And AXhdt She (a girl) menstruated: and attained to puberty. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. Alt-aXah-udu in prayer is well known; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) The reciting of the form of words commencing with Alt-aHiy-aAtu lil-ehi: [see art. HI:] from the occurrence therein of the words OaXohadu Oano laA UilaAha Uil-aA Qll-ehu waOaXohadu Oan-a muHam-adFA Eaboduhu warasuwluhu. (Mgh,* TA. [See also Ḥar p. 611.])
And taXah-ada also signifies He sought, or desired to obtain, martyrdom. (L.)

10. AstXhdhu He asked him, or required him, to tell what he had witnessed, or seen or beheld with his eye; to declare what he knew; to give testimony, or evidence; to bear witness; or to give decisive information. (Ṣ, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, AisotaXohadotu fulaAnFA EalaI fulaAnK I asked, or required, [or cited, or summoned,] such a one to give his testimony, or evidence, or to bear witness, against such a one. (L.) And AisotaXohadotu Alr-ajula EalaI UiqoraAri Algariymi and OaXohadotuhu↓ I asked, or required, [&c., and made,] the man to bear witness to, or to be witness of or to, the confession, or acknowledgment, of the debtor. (L.)
[Hence,] AstXhd bibayotK EalaI maEonaI kalimapK [He adduced, or urged, or cited, a verse as an evidential example of the meaning of a word]. (A phrase of frequent occurrence in the larger lexicons.)
AusotuXohida (Ṣ, Ḳ) and OuXohida↓ (Ḳ) He was slain a martyr in the cause of God's religion. (Ṣ, Ḳ. [See XahiydN.])

hom.sense: XahodN: see XaAhidN, first sentence.

Also, and XuhodN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former of the dial. of Temeem, and the latter of the people of El-ʼÁliyeh, (Mṣb, TA,) Honey: (Ḳ:) or honey in its wax [i. e. its comb]; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) honey not expressed from its wax [or comb]: (TA:) pl. XihaAdN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) XahodapN is a more particular term, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the n. un., [signifying a portion thereof; and a honey-comb, or a portion of a honey-comb;] as also XuhodapN. (TA.)

entry.sense: XuhodN: see the next preceding paragraph.
XuhuwdN: see XaAhidN, in two places.

XahiydN is also written and pronounced XihiydN, with kesr to the X: (Ḳ, TA:) and in like manner is every word of the measure faEiylN having a faucial letter for its, medial radical, whether an epithet, like this, or a subst., like ragiyfN and baEiyrN: El-Hemdánee says, in the “Iaráb el-Ḳur-án,” that the people of El-Ḥijáz, and Benoo-Asad, say raHiymN and ragiyfN and baEiyrN, with fet-ḥ to the first letter; and Keys and Rabee'ah and Temeem say raHiymN and rigiyfN and biEiyrN, with kesr to the first letter: Sub says, in the R, that Temeem pronounce every faEiyl of which the medial radical letter is hemzeh or any other faucial with kesr to the first letter: and En-Nawawee states, on the authority of Lth, that some of the Arabs do the same when the medial radical letter is not a faucial; as in kbyr and krym and jlyl and the like thereof. (TA.) [This last pronunciation obtains extensively in the present day: and so, in similar cases, does the intermediate pronunciation termed UimaAlapu AlfatoHi, (i. e. the pronouncing fet-ḥ like “e” in the English word “bed,”) which may be justly regarded as the best to be followed because intermediate and because sanctioned by the usage of the classical times, except in cases that are pointed out by the grammarians as presenting obstacles to the pronunciation thus termed.]
XahiydN is syn. with XaAhidN [in several senses, as shown below]: and its pl. is XuhadaMCu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See XaAhidN, in six places.

Also Possessing much knowledge with respect to external things: xabiyrN is used in the like sense with respect to internal things; and EaliymN, in the like sense absolutely. (L.) [Hence, perhaps,] waQdoEuwA XuhadMCakumo, in the Ḳur ii. 21, [as though meaning And call ye to your aid those of you who possess much knowledge: or] the meaning here is, your helpers: (Bḍ:) or your gods whom ye worship. (Jel.) AlX-ahiydu as a name of God means The Faithful, or Trusty, in his testimony (Zj, L,) or in testimony: (Ḳ:) and (Zj, Ḳ) as some say, (Zj,) He from whose knowledge nothing is hidden; the Omniscient. (Zj, L, Ḳ.)

Also, derived from AlX-ahaAdapu, or from AlmuXaAhadapu, or from AlX-uhuwdu, [all inf. ns.,] accord. to different opinions; (TA;) and of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; (Mṣb, TA;) or in the sense of the measure faAEilN; (TA;) A martyr who is slain in the cause of God's religion; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [i. e.] one who is slain by unbelievers on a field of battle; (Mṣb;) one who is slain fighting in the cause of God's religion: (IAth:) so called because the angels of mercy are present with him; (Ḳ;) because the angels are present at the washing of his corpse, or at the removal of his soul to Paradise: (Mṣb:) or because God and his angels are witnesses for him of his title to a place in Paradise: (IAmb, Mgh,* Ḳ:) or because he is one of those who shall be required to bear witness on the day of resurrection, (Ḳ, TA,) with the Prophet, (TA,) against the people of past times, (Ḳ, TA,) who charged their prophets with falsehood: (TA:) or because of his falling upon the XaAhidap↓, or ground: (Ḳ:) or because he is still living, and present with his Lord: (ISh, Mgh, Ḳ:) or because he witnesses. or beholds, God's world of spirits and his world of corporeal beings: (Ḳ,* TA:) [and several other reasons are assigned for this appellation:] the primary application is that expl. above: but it is also applied by the Prophet to one who dies of colic: one who is drowned: one who is burned to death: one who is killed by a building falling to ruin upon him: one who dies of pleurisy: (IAth, L:) one who dies of plague, or pestilence: a woman who dies in a state of pregnancy: (L:) and to some others: (IAth:) the pl. is XuhadaMCu. (A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.)

XahaAdapN [see 1:] Information of what one has witnessed, or seen or beheld with his eye: (IF, Mgh, L, Mṣb:) this is the primary signification: (L:) said to be a subst. from AlmuXaAhadapu: (Mṣb:) declaration of what one knows: testimony, attestation, evidence, or witness: (L:) decisive information. (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.)
An oath: pl. XahaAdaAtN: so in the Ḳur xxiv. 6 [and 8]. (TA.)
Martyrdom in the cause of God's religion. (Ṣ, Ḳ. [See XahiydN.])
Also i. q. maXohadN as expl. below: see the latter word.
[And it is used in the sense of muXaAhadN: thus,] EaAlimu Algayobi waAlX-ahaAdapi, in the Ḳur vi. 73, &c., means The Knower of what is unseen and of what is seen. (Jel.)
XahiydapN A roasted lamb: or [the kind of food called] hariysap [q. v.]: pl. XihaAdN. (Ḥar. p. 609.)
[Xah-aAdN Always present. (Freytag from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]

XaAhidN (Ṣ, Mgh, L, Ḳ) and XahiydN↓ (Ṣ,* Mgh, L) One who tells, or gives information of, what he has witnessed, or seen or beheld with his eye: (Mgh, L:) one who declares what he knows: (L:) one who knows, and declares what he knows: (ISd, TA:) a witness, as meaning one who gives testimony, or evidence; who bears witness: (Ṣ,* L, Ḳ:*) [one who gives decisive information: (see 1, first sentence:)] pl. of the former XahodN↓, (Akh, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or [rather] this is a quasi-pl. n., (Sb, TA,) like as SaHobN is of SaAHibN, and saforN of saAfirN, (Ṣ,) but some disallow this; (TA;) and XuhuwdN↓ [but see what is said of this in the latter half of the paragraph] and OaXohaAdN are also pls. of XaAhidN, (Mgh, L,) or of XahodN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the pl. of XahiydN↓ is XuhadaMCu. (Ṣ, Mgh.) [Hence,] maEahaA saAYiqN waXahiydN↓, in the Ḳur 1. 20: see art. swq.
[Hence also] AlX-aAhidu a name of the Prophet; (Ḳ;) meaning The witness against those to whom he has been sent. (Jel in xxxiii. 44.)
And XaAhidN An angel: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or a guardian angel: (Mujáhid:) pl. OaXohaAdN: or this means the prophets. (TA.)

And The tongue: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) from the saying, lifulaAnK XaAhidN HasanN Such a one has an elegant diction. (L.) One says also, maA lifulaAnK ruwaMCN walaA XaAhidN Such a one has neither goodliness of aspect nor tongue. (Aboo-Bekr, L.)

[As a conventional term used in lexicology, &c.,] An evidential example, generally poetical, of the form or meaning of a word or phrase: pl. XawaAhidu: the sciences that require XawaAhid being those of All-ugap and AlS-arof and Aln-aHow and AlmaEaAniI and AlbayaAn and AlbadiyE and AlEaruwD and AlqawaAfiI. (MF on the xuTobap of the Ḳ.) [One says, hecaA XaAhidN likacaA and EalaI kacaA This is an evidential example of such a thing.] With respect to the classical language, absolutely, XwAhd are taken, by universal consent, from the Ḳur-án, and from the language [both verse and prose (Kull p. 348)] of those Arabs who lived before the period of the corruption [in any considerable degree] of the Arabic tongue: [see muwal-adN:] also, accord. to the general decision of the learned, from the Traditions of Moḥammad; [which last source is excluded by some because traditions may be corrupted in language by their transmitters, and interpolated, and even forged;] and electively from the language of those Arabs who lived after the first corruption of the Arabic tongue, but before the corruption had become extensive. (Mz, 1st nwE; and MF ubi suprà. [See, again, muwal-adN.]) The classes of the poets from whose poetry XwAhd are taken are the Pagan Arabs, the Mukhadrams, the Islámees, and the Muwelleds: [see jaAhiliI-N and muxaDoramN and UisolaAmiI-N and muwal-adN:] with respect to all the sciences above mentioned, they are taken from the poetry of the first, second, and third, classes; from that of the first and second by universal consent, and from that of the third electively: (MF ubi suprá:) but they are taken from the poetry of the fourth class with respect only to the sciences of AlmaEaAniI and AlbayaAn and AlbadiyE. (Idem, and Kull p. 348.) [The age of the earliest existing classical poems (though some older fragments and couplets and single verses have been preserved) is only about a century before the birth of Moḥammad: that of the latest, about a century after his death. (See the Preface to this work.)]

Knowing, (Mṣb,) and witnessing, or seeing or beholding with his eye; a witness, as meaning an eyewitness; (L, Mṣb;) as also XahiydN↓: pl. of the former [or, as is said in the L in art. mjd, of the former or of the latter,] OaXohaAdN and XuhuwdN; [but see what is said of these pls. in the first sentence of this paragraph;] and of the latter XuhadaMCu. (Mṣb.) [See an ex. of XahiydN↓ in this sense in a verse cited voce rab-N.]
[Hence, in the present day, applied to A notary, who hears and writes and attests cases to be submitted for judgment in the court of a ḳádee.]

Present; a witness as meaning one personally present; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also XahiydN↓: (Mṣb:) pl. of the former Xuh-adN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) [and OaXohaAdN, as above,] and XuhuwdN↓, (Ḳ,) or this last is used as a pl. but is originally an inf. n. (Ṣ, L.) One says, AlX-aAhidu yaraI maA laA yaraI AlgaAYibu, meaning The present knows what the absent knows not. (Mṣb.) And qawomN XuhuwdN People, or persons, present. (Ṣ, A.) And kal-amotuhu EalaI ruWuwsi AlOaXohaAdi [I spoke to him before witnesses, or persons present]. (A.)

[Hence, app., being opposed to gaAYibN,] A running in which a horse exerts his force unsparingly; (A, L;) as in the saying, lilofarasi gaAYibN waXaAhidN The horse has a run which he reserves [for the time of need], and a run which he performs unsparingly; like the saying, lahu SawonN wabacolN: (A: [see 1 in art. bcl:]) or XaAhidN means a running that testifies the excellence of a horse, (IAạr, Ḳ,) and his quality of outstripping others. (IAạr, TA.)
A star [app. when visible]; (Aboo-Eiyoob, Ḳ;) as being present and apparent in the night. (TA.)
