[Hence, accord. to some,] SalaApu AlX-aAhidi The prayer of sunset; (A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because it is the prayer that is performed when the star becomes visible; (Sh, L;) also called SalaApu AlbaSari, because the stars are seen at the time thereof: or, accord. to some, the prayer of daybreak; (L;) [and so, accord. to some, SalaApu AlbaSari; (see art. bSr;)] as also AlmaXohuwdu↓; (TA;) and it is said to be so called because he who is travelling must perform it without abridging it, like him who is present at his home: Aboo-Saʼeed Ed-Dareer says that the former prayer is so called for this reason [as is also said in the A and Mṣb]: AM asserts that the first reason assigned above is the right one, because the prayer of daybreak, in like manner, may not be abridged, and is not thus called; but it is thus called by a poet. (L.)

And AlX-aAhidu is a name of Friday; (Fr, Ḳ;) as also AlmaXohuwdu↓: or the latter is the day of resurrection: (Ḳ:) or the day of ʼArafeh: (Fr, Ḳ: [see Earafapu:]) because of the presence and congregation of people on each of those days. (TA.)

XaAhidN also signifies Matter resembling mucus, that comes forth with the fœtus: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. XuhuwdN: which latter, accord. to ISd, means the OagoraAs [pl. of girosN, q. v.,] upon the head of a young camel at the time of its birth. (TA.) And XuhuwdN Aln-aAqapi means The marks left by the blood, or by the membrane that enclosed the fœtus, of the she-camel, in the place where she has brought forth. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also A quick, or an expeditious, thing or affair. (Ḳ.)
AlX-aAhidapu The earth, or ground. (Ḳ.) See XahiydN, last sentence.

maXohadN A place where people are present or assembled; a place of assembling; an assembly; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) as also maXohadapN↓ and maXohudapN↓ (Ḳ) and XahaAdapN↓: (L:) pl. maXaAhidu. (A.) [Hence,] maXaAhidu mak-apa The places of religious visitation, where the ceremonies of the pilgrimage, &c. are performed, at Mekkeh. (L.)
[A funeral assembly or procession.]
[A place where a martyr has died or is buried.]
[And The aspect, or outward appearance, of a person; like maroOFI: see an instance voce EawodN.]
muXohadN Slain a martyr in the cause of God's religion. (Ḳ. [See also XahiydN.])
AimoraOapN muXohidN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) without p, (Ṣ,) and muXohidapN, (A,) A woman whose husband is present with her: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) opposed to AimoraOapN mugiybapN; (Ṣ, A;) this last with p. (Ṣ.)
maXohadapN and maXohudapN: see maXohadN.

majolisN maXohuwdN [A place of assembling at which numerous persons are present]. (A.) And yawomN maXohuwdN [A day on which numerous persons are present: and particularly] a day on which the inhabitants of heaven and earth will be present. (TA.) And SalaApN maXohuwdapN makotuwbapN A prayer at the performance of which the angels are present, and the recompense of which, for the performer, is written, or registered. (L.) See also XaAhidN, in two places, in the last quarter of the paragraph.
maEohuwdN wamaXohuwdN wamawoEuwdN Past and present and future; the tenses of a verb. (Kh, L in art. Ehd.)

XahodaAnijN, (Ḳ accord. to the TA,) with fet-ḥ to the X and kesr to the n, (TA,) and XaAhodaAnijN, (Ḳ accord. to the TA,) or XahodaAnajN, (Mgh, Mṣb, and so in the CK, except that it is there written as though imperfectly decl.,) with fet-ḥ to the n, (Mṣb,) and XaAhodaAnaj, (CK,) arabicized from [the Pers.] XaAho daAnaho, which means “king of grains,” (Ibn-El-Kutbee, TA,)
The seed of the qin-ab [or hemp]: (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) it is useful as a remedy for the quartan fever, (Ḳ,) prepared as a beverage, (TA,) and for the [kinds of leprosy called] bahaq and baraS, (Ḳ,) applied as a liniment, (TA,) and it kills what are called Hab-u AlqaroEi, (Ḳ,) which are worms in the belly, [tape-worms,] (TA,) when eaten, and also when applied to the belly externally. (Ḳ.)

1. Xaharahu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXoharu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. XahorN and XuhorapN; (Ṣ;) and Xh-rhu↓, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. taXohiyrN; (Ṣ;) and AXthrhu↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He made it apparent, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, notable, commonly known, or public: (Ṣ, O, MF:) or [it generally means] he made it apparent,, &c., as bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly; he exposed it as such; or rendered it notorious in a bad sense, or infamous. (A, Ḳ.) You say, Xaharotu AlHadiyva, inf. n. as above, I divulged the story, or discourse. (Mṣb.) And lifulaAnK faDiylapN QXotaharahaA↓ Aln-aAsu [Such a one has an excellent quality which the people have made commonly known]. (Ṣ.) And Xaharotuhu bayona Aln-aAsi I rendered him conspicuous [or notorious or celebrated or renowned] among the people. (Mṣb.) And Xaharotu zayodFA bikacaA and Xh-rth↓ [I rendered Zeyd conspicuous, notorious, celebrated, or renowned, for such a thing]; (Mgh,* Mṣb;) [but] the latter has an intensive signification: OaXoharotuhu↓, with A, in the sense of Xaharotuhu, has not been transmitted: (Mṣb:) or is not of established authority. (Mgh.) One says also, Xuhira bikacaA, and AiXotahara↓, [generally, but not always, in a bad sense, meaning] He was rendered, or became, notorious, or infamous, for such a thing: (A:) the latter verb being intrans. as well as trans. (TA.) And [hence one says,] AiXotaharotu↓ fulaAnFA meaning ‡ I held such a one in light, or little, estimation, or in contempt, and exposed his vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions. (A.)

And Xahara sayofahu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXoharu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XahorN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He drew his sword (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) from its scabbard: (TA:) or he drew his sword and raised it over the people; (A, Ḳ;) as also Xh-rhu↓. (Ḳ.)

2: see above {1}, in three places. [In modern Arabic, Xh-r often signifies He paraded an offender as a public example; and it occurs in this sense in the Ṣ and TA in art. bls, &c.: the offender, in this case, is generally mounted upon an ass or a camel, and often with his face towards the animal's tail.]

3. XAhrhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muXaAharapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and XihaArN, (Ḳ,) He hired him, or took him as a hired man or hireling, for [or by] the month: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) or he made an engagement, or a contract, with him for work or the like, by the month, or month by month: (TA:) AlmuXaAharapu from AlX-ahoru is like AlmuEaAwamapu from AlEaAmu. (Ṣ, TA.)

hom.sense: 4: see 1.

OaXoharonaA, (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) inf. n. UiXohaArN, (Mṣb,) A month passed (lit. came) over us. (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ.) And AXhr AlS-abiI-u [The child became a month old; or] a month passed (lit. came) over the child: similar to OaHowala, (A,) or to OaHaAla. (Mṣb.) And AXhrt Ald-aAru The house became altered, or changed, and months passed over it. (TA in art. Hwl.)
Also We remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, a month in a place. (ISk, Ṣ.)
And We entered upon the month, i. e., the lunar month. (Th, Ṣ.)
And AXhrt She (a woman) entered upon the month of her bringing forth. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)

8. AXthr It was, or became, apparent, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, notable, commonly known, or public: (Ṣ:) or [it generally means] it was, or became, apparent,, &c., as bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly; it was, or became, exposed as such, or rendered notorious in a bad sense or infamous. (A, Ḳ.) It (a story, or discourse,) became divulged, or public. (Mṣb.) AXthr bikacaA: see 1.
As a trans. verb: see 1 in three places.

entry.sense: XahorN The new moon, when it appears: (IF, A, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) so called because of its conspicuousness. (Mgh, Mṣb.) This is the original signification. (Mgh.) [See the last sentence of this paragraph.] You say, raOayotu AlX-ahora, meaning I saw the new moon of the month. (Mgh.) Hence it is said in a trad., SuwmuwA AlX-ahora, meaning Fast ye the first day of the lunar month. (Lḥ, TA.) And hence the trad., Uin-amaA AlX-ahoru tisoEN waEiXoruwna, meaning The utility of watching for the new moon is on the nine and twentieth night. (L, TA.) [Or the meaning is, that the lunar month is a period of nine and twenty nights.]
Also The moon: or the moon when conspicuous, and near to being full. (Ḳ.)

And [A lunar month;] a certain well-known number of days: so called because made manifest by the moon: (ISd, Ḳ:) an arabicized word; or, as some say, Arabic; (Mṣb;) and so called because of its being manifest: (Mṣb, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaXohurN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of mult.] XuhuwrN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) The following are the modern names of the months: 1. AlmuHar-amu [to which the epithet AlHaraAmu is often added]: 2. SafarN [to which the epithet Alxayoru is often added]: 3. rabiyEN AlOaw-alu: 4. rabiyEN AlMxiru [or Alv-aAniI]: 5. jumaAdaI AlOuwlaI: 6. jumaAdaI AlMxirapu [or Alv-aAniyapu]: 7. rajabN [to which is often added the epithet AlOaSam-u, and that of Alfarodu]: 8. XaEobaAnu [to which we often find the epithet AlmuEaZ-amu added, and sometimes that of AlX-ariyfu]: 9. ramaDaAnu [to which the epithet AlmubaAraku is appropriated]: 10. Xaw-aAlN [to which the epithet Almukar-amu is frequently added]: 11. cuw AlqaEodapi: and 12. cuw AlHij-api: [see the second of the two tables in p. 1254:] and the following are the names by which they were called by the tribe of 'Ád, agreeably with the foregoing numeration: 1. muWotamirN: 2. naAjirN: 3. xaw-aAnN: 4. buS-aAnN [q. v.]: 5. rub-aI: 6. HaniynN: 7. AlOaSam-u: 8. EaAcilN: 9. naAtiqN: 10. waEolN: 11. waronapu: and 12. burakN [or buraku?]. (Ibn-El-Kelbee, in TA, voce muWotamirN. [But authors differ respecting some of these names, as will be seen in other articles.]) OaXohurN maEoluwmaAtN, said, in the Ḳur [ii. 193], to be the period of the pilgrimage, for by AlHaj-u, which immediately precedes, is meant waqotu AlHaj-i, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or zamaAnu AlHaj-i, (Mṣb,) applies to Showwál and Dhul-Kaadeh and ten days of Dhu-l-Hijjeh, (Mgh, Mṣb,) accord. to Aboo-Ḥaneefeh (Mgh) and most of the learned, part of Dhu-l-Hijjeh being called a month tropically, as is often done by the Arabs in similar cases, relating to time; for ex. when they say, maA raOayotuhu muco yawomaAni, the period of separation having been a day and a part of a day: (Mṣb:) or [and] nine days of Dhu-l-Hijjeh with the night preceding the day of the sacrifice, accord. to Esh-Sháfiʼee: (Mgh:) or [and] all Dhu-l-Hijjeh, accord. to Málik: (Mgh, Mṣb:) [in these two explanations the two months next preceding being meant to be included:] or Showwál and Dhu-l- Kaadeh and Dhu-l-Hijjeh and Moharram, accord. to Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Shaabee. (Mṣb.)
Also † A learned man: (O, Ḳ:) [because of his celebrity:] pl. XuhuwrN. (O, TA.)

[And accord. to the Ḳ, it signifies also The like of a nail-paring: but this is app. a mistake, perhaps originating from a mutilated transcript of what here follows:] a poet says, describing camels,
OabodaOona mino najodK EalaI viqapK
waAlX-ahoru mivolu qulaAmapi AlZ-ufori
[They went forth from Nejd in a state of confidence, the new moon being like the nail-paring]. (O.)

XuhorapN a subst. from AlAiXotihaAru, (Mgh,) signifying The appearance, conspicuousness, manifestness, notoriousness, notableness, or publicity, of a thing: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) or [generally] its appearance,, &c., as bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly; its notoriousness in a bad sense, or infamousness. (A, Ḳ.)
Any evil thing that exposes its author to disgrace; any disgraceful, or shameful, thing; a vice, or fault, or the like. (IAạr, O, TA.)
A dress of the most excellent or superb kind; and one of the vilest or meanest kind: both of which are forbidden. (Mgh.)

[It is also used in the sense of maXohuwrN.] One says, jaEalahu XuhorapF ‡ [He rendered him notorious, either in a bad or in a good sense]. (A.) And SaAra XuhorapF, (Ḳ in art. dwl,) i. e. maXohuwrFA † [He became notorious,, &c.]; said of a man. (TḲ in that art.)

A brcwn [or hackney] between the ramakap [or mare of mean breed] and the horse of generous breed: one says, lamo yarokabi AlX-ihoriy-apa and AlX-ahaAriIa [He did not ride hackneys of the sort above mentioned]: (A:) or Xihoriy-apN signifies baraAciyn [or hackneys]; and its pl. is XahaArK: (Mgh:) or a sort of baraAciyn [or hackneys]; (Lth, O, Ḳ;) a horse of which the dam is Arabian but not the sire. (Lth, O.)
XahiyrN: see maXohuwrN.
XahiyrapN A woman, and a she-ass, broad (O, Ḳ) and bulky. (O.)
[OaXoharu More, and most, apparent, conspicuous, manifest, notorious,, &c.; better, and best, known.]
[Hence, AlOaXoharaAni The drum and the banner. (Gol., from Meyd.)]
OaXaAhiru [in the CK AaXAhiyru] The whiteness of the narcissus. (Ḳ, TA.)
muXohirN A child a month old. (O, TA.)
muXah-arN: see the following paragraph.

maXohuwrN Of known place or station; (Ḳ;) well known; well spoken of; celebrated; held in repute; reputable; notable; eminent; (O, Ḳ, TA;) applied to a man; (O, TA;) as also XahiyrN↓, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and [in an intensive sense] muXah-arN↓. (TA.) [And Anything apparent, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, notable, commonly known, or public: lit. rendered apparent, &c. Applied to a word or phrase or meaning, Commonly known or obtaining or received; well known; or held in repute. Hence EalaI AlmaXohuwri According to common, or well-known, usage; or according to common repute.]
1. Xahaqa, aor. _a {yaXohaqu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. XuhuwqN, (Mṣb,) [said of a mountain, and of a building, &c., (see XaAhiqN,)] It rose high; or became high, or elevated, or lofty. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

Xahaqa, aor. _a {yaXohaqu} and _i {yaXohiqu}, inf. n. XahiyqN [and taXohaAqN], said of an ass, [He uttered the ending of his braying, or the final sounds thereof;] (Ṣ;) [for] XahiyqN signifies the ending, or final part, of the crying, or braying, of the ass; (Ṣ, O;) and to this the cries of the punished in Hell are likened in the Ḳur xi. 108; (O;) and zafiyrN signifies the “beginning, or commencing part, thereof:” (Ṣ:) or Xhyq signifies the drawing back of the breath; and zfyr the “emitting thereof:” (Lth, Ṣ: [but the reverse is said by Lth and in the Ṣ in art. zfr:]) and taXohaAqN signifies the same as XahiyqN: (Ṣ:) or both of these words signify [absolutely] the crying, or braying, of the ass: (O, Ḳ:) Zj says that XahiyqN as denoting one of the cries of the afflicted [in Hell] means a very high-sounding moaning: and that, accord. to some, zafiyrN [as used in the Ḳur ubi suprà] is similar to the beginning of the cry of the ass, termed Xahiyq; and that XahiyqN is in the chest. (TA.) [Said of a man,] Xahaqa, aor. _a {yaXohaqu} and _i {yaXohiqu}; and Xahiqa, aor. _a {yaXohaqu}; inf. n. XahiyqN and XuhaAqN (O, Ḳ) and XuhuwqN (O) and taXohaAqN; signify The [sound of] weeping became reiterated in his chest: (O, Ḳ:) or, as in the L, he reiterated the [sound of] weeping in his chest. (TA.) [Or] Xahaqa, aor. _a {yaXohaqu} and _i {yaXohiqu}, inf. n. XahiyqN, signifies [or signifies also] He reiterated his breath, making his voice audible, naturally. (Mṣb.) One says also, Xahaqa fulaAnN XahoqapF famaAta Such a one uttered a single cry and died. (Ṣ, TA.)
And Xahaqato Eayonu Aln-aAZiri Ealayohi ‡ The eye of the looker smote him with evil influence: (O, Ḳ, TA:) or, was pleased with him, and therefore continued looking at him. (A, TA.)
XahoqapN A single cry. (Ṣ, TA.) [See 1, last sentence but one.]
XuhoqapN Height, elevation, or loftiness. (TA.)

XaAhiqN High, or lofty; applied to a mountain, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and to a building, &c.: (O, Ḳ:) or, applied to a mountain, high and inaccessible: (JK, TA:) pl. XawaAhiqu: (JK, Mṣb, TA:) you say jibaAlN XaAhiqapN and XaAhiqaAtN and XawaAhiqu. (Mṣb.)
Applied to a vein [or an artery], ‡ Pulsing upwards: (O, Ḳ, TA:) a term of the physicians. (O, TA.)

cuw XaAhiqK ‡ A man whose anger is vehement: (JK, Ṣ, A, O, L, TA:) wrongly expl. in the Ḳ by the words laA yaXotad-u gaDabuhu: (TA:) and so cuw SaAhilK. (A, TA.) And ‡ A stallion [camel] Excited by lust, assaulting [the she-camels], and causing a sound to be heard from his inside; as also cuw SaAhilK. (TA.)
taXohaAqN an inf. n. (Ṣ,* O, Ḳ. [See 1.])
[And also an epithet.] One says DaHikN taXohaAqN [app. meaning † A loud laughing, likened to the taXohaAq of the ass]. (Ṣ, O.)

1. Xahila, aor. _a {yaXohalu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XahalN, (Ṣ,* O,* TA,) He (a man, Ṣ, O) had that quality of the eye which is termed XuholapN [expl. below]; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also AXhl-↓, inf. n. AiXohilaAlN. (Ḳ.) [And in like manner each of these verbs is probably used as said of the eye.]
2. taXohiylN is a vulgar dial. var. of tasohiylN [inf. n. of sah-ala, q. v.]. (TA.)

3. XAhlhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muXaAhalapN, (Ṣ, O, TA,) He acted with him in an evil manner; or contended, or disputed, with him; syn. XaAr-ahu; (Ṣ,* O,* Ḳ, TA;) and laAHaAhu [which has the latter of these significations]: and opposed him, being opposed by him; syn. EaAraDahu: (TA:) he reviled him; or reviled him, being reviled by him: (Ḳ:) he exchanged bad names with him; syn. qaAraSahu: (Ṣ,* TA: [in the O, AlmuqaAraDap is put for AlmuqaAraSap:]) he bandied words with him. (Ṣ, O, TA.)
5. tXh-l, said of the freshness, or brightness, and beauty, of the face, (maMC Alwajoh,) It went away, or departed, (O, Ḳ, TA,) by reason of emaciation. (TA.)
9: see 1.

hom.sense: XaholN A mixture of two colours. (ISk, TA.)
Hence, (ISk, TA,) one says, fiI fulaAnK waloEN and XaholN, (ISk, O, Ḳ,*) or fI flAn XaholN, (JK,) † In such a one is lying. (ISk, JK, O, Ḳ.)
See also XaholapN.

entry.sense: XahalN [properly inf. n. of Xahila]: see XuholapN.

XaholapN A middle-aged, intelligent woman: an epithet peculiarly applied to a woman: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) one says AimoraOapN XaholapN kaholapN, but not rajulN XaholN↓ kaholN; though IDrd mentions XaholN kaholN. (TA.)
And An old woman. (Ḳ.)

XuholapN A tinge, or mixture, of zuroqap [i. e. blueness, or grayness, or a greenish hue,] in the black of the eye: (Ṣ, O:) or, as also XahalN↓, [this latter mentioned above as inf. n. of Xahila, a tint] less than zaraqN, [in the CK Alz-uroq is erroneously put for Alz-araq, which is here used in the sense of Alz-uroqap,] and more beautiful than this, in the black of the eye: (Ḳ, TA:) thus in the M: (TA:) or a tinge of redness in the black of the eye, not in lines, like XukolapN, but [consisting in] a paucity of blackness of the black of the eye, so that it is as though it inclined to redness: (Ḳ:) or a hue of the black of the eye between redness and blackness: or a lack of purity of the blackness thereof: or a redness in the black of the eye; XukolapN being the like of a redness in the white thereof; thus expl. by AʼObeyd; and in like manner by Es-Semmák. (TA.)

hom.sense: XaholaMCu fem. of OaXohalu [q. v.]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
Also A want; syn. HaAjapN: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) said by IF to be originally XakolaMCu. (O.)

entry.sense: XiholiyliI-N A diroham [app. meaning a silver coin] of the measure of the breadth of the hand. (Mgh.)

OaXohalu, applied to a man, (Ṣ, O,) Having that quality of the eye which is termed XuholapN: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) accord. to AZ, syn. with OaXokalu: (TA: [but see this latter epithet:]) fem. XaholaMCu; (Ḳ;) which is applied as an epithet to an eye. (Ṣ, O.)
Also A mountain, and a wolf, dust-coloured inclining to whiteness. (En-Naḍr, TA.)
And AlOaXohalu is the name of A certain idol. (Ibn-El-Kelbee, O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. Xahuma, aor. _u {yaXohumu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. XahaAmapN (Ṣ, TA) and XuhuwmapN, (TA,) He (a man) was, or became, hardy, strong, sturdy, enduring, or patient; (Ṣ;) [or] acute of mind or intellect; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) clever, ingenious, sharp, or penetrating. (Ḳ.)
And ‡ He (a horse) was, or became, swift; brisk, lively, sprightly, or agile; and strong. (Ḳ, TA.)
[And app. It was, or became, rough, harsh, or coarse: for] XahaAmapN signifies xuXuwnapN. (Ḥam p. 699.)
Xahamahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXohamu} and _u {yaXohumu}, inf. n. XahomN and XuhuwmN, (Ḳ,) He frightened him, or made him afraid; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) namely, a man. (Ḳ.)
And Xahama Alfarasa, aor. _a {yaXohamu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XahomN, (TA,) He chid the horse; (Ḳ;) or incited him to quickness. (JK, Ḳ, and Ḥam p. 699.)

XahomN, applied to a man, Hardy, strong, sturdy, enduring, or patient; (Ṣ;) acute of mind or intellect; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) clever, ingenious, sharp, or penetrating; and maXohuwmN↓ signifies the same: pl. of the former XihaAmN (Ḳ) [and app. XuhumN also: see suhumN, and see what here follows].

A chief whose judgment, or judicial decision, or exercise of authority, is effectual in affairs; (Ḳ,* TA;) courageous; or sharp, or vigorous and effective, in affairs which others are unable to accomplish: or, accord. to Fr, forbearing, or clement; who performs well that which is imposed upon him; whom one finds not otherwise than forbearing, or clement, and pleased, or content, with that which is imposed upon him:
and in like manner applied to other than a man: (TA:) pl. XuhuwmN (Ḳ) [and app. XuhumN]: see suhumN, with which XuhumN is syn. (TA in art. shm.)
And, applied to a horse, ‡ Swift; brisk, lively, sprightly, or agile; and strong. (Ḳ, TA.)

Also A stone which is placed at the entrance of a trap (maSoyadap or maSiydap in different copies of the Ḳ) for a lion, and which falls upon it when he enters: as also sahomN: (Ḳ,* TA:) the latter is the word [better] known to the leading lexicologists. (TA.)

entry.sense: XahaAmN i. q. siEolaApN [app. meaning The kind of goblin, or demon, thus called]. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

XayohamN The dulodul [q. v., i. e. hedge-hog; or a certain species of hedge-hog;, &c.]: (Ḳ:) [see also the last sentence of this paragraph:] and, (Ḳ,) or accord. to AZ, (TA,) the male hedge-hog: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or such as has large prickles or spines, of male hedge-hogs, (Ḳ, TA,) and the like. (TA.) EalaI Zahori XayohamK, occurring in a verse of El-Aạshà, is said by AO to mean † In a state of fright, or fear. (TA.)
XayohamapN An old woman: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to IAạr, a hedge-hog. (TA.)

hom.sense: maXohuwmN: see XahomN.
Also Frightened, or made afraid. (Ṣ, TA.)
And, applied to a horse, Chidden; or incited to quickness. (TA.)

entry.sense: XihoniyzN i. q. XiyniyzN, (ADk, Ḳ,) and XuwniyzN, i. e. AlHab-apu Als-awodaMCu. (ADk, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Xahiyahu and XahaAhu: see 8.

XahaA, aor. _u {yaXohuwu}; and XahiIa, aor. _a {yaXohawu}; inf. n. XahowapN; It [food, &c.] was good, sweet, pleasant, or the like. (MA. [But this, the only meaning there assigned to these two verbs, I do not find elsewhere.])

entry.sense: 2. Xah-ayotuhu [I made him, or caused him, to desire, to long, or to desire eagerly]. (Mṣb.)
[And Xh-I It excited desire, longing, eager desire, or appetence. For ex., in art. smq in the Ḳ, yuXah-iI is said of the sum-aAq, or berry of the sumach, meaning It excites appetence.]

And Xh-I AlX-aIoCa He, or it, caused the thing to be desired, longed for, or desired eagerly: made it to be good, sweet, pleasant, or the like. (MA.) One says, hecaA XaIoCN yuXah-iI AlT-aEaAma i. e. [This is a thing that causes the food to be desired,, &c.; that makes it sweet,, &c.; or] that incites to desire, or eager desire, of the food. (Ṣ, TA.)

[And accord. to an explanation of the inf. n., taXohiyapN, in the KL, Xh-Ahu seems to signify also He said to him, I will give to thee what thou desirest, longest for, or eagerly desirest; agreeably with a rendering of the verb alone, as on the authority of that work, by Golius.]

hom.sense: 3. XAhAhu, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. muXaAhaApN, (TA,) He was, or became, like him; he resembled him. (Ḳ, TA.)
Also He jested, or joked, with him: (IAạr, TA:) [and] so haAXaAhu. (Ḳ in art. hXw.)
And accord. to IAạr, it is also used in relation to the smiting action of the [evil] eye [perhaps meaning He vied with him in smiting with the evil eye: see also 4]. (TA.)
4. AXhAhu He gave him what he desired or eagerly desired. (Ḳ.)
And He smote him with an [evil] eye: (Ḳ:) in this sense [said to be] formed by transposition from OaXaAhahu. (TA.)

maA OaXohaAhaA UilaI-a means that she is desired, or eagerly desired, [i. e. How great an object of desire is she to me!] as though it were from XuhiIa, though this was not said: and maA OaXohaAniI lahaA means that thou art desiring, or eagerly desiring, [i. e. How desirous, or eagerly desirous, am I of her!] so says Sb. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tXh-I He demanded with repeated desire. (Ḳ, TA.) So in the saying, (TA,) tXh-I EalaI fulaAnK kacaA (Ṣ, TA) [He demanded with repeated desire, of such a one, such a thing].
See also what next follows {8}.

8. AXthAhu (Ṣ, &c.) He desired it, or longed for it: (Mṣb:) he loved it; and desired it, or wished for it: (Ḳ:) or he desired it eagerly, or intensely: (M in art. frs: [see an ex. in a poetical citation voce far-asa:]) and Xahiyahu↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaXohawu}; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also XahaAhu↓, aor. _u {yaXohuwu}; (AZ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) inf. n. XahowapN (Ṣ, TA) and XaAhiyapN, which last is an inf. n. [of a rare class] like EaAqibapN; (TA;) signifies the same: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and so does tXh-Ahu↓. (Ḳ.) [See what next follows.]

XahowapN [mentioned above as an inf. n.] is a word of well-known meaning; (Ṣ;) Desire, or longing, or yearning, of the soul for a thing; (Er-Rághib, Mṣb, TA;) [meaning for a thing gratifying to sense: or eager, or intense, desire; particularly for such a thing; for] it has a more intensive signification than UiraAdapN; and the intelligent agree in opinion that it is not commendable: (M in art. frs:) [being either lawful or unlawful, it may be rendered as above: or appetite: or appetence: or lust: or carnal lust:] in the present state of existence, it is of two sorts, SaAdiqapN [i. e. true], and kaAcibapN [i. e. false]; the former being that without which the body becomes in an unsound state, as the Xahowap [or desire, &c.] for food on the occasion of hunger; and the latter being that without which the body does not become in an unsound state: and sometimes it is applied to the object of desire, &c., or thing desired, &c.: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and agreeably with this last explanation the first of the following pls. is used in the Ḳur iii. 12: (Ksh, Bḍ, Jel:) sometimes also it is applied to the faculty to which a thing is made an object of desire, &c.: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [also, to the gratification of venereal lust; thus in the Ḳ in art. Xfr; see Xafirato and XafirapN:] the pl. is XahawaAtN (Mṣb, TA) and OaXohiyapN and XuhFI; the last mentioned by AḤei, and a rare instance of a pl. of the measure fuEalN from a sing. of the measure faEolapN having an infirm letter for its last radical, like juhFI pl. of jahowapN [and like qurFI pl. of qaroyapN]. (TA.) [AlX-ahowataAni means The two appetites, that of the stomach and that of the generative organ.] AlX-ahowapu Alxafiy-apu [The latent desire, &c.] mentioned in a trad. is said to be any act of disobedience which one conceives in his mind, and upon which he resolves: or one's seeing a beautiful young woman, and lowering his eyes, then looking with his heart, and imaging her to his mind, and so tempting himself. (JM.) [Xahowapu AlT-iyni, lit. The longing for clay, is app. used as a general term for malacia: see Hum-aADN.]

XahowaAnu (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) and XahowaAniI-N↓ and XahiI-N↓, (Ḳ, TA,) applied to a man, Desirous, or longing; (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Ḳ,* TA;) or very desirous or longing; greedy; or voracious: (TA:) fem. (of the first, Mṣb) XahowaI: (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) pl. [of the first] XahaAwaI, (Ḳ, TA,) like sakaAraI [pl. of sakoraAnu]. (TA.) [See an ex. of the pl. in a verse cited voce jarodabaAnN.] One says, rajulN XahowaAnu lilX-aIoCi [A man desirous, &c. of the thing]. (Ṣ.)
XahowaAniI-N: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: XahiI-N i. q. muXotahFI↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb) [i. e. Desired, longed for, or eagerly desired:] or pleasant, delicious, or sweet: (Mṣb, TA:) applied to food, (Ṣ,) and to water. (TA.)
[Hence,] Oabuw AlX-ahiI-i † The barobaT [or Persian lute]. (KL.)
[And Golius adds, as on the authority of a gloss in a copy of the KL, † The water-melon (anguria).]
See also XahowaAnu.

entry.sense: Xah-aMCN A man having much, or frequent, desire or longing or eager desire. (TA.) [See also XahowaAnu.]

hom.sense: XaAhK [act. part. n. of 1; Desiring, or longing;, &c.]. (Sb, TA.)
XaAhiI AlbaSari A man sharp of sight: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) formed by transposition from XaAYihu AlbaSari. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: OaXohaI [More, and most, desirable, or pleasant or delicious or sweet]. One says, huwa OaXohaI UilaI-a mino kacaA [It is more desirable, or pleasant, &c., to me, or in my estimation, than such a thing]. (Mṣb voce UilaI.) See also another ex. in a verse cited voce UilaI, in art. Alw.
muXotahFI: see XahiI-N.
[Used as a subst., its pl. is muXotahayaAtN.]

hom.sense: 1. XaMCaniI, formed by transposition from XaMniI, aor. yaXuwoCu and yaXiIoCu, [but the latter form of the aor. is disallowed by MF,] He preceded me, or outwent me. (Ḳ.)
And He grieved me. (Ḳ.)
And He pleased me. (Ḳ.) Thus it bears two contr. significations. (TA.) And XuWotuhu, aor. OaXuwoWuhu, I pleased him. (Lth, O.)
And XuWotu bihi I was pleased with, and rejoiced in, him, or it. (Lth, O, Ḳ.) [See also art. XOw.]

entry.sense: XaMCN, n. un. XaApN: see art. Xwh.

Xay-iMnN, (Ḳ, TA, and L in art. tyH,) in form like the dual of say-idN [except as to the final vowel], (TA,) [erroneously written in the CK XayoYAen,]
and Xay-aMnN, like tay-iHaAnN and tay-aHaAnN [q. v.], (L in art. tyH,) [applied to a man,] Far-sighted; (Ḳ;) either in the proper sense, or metonymically applied to a man characterized by deliberation, and reflection, and looking to the results of affairs. (TA.) Each is also applied as an epithet to a horse. (L in art. tyH.) [The radical letters of this epithet are either XwO or XyO; therefore it is mentioned again in art. XyO; and another form thereof, without C, (Xay-aAn,) is mentioned in art. XwI.]

1. XaAbahu, aor. yaXuwbuhu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) inf. n. XawobN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XiyaAbN, (Ḳ,) He mixed it; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) such as milk with water; (Mṣb;) or honey with water. (A.) [And It mingled with it: for] one says also, kaOan-a riyqatahaA xamorN yaXuwbuhaA EasalN [As though her saliva were wine with which honey mingled]. (A.)

[It is sometimes used in a good sense, but more frequently in a bad sense; and often means He adulterated, vitiated, or sophisticated, it.] It is said in a trad., yaXohadu bayoEakumu AlHalifu waAll-agowu faXuwbuwhu biAlS-adaqapi † [Swearing, and unprofitable speech, attend your selling; therefore mix ye it with alms]. (TA.) And it is said in a prov., huwa yaXuwbu wayaruwbu † He mixes, or confounds, or makes a confusion or disorder, in speech and in actions: (Ṣ, TA:) or he says right one time and wrong another time: (Aṣ, TA:) or he defends without energy: (TA:) or he is sometimes incited to motion, or action, and defends himself, but without energy, and sometimes he is motionless, and does not become excited to motion, or action; and it is not from [the words XawobN and rawobN applied to] milk: so says Aboo-Saʼeed [i. e. Aṣ]: and he says also that XaAba Eanohu waraAba means he defended him at one time, and was sluggish, or indolent, at another time: and that Xw-b↓ Enh, inf. n. taXowiybN, means he defended him without energy: and thus this latter is expl. in the Ḳ, as is likewise XAb Enh: also that the Arabs say, laqiytu fulaAnFA Alyawoma yaXuwbu Eano OaSoHaAbihi, meaning I found such a one to-day defending his companions in some measure. (TA.) [See also art. rwb.]

XAb also signifies He acted treacherously, perfidiously, or unfaithfully: (Fr, TA:) he lied: he deceived in selling or buying: and he acted dishonestly, insincerely, or with dissimulation. (IAạr, TA.)
[See also Ḥar p. 448; where it is implied that it signifies also He spoke truth, or was veracious.]
2: see the preceding paragraph {1}.
7: see what next follows {8}.
8. AXtAb It was, or became, mixed; (O, Ḳ;) as also AnXAb↓. (Ḳ.)
XawobN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Ṣ, A, &c.)

[Hence,] laA Xawoba walaA rawoba, occurring in a trad., means There is, or shall be, no dishonesty, insincerity, or dissimulation, nor mixing, in the selling, or buying: so says IAạr: or I am irresponsible with respect to this commodity: or, as he is related to have said, thou art irresponsible for its being faulty, or defective. (TA. [See also XawobapN.])

And XawobN (TA) and XiyaAbN↓, (Ṣ, TA,) [each an inf. n. used as a subst. properly so termed,] or XiyaAbapN↓, (so in one copy of the Ṣ,) signify A mixture; an admixture; or a thing mixed with another thing. (Ṣ, TA.) Thus XawobFA signifies in the Ḳur xxxvii. 65: (TA:) or, accord. to one reading, the word there is XuwbFA↓, meaning a thing with which another thing is mixed. (Bḍ.) AlX-awobu also signifies [particularly] What is mixed [with something else], of water or of milk: (Ḳ:) one says, saqaAhu Alc-awoba biAlX-awobi He gave him to drink honey with water, or milk, mixed [therewith]: (TA:) or saqaAhu AlX-awoba biAlc-awobi He gave him to drink milk [mixed] with honey. (IDrd, TA.) And Mixed honey; as in the saying, maA EinodiI XawobN walaA rawobN I have not mixed honey nor milk such as is termed raAYib [q. v.]: (IAạr, TA:) or [simply] honey, &c.; (A, Mṣb, TA;) so called because they mix it with beverages; (Mṣb;) as in the saying, saqaAhu AlX-awoba biAlr-awobi He gave him to drink honey with clarified butter, or with milk. (A.) And Broth; as in the saying, maA Einodahu XawobN walaA rawobN He has not broth nor milk. (Ṣ, Ḳ: but in the latter, maA lahu.) And XawobN signifies also A piece of dough. (Ḳ.)

And [the pl.] OaXowaAbN signifies † A medley, or mixed multitude, of sundry sorts: a less particular term than OawobaAXN, which signifies a medley, or mixed multitude, of the low, or lower, or lowest, sort: (TA, from a trad.:) accord. to El-Jawáleeḳee, it is an arabicized word, from the Pers. MXuwbN. (TA in art. wXb.)
XuwbN: see XuwbFA in the next preceding paragraph.
XawobapN Deceit, delusion, guile, or circumvention: (Ḳ: [see also XawobN:]) [or, app., somewhat thereof:] one says, fiI fulaAnK XawobapN [In such a one is deceit,, &c.]. (TA.)

XayobaMCu A virgin in the night of her devirgination: (Ibn-Abi-l-Hadeed, MF:) [either from XaAba having for its aor. yaXuwbu, signifying “he mixed,” or from XaAba having for its aor. yaXiybu, signifying “he became white-headed, or hoary;” as shown by what follows:] one says, baAtato bilayolapi XayobaMCa, (Ṣ and A in art. Xyb, and Ḳ in the present art.,) and bilayolapi AlX-ayobaMCi, (Ḳ,) She passed the night of a virgin then devirginated, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and of the virgin then devirginated: (Ḳ, TA:) said of a virgin-bride when she is devirginated by the bridegroom in the night in which she has been first brought to him: (A, Ḳ, TA:) in the contr. case, when she is not devirginated, one says, baAtato bilayolapi Hur-apK: (Ṣ, TA:) and one says also, bilayolapK XayobaMCa and bilayolapK Hur-apK: (TA in art. Hr:) Z, in the A, mentions the first phrase in art. Xyb, and makes it to be tropical, as though the bride were in that night afflicted by an event so severe as to cause the locks of her hair to become white: in the L it is said that the I in XybAC is substituted for w, because of [the allusion of the phrase to] the mixing of the sperma genitale of the man with that of the woman; but that eXawobaMC has not been heard instead of XybAC: ISd, in the M, mentions it in arts. Xwb and Xyb; observing that the I is said to take the place of w: J, as well as Z and others, mentions it in art. Xyb [q. v.]. (TA.)
XiyaAbN and XiyaAbapN: see XawobN.
XaAYibapN sing. of XawaAYibu meaning The whiteness [mixing] with the darkness of night. (Ḥar p. 58.)

The saying layosa fiyhi XaAYibapu mulokK may be from XaAbahu “he mixed it;” meaning There is not in it anything [of ownership, or right of possession,] mixed therewith, though small, or however small; like as one says, layosa fiyhi EuloqapN walaA XubohapN; it being an instance of the measure faAEilapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN, as in EiyXapN raADiyapN: thus the lawyers use it. (Mṣb.)
XaAYibapN is also sing. of XawaAYibu meaning Uncleannesses, filths, or pollutions; or unclean, filthy, or foul, things. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.*)

maXuwbN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and maXiybN, the latter from Xiyb [“it was mixed”], Mixed. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) A poet says, (namely, Suleyk Ibn-Es-Sulakeh Es-Saadee, TA,)
wamaMCu quduwrK fiI AlqiSaAEi maXiybu
i. e. [And the water of cooking-pots, in the wooden bowls,] mixed with seeds for seasoning and with sauces. (Ṣ.)

AlfatoHapu AlmaXuwbapu biAlkasorapi means [The fet-ḥah that is mingled with kesreh; which is] the fethah that precedes the A of UimaAlap; as in EaAbidN and EaArifN [when they are pronounced “'ébidun” and “'érifun”]; for AmAlp consists in inclining [the sound of] fet-ḥah towards [that of] kesreh; whereby [the sound of] the A that follows it is inclined, and is not a pure A; for like as [the sound of] the fet-ḥah is mingled [with that of kesreh], so is [the sound of] the A [mingled with that of I]. (L, TA.)

muXaAwabN, with damm [to the m], and fet-ḥ to the w, [not with both of these vowels to the w as supposed by Freytag,] The case (gilaAf) of a flash or bottle; (Ḳ;) because it is mixed with redness and yellowness and greenness; mentioned by AḤát on the authority of Aṣ: (TA:) pl. maXaAwibu: (AḤát, Ḳ:) or the pl. signifies [receptacles of the sorts called] OasofaAT [pl. of safaTN] and Huqaq [pl. of Huq-apN] made of palm-leaves. (A.)

2. Xaw-aca Als-aHaAbu AlX-amosa The clouds covered the sun, (Ḳ,) as though it were turbaned with a dustcoloured haze inclining to yellow; as is the case in a year of drought; i. e. (T, L) thin clouds containing no water surrounding it, (T, L, Ḳ,) having the hue above described. (T, L.)

Xaw-acat AlX-amosu [thus in the L and Ḳ, not Xuw-icat nor taXaw-acat,] The sun inclined to setting, (T, L, Ḳ,) and became covered with such clouds [as those above described]: (T, L:) became turbaned with clouds. (AḤn, L.)

Xaw-acahu, (inf. n. taXowiycN, L,) † He turbaned him; attired him with a turban: (AZ, T, L, Ḳ:) app. from Xw-ct AlXms. (T, L.)
And Xw-c raOosahu † He turbaned his head. (Mṣb.)
5. tXw-c and AXtAc↓ † He turbaned himself; attired himself with a turban. (AZ, T, Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) [See above.]
8: see what next precedes {5}.
fulaAnN Hasanu AlX-iycapi † Such a one is goodly in his manner of turbaning. (Ḳ.)
xayoru AlOaXaAwici † The best of the creation, or of mankind, or people; syn. xayoru Alxaloqi. (Ḳ.)
miXowacN † A turban; (IAạr, Ṣ, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also miXowaAcN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. of the former maXaAwicu; (Ṣ, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and of the latter maXaAwiycu. (Ḳ.)
† A king: (Ḳ:) a crowned king. (TA.)
† A lord, or chief, (Ḳ,) to whom obedience is paid. (TA.)
miXowaAcN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: 1. XaAra, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaXuwru, (Mṣb,) inf. n. XaworN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and XiyaArN and XiyaArapN and maXaArN and maXaArapN; (Ḳ;) and AXtAr↓, and AXAr↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AstXAr↓; (A, Ḳ;) He gathered honey; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) extracted it from the small hollow [in the rock in which it had been deposited by the wild bees]; (A, Ḳ;) gathered it from its hives and from other places. (TA.)
XAr, inf. n. XaworN, He exhibited, showed, or displayed, a thing. (IAth, TA.)

XAr Ald-aAb-apa, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XaworN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XiwaArN, (Ḳ, TA,) or XawaArN; (CK;) and Xw-rhA↓, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. taXowiyrN; (TA;) and AXArhA↓, (Th, Ḳ,) but this last is rare; (Th, TA;) He exhibited, or displayed, the beast, for sale, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) going to and fro with it, (Ṣ, Mgh,) or making it to run, and the like: (Mṣb:) he tried the beast, to know its pace, or manner of going: (A, Mgh:) he made the beast to run, that he might know its power: (TA:) he broke, or trained, the beast: or he rode it on the occasion of exhibiting, or displaying, it to its purchaser: or tried it, to see its powers: or he examined it, as though he turned it over; and in like manner, AlOamapa the female slave. (Ḳ, TA.) [Hence] XAr nafosahu He displayed his agility, to show his power. (TA, from a trad.)
And Xurotuhu I ornamented, or decorated, it. (TA.)
XAr He (a man) became goodly in countenance. (Fr, TA.)

He (a horse) became fat and goodly: (Ṣ:) and so XArt said of a she-camel: (TA:) [and tXw-rt↓ said of a woman: (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees:)] or XArt said of a she-camel, she became fat; (Ḳ;) and in like manner AXtAr↓ and AstXAr↓ said of a he-camel: (Ṣ:) and AXtArt↓ AlUibilu the camels became somewhat fat: (Ṣ:) and AstXArt↓ they became fat and goodly: (Ḳ:) or this last signifies ‡ they became fat; because their owner points to such with his fingers; as though they desired to be pointed to. (A.)

entry.sense: 2. Xw-r Ald-aAb-apa, inf. n. taXowiyrN: see 1.
Xw-r bihi He did to him a deed of which one should be ashamed: (Yaạḳoob, Th, A, Ḳ:) or he made bare his pudenda: (O:) or as though he made bare his pudenda. (Ṣ.)

And Xw-rhu, (Lḥ, Ṣ,) and Xw-r bihi, (Lḥ, TA,) He made him to be confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, by reason of shame; or ashamed, and confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, in consequence of a deed that he had done. (Lḥ, Ṣ.)
Xw-r AlquTona He turned over [or separated and loosened] the cotton by means of the miXowaAr [q. v.]. (TA.)
See also 4, in two places.

3. XAwrhu, (inf. n. muXaAwarapN and XiwaArN, TA,) and AstXArh↓, both signify the same, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He consulted him, or consulted with him; he debated with him in order that he might see his opinion; (Mṣb;) fiI AlOamori respecting the thing or affair: (Ṣ, Mgh,* Mṣb:*) or ↓the latter, (A, Ḳ,) or both, (TA,) he sought, desired, or asked, of him counsel, or advice. (A, Ḳ.) See also 6.

hom.sense: 4: see 1, first sentence.
OaXironiI EasalFA, (Ḳ,) or EalaI AlEasali, (Sh, Ṣgh, L,) Help thou me to collect honey, or the honey. (Sh, Ṣgh, L, Ḳ.)
AXAr Ald-aAb-apa: see 1.

AXAr Aln-aAra, and AXAr bihaA, (Ḳ,) and OaXowarahaA, or OaXowara bihaA, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ, the former accord. to the text of the Ḳ in the TA,) and Xw-r↓ bihaA, (Ḳ, TA,) He stirred up the fire, or made it to burn up; syn. rafaEahaA. (Ḳ.)

AXAr Uilayohi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiXaArapN, (Mṣb,) He made a sign to him, with the hand, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or with the head, (Mṣb,) or with the eye, or with the eyebrow, (Ḳ,) or with a thing serving to convey intelligence of what he would say; as when one asks another's permission to do a thing, and the latter makes a sign with his hand or with his head, meaning that he should do it or not do it; (Mṣb;) as also Xw-r↓ Alyh, (ISk, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taXowiyrN. (Mṣb.)

[And He, or it, pointed to it or at it, pointed it out, or indicated it. Hence, in grammar, Aisomu UiXaArapK A noun of indication; as caA, &c. And] AXAr UilaI AlHarakapi biSawotK xafiI-K [He indicated the vowel by a somewhat obscure sound;] meaning he pronounced the vowel in the manner termed Alr-awomu. (I’Aḳ p. 351.) And AXAr UilaI AlUiEoraAbi fiI Alwaqofi [He indicated the caseending by the pronunciation termed Alr-awomu in pausing; as when you say OaI-u with a slurring of the final vowel-sound to one who says to you mar-a biI rajulN]. (Ṣ voce OaI-N.)
AXAr bihi He made it known. (Ḥar p. 357.)
AXAr Ealayohi He made known, or notified, to him the manner of accomplishing the affair that was conducive to good, and guided him to that which was right. (Ḥar ibid.)

AXAr Ealayohi bikacaA [in the CK Alyh] He counselled him, or advised him, to do such a thing; (Ṣ,* Mṣb;) showed him that he held it right for him to do such a thing: (Mṣb:) or he commanded, ordered, or enjoined, him to do such a thing. (Ḳ.)

He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, by reason of shame; or ashamed, and confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, in consequence of a deed that he had done. (Lḥ, Ṣ.)
See also 1, last sentence.

6. tXAwrwA and AiXotawaruwA↓ (A, Mgh, Mṣb) They consulted one another, or consulted together; they debated together in order that they might see one another's opinion: (Mṣb:) taXaAwurN signifies the extracting, or drawing forth, opinion; as also muXaAwarapN↓ and maXowarapN↓ and maXuwrapN↓, from XaAra “he extracted honey;” (Bḍ in ii. 233;) and XuwraI↓ signifies the same as taXaAwurN. (Bḍ in xlii. 36, and Mgh.)

taXaAyarahu Aln-aAsu occurs in a trad. as meaning AiXotaharuwhu biUiboSaArihimo [app. The people rendered him conspicuous, or notorious, by their looking at him]. (TA. [There mentioned in the present art.; as though the I were a substitute for w.])
8. AXtAr: see 1, first sentence.
And see 10.
See also 1, last sentence, in two places.
AXtAr canabahu i. q. AikotaAra [He (a horse) raised his tail in running]. (Ṣgh, TA.)
AiXotawaruwA: see 6.
10. AstXAr: see 1, first sentence.
See also 3, in two places.
AstXAr Aln-aAqapa He (a stallioncamel) smelt the she-camel and examined her, to know if she had conceived or not; (Ḳ;) as also AXtArhA↓. (AʼObeyd, TA.)
It (a man's case or affair) became manifest. (AZ, Ḳ.)
He put on, or clad himself with, goodly apparel. (Ḳ.)
See also 1, last sentence, in two places.

entry.sense: XaArN: see Xay-irN, in two places.
XaworN Honey gathered, or extracted, from its place: (Ḳ, TA:) originally an inf. n. (TA.)
See also XuwrapN, with which it is syn. in several senses accord. to the O and some copies of the Ḳ.
XuwrN: see XuwrapN, with which it is syn. in several senses accord. to the L and some copies of the Ḳ.
XaArapN: see XuwrapN, in three places.

hom.sense: XaworapN: see XuwrapN, in three places:
and see miXowaArapN.
Also i. q. xajolapN [i. e. Confusion, or perplexity, and inability to see one's right course, by reason of shame:, &c.]. (Ḳ.)

XuwrapN, (Ṣ, IAth, O, L, Ḳ,) with damm, (IAth, L,) and XaworapN↓, (TA, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) and XaArapN↓, (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ,) in which the | is changed from w, (TA,) and XuwrN↓, (so in the L and in some copies of the Ḳ,) or XaworN↓, (so in other copies of the Ḳ and in the O,) and XawaArN↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and XiyaArN↓, (O, Ḳ,) Form, or appearance; figure, person, mien, feature, or lineament; external state or condition; state with respect to apparel and the like, or garb. (Ṣ, IAth, O, L, Ḳ.) One says, fulaAnN Hasanu AlX-aArapi↓ and AlX-uwrapi Such a one is goodly in form or appearance,, &c. (TA.) And huwa rajulN Hasanu AlS-uwrapi waAlX-uwrapi He is a man goodly in respect of form and of appearance,, &c. (Fr. Ṣ. [See also below.])

Goodliness, or beauty: (IAth, L, Ḳ:) so XuwrapN is expl. by IAạr: (O:) and XaworapN↓, with fet-ḥ, is expl. as signifying pleasing beauty: (TA:) app. from XaworN, the “act of exhibiting, or showing,” a thing. (IAth, TA.)
Clothing, or apparel: (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ:) XaworapN↓, with fet-ḥ, is said to have this signification by Th: and XaArapN↓ is also expl. as signifying goodly, or beautiful, apparel. (TA.)
Ornament, ornature, or finery. (Ḳ.)
Fatness. (Ḳ.)

And XuwrapN, with damm, and miXowaArN↓, Aspect, or pleasing aspect; syn. manoZarN: and Internal, or intrinsic, state or quality; syn. maxobarN. (Ḳ,* TA.) One says, layosa lifulaAnK miXowaArN↓ i. e. manoZarN [Such a one has not a pleasing aspect]. (TA.) And fulaAnN Hasanu AlS-uwrapi waAlX-uwrapi Such a one is good in respect of form, and of internal state or qualities, when tried. (TA.) And fulaAnN Hasanu AlmiXowaAri↓ Such a one is good when one tries him. (Aṣ, TA.)
For the first word (XuwrapN), see also miXowaArapN.
And see musotaXiyrN.

entry.sense: XaworaI A certain marine plant; (Ḳ;) a sort of trees, of the trees of the shores of the sea: (Ṣgh, TA:) [it is, as supposed by Freytag, the plant called by Forskål (Flora Aegypt. Arab, p. 37,) sceura marina; of the class tetrandria, order monogynia; foliis lanceolatis, integris; floribus fulvis:, &c.: said by him to be called in Arabic “schura” Xwrh; and by the people of Maskat, “germ” qrm:] a sort of trees growing in inlets of the sea, in the midst of the water of the sea, resembling the dulob in the thickness of its stem and the whiteness of its bark, and also called quromN. (O.)
XuwraI: see maXowarapN, in four places; and 6.
XaworaAn [whether with or without tenween is not shown] i. q. EuSofurN [i. e. Safflower, or bastard saffron]. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: XawaArN: see XuwrapN.

Also, (ISk, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and XiwaArN↓, and XuwaArN↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) The furniture and utensils of a house or tent; (ISk, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) such as are deemed goodly: (Ḥam p. 305, in explanation of the first:) and of a camel's saddle. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

And the first, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and ↓second, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and ↓third, (Ḳ,) The pudendum, or pundenda, (faroj, Ṣ, Mṣb,) of a woman and of a man: (Ṣ:) or a man's penis, [see also miXowaArN,] and his testicles, and his posteriors or anus (Aisot). (Ḳ.) OabodaI Qll-ehu XawaArahu is a form of imprecation, (TA,) meaning May God make bare his pudenda. (Ṣ, A, TA.)
riyHN XawaArN A soft, or gentle, wind: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (Ṣgh, TA.)

entry.sense: XuwaArN: see XawaArN; each in two places.
XiwaArN: see XawaArN; each in two places.

hom.sense: XiyaArN: see XuwrapN.

Also a name given by the Arabs to Saturday, (Ṣ in this art., and Ḳ in art. Xyr,) in the Time of Ignorance: (TA in art. Xyr:) pl. [of pauc.] OaXoyurN and [of mult.] XuyurN and XiyrN: (Zj, Ḳ:) accord. to Zj, you may say valaAvapu XiyrK [Three Saturdays, using Xiyr as a pl. of pauc.]: so in the Tekmileh. (TA.)

entry.sense: Xay-irN One's consulter, or counseller with whom he consults: and one's waziyr [q. v.]: (Ḳ:) one qualified for consultation: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. XuwaraMCu. (Ḳ.) One says, fulaAnN xay-irN Xay-irN Such a one is [good,] qualified for consultation. (Ṣ, TA.)

A man goodly in respect of XaArap [i. e. appearance, or apparel,, &c.]: (Fr, Ṣ, A:) or beautiful, or good: in this or in the former sense, the fem., with p {Xay-irapN}, is applied to a woman. (TA.) One says, Uin-ahu laSay-irN Xay-irN Verily he is goodly in form and in appearance or apparel, &c. (Fr, Ṣ, A.)

A man goodly in his internal, or intrinsic, states or qualities, when tried; as also XaArN↓: one says rajulN Xay-irN Say-irN and XaArN↓ SaArN A man goodly in his internal, or intrinsic, states or qualities, and equally so in his outward appearance. (TA.)
Fat: (TA:) or fat and goodly: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) pl. XiyaArN, applied to horses, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and to camels. (Ṣ.)
qaSiydapN Xay-irapN A beautiful ode; (Ḳ;) an excellent ode. (TA.)

OaXowaru [More, and most, distinguished by Xuwrap or XaArap, i. e., form, or appearance;, &c.]. OaXowaru EaruwsK turaI [The comeliest bride that was to be seen] is a phrase occurring in a trad. relating to Ez-Zebbà [a queen of El-Heereh, celebrated for her beauty]. (A, TA.)

maXaArN A xaliy-ap [or habitation of bees, generally a hollow in a rock,] (Ṣ, Ḳ,) from which one gathers, or extracts, honey; (Ṣ;) a bee-hive; as also muXotaArN↓. (KL.) See the next paragraph. [And see also miXowaArapN.]

maAciI-N muXaArN White honey (TA) gathered, (Ṣ, TA,) or which one has been assisted to gather. (Ḳ, TA.) AA cites the following verse, (Ṣ,) of El-Kutámee, (accord. to a copy of the Ṣ,) or of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, (O, TA.)
wasamaAEK yaOocanu AlX-ayoxu lahu
waHadiyvK mivoli maAciI-K muXaArN
[And a singing, or a musical performance, (or, instead of And, the meaning may be Many,) to which the old man would lend ear, and a discourse like gathered white honey]: but Aṣ disapproves of this, and says that the right reading is maAciI-i maXaArN↓ [white honey of a habitation of bees from which it has been extracted], the former of these words being prefixed to the latter, governing it in the gen. case, and the latter being with fet-ḥ to the m. (Ṣ, TA.)
maXuwrN A thing ornamented, or decorated. (Ḳ.)
miXowarN, (Ṣ,) or miXowaArN↓, (Ḳ,) or both, (TA,) The wooden implement with which honey is gathered: (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA:) pl. of the former maXaAwiru. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: maXaArapN: see miXowaArN.

Also A rivulet, or streamlet, for irrigation; syn. saAqiyapN: (TA voce rakiybN:) or a channel of water: (TA voce dabor:) or a daborap [i. e. either a small channel of water for irrigation or a portion of ground] in land sown or for sowing: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a daborap [app. here meaning a portion of ground] cut off, or separated, from the adjacent parts, (muqoTaEapN,) for sowing and for planting: it may be of this art., or from AlmaXorapu: (ISd, TA:) or what is surrounded by dams [or by ridges of earth] which confine, or retain, the water [for irrigation]; as also daborapN and HibosN: (R, TA:) pl. maXaAwiru and maXaAYiru. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: maXuwrapN: see the next paragraph, in four places.

maXowarapN and maXuwrapN↓ and XuwraI↓ signify the same: (Ṣ:) the first and second are substs. from XaAwarahu, and the third is a subst. from taXaAwaruwA: (Mṣb:) or the first (Lth) and second [which is written in the CK maXowarapN] (Lth, Ḳ) and third (Ḳ) are from AlUiXaArapu (Lth) or OaXaAra Ealayohi: (Ḳ:) [they signify Consultation; or mutual debate in order that one may see another's opinion; or counsel, or advice: or a command, an order, or an injunction: or] the extracting, or drawing forth, opinion: (Bḍ, as mentioned above: see 6:) maXuwrapN↓ [in the CK maXowarapN] is of the measure mafoEulapN, [originally maXowurapN, in the CK mafoEalapN,] not mafoEuwlapN, (Ḳ, TA,) because it is an inf. n., [or rather a quasi-inf. n.,] and such a noun has not this last measure: (TA:) it is like maEuwnapN; (Mṣb;) and is a contraction of maXowurapN: (Fr, TA:) and it is said also to be from XaAra Ald-aAb-apa; or, accord. to some, from XaAra AlEasala; good counsel or advice being likened to honey. (Mṣb.) One says, Ealayoka biQlomaXowarapi fiI Oumuwrika and biQlomaXuwrapi↓ [Keep thou to consultation, or take counsel, in thine affairs]. (A.) And fulaAnN jay-idu AlmaXuwrapi↓ and AlmaXowarapi [Such a one is good, or excellent, in consultation, or counsel]. (TA.) And Oamoruhumo XuwraI↓ bayonahumo, like Amrhm fawoDaI bynhm, [Their affair, or case, is a thing to be determined by consultation among themselves,] i. e., none of them is to appropriate a thing to himself exclusively of others. (Mṣb.) It is said of ʼOmar, taraka AlxilaAfapa XuwraI↓ (A, Mgh) He left the office of Khaleefeh as a thing to be determined by consultation: for he assigned it to one of six; not particularizing for it any one of them; namely, ʼOthmán and ʼAlee and Talhah and Ez-Zubeyr and ʼAbd-Er-Raḥmán Ibn-'Owf and Saạd Ibn-Abee-Wakkás. (Mgh.) And one says also, Aln-aAsu fiyhi XuwraI↓ [The people are to determine by consultation respecting it]. (A.)
AlmuXiyrapu The forefinger, or pointing finger. (A, Ḳ.)
vawobN muXaw-arN A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed with XaworaAn, meaning EuSofur [i. e. safflower]. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: miXwaArN: see miXowarN.
Also The string of the minodaf [q. v.]: (Ḳ, TA:) because the cotton is turned over [or separated and loosened] (yuXaw-aru i. e. yuqal-abu) by means of it. (TA.)

Also A place in which beasts are exhibited, or displayed, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) for sale, and in which they run. (Mgh, Mṣb.) Hence the saying, Uiy-aAka waAlxuTaba faUin-ahaA miXowaArN kaviyru AlEivaAri ‡ [Avoid thou orations, for they are means of display in which one often stumbles]. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
And The pace, or manner of going, of a horse: one says farasN Hasanu AlmiXowaAri [A horse good in respect of pace, or manner of going]. (A.)
See also XuwrapN, latter part, in three places.
One says of camels, (Ḳ,) or of a beast, (daAb-ap, TA,) Oaxacato miXowaArahaA and maXaAratahaA↓ They, or it, became fat and goodly (Ḳ, TA) in appearance. (TA.)

[It occurs in the O and Ḳ, in art. xwq, as signifying The penis of a horse: perhaps a mistranscription for XiwaAr, q. v.: I find it expl. in this sense in Johnson's Pers., Arab., and Engl. Dict.; but he may have taken it from the Ḳ.]

[It is said to signify] also A portion that a beast has left remaining of its fodder: (O, Ḳ, TA:) but Kh says, “I asked ADk, Is it niXowaArN or miXowaArN? and he said niXowaArN, and asserted it to be Pers.:” (O, TA:) it is an arabicized word, (Ḳ,) originally niXoxuwaAr: (O, Ḳ: or, as in the CK, nuXoxwAr: [correctly niXoxowaAro or nuXoxowaAro:]) one says, naXowarati Ald-aAb-apu niXowaArFA. (TA.)

entry.sense: miXowaArapN A place in which bees deposit their honey; as also XuwrapN↓; (Ḳ;) or, as written by Ṣgh, the latter word is [XaworapN↓,] with fet-ḥ. (TA.) [See also maXaArN.]
muXotaArN A gatherer of honey. (Ṣ, TA.)
See also maXaArN.
musotaXiyrN Fat; (AA, Ṣ;) as also XuwrapN↓, with damm, applied to a she-camel: (Ḳ:) or the latter signifies of generous race; or excellent. (TA.) [See also Xay-irN.]
And A stallion-camel (El-Umawee, T, Ṣ) that knows the female which has not conceived, and distinguishes her from others. (El-Umawee, T, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. Xawisa, (Ḳ,) aor. yaXowasu, (TA,) inf. n. XawaXN; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA;) and XaAsa, aor. yaXaAsu, (Lth, Ḳ, TA,) or yaXuwsu; (Ḥam p. 68;) He looked from the outer angle of his eye, by reason of pride, or of anger, or rage: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or, as in the M, he looked with one of his eyes, inclining his face towards the side of that eye; doing so naturally, or by reason of pride and self-conceit and anger: or he raised his head in pride: (TA:) or he made the eye small, contracting the lids, to look: and tXAws↓ has the first of the meanings above mentioned; (A, Ḳ;) or the last: (A:) or one says, tXAws fiI naZarihi, meaning he looked with the look of the haughty, or proud: (TA:) or tXAws Uilayohi he looked at him from the outer angle of his eye, inclining his face towards the side of the eye with which he looked: (AA, Ṣ, TA: [see also 3:]) or tXAws signifies he looked towards the sky with one of his eyes: or it means he showed, or manifested, pride and self-conceit, and haughtiness; agreeably with the general analogy of verbs of this measure: and XawasN is in the natural disposition. (TA.)
Also He was such as is termed OaXowas meaning bold, or daring, to engage in fight, and strong. (TA.)
XawosN [inf. n. of XaAsa] in relation to the siwaAk [or toothstick] is a dial. var. of XawoSN: (IAạr, Ḳ, TA:) one says, XaAsa faAhu biAls-iwaAki, like XaASahu [q. v.]. (Fr, TA.)

entry.sense: 3. XaAwasahu [He looked at him in the manner of him who is termed OaXowas; like tXAws Uilayohi: see muXaAwisN].
6: see the first paragraph {1}.

OaXowasu, applied to a man, (Ṣ, A,) Who looks in the manner expl. above, in the first sentence of this art.: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or in whose look is known anger; or rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; and pride: (TA:) or raising his head by reason of pride: (AA, TA:) fem. XawosaMCu: (A, TA:) and pl. XuwsN. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) [Hence the saying,] buliIa fulaAnN biXuwsi AlxuTuwbi ‡ [Such a one was tried with terrifying, or severe, calamities or afflictions]. (A, TA.)
Also Bold, or daring, to engage in fight, and strong. (TA. [See also XuwXN: and see OaXorasu.])

muXaAwisN ‡ Water hardly to be seen, by reason of its paucity, and the depth to which it has sunk; (A,* Ḳ;) as though it looked at him who came to it in the manner of him who is termed OaXowas (kaOan-ahu yuXaAwisu AlwaArida). (A, TA.)

2. Xw-X Ealayohi AlOamora, inf. n. taXowiyXN, He rendered the affair, or state, or case, confused, disordered, or perplexed, to him: (El-Fárábee, Ṣ,* Mṣb: the inf. n., and that only, mentioned in the Ṣ in art. XyX:) or, accord. to certain of those skilled in the abstrusities and niceties of science, Xw-X is a post-classical word, and the chaste word is haw-aXa: accord. to IAmb, the leading lexicologists hold that one should only say hw-X; and Az and others say the same: (Mṣb:) [F also says,] taXowiyXN is a mistake for tahowiyXN. (Ḳ.) See also XawaAXK.

5. tXw-X Ealayohi AlOamoru The affair, or state, or case, became confused, or perplexed, to him: (El-Fárábee, Ṣ, Mṣb: mentioned in the Ṣ in art. XyX:) or this is post-classical: (Mṣb:) or taXaw-uXN is a mistake for tahaw-uXN. (Ḳ.)
6. tXAwX Alqawomu The people, or company of men, became mixed, or confounded, together; syn. tahaAwaXa. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.*)
XawXN in the phrase OaboTaAlN XuwXN i. q. XuwsN [pl. of OaXowasu, q. v.]. (O, Ḳ.)

XawoXaMCu and XawoXaApN, (Lth, O, Ḳ,) or the former is a mistake, (TA,) the latter said by Az to be that which he heard from the Arabs, (O, TA,) applied to a she-camel, Light, or agile: (Lth, O, Ḳ:) or, so applied, swift: (AʼObeyd, O:) and applied to a woman as an epithet of discommendation. (O.) A poet, cited by AA, applies the epithet XawaAXiY↓, with hemz, by poetic license, to a naADiH [properly meaning a camel upon which water is drawn from a well]; originally from XawoXaMCu, (O,) or XawoXaApN, (TA,) meaning “Light,” or “agile,” applied to a she-camel: so says AA. (O, TA.)

bayonahumo XawaAXK, (O, and so in the TA as from the Ḳ,) or XawaAXN, (so in the CK and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,) Between them is disagreement, dissension, discord, or difference: (O, Ḳ:) the vulgar say taXowiyXN↓. (O, TA.)
XawaAXiY: see XawoXaMCu.
maXuwXN, (so accord. to my copy of the KL,) or miXowaXN, (so accord. to Golius from the KL,) A small turban (dasotaAroJaho). (KL. [Comp. miXowacN.])
muXaAwiXN Water not to be seen, (Ḳ,) or hardly to be seen, (TA,) by reason of its remoteness [from the surface of the ground] or its paucity: (Ḳ:) a dial. var. of muXaAwisN [q. v.]. (TA.)

1. XaASa, aor. yaXuwSu (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and yaXaASu, in all its senses, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. XawoSN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He set up a thing with his hand: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he put it into a state of commotion: (Mṣb:) or it signifies also he moved it violently from its place. (IDrd, Ḳ.)
He rubbed a thing with his hand. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

He washed (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) a thing, (Mṣb,) or anything: (AʼObeyd:) he cleansed (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ) a thing: (AO:) as, for instance, his mouth, with the siwaAk [or toot-stick]: (Ṣ:) he rubbed and cleansed the teeth and the side of the mouth. (IAạr.) You say XaASa faAhu He cleansed and washed his teeth, (Mgh,) biAls-iwaAki [with the tooth-stick]. (Mṣb.) And XaASa OasonaAnahu, (A,) or faAhu, (TA,) [or app., XaASa alone, accord. to the Ḳ,] He cleansed his teeth with the siwaAk: (AA, Ḳ, TA:) or he did so by passing it across his teeth: (A, TA:) or from below upwards: (Ḳ, TA:) or by thrusting it into them, or between them: (TA:) and in like manner you say, AXAS↓ faAhu, (TA,) inf. n. UiXaASapN; (Fr, Ḳ, TA;) and Xw-S↓ fAh, (TA,) inf. n. taXowiySN. (Ḳ, TA.)
Also He chewed a siwaAk [app. to separate the fibres at the end and so make it like a brush, to prepare it for cleaning his teeth with it]. (Ḳ,* TA.)
2: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.
4: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

XawoSu Als-iwaAki The washings (gusaAlap) of the toothstick: or what remains from the tooth-stick when one cleans his teeth with it: each of these meanings is assigned to it in explanations of a trad.: AisotagonuwA Eani Aln-aAsi walawo biXawoSi Als-iwaAki [Be ye independent of other men, if it be only by means of possessing the washings,, &c., of the tooth-stick: i. e., as long ye possess anything]. (TA.)
1. XaATa, aor. yaXuwTu, inf. n. XawoTN, He ran a heat, or single run, or a run at once, to a goal, or limit. (TA.)

hom.sense: 2. Xw-T, inf. n. taXowiyTN, He (a man, IAạr) made a long journey; his journey was, or became, long. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
Xw-T Alfarasa: see 5.
Xw-T safiynatahu He voyaged with his ship. (TA.)
Also Xw-T He made a cooking-pot to boil. (El-Kilábee.)
He cooked thoroughly flesh-meat; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣgh, Ḳ;) as also Xy-T: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣgh:) or both signify he smoked it, or made it smoky, and did not thoroughly cook it. (TA.)
† It (hoar-frost, or rime,) burned (OaHoraqa, q. v.) a plant, or herbage: (Ḳ:) and in like manner one says of medicine which is sprinkled upon a wound. (TA.) See also 4 in art. XyT, in two places.

entry.sense: 5. tXw-T Alfarasa, [in the CK, Xaw-aTa↓, but as this, in the manner in which it is there mentioned, is a needless repetition, being implied, if correct, it is doubtless a mistranscription,] He continued to drive, or urge on, the horse, until he was tired, or fatigued. (Ḳ,* TA.)

hom.sense: XawoTN A heat; a single run, or a run at once, to a goal, or limit; (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) syn. TalaqN: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. OaXowaATN. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, EadaA XawoTFA He ran a heat. (Ṣ.) And TaAfa baAlbayoti saboEapa OaXowaATK He performed seven circuits round the House [of God, i. e. the Kaabeh]: (Ṣ, TA:) from the [Black] Stone to the [Black] Stone [again] is one XawoT: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) but some of the lawyers disapprove of this application of the term AXwAT. (IF, Ḳ, TA.)

[It is also, app., an inf. n. used as an epithet: for one says, jaMCa XawoTN mina Alxayoli: see sananN, in the latter part of the paragraph.] It is sometimes used in relation to the wind: so says Lth: and he cites the following as an instance in which the wind is meant:
wanaAziHK muEotakiri AlOaXowaATi [app. meaning And a wind, or many a wind, exhausting, or drying up, the waters, the blasts thereof bringing dust]. (TA.)
And it is also [used as meaning A bout] of shooting arrows. (T and M in art. rXq.)

Also The space of ground over which a horse runs; such as a mayodaAn, and the like; which is [said by some to be] the primary signification; [but the primary signification is said by others to be the first given above; (see Ḥar p. 574;)] and so taXowiyTapN↓. (TA.)
Also † A scope; an object to be reached, or accomplished; syn. gaAyapN: whence the saying, AlX-awoTu baTiynN † The scope is remote: (Ḥar p. 574:) a prov., relating to the long extent of hope. (TA.)

And † A place between two elevated tracts of ground, through which water and men pass, as though it were a road, extending as far as the voice of a caller can be heard, then ending, (ISh, O, Ḳ,) of such depth that it will conceal the camel and his rider, found only in plain, or soft, ground, and producing good herbage: (ISh, O:) pl. XiyaATN; (ISh, O, Ḳ;) originally XiwaATN. (ISh, O.) Z writes it with s. (TA. See sawoTN.)
XawoTu baraAHK i. q. Aibonu MwaI [The jackal]: (IDrd, Ṣ, Z, O, L, Ḳ:) or some other beast. (L.)
XawoTu baATilK: see sawoTu baATilK, in art. swT: accord. to IDrd, it is not of established authority. (O.)

entry.sense: taXowiyTapN: see XawoTN.
It is also, metonymically, applied to ‡ The plague, or pestilence; and other destructive diseases. (TA.)

XuwaAZN and XiwaAZN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c., [but in one copy of the Ṣ, I find only the former, which is the more common,]) occurring in the Ḳur [lv. 35], where Ibn-Ketheer read XiwaAZN, (TA,) Flame (Ṣ, Bḍ, Jel, Ḳ) without smoke: (Ṣ, Jel, Ḳ:) or smoke of fire: and heat of fire: (ISh, Ḳ:) and heat of the sun: (Ḳ, TA:) or a piece of fire in which is no smoke: or flame of fire: or only of fire and something mixed therewith. (L.)
[And hence,] ‡ Vehemence of thirst: (Ḳ, TA:) or simply, thirst. (A, TA.) You say, jamalN bihi XwAZN ‡ A thirsting camel. (A, TA.)
And ‡ Clamour. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Xufotuhu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. OaXuwfuhu, (O,) inf. n. XawofN, (O, Ḳ,) I polished it; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) namely, a thing, (Ṣ, O,) or an ornament of gold or silver. (Mgh.)

[Hence,] Xiyfati AljaAriyapu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) also written Xuyofat, (thus in one of my copies of the Ṣ, in the other written XuYifat, and thus only,) aor. tuXaAfu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) The girl, or young woman, was adorned. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And [hence likewise,] XawofN also signifies The smearing of a camel with tar. (Ḳ.) One says, Xufo baEiyraka Smear thy camel with tar. (O.)
[The inf. n.] XawafaAnN as syn. with taXaw-ufN [but in what sense is not said] is vulgar. (TA.)
So too is [the inf. n.] XawofN as meaning The act of seeing [and of looking]. (TA.) [XAf is much used in the present day as meaning He saw, and he looked at, a thing.]
2. Xw-f AljaAriyapa, inf. n. taXowiyfN, He adorned the girl, or young woman. (TA.)
Xy-f Ald-awaMCa He made the medicament to be what is termed XiyaAf [q. v.]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.) [The I in this verb is substituted for w.]

4. AXAf Ealayohi i. q. OaXorafa [meaning He was, or became, on the brink, or verge, or at the point, of it], (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) namely, a thing; like OaXofaI; (Ṣ, O;) from which it is formed by transposition. (Ṣ.)
And AXAf He feared. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.) You say, AXAf minohu He feared him, or it. (Ḳ.)
See also 5, last sentence.

5. tXw-f He adorned himself: (Ḳ:) or tXw-ft she (a woman, IDrd, O, or a girl, or young woman, Ṣ) adorned herself. (IDrd, Ṣ, O.) One says of a woman divorced by a sentence that admits of her returning, tutaXaw-afu lizawojihaA i. e. She adorns herself for her husband, by making her face clear, and polishing her cheeks; from 1 in the first of the senses assigned to it above. (Mgh.)

tXw-ft AlOawoEaAlu The mountain-goats ascended upon the tops of the mountains, (Lth, O, Mṣb,) and looked down, (Lth, O,) to see the plain country and its freedom from those whom they feared, in order that they might repair to the water and the pasturage. (Mṣb.)

Hence, tXw-f likacaA He (a man) raised, or stretched and raised, his eyes, or sight, towards such a thing: and hence the verb became used to denote hope, or expectation, and desire, or seeking. (Mṣb.) And tXw-f mina Als-aToHi He stretched himself up, and looked, and overlooked, or looked down, from the house-top. (Ḳ.) One says, Aln-isaMCu yataXaw-afona mina Als-uTowHi The women look, [or look down,] stretching themselves up, from the house-tops. (Ṣ, O.) [See also 8.] And one says also, tXw-f UilaI AlXIoCi, (Ṣ,) or AlI Alxayori, (O, Ḳ,) or AlI Alxabari, (CK,) He looked for [the thing, or good, or the news or tidings], (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,), &c. (TA.)
And tXw-f AlX-aIoCu The thing rose, or became high or elevated; as also AXAf↓. (TA.)
8. AXtAf He (a man, Ṣ, O) stretched himself up, and looked: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and in like manner one says of horses. (TA.) [See also 5.]
And AXtAf Albaroqa He looked at the lightning, or at the cloud thereof, to see whither it was tending, and where it would rain; syn. XaAmahu. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
Also, said of a wound, It became rough, or thick; (AZ, O, Ḳ;) and so AstXAf↓, thus without hemz. (TA.)

entry.sense: 10: see what next precedes {8}.
XawofN The mijar-, (O, Ḳ,) i. e. a wooden implement, (O,) [meaning a harrow,] by means of which the ploughed land is made even. (O.)
XaAfapN: see XaOofapN, in art. XOf. (TA.)
XiyaAfN Medicaments for the eye and the like: (O, Ḳ:) from 1 in the first of the senses assigned to it above: originally XiwaAfN. (O.)
Xaw-aAfN A sharp-sighted man. (TA.)
Xay-ifapN A scout, or scouts, (TaliyEapN,) employed to look out for a party; (IAạr, Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also Xay-ifaAnN↓. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.)
Xay-ifaAnN: see what next precedes.

Polished: applied to a diynaAr [&c.]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) 'Antarah says,
walaqado Xaribotu mina AlmudaAmapi baEoda maA
rakada AlhawaAjiru baAlmaXuwfi AlmuEolami
[And verily I have drunk wine, after that the vehement noon-day-heats of summer had remitted, purchased with the polished, charactered deenár]: (Ṣ, O, and EM p. 237:) he means the deenár polished by the minter thereof: (TA:) or, as some say, he means the bright, charactered, or figured, bowl. (O, TA.*)
Also A camel smeared with tar; (O, Ḳ;) because it polishes him. (TA.)

And (Ḳ) accord. to AA (O, TA) and AʼObeyd, (TA,) as used by Lebeed, (O, TA,) A camel in a state of excitement by lust: (O, Ḳ:*) but as some relate the verse in which it occurs, the word is with s, and means “smelt” by the [other] camels because smeared with tar. (O, TA.)
And, (Ḳ,) as some say, (O, TA,) it means [A camel] decorated with wools of various colours, and with other things. (O, Ḳ. [In the CK, Almuzay-inu is erroneously put for Almuzay-anu.])
muXaw-afapN like muEaZ-amapN [in measure], A woman who exposes herself to view in order that men may see her. (Aboo-ʼAlee, TA.)

1. XaAqaniI, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaXuwquniI, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. XawoqN; (Mṣb, TA;) and Xaw-aqaniI↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) inf. n. taXowiyqN; (TA;) It (a thing, Ṣ and Mṣb in relation to the former verb, or the love of a female, Ḳ, and the mention of her, and her beauty, TA, or the latter verb is said of a man, Mṣb,) excited my desire, or the yearning or longing of my soul. (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ * TA.) [Hence,] one says, Xuqo Xuqo fulaAnFA, meaning Render thou desirous, render thou desirous, such a one (Xaw-iqohu↓) for the ultimate abode or ultimate state of existence in the world to come (UilaI AlMxirapi). (IAạr, Ḳ, TA. [See also 2.])

And XAq AlT-unuba UilaI Alwatidi, (Ḳ,) aor. yaXuwquhu, inf. n. XawoqN, (TA,) ‡ He tied, and made fast, the tent-rope to the tent-peg; (Ḳ, TA;) as also XAqh having for its inf. n. XayoqN; (TA in art. Xyq;) like naATahu bihi, inf. n. nawoTN: mentioned also by Z. (TA.)
And XAq Alqirobapa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) ‡ He set up the water-skin, leaning it against the wall: (Ḳ, TA:) mentioned by Ibn-Buzurj. (TA.)

2: see above {1}, in two places. A poet says, (O,) a man of the tribe of Kelb, (Ḥam pp. 145 et seq.,)
waHan-ato naAqatiI TarabFA waXawoqFA
UilaI mano biAlHaniyni tuXaw-iqiyniI
[And my she-camel uttered a yearning cry, by reason of lively emotion, and desire; whereupon I said, For whom, by the yearning cry, dost thou render me desirous?]: tuXaw-iqiyniI being for tuXaw-iqiynaniI. (O, and Ḥam p. 146, q. v.) Lth says that Alt-aXowiyqu in relation to reading or recitation [of the Ḳur-án], and [sacred] narratives, is as when one says, Xaw-iqonaA yaA fulaAnu [lit. Do thou render us desirous, O such a one], meaning do thou mention [to us] Paradise and what is therein, by narratives, or reading or recitation; may-be we shall become desirous of it, and therefore work for it. (O, TA.)
4. AXAqhu signifies wajadahu XaAYiqFA [app. meaning, EaAXiqFA, i. e. He found him to be an excessive, or attached, or admiring, lover]. (IAạr,* TA.)
One says also, maA OaXowaqaniI Uilayoka [How great is my desire, or the yearning or longing of my soul, for thee!]. (TA.)
5. tXw-q He was, or became, excited by desire, or yearning or longing of the soul; quasi-pass. of Xaw-aqahu (Ṣ, TA) and XaAqahu. (TA.) See also 8.
And (TA) He showed, or made a show of, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and affected, (O,) or affecting, (Ḳ, TA,) desire, or a yearning or longing of the soul. (O, Ḳ, TA.)

8. AXtAq Uilayohi, (MA, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AXtAqhu, both signifying the same, (MA, O, Ḳ,) as also tXw-q↓ Uilyh, i. e. He was, or became, desirous of it; or affected with desire for it; (MA;) [or he yearned or longed for it in his soul; for] AiXotiyaAqN is syn. with XawoqN, (q. v.) as expl. below. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: XawoqN Desire, or yearning or longing of the soul, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) UilaI XaIoCK for a thing; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also AiXotiyaAqN↓: (Ṣ:) [or] the motion of love: (IAạr, O, Ḳ:) pl. OaXowaAqN. (Ḳ.) One says, bar-aHa biI AlX-awoqu [Desire,, &c., distressed me]: and balagato min-iI AlOaXowaAqu [meaning in like manner Desires,, &c., distressed me]. (TA.) banaAtu AlX-awoqi means † The effects of AlXwq [or desire,, &c.]. (Ḥam p. 539.)
Also inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Mṣb, TA.)

entry.sense: XiyqN: see what next follows.

XiyaAqN † The thing with which a thing is extended in order to its being tied to a thing; (O, Ḳ;) like niyaATN; (Ṣ in art. Xyq, O, TA;) originally. XiwaAqN: and XiyqN↓, originally XiwoqN, signifies the same. (TA.)
XaAYiqN Exciting one's desire, or the yearning or longing of the soul of a person. (Ṣ, TA.)

Also [a possessive epithet, meaning cuw XawoqK. And hence,] An excessive, or attached, or admiring, lover; syn. EaAXiqN; and so maXuwqN↓: (Ḥar, p. 142:) or ↓the latter signifies one whose desire, or yearning or longing of the soul, is excited: (Ṣ, TA:) the former is sing. of XuwqN, (TA,) which is syn. with EuX-aAqN [pl. of EaAXiqN] (IAạr, O, Ḳ, TA) as well as pl. of OaXowaqu. (Ḳ.)

Xay-iqN i. q. muXotaAqN↓ [i. e. Desirous, or yearning or longing in the soul]: (O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or i. q. maXuwqN [q. v. voce XaAYiqN, in two places]: (JK:) originally XayowiqN, of the measure fayoEilN. (O, TA.)
Xaw-aAqN [Very desirous; or desiring, or yearning or longing, in the soul, much]. (JK and Mṣb voce taw-aAqN.)
OaXowaqu Tall; (IDrd, O, Ḳ;) applied to a man; but not of established authority: (IDrd, O:) pl. XuwqN. (Ḳ.)
maXuwqN: see XaAYiqN, in two places.
qirobapN maXuwqapN ‡ A water-skin set up, leaned against a wall. (Ibn-Buzurj, O, Ḳ, TA.)

muXotaAqN: see Xay-iqN. AlmuXotaOaq (so in the Ṣ,) or AlmuXotaYiq, because muXotaAqN is originally muXotawiqN, of the measure mufotaEilN, (O,) is used by poetic license for muXotaAq, (Ṣ, O,) as Sb says; (Ṣ;) for the poet, requiring to make the last letter but one movent, makes it so by the original vowel. (O.)

1. XaAkatoniI AlX-awokapu, (Aṣ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,*) aor. taXuwkuniI, (Aṣ, Ṣ, O,) inf. n. XawokN, (TA,) The thorn entered into [or pierced me, or] my body or person. (Aṣ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.*) And XAkt UiSobaEahu It (a thorn) entered into [or pierced] his finger. (TA.) And XaAkatoniI AlX-awokapu, (Ḳ,) aor. as above, (TA,) The thorn hurt me, or wounded me; syn. OaSaAbatoniI. (Ḳ, TA.) And XaAkaniI AlX-awoku, aor. yaXuwkuniI, The thorns hurt, or wounded, (OaSaAba,) my skin. (Mṣb.) [Hence,] laA yaXuwkuka min-iI XawokapN↓ ‡ No harm, or hurt, shall ensue to thee from me. (TA.)

Xukotuhu, aor. OaXuwkuhu, [I pierced him with a thorn;] I made a thorn to enter into his body or person; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also OaXakotuhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UiXaAkapN: (TA:) the former verb from Ks; (T, Ṣ, O;) as though he made it to be doubly trans. [meaning that XawokapF is to be understood]. (Az, TA.) And maA OaXaAkahu↓ XawokapF [and maA XaAkahu biXawokapK as is meant by its being added] walaA XaAkahu bihaA He did not hurt him with a thorn; (Ḳ,* TA;) as expl. by IF: (TA:) and OaXakotuhu↓ I hurt him with thorns: (TA:) or Xaw-akotuhu↓ biAlX-awoki and OaXakotuhu↓ bihi I hurt him, or wounded him, with thorns, or the thorns. (Mṣb.)

Accord. to IAạr, (TA,) XAk AlX-awokapa, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, AlX-awokapu,]) aor. yaXaAkuhaA, (TA,) signifies xaAlaTahaA [app. meaning He pierced (lit. mixed or blended) himself with the thorn: unless Xawokap be improperly used in this instance, by poetic license, as a coll. gen. n., as seems to be implied in the Ṣ and O by an explanation of a verse cited-voce naqaXa, q. v., in which case the meaning is, he entered among the thorns]. (Ḳ, TA.)
[It is also said that] XAk AlX-awokapa, aor. yaXaAkuhaA, inf. n. XawokN, signifies He (a man) extracted the thorn from his foot. (MA.)
Xiyka, aor. yuXaAku, inf. n. XawokN, He (a man) was, or became, pierced by a thorn. (Ṣ, O.)

XaAka, (Ḳ,) or [first pers.] Xikotu, (Ṣ, O,) aor. yaXaAku, (Ḳ, and the like in the Ṣ and O,) inf. n. XaAkapN and XiykapN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) He, (Ḳ,) or I, (Ṣ, O,) fell, or lighted, among thorns: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ: [whence, accord. to the Ṣ and O, the verse above referred to, voce naqaXa:]) and Xikotu AlX-awoka, aor. OaXaAkuhu, I fell, or lighted, among the thorns: (Ḳ:) accord. to IB, Xikotu, aor. OaXaAku, is originally Xawikotu. (TA.)

XAkt AlX-ajarapu, aor. taXaAku, inf. n. XawokN; and AXAkt↓; (Mṣb;) or Xaw-akat↓, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. taXowiykN; in some of the copies of the Ḳ Xawikat; (TA; [in the CK, Xawakat;]) and OaXowakat↓; (Ḳ;) The tree was thorny, or prickly; abounded with thorns, or prickles: (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) [and] OaXowakat↓ said of a palm-tree has the like signification. (Ṣ, O.)

[Hence,] XAk laHoyaA AlbaEiyri † The two jaws of the camel put forth his canine teeth; (Ṣ O;) as also Xw-k↓, (Ṣ, O,) inf. n. taXowiykN: (Ṣ:) or the phrase with the latter verb means The camel's canine teeth became long. (Ḳ.)

And XAk vadoIu AljaAriyapi † The breast of the girl was ready to swell, or become protuberant or prominent; as also Xw-k↓, inf. n. taXowiykN; (Ṣ;) and, accord. to Z, Xawika, like fariHa: (TA:)
or Xw-k↓ vadoyuhaA signifies ‡ her breast became pointed in its extremity, (IDrd, O, Ḳ, TA,) and its protrusion appeared. (IDrd, O, TA.)

XAk Alr-ajulu, aor. yaXaAk, inf. n. XawokN, ‡ The man exhibited his Xawokap [i. e. vehemence of might or strength, or of valour or prowess,, &c.], and his sharpness. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) [And The man was completely armed; (as though meaning he bristled with arms;) for] the inf. n. XawokN signifies a man's being completely armed. (KL.)
And Xiyka ‡ He was, or became, affected with the disease termed Xawokap [q. v.]. (Ḳ, TA.)
2. Xaw-akotuhu biAlX-awoki: see 1, former half.
Xw-k AlHaAYiTa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taXowiykN, (TA,) He put thorns upon the wall. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also 1, latter half, in four places.

Xw-k Alz-aroEu ‡ The seed-produce, or corn, became white, before its spreading: (Ḳ:) or came forth [pointed,] without forking, or shooting forth into separate stalks, (Had-ada,) and became white, before its spreading; as also OaXowaka↓: (TA:) [or began to come forth: see muXaw-ikN.]
Xw-k naAbu AlbaEiyri † [The canine tooth of the camel grew forth]. (TA.)

Xw-k riyXu Alfaroxi, (IDrd, O,) and XaAribu AlgulaAmi, (IDrd, O, Ḳ,) ‡ The feathers of the young bird, (IDrd, O,) and the mustache of the young man, became rough to the feel. (IDrd, O, Ḳ, TA.)
