And Xw-k Alfaroxu † The young bird put forth the heads of its feathers: (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA:) in [some of the copies of] the Ṣ and A, Xw-k Alfaroju, thus with j, expl. by Oanobata. (TA.) And Xw-k Alr-aOosu baEoda AlHaloqi ‡ The head put forth its hair after the shaving. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
4. as a trans. verb: see 1, former half, in four places:
as intrans.: see 1, latter half, in three places: and see also 2.
5. taXaw-ukN The having thorns; expl. by baA xaArN Xudano. (KL.)

XawokN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) of a tree, (Mṣb,) or of a plant, (TA,) Thorns, prickles, or spines; (PṢ, TḲ;) the kind of thing that is slender [or pointed] and hard in the head; (TA;) well known: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) n. un. with p {XawokapN}. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) [Hence the saying,] laA yaXuwkuka min-iI XawokapN: see 1, near the beginning. [The Xawok of the palm-tree are commonly called sul-aMCN.] Xawoku Als-unobuli [The sharp prickles that compose the awn, or beard, of the ear of corn]. (AḤn, TA in art. bhm.)
[For other significations of XawokapN, see this word below.]
XawikN and its fem. with p {XawikapN}: see XaAYikN, in three places.
XawokapN n. un. of XawokN [q. v.]. (Ṣ, &c.) [Hence various meanings here following; all of which seem to be tropical.]

OaSaAbatohumo Xawokapu AlqanaA [app. † The point of the spear hit, hurt, or wounded, them]. (TA. [There expl. only by the words whI Xbh AlAsnp, i. e. wahiIa Xibohu AlOasin-api; as though relating to a pl. number.])
jaAWuwA biAlX-awokapi waAlX-ajarapi ‡ They came with multitude [app. meaning of armed men]. (TA.)
Xawokapu AlEaqorabi † The sting of the scorpion. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

Xawokapu AlHaAYiki ‡ The weaver's implement with which he makes the warp and the woof even: (Ṣ, O, TA:) i. e., (TA,) AlX-awokapu signifies AlS-iySiyapu, (O, Ḳ, in the CK AlS-iySapu,) as having this meaning:
and also as meaning ‡ The spur of the cock. (O, TA.)

And AlX-awokapu, (Lth, O,) or Xawokapu Alkat-aAni, (Ḳ, TA,) † A piece of clay, (Lth, O, Ḳ, TA,) in a moist state, (Ḳ, TA,) made into a round form, and having its upper part pressed so that it becomes expanded, then (Lth, O, TA) prickles of the palm-tree are stuck into it, (Lth, O, Ḳ, TA,) and it dries; (Ḳ, TA;) used for clearing [or combing] flax therewith: (Lth, O, Ḳ, TA:) mentioned by Az: and also called XuwaAkapu↓ Alkat-aAni. (TA.)

XawokapN also signifies ‡ A weapon, or weapons; syn. silaAHN; (Ḳ, TA, and Ḥam p. 526;) as in the phrase fulaAnN cuw XuwokapK ‡ [Such a one is a possessor of a weapon or weapons; though this admits of another rendering, as will be shown by what follows]: (TA:) or ‡ sharpness thereof: (Ḳ, TA:) or † the point, or edge, in a weapon. (Ṣ, O.)

And † Vehemence of might or strength, or of valour or prowess, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) in respect of fighting: (Ḳ, TA:) and † vehemence of encounter: and † sharpness: (TA:) and † the infliction of havock, or vehement slaughter or wounding, syn. nikaAyapN, [app. meaning effectiveness therein,] among the enemy: (Ḳ, TA:) and † strength in weapons [app. meaning in the use thereof]: (Mṣb:) and [simply] † strength, or might. (Ḥam p. 526.) One says, lahumo XawokapN fiI AlHarobi † [They have vehemence of might or strength, or of valour or prowess, in war]: and huwa cuw XawokapK fiI AlEaduw-i † [He has effectiveness in the infliction of havock among the enemy]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., halum-a UilaI jihaAdK laA Xawokapa fiyhi † [Come to a war in the cause of religion wherein is no vehemence of might or strength,, &c.]; meaning the pilgrimage. (TA.)

Also ‡ A certain disease, (IDrd, O, Ḳ, TA,) well known; (Ḳ;) namely, plague, or pestilence; syn. TaAEuwn. (IDrd, O.) And † A redness that arises (A,* O, Ḳ) upon the body (Ḳ) or upon the face, and part of the body, and is [said to be] allayed by means of charms, or spells: (O:) because the sting of the scorpion, which is thus called, when it strikes a man, mostly produces redness. (A, TA.)
[In one instance, in the CK, XawokapN is erroneously put for XawikapN, as an epithet applied to a tree.]

XawokaMCu, applied to a [garment such as is called] burodap, (Ṣ, O,) or to a [garment or dress such as is called] Hul-ap, (A, O, Ḳ,) ‡ Rough to the feel, because new: (AO, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) but Aṣ said, “I know not what it is.” (O, L, TA.)
XaAkiI Als-ilaAHi and XaAkK fiI AlslAHi: see XaAYikN, in three places.
XuwaAkapu Alkat-aAni: see XawokapN.
XuwayokapN, like juhayonap [in measure], accord. to the Ḳ, A certain species of camels; and thus in the Moḥeeṭ and the Moḥkam: but the correct word is that which here follows. (TA.)

UibilN Xuwayokiy-apN, (Ṣ, O, TA,) thus [says Ṣgh] I have seen the latter word in a verse in the Deewán of Dhu-r-Rummeh in the handwriting of Skr, with a distinct sheddeh to the [latter] I, but in the handwriting of El-Bujeyrimee without a sheddeh; (O, TA;) † Camels whose canine teeth have grown forth: (Ṣ,* O, TA:) some say that it is XuwayokiYap, with C, and is for XuwayoqiYap [q. v.], the q being changed into k. (O, TA.)

XajarN XaAYikN (Ṣ, O) and XawikN↓ and XaAkN↓ (O) Trees having thorns; (Ṣ, O;*) and XajarapN muXiykapN↓ a tree having thorns: (TA:) [or thorny; having many thorns; for] XajarapN XaAkapN↓ signifies a thorny tree, or a tree having many thorns, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) accord. to ISk; (Ṣ, O;) as also Xjrp XawikapN↓ [in the CK (erroneously) XawokapN] and XaAYikapN (Ḳ, TA) and muXowikapN↓. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,* TA.) And OaroDN XaAkapN↓ A thorny land, or a land in which are many thorns: (Ḳ, TA:) and [in like manner] OaroDN muXowikapN↓ (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) a thorny land, or a land abounding with thorns; (O;) a land in which are the [thorny trees called] siHaMC and qataAd and haraAs. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

XaAYiku Als-ilaAHi (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XaAku↓ AlslAHi, (Fr, Ḳ, TA,) with refa to the k, (TA,) [in the CK, erroneously, XAki,] and Xawiku↓ AlslAHi, (Ḳ,) which is of the dial. of El-Yemen, (TA,) and XaAkiI↓ AlslAHi, (Fr, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) this last formed by transposition from the first, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, TA,) or, as Fr says, XaAkiI AlslAHi and XaAku AlslAHi are like jurufo haArK and haArN, (TA,) ‡ A man who exhibits his Xawokap [i. e. vehemence of might or strength, or of valour or prowess,, &c.], and his sharpness: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) or a man whose weapon is sharp, or whose weapons are sharp: (Ḳ, TA:) or XaAkiI↓ AlslAHi, as some explain it, a man whose spear-head and arrow-head and the like are sharp: (TA:) [or all may be rendered bristling with arms:] and accord. to AZ, one says XaAkK↓ fiI Als-ilaAHi and XaAYikN. (TA.)
maXuwkN Affected with the disease, (Ḳ,* TA,) or redness, (O, Ḳ,*) termed XawokapN; (O, Ḳ, TA;) applied to a man. (O.)
muXowikN: see its fem. voce XaAYikN, in two places.
muXiykN: see its fem. voce XaAYikN.
zaroEN muXaw-ikN Seed-produce of which the first portion has come forth. (A, TA. [See also 2.])

hom.sense:
1. XaAla, [aor. yaXuwlu,] (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XuwolN, (TḲ,) It rose; or became raised, or elevated; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) said, in this sense, of a she-camel's tail; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) [and in like manner of a star; (see Ḥam p. 239;)] and AnXAl↓ signifies the same, (O, Ḳ,)
said of a stone, (Ḳ,) and so AnXAlt said of a jar (jar-ap); (Ṣ, O;) and likewise AXtAl↓. (TA.)

[Hence,] XAl AlmiyozaAnu The balance had one of its two scales higher than the other, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, TA,) by reason of its lightness. (Mṣb.) Whence the saying, XAl miyzaAnu fulaAnK, aor. yaXuwlu, inf. n. XawalaAnN, meaning ‡ Such a one was overcome in contending with another for superiority in glory or the like. (TA.)
And XAlt Alqirobapu, and XAl Alz-iq-u, The legs of the water-skin, and of the skin for wine, &c., became raised, or elevated, on the occasion of its being filled, or inflated. (TA.)
And XaAla labanuhaA [meaning Her milk became drawn up, or withdrawn,] is said of a camel. (TA.)

One says also, XAlt naEaAmatuhu, meaning † He was, or became, flurried, agitated, or excited, (xaf-a,) and angry, and then became calm. (Ḳ.) And XAlt naEaAmatuhumo † Their might (Eiz-uhumo) departed: (O, Ḳ:) or their abodes became clear of them, as though lightened of them, (xaf-ato manaAziluhumo minohumo, Ḳ, TA,) and they went away: (TA:) or their expression of opinion was, or became, discordant: (tafar-aqato kalimatuhumo: Ḳ:) or they died: and they became scattered, or dispersed; as though there remained not of them save a remnant; [see XawolN;] Aln-aEaAmapu signifying AljamaAEapu: (TA:) or they became irresolute, by reason of fear, and fled: (Mṣb:) or they were frightened, and fled. (M in art. rOl.) [See also naEaAmapN: and see a verse cited voce Uim-aA.]

Xulotu bihi, and Xulotuhu; (Mṣb;) and OaXalotuhu↓; (O, Mṣb;) or Xulotu biAljar-api, for which one should not say Xilotu [which the vulgar say in the present day, making it trans. by itself]; (Ṣ, O;) and OaXalotuhaA↓; (Ṣ;) or XAl biAlHajari; and AXAlhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UiXaAlapN; (TA;) and XAwlhu↓; (Ḳ;) aor. of the first as above, inf. n. XawolN; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb;) I raised, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) or he raised, (Ḳ,) it, (O, Mṣb,) namely, a thing, (O,) or the jar, (Ṣ, O,) or the stone. (Ḳ.) And XAlt bicanabihaA, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. XawolN (O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XawalaAnN; (O, Ḳ;) and AXAlthu↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiXaAlapN; and AstXAlthu↓; (TA;) She (a camel) raised her tail, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) having become pregnant. (Mṣb. [See XaAYilN: and see also 2.]) And XAlt bicanabihaA It (a scorpion) raised its tail. (TA.) And XAl yadahu He raised his arm or hand; like XAl bihaA. (Mṣb.) And AXAl↓ biDaboEihi He raised his DaboE [generally expl. as meaning the upper half of the arm, from the elbow to the shoulder-blade]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. Xw-lt, said of a she-camel, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) She became such as is termed XaAYilap: (Ṣ, O, TA: [in one of my copies of the Ṣ, SaAra XawolFA is erroneously put for SaArato XaAYilapF:]) or her supplies of milk dried up; (jaf-ato OalobaAnuhaA; Ḳ, TA; [but perhaps the right reading is xaf-ato, meaning became scanty; for SM adds,]) and became little in quantity. (TA.) And Xw-lt AlUibilu The camels became in such a state that their bellies [were drawn up as though they] reached their backs: (Ḳ, TA:) or became such as to have [only] a Xawol [or small quantity remaining] of milk: like as one says, (O, TA,) Xw-lt AlmazaAdapu The mzAdp [or leathern water-bag] had little water remaining in it: (O, Ḳ, TA:) one should not say XaAlat. (TA.)

[Hence, app.,] taXowiylN of the cakar signifies Its being in a relaxed state on the occasion of mujaAmaEap. (O, Ḳ.) And Xw-l said of a horse means, like raf-aDa, He put forth his veretrum without being vigorously lustful. (TA in art. rfD.)

Xw-l said of a garob [or large bucket], Its water became little in quantity. (O, Ḳ.) Said of a she-camel's milk, It became deficient: (Ḳ, TA:) and it became withdrawn. (TA.) And said of water, It became little in quantity. (Ḳ.)

In the following saying, (Ṣ, TA,) of Abu-n-Nejm, (TA,)
Hat-aI UicaA maA AlEiXoru EanohaA Xaw-alaA
the poet means, cahaba and taSar-ama [i. e. Until, when the coming to water on the tenth day after the next preceding period of abstinence ceased from her or them... referring to a camel or to camels]. (Ṣ, TA.)
Xw-l fiI AlmazaAdapi He left somewhat remaining (OaboqaI XawolFA) of water in the mzAdp [or leathern water-bag]. (Ḳ,* TA.)
3. XAwlhu: see 1, latter half.
Also, and XAwl bihi, and XAwl bihi fiI AlT-iEaAni, [inf. n. muXaAwalapN,] He contended with him in thrusting [with the spear]. (TA.) See also 6.
And XAwl AlfaHolu AlfaHola The stallion [camel] fought with, or combated, the stallion [camel]. (Ḥam p. 660.)
4: see 1, latter half, in five places.

6. tXAwlwA They reached, or smote, one another, (tanaAwala baEoDuhumo baEoDFA,) in fight, with the spears: and muXaAwalapN↓ has a similar signification [to taXaAwulN, as shown above by an explanation of its verb, 3]. (AZ, Ṣ, O.)
7: see 1, first sentence.
8: see 1, first sentence.
AXtAl lahu ‡ He opposed himself to him, and reviled him. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
10: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

hom.sense: XaAlN A certain fish of the sea, or of great rivers (samakapN baHoriy-apN): (TA:) [in Egypt this name is applied to a fish of the genus silurus, found in the Nile: it is well described by Sonnini, in p. 407 of the 4to Engl. ed. of his Travels in Upper and Lower Egypt.]
XawolN: see XaAYilapN, voce XaAYilN:
and XawolapN.

Also Somewhat remaining of water in the skin and in the bucket, (Ḳ,) and of milk in the udder: (TA:) and a small quantity of water (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) in the bottom of the water-skin (Ṣ, O, TA) and of the leathern water-bag: (TA:) [in the CK, AlmAlu Alqaliylu is erroneously put for AlmaMCu Alqaliylu:] pl. OaXowaAlN. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) It is said in a prov.,
maA Dar-a naAbFA XawoluhaA AlmuEal-aqu , (Meyd, TA,) i. e. Her small quantity of water [that is hung upon her does not harm an aged she-camel]: or naAbiI [my aged she-camel]: applied to the case of carrying that which will not harm thee if it be with thee, and will be useful to thee if thou be in want of it: (Meyd:) or applied to him who is enjoined to take the prudent course and to supply himself with travelling-provision though he be going to such provision. (TA.)
And Light, active, or agile; syn. xafiyfN: (Ḳ:) so in the M. (TA.) [See also the next paragraph.]

entry.sense: XawilN One that raises a thing. (TA. [See also XaAYilN.])

And A man light, active, or agile, (xafiyfN,) in work, and in service, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and in respect of what is wanted; and quick: (Ḳ:) thus in a verse of El-Aạshà: (O, TA:) [but accord. to the reading of AO of that verse, it is XuwulN↓, which has a similar, but intensive, meaning. (De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., 2nd ed., ii. 484-5.) See also what next follows.]
XuwalN, like SuradN [in measure], One who aids, or assists, much or well; syn. naSuwrN. (O, TA.) [See also what next precedes.]
XuwulN: see XawilN.

hom.sense: XawolapN The part that it raises of the tail of the scorpion; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and so XawolN↓: (Ḥam p. 649:) or, accord. to Sh, its sting, with which it strikes. (TA.)

[Hence,] AlX-awolapu † Two bright stars, near together, [λ and ν,] (Ṣ, O,) in the end of the tail of Scorpio, (Ḳzw,) which are one of the Mansions of the Moon, (Ṣ, O, Ḳzw,) namely, the Nineteenth Mansion; (Ḳzw;) also called Humapu AlEaqorabi. (Ṣ, O.) [See manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.]
And Xawolapu is a proper name for The scorpion; (O, TA;) [and] so Xaw-aAlapu↓. (Ḳ, TA.)

Also A foolish, or stupid, woman. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.) Xawolapu was the name of A certain foolish female slave, belonging to [the tribe of] 'Adwán, and she used to give advice to her masters, and it resulted in evil to them; whence the saying, Oanota Xawolapu Aln-aASiHapu [Thou art Showleh the giver of advice]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
Also the name of The mare of Zeyd-el-Fawáris Ed-Ḍabbee. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: XuwayolaMCu A certain plant, (AḤn, O, Ḳ,) mentioned, but not described, by Aṣ; of the kind termed EuXob, growing in plain, or soft, land, (AḤn, O,) used as a medicament, (AḤn, O, Ḳ,) and well known: (AḤn, O:) [Ṣgh says,] I have seen it: it is dust-coloured, spreads upon the ground, has no thorns, and the cattle eagerly desire it: (O:) it is called (O, Ḳ) sometimes, (Ḳ,) by some of the people of El-'Irák, (O,) Xuw-ayolN↓, like fub-ayoTN [in measure]. (O, Ḳ.)
Xaw-aAlN The tail of the scorpion. (TA. [So called because often raised.])

Also, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and sometimes it is called AlX-aw-aAlu, (Mṣb,) The month of the festival of the breaking of the fast; (Mṣb, Ḳ;*) the month next after ramaDaAn; (TA;) the first of the months of the pilgrimage; (Ṣ, O;) [the tenth month of the lunar year:] as some assert, (IDrd, O,) so called because [when first thus named] it coincided with the season when the she-camels [being seven or eight months gone with young] raised their tails: (IDrd, O, Mṣb, TA:) [for the camels generally couple in winter:] or because of their milk becoming then withdrawn; such being the case with the camels in the time of vehement heat and of the coming to an end of the juicy fresh herbage: [see a table of the months voce zamanN:] the Arabs used to regard the making of marriage-contracts in this month as of evil omen; and to say that the woman [then] married would resist him who married her, like as the she-camel resists the stallion and raises her tail; but the Prophet abolished their thus auguring, and he married ʼÁïsheh in this month: (TA:) the pl. is Xaw-aAlaAtN and XawaAwiylu (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XawaAwilu, this last formed by rejecting the augmentative letter [in the second]. (TA.)
Xuw-ayolN: see XuwayolaMCu.

Xaw-aAlapN [not (as is implied in the Ḳ) Xaw-aAlapu] A certain bird, (AḤát, O, Ḳ,) a dux-alap [n. un. of dux-alN q. v.], of a dusky colour, which, when it alights upon a stone or a tree, moves up and down its tail like as does the camel; so called because it raises its tail; and in its belly and its hinder part is somewhat of redness. (AḤát, O, TA.)
See also XawolapN.
[Hence, as being likened to the scorpion, whence also the phrase Uin-ahu latadib-u EaqaAribuhu,] AimoraOapN Xaw-aAlapN † A woman wont to calumniate. (Ḳ.)

XaAYilN A she-camel raising her tail, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) having conceived, (Mṣb,) or by reason of having conceived, and having no milk whatever: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or a she-camel that has conceived, and raises her tail to the stallion as a sign of her having conceived, raising her head therewith, and elevating her nose: (Az, TA:) the word is without p because it is an epithet of peculiar application [to a female]: (Mṣb:) or it is without p anomalously; for the male also raises his tail: (ISd, TA:) the pl. is Xuw-alN (Az, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Xuy-alN and Xiy-alN and Xuw-aAlN. (Ḳ.) Also, with p {XaAYilapN}, applied to a mare, as meaning Raising the tail. (TA.)

And XaAYilapN, which is anomalously with p because it is an epithet denoting an attribute not shared with the female by the male, (ISd, TA,) A she-camel that has passed seven months, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or eight, (Ṣ, O,) since the period of her bringing forth, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or of her becoming pregnant, (Ḳ,) and whose milk has dried up, (jaf-a labanuhaA, Ḳ, and so in a copy of the Ṣ,) or whose milk has become scanty, (xaf-a labanuhaA, O, and so in another copy of the Ṣ,) and her udder drawn up, (Ṣ, O,) there remaining in her udder no more than a Xawol, a third of the quantity of the contents thereof when her bringing forth was recent: (TA:) she-camels in this case are termed XawolN↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) an anomalous pl., (Ḳ,) [or rather a quasi-pl. n.,] expl. by some as applied to she-camels whose milk has become deficient, which is the case when their young are weaned at the period of the [auroral] rising of suhayol [or Canopus, a period which commenced, in Central Arabia, about the beginning of the era of the Flight, on the 4th of August, O. Ṣ.], and they cease not to be thus termed until the stallion is sent among them; (TA;) the pl. pl. [or pl. of XawolN] is OaXowaAlN; (Ḳ;) and XawaAYilu is a pl. of XaAYilapN meaning [as expl. above, or] a she-camel whose milk has become withdrawn. (TA.)
XaAYilN is also applied to Anything that is raised, or drawn up, or withdrawn. (TA.)
XawoXalaMCu Initus; syn. nayokN: said to be an Abyssinian word. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
miXowalN A small minojal [or reaping-hook: in the CK, erroneously, munoxul]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.)
muXiylN act. part. n. of 4. See an ex. in a verse cited voce xaAfiD; cited also in the present art. in the Ṣ and O.
miXowalapN is said by Yz to signify A certain thing with which one plays. (O, TA.)
miXowaAlN A stone that is raised. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)

1. XaAha wajohuhu, aor. yaXuwhu; (Ḳ;) and XaAhati Alwujuwhu, aor. taXuwhu; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) inf. n. XawohN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and XawohapN, (Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (TA;) and Xawiha wajohuhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XawahN; (TA;) His face was, (Ḳ,) and the faces were, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) foul, unseemly, or ugly. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And Xawiha, (Mṣb,) and Xawihato, (Mgh,) inf. n. XawahN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) He, (a man, Mṣb,) and she, (a woman, Mgh,) was, or became, foul, unseemly, or ugly, (Mgh, Mṣb,) in face, (Mgh,) or in make. (Mṣb.)
XawahN is also syn. with HusonN [app. as an inf. n., of which the verb is Xawiha signifying He was, or became, beautiful: thus having two contr. meanings]. (TA.)

Also, (Ḳ,) as an inf. n., (TḲ,) The neck's being long, (Ḳ, TA,) and high, and the head's overtopping; whence OaXowahu↓ applied to a horse: (TA:) and the neck's being short: thus [again] having two contr. meanings: (Ḳ:) one says, [app. of a horse,] Xawihato Eunuquhu His neck was long [&c.]: and his neck was short: (TḲ:) or XawahN said of the neck [of a horse] signifies the being extended: and said of the Xidoq [or side of the mouth], the being wide, (JK. [It probably signifies any of the attributes denoted by the epithet OaXowahu, q. v.])
Also, [and app. in this sense likewise an inf. n. of which the verb is Xawiha,] The being quick to smite with the [evil] eye. (Ṣ.)

And one says, XaAha fulaAnFA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XawohN, (TA,) He smote such a one with the [evil] eye; (Ḳ, TA;) as also AXAhhu↓: (TA in art. Xhw:) and in like manner, maAlahu [his cattle, or property]: (Lḥ, TA:) or XawohN signifies the smiting vehemently therewith. (TA.) And laA tuXaw-iho↓ EalaI-a Smite not thou me with an [evil] eye: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to Abu-l-Mekárim this means say not, How eloquent art thou! (Az, TA,) or say not, How beautiful art thou! (ISk, Ṣ,) and so doing smite me with the [evil] eye, or with an [evil] eye. (ISk, Az, Ṣ, TA.) tXw-h↓ signifies He practised artifice to smite people with the evil eye. (JK.) And one says, huwa yataXaw-ahu↓ OamowaAla Aln-aAsi liyuSiybahaA biAlEayoni i. e. He raises his look towards the cattle, or possessions, of the people to smite them with the [evil] eye. (TA.) [See also 1 in art. Xyh.]
Also, He frightened, or terrified, such a one. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)
And He envied such a one. (Ḳ.)
And XaAhato nafosuhu UilaI kacaA His desire became raised towards such a thing. (AA, Ḳ.)

2. Xw-hhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taXowiyhN, (TA,) He (God) rendered foul, unseemly, or ugly, his face: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and it, i. e. the conformation of the face. (TA, from a verse of El-Hotei-ah.) And Xaw-ahotu Alwujuwha I rendered foul, unseemly, or ugly, the faces. (Mṣb.)
And Xaw-aha Qll-ehu Huluwqakumo God rendered, or may God render, wide your throats, or fauces. (TA.)
laA tuXaw-iho EalaI-a: see 1, latter half.
Xw-h biyadihi He (a man) made a sign with his arm, or hand. (JK.)
4. AXAhhu: see 1.

hom.sense: 5. tXw-h lahu He became altered in countenance to him, so as to be not known by him, (syn. tanak-ara, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and assumed various appearances. (Ṣ.)
See also 1, in two places, near the end.
tXw-h XaApF He hunted a XAp [app. here meaning a wild bull, as seems to be indicated by the context in the Ṣ]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: XaMCN: see the next paragraph.

XaApN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) originally XaAhapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) A sheep, or goat; [each and either, but more commonly the former; see an instance voce SuwfN;] i. e. one of what are termed ganam; (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Ḳ;) applied to the male and to the female; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) so that one says of the male, hecaA XaApN, (Mṣb,) which is said by Kh to be like the phrase hecaA raHomapN mino rab-iI; (Sb, TA;) and of the female, hecihi XaApN; and XaApN cakarN and XaApN OunovaI: (Mṣb:) or it may be [one] of sheep, and of goats, and of gazelles or antelopes, and of the bovine kind [app. of the wild bovine kind i. e. of bovine antelopes], and of ostriches, and of wild asses; (Ḳ;) it is applied to a wild bull by Tarafeh, in his saying,
kasaAmiEataIo XaApK biHawomala muforadi ; (Ṣ) i. e. Like the two ears of a wild bull, in Howmal, solitary; the poet likening thereto the ears of a she-camel in respect of sharpness and erectness; (EM p. 76;) and likewise by Lebeed, and by El-Farezdaḳ: (IB, TA:) and it is also applied to [a wild cow; (though said in the Ḳ in art. XwI to signify the wild bull, specially the male;) and hence, as being likened thereto,] ‡ a woman; (Ḳ, TA;) thus by El-Aạshà; and thus also by Antarah, in his saying,
yaA XaApa maA qanaSK limano Hal-ato lahu
Harumato EalaI-a walayotahaA lamo taHorumi (TA) O XAp [i. e. wild cow] of the chase (mA being redundant) for him to whom she is lawful: she has become forbidden to me, and would that she were not forbidden: (EM p. 246:)
pl. XaMCN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) originally XaAhN, (Ḳ,) used when they are many in number, (Ṣ,) [but this is properly termed a coll. gen. n.,] and XiyaAhN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with h, which is used of a number from three to ten [inclusive], for more than which it is with t [meaning p, i. e. XaApN, agreeably with a general rule], (Ṣ,) and XiwaAhN, [the original of XiyaAhN,] (Ḳ,) and XawiI-N↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, XawFI,]) which is pl. of XaMCN, (Ṣ, TA,) or rather a quasi-pl. n., originally XawiyhN, the h being changed into I like as it is in ciI for ciho, (TA,) and OaXaAwihu, (Ḳ,) and XayohN↓, (so in copies of the Ḳ, [in the TA said to be like EinabN, which is a mistake, (perhaps for EayonN,) for it is there said to be a quasi-pl. n., which could not be said if it were XiyahN,]) and XiyhN↓, (CK, [but this, which is another quasi-pl. n., is not in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ nor in the TA,]) and Xay-ihN↓, (Ḳ,) originally XayowihN, but this, also, is a quasi-pl. n., (TA,) and XiyapN↓ also is syn. with XaMCN: (IAạr, Ḳ in art. XwI:) it has not a pl. formed with A and t, [i. e. it has not for a pl. XaAMtN,] whether it be used as a gen. n. or as a proper name: (TA:) the dim. is XuwayohapN↓. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) The sing. is also used in the sense of the pl., in the saying fulaAnN kaviyru AlX-aApi waAlbaEiyri [Such a one is possessor of a large number of sheep or goats, and of camels], because the article Al denotes the genus. (Ṣ.) And it is said in a trad. faOamara lahaA biXiyaAhi ganamK [And he ordered that sheep or goats should be given to her]: XyAh being prefixed to gnm, governing it in the gen. case, for the sake of distinction; because the Arabs [sometimes] call an animal of the wild bovine kind XAp. (IAth, TA.)

AlX-aApu is also the name of † Certain small stars (Ḳ in art. XwI) between AlqrHh [or Alfrjp, thus in the work of Ḳzw, in his descr. of Cepheus, and there said to be the star in the breast of Cepheus,] and AljadoIu [i. e. the pole-star]; (TA in that art.;) [the same that are described by Ḳzw as certain small stars, called by the Arabs AlOagonaAmu, between the legs of Cepheus and the star AljadoIu.]
XaAhu AlbaSari, and XaAhiI AlbaSari: see XaAYihN.

hom.sense: XawahN an inf. n., of Xawiha. (Mgh, Mṣb, TA. [See 1, in several places.])
Also a subst. meaning Unluckiness, or inauspiciousness, of a woman. (TA.)

entry.sense: XayohN and XiyhN and XiyapN: see XaApN.

XuwhapN Remoteness: (Ḳ, TA:) and so buwhapN: one says, in dispraise, XuwhapF lahu wabuwhapF [i. e. buEodFA lahu, lit. Remoteness to him! meaning may God alienate him or estrange him, from good, or prosperity! or, curse him!]. (TA.)
XawiI-N, originally XawiyhN: see XaApN.
XuwayohapN dim. of XaApN, q. v. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
XaAYihN Envying: pl. Xuw-ahN: (Aṣ, Lḥ, TA:) or the latter signifies persons practising artifice to smite men with the [evil] eye. (JK.)

And XaAYihu AlbaSari, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and XaAhu↓ AlbaSari, (JK, Ḳ,) and XaAhiI AlbaSari, (JK, TA, and Ṣ and Ḳ in art. Xhw,) the last formed by transposition from the first, (Ṣ in art. Xhw,) A man sharp of sight. (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
XaAYiI-N: see the next paragraph.
XaAhiI-N: see the next paragraph.

XaAwiI-N and XaAhiI-N↓ A man possessing XaMC [meaning sheep or goats or both]: (Ḳ:) the former is the rel. n. of XaMCN; and the latter, that of XaApN: but used as a proper name of a man, it is XaAYiI-N↓, and, if you will, XaAwiI-N. (Ṣ, TA.*)

hom.sense: Xay-ihN: see the next paragraph:
and see XaApN.

entry.sense: OaXowahu, applied to a man, (Mṣb,) Foul, unseemly, or ugly, (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in face, (JK, Ḳ,) or in aspect, (Mṣb,) and, as also Xay-ihN↓, of which the pl. is Xay-ihuwna, in make: (JK:) fem. XawohaMCu: (JK, Mgh, Mṣb:) and pl. XuwhN. (Mṣb.) Any created thing incongruous in its several parts; as also muXaw-ahN↓. (TA.) And the fem., A woman frowning, or morose, in face; (Ḳ,* TA;) foul, unseemly, or ugly, in make: (TA:) and also beautiful, goodly, or comely; (Ḳ,* TA;) that excites admiration and approval by her beauty: (TA:) thus having two contr. meanings. (Ḳ, TA.) Also, the fem., Unlucky, or inauspicious. (Ḳ.)

And the masc. applied to a man, (Lth, Ṣ, TA,) and the fem. applied to a woman, (Lth, TA,) That smites quickly with the [evil] eye: (Lth, Ṣ, TA:) or that smites people effectually with his, and her, [evil] eye. (TA.) And OaXowahu AlEayon Having an evil eye. (Fr, TA in art. Xzr.)

The fem. is also applied to a mare, (JK, T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) as an epithet of commendation, but not the masc. to a horse, meaning, it is said, Wide in the XidoqaAni [or two sides of the mouth]: (Ṣ:) or long in the head, and wide in the nostrils: (JK:) or tall, and such as excites admiration and approval by her beauty or excellence: (Ḳ,* TA:) or exceedingly wide in the XidoqaAni [or two sides of the mouth] and the nostrils: (Ḳ, TA:) or, as some say, wide in the mouth: (TA:) and small in the mouth: thus having two contr. meanings: (Ḳ, TA:) or sharpsighted: (T, TA:) or sharp in spirit: (TA:) see also 1.
Also, the masc., Proud, and self-conceited. (Ḳ.)
And xuTobapN XawohaMCu [An oration from the pulpit] in which a blessing is not invoked on the Prophet. (TA.)
OaroDN maXaAhapN A land in which are XaMC; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ;) like as one says OaroDN maOobalapN: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ:) or in which are many thereof. (Ḳ.)
muXaw-ahN Rendered foul, unseemly, or ugly, in face, by God: (TA:) or foul,, &c., in shape. (Ḳ.) See also OaXowahu, second sentence.
And Bad in intellect. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. XawaI All-aHoma, (aor. _i {yaXowiIu} TA,) inf. n. XaI-N, (Ṣ, MA, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He roasted, broiled, or fried, the flesh-meat; (MA, KL,* PṢ;) and AXwAhu↓ signifies the same; as also AXtwAhu↓; (Mṣb, TA;) or this last, (TA,) or AXtwI [alone], (Ṣ, MA,) signifies he prepared, or prepared for himself, (Ṣ, MA,* TA,) XiwaMC, (Ṣ, TA,*) or roasted, broiled, or fried, flesh-meat. (MA.)
And XawaI AlmaMCa, (IAạr, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (TA,) He heated the water. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
[And accord. to Freytag, XawaI signifies also He cut off from (mn) roasted flesh-meat: but for this he has named no authority.]
See also 4.

entry.sense: 2: see 4.
Also Xw-Ahu laHomFA He gave him flesh-meat [app. in an unrestricted sense]. (TA.)
3. yuXaAwiI, for yuXaAYiI: see 3 in art. XOw.

hom.sense: 4. AXwI All-aHoma: see 1.

OaXowaAhumo; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and Xaw-aAhumo↓, inf. n. taXowiyapN; (Ḳ;) He fed them with XiwaMC [i. e. roasted, or broiled, or fried, flesh-meat]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And (both verbs with their complements) He gave them flesh-meat that they might roast, or broil, or fry, thereof. (AZ, Ḳ.)
And AXwI ‡ He left a portion remaining of his supper: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or he left some roasted, or broiled, or fried, flesh-meat of his supper. (A, TA.)
And AXwI AlqamoHu The wheat became fit to be rubbed with the hands and to be roasted. (ISd, Ḳ.)
And AXwI Als-aEafu † The palmbranches became yellow on the occasion of their drying up; (Ḳ, TA;) as though a roasting affected them. (TA.)
Also He got, or acquired, the worse, or viler, sort of cattle. (Ḳ.)

AXwAhu said of a shooter or caster, He hit (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Ḳ) his XawaI, (Ḳ,) i. e. [one or more of his] extremities, (TA,) not a [vital] place where a wound would occasion death; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and so XawaAhu↓, as in the Tekmileh: in the Ḳ, erroneously, Xw-Ahu. (TA.)
[Hence, He missed it, i. e. the object of his aim. See muXowFI: and see also Ḥam p. 91.]
[Hence, also, app.,] Hr says that AXwI is allowable in the sense of OasoqaTa † [He dropped, left out, omitted,, &c., anything]; like OasowaI [q. v.]. (TA in art. swI.)

In the saying maA OaEoyaAhu waOaXoyaAhu (Ṣ, Ḳ, [in some copies of the Ḳ wamaA OaXoyaAhu,]) and so in mA AEyAh waOaXowaAhu, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA,) the latter verb is an imitative sequent to the former [added only for the purpose of corroboration]. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 7. AnXwI All-aHomu The flesh-meat became roasted, broiled, or fried; (MA;) quasi-pass. of XawaI All-aHoma; (Ṣ,* M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AXtwI↓; (M, Ḳ;) [or] the latter in this sense is not allowable. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 8: see 1.
[Hence,] AiXotawayotuhaA, referring to a she-camel, † I journeyed upon her until the heat of the middays of summer emaciated her and she became as though she were burnt. (Ḥam p. 783.)
See also 7.

entry.sense: XaApN: see what next follows: and see more in art. Xwh.

XiyapN i. q. XaMCN [q. v. in art. Xwh]; as also XawiI-N↓; (IAạr, Ḳ;) the latter is like ganiI-N, [AlX-aweI in the CK as syn. with AlX-ACu being a mistranscription,] and is said by IAth to be a quasi-pl. n., or [what lexicographers term] a pl., of XaApN↓ [n. un. of XaMCN]. (TA.)
XiI-N is originally XiwoIN. (ISd, TA.) One says, jaMCa biAlEiI-i waAlX-iI-i, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) using the latter noun as an imitative sequent to the former [for the purpose of corroboration: see art. EI]. (TA.)

XawFI is pl. of XawaApN: [or rather the former is a coll. gen. n. of which the latter is the n. un.:] the latter signifies The skin of the head: (Ṣ, TA:) so [accord. to some] in the Ḳur lxx. 16: (TA:) or the exterior of the skin of the head, in which grows the hair: (Aboo-Safwán, TA in art. bXr:) and some say, the exterior of all, or of any part, of the skin: (TA in the present art.:) and the former signifies the arms or hands and the legs or feet, or the fore and hind legs, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and (Ḳ) the extremities (Mṣb, Ḳ) collectively, (Ḳ,) and the head of a human being, (Ṣ,) or the qiHof of the head [i. e. the bone above the brain, or a separate portion of the skull, or a distinct bone of the skull], (Ḳ,) but of a horse the legs, not the head, because one says Eabolu AlX-awaI [i. e. thick in the legs], for this cannot relate to the head of the horse, (Ṣ,) and any part that is not a [vital] place [i. e.] where a wound causes death (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) such [for instance] as the legs. (Mṣb.) vaAlibapu AlX-awaI means A woman having cracked, or chapped, feet. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. vlb.)

It is also a subst. [app. meaning a quasi-inf. n.] from OaXowaAhu [q. v.] as said of a shooter or caster: (TA:) [and hence] the saying (Ṣ, TA) of the Hudhalee, (Ṣ, [accord. to the TA, Khálid Ibn-Zuheyr,])
faUin-a mina Alqawoli Al-atiI laA XawaI lahaA
UicaA zal-a Zahori All-isaAni QnofilaAtuhu
means † [And, or for] verily of speech is that sentence (kalimap, a word understood,) which does not hit a place where a wound will not occasion death, [i. e. which does not miss its object, when its escaping from the upper surface of the tongue is quick,] but which kills. (Ṣ, TA.) And XawFI is used [app. in like manner, as a quasi-inf. n.,] in the case of anything that has missed an object of aim, though there be to it [really] no place where a wound would occasion death nor anything that is [properly] termed XawFI [as meaning a place where a wound will not occasion death]. (TA.) And [hence] it signifies † A mistake; syn. xaTaON. (TA.)

Also ‡ A thing, (Ṣ,) or an affair, (Ḳ,) that is paltry, mean, despicable, or of no account or weight or worth: (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA:) in this sense, from the same word as signifying the “extremities” [of an animal]. (IAth, TA.) Hence, in a trad. of Mujáhid, kul-u maA OaSaAba AlS-aAYima XawFI Uil-aA Algayobapa ‡ [Everything that befalls the faster is a matter of no account, except absence of mind]; i. e. nothing that befalls the faster annuls his fast except Algybp, for this does annul it. (TA.)
And † The worse, or viler, sort of cattle, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) of camels, and of sheep or goats; and the small, or young, thereof. (TA.) [See also XuwaAyapN.]
And † A remainder, or remaining portion. (TA.) [See, again, XuwaAyapN.]

Also i. q. UiboqaMCN † [The making, or causing, or suffering, to remain; or, perhaps, to continue in life, and if it mean thus, it may be from the same word in a sense expl. above, for the animal that one hits in a part that is not vital is suffered to continue in life]. (TA.)
XuwaMCN: see what next follows.

XiwaMCN Roasted, broiled, or fried, flesh-meat; (Ṣ,* MA, Mṣb, Ḳ,* KL;) as also XuwaMCN↓; (Ks, Ṣgh, Ḳ;) but the former is more usual and more chaste: (TA:) a subst. from XawaI All-aHoma: and XiwaMCapN↓ [as its n. un.] signifies a piece thereof. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: XawiI-N (Ḳ) and maXowiI-N↓ (Mṣb) [Roasted, broiled, or fried], the latter originally maXowuwIN. (Mṣb.) [In the Ḳ the former is said to be like XiwaMCN; but it has the signification of the latter, i. e., of a pass. part. n.]
See also XiyapN.
Ks says, (Ṣ,) in the phrase EayiI-N XayiI-N, and so in EayiI-N XawiI-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) some say (Ṣ) the latter word is an imitative sequent to the former [i. e. a corroborative: see art. EI]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: XiwaMCapN: see XiwaMCN.
Xawiy-apN: see the next paragraph.
XawaAyapN: see the next paragraph.
XuwaAyapN What is cut off from, or of, flesh-meat: (Ḳ, TA:) or what the slaughterer cuts off from, or of, the extremities of a sheep or goat. (TA.)

A small thing [or portion] of that which is large; as a piece, or detached portion, of a sheep, or goat: one says, maA baqiIa mina AlX-aApi Uil-aA XuwaAyapN [There remained not of the sheep, or goat, save a piece]. (Ṣ.)
Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and XiwaAyapN↓ and XawaAyapN↓, (Ḳ,) A quroS [or round cake, or small round cake,] of bread. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And ‡ The bad, or vile, sort, (Ḳ, TA,) or worse, or viler, sort, (TA,) of camels, and of sheep, or goats: (Ḳ, TA:) in this sense written by ISd with kesr and with fet-ḥ. (TA.) [See, again, XawFI.]
[And accord. to Freytag, XwAyp AlrDf (i. e. XwAypu Alr-aDofi) is expl. by Meyd as meaning Cooked milk cast upon a hot stone, so that only a small portion remains.]
XiwaAyapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Xaw-aMCN A seller of roasted, broiled, or fried, flesh-meat. (KL.)

hom.sense: Xay-aAnu [mentioned in this art. as though originally XawoyaAnu] i. q. damu AlOaxawayoni [The red, resinous, inspissated juice called dragon's blood: see art. dmw]. (Ṣ. Ḳ.)
And Far-seeing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
XaAwiI-N A possessor of XaMC [meaning sheep or goats or both]. (Ṣ, Ḳ. [In the CK without teshdeed. Mentioned also in art. Xwh, q. v.])
saEafapN XaAwiy-apN (with teshdeed to the I, TA, [but in the CK without teshdeed,]) † A palm-branch that has become yellow in drying up. (Ḳ. [See 4.])

entry.sense: XawoXaApN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, [in some copies of the Ḳ XawoXaMCN, but]) like mawomaApN, (Ṣ,) A swift she-camel. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

sense.ref: a pl. pl. of XaIoCN, q. v.

entry.sense: muXowFI, like muhodFI, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, maXowiI-, like mahodiI-, erroneously, as is proved by a verse cited as an ex. in the TA, pass. part. n. of 4,]) applied to a portion of a living serpent, (TA,) That has been missed by the stone [cast at it]. (Ḳ, TA.)
miXowFI (Ḳ in art. Swl) A frying-pan. (TḲ in that art.)
maXowiI-N: see XawiI-N.
muXotawFI [A place of roasting, broiling, or frying, flesh-meat]. (Ṣ in art. Tbx.)
4. OaXoyaAhu an imitative sequent to OaEoyaAhu in the phrase maA OaEoyaAhu waOaXoyaAhu: see 4 in art. XwI.
XiyapN, syn. with XaMCN: see art. XwI.
XaI-N and yaA XaI-a maA liI: see XaIoCN, in art. XyO.
XiI-N an imitative sequent to EiI-N: see art. XwI.
XayiI-N an imitative sequent to EayiI-N: see XawiI-N.
Xay-aAnu: see art. XwI.

hom.sense: 1. XaMCahu, (Mṣb,) [originally XayiYahu,] like xaAfahu, [which is originally xawifahu,] (MF,) first. pers. XiYotuhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yaXaAWuhu, (Mṣb,) [and by poetic license yaXaAhu, without C,] first pers. OaXaAWuhu, (Ṣ. Ḳ,) inf. n. XaIoCN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and maXiyoYapN, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) or this is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and maXaMCapN and maXaAYiyapN, (Ḳ,) [or these two also are simple substs.,] He, and I, willed, wished, or desired, it; syn. OaraAdahu (Mṣb) and Oaradotuhu: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) most of the scholastic theologians make no difference between AlmaXiyoYapu and AlUiraAdapu, though they are [said to be] originally different; for the former, in the proper language, signifies the causing to be or exist, syn. AlUiyjaAdu; and the latter, the willing, wishing, or desiring; syn. AlT-alabu. (TA.) A Jew objected, to the Prophet, his people's saying maA XaMCa Qll-ehu waXiYotu [What God hath willed and I have willed], as implying the association of another being with God: therefore the Prophet ordered them to say maA XaMCa Qll-ehu vum-a XiYotu [What God hath willed, then I have willed]. (TA.) [maA XaMCa Qll-ehu as signifying What hath God willed! is used to express admiration. And as signifying What God willed it is a phrase often used to denote a vague, generally a great or considerable, but sometimes a small, number or quantity or time: See De Sacy's Relation de l'Égypte par Abdallatif, pp. 246 and 394, &c.]
2. Xay-aOotuhu EalaI AlOamori [in some copies of the Ḳ (erroneously) XiYotuhu] I incited him, or made him, to do the thing, or affair. (Aṣ, Ṣ, L, Ḳ, TA.)
And Xay-aOa Qll-ehu wajohahu, (Ḳ, TA,) and xaloqahu, (TA,) God rendered, or may God render, foul, unseemly, or ugly, his face, (Ḳ, TA,) and his make. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. OaXaMCahu Uilayohi He, or it, compelled him, constrained him, or necessitated him, to have recourse, or betake himself, to it; syn. OalojaOahu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a dial. var. of OajaMCahu; (Ṣ;) of the dial. of Temeem. (TA.) Temeem say, Xar-N maA yuXiyWuka UilaI mux-api EuroquwbK, meaning yujiyWuka [q. v., i. e. It is an evil thing that compels thee to have recourse to the marrow of a hock]. (Ṣ.)
5. tXy-O His anger became appeased: (Ḳ:) said of a man. (TA.)

hom.sense: XaIoCN [A thing; anything; something; somewhat;] a word of well-known meaning: (Ḳ:) [sometimes, in poetry, written and pronounced XaI-N: see an ex. in a verse cited voce SuWaAbapN: see also the last sentence but one of this paragraph:] AlX-aIoCu properly signifies what may be known, and that whereof a thing may be predicated: (Mgh, KT:) accord. to Sb, it denotes existence, and is a name for anything that has been made to have being, whether an accident, or attribute, or a substance, and such that it may be known, and that a thing may be predicated thereof: (KT:) MF says that it is app. an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n., meaning what is willed, and meant, or intended, [in which sense maXiyoYapN↓ (pl. maXiyoMtN) is often used,] without restriction to its actuality or possibility of being, so that it applies to that which necessarily is, and that which may be, and that which cannot be; accord. to the opinion adopted by the author of the Ksh: [or, as an inf. n. in the sense of a pass. part. n., it may be expl., agreeably with what is said to be the proper meaning of the verb, as signifying what is caused to be or exist; accordingly,] Er-Rághib says that it denotes whatever is caused to be or exist, whether sensibly, as material substances, or ideally, as sayings; and Bḍ and others expressly assert that it signifies peculiarly what is caused to be or exist; but Sb says that it is the most general of general terms; and some of the scholastic theologians apply it to what is non-existent; such, however, are overcome in their argument by its not being found to have been thus used by the Arabs, and by such passages as kul-u XaIoCK haAlikN Uil-aA wajohahu [Everything is subject to perish except Himself (Ḳur xxviii. last verse)] and waUino mino XaIoCK Uil-aA yusab-iHu biHamodihi [And there is not anything but it glorifies Him with praising (Ḳur xvii. 46)], for what is nonexistent cannot be described as perishing nor imagined to glorify God: (TA:) the pl. is OaXoyaMCu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) imperfectly decl., (Mṣb, TA,) or rather this is a quasi-pl. n., (Sb, TA,) respecting the formation of which there is much difference of opinion [as will be shown hereafter], (Mṣb, TA,) and OaXoyaAwaAtN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a pl. pl. [i. e. pl. of OaXoyaMCN], (MF, TA,) and OaXaAwaAtN, [a contraction of that next preceding,] (Ḳ,) and OaXaAwaI, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with fet-ḥ to the w, (MF, TA,) and it is also mentioned as with kesr, (TA,) [and is written in both of my copies of the Ṣ OaXaAwaI, though if with kesr it should be either OaXaAwK or OaXaAwiI-u, but OaXaAwaI only is meant by J, as is shown by what here follows,] originally OaXaAyiI-u, with three I s, not OaXaAYiI-u as J says, [or rather as the word is written in copies of the Ṣ, for J may have held it to be OaXaAYiI-u or OaXaAyiIoCu, as he says that the C was changed into I thus occasioning the combination of three I s, so that he held its secondary form to be OaXaAyiI-u, as will presently be shown,] because the first I is radical, not augmentative, (IB, Ḳ,) the medial I of the three being suppressed, and the final one changed into A [though written I], and the initial one changed into w, (Ṣ,) and another form of pl. is OaXaAyaA, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with the I preserved, not changed into w [as it is in OaXaAwaI], (TA,) [likewise] a pl. of OaXoyaMCu, (Mṣb,) and OaXayaAyaA also is mentioned, (Ḳ,) as formed [from OaXoyaMCu] by the change of C into I and adding A, (TA,) and OaXaAwihu, which is strange, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) as there is no h in OaXayaMCu, (Lḥ,) or in XaIoCN: (Ḳ:) with respect to the first of these forms, [the quasi-pl. n.] OaXayaMCu, the most probable opinion is that of Kh: (Mṣb, TA:) accord. to him, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) it is originally of the measure faEolaMCu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) in lieu of OafoEaAlN, (Ḳ,) and therefore imperfectly decl., (Ṣ,) [i. e.] it is originally XayoYaMCu, (Mṣb,) and the two hemzehs combined in the latter portion being found difficult of pronunciation, the former of them is transposed to the beginning of the word, so that it becomes of the measure lafoEaMCu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) as is shown by its having for its pls. OaXaAwaI and OaXaAyaA and OaXoyaAwaAtN: (Ṣ:) accord. to Akh, it is [originally] of the measure OafoEilaMCu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) but if it were thus a broken pl., [not a quasi-pl. n.,] its dim. would not be OuXoy-aMCu↓, as it is, but XuyayoMtN: (Ṣ:) accord. to Ks, it is of the measure OafoEaAlN, and made imperfectly decl. because of frequency of usage, being likened to faEolaMCu; but were it so, OabonaMC and OasomaMC would be imperfectly decl.: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) accord. to Fr, XaIoCN is originally Xay-iYN, and therefore has a pl. of the measure OafoEilaMCu, afterwards contracted to faEolaMCu; but were it so, it would not have for its pl. OaXaAwaI. (Ṣ. [Much more respecting this pl. is added in the TA, but it is comparatively unprofitable.]) The dim. of XaIoCN is XuyaIoCN↓ and XiyaIoCN↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA, but only the former in some copies of the Ḳ, the word being written in other copies XuyaIoCN / XiyaIoCN;) not XuwaI-N↓, or XuwaIoCN↓; (the former accord. to my two copies of the Ṣ and accord. to the copies of the Ḳ followed in the TA, in which it is said to be with teshdeed to the I, and the latter accord. to the CK and my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ;) or this is a dial. var. of weak authority, (Ḳ,) used by post-classical poets in their verses. (MF, TA.)

When a man says to thee, “What dost thou desire?” thou answerest, laA XayoYFA [Nothing]: and when he says, “Why didst thou that?” thou answerest, lilaA XaIoCK [For nothing]: and when he says, “What is thine affair?” thou answerest, laA XaIoCN [Nothing]: it is with tenween in every one of these cases. (Aṣ, AḤát, TA.) [When one says laA XaIoCa, he means thereby There is nothing.]
layosa biXaIoCK means [It is nought, of no account or weight; it is not worthy of notice, or not worth anything;] it is not a good thing; or it is not a thing to be regarded. (W p. 27.)
[fiyhi XaIoCN mina AlT-uwli occurs in the TA voce HusobaAnapN, meaning In it is somewhat, or some degree, of length; i. e. it is somewhat long; and is used in the present day in this sense.]
In the phrase huwa OaHosanu minoka XayoYFA, the last word is for biXaIoCK [i. e. He is better than thou in something; meaning he is somewhat better than thou]. (IJ, L.)

maA Oagofalahu Eanoka XayoYFA is a phrase of the Arabs [app. lit. signifying How unmindful of thee is he as to anything!] mentioned by Sb as meaning daEi AlX-ak-a Eanoka [Dismiss doubt from thee (respecting him as to anything)]: IJ says that XyYA is here put in the accus. case as an inf. n., as though the saying were maA Oagofalahu Eanoka gufuwlFA, because the verb of wonder does not require to be corroborated by the inf. n. [proper to it]: (L, TA:) [or it is a specificative:] IF says that it is a phrase of dubious meaning; and that the most probable explanation of it is this; that mA is here lit. interrogative, but in meaning denotative of wonder; and that XyYA is governed in the accus. case by some other word, or phrase, as though the saying were dismiss a thing by which he is not occupied in mind, and dismiss doubt as to his being occupied in mind by it. (TA in art. mA.)
[XayoYFA faXayoYFA means Thing by thing, part by part, bit by bit, piecemeal, inch by inch, drop by drop, little and little in succession, by little and little, by degrees or gradually.]

OaI-u XaIoCK [meaning What thing?] is, by the alleviation of the I [in AI-] and the suppression of the C [in XIC], made into one word, OayoXaIo: so says El-Fárábee: (Mṣb:) or, [as is commonly the case in the present day,] by reason of frequency of usage, it is contracted into OayoXa. (TA in art. jrm, as on the authority of Ks.)
XaIoCN in the Ḳur lx. 11 may mean Any one (Bḍ, Jel) or more. (Jel.)
[It is also applied to † The penis of a man; as in the explanation of a phrase mentioned voce canabN; like as its syn. hanN is to the same and (more commonly) to the “vulva” of a woman.]

In algebra, it signifies [A square root;] a number that is multiplied into itself; which in arithmetic [and in algebra also] is called jcr [i. e. jacorN]; and in geometry, DlE [i. e. DiloEN or DilaEN]; (“Dict. of the Techn. Terms used in the Sciences of the Musalmans,” p. 202;) an unknown number that is multiplied into itself. (Idem, p. 730.)

It is also said, on the authority of Lth, to signify Water: and he cites as an ex.,
taraI rakobahu biAlX-aIoCi fiI wasoTi qaforapK
[Thou seest, or wilt see, his company of riders at the water in the midst of a desert]: but AM says, I know not AlXIC in the sense of “water,” nor know I what it is. (TA.)

yaA XaIoCa is an expression of regret, (El-Aḥmar, Ks, TA,) or of wonder, (Ḳ, TA,) [or of both,] meaning [Oh! or] O my wonder! (Ks, Lḥ, TA.) One says, yaA XaIoCa maA liI, (El-Aḥmar, Ks, Lḥ, Ḳ,) and yaA XaI-a maA liI, i. e. with and without C, (Ks, TA,) and yaA haIoCa maA liI, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) yA haI-a mA lI, and yaA faI-a mA lI, (El-Aḥmar, Ks, TA,) neither of these two with C, (Ks, TA,) [meaning Oh! or O my wonder! What has happened to me?] in all of these, (Ks, TA,) mA being in the place of a noun in the nom. case. (Ks, Lḥ, TA.)
Some also say, yaA XaIoCa and yaA haI-a and yaA faI-a, and some add maA, saying, yaA XaIoCa maA and yaA haI-a maA and yaA faI-a maA, meaning How good, or beautiful, is this! (Ks, TA.)

entry.sense: XiyoYapN [Will, wish, or desire,] a subst. from XaMCahu, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) [and] so is maXiyoYapN↓ [which is mentioned in the Ḳ as an inf. n.]. (Mṣb.) One says, kul-u XaIoCK biXiyoYapi Qll-ehi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. bamiXiyoYatihi↓ [Everything is by the will of God]. (Ṣ.)
XuyaIoCN and XiyaIoCN and XuwaI-N or XuwaIoCN: see XaIoCN in the middle of the paragraph.
Xay-iMnN and Xay-aMnN: see art. XwO.
OuXay-aMCu dim. of OaXoyaMCu: see XaIoCN, in the latter part of the former half of the paragraph.
maXiyoYapN: see XiyoYapN, in two places:
and see also XaIoCN, near the beginning of the paragraph.
muXay-aON Incongruous, unsound, (Ḳ, TA,) foul, or ugly, (TA,) in make, or formation. (Ḳ, TA. [See Ḥam p. 192.])
And accord. to Aboo-Saʼeed, A child born preposterously, the legs coming forth before the arms. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. XaAba, aor. yaXiybu, inf. n. XayobN and XayobapN (Mṣb, TA) and maXiybN, (TA,) He became whitehaired, or hoary. (Mṣb, TA.) And XAb raOosuhu (Ṣ,) and raOosuhaA, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. XayobN and XayobapN, (Ṣ,) His head, and her head, became white, or hoary. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.)
[Hence,] XaAbato ruWuwsu AlMkaAmi ‡ [The heads, or summits, of the hills became white, or hoary]. (A.)

And XAb Alr-aOosa It whitened the head: so expl. by ISk as used in the following saying, (Ṣ,) ascribed by J to 'Adee, but it is of 'Abeed Ibn-El-Abras: (IB, TA:)
taSobuw waOan-aI laka Alt-aSaAbiI
waAlr-aOosu qado XaAbahu AlmaXiybu↓
[Thou inclinest to silly and youthful conduct: but whence cometh to thee the inclining to such conduct when hoariness, or the entering upon the period of hoariness, hath whitened the head?]. (Ṣ,* IB, TA.) [See also 2.]

entry.sense: 2. Xy-bhu AlHuzonu, (Ks, Ṣ, A,) and Xy-b AlHuzonu raOosahu, and biraOosihi, (Ks, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which last is a strange phrase, as it exhibits together two means by which a verb is rendered trans., [namely, the doubling of the medial radical letter of the verb and the introduction of the prep. bi,] (TA,) Grief rendered him white-headed, or hoary-headed; (Ks, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AXAbhu↓, (A,) and AXAb↓ raOosahu and biraOosihi. (Ks, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.*)

hom.sense: 4. AXAb, said of a man, He had children that had become white-headed, or hoary. (Ṣ, TA.)
See also the next preceding paragraph {2}, in two places.

entry.sense: XayobN The hair (Ḳ, TA) itself: sometimes it is thus called: (TA:) [but app. only when white, or hoary; in which sense it is often used; as in the TA in arts. xDb and Sbg, &c.:] or (Ḳ, TA, in the CK “and”) whiteness of the hair, or hoariness; (A, Ḳ, TA;) as also maXiybN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) both signify the same [and are thus used as simple substs. and are also inf. ns.]: (Ṣ:) or the former has the latter of the two significations given above; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) and is little and much [whiteness of the hair]: one says, EalaAhu AlX-ayobu [Whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, came upon him]: (TA:) but maXiybN↓ signifies a man's entering upon the period of whiteness of the hair, or hoariness: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb:) see an ex. of this latter in the first paragraph. In the phrase in the Ḳur [xix. 3], waQXotaEala Alr-aOosu XayobFA, (Ṣ,) meaning And whiteness of the hair of the head hath spread therein like as the radiance of fire spreads in firewood, (Jel,) [or the head has become glistening with whiteness of the hair, or hoariness,] XybA is in the accus. case as a specificative: or, accord. to Akh, as an inf. n., as though it were said waXaAba Alr-aOosu XayobFA. (Ṣ, TA.*)

hom.sense: XiybN, of a whip, a genuine Arabic word of wellknown meaning; (Ṣ;) The thong (Ḳ, TA) at the upper extremity (TA) of a whip: (Ḳ, TA:) there are two of such thongs, called XiybaAni. (TA.)
Also A word imitative of the sounds made by the lips of camels (Ṣ, Ḳ) in drinking. (Ṣ.)
And pl. of OaXoyabu [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.)

entry.sense: XuyubN a pl. of which the sing. is doubted: see OaXoyabu.

hom.sense: XayobapN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
And accord. to El-Khafájee, A white, or hoary, beard: but MF says that this is a conventional post-classical meaning. (TA.)
[Also, in the present day, applied to A species of artemisia; (Forskål's Flor. Aegypt. Arab., p. lxxiii., no. 439;) the artemisia arborescens of Linn.: (Delile's Flor. Aegypt. Illustr., no. 799:)]
[and Lichen; (Forskål ubi suprà;) the lichen prunastri of Linn. (Delile, ib., no. 976 †.) And Xayobapu Aljabali Lichen scyphifer. (Forskål, p. lxxviii., no. 559.)]

entry.sense: XayobaAnu: see OaXoyabu; near the end of the paragraph:
and see also the paragraph here following.

XiybaAnu and miloHaAnu, (Ṣ, A,) thus in a verse of El-Kumeyt, as related by Ibn-Selemeh, with kesr to the X and m, (Ṣ,) or the former word is written XayobaAnu↓, and sometimes XiybaAnu, and the latter is as above, (Ḳ,) and sometimes maloHaAnu, (TA,) ‡ The two months of winter; (A, TA;) [as though meaning the second of the Six Seasons, commencing two months after the autumnal equinox; (see the former of the two tables in p. 1254;)] i. q. XahoraA qimaAHK, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) which are the two coldest months; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) so called because of the earth's being then white with snow and hoar frost; (Ṣ, TA;) falling at the period of the [auroral] rising of the Scorpion and the Vulture, (AlEaqorab and Aln-asor, [by which latter is meant Aln-asoru AlwaAqiEu, i. e. the star a of Lyra,]) said by him who knows not to be the two Kánoons [i. e. kaAnuwnu AlOaw-alu and kaAnuwnu Alv-aAniI, corresponding to December and January O.S.]: (TA:) [it appears that they nearly agree with the two Kánoons; for El-Ḳazweenee and others say that Alqalobu (i. e. the heart of the Scorpion, which is the 18th of the Mansions of the Moon,) and Aln-asoru AlwaAqiEu rise together, and their auroral rising in Central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, accord. to my calculation, (see manaAzilu Alqamari in art. nzl,) was on the 25th of November O. Ṣ.: see also miloHaAnu, and qimaAHN: it is also said that] XiybaAnu [used alone] is a name of [the month] kAnwn AlAw-l, because of the whiteness of the earth by reason of the hoar-frost and snow. (Mgh.)
XiyaAbN and XiyaAbapN [the former erroneously written by Golius Xay-aAbN]: see XawobN, in art. Xwb.
XayuwbN: see OaXoyabu.
XaAYibN [Being, or becoming, white-haired, or hoary]: see OaXoyabu.
XayobN XaAYibN is a phrase like layolN laAYilN, (Ṣ,) or like XiEorN XaAEirN: it means Intense whiteness of the hair. (TA.)

OaXoyabu White-haired, white-headed, or horary: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [it is said to be] anomalous in form; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) for an epithet of this measure is only formed [by rule] from a verb of the measure faEila, aor. yafoEalu; (Ṣ, TA;) and it is a condition of the formation of such an epithet that it must denote a defect or the like, or a colour: but OaXoyabu signifies white-headed, or hoaryheaded; [so that it does denote a colour;] and El-Khafájee says that it is reckoned among epithets denoting defects, or blemishes, like OaEomaI and OaEoraju: (MF, TA:) it is said in the Ḳ that it has no faEolaMC, i. e., (TA,) the epithet XayobaMCu is not applied to a woman; (Mṣb, TA;) XamoTaMCu being used in its stead; (TA;) though one says XaAba raOosuhaA: (Mṣb, TA:) [but see Ḥar p. 418, where XayobaMCu is mentioned, applied to a woman, as meaning aged, and white, or hoary, in the head: and see XayobaMCu in art. Xwb:] the pl. is XiybN; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) with which is syn. Xuy-abN; (TA, as from the Ḳ; [but not found by me in the copies of the Ḳ to which I have had access;])
and XuyubN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) this last is said by IM to be allowable in poetry, EalaI Alt-amaAmi [here meaning as though it were a word composed of sound letters]; and this is the assertion of the lexicologists [in general]: ISd thinks it to be pl. of XaAYibN↓ [q. v.], like as buzulN is of baAzilN; or pl. of XayuwbN↓ [which app. means very white or hoary in the head], accord. to the dial. of the people of El-Ḥijáz, who say dajaAjapN bayuwDN and dajaAjN buyuDN. (TA.)

[Hence,] one says, raOayotu AljibaAla XiybFA ‡ I saw the mountains white with snow and hoar frost. (A, TA.) And XiybN [used alone] signifies † Mountains upon which snow falls, and which are white, or hoary, therewith: (Ṣ, L:) or mountains white with snow or with dust: and, some say, white clouds: sing. OaXoyabu. (L, TA.) And, applied to truffles (kamoOap), † White and large: (TA:) or simply white. (Id. voce taEaAXiybu.)
yawomN OaXoyabu † A day in which are cold and clouds and SuraAd [correctly Sur-aAd, meaning thin clouds, or cold and humid clouds, in which is no water]; as also yawomN XayobaAnu↓. (Ḳ.)

layolapu AlX-ayobaMCi, (Ḳ,) or layolapu XayobaMCa, (TA,) and layolapN XayobaMCu, (TA voce Hur-N,) † The last night of the [lunar] month: (Ḳ, TA:) its first night is called layolapu Hur-apK and layolapN Hur-apN. (Ḳ voce Hur-N.) baAtato bilayolapi XayobaMCa, and bilayolapi AlX-ayobaMCi: see in art. Xwb.
maXiybN: see XayobN, in two places.
1. XaAHa: see 4.
[Also, accord. to Freytag, on the authority of the “Kitáb el-Addád,” He was brave, or bold: thus having two contr. significations.]
[Another meaning assigned to it by him, in common with XaAyaHa and OaXaAHa, as on the authority of the Ḳ, i. e. “Diligens fuit,” is a mistake.]

hom.sense: 2. Xy-Hhu, (O,) inf. n. taXoyiyHN, (Ḳ,) He cautioned him; or made him to fear, or be in fear. (O, Ḳ.*)
And He removed him, or it, far away. (O.)
And Xy-H, (O, TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) He looked at his adversary, or antagonist, and straitened him, or treated him with hardness or harshness: (O, Ḳ,* TA:) from IAạr. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3: see the next paragraph {4}, in two places.
Also He fought. (T, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: But in the dial. of Hudheyl, (Ṣ,) He strove, laboured, toiled, or exerted himself, fiI OamorK [in an affair]; and so XAyH↓. (Ṣ, A.)
And He continued journeying, or going on. (O.)

AXAH biwajohihi He turned away his face, (Ṣ, A, TA,) from a [person or] thing, or from the heat of fire, or a hot odour, and from something hurtful: (TA:) or he exerted himself in aversion or turning away. (IAạr, TA.) One says, kal-amotuhu faOaXaAHa biwajohihi I spoke to him, and he turned away his face. (A.)
AXAH also signifies He advanced, or came forward; syn. Oaqobala. (Fr, O, TA.) [Thus it has two contr. meanings. See also the part. n., muXiyHN.]
And He defended what was behind his back. (IAth, TA.) [See, again, the part. n.]

AXAH bicanabihi, said of a horse, He let his tail hang down loosely. (Lth, Ṣ.) F, in the Ḳ, following Az and Ṣgh, says that this is a mistranscription of the verb, for AsAH; but his assertion requires proof. (MF.) [See the latter verb, in art. syH.]
AXAHt AlOaroDu The land produced the plant called XiyH. (AḤn, O, Ḳ.)

XiyHN Cautious, or fearing; (A, Ḳ;) as also XaAYiHN↓, (A, TA,) and muXiyHN↓: (Aṣ, O:) or this last, cautious, or fearing, and at the same time striving, labouring, toiling, or exerting himself: (Az, TA:) or all signify prudent; discreet; or having, or using, precaution, or good judgment; (Ḥam p. 281;) and so XayoHaAnu↓. (Id. p. 43.)

In the dial. of Hudheyl, (Ṣ, O,) Striving, labouring, toiling, or exerting himself, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) in affairs; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and so XaAYiHN↓, (A, Ḳ,) and muXiyHN↓: (Aṣ, O, Ḳ:) pl. of the first [and app. of the second also] XiyaAHN: (Ṣ, O.)

Also [The artemisia Judaïca; and absinthium Ponticum; species of wormwood;] a certain plant, (AḤn, Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) well known, (AḤn, O, Ḳ,) of several species, (AḤn, O,) of some [species] whereof brooms are made, (L,) [and which is also used for fumigation,] the leaves of which are [of the kind called] hadab; (AḤn, O, L;) it has a sweet odour, but its taste is bitter; is pasture for horses and camels; and the places of its growth are the plains and the meadows: (AḤn, O, L:) pl. XiyHaAnN. (Fr, O, L.)

Accord. to the Ḳ, [probably on the authority of Lth,] it signifies also A [garment of the kind called] burod, of El-Yemen: but Az says that there is no kind of garment so called: the correct word is sayoHN, with [the unpointed] s [and with fet-ḥ]. (TA.)

entry.sense: XayoHaAnu [and probably with tenween also]: see XiyHN.
Also Very jealous; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) because such is cautious for his wives, or women under covert, or household or family; (Ṣ, O;) and so XaAYiHN↓. (Ḳ.)
Also, (O, Ḳ,) and XiyHaAnN↓, (Aṣ, O, Ḳ,) Tall: (O, Ḳ:) or goodly in tallness. (L.)

And the former, That makes, or utters, a low sound in running; [so I render yataham-asu EadowFA in the Ḳ and TA; in the O and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, yataham-aXu; but the former I think the right reading; app. by reason of quickness, or swiftness; for it is added,] quickness, or swiftness, is meant thereby: (O, TA:*) mentioned by Az, on the authority of Khálid Ibn-Jembeh. (TA.) [In this sense it seems to be with tenween: for] XayoHaAnapN [is its fem. and] means A quick, or swift, she-camel. (Ṣ, O.)
Also A horse strong in spirit; syn. Xadiydu Aln-afosi; (O, Ḳ, TA; in the CK, Aln-afasi [i. e. in breath];) and so XiyHaAnN↓: thus expl. by Skr. (O.)
XiyHaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

hom.sense: XiyaAHN Mutual caution or fear. And The act of striving, labouring, toiling, or exerting oneself, in anything. (Ḳ.) [But in both of these senses it seems to be an inf. n. of 3, q. v.]
Also (Ḳ) Drought, dearth, scarcity. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: XaAYiHN: see XiyHN, in two places:
and see also XayoHaAnu.

muXiyHN: see XiyHN, in two places. It is also expl. as meaning Striving, labouring, toiling, or exerting himself, and persevering in his work: (A:) and striving, &c., and hastening, or going quickly. (TA.)
Also Advancing, or coming forward, to one. (Fr, O, Ḳ.)
And Defending what is behind one's back. (Fr, O, Ḳ.)
muXay-aHN is expl. as meaning Striped; applied to a garment: but Az says that there is no such word, so applied: the correct word is musay-aHN, with [the unpointed] s. (TA.)
maXiyHaI: see the following paragraph.
maXiyHaMC: see the following paragraph.
maXoyuwHaI: see the following paragraph.

hom.sense: maXoyuwHaMCu (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and maXiyHaI↓ (O, Ḳ) A state of haste: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or a state of confusion: (Ḳ:) the latter meaning mentioned in the L: (TA:) you say, humo fiI maXoyuwHaMCa mino Oamorihimo (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and fI maXiyHaI mn Amrhm (O, Ḳ) They are in a state of haste in respect of their affair: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or in a state of confusion in their affair: (L, Ḳ:) as having the latter meaning, Ibn-Málik says that it is maXiyjaMC, with j and medd, of the measure faEiylaMC, not mafoEilaMC; but this requires consideration: Ibn-Umm-Málik and others, following AḤei, say that Alqawomu fiI maXiyHaMCa↓ mino Oamorihimo means the people, or party, are in a state of striving, labour, toil, or exertion, and determination, or resolution, in respect of their affair. (TA.)

maXoyuwHaMCu also signifies A land that produces the plant called XiyH; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and so maXoyuwHaI↓: (O, Ḳ:) or it signifies many plants of the kind so called: thus in the T, on the authority of Aṣ and AʼObeyd, and so says AḤn, as is stated [in the O and] in the R; (TA;) AḤn saying further that it is like maXoyuwxaMC meaning a company of Xuyuwx [or elderly men], and maEoyuwraMC meaning a herd of Euyuwr [or asses], &c.; (O;) [so that it is a quasi-pl. n.;] but this is disallowed by El-Mufaddal Ibn-Selemeh. (TA.)

entry.sense:
1. XaAxa, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaXiyxu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XayaxN, with fet-ḥ to the I, (Ṣ, Ḳ,)
and XuyuwxapN (Ḳ) and XiyuwxapN (TA) and Xuyuwxiy-apN (Ḳ) and Xiyuwxiy-apN (Zbd, TA) and XayoxuwxapN [the most common form, respecting which see what follows,] (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Xayoxuwxiy-apN; (Ḳ;) and Xy-x↓, inf. n. taXoyiyxN; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and tXy-x↓; (Ḳ;) He became a Xayox [i. e. an old, or elderly, man;, &c.]: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) in XayoxuwxapN, the I is originally movent [with fet-ḥ], and afterwards made quiescent, for there is not in the language a word of the measure faEoluwlN [except SaEofuwqN, as is said in the Ṣ in art. Hyd]: as to the similar words whose medial radical letter is w, as kayonuwnapN and qayoduwdapN and dayomuwmapN and hayoEuwEapN, these are originally kay-anuwnapN [for kayowanuwnapN, of the measure fayoEaluwlapN,] and the like, and are contracted; for were it not so, they would be kawonuwnapN and the like. (Ṣ, L.)

hom.sense: 2. Xy-x: see the preceding paragraph {1}.
Xy-xhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taXoyiyxN, (TA,) He called him by the appellation of Xayox, to pay him honour, or respect. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

And Xy-x Ealayohi He attributed or imputed to him, or charged him with, a vice, or fault; blamed, or reproached, him; (Ḳ, TA;) cast a bad, an evil, a foul, or an excessively bad or evil or foul, imputation upon him. (TA.) And Xy-x bihi [and so Xy-xhu accord. to an explanation of Xay-axotu Alrjl, as on the authority of AZ, in the TA, but this may be a mistranscription for Xy-xt biAlr-ajuli,] He exposed his vices, faults, or evil actions; disgraced him; or put him to shame. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tXy-x: see 1.
[It signifies also] He feigned, or made a show of, old age. (KL.)

hom.sense: XayoxN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and XayoxuwnN↓, (Ḳ,) but the latter is a strange word, mentioned by some of the expositors of the Fṣ, as expressing more than the former word, (MF,) [An old, or elderly, man; an elder, as meaning a man whose age gives him a claim to reverence or respect; a senior;] one advanced in age, (Mgh,) such as is beyond him who is termed kaholN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) which means him whose XabaAb [i. e. youthfulness, or prime of manhood,] is ended: (Mgh:) one in whom age has become apparent, (L, Ḳ,) and hoariness: (L:) or a man from the age of fifty, or fifty-one, to the end of his life, or to the age of eighty: (L, Ḳ:) also expl. as meaning a man advanced in age but having strength, or vigour, to fight: and an old and weak, or a decrepit, man, who is of no service: (Mgh:) [in the present day, XayoxN is used in the senses above mentioned; and is also especially applied, as an appellation of honour, to a doctor of religion and law; a head, or chief, of a religious confraternity; a chief of a tribe or the like, and of a village; and to a reputed saint:] fem. XayoxapN↓, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) an old, or aged, woman; syn. EajuwzN: (A:) [and applied in the present day particularly to a learned woman; an instructress; and the like:] the pl. [of pauc.] of XayoxN is OaXoyaAxN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XiyxapN (Kr, ISd, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of mult.] XuyuwxN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XiyuwxN (Ḳ, with kesr, to agree with the I, TA) and XiyxaAnN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XiyaxapN (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) and XayaxapN (A [there said to be like EabadapN]) and maXoyaxapN↓, (Ḳ, and so in one of my copies of the Ṣ,) or this last is a quasi-pl. n., (Mgh, Mṣb,) and [so are] miXoyaxapN↓ and maXoyuxapN↓ and miXoyuxapN↓ (TA) and maXiyxapN↓ (Ḳ, and so in one of my copies of the Ṣ,) and maXoyuwxaMCu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the last like maXoyuwHaMCu and maEoluwjaMCu and masoluwmaMCu and maEobuwdaMCu and maEoyuwraMCu, which are said to be the only other instances of this form, (TA,) [but to these should be added maHomuwraMCu and makobuwraMCu and matoyuwsaMCu and perhaps some other instances,] and maXoyuxaMCu↓, (Ḳ,) and another pl. is maXaAyixu↓, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or this last is pl. of maXoyaxapN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and is disallowed by IDrd and Ḳz (TA) [though very commonly used in the present day, especially as applied to doctors of religion and law]; and the pl. of OaXoyaAxN is OaXaAyiyxu, like OanaAyiybu pl. of OanoyaAbN: (Z, TA:) the dim. of XayoxN is XuyayoxN↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and XiyayoxN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with kesr to the X: (Ṣ:) XuwayoxN↓ is not allowable, (Ṣ, A,) or is rare. (Ḳ.)
[AlX-ayoxaAni, The two Sheykhs, is a title peculiarly applied to the first two Khaleefehs, Aboo-Bekr and ʼOmar.]
XayoxN also signifies † A woman's husband, (Ḳ,) though young: and in like manner, a man's wife, whether old or young, is called his Eajuwz. (Az, TA in art. Ejz.)

[And ‡ An ancestor. Accord. to a copy of the A that seems to have been used by the author of the TA, one says, wariva mino maXiyxapi Alkaram and mn OaXoyaAxihi, which is tropical, meaning mino MbaAYihi: but the right reading is evidently mn maXiyxatihi↓, and Alkarama; and the meaning, ‡ He inherited, from his ancestors, generosity.]
Xayoxu Aln-aAri means ‡ Iblees: because he was created of fire, or because his ultimate place will be the fire of Hell. (Ḥar p. 130.)
And AlX-ayoxu † The mountain-goat that is advanced in age, or fullgrown. (TA.)
And † The milk-skin. (TA.)

OaXoyaAxu Aln-ujuwmi i. q. OuSuwluhaA, (Ḳ,) i. e. † The seven [or five] planets; (TḲ;) or the daraAriIoC [also applied by some to the five planets, Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn]; accord. to IAạr, AXyAx Alnjwm, (TA in this art.,) or OasonaAxu Aln-ujuwmi as is related by Th, (TA in art. snx,) means the stars that do not make their [temporary] abode in the Mansions of the Moon, which [latter] are called nujuwmu AlOaxoci: ISd says, I think that he means, by the njwm, the fixed stars: Th says that they are called only OasonaAxu Aln-ujuwmi, i. e. the OuSuwl thereof, around which the [other] stars revolve, and pursue their courses. (TA. [See also sinoxN, last sentence.])

XayoxN signifies also A certain tree; (AZ, Ḳ, TA;) also called Xajarapu AlX-uyuwxi, the fruit of which is a jirow [q. v.] like that of the xir-iyE, which is the bastard saffron (Xajarapu AlEuSofuri); it grows in the meadows, and the quroyaAn [or places where water runs to, or in, or into, meadows,, &c.]. (AZ, TA.)

entry.sense: XayoxapN fem. of XayoxN, q. v. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
XayoxuwnN: see XayoxN.
XuyayoxN and XiyayoxN and XuwayoxN: dims. of XayoxN, q. v.
maXoyaxapN and miXoyaxapN, &c.; and the pl. maXaAyixu: see XayoxN, in seven places.
maXoyuxaMCu: see XayoxN.
maXoyuwxaMCu: see XayoxN.

hom.sense: 1. XaAdahu, aor. yaXiydu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XayodN, (Ṣ,) He plastered it (a wall) with Xiyd, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. gypsum, or the like: (Ḳ:) he built it (a structure) with Xiyd, meaning gypsum. (Mṣb.)
See also 2.
XaAduwA Ald-iyna † They strengthened and exalted the religion: from XaAda in the first of the senses expl. above: (Ḥar p. 5:) [or rather from this verb as syn. with Xay-ada and OaXaAda.]
See also 4.

As inf. n. of XaAda in the phrase XaAda biAlUibili, aor. as above, (TḲ,) XiyaAdN signifies † The calling camels, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ, TA,) as also UiXaAdapN↓, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O,) raising the voice in doing so. (TA.)

Also, (Ḳ,) as inf. n. of the same verb, (TḲ,) † The rubbing perfume with the skin; (Ḳ;) as also taXay-udN↓; in some copies of the Ḳ, taXoyiydN↓: (TA:) [the former of these two seems to be the right; and the meaning seems to be, the rubbing the skin with perfume; for,] accord. to AA, one says taXay-ado↓ bihecaA AlT-iybi, meaning Rub thy skin with this perfume. (O.)
XaAda, (said of a man, TA,) aor. as above, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XayodN, (TA,) also signifies He perished, or died. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. Xy-dhu, (A, L, Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. taXoyiydN, (L, Mṣb, TA,) He raised it high; (A, Mṣb, TA;) namely, a palace, (A,) or a building; (Mṣb, TA;) as also AXAdhu↓, (A, L, TA,) and XaAdahu↓: (A: [this last is app. included with the two other verbs, in the A, as having this meaning, which is confirmed, as pertaining to it, by an explanation of its pass. part. n., maXiydN, q. v.:]) or Xy-dhu [implies a repetition of the act of building: (see maXiydN:) or] signifies he built it firmly, or strongly, and raised it high. (L.)
See also 1.
4. AXAdhu: see 2.

Hence, (L,) UiXaAdapN signifies ‡ The raising the voice in saying a thing (Lth, Ṣ, L, Ḳ) [of any kind, or] such as one's companion dislikes; like tanodiydN. (Lth, L.) See also 1. You say, AXAd Sawotahu and biSawotihi ‡ He raised his voice. (A.) And AXAd bihi ‡ He proclaimed it, or cried it, raising his voice; namely, a stray, or any other thing: (Aṣ, L:) ‡ he made it known; (AA, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;*) namely, a stray. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And AXAd bicikorihi ‡ He raised his good fame, by praising him; raised a good report of him: (Ṣ,* A, L:) and he raised his ill fame, by dispraising him; raised an evil report of him: and AXAdhu and XaAdahu↓ he raised his notoriety or fame. (L.) And AXAd Ealayohi ‡ He published against him something disliked, disapproved, or odious: one says, AXAd Ealayohi qabiyHFA and biqabiyHK ‡ [He published against him something bad, evil, abominable, or foul]. (A.)
And UiXaAdapN also signifies ‡ The act of destroying: (Ḳ, TA:) from the same word as syn. with tanodiydN. (TA.)
5: see 1, in two places.
XayodN, a Pers. word, [or rather of Pers. origin, from XayodaA,] Possessed; or mad, or insane: or intoxicated. (TA.)

XiydN Anything with which a wall is plastered, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) consisting of gypsum and the like; (A, Ḳ;) J says, of gypsum or balaAT; but this last word is a mistake, [probably originated by an early transcriber of the Ṣ,] for milaAT, i. e. mud, or clay: (Ḳ:) or [peculiarly] gypsum. (Mṣb.)
Az says that some of the Arabs sometimes call thus A HiSon [i. e. fortress, fort, or fortified place]. (TA.)

maXiydN Plastered with Xiyd; and so, as some say, muXay-adN↓: (T:) or built with gypsum: (Mṣb:) or made with Xyd, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) i. e. gypsum; and so, some say, muXay-adN↓: (A:) or the latter signifies raised high, or made lofty; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and so the former, applied to a place, (A,) or building: (TA:) the former has this meaning in the Ḳur xxii. 44: (Jel:) J says in the Ṣ, Ks says, maXiydN is applied to a sing., from the saying in the Ḳur, [ubi suprà,] waqaSorK maXiydK; and muXay-adN↓, to a pl., from the saying in the same, [iv. 80,] fiI buruwjK muXay-adapK: but this is a mistake: what Ks says is that muXay-adapN, with p and teshdeed, is a pl. [i. e. a lexicological, not a grammatical, pl.] of muXay-adN: (IB, Ḳ:*) or the saying of Ks [if as quoted in the Ṣ] may be expl. accord. to the opinion of those who hold that maXiydN and muXay-adN both signify plastered with Xiyd, on the supposition that the Arabs did not use maXiydapN as applied to a pl., but only to a sing.: (Az, L:) [for] Fr says that the pass. part. n. of the unaugmented verb only is used when applied to a sing. and not denoting repetition, or muchness; but either this or the pass. part. n. of the verb of the measure faE-ala may be used when applied to a sing. and denoting repetition, or muchness, and when applied to a pl.: thus you say kaboXN macobuwHN [“a slaughtered ram”]; but not mucab-aHN; but you may say vawobN muxar-aqN [as meaning “a garment in which holes have been repeatedly made,” or “in which many holes have been made,” or “much pierced with holes,” as well as vawobN maxoruwqN meaning “a garment in which a hole has been made,” or “in which holes have been made,”] and kibaAXN mucab-aHapN [“slaughtered rams”]: and hence you may say qaSorN muXay-adN↓; because taXoyiydN denotes building, and the act of building is repeated, and a building becomes high by degrees. (L.)
muXay-adN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.
6. tXAyr: see 6 in art. Xwr.
XiyarN: n. un. XiyarapN: pl. of the latter XiyaraAtN: and dim. XuyayorapN and XiyayorapN: see XajarN.
XiyaArN: see art. Xwr.
Xay-irN: see art. Xwr.

XiyzN and XiyzaI↓ A kind of black wood, of which bowls (qiSaAE) are made: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the latter is a certain black wood of which combs and bowls (jifaAn) are made: (Mgh:) or ebony: or saAsam [a certain wood of which bows or arrows are made]: (AA, Ḳ:) or walnut-wood: (Aṣ, Ed-Deenäwaree [AḤn], Mgh, Ḳ:) Aṣ says of the XyzI, by the name of which the Arabs call bowls (jfAn and qSAE) and the sheaves of pulleys, that it is walnut-wood, but it becomes blackened by grease, and therefore is thus called, and it is not Xyz: so says AḤn: and he adds, the case is as he has described it; for the Xyz does not become thick so as that bowls may be carved from it: (Ṣgh, TA:) of this latter, only combs and the like are made; and it is black: it is also said, in the T, that bowls made from the walnut-tree are called XiyzaI. (TA.)
XiyzaI: see the preceding paragraph.
4. AXAXt Aln-axolapu The palm-tree produced dates such as are termed XiyX. (O, Ḳ.)

XiyXN and XiyXaMCN↓ A sort of dates which do not organize and compact stones; (Fr, O, Ḳ;) or, if they do so, they do not become hard; and when they dry, they become such as are termed HaXaf, not sweet: (O, Ḳ:) dial. vars. of XiySN and XiySaMCN: (Ṣ:) accord. to AḤn, (TA,) of Persian origin. (O, TA.)
XiyXaMCN: see the next preceding paragraph.
2: see the next paragraph {4}.

4. AXASt Aln-axolapu The palm-tree was not fecundated by the flowers, or pollen, of the male tree: (A, Ḳ:) or its dates dried up: and it bore dates such as are termed XiyS: (Mṣb:) or it became bad, and its dates became such as are termed XyS; (TA;) as also Xy-St↓. (Kr, TA.)
5. tXy-S Alt-amoru The dates became such as are termed XiyS. (Ṣ.)

XiySN Dates of which the stones do not become hard; as also XiySaMCN↓; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) which is only the case when the palm-tree has not been fecundated by the flowers, or pollen, of the male tree: (Ṣ:) and sometimes, having no stones: (Fr, TA:) or bad dates: (A:) or the worst of dates; (IF, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also ↓the latter word: (Mṣb:) or the worst of dates when full-grown but unripe: (Lth, TA:) called in the dial. of Belhárith Ibn-Kaab, SiySN; and by the people of El-Medeeneh, sux-alN: (El-Umawee, TA:) and said by some to be a Persian word, arabicized: (TA:) n. un. with p; (A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e., XiySapN and XiySaMCapN. (A, Mṣb.)
XiySaMCN: n. un. XiySaMCapN: see XiySN, in two places.

hom.sense: 1. XaATa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaXiyTu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n.
