XayoTN and XiyaATapN (Ḳ) and XayoTuwTapN, (Lth, Ḳ,) It (a thing, Mṣb, TA, or, as some say, particularly, olive-oil, and rob, TA) burned, or became burnt; (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) as also tXy-T↓, (Ḳ,) said of flesh-meat: (TA:) or both, said of flesh-meat, signify its upper part became burnt by the contact of fire: (Lth, TA:) the latter is also said of wool; and the former likewise, of wool, and of hair: (TA:) the former also signifies it was near to becoming burnt: (TA:) and, said of clarified butter, and of olive-oil, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) it became cooked so much that it burned; (Ṣ;) because, in that case, it perishes; (O;) [which implies that a signification hereafter to be mentioned is held to be the primary one;] or became thick; or became cooked so much that it almost perished. (Ḳ.) You say also, XaATati Alqidoru The cooking-pot burned, and had something sticking in it: (Ṣ:) or had something burnt sticking in the bottom of it. (O, Ḳ.)

XaATa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ṣ,) also signifies He (a man) perished, or died. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [The art. in the Ṣ commences with this signification, which, as remarked above, seems to be regarded by some as the primary one.]
Also He burned with anger. (TA in art. XTn.)
And It was, or became, null, void, of no account, or of no force. (Mṣb, TA.)
His (a man's) blood, (Ṣ,) or it, (his blood,) (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) went (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) for nothing, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct; it was, or became, of no account. (Ṣ, Mgh,* Mṣb.)
And It (any- thing) went away;

XaATati Aljazuwru ‡ The slaughtered camel became dispensed; syn. tanaf-aqat; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) there remained not of it any portion that was not divided and given: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) and XaATa laHomu Aljazuwri The flesh of the slaughtered camel went away divided and distributed, nothing thereof remaining. (A, TA.)
XaATa also signifies ‡ He hastened (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) in an affair. (Ḳ, TA.)
[XaATahu seems to be dial. var. of saATahu, as signifying He mixed it.]

[And hence,] XaATa Ald-imaMCa ‡ He mixed the bloods; as though he shed, or poured forth, the blood of the slayer upon that of the slain. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) A poet, (Ṣ,) namely, El-Mutalemmis, (TA,) uses the expression lawo tuXaATu dimaAWunaA [If our bloods were mixed]; (Ṣ, TA;) accord. to one relation; but accord. to another, the verb is with s. (TA.)
XaATa bidamihi: see 4.

entry.sense: 2: see the next paragraph {4}, in five places.

4. AXAThu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiXaATapN, (Mṣb,) He burned it, or made it to burn; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, a thing, (Mṣb,) as, for instance, olive-oil; (TA;) as also Xy-Thu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taXoyiyTN. (TA.) ↓The latter also signifies He burned its wool, namely, that of a sheep, in order to cleanse it; and so Xw-Thu: (Ṣ, TA:) and each of these, he (a cook) set it on fire, namely the foot of a bull or cow, or of a sheep or goat, and the head, so that what was upon it, of hair, or wool, became burnt. (TA.) You say also, XAT Alqidora He made the cooking-pot to burn, and to have something sticking in it. (Ṣ.) And Xy-T↓ Alqidora He made the cooking-pot to boil; as also Xw-ThA. (El-Kilábee.) And Xy-T↓ All-aHoma He cooked thoroughly the flesh-meat; as also Xw-Thu: (Ibn-ʼAbbád:) or he smoked it, or made it smoky, and did not thoroughly cook it; (Ṣ;) and so the latter. (TA in art. XwT.) And Xy-T↓ AlD-abuEu Aln-abota; and Ald-awaMCu AljuroHa; ‡ The year of drought burned the herbage; and the medicine, the wound. (A, TA:) [See also Xaw-aTa.]
Also, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) He destroyed him, or it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

AXAT damahu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and bidamihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He (the Sultán, Mgh, Mṣb) made his blood to go for nothing, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct; made it to be of no account: (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA:) or the latter, (TA,) or both, (Ḳ,) he laboured to destroy him, or to kill him: (Ḳ, TA:) or both, he exposed him to slaughter: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, accord. to IAmb, you say, XaATa↓ bidamihi, meaning he exposed him to destruction. (TA.) You say also, AXAT dama Aljazuwri He shed the blood of the camel that was to be slaughtered. (Aṣ, Ḳ.)

AXAT All-aHoma ‡ He distributed the flesh, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. the flesh of a slaughtered camel: (TA:) or AXAT Aljazuwra he dispensed the last remaining portion of the slaughtered camel, after all beside had been distributed. (Ṣ, TA.) Also † He cut up, or cut in pieces, the flesh of the slaughtered camel before the distribution. (ISh.)
5: see 1, first sentence.

10. AstXAT ‡ He became inflamed by anger; Ealayohi against him: (Ḳ, TA:) or he became as though he were inflamed in his anger; accord. to Aṣ, from miXoyaATN as applied to a she-camel: (Ṣ, TA:) [or] he burned, and became inflamed, by vehement anger. (TA.)
‡ He (a man, TA) became brisk, or sharp; (Ḳ,* TA;) he burned; (TA;) mina AlOamori by reason of the thing, or affair. (Ḳ, TA.)
‡ It (a pigeon) flew briskly. (Ḳ, TA.)
‡ He sought to be slain in war or fight. (TA.)
‡ He became at the point of destruction. (TA.)
‡ He (a camel) became fat: (Ṣ, TA:) [as though he desired, or demanded, that he should be slaughtered, and that his flesh should be distributed:] or fatness spread in him. (TA.)

XayoTaAn [i. e. XayoTaAnN or XayoTaAnu, accord. to different authorities, as shown below, A devil; and with the article Al, the devil, Satan;] is, accord. to some, from XaATa, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) as signifying “it was, or became, null, void, of no account;” and the like: (Mṣb, TA:) or “he perished:” (Ḳ, TA:) or “he went away:” or “it burned,” or “became burnt:” two reasons given for this derivation are, that among the names of the devil are Almucohabu and AlbaATilu: and another is this; that several read, in the Ḳur xxvi. 210, AlX-ayaATuwna [instead of AlX-ayaATiynu]: but some say that it is from XaTana, signifying “he became distant,” or “remote:” Sb gives both of these derivations: respecting the former of which, it should be observed that if from XAT as signifying “it burned,” or “became burnt,” it is proper; but if from the same in any of the other senses mentioned above, it is tropical: and if belonging to this art., it is imperfectly decl., being of the measure faEolaAn: (Ṣ in art. XTn, in which see it:) [but in the Ḳur-án it is always perfectly decl.: and SM says that] it is perfectly decl., unless used as a proper name; in the latter case being imperfectly decl. (TA.)

hom.sense: XiyaATN The smell of a piece of cotton burning, or burnt. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also miXoyaATN.

entry.sense: XaAYiTN and XaATK, like haAYirN and haArK, [the latter being formed by transposition from the former, XaATK and haArK being for XaATiIN and haAriIN,] Flesh-meat [&c.] burning, or being burnt. (TA.)
taXoyiyTN Flesh-meat roasted, (Ḳ,) or made good, and roasted, (TA,) for a company of men: (Ḳ:) a subst., like tamotiynN. (Ḳ, TA.) [In the CK, for AisomN kaAlt-amotiyni, we find wAsmN kAlt-amotiyni.]

miXoyaATN ‡ A she-camel that quickly becomes fat: (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) applied also to a he-camel: (TA:) pl. maXaAyiyTu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) in some of the copies of the Ṣ, maXaAyiTu: and you say also UibilN XyAT↓ [app. a mistake for miXoyaATN, which is fem., like UibilN, as well as masc.]: AA says that mXAyT, [or maXaAyiyTu,] applied to camels, signifies assigned for slaughter; from XaATa said of a person's blood. (TA.)
musotaXiyTN ‡ A fat camel. (Ḳ.) [See 10.]
‡ Laughing exceedingly; (Ḳ;) laughing vehemently, like one exerting himself in his laughing. (ISh.)

hom.sense: 1. XaAEa, aor. yaXiyEu, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. XuyuwEN (O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XayoEuwEapN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and XayoEN (Ḳ) and XayaEaAnN and maXaAEN, (O, Ḳ, the last, in the CK, maXaAEap,) said of information, an announcement, a piece of news, or a narrative, or story, (TA,) or of a thing, (O, Mṣb,) It became spread, published, divulged, revealed, made known, or disclosed; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) or it became apparent, or manifest; (Mṣb, TA;) fiI Aln-aAsi [among the people]; so as to reach every one, becoming equally known by the people, not known by some exclusively of others. (TA.)

[Hence, app.,] XAE, aor. as above, said of a thing, signifies also † It became scattered, or dispersed; like XaE-a. (TA in art. XE.) You say, XAE All-abanu fiI AlmaMCi, (Mṣb,) or XAEt qaTorapN mina All-abani fiI AlmaMCi, and tXy-Et↓, (TA,) † The milk, (Mṣb,) or the drop of milk, (TA,) became dispersed in the water, (Mṣb, TA,) and mixed: (Mṣb:) and Xay-aEa↓ fiyhi likewise signifies it became dispersed in it. (TA.) And XAE AlX-ayobu, inf. n. XayoEN and XiyaAEN and XayaEaAnN and XuyuwEN and XuyuwEapN and maXiyEN, ‡ Whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, appeared, and became scattered: and XAE fiyhi AlX-ayobu, inf. n. as above, ‡ Whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, spread upon him; as also tXy-Ehu↓ [or tXy-E fiyhi, agreeably with what has been said above]. (TA.) And XAE AlS-adoEu fiI Alz-ujaAjapi † The crack spread, and became dispersed, in the glass, or glass vessel. (Th, TA.) And tXAyEt↓ AlUibilu † The camels became scattered, or dispersed; or they scattered, or dispersed, themselves. (TA.)
As trans. by means of bi: see 4, in two places.

[It is also trans. by itself.] XaAEakumu Als-alaAmu is like the saying Ealayokumu Als-alaAmu [Safety, or peace,, &c., be, or light and abide, on you]; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) but is only said by a man to his companions when he desires to quit them: (Ṣ, O:) or it means [may safety,, &c.,] follow you: (O, Ḳ:) or, not quit you: (Ḳ:) whence, (TA,) one says also XaAEaka Alxayoru may prosperity not quit thee; and in like manner Lebeed says of praise (HamodN): (O, TA:) [and J says that] XAEhu, inf. n. XiyaAEN, signifies he, or it, followed him: (Ṣ:) or XAEkm AlslAm, (Yoo, O, Ḳ,) aor. yaXaAEukum, inf. n. XayoEN, (Yoo, O,) means [may safety,, &c.,] fill you: (Yoo, O, Ḳ:) [app. from what next follows.]
One says also XiEotu AlUinaMCa, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. OaXiyEuhu, inf. n. XayoEN, (TA,) I filled the vessel. (Ḳ, TA.)
2. Xy-E fiyhi: see 1.
Xy-E said of a pastor, He blew in the reed-pipe [called XiyaAE, by means of which the camels are called together]. (Lth, Ḳ, TA.)

Xy-E biAlUibili He (a pastor) called to the camels, whereupon they followed one another; (Mṣb;) in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, i. q. AXAC bhA, [in the CK AaXAbahA,] but correctly OaXaAEa↓ bihaA, (TA,) which means he called to the camels, (Ḳ in another part of the art., and TA,) when some of them remained, or lagged, behind: (TA:) and [in like manner] XAyE↓ biUibilihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. muXaAyaEapN and XiyaAEN, (Ṣ,) he (a pastor, Ṣ) shouted and called to his camels, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) when some of them remained, or lagged, behind: (Ṣ:) or Xy-E Uibilahu he (a pastor) called out among his camels, whereupon they went along, following one another: (Mgh:) and Xy-E Alganama he urged on the sheep, or goats, (Ḳ,* TA,) because of their lagging behind, (TA,) in order that they might follow the others. (Ḳ, TA.) [The last two phrases are app. from the second of the explanations here following.]
Xy-Ehu, inf. n. taXoyiyEN, also signifies He sent, or sent on, him, or it. (TA.)
And He made him, or it, to follow. (TA.)

[And He made it to be followed by another thing.] One says, Xay-aEotu ramaDaAna bisit-K mino Xaw-aAlK [or rather bisit-apK] † I made [the fasting of] Ramadán to be followed by [the fasting of] six [days] of Showwál expl. by OatobaEotuhu bihaA [a well-known phrase, of frequent occurrence, but one which I have not found in any of the lexicons, except in explanations; the approved phrase used in its stead being OatobaEotuhu Uiy-aAhaA, lit. meaning “I made them to follow it;” this being virtually the same as “I made it to be followed by them”]: (Mṣb:) [and in like manner, the elliptical phrase] Xy-E ramaDaAna, (Ḳ,) or Xy-E Xahora ramaDaAna, (O, TA,) means He fasted after Rama- dán, or the month of Ramadán, six days; (O, Ḳ, TA;) i. e. OatobaEahu bihaA. (TA.)

Xay-aEotuhu Einoda raHiylihi (Lth,* Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ *) I went forth with him (Lth, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) on the occasion of his departure, (O, Mṣb,) namely, a guest, (Mṣb,) in order to bid him farewell, and to conduct him to his place of alighting, [app. meaning, to his first place of alighting,] (Lth, O, Ḳ,) or to show honour, or courtesy, to him; and I bade him farewell: (Mṣb:) or Xy-E AlD-ayofa signifies he followed the guest [app. on the occasion of his departure, in order to bid him farewell,, &c.]: (Mgh:) or Xy-Ehu Einoda raHiylihi he went forth with him on the occasion of his departure, desiring to cheer him by his company to some place: and XAyEhu↓ signifies the same. (TA.)
[Xy-Ehu sometimes signifies He followed him, not coming up with him, but always going behind him]. See AlmuXay-iEapu, voce muXay-aEN.
[And He followed, or imitated, him; conformed, agreed, or complied, with him; like XaAyaEahu]. See 3, in three places.

Xy-E fulaAnFA ‡ He encouraged such a one, and emboldened him, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and strengthened him. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN yuXay-iEuhu EalaI celika ‡ Such a one strengthens him to do that. (TA.) And Xay-aEa hecaA bihecaA † He strengthened this with this. (TA.)
Xy-Ehu Aln-aAra ‡ He threw, or put, firewood upon the fire to make it blaze or flame, burn up, or burn brightly or fiercely. (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
And Xy-Ehu biAln-aAri † He burned him, or it, with fire. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) Of anything that has been burned, one says, Xuy-iEa. (TA.)
Also (O, Ḳ) He befriended him, or was friendly to him; syn. waAlaAhu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) from AlwaliI-u. (Ṣ.)
XAyEhu Einoda raHiylihi: see 2, in the latter part of the paragraph.
XAyE biUibilihi: see 2, near the beginning. [Hence, app.,] one says also, XaAyaEa bihimu Ald-aliylu faOaboSaruwA AlhudaI The guide called to them [and they saw the right direction]. (TA.)

AlX-iyaAEu occurs in a trad., as some relate it, and is expl. as there meaning AlmufaAxarapu bikavorapi AljimaAEi: but AA says that it is a mistranscription for Als-ibaAEu, with s and b; or that it may be from XaAEapN signifying “a wife.” (IAth, TA.)

entry.sense: 4. AXAE Alxabara, (Ṣ, O,) or AlX-aIoCa, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or rather Als-ir-a, as in the L; (TA;) and AXAE bihi; (O,* Ḳ;) as also XAE↓ bihi, first pers. XiEotu bh; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) He spread, published, divulged, revealed, made known, or disclosed, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and (Ḳ) made apparent or manifest, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) the information, announcement, news, narrative, or story, (Ṣ, O,) or the thing, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or the secret. (L, TA.) And AXAE cikora AlX-aIoCi He made the mention, or fame, of the thing to fly [abroad, or to spread]. (TA.)

OaXaEotu AlmaAla bayona Alqawomi † I dispersed, or distributed, the property among the people, or party; and Alqidora fiI AlHaI-i the [contents of] the cooking-pot among the tribe. (AʼObeyd, TA.) [See also its pass. part. n.]

OaXaAEakumu Qll-ehu Als-alaAma, (Ṣ, O,) or biAls-alaAmi, (Ḳ,) or both, (TA,) as also XaAEakumu↓ Qll-ehu biAls-alaAmi, (Ḳ,) May God make safety, or peace,, &c., [to light and abide upon you, or] to accompany and follow you. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ. [See also 1, latter half.])
AXAE biAlUibili: see 2.
[AXAEt is also expl. in the TA as meaning xrjt: but I suspect a mistranscription or an omission in this case.]

hom.sense: 5: see 1, in two places.
tXy-E said of a man, (Ṣ, O,) He asserted himself to hold the tenets of the XiyEap [q. v.]: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, KL, TA:) or he became a XiyaEiI-: a verb similar to taHan-afa and taXaf-aEa. (TA.)
[Accord. to Golius, it is expl. in the KL as meaning He left a portion of a thing undistributed: but this explanation is not in my copy of that work.]
tXy-E fiI AlX-aIoCi He strove, or laboured, or he distressed himself, or he courted death, (Aisotaholaka,) in his love of the thing. (TA.)
tXy-Ehu AlgaDabu Anger excited him to lightness, levity, or unsteadiness; or flurried, or disquieted, him. (TA.)
See also 3, first sentence.

entry.sense: 6. tXAyEt AlUibilu: see 1.
tXAyEwA is from AlX-iyEapu, (Ṣ, O,) and signifies They became XiyaE [i. e. separate parties,, &c., pl. of XiyEapN, q. v.]. (TA.)
And They went, or went along, together. (KL.)
[See also the part. n., voce Xay-iEN.]
8. AXtAEt bibawolihaA, said of a she-camel: see 4.
[See also the part. n., voce Xay-iEN.]
XaAEN, originally XaAYiEN: see the latter word.

Also The urine of the she-camel, that becomes scattered when the stallion leaps her. (Aṣ, O, Ḳ.) And, (Aṣ, O, [accord. to the Ḳ “or,”]) The urine of the he-camel when he is excited by lust. (Aṣ, O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: XayoEN A space [of time]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) One says, OaqaAma fulaAnN XahorFA Oawo XayoEahu (Ṣ, O) i. e. Such a one remained, or stayed, a month or the space thereof: or nearly the space thereof. (TA.)
One says also, Mtiyka gadFA Oawo XayoEahu I will come to thee to-morrow or after it: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or to-morrow or the day after it. (L, TA.)
And hecaA XayoEu hecaA This is he that was born next after this; like XawoEuhu: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, all in art. XwE:) or this is the like of this. (AʼObeyd, O and Ḳ in the present art.)
XayoEN signifies also A follower: and a friend, or a comrade, or an assistant. (KL.)
And A lion's whelp: (Lth, IDrd, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or when he has attained to taking prey; so in the L: and some say the lion [himself]. (TA.)
See also XaAYiEN.

entry.sense: XiyEu nisaMCK One who follows after women, and mixes, associates, or converses, with them. (Ḳ,* TA.)

hom.sense: XaAEapN A wife: because she follows, or conforms with, [the wishes of] her husband. (Sh, O, Ḳ, TA.)
See also XaAYiEN.

entry.sense: XayoEapN A certain tree, (O, Ḳ,) below the stature of a man, having knotted, or jointed, rods, and small, dark-red blossoms, smaller than the jasmine: (O:) the bees feed upon it; (O, Ḳ;) and men eat its tender extremities, being rendered healthy, or sound, thereby; (yataSaH-aHuwna bihi;) and it has a hot quality in the mouth; and is sweet in odour: (O:) clothes become sweet-scented by adhering to it, (O, Ḳ,* TA,) i. e. to its blossom, agreeably with what is said in the “Book of Plants,” not to the tree, to which the pronoun refers in the O and Ḳ; (TA;) and its honey is clear, (O, Ḳ,) very clear, and is well known: it is a pasture; and grows in the plains, and near to seed-produce. (O.)

XiyEapN A separate, or distinct, party, or sect, (O, Ḳ, TA,) of men: this is the primary signification: so called from their agreeing together, and following one another: or, accord. to some, the I is originally w, and it is from Xuw-aEa qawomahu, which means “he collected his people or party:” (TA:)
the followers and assistants (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) of a man: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) any people that have combined in, or for, an affair: (Mṣb, TA:) accord. to Az, persons who follow, or conform with, one another, [though] not all of them agreeing together: (TA:) and any assistant and partisan of a man: (O, TA:) [for] the word is applied to one and to two and to a pl. number and to the male and to the female, (Ḳ, TA,) without variation: (TA:) the pl. is XiyaEN and OaXoyaAEN, (Ṣ,* O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter a pl. pl.; (Mṣb;) and the former is applied to any people, or party, whose affair, or case, is one, who follow one another's opinion. (Ṣ.) The saying, in the Ḳur [xxxiv. last verse], kamaA fuEila biOaXoyaAEihimo mino qabolu means As was done with the likes of them, of the same persuasion as they, of the peoples that have gone before: (Ṣ,* TA:) and similar to this is the saying in the Ḳur liv. 51. (TA.)

Afterwards, AlX-iyEapu became a name of A particular party [or sect]; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) being predominantly applied to all who took as their friends, or lords, ʼAlee and the people of his house: (Ḳ:) those who followed ʼAlee, saying that he was the [rightful] Imám after the Apostle of God, and believing that the office of Imám should not depart from him and his descendants: (KT:) they are an innumerable people, who are innovators; the extravagant zealots among them are the Imámeeyek, who revile the Two Sheykhs [Aboo-Bekr and ʼOmar]; and the most extravagant of them call the Two Sheykhs disbelievers: some of them rise to the pitch of [that misbelief which is termed] Alz-anodaqap [q. v.]. (TA.) [It is also applied to A single person of this party, or sect; agreeably with what has been said above; and such a person is likewise called XiyaEiI-N↓: see 5.]
XiyaEiI-N: see the next preceding sentence.
[XiyaEiy-apN and XiyoEiy-apN The way of doctrine and practice, or the system of tenets, of the sect called AlX-iyEapu.]
XayaAEN: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: XiyaAEN The reed-pipe of the pastor; (IAạr, O, Ḳ;) the instrument with which the pastor blows; so named because he calls together the camels with it: (A, TA:) or the sound of the pastor's reed-pipe. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And Callers, or summoners; syn. duEaApN, (O, Ḳ,) pl. of daAEK: (Ḳ:) in the Tekmileh, duEaMC [a call, or calling,, &c.]. (TA.)

Also, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and XayaAEN↓, (O, Ḳ,) but the former is the more chaste, (O, [and the same is implied in the Ḳ,]) ‡ Slender firewood, with which a fire is made to blaze or flame, burn up, or burn brightly or fiercely: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) and XayuwEN↓ signifies [the same, i. e.] slender firewood (AḤn, O, Ḳ) that is quickly kindled by a weak fire, so that it prevails over the thick, or large, firewood. (AḤn, O.)

entry.sense: XayuwEN: see next preceding sentence.

Xay-iEN A sharer, or partner: (TA:) pl. XuyaEaMCu. (O, Ḳ, TA.) One says, humo XuyaEaMCu fiyhaA [They are sharers, or partners, in it, i. e. a house (daAr) or land;] i. e. every one of them is a Xay-iE to his fellow [or fellows]. (O, Ḳ.) And humaA mutaXaAyiEaAni↓ fiI daArK, (O, Ḳ,) or OaroDK; (O;) and muXotaAEaAni↓, (O, TA,) in the copies of the Ḳ, erroneously, mutaXaAEaAni; (TA;) They two are sharers, or partners, in a house, (O, Ḳ,) or land. (O.)
And Ald-aAru Xay-iEapN bayonahumo The house is undivided [i. e. shared] among them; syn. muXaAEapN↓. (O, Ḳ. [See also XaAYiEN.])

XaAYiEN Information, an announcement, a piece of news, a narrative, or a story, spreading; or becoming spread, published, divulged, revealed, made known, disclosed, apparent, or manifest; fiI Aln-aAsi [among the people]; so as to reach every one, becoming equally known by the people, not known by some exclusively of others: (TA:) and XaAEapN↓ [is app. a pl. thereof, like as baAEapN is of baAYiEN, signifying, or so OaxobaArN XaAEapN,] news, or tidings,, &c., spreading, or becoming spread. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.)

[† A thing scattered, or dispersed, or in a state of dispersion: fem. with p {XaAYiEapN}: pl. of the latter XawaAYiEu; which may also be pl. of the former applied to a rational being, like fawaArisu pl. of faArisN.] One says, jaMCati Alxayolu XawaAYiEa † The horsemen came scattered, or dispersed, or in a state of dispersion; as also XawaAEiIa, formed by transposition. (TA. [But the latter is also mentioned as belonging to art. XEw.])

Also A lot, share, or portion, (sahomN, Ṣ O, Mṣb, Ḳ, and naSiybN, TA,) undivided; and so XaAEN↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) like as one says saAYiru AlX-aIoCi and saAruhu; (Ṣ, O;) and muXaAEN↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [i. e. shared in common; as though] spread; (TA;) so called because mixed, not being separated: (Mṣb:) [and it seems, from the usage of a phrase in art. xlT of the Ḳ, (AlmuXaAriku fiI AlXuyuwEi,) that XayoEN↓, as sing. of XuyuwEN, signifies an undivided portion.]
Also Anything that is a supplement to a thing: or an addition, or augment, thereto. (TA.)
muXaAEN; and its fem. muXaAEapN: see XaAYiEN and Xay-iEN.
maXiyEN Filled; (O, Ḳ;) applied to a vessel. (Ḳ.)

[Hence,] † Very rancorous, malevolent, malicious, or spiteful; filled with baseness, meanness, or sordidness. (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, erroneously said to be, in this sense, miXoyaE, like makoyal; instead of maXiyE, like makiyl.]) Hence also, huwa Dab-N maXiyEN † He is [like a lizard of the kind called Db- that is] very rancorous,, &c. (TA.) IAạr says, I heard Abu-l-Mekárim revile a man, saying, huwa xab-N maXiyEN, [perhaps correctly Dab-N, but see this word, which is used as a syn. sequent to xab-N,] meaning He is like a Dab- that is very rancorous,, &c., and unprofitable; (O, TA;) maXiyEN, here, being with fet-ḥ to the m; (O;) from XiEotuhu “I filled it.” (O, TA.)
miXoyaEapN A quf-ap [or kind of basket, of palmleaves,] in which a woman puts her cotton and other things: (IDrd, O, L, Ḳ:) so called because it accompanies and follows her. (TA.)
miXoyaAEN One who will not keep, or conceal, a secret; or one who is unable to conceal his information, news, or tidings; [a babbler of secrets, &c.;] syn. micoyaAEN. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

muXay-aEN ‡ Courageous: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) as though he were encouraged and emboldened and strengthened by another, or encouraged and emboldened by the strength of his heart: (O, Ḳ:) or whose heart is encouraged and emboldened by every formidable affair in which he has embarked. (A, TA.)
And ‡ Very quick or speedy or hasty. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Z, O, Ḳ.)

AlmuXay-aEapu, in a trad. relating to sheep or goats to be slaughtered as victims on the day of sacrifice, in which trad. such are forbidden, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) means the sheep or goat (Mgh) that requires one to urge it on after the [other] sheep or goats, (Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) because of its weakness (Mgh, Ḳ) and leanness, (Mgh,) or because of its lack of strength to follow them: (O:) or, as some relate it, the word is AlmuXay-iEapu↓, (Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) meaning that ceases not to follow the [other] sheep or goats, (laA tazaAlu tuXay-iEu↓ Alganama, O, Ḳ,* i. e. tatobaEuhaA, Mgh, O, Ḳ,) or that ceases not to lag behind the [other] sheep or goats, (Mṣb,) not coming up with them, (Mgh, TA,) but always going behind them, (TA,) because of its leanness; (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) from Xay-aEa AlD-ayofa [expl. above (see 2)]; (Mgh;) or as though urging on the [other] sheep or goats. (Mṣb.)
AlmuXay-iEapu: see what next precedes.

muXaAyiEN Overtaking, or coming up with another or others; or one that overtakes,, &c.: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) as in the saying of Lebeed,
kamaA Dam-a OuxoraI Alt-aAliyaAti AlmuXaAyiEu
[Like as he that overtakes collects together the last of those cattle that go behind the others]. (TA.)
muXotaAEN: see the dual, voce Xay-iEN.
mutaXaAyiEN: see the dual, voce Xay-iEN.
2. Xy-f Ald-awaMCa [from XiyaAfN]: see 2 in art. Xwf.

XiyfN The prickles (Xawok) that are at the back of the Easiyb [or leafless portion, next above the lowest and thickest part, of the branch] of the palm-tree: (O, Ḳ:) so says AḤát: (O:) but Lth says that the word is [siyfN, q. v.,] with the unpointed s. (TA.)
XiyaAfN, originally XiwaAfN: see art. Xwf.
Xiy-ifapN and Xiy-ifaAnN: see art. Xwf.
1. Xiqotu AlT-unuba UilaI Alwatidi, (Ṣ,) inf. n. XayoqN, (TA,) is like nuTotuhu. (Ṣ.) [See 1 (last sentence but one) in art. Xwq.]

hom.sense:
XiyqN A mountain: (IAạr, Ṣ:) or the highest part of a mountain: (Skr, O, Ḳ:) or a part that is even, (Lth, O, Ḳ,) and small in breadth, in the face of a mountain, resembling a wall, (fiI lihobi jabalK,) (Lth, O,) that cannot be ascended: (Lth, O, Ḳ:*) or the most difficult place in a mountain. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) A poet says, cited as using it in the last sense,
XagowaMCu tawTinu bayona AlX-iyqi waAln-iyqi
[An eagle dwelling between the most difficult place in a mountain and the highest part thereof]. (Ṣ, O.) See also a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb cited voce xaAfapN, in art. xwf.
A long, or tall, mountain; (jabalN TawiylN;) (Ḳ;) thus accord. to some in the verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb. (TA.)
And accord. to some, it signifies in that verse (TA) A narrow cleft in a mountain: or in the head thereof: or a cleft between two rocks. (Ḳ, TA.)
A side; syn. jaAnibN. (Skr, O, Ḳ.) One says, AimotalOa mina AlX-iyqi UilaI AlX-iyqi It became filled from side to side. (TA.)
The head [or glans] of the penis. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.)
The hair of a horse's tail: n. un. with p {XiyqapN}. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.)
A species of fish. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.)

The aquatic bird [or rather birds] called burak [pl. of burokapN, q. v.]: (Ḳ:) n. un. with p {XiyqapN}. (TA. [In the Ḳ, XiyqapN is mentioned in another place as meaning a certain aquatic bird: and in the O as meaning a species of aquatic birds.])
And accord. to Ibn-ʼAbbád, i. q. kitaAbN [A writing, or book,, &c.]. (O.)
See also art. Xwq.

entry.sense: XiyaAqN: see art. Xwq.
Xay-iqN: see art. Xwq.

1. XayolN is a bad [or vulgar] dial. var. of XawolN: one says, Xilotu bihi, [and now, more commonly, Xilotuhu, like Xulotuhu, meaning I raised it; and, as now used, I lifted it; and hence, I removed it, or took it away; and I carried it; and I loaded it, namely, luggage upon a beast, &c.;] aor. OaXiylu, inf. n. XayolN and maXoyalN, the latter [in measure] like maqoEadN. (TA.)
XiyaAlapN The occupation of the Xay-aAl, i. e. porter, or carrier of burdens. (TA.)
Xuy-alN and Xiy-alN pls. of XaAYilN. (Ḳ in art. Xwl, in which see the singular.)
Xay-aAlN, from Xilotu bihi [expl. above], A porter, or carrier of burdens. (TA.)
farasN miXoyaAlu Alxaloqi A horse incongruous, unsound, faulty, or weak, in make: (AO, O and TA in the present art.:) mentioned in the L in art. Xwl. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. XaAma AlX-aIoCa fiI AlX-aIoCi, (Ḳ,) [aor. yaXiymu,] inf. n. XayomN, (TA,) He hid, or concealed, the thing in the thing: (Ḳ, TA:) and he inserted the thing in the thing. (TA.) [Hence,] XAm sayofahu, (Ḳ,) first pers. Ximotuhu, (Ṣ,) aor. as above, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XayomN, (TA,) He sheathed his sword; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and [in like manner] XAm nabolahu [He put his arrows into the quiver]: (TA:) and the former signifies also He drew his sword: thus having two contr. meanings: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) AʼObeyd doubted of the latter meaning; and Sh knew it not; but the verb is said to have this meaning in a verse of El-Farezdaḳ. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Aboo-Bekr that a complaint was made to him against Khálid Ibn-El-Weleed, and he said, laA OaXiymu sayofFA sal-ahu Qll-ehu EalaI AlmuXorikiyna i. e. I will not sheath a sword [which God has drawn against the believers in a plurality of gods]. (TA.) [Hence also,] one says, XAm OabaA EumayorK (Ḳ, TA) i. e. [He sheathed] the cakar; (TA;) meaning † he attained his desire of the virgin. (Ḳ, TA.)

And XAm fiI Alfarasi saAqahu He struck the mare with his shank to make her run: (Ḳ:) or he impressed (lit. inserted) his leg [or shank] in the belly of the mare, striking her [with it]. (Aboo-Málik; TA.)
Ximotu maxaAyila AlX-aIoCi I directed my look towards the indications, or symptoms, of the thing, waiting, or watching, for it. (Ṣ.)

And [hence, or the reverse may be the case,] Ximotu Albaroqa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Mṣb, TA,) I looked at, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) or watched, or observed, (Mṣb,) the lightning, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or the cloud thereof, to see where it would rain, (Ṣ,) or to see where it would pour, or bring rain, (Mṣb,) or to see whither it tended and where it would rain: (Ḳ:) this is done only when it flickers and disappears without delay: and [it is said, but, in my opinion, fancifully, and with little reason, that] the drawing and sheathing of a sword are likened to lightning flickering and disappearing. (TA.) [Hence the phrase, Ximotu baroqa fulaAnK † I looked hoping for the benefits of such a one: mentioned by Freytag on the authority of Meyd: and the like is said in Ḥar p. 319.] And XAm Als-aHaAba He looked at the clouds from afar: and [in like manner,] Aln-aAra the fire. (TA.) It is said in a prov.,
laA taXimi Algayova faqado OawodaI Aln-aqado
i. e. [Look not thou hoping for rain, for] the lambs have perished: addressed to him who mourns for that which has past. (Meyd.) And one says, fulaAnN muwsirN walaA OaXiymuhu mino faqorK † [Such a one is wealthy, and I do not look at him in hope by reason of poverty]; meaning that he is independent of him. (Z, TA.)

[Hence also,] Ximo maA bayonahumaA ‡ Compute thou, or estimate, or consider, (Ḳ, TA,) and look, or see, (TA,) what [relation, or difference,] is between them two. (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, Xay-ama is erroneously put for Ximo; and qad-arahu, in the explanation, for qad-irohu.])

XaAma also signifies It (a thing, TA) entered, fiI XaIoCK into a thing; (Ḳ, TA;) quasi-pass. of the same verb in the latter of the two senses expl. in the first sentence of this art.; (TA;) and so AnXAm↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and AXAm↓, and AXtAm↓, and tXy-m↓, and Xy-m↓. (Ḳ, TA.)
Also, (Ḳ,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. XayomN and XuyuwmN, He made a valid charge, or assault, or attack, in war, or battle. (Ḳ.)

Also, (Ḳ,) aor. as above, (TA,) He (a man) had a black raqomap [app. meaning spot, or mole, i. e. XaAmap,] apparent in his skin. (Ḳ.) And Xiyma, inf. n. XayomN, [perhaps a mistranscription for XayamN,] He was marked with a XaAmap [or mole]: or, as some say, [the pass. part. n.] maXoyuwmN [signifying “marked with a XAmp”] has no verb: and AZ says that XayamN↓, signifying the having upon him a XAmp, has no known verb: (TA:) or XayamN is an inf. n. signifying the having upon him XaAm [i. e. moles]. (Ḥam p. 361.)

XaAma fulaAnFA, (Ḳ,) aor. as above, (TA,) He soiled the legs, or feet, of such a one with dust, or earth: (Ḳ, TA:) in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, gay-ara rijolayohi biAlX-iyaAmi; but correctly, [as in the CK and in my MṢ copy of the Ḳ,] gab-ara; and accord. to the M, from AlX-iyaAm, [meaning that the verb is derived from this word,] i. e. Alt-uraAb. (TA.)
2: see 1, in the latter half.
Xy-m yadayohi fiI raOosihi, or vawobihi, He seized his head, or his garment, fighting him. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1, in the latter half.

hom.sense: 5: see 1, in the latter half.

tXy-mhu AlD-iraAmu The kindling of fire entered it; namely, a wood; as used in a verse of Sá'ideh: or, as some relate it, tasan-amahu [q. v.]. (Ṣ, TA.) And tXy-m AlHariyqu AlqaSaba The fire entered, and mixed with, the reeds, or canes. (TA.)

And tXy-mhu AlX-ayobu ‡ Hoariness came upon him, (Ḳ, TA,) and became intermixed upon him: or, accord. to IAạr, became abundant upon him, and spread; (TA;) as also tasan-amahu. (IAạr, M and TA in art. snm.)
tXy-m OabaAhu He resembled his father in Xiymp i. e. nature, or natural disposition. (IAạr, Ḳ, TA.)
7. AnXAm: see 1, in the latter half.
Also He (a man) became one who was looked at. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 8: see 1, in the latter half.

hom.sense: XaAmN: see XaAmapN, in three places.
The country of AlX-aAm [i. e. Syria] has been mentioned in art. XOm [as originally AlX-aOom].
XiymN A certain species of fish. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
Also pl. of OaXoyamu [q. v.]. (Ṣ, TA.)
And pl., in one sense, of XiyaAmN [q. v.]. (Ḳ.)
XayamN: see 1, near the end.

Also Any land, or ground, in which one has not yet dug, remaining in its [original] hard state, (Aboo-Saʼeed, Ḳ, TA,) so that the digging therein is more difficult [than elsewhere] to the digger. (Aboo-Saʼeed, TA.)

entry.sense:
XaAmapN A mole, syn. xaAlN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) upon the person; (Mṣb;) [i. e.] a pimple inclining to blackness, upon the person; (Mgh;) or a [natural] mark differing from the colour of the person upon which it is: (Ḳ,* TA:) its medial radical letter is originally I: (Ṣ, TA:)
and it is also with C, i. e. XaOomapN: (IAth, TA:) pl. XaAmN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and [the pl. properly so termed is] XaAmaAtN. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) Hat-aI takuwnuwA kaOan-akumo XaAmapN fiI Aln-aAsi [So that ye may be as though ye were a mole amid the people], occurring in a trad., means [that ye may] be in the goodliest garb or guise, appearing like the XAmp, at which one looks exclusively of the rest of the person. (IAth, TA.) And one says, SaAruwA XaAmFA↓ fiI AlbilaAdi, meaning † They became scattered [in the countries] like the XAm [or moles] upon the person. (TA.)

Also A black mark upon the person, [an explanation which seems to apply, like the former in the Ḳ, to a mole, though given as differing therefrom,] and upon the ground: pl. [or coll. gen. n.] XaAmN↓. (Ḳ.)
It is also [A mark, or spot,] upon a mare, upon a place that is disapproved, and sometimes upon her dawaAYir [which means what are termed feathers, pl. of daAYirapN, q. v.]. (ISh, TA.)
And A spot (nukotap) [upon the face] of the moon. (Ḳ.)

And ‡ A black she-camel: (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) accord. to Nifṭaweyh, XaOomapN, with; but ISd says, I know not the reason of this, unless it be extr., like AlxaOotamu and AlEaOolimu. (TA.) One says, maA lahu XaAmapN walaA zahoraMCu, meaning, ‡ He has not a black she-camel nor a white one. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: XiymapN Nature; natural, native, or innate, disposition, temper, or other quality or property; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also XiYomapN, (Ḳ,) which is an extr. dial. var.: (TA:) pl. XiyamN. (Mṣb.)
Also Dust, or earth, dug from the ground; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so XiyaAmN↓. (Ṣ, as on the authority of Aṣ; but only in one of my two copies of the Ṣ.)

entry.sense: XayaAmN Soft, or plain, land; (AA, Ḳ, TA;) of which the earth is soft, or uncompact. (TA.)
See also the paragraph here following, in two places.

hom.sense: XiyaAmN Dust, or earth, (Ḳ, TA,) in a general sense; (TA;) as also XayaAmN↓: (Ḳ:) see also XiymapN: [or,] accord. to Kh, a hollow dug in the ground: or, as some say, land of which the earth is soft, or uncompact. (Ṣ, TA.)
And A [covert such as is termed] kinaAs: so called because of the wild animal's entering (lAinoXiyaAmi AlwaHoXi i. e. duxuwlihi) into it. (Aṣ, Ṣ, TA.)
Also The rat, or mouse; syn. faOorN: (IAạr, Ḳ, TA:) but written by Aboo-ʼAmr Ez-Záhid XayaAmN↓, and said by him to be the jurac [generally meaning a large field-rat]: (TA:) pl. XiymN. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: qawomN XuyuwmN A people, or party, in a state of security: occurring in a trad.: and it is said that Xywm is an Abyssinian word: but, as some relate the trad., it is suyuwmN [q. v., voce saAYimN, of which it is said to be pl.]. (TA.)

OaXoyamu A man (Ṣ, Mṣb) having a XaAmap [or mole] upon his person; (AZ, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;*) and maXiymN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and maXuwmN↓ (Ḳ) and maXoyuwmN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) signify the same [or rather marked with a mole]: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) or OaXoyamu signifies having upon him XaAm [or moles]: (Ḥam p. 361:) fem. XayomaMCu: (TA:) and pl. XiymN. (Ṣ, TA.)
And A beast, (Lth, AO, TA,) and anything, (Lth, TA,) having upon him, or it, a [mark such as is termed] XaAmap, (Lth, AO, TA,) or [marks such as are termed] XaAm. (AO, TA.)

And Xiymu AlUibili † Such as are black, of camels: sing., masc. and fem., as above: (TA:) occurring in this sense in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, as related by AA: but as heard by Aṣ, in this verse, XuwmuhaA, and thought by him to be a pl. [originally Xuyom] of OaXoyamu. (Ṣ.) See also OaXoOamu (in art. XOm), last sentence.

hom.sense: maXuwmN: see the next preceding paragraph.
And see maXoWuwmN, in art. XOm.
maXiymN: see OaXoyamu:
and see also the paragraph here next following.

entry.sense: maXiymapN The giros; (Ṣ, TA;) i. e. (TA) the place of, (Ḳ, TA,) or [membrane that encloses, or forms the] covering of, (Mṣb,) the fœtus (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) of a human being: (Mṣb: [see girosN:]) originally maXoyimapN: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. maXaAyimu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and [coll. gen. n.] maXiymN↓. (IB, Ḳ.) [See also salFI.]
maXoyuwmN: see OaXoyamu.

1. XaAnahu, aor. yaXiynuhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. XayonN, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, TA,) He, or it, disgraced him, or dishonoured him; rendered him ugly or unseemly, disfigured him, or blemished him; (MA, PṢ;) i. q. EaAbahu; (Mṣb, TA;) contr. of zaAnahu; (Ṣ,* Ḳ;) [and Xy-nhu↓, inf. n. taXoyiynN, signifies the same, (the verb alone rendered by Freytag, on the authority of Meyd, “dehonestavit,”) like as the contr. zy-nhu signifies the same as zaAnahu.]

The saying of Lebeed,
yaXiynu SaHaAHa Albiydi kul-a EaXiy-apK
biEuwji Als-araMCi Einoda baAbK muHaj-abi
[They deface what is unmarred of the deserts, every evening, with the crooked things (i. e. the bows) of the wood of the tree called saraMC, at a veiled door, (referring to a company of men, and therefore the verb is sing.,)] means that they vie, one with another, in glorying, or boasting, and make marks, or lines, with their bows, upon the ground, as though they disfigured it (XaAnuwhaA) with those marks, or lines. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 2: see 1.
Xy-n XiynFA HasanFA (T, TA) or HasanapF (Ḳ) He made, (Th, TA,) or wrote, (Ḳ,) a beautiful X. (Th, Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: XayonN is the contr. of zayonN: (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and maXaAyinu↓ [in the CK maXAYin] is an anomalous pl. thereof: (TA:) the latter signifies Disgraces or dishonours, i. e. things, or qualities, that cause to be disgraced or dishonoured; things that render ugly or unseemly, that disfigure, or that blemish; syn. maEaAyibu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and maqaAbiHu; (Ṣ, TA;) on the authority of Fr.: (TA:) [XaAYinapN↓, also, signifies the same; and its pl. is XawaAYinu;] one says hecihi XaAYinapN mina AlX-awaAYini [This is one of the things that disgrace or dishonour,, &c.]. (TA.)
[It is also used as epithet, like as is its contr. zayonN:] one says, wajohuhu XayonN, i. e. His face is ugly, or unseemly; for cuw XayonK; mentioned by Az. (TA.)

hom.sense: XiynN One of the letters of the alphabet, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [i. e. the name of that letter; (see art. X,)] of the letters termed mahomuwsap [expl. in art. X], with somewhat of Alt-anogiym and Alt-agoXiyap [app. meaning that kind of utterance which is undertoned, and muffled, exactly like our “sh”], its place of utterance being the Xajor, i. e. the place of the opening of the mouth, (Ḳ, TA,) near the place of utterance of j: masc. [as meaning a Harof, or letter], and fem. [as meaning a kalimap, or word]: pl. OaXoyaAnN and XyAnAt [a mistranscription for XiynaAtN]. (TA.)
Also, thus with kesr, A man having many riqaAE [i. e. patches in his garment, pl. of ruqoEapN]. (Kh, TA.)
And A long marokab [app. meaning ship or boat]. (TA.)

entry.sense: fiEolN XaAYinN [An action that disgraces or dishonours,, &c.]. (TA.)
XaAYinapN [a subst. from XaAYinN]: see XayonN.
maXiynN Disgraced, or dishonoured; rendered ugly or unseemly, disfigured, or blemished; pass. part. n. of 1. (Mṣb.)
maXaAyinu an anomalous pl. of XayonN, q. v. (TA.)
1. XaAhahu, aor. yaXiyhuhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. XayohN, (TA,) i. q. EaAnahu, (Ibn-Buzurj, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously EAbahu,]) i. e. He smote him with the [evil] eye. (TA.) [See also 1 in art. Xwh.]
XayohN and XiyhN: see XaApN (of which they are quasi-pl. ns.) in art. Xwh.
XiyaAhN: see XaApN (of which it is a pl.) in art. Xwh.
XayuwhN That smites vehemently with the [evil] eye. (Ibn-Buzurj, Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, EayuwbN is erroneously put for EayuwnN.])
Xay-ihN: see XaApN (of which it is a quasi-pl. n.) in art. Xwh.

OaXoyahu [More, and most, wont to smite with the evil eye]. One says, huwa mino OaXoyahi Aln-aAsi [He is of the most wont, of men, to smite with the evil eye: this meaning being indicated by the context]. (Ibn-Buzurj, Ḳ, TA.)
